title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Mets Halt Giants, 41, as Ryan Hurls a 3Hitter and Fans 8
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 Nolan Ryan, who pitched a onehitter and a twohitter in his previous starts, pitched a threehitter today as the New York Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants. 41.

title: Morgan library Displays Letters
description: Sixtyfive hitherto un known letters to Sir Philip Sidney, the dashing Eliza bethan poet and soldier, from leading European statesmen and scholars, were disclosed last night in the stately Ren aissance splendor of the Pier pont Morgan Library.

title: CAPTAIN DROWNS AS TUG CAPSIZES
description: A tug, carrying a crew of nine, overturned in the nar row channel between Staten Is land and Elizabeth, N.J., yes terday afternoon resulting in the loss of one life and re ports of two men missing.

title: BAHNSEN SUBDUES ANGELS ON 5 HITS.
description: Stan Bahnsen and Roy White sometimes miss a Yankee game because of their duties in the Army reserves, but they were in Yankee Stadium last night.

title: City Center Chairman Offers Plan for Ballet Accord
description: Richard M. Clurman, chair man of the board of the City Center of Music and Drama, has called upon striking members of the New York City Ballet orchestra to drop their demand for a reduced work weekthe central is sue in the labor disputeand to convert this demand into money terms.

title: Quebec's New Premier
description: QUEBEC, April 30An out sider observing Robert Bourassa for the first time on the Quebec hustings said, He looks just like a winded runner who has just stopped to catch his breath.

title: The Screen
description: MARCEL FABRE'S The Extraordinary Adven tures of Saturnino Farando la, made in Italy in 1913, re ceived its American premiere last night in Alice Tully Hall, as second feature to Tod Browning's The Unknown (1927) in a program of the Lincoln Center spring film festival. About Marcel Fabre I know nothing, except that in 1913 he was a good look ing young man of sufficient parts to have starred in his own imaginative, vigorous, occasionally lovely movie that seems, by the way, to have been compiled from episodes in a much longer serial.

title: Politicians in Massachusetts Doubt That Kennedy Is Hurt There
description: BOSTON, April 30  Most politicians declined to comment publicly today on the potential impact of the Mary Jo Ko pechne inquest findings on Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy's po litical career in Massachusetts.

title: Advertising: U.S. Steel on a New Channel
description: We're inyolved is the umbrella theme that the United States Steel Corpora tion's new agency, Compton, will use to pull the giant company back into television after an absence of six years.

title: Roundup: Braves Stagger Cubs With Carty's Hot Bat
description: During Rico Carty's torrid September hitting streak that helped Atlanta win the Na tional League's Western Divi sion title last season, some one noticed a rabbit's foot sticking out of Carty's pocket and asked if the foot was for luck.

title: To Bonnie Cashin, Obsolescence in Fashion Is Obsolete
description: THE way we Iook and function against the modernday backdrop of utterly new forces, physical and sociological, is what valid fashion is all about.... The assumption that obsolesence do clothing must be created to improve business is, in our opinion, hopelessly obsolete in itself.

title: EBAN ASKS U.S AID TO OFFSET SOVIET
description: JERUSALEM, April 30For eign Minister Abba Eban said today that the use of Soviet pilots in the United Arab Re public was an almost revo lutionary change in the mili tary situation and called for quick international assistance to Israel to compensate for it. The call was directed mainly at the United States, which last month announced that it was holding in abeyance Israel's re quest for additional jet fighters. Mr. Eban said that the condi tion set forth by the United States for producing such aid a shift in the balance against Israelhad no w been fulfilled.

title: Policeman Shoots Attacker Who Stabbed Him in Neck
description: A patrolman and his alleged attacker were in critical con dition with neck wounds last night after a fight on Washing ton Square North.

title: Blast Rips Chemical Plant
description: BATON Rouge, La., April 30 (UPI)An explosion ripped the PetroChemical Complex along the Mississippi River last night. There were no injuries.

title: EGYPTIAN TROOPS CROSS SUEZ CANAL
description: CAIRO, April 30  The United Arab Republic reported today that a heavily armed bat talion of its troops crossed the Suex Canal along a 15mila front last night, attacking Is raeli positions and killing or Wounding tens of defenders.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOME of my favorite moments in Donald Barthelme's remarkable new collection of stories are the following: When the narrator of Views of My Father Weeping speculates that his father wants his back rubbed, his neck kneaded, his wrists patted, his elbows annointed with rare oils, his toenails painted with tiny scenes represent ing God blessing America. . . When the cab driver in The Po liceman's Ball wonders to him self why basket ball spectators don't applaud the ball for going into the net rather than the man who makes the shot. And when Ramona, in the title story, thinks about the city: This muck heaves and palpitates. It is multidirectional and has a mayor. There are others, of course, and you'll have yours. For the best in City Life is up to the best Barthelme has ever written. The collection as a whole fits together better than either of his two previous ones, Come Back, Dr. Caligari and Unspeakable Practices, Unnatural Acts. And its impact, as entertainment and as a statement on the uses of fictional art, is far stronger than his novel, Snow White.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 30, 1970

title: Yale Rally Cry: Bulldog and Panther
description: NEW HAVEN, April 30  The Bulldog and the Panther have got to move together.

title: MRS. ROBERT BUCKLES
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 30 Mrs. Doris Howell Buckles, flower show judge, died today at Stamford Hospital after long illness. She was 62 years old and lived on West Lane. She was the wife of Robert A. Buckles, a patent lawyer.

title: MISS CRUMP GETS BERTH ON FATHOM
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 The 96th running of the Ken tucky Derby on Saturday has attracted 18 entrants, the largest field for the 1mile test in 19 years. The turnout was a surprise; it included at least two horses that had been considered quite unlikely start ers.

title: CHURCHMEN TO SEE RHODESIAN LEADER
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 30  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has agreed to meet with leaders of the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches to dis cuss the churches' rebellion against legislation that bars in terracial worship.

title: Missile Fired by Accident Damages 2 Riviera Villas
description: TOULON, France April 30 (Reuters)  A missile fired ac cidentally from a French war ship Ianded on a Riviera beach today and damaged two villas.

title: Flip Wilson's Mother Dies
description: JERSEY CITY, April 30 Mrs. Cornelia Wilson Carter, the mother of Flip Wilson, the comedian, died yesterday at her home, 17 Brinkerhoff Street, after a long illness. Her age was 68. She was the mother of 12 children.

title: NIXON SENDS COMBAT FORCES TO CAMBODIA TO DRIVE COMMUNISTS FROM STAGING ZONE
description: WASHINGTON, April 30In a sharp departure from the pre vious conduct of war in South east Asia, President Nixon an nounced tonight that he was sending United States combat troops into Cambodia for the first time.

title: Law Journal Appoints
description: The appointment of Nelson Seitel as associate publisher of the New York Law Journal was announced yesterday by Jerry Finkelstein, the publisher. Mr. Seitel, who was Commissioner of the City Department of Labor in the administration of Mayor Robert F. Wagner, suc teeds M, Marvin Berger, who was appointed a Criminal Court Judge last Feb. 16 by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Johnson to Speak Tonight At Chicago Fund Dinner
description: CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) Former President Lyndon B. Johnson will make his first public address since leaving of fice when he speaks tomorrow night at a Democratic fund raising dinner in Chicago.

title: Amsterdam Youths Protest
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, April 30 (Reuters)Hun dreds of youths disrupted traffic and threw bricks at policemen here today in an apparent attempt to disrupt celebrations of Queen Juliana's Gist birthday. Protests have be come traditional since Crown Princess Beatrix married Claus von Amsberg, a West German, in 1966.

title: Saigon Official, in Paris, Terms Attack Defensive
description: PARIS, April 30The Saigon delegation at the Vietnam peace conference here declared today that North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces were in troducing large quantities of arms and reinforcements into the Cambodian frontier area in preparation for a new offen sive.

title: Article 1  No Title
BRITISH EASE RULE ON STERILIZATION
description: LONDON, April 30  The Government announced today that male sterilization opera tions could be performed free and with comparative ease un der the National Health Service.

title: G.I.'s and Bombers Begin Drive on Foe's Sanctuary
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, May 1The United States sent troops and B52 bombers inside Cambodia early today in the first strike of an attempt to crush the sanctuary there of the North Vietnamese and Viet cong forces.

title: In Memoriam
description: KUPPERSMITHRosalyn. Cherished memo ries, beautiful one oil your birthday and always.

title: Critics Award Goes to Borstal Boy
description: The New York Drama Crit ics Circle yesterday voted Borstal Boy the best play of the 196970 season, The Effect of Gamma Rays on Maninthe Moon Marigolds as the best American play and Company as the best musical.

title: Cahill Warns Democrats on Prosecutor Nominee
description: TRENTON, April 30Gov. William T. Cahill warned the powerful, oldline Hudson County Democratic organiza tion today that he would send in a special deputy state attor ney general as county Prosecu tor if the organization insisted on blocking his nominee for the post.

title: Key Congressmen Briefed; Reaction Called Favorable
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  President Nixon was reported tonight to have received a gen erally favorable reaction from Congressional leaders to his de cision to send American ground combat troops into Cambodia to destroy Communist sanctu aries in that country.

title: HARVARD UNIT ASKS KEY STUDENT ROLE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 30 An interim report issued to day by a Harvard University committee recommended that students be authorized to sit on boards and committees that consider student disciplinary cases.

title: Czech Comedy Wins Award
description: GENEVA, April 30A Czech oslovak mime comedy about six jail breakers won thte Golden Rose award today of the 10th annual international competi tion for light television shows at Montreux. The choice for the Silver Rose second prize from among 29 entries from 25 countries was the United States show, Annie, the woman in the life of a man, starring Anne Bancroft, of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: Students at American U. Vote to Call Strike Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 Students at American Univer sity here are planning to go on a oneday strike tomorrow pro testing the Administration's ac tions on Cambodia, the trial of Black Panthers in New Haven, an a recent speech by Vice President Agnew.

title: NEW PLAN SEEKING RACEWAY CONTROL
description: A new plan for control of Roosevelt Raceway was an nounced late yesterday by George Morton Levy, president. The Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Transna tional Development Corpora tion, which collectively own about 63 per cent of the stock of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., would put their joint holdings into a paper corporation that would then seek to gain control of the racetrack and its properties.

title: Market Place
description: THOSE New York City tax exempt municipal bonds may not turn you on if you look at their Baal rating, but you needn't be sheepish about it if they appeal to you for other reasons.

title: French Assembly, By Big Vote, Backs A Curb on Violence
description: PARIS, April 30The Gov ernment marshaled its big majority in the National As sembly early today behind a bill reinforcing France's legal arse nal against troublemakers.

title: FRANCIS I. DU PONT IN CAPITAL REPORT
description: Francis I. du Pont & Co., one of the nation's largest stock brokerage firms, issued yester day a quarterly statement of its financial condition that re ported the firm's total capital funds as of March 31 were $62,594,000. It said the amount was the third highest among general brokerage firms.

title: HYNDMAN AND MOREY GAIN AT PINEHURST
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 30 (AP)Bill Hyndman and Dale Morey, former winners, Gary Cowan of Kitchener, Ontario, and John Birmingham of Pitts burgh scored quarterfinal vic tories today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: V.F.W. Proclaims Mayor Unwelcome
description: Angered by Mayor Lindsay's statement that some draft re sisters were heroic, the spon sors of tomorrow's Loyalty Day parade threatened yesterday to bar the Mayor from the event.

title: Antiwar Rally May 9 Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The New Mobilization Com mittee to End The War in Viet nam, which organized the Octo ber and November moratoriums in the capital, has set May 9 for a demonstration to portest the expansion of the war into Cambodia, Stewart Mercham, a member of the coordinating

title: Survey Finds Businesses in U.S. Plan Increase in Capital Spending
description: If American business has in mind retrenchment in the face of recessive trends, it does not include the cutting of invest ment for new plants and equip ment, McGrawHill Publications pointed out yesterday.

title: HOUSE BARS MOVE TO REDUCE FUNDS FOR ABM SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, April 30In sometimes emotional debate, the House rejected today ef forts to cut funds for the Safe guard antimissile system.

title: Leary Called Unfit to Investigate His Own Force
description: Five New York City Congress men demanded yesterday that Mayor Lindsay remove Police commissioner Howard R. Leary from the special committee in vestigating charges that police men in the city receive millions of dollars a year in graft.

title: Mrs. Isobel Dezell Wed in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 30  Mrs. Isobel Victoria Cawthra Dezell of Stamford, widow of Dr. William R. Dezell, a New York surgeon, was married here today to Holgar J. Johnson. The bride groom, who retired recently as president of the Council for Financial Aid to Educa tion, was for 22 years presi dent of the Institute of Life Insurance. The Rev. Robert Hardman performed the cere mony in the chapel at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Another Weekend Experiment Gets Under Way at Monticello
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., April 30Mild weather and reason ably fast horses greeted about 5,802 harness racing fans as Monticello Raceway opened its 13th straight season tonight. It was the earliest start at the track and the 8:45 P.M. first post time was the earliest.

title: 13 in House Back Drive to Put Public Members on G.M. Board
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Five black members of the Souse of Representatives and eight more members from the New York City area endorsed in separate statements today a drive to elect representatives of the public to the board of the General Motors Corporation.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: LOEW'S GETS PART OF FRANKLIN CORP
description: Loew's Theaters, Inc., which two years ago was rebuffed in a bitter battle for control of one of the nation's largest fi nance companies, has acquired an interest of roughly 15 per cent in the Franklin New York Corporation, parent company of the $3billion Franklin National Bank.

title: Sports of The Times
description: TOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30  Dawn slipped into the ancient cavalry post at Churchill Downs today with a sullen slowness. It edged through the cover of gray clouds that hovered over the barn area like an oppressive blanket. Even in early morning it was hot and sticky with temperatures heading toward 90 and with the threat of thunderstorms before nightfall. The day thus began on a depres sing note.

title: Outgoing Democrat Lauds Mitchell for Crime Fight
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)Charles H. Rogovin, Democrat who is resigning his Justice Department job over policy and personal differences, nonetheless gave Attorney Gen eral John N. Mitchell yesterday high praise for the Govern ment's crackdown on organized crime.

title: 40 Puerto Rican Students Lock Brooklyn College Head in Office
description: About 40 Puerto Rican stu dents barricaded the president of Brooklyn College inside his office yesterday afternoon and demanded that the number of Puerto Ricans at the school be increased.

title: Emerson, Stollein Ohio Tennis
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 30 (UPI)Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle meet tomorrow night in the classic set of the Univer sity of Dayton tennis cham pions classic, with a $10,000 purse to the winner.

title: Foreign Affairs: The French Evolution
description: PARIS  France's Fifth Re public has reason to regard the arrival of May with special querulousness since it was ushered in by the events of May, 1958, which destroyed its predecessor and brought back de Gaulle, while the general himself was ushered out by the events of May, 1968, featuring student uprisings and massive strikes. He resigned only a year later but his real political revolution was bracketed by the decade separating two up roarious Mays.

title: College Has Skating Course
description: PUEBLO, Colo. (AP)A course in roller skating is being offered by the physical education de partment at Southern Colorado State College, with the course including basic skating and fun damentals of dancing on skates.

title: Kentucky Derby Field
description: aMrs. Ethel D. Jacobs entry; fMutuel field.

title: Rochester Site for Tennis
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 30 (AP)The United States Na tional amateur claycourt ten nis championships will return to Rochester for the second consecutive year this summer The competition begins July 27 and ends Aug. 2 at the Tennis Club of Rochester.

title: DanishAlbanian Ties Set
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 30 (UPI)Denmark has agreed to establish diplomatic relations on ambassadorial level with Albania, the Foreign min istery said today.

title: Miss Rosita Arias to Be Wed On May 29 to George B. Hanily
description: Dr. Roberto Arias and Dame Margot Fonteyn have an nounced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Rosita Arias, to George B. Hanily, a former Marine captain, who is with the treasury depart ment of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here. The wed dine is set for May 29.

title: Piggott Completes Guineas Double
description: NEWMARKET, England, April 30 (UPI)Lester Piggott, the jockey, won his first 1,000 Guineas race today when he rode the cofavorite, Humble Duty, to a sevenlength victory in the $74,376 classic for 3 yearold fillies.

title: Edgar Van Slyke, Taught Zoology in 2 Universities
description: NYACK, N. Y., April 30 Edgar Van Slyke of South Nyack, a zoologist, died last night at Nyack Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Threat in Trinidad

title: TWO ARRESTED HERE IN PLANE INCIDENTS
description: Two men were arrested Wednesday after one allegedly struck a stewardess and the other had walked about naked during an Eastern Airlines flight from San Juan, P. R., to Kennedy International Airport.

title: Meeting Heavily Guarded
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 30 Mindful that Yale University and its restless student body is only 40 miles away, the Olin Corporation took precautions today to insure that its annual meeting would not be disturbed by outsiders.

title: Nixon Decries Attacks On Great Institutions
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 While addressing the nation tonight on the crisis in Cam bodia, President Nixon also declared that we live in an age of anarchy both aboard and at home.

title: Textile Bill's Details Spelled Out by U.S.
description: Stanley Nehmer, Deputy As sistant Secretary of Commerce, spelled out yesterday what the textile quota bill would do in cutting back imports. Mr. Neh mer was active in the year long discussions with textile exporting countries that failed to produce a voluntary agree ment.

title: City Urges Penalty For Poor Service By Phone Company
description: ALBANY, April 30  The Corporation Counsel for New York City today denounced the New York Telephone Com pany's request for a rate in crease and said that the com pany should be penalized in stead for poor service.

title: Injury to West Gives Knicks an Added Edge
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30 Right now, the New York Knickerbockers have the upper hand in their struggle with the Los Angeles Lakers for the Na tional Basketball Association championship  strategically, physically, tactically and men tally  as the result of last night's 111108 overtime vic tory.

title: Rebuilding Confidence
description: Reaffirming his faith in the economy, President Nixon this week sought to rally the stock market, which has fallen to its lowest level since President Kennedy's assassination. Frankly, said Mr. Nixon, if I had any money, I would be buying stocks right now.

title: Journalism Week Speakers
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., April 30 (UPI)Harry Reasoner of C.B.S. News and Arthur Ochs Sulz berger, president and publisher of The New York Times, will be featured speakers at the Uni versity of Missouri's 61st an nual Journalism Week begin ning Sunday. Mr. Reasoner and Mr. Sulzberger will be pre sented honor awards for dis tinguished service in journal ism, along with John Mack Carter, editor of the Ladies' Home Journal and the French newpaper Le ??

title: Irvin E. Houck, Officer Of Insurance Brokerage
description: OAK PARK, Ill., April 30 Irvin E. Houck, retired direc tor and senior vice president of Marsh & McLennan, Inc., insurance brokers, died yester day at West Suburban Hospi tal of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: New Orders and Backlog Both Down in March Wage Rise Steady
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Manufacturers' inventories rose by less than $100million in March, the smallest increase since the slowdown in the economy began, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Rockets Turn Back Stars In Playoff Opener, 123113
description: DENVER, April 30 (AP)The Denver Rockets needed a three point goal at the buzzer to pull even before they blitzed the Los Angeles Stars in over time for a 123113 victory in the first game of the American Basketball Association Western Division final playoff tonight.

title: Slight Pickup Indicated in Press Talks
description: Negotiators for the typo graphical union and the city's newspapers yesterday resumed their efforts to find a solution to their deadlock on the key money issue.

title: MRS. MARJORIE MERZ
description: SUMMIT, N. J., April 30 Mrs. Marjorie Clune Merz, a teacher in the special services department of the Springfield public school system, died to day of a heart attack in Over look Hospital. She lived at 10 Bradford Street, New Provid ence.

title: Sarah Catherine Nimitz Affianced
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 30Miss Sarah Cathe rine Nimitz, granddaughter of the late Fleet Adm. Ches ter W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet during World War II and Chief of Naval Operations from 1945 to 1947, plans to be married on June 13 to F. Curtis Smith, a class mate at St. Lawrence Univer sity.

title: A Physician Says His Study Found Adverse Reactions to Use of Marijuana
description: Citing his observations of marijuana users who partici pated in research studies or who were treated as patients in a hospital, a physician has reported that distinct types of adverse reactions, such as pan ic, occur among some smokers of this drug.

title: Questions Are Raised by Judge's Report on Inquest
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 Judge James A. Boyle's inquest report on the death of Mary Jo Kopeahne has raised more questions than it has settled, by implying that Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy probably committed a crime but not re quiring that he be charged with a violation. Friends and supporters of Senator Kennedy are say ingwith consid erable bitterness that Judge Boyle in effect made charge that he failed to stand behind. But because of the ex traordinary features of the Massachusetts inquest law, the cloud left over Senator Ken nedy may never be completely dispelled.

title: STOOKS ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
NEW CLASH ERUPTS AT OHIO STATE U.
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30  National Guardsmen and po lice repeatedly scattered crowds of students on the cam pus of Ohio State University to day, firing hundreds of rounds of tear gas and pepper gas, and discharging shotguns at the youths.

title: LOOK TRIAL HEARS OF SOURCE IN F.B.I.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 An agent of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation was named in court today as the source of some of the material printed in a Look magazine article that linked Mayor Jo seph L. Alioto to men identi fied as Mafia hoodlums.

title: UNION PACIFIC'S NET DOWN FOR QUARTER
description: The Union Pacific Corpora tion announced yesterday that is net income in the first cuarter declined to $13,500,000, or 64 cents a share, from $15, 200,000, at 72 cents, in the yearago period. Gross revenues increased to $215,525,000, a gain of $53.6 trillion over the first quarter of 1969. The 1970 figures include the operations of the Champlin Petroleum Company and the Pontiac Refining Corporation for the first time.

title: Bridge
description: PLAYERS representing the Metropolitan Life Insur ance Company dominated the competitions of the Metro politan Commercial Bridge League during the past sea son. Although their team was narrowly defeated by I.B.M. in the 12aside contest that runs through the season, they captured titles in both the competitions that wound up the season.

title: CITY STUDY BACKS INCREASE IN RENTS
description: A massive, detailed study of the economics of the city's housinga study on which the Lindsay administration plans tc base its revisions of rent con trolhas concluded that higher rents are necessary but not sufficient to stem the flood of decayed and abandoned apart ments here.

title: Bonn Approves Foundation For Handicapped Children
description: BONN, April 30The West German Cabinet today ap proved a bill for the estab lishment of a public foundation to help mentally and physically handicapped children, including victims of thaliodomide, the tranquilizer sold here and abroad 10 years ago.

title: Owner of East Side Store Shoots a Holdup Suspect
description: A liquor store owner thwart ed a holdup yesterday when he drew his revolver and fired five shots, three of them hit ting the gunman who was at tempting to rob his store. The wounded suspect, although in serious condition, is expected to live.

title: Confessor of John XXIII Dies
description: ROME, April 30Msgr. Al fredo Cavagna, who was the father confessor of Pope John XXIII, died here today. He was 90 years old. Monsignor Cav agna was born in Venice and served for 37 years as spiritual adviser to the girls' branch of the Catholic Action movement in Italy. Pope John made him a titular Bishop without a see in 1962.

title: LOVELL RULES OUT A POLITICAL RACE
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. seemed today to rule out any prospect that he would enter politics in the next few years.

title: Doyle Dane Bernbach Wins Six Andy Firsts
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach walked off with six of the 24 first place Andy Awards presented last night by the Advertising Club of New York in the New York Hilton. That's no surprise. The sur prise was seeing J. Walter Thompson tying Young & alubicam for second place with three, and Grey Adver tising coming in third with two. Those were the only multiple first place winners and J. W. T., and Grey are hardly the hot creative shops that are so well pub licized.

title: Dance: Nikolais Weaves a Premiere of Structures
description: ALWIN NIKOLAIS is some kind of magician. He makes the theater into a palace of wonders and turns his audience into children staring, wideeyed and aston ished at his Aladdin's cave of jewels and baubles.

title: Playing With Fire
description: A particularly cruel and odious consequence of the disruptions at Hunter has been harassment, by a rash of false fire alarms, of the elementary school affiliated with the college. As often as three times in one day, the school has been forced to evacuate all its young pupils. The emotional impact of these recurring emergencies on small children, some as young as four years of age, is extremely damaging. Yet the fact that dissident students have actually been setting real fires in various locations near the school makes it necessary to heed the alerts each time they are sounded.

title: Anveilings
description: SHUGALTERMallie. A monument will be erected in memory of Mallie Shugalter at BethEl Cemetery, Paramus, N.J., Block 18, section 4, on Sunday, May 3, at 1 P.M.

title: REV. EDWIN J. GRUBB
description: JERSEY CITY, April 30 The Rev. Dr. Edwin J. Grubb, chaplain of the Jersey City Fire Department and pastor emeri tus of the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer, died yesterday in Christ Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 2600 Kennedy Boulevard.

title: PRISON TERNI SET FOR LESLIE FIEDLER
description: BUFFALO, April 30 Dr Leslie A. Fiedlre, the author and literary critic, was sentenced today to six months in the Erie County Penitentiary for permitting marijuana to be smoked in his home here. He was released in $500 bail to await an appeal.

title: Transcript of President's Address to the Nation on Military Action in Cambodia
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's televised address last night as recorded by The New York Times:

title: PRICE RAISED 4.7% ON BASIC STEELS
description: Bethlehem's Move Affects Metal Comprising 35% of Industry Shipments The Bethlehem Steel Corpo ration announced late yesterday afternoon increases in the price of flat rolled steers averaging 4.7 per cent.

title: NIXON MAY NAME MINES DIRECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The White House was reported today to be ready to announce the nomination of J. Richard Lucas, a 42yearold profes sor of mineral engineering at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, to be the new director of the troubled and demoralized Bureau of Mines.

title: BLUES SCORE, 43, REACH CUP FINAL
description: PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) The St. Louis Blues advanced to the Stanley Cup final tonight with a 43 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins. The win ning goal was scored by Larry Keenan, who shoved a loose puck into the net with 5:45 to play.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: White House Says 80% Of Callers Back Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The White House Press Sec retary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said tonight that the telephone response to the President's address on Cambodia seemed to be running 6 to 1 in the President's favor.

title: 5 WORKS IN FINALE OF MUSIC EVENINGS
description: The season's final Evenings for New Music program, given last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, offered five works that seemed admirably structured for the composers' purposes but seldom convinced this listener that the purposes were worth while.

title: LOSS IS EXPECTED BY FOUR SEASONS
description: Four Seasons Nursing Cen ters of America, Inc., whose earnings have been soaring for the last three and a half years, announced yesterday that it ex pects to report a loss for the quarter ended March 31.

title: JAMES H. HUBERT OF URBAN LEAGUE
description: James H. Hubert, the first executive director of the New York Urban League, died after a brief illness Wednesday at the Hillcrest General Hospital, Ja maica, Queens. He was 84 years old and lived at 10465 165th Street. Jamaica.

title: True North, $7.60, Scores By 3 Lengths at Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 (AP)  C. V. Whitney's True North came on with a strong stretch drive today to win the seven  furlong $15,000 added Churchill Downs Handicap, leading Advance Party by three lengths at the finish.

title: Genet Emerges as an Idol of Panthers
description: When the demonstration in support of the Black Panther trial in New Haven gathers on the Town Green there today, somewhere in the throng  probably close to the center of actionwill be the short, squat, bald figure of Jean Genet.

title: Burns Sees Progress in Fighting Inflation  Cites Peak in Rates
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 Arthur F. Burns said today the Federal Reserve Board is de termined to resist any re emergence of excess demand later this year or in 1971.

title: N.B.A. Championship
description: AT LOS ANGELES TV.CHANNEL 7, 9:55 P.M.

title: Mobster Denies Gun Charge
description: CHICAGO, April 30 (UPI) Tony Accardo, reputed Chicago Crime syndicate boss, pleaded not guilty today to unlawful possession of two guns.

title: Slight Growth Is Goal
A Portrait of the School Paraprofessional
description: Mrs. Julia Fuentes, who is 40 years old and just begin ning her college education, is from Puerto Rico and is the sole support of her three children. She lives on the Lower East Side and was for merly on welfare.

title: Executive Changes
description: D. Allen Sedgwich has been elected vice president in charge of West Coast operations for Texaco, Inc., with headquarters in Los Angeles. He succeeds Wallace E. Avery, who is retiring.

title: WILLIAM MADDEN, 72, PAPER CONCERN HEAD
description: William E. Madden, chair man of the board of Charles W. Williams & Co., Inc., 6 Stanwix Street, Brooklyn, mak ers of paper for boxes, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 609 East 37th Street, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old.

title: Giants Trade 2 for Shiner of Steelers
description: The Giants traded Henry Da vis and John Fuqua, two of their lesser players, to the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday for Dick Shiner, a reserve quarterback who has also play for the Browns and the Red skins.

title: Abortion Reform Veto Overridden in Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, April 30 (APThe Alaska Legislature voted, 41 to 17, today to override Gov. Keith Miller's veto of a liberalized abor tion law.

title: Card of Thanks
description: LUFTIGMrs. Libby Luftiz and daughter, Ruth sincerely thank their friends and rela tives for their kind expressions of Sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: CHOU PLAYED ROLE IN LEFTIST PARLEY
description: HONG KONG, April 30  A major role for Communist China in last weekend's conference of Cambodian, Laotian and Viet inamese Communist and pro Communist leaders was dis closed In official reports reach ing here today from Peking and Hanoi.

title: Mrs. Norris, H.P. Patterson Married Here
description: The marriage of Mrs. Patricia Shephard Norris to Herbert P. Patterson, presi dent of the Chase Manhattan Bank, took place in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon. Only members of the couple's immediate families attended the ceremony, performed by the Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read, minister of the church. A reception for 300 followed at the Colony Club.

title: TOKYO STOCKS HIT WITH RECORD DROP
Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partment store sales at $690 million, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $659million. Total retail store sales last week were about $6,919,000,000, up 4 per cent from $6,650,000,000.

title: Moscow Condemns U.S. And Saigon on Cambodia
description: MOSCOW, April 30 The Soviet Union today condemned the intrusion into Cambodian territory by Americansupported South Vietnamese forces. It called it direct aggression against a member of the United Nations.

title: Minimum Wage Bill Signed
description: ALBANY, April 30 (UPI) The state's minimum wage will he increased from $1.60 to $1.65 an hour on July 1 under a bill signed by Governor Rockefeller today. The Governor estimated that the bill, which was part of hiq legislative program, would increase the pay of 700,000 persons.

title: Bankers Plan Minority Loans
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)The American Bankers Association said today it had set a goal of lending $1bil lion for minority businesses over the next five years and committed itself to an ag gressive policy of equal op portunity employment.

title: The Legal Basis for U.S. Role in Conflict in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 President Nixon made no attempt in his speech tonight to expound a legal justifica tion for his move into Cam bodia, other than to refer to his duties as Commander in Chief under the Constitution and the need to protect the lives of American soldiers.

title: Employes at Newsday Vote For Unionization by U.A.W.
description: The editorial employes of Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, have decided to ask the United Automobile Workers of America to begin an organ izing campaign at the publica tion.

title: Woman Seeks Governorship
description: BOSTON, April 30 (AP) Cedalle H. Pearl announced her candidacy today for Governor of Massachusetts. Miss Pearl, 47 years old said she was running as an independent. Her platform includes abolishing prisons and patronage jobs, and the arming of the police with tranquilizer pellets for their guns.

title: The Screen
description: JEANLUC GODARD'S Two or Three Things I Know About Her, which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, and which was an entry at the 1968 New York Film Festival, was shot in 3966 concurrently with Made in U.S.A. He simply ar ranged his schedule so as to be able to work on one in the morning and the other in the afternoon. Filmographically speaking, it comes after Al phaville, Pierrot Le Fou and MasculinFeminin, all made in 1965, and it precedes several short films as well as the features, La Chinoise (1967), Weekend, Le Gai Savoir and One Plus One (also called Symphathy for the Devil), all made in 1968.

title: Ears of TourneyHopping Pros Burn at the Mention of Rabbit
description: DALLAS, April 30Golf's socalled Rabbits, the pro fessionals who hop from tour nament to tournament seek ing a qualifying place in a circuit tournament, are jump ing with indignation. They object to the name by which they are described.

title: BALTIMORE POLICE HOLD 10 PANTHERS
description: BALTIMORE, April 30Ten persons identified as Black Panthers or their sympathizers were arrested today in a series of raids by 150 policemen in connection with the slaying last year of a 20yearold Balti more resident reputed to be a Panther.

title: U.S. Troops Flown In for Panther Rally; New Haven Braces for Protest by 20,000
description: NEW HAVEN, April 30Fed eral troops were flown to New England today to stand by in the event of violence at a mas sive demonstration planned for here tomorrow to protest the murder trial of the Black Pan ther national chairman, Bobby Seale.

title: 13 Indicted on Drug Charge
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury has indicted 13 persons for al legedely participating in an in ternational wholesale drug ring, nine of those indicted were ar rested late yesterdayseven in Boston and one each in New York and Milwaukee. The others were being sought.

title: Dem Sem That Is Appetizing
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vicin ity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

title: NEW TOWING FEE IN EFFECT TODAY
description: A new $5 minimum fee to the the franchised towing opera tors serving New York City's parkways and expressways goes into effect today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Contribu tions10:30 A.M. and 2:45 P.M.

title: Shipping Unit Reelects Will
description: The New York Shipping As sociation yesterday elected Adm. John M. Will to a fourth consecutive oneyear term as president. Admiral Will is board chairman of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines.

title: Friends of Miss Kopechne Said They Were Told She Was Safe
description: BOSTON, April 30  Joseph F. Gargan, a cousin of Edward M. Kennedy's who was with him immediately after his July accident on Chappaquiddick Island, told three of Mary Jo Kopechne's friends that night that she had returned to Martha's Vineyard alone in the Senator's Oldsmobile, accord ing to the friends' testimony at, the inquest into Miss Ko pechne's death.

title: HALL JOHNSON, 82; LED FAMED CHOIR
description: Hall Johnson, 82yearsold violinist, composer and arranger died of burns received in a fire at his Harlem apartment last night, fire officials reported.

title: LOUIS B. BRODSKY, 86, FORMER MAGISTRATE
description: Louis B. Brodsky, a former city magistrate, died at Mount Sinai Hospital on Wednesday. He was 86 years old and lived at 465 Park Avenue.

title: STOCK AVERAGES DRIFT DOWNWARD
GORDON M. BUCK, 94, RAILROAD COUNSEL
description: GREENWOOD, Va., April 30  Gordon Mountjoy Buck, a retired lawyer who had rep resented the Southern Pacific Company and the Pacific Oil Company, died Sunday at his estate in Greenwood. He was 94 years old.

title: Future View: 12Meter in Every Man's Boathouse
description: A PEEK into the future: Modern factories the size of football fields, hous ing giant molds that every 10 minutes plop out a com plete boat hull. Helicopters hover, waiting to swoop down and carry the boats off to a nearby lake for tests. The material? Anythting that can be melted down, which in cludes fibreglass, vinyl and the my riad thermoplas tics of the day. The cost? about a third of what it is today.

title: Reports From U.A.R. Confirm Role of Russian Pilots
description: BEIRUT, April 30Accord ing to reliable Information reaching here from Cairo, So viet fighter pilots have un questionably been flying from Egyptian bases in recent weeks, as charged yesterday by Israel.

title: Martha Mitchell: Capital's Most TalkedAbout Talkative Woman
description: WASHINGTON  People in VI Pine Bluff, Ark., remem ber Martha Elizabeth Beall as a deepdimpled, happygo lucky, headstrong, highstrung girl who was never at a loss for words.

title: Washington: The Latest Fad WrongWay Politics
description: WASHINGTON, April 30If you're a little confused about what's going on around here these days, it may be because you haven't caught on to the new rule of politics. The new rule is that logic is out and reverse logic is in, and under this rule everybody talks and acts against his own selfinter est and in the interest of his opponent.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: THE effort to establish the striped bass as a game fish in New York State has once again failed.

title: Welfare Plan Stirs Job Rules Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The Senate Finance Committee was startled to learn today that President Nixon's new wel fare program would involve less total assistance, in some cases, for poor people who worked than for those who did not.

title: Pace of Trading Light
description: Prices of Government bonds and notes declined yesterday, bringing their yields more into line with the terms of the $16.6billion refunding opera tion announced late Wednes day.

title: Rutgers Names Law Dean
description: NEWARK, April 30 (AP) Tames Paul, a University of Pennsylvania law professor, has been named dean of the Rut gers University law school here. Mr. Paul, 43 year old, has spent the last six years ?? and building a law ??.

title: Commitment to Confederation
description: The sweeping Liberal party victory in Quebec, turning back an ominous separatist threat to Cana dian unity, offers hope for stability and badly needed economic development in the Frenchspeaking prov ince. It constitutes an impressive endorsement of the federalist policies of Liberal Prime Minister Trudeau.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) The Defense Department to day identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: House Unit Backs Money Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)The House Appropria tions committee approved to day a $5.8billion money hill to pay for recently passed Federal wage increases and other Gov ernment costs.

title: Law: Is It Dead or Breathing Hard?
description: Against a background of illegal strikes by postal work ers, student disorders at ma jor universities, draft resist ance, rising crime rates and disruptions in courtrooms, Whitney North Seymour asked yesterday: Is law dead?

title: Wreck of French Sub Found
description: TOULON, France, April 20 (AP)The United States Navy research ship Mizar has found a major section of the French submarine Eurydice, which dis appeared off the Mediterranean port March 4 with 57 men aboard. The French bathyscape Archimede will dive the next few days to inspect the wreck age in an effort to determine the cause of the submarine's loss.

title: Jersey Acts on Bill to Widen Power of Harbor Agency
description: TRENTON, April 30 (AP) At the urging of Gov. William T. Cahill, the Legislature moved today to clear the way for passage by May 11 of a bill expanding the authroity of th Waterfront Commission to cov er three metropolitan area jet ports.

title: Damage Suit Against RKO Is Upheld by Appeals Court
description: The United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday $7.0million damage award against RKO General, Inc., for using insider information to buy stock.

title: R.C.A. Asks U.S. Backing on AirSafety Device
description: The Radio Corporation of America proposed yesterday that the Government support the development of an anti midaircollision system invent ed by an R.C.A. engineer who has publicly critictized his own management on the subject and denounced an airlines' anticol lision project as totally inad equate.

title: 2 U.S. NET STARS UPSET IN ENGLAND
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 30 (UPI)United States hopes for the women's singles title in the $36,000 Rothmans British hardcourt tennis cham pionships were dashed today when Mrs. Billie Jean King and Julie Heldman were eliminated in the quarterfinals.

title: Forecasters of Businessl Expect a Sharp Rise in Economy by Yearend
description: Business activity should ac celerate sharply toward the end of the year, a group of the na tion's leading business fore casters predicted yesterday, with little likelihood of signifi cant relief from inflation by the end of the year.

title: Guard on Duty in Ohio as Teamster Strike Goes On
description: CLEVELAND, April 30Na tional Guardsmen patrolled the interstate highways around this industrial city today as a wild cat teamsters strike moved in to its 30th day.

title: SUTTON'S SUPPORT GOES TO GOLDBERG
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, a delegate of the New Democratic Coali tion, yesterday endorsed Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic or ganization designee for Gov ernor.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: Pittsburgh vs. St. Louis

title: Soviet Offers Yak40 as DC3 Successor
description: HANOVER, West Ger many, April 30The Soviet aviation industry has made its first appearance at Han over's international air show with a sturdy, shorthaul pas senger jet that aspires to the workhorse fame of the venerable DC3.

title: Deficit Is $977,000 By ROBERT WALKER
description: PITTSBURGH, April 30Wil iiam J. Stephens, chairman and chief executive officer of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corpo ration, told the annual meeting here today that the concern had a loss of $977,000 in the first Quarter.

title: Unbelievable Story
description: The release of Judge James A. Boyle's report on the closed inquest into the death of Miss Mary Jo Kopechne may prove to be the final legal act in the prolonged summerisland tragedy involving Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. If so, ironically, it exposes the utter inadequacy of the efforts of local lawenforce ment officials to arrive at the truth.

title: Fiesta Planned For Polyclinic
description: New York Polyclinic Hos pital will benefit from the sixth annual Polyclinic In ternational Fiesta tomorrow in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

title: Oil on Florida Beaches
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 30 (AP)Oil washing in off the Gulf of Mexico blackened more beaches in the Florida Pan handle today and resort owners awaiting the summer tourist season braced for more of it. State pollution officers specu lated that the oil was from spills off the Louisiana coast.

title: Inger Stevens, Actress, Is Dead; Star of TV Farmer's Daughter
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 30 (UPI) Inger Stevens, the blonde actress who played the beguil ing housekeeper on The Farm er's Daughter television series for three years, was found dead in her home today.

title: Cerebrum Scores by a Nose And Pays $18.40 at Pimlico
description: BALTIMORE, April 30 (AP) Cerebrum raced wide in the stretch and captured the 11/16 mile feature race at Pimlico today in a threehorse photo finish.

title: L.I. Police Arrest 150 For Failure to Pay Toll
description: VALLEY STREAM, L.I., April 30A crackdown on motorists who fail to deposit the required 10cent toll in the exactchange baskets on the Southern State Parkway has resulted in the arrest of about 150 persons by the Long Island State Parkway Police since Tuesday.

title: Illiterates Increase in India
description: NEW DELHI (AP)  There are 237 million illiterate people above 10 years of age in India 22 million more than there were nine years ago, the Edu cation Minister says.

title: Cancer Society Said to Avoid New Smoking Study
description: The Tobacco Institute dis closed at a news conference here yesterday that the Amer ican Cancer Society had twice denied its request for an inde pendent scientific review of a study in which the society said cigarette smoking produced cancer in dogs.

title: Line to Enlarge Ships
description: OSLO, Norway (AP)The Wilhelmsen Shipping Line of Norway has announced it will enlarge nine of its cargo liners to increase their container capacity on Far East routes.

title: Good Thing It's a Gallop and Not a Pace
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 When the clerk said, 17 is Personality, the crowd in the racing secretary's steamy office let out its breath in a collective Ohhhhh t!

title: TRUCK TONNAGE OFF 30.4% FROM '69 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 30In tercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended April 25 af fected by week stoppages throughout the nation, was con siderably below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Freight traffic on United States railroads in the same pe riod registered an increase.

title: Radio Coverage Due at Yale
description: Scores of student corres pondents and technicians from eastern college campus radio stations are on their way to New Haven to cover Yale's weekend of protest for their stations. According to a spokes man for the Yale station, WYBC, students from Dart mouth, Harvard, Boston Uni versity, the Massachusetts In stitute of Technology, Colum bia and Princeton, as well as other colleges, have already set up makeshift broadcasting fa cilities or are planning to.

title: Mother Declines Comment Until She Reads Testimony
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N. J., April 30Mrs. Gwen Kopechne declined to comment today on Judge James A. Boyle's opinion that the death of her daughter, Mary Jo, might have been due to negligent driving by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Military HallucinationAgain
description: President Nixon's assurance in his address last night that his decision to send American troops against Communist sanctuaries in Cambodia will save lives, hasten the withdrawal of American forces and shorten the war has a familiar and wholly unconvincing ring.

title: VATICAN ASKS TALKS ON MIXED MARRIAGE
description: ROME, April 30The Vati can's leading ecumenist, Jan Cardinal Willebrands, called today for interfaith talks on mixed marriages.

title: SENATORS PUT OFF VOTE ON BLACKMUN
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)  The Senate Judiciary Committee delayed today until Tuesday a vote on Judge Harry A. Blackmun's nomination to the Supreme Court but con firmation still appeared tob e certain.

title: Seale Is the Main Drawing Card For Panther Rally in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, April 30The impending Black Panther trial is expected to prompt a mas sive gathering on the New Haven Green here tomorrow.

title: ATOMARMS PARLEY HOLDS FIFTH SESSION
description: VIENNA, April 30  The United States and the Soviet Union continued their nuclear armslimitation talks today in an atmosphere that informed sources said was free of propa ganda and polemics.

title: Christianity Linked to Pollution
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., April 30 A group of Protestant theo logians asserted here today that Christianity had played its part in provoking the cur rent environmental crisis and that any solution to it would require major modification of current social and religious values.

title: FEDERALISTS WIN QUEBEC MANDATE
description: QUEBEC, April 30Robert Bourassa, the 36yearold leader of the profederalist Liberial party of Quebec, has won an unqualified mandate to keep the predominately French speaking province within the Canadian confederation.

title: Pan Am Airways Cuts Loss In Quarter Operating Results
description: Pan American World Air ways, Inc., showed little im provement in operating results in the first quarter from the preceding three months, al though the month of March made some progress with a re duced loss from that month last year, according to the pre liminary unaudited statement issued yesterdays.

title: Badillo Endorsed by Lindsay In Race for Seat in Congress
description: Mayor Lindsay endorsed for mer Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo yesterday for election as Representative from the 21st Congressional District.

title: Amphitryon Will Close Season in Lincoln Center
description: The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center will present the American premiere of Amphi tryon, by Peter Hacks, the 42yearold German writer, on May 28 as its fourth and final production in The Forum. Based on the Greek legend, Mr. Hack's work was translated from the German by Ralph Manheim.

title: Court Bars Police TieUp; P.B.A. Ponders Its Reply
description: The city was granted a preliminary injunction yesterday against a threatened police work stoppage in a salary dis pute, but the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Asso ciation declined to say wheth er the union would observe the court order.

title: FUTURES IN CORN ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Inclement weather in many growing areas resulted in in creased soybeans and corn fu tures prices yesterday on thp Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat futures rose early in the ses sion but the advance dissi pated under profit taking and stoploss selling.

title: PUERTO RICAN ACE HAS DERBY MOUNT
description: It didn't take Eddie Belmonte, the Puerto Rican riding star, long to renew his concentration on Saturday's Kentucky Derby, after being notified at Aque duct yesterday that he had been held blameless for a questionable ride on Interwood Wednesday.

title: Respecting the Law
description: Rather than carry out a threatened job action at midnight tonightwhich would defy a State Supreme Court preliminary injunction issued yesterday against the Patrolmen's Benevolent Associationthe city's uniformed patrolmen can show their own respect for the law by taking their wage dispute to the Office of Collective Bargaining.

title: TRIAL SPEED LIMIT INCREASED FOR 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 30 (AP)Harlan Fengler, the chief steward, looked over the re paved Indianapolis Motor Speedway today and immedi ately raised the speed limit for tomorrow's opening prac tice session from 155 to 160 miles an hour.

title: Independent Candidates Win Overseas Press Club Vote
description: The entire slate of indepen dent candidates won control of the financially beset Overseas Press Club last night.

title: Music: Maazel Evening
From Guggenheim's Vaults Comes 190070
description: MANY art museums, par ticularly those lacking sufficient space to keep their permanent collections on public exhibition at all times, often find themselves in the paradoxical position of showing works of art (and sometimes entire exhi bitions) that are distinctly inferior in quality to the quantities of art stored away in their own warehouses. The Solomon R. Guggenheim Mu seum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, is certainly one of these. In the succession of temporary exhibitions  some excellent, some less so  which regularly occupy the building Frank Lloyd Wright designed for the mu seum in the late 1950's, we tend to lose sight (literally) of this museum's superb permanent collection.

title: Hofstra Nine Snaps Manhattan Streak With 31 Triumph
description: Ed Gaffney, a Junior center fielder, made four hits yester day and helped Hofstra Univer sity snap Manhattan College's fourgame winning streak with a 31 baseball victory at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Pay Rise for Jersey Judges
description: TRENTON, April 30 (AP) The New Jersey Assembly to day approved raises ranging from 14 to 25 per cent for state judges. It also passed a bill raising the cost of filing legal papers by $10, bringing the fig ure to $60, to pay for the salary increases. Both measures were sent to the Senate where they are expected to be passed.

title: S.E.C. Punishes Harris, Upham; Hertz, Warner Also Is Penalized
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Settle ment today of disciplinary cases against two member firms of the New York Stock Ex change, Hertz, Warner & Co. and Harris, Upham & Co.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Manipulation of Laboratory Tests Is Laid to Aides in Federal Drug Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminis tration is investigating charges that agency officials have man ipulated laboratory results for years to avoid weakening or contradicting established Gov ernment policies on food addi tives and pesticide safety.

title: EL PASO GAS PROFIT ADVANCES SLIGHTLY
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries re ported yesterday first quarter operating revenues of $238,278, 000 against $215,897,000 a year earlier. Net income edged ahead to $13,775,000, or 48 cents a share, from $13,754,000, equal to 48 cents a share on fewer shares, in the 1969 quarter. Earnings included certain reve nues from increased gas rates, effective March 7, 1969 and sub ject to refund.

title: Reds Seize Laos Town, Killing 93
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 30  North Vietnamese forces took control of the embattled town of Attopeu in southern Laos early this morning.

title: Morgan's Cup Hopeful To Be Launched Today
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 1 (UPI)The 12meter yacht Heritage, first Amer ica's Cup challenger ever built in the south, will be launched and christened here tomorrow.

title: U.S. Said to Be Inquiring Into Pricing of Copper
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (Reu ters)The Justice Department has opened an investigation into the pricing of the American copper industry, an informed source close to the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Back in Paris Triumphs By 5 Lengths in Jersey
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 1 (UPI)  The Elkeron Farms' Back in Paris scored a five length victory in the $15,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares at Garden State Park today.

title: W. Nelson Young, 64, Dies; Officer in Scarsdale Bank
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 1W. Nelson Young, a vice president of the Scarsdale National Bank.

title: WING OF F111 CRACKS DURING FATIGUE TEST
description: The Air Force announced yesterday that an F111 wing structure undergoing onthe ground fatigue tests had cracked at a point in the tests equivalent to seven and a half years of standard flight opera tions.

title: Boarded Windows and Greased Flagpole Greet Panther Protest in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, May 1As a tram of carpenters fitted a large plywood panel over the window of an apparel shop here, a young man with a bead ed hair braid waited patiently, off to one side.

title: Primary Race: The Game Is Names
description: ALBANY, May 1Demo crats who hope to win the right to represent their par ty in the Governor's race this year are in the final days of the first test of the efficiency of their campaign organizations.

title: Ore Project Slated
description: CLEVELAND, April 25 (UPI) The Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company and Texas Gulf Sul phur Company have agreed in principle on a joint ven ture to develop a $100mil lion ironore project in the Robe River area of Western Australia.

title: A Saigon General Rides Into Cambodian Town
description: SVAYRIENG, Cambodia, May 1With a swagger stick under his arm, the beaming South Vietnamese commander of the allied thrust into Cambodia drove into this provincial capi tal at 12:10 P.M. today, em braced the commander of the Cambodian soldiers defending the town and pronounced its residents safe from the Viet cong.

title: LEO M. SOLOMON, 74, A PHOTO CONSULTANT
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Leo M. Solomon, a photography consultant and a former picture editor, died today at Washing ton Hospital Center following a stroke. He was 74 years old.

title: NOW's New President Sees Men Helped, Too
description: THE new president of the National Organization for Women (NOW) is tall, slen der, welleducated, divorced, glib, 44 years old, a fervent feminist, and heads her own industrial consulting firm in San Francisco.

title: Washington: For the Record
Cyanide Stolen in Scotland
description: EAST KILBRIDE, Scotland (UPI)  The police announced the theft of a sixgallon bottle of cyanide from a chemical company, a sufficent amount of poison to kill 60,000 people.

title: COLON TOPS FIKES IN MILE AT RELAYS
description: Tony Colon has won the bat tle, but the war isn't over.

title: Victory Brings Lunch
description: NEW DELHI (AP)B. D. Kho bargade, a 45yearold untouch able, was elected deputy chair man of the upper house of the Indian Parliament, and the first official duty he performed was to adjourn the house for lunch.

title: TOWN HALL RECITAL IS GIVEN BY M'COLLS
description: In these days of folkrock, superslick showmanship and protest songs written with one ear to the cashregister, last night's Town Hall concert by Ewan MacColl and Peggy See ger was as refreshingly rare as a breath of unpolluter air. It has been 10 years since Mr. and Mrs. MacColl were in New Yorkand a little more than five years since the State De partment denied their request for visas to make an American tour  and many old friends were in the welcoming audi ence, including Miss Seeger's brother, Pete.

title: Italians Picket F.B.I. Office Here
description: Joseph Colombo, the rep uted head of one of the six Mafia families in the met ropolitan area, led a picket line Thursday night that some of his friends and others not associated with the Mafia continued yesterday in front of Federal Bureau of Investi gation headquarters here.

title: Kennedy Describes Action In Cambodia as Madness
description: BOSTON, May 1 (AP)Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy criti ing American cized President Nixon today for sending American troops into Cambodia.

title: Galaxy Emitting XRay Energy at Unexplained Rate
description: Observations by a racket fired from Brazil to scan the southern heavens have dis closed that one of the most remarkable galaxies in the sky is emitting Xray energy at a rate that, physicists say, cannot be explained by known processes.

title: Bourbon Unit Chief
description: Russell R. Brown, chair man of the board and presi dent of the American Distill ing Company, has been elect ed chairman of the board of the Bourbon Institute. He succeeds B. C. Ohlandt, vice chairman of the National Dis tillers and Chemical Corpora tion and vice president and general manager of the Na tional Distillers Products Company. Julian P. Van Winkle Jr., president, Stitzel Weller Distillery, was elected vice chairman of the board and Bernard Goldbert, presi dent, Schenley Industries, Inc., was elected chairman of the executive committee.

title: M.P. BLOCH, FOUGHT ELECTION FRAUDS
description: Monroe Percy Bloch, presi dent and counsel of the Honest Ballot Association, who was long active in combating fraud in elections here, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

title: Scot Tweed Gains
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May 2 (AP)Scottish tweed mills exported 6.5 million pounds of cloth in 1969, up 5 per cent from the 1968 level, accord ing to the council of the Na tional Asociation of Scottish Woolen Manufacturers. Exports accounted for, almost 40 per cent of Scottish pro duction.

title: I.C.C. URGED TO BAR FREIGHTRATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The National Grain and Feed Association urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to deny a 6 per cent freight rate increase sought by the rail roads.

title: 2 Nuclear Tests in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 1 (AP)Two nuclear tests, both in the yield range of fewer than 20 kilotons, were con ducted at the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada test site today, the commission an nounced. The two tests raised to 16 the total number of an nounced detonations in 1970.

title: NEW ISSUES SKID TO LOWER GROUND
description: The newissue marketwhere shares of companies that had never previously been avail able to the public are traded  skidded substantially more than the stock market as whole during the first four months of this year, an analysis showed yesterday.

title: Ford in Moscow's Future
description: The redcarpet treatment So viet officials gave Henry Ford 2d suggests that the Kremlin hopes history will repeat itself. Two generations ago, in the late nineteentwenties, a path breaking deal be tween the Ford Motor Company and the Soviet Union opened the way for a major transfusion of American tech nical knowhow. There would seem to be little doubt that similar FordKremlin deal in the early nineteenseventies would set a precedent that many other American concerns in diverse fields could follow.

title: Mitchell Warns of Danger In Attacks on High Court
description: WASHINGTON, May 1At torney General John N. Mitchell warned today that irresponsi ble and malicious criticism of the Supreme Court had reached a danger point that threatened constitutional liberties.

title: POLICE POSTPONE TIEUP OVER PAY
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association voted yesterday to postpone a threatened job action scheduled to start at 12:01 A. M. today after the city agreed to a speedy trial of a court action involving pay dispute that has been sim mering since last January.

title: Selling Tons of Fish a Week
description: THE Savarese family has been running a successful fish business since 1914 when it first started supplying in stitutional and retail custom ers from its stores in Man hattan and Brooklyn. Thirty years ago, when George Sav arese was growing up in the neighborhood near his father's store, the Ninth Avenue Fish Market at 233 Ninth Ave nue (between 24th and 25th Streets), the clientele was French, Ital ian and Irish. Since then, the proportion of Jewish custom ers has increased with a re sulting demand for such fresh water fish as carp, whitefish and pike, Cousins of Mr. Savarese run the Fifth Avenue Fish Market, 157 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn (near Lincoln Place), which was started by his uncle and grandfather.

title: TRAVELERS CORP. REPORTS NET RISE
description: The Travelers Corporation reported yesterday that net ad justed earnings advanced sharply in the first quarter to $26.67million, or 57 cents share, from $15.32million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings for the 12month period ended March 31 rose to $2 a share from $1.44.

title: New PATH Turnstiles To Take Exact Change
description: JERSEY CITY, May 1 (UPI)Experimental 30cent exactchange turnstiles will go into operation Monday at certain locations in the Jour nal Square and Hudson ter minals of the Port Authority TransHudson (PATH).

title: Clark Backs Blackmun
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 1 (AP)Ramsey Clark, former United States Attorney General has given limited en dorsement of Judge Harry A. Blackmun as President Nixon's, nominees to the United States Supreme Court. I've seen nothing to this point that would indicate he's not quali fied, Mr. Clark, said last night during Law Day observances at Pennsylvania State Univer sity.

title: Boycott Continues at City University
description: Two rallies, a meeting at City Hall and several picket lines marked the third day of the boycott of classes at the vari ous campuses of City Univer sity of New York as the initial intensity of activity appeared to wane.

title: Pennsylvania Alerts Units of Guard in Truck Strike
description: HARRISBURG, May 1 (AP) Attorney General William C. Sennett announced today that three National Guard units had been put on alert for possible violence in connection with the wildcat teamsters strike in western Pennsylvania.

title: GOLDBERG SCORES COURT BACKLOGS
description: Arthur J. Goldberg charged yesterday that there had been a virtual breakdown in the process of criminal justice at the trial level in this country.

title: Giving Meaning to Law Day
description: The city's law men marked Law Day yesterday the most positive way open to them: by demonstrating their respect for law in a matter of direct and imme diate concern to every member of the police force.

title: Raytheon Plans to Acquire Atheneum
description: Atheneum Publishers, one of the most prestigious of the dwindling group of independent publishing houses, has agreed to sell to the Raytheon Com pany, an expanding electronics conglomerate.

title: 5 WORKS IN FINALE OF MUSIC EVENINGS
description: The season's final Evenings for New Music program, given Thursday night in Carnegie Re cital Hall, offered five works that seemed admirably struc tured for the composers' pur poses but seldom convinced this listener that the purposes were worthwhile.

title: 23,000 Derelict Vehicles
description: The Sanitation Department reported yesterday it had picked up nearly 23,000 aban doned vehicles in the city since Jan. 1.

title: PIPING ROCK GETS INTERCLUB LEAD
description: Only one district champion was in the lead when the second round of the Women's Metro politan Golf Association's inter club team matches were com pleted yesterday.

title: A Garden Spot for Outdoor Sculpture
description: NOW decked out in spring green, Battery Park seems a perfect site for an outdoor sculpture plantingand ap parently the Parks, Recrea tion, and Cultural Affairs Administration has had the same vibrations. It has placed there an untitled work by Chuck Ginnever, made of Cor Ten (rustresistant) steel and stretching 50 feet on the long axis of a sward that points toward the Customs House.

title: Soviet Publishes Works Of Brezhnev Since '64
description: MOSCOW, May 1Leonid L Brezhnev's preeminence as the leader of the Soviet Union's Communist party was underscored today with the announcement that a twovolume collection of his speeches and articles since 1964 has been published.

title: Crucible Sets Layoffs
description: MIDLAND, Pa., May 1 (UPI) of Colt Industries, Inc., said to The Crucible Steel Division day it will have to lay off 400 more workers because of the steel haulers strike, bringing total layoffs to 1,000.

title: JET BOOM REMEDY CALLED POSSIBLE
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1  Elimination of the destructive sonic boom from supersonic planes is possible, officials of an engineering concern said.

title: Students Press Strike at Ohio State U.
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 1 Students at Ohio State Univer sity picketed a dozen campus buildings today, but the univer sity president predicted that their strike would fail.

title: Boyden Roseberry, Headed Westchester Medical Unit
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., May 1  Boyden Roseberry, execu tive director of the West chester County Medical Society from 1944 until his retirement in 1968, died yesterday after a stroke in Northern West chester Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at Old Stonehill Road, Pound Ridge.

title: Governor Signs Bill To Give the Elderly Community Centers
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday that he had signed a bill authorizing $50 million in lowcost state loans to nonprofit organizations that want to build community cen ters for old people.

title: SEAVER'S 4HITTER BEATS PADRES, 21
description: SAN DIEGO, May 1  Tom Seaver, the man with the most, pitched his fifth straight vic tory of the season tonight as the New York Mets defeated the San Diego Padres, 21.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC CITES INCOME DIP
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in energy sales and revenues for the first quarter. However, net income slipped by 12.3 per cent, to $10.9million from the $12.5million reported a year earlier.

title: Daniel Ends Deal's Streak On Decision in A.A.U. Bout
description: TRENTON, May 1 (AP) Quienceland Daniel, 22yearold interservice boxing champion, outpointed John Deal, 17, of Trenton today in the nextto last day of the national Ama tuer Athletic Union boxing tour nament. Daniel, who weighed 139 pounds, snapped a 17bout unbeaten string piled up by Deal, the last unbeaten fighter in the A.A.U. tourney.

title: BRIEF AMEX RALLY FALLS A BIT SHORT
description: The American Stock Ex change staged a brief after noon rally yesterday to erase most of its earlier losses, but the gains were not enough to put most issues into the plus column at the close.

title: New Cologne Hotel Set
description: A 296  room hotel will he built in Cologne, Germany, by a company in which the West German Lufthansa Airline and the Inter  Continental Hotels Corporation are partners. The $7.5million hotel will he man aged by InterContinental.

title: Prague Resumes Parades
description: PRAGUE, May 1 (Reuters)  A May Day parade, the city's first since the 1968 Sovietled invasion, lasted only an hour this morning amid snow, rain and official scorn for the past reform era. Gustav Husak, the Commu nist party leader, addressed a crowd of about 90,000 people in Wenceslas Square. Many were huddled under umbrellas. He said that during the 1968 democratization period, antiso ist forces, supported by imper ialist countries, tried to over throw the socialist regime.

title: Mayor Says Papers Took From Context His Draft Remark
description: The distortion of that in the press, he said, had led to some public stir against him. Specif ically, he had been disinvited from a Loyalty Day parade of the Veterans of Foreign Wars that he had not intended to march in, anyway, he said.

title: NUCLEAR STORAGE STIRS OREGONIANS
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 1 A nuclear waste storage company is continuing its fight, for a permit to expand its east ern Oregon operations amid charges of a conflict of interest.

title: END TO RECESSION SEEN BY FRIEDMAN
description: CHICAGO, May 1The econ omy is about halfway through a relatively mild recession that is expected to end in the third or fourth quarter of this year, economist Milton Friedman said today.

title: Apollo Explosion Laid to Short Circuit
description: HOUSTON, May 1A prelim inary report has indicated that the explosion imperiling the Apollo 13 crew on its flight to the moon last month may have been caused by a short circuit in an oxygen tank.

title: Haitians Reach Puerto Rico After Attempt at a Coup
description: ROOSEVELT ROADS, Puerto Rico, May 1 (UPI)Three bat tered Haitian coast guard ves sels arrived today with 119 persons involved in the attempt ed coup last Friday against Franois Duvalier, the Haitian President.

title: New England Utility Gets Approval on Power Plant
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The Federal Power Commis sion announced approval today of the New England Power Company's plans to build a $63.9million power generating plant at Bear Swamp on the Deerfield River in the towns of Rowe and Florida. Mass.

title: TOM RUSH PERFORMS A VARIETY OF SONGS
description: Tom Rush is singing a variety of songs in his special style through tomorrow at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: Saigon Translates Drive Into Ultimate Victory
description: WASHINGTON, May 1A Pentagon spokesman said to day that the allied offensive into the Fishhook area of Cambodia hes been named. Operation Ultimate Victory by Saigon's field command ers. He said that other opera tions under the name Ulti mate Victoryalso trans lated as Total Victory or Complete Victoryhad been conducted by the South Vietnamese in recen weeks.

title: Spain Gains Soccer Finals
description: VIAREGGIO, Italy, May 1 (AP)Spain routed Italy, 60, today to move into the finals of the European soccer cham pionships for national amateur teams.

title: Fordham Students Vote 10 to 1 To Gain Voice in School Policy
description: Fordham University students have overwhelmingly approved a proposal to form a council designed to give students an in fluential voice in policy deci sions on the Bronx campus.

title: Alabama Job Discrimination Charged
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 30 The Department of Labor is investigating charges that Ala bama officials discriminated against Negroes in the admin istration of job training pro grams here.

title: Times Printers to Increase Pressure
description: The head of the typographical local here announced last night that it would lengthen its daily union meetings at The New York Times on Monday night in an effort to force a quick conclusion to the protracted contract negotiations.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE triumphs in P. M. Pasinetti's latest novel are minor ones. In one passage a young man comes to the home of his girl friend, bouncy, energetic, hungry. The maid, who had once had the same job in his own home, whips up an omelette lunch for him. During the preparation and consumption of the meal, the strong affection and trust they have for each other show themselves in small gestures and half expressed phrases. They are even held by a physical though innocent bond. The render ing is perfect; another touch of color would have spoiled it, another detail would have pushed it out of shape. In another scene, the same young man, who is on his way to America, bargains with an editor for more money for the pieces he plans to write. He does so in the presence of an aging and not overly successful journalist. The young man's as surance, indifference, and cruelty bring on contrasting reactions. The editor rather likes the boy's confidence and independ ence, seeing, perhaps, something of him self in the youngster before him. The older writer stands in silent resentment, know ing he wouldn't dare behave in similar fashion, that he couldn't afford such a gesture or get away with it. It's what is not said here that counts. The unspoken mixture of frustration, admiration and un caring deviltry gives the incident a tragic force.

title: Roundup: Fists and Bats Pump Life Into Baseball
description: Baseball tried to liven itself with the experimental X5 ball in spring training, but now the game apparently has turned to the XKO.

title: A SERGEANT SAYS HE'LL SEE RUSKIN
