description: A New York police sergeant with more than a decade of ex perience and four citations for bravery called Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin yesterday and made an appointment to discuss specific cases of corruption within the Police Department.

title: FAST HILARIOUS CARTER FAVORITE
description: My horse in tomorrow's Carter has tremendous speed, said Jacinto Vasquez between races at Aqueduct yesterday. Anyone who beats him will have to go awful fast.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP AS TURNOVER LAGS
description: The stock market, trending a bit lower in dull trading yes terday, reacted with sur prising calm to the Thursday night announcement by Pres ident Nixon that the United States had sent combat troops into Cambodia.

title: SEVERAL TORNADOES HIT OKLAHOMA CITY
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 30 (AP)  A series of tornadoes struck this city of 350,000 and adjoining communities early to day, smashing homes and rip ping roofs from apartment buildings. Eight persons were treated for injuries.

title: Fishhook area were first re Malaysian Has Hard Head
description: PENANG, Malaysia (UPI)  S. Ramasamy, a plantation worker, was laboring in the field when a coconut fell on his head. The Straits Times reported that the coconut cracked, hut Mr. Ramasamy, though knocked out and rushed to the hospital, showed no in jury to his skull.

title: Protanto, 201 Shot, Is Scratched From Derby, Reducing Today's Field to 17
description: LOUSVILLE, Ky., May 1 The field for tomorrow's Ken tucky Derby was whittled to 17 this morning when Protanto was scratched, but it will still be the richest Derby with gross purse of $170,300 and $127,800 winner's share.

title: 2 GUILTY OF SLAYING OF CLERIC IN HOLDUP
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday convict ed two men of killing the Rev. Thomas Logan, assistant pastor of St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Manhattan, during a holdup in Brooklyn Heights last Aug. 29. The trial began April 9 before Justice Milton Mollen.

title: School Supervisors Planning To Seek Union Charter Here
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 1The Council of Super visory Associations, which rep resents most of the principals and other supervisors in the New York City school system, is planning to become a full fledged union.

title: Mrs. Huntsman, Charles S. Rowe Marry in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  The marriage of Mrs. Mary Ann Else Huntsman to Charles Spurgeon Rowe, edi tor and copublisher of The Free LanceStar in Fredericks burg, Va., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Loring D. Chase performed the ceremony in the Westmore land Congregational Church.

title: Behind the President's Decision
description: News Analysis

title: New York Choral Society Gives U.S. Debut of J. C. Bach Work
description: The New York Choral So ciety, which is conducted by Martin Josman, gave most of Its attention to Mozart's Re quiem in its concert at Phil harmonic Hall last night, but the early portion of the eve ning offered a work that had not been sung previously in this country. It was a setting of the Dies irae by Johann Christian Bach, whom Mozart met in London in 1764.

title: Elizabeth Sessions Is Wed in Jersey
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 1 Miss Elizabeth Phelps Ses sions, the daughter of Roger Sessions, the composer, and Mrs. Sessions, was married to Robert Louis Pease this afternoon at the home of her parents.

title: Big Rallies Are Planned
description: The national antiwar move ment, drained of vigor in recent months, seemed yesterday to have found a new rallying point and an Impetus to renewed pro test in President Nixon's an nouncement of direct interven tion in Cambodia by United States troops.

title: Lakers Overcome Knicks, 121115, in Overtime and Tie Final Series at 22
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1  Comes the revolution, and all athletic entertainment will be as continually fascinating as the National Basketball Asso ciation playoffs, whose final round was evened at two games apiece tonight when the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 121115, in another overtime game.

title: Day of Indecision at Louisville: One Hunch as Good as Another
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 Disoriented handicappers got a small break today when Protanto, the problem horse, was scratched from tomor row's Kentucky Derby.

title: Anton Myrer Marries Patricia Schartle
description: Anton Myrer, a novelist, of Saugerties, N.Y., and Patricia Schartle, his literary agent, were married in the First Unitarian Church in Brook lyn Heights yesterday by the Rev. Donald McKinney.

title: U.S. Sues a School System In Louisiana on Segregation
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The Government filed suit today against the school sys tem in Franklin Parish, Louis iana, contending that school of ficials made no attempt to de segregate the 11 allwhite and 7 allNegro schools in the dis trict.

title: New Canaan G.I. Killed
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that Army Spe cialist 5 David M. Burke Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., had died from wounds in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Princeton Coed Captures Pimlico Dash by 6 Lengths
description: BALTIMORE, May 1 (AP) Princeton Coed, a sophomore filly, scored a sixlength victory today in the American Medical Center purse at Pimlico.

title: TWO STUDENTS HELD IN CAMPUS BOMBING
description: GENEVA, N. Y., May 1 (AP) Two Hobart College students, quoted by the police as saying that they did not like the R.O.T.C., were arrested on ar son charges today in connec tion with the firebombing of Air Force offices on the school's campus.

title: Druggist Slays Holdup Man
description: A Bronx druggist shot and killed a holdup man yesterday as he and an accomplice fled with $58 from the cash regis ter, the police said. The slain man, who was armed with a toy pistol, was dead on arrival at Morrisania Hospital. He was not immediately identified. The accomplice escaped. The drug gist, Irving Weisenfeld, 56 years old, was alone in the store, at 2 E. 167th Street, when the holdup occurred.

title: LANDLORDS FEAR RENT STUDY ROLE
description: A group of landlord spokes men voiced fear yesterday that the Lindsay administration would use the housing study made by Prof. George Stern Heb of Rutgers to avoid sub stantial rent increases in 1.3 million apartments here.

title: Microfilming Group Elects
description: The National Microfilming Association yesterday elected George Harmon of Information International, Inc., as president for the following year. John Robertson of the Eastman Ko dak Company was named vice president and Milton Mandel of The New York Times was named treasurer.

title: French Monthly Pay Plan Seen Raising the Status of Workers
description: PARIS, May 1The radical nature of the idea is perhaps best shown by the failure of the English language to pro vide a good translation. Mensualisation means more than pegging workers' pay to a monthly cycle. It is the ve hicle for uplifting the status of workers, giving them fringe benefits now directed toward the whitecollar staffs, en dowing bluecollar jobs with a quality of permanence and dignity, and reducing the psychological gap and pres sures for conflict between the factory hands and the ad ministrators.

title: ADDONIZIO LOSES DISMISSAL MOPE
description: NEWARK, May 1  Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and 12 other defendants charged with extortion and in come tax evasion have been turned down again in their at tempt to have their indictments dismissed, their trial postponed and a variety of other defense motions granted.

title: MRS. JAMES E. KNOX
description: JOHNSTOWN, N. Y., May 1 Mrs. James E. Knox, mother of John B. Knox, president of Knox Gelatine, Inc., died at her home here Tuesday after a long illness. She was 79 years old.

title: Unbeaten Harvard, Penn Crews To Meet on the Charles Today
description: It is merely another cup race but one to help settle the theoretical national champion ship of intercollegiate rowing because Harvard and Pennsyl vania are involved. These two have the best crews in the na tion and they meet today in the Adams Cup regatta on the Charles River in Boston, with Navy the third party.

title: ExPresident in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, May 1Former President Lyndon B. Johnson appealed to all Americans to night to support President Nix on in the Southeast Asian crisis.

title: Loanshark Gets 8 Years For Threat On Debtor
description: A loanshark identified as a member of Carlo Gambino's Mafia family was sentenced to eight years in Federal prison yesterday and fined $20,000 for threatening a furrier with phys ical violence in trying to col lect a usurious $40,000 loan.

title: Wishnick Captures 200Mile Griffith Powerboat Race
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 1 (AP)The Weather Bureau warned small craft to exercise caution today, so Bill Wishnick ran a cautious 51  miles  an  hour average speed to win the 200mile Griffith Memorial powerboat race.

title: Cry, the Beloved Country
description: LONDON, May 1American students are told that they must respect institutions. Their Pres ident deplores mindless at tacks on all the great institu tions which have been created by free civilizations.

title: Japan's External Reserves Rose to Record in April
description: TOKYO, May 1 (Reuters) The Finance Ministry said to day that Japan's external re serves at the end of April rose $55million to a record $3,923, 000,000 from $3,868,000,000 in March.

title: Referee for a Rally
description: Man in the News

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Life Urges Court to Kill Libel Suit of Gov. Rhodes
description: Life magazine and Denny Walsh, a writer, asked the United States District Court here yesterday to dismiss a li bel suit filed by Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio in connection with an article linking him with an alleged Mafia mobster.

title: Antiques: The Lasting Magic of Glass
description: THE two thousand objects displayed in the new glass gallery at the Toledo Museum of Art should ex plain the popularity of glass among antiques collectors.

title: Judy Tienken Plans Nuptials
description: Arthur Tienken Jr., deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in Lusaka, Zambia, and Mrs. Tienken have announced here the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Judy Tienken, to Law rence Edwin Nelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Nelson of St. Cloud, Minn.

title: Encyclopedia on Rents
description: The longawaited Sternlieb report on the economics of rental housing in this city is a scholarly treasure trove. Nothing remotely comparable has been done by any research team on the complex factors involved in the decay of New York's supply of apartments, both rentcontrolled and uncontrolled.

title: Topics: How to Get Out of Vietnam  By 1789
description: There is not much point in suggesting now how we might have avoided getting bogged down in Vietnam. But in view of the embarrassment about getting out, perhaps the awareness that another country apart from the emasculated French empirehas solved the problem can lessen the un thinkability of prompt with drawal.

title: ALIOTO, ON STAND, DENIES MAFIA LINK
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 Mayor Joseph L. Alioto re peated under oath from the wit ness stand today the denials he had been making since last Septemoer of a Look magazine article that linked him with group of Mafia figures.

title: Columbia Conquers Penn, 31; Yankee Scout Sees Gordon Star
description: One of Frank Gordon's fa vorite scouts was at Baker Field watching him play yester day and the Columbia center fielder put on quite a show for him, collecting four hits in four times at bat while knocking in two runs in the Lions' 31 vic tory over Pennsylvania.

title: WILLIAM ST. ONGE OF CONNECTICUT
description: GROTON, Conn., May 1 (AP) Representative William L. St. Onge suffered a heart attack today while en route to attend a submarine launching in Gro ton. He died before reaching a hospital. He was 55 years old and was nearing the end of his fourth term in the House.

title: 11 HURT BY BOMBS IN 2 MOVIE HOUSES
description: Eleven persons were re ported injured, none seriously, when bombs exploded in two movie theaters about a mile apart in the Bronx last night.

title: Europe Surprised and Worried by Move
description: LONDON, May 1Surprise and concern were the dominant reactions in Europe today to the American military move into Cambodia.

title: Gray Line Will Try to Vote At 5th Ave. Lines Meeting
description: Gray Line, Inc., announced yesterday that it plans to bring an action in Supreme Court of New York County seeking declaratory judgment directing that Gray Line can vote its 214,000 shares of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., at the forth coming annual meeting sched uled for May 20.

title: Israeli Aide Seeks to Curb Tours of Occupied Areas
description: TEL AVIV, May 1The Min ister, of Tourism Moshe Kol, today advocated limited cur tailment of tours through Is raelioccupied Arab areas as safety measure. His proposal was regarded as a reaction to a terrorist handgrenade at tack in Nablus  on the west bank of the Jordan River in occupied Jordanon April 22. Six tourists, inluding three Americans, were among the in jured.

title: MAIL GROUP VOTES STRIKE BY MAY 14
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) A dissident group in the Na tional Association of Letter Carriers voted today to resume postal strikes if Congress does not enact a promised addition al 8 per cent pay raise by May 14.

title: Trust Runs Madison Paper
description: MADISON, Wis., May 1 (AP) Control of The Madison Cap ital Times will be left to a five man board of trustees of the William T. Evjue Charitable Trust, unuder terms of a will filed today in Dane County Court. Preliminary estimates put the value of Mr. Evjue's estate at $2 million. Mr. Evjue, who founded the paper in 1917, was its editor at the time of his death April 23 at the age of 87.

title: AMERICAN CURBS EASED BY BRAZIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1 Brazil is now turning to pri vate and foreign enterprise to develop the nation's extensive mineral resources after years of mistrust and statism.

title: ALLIES DRIVE AHEAD IN CAMBODIA; NIXON AGREES TO DISCUSS DECISION WITH 4 COMMITTEES OF CONGRESS
description: LANDING ZONE XRAY, Cambodia, May 1A huge al lied task force including, 5,000 American infantrymen swept into Cambodia today and formed an arc around the sus pected headquarters of the Vietnamese Communist forces.

title: Legal Aid Threatened By a Strike
description: Lawyers employed by the Legal Aid Society of New York, who handled 221,000 cases in the courts here last year, will begin a partial strike Monday, they announced yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Mansfield Speech on War
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Following are excerpts from a speech opposing United States action in Cambodia, delivered in the Senate today by Mike Mansfield of Mon tana, the majority leader:

title: Rev. Michael Frassrand Dies; Treasurer of Paulist Fathers
description: The Rev. Michael X. Frass rand, general treasurer of the Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle since 1952, died Thursday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 75 years old and lived at the Paul ist Fathers Generalate in Scars dale, N. Y.

title: TV Technicians Strike Off
description: A threatened technicians strike against National Broad casting Company stations in five cities was postponed yes terday on an hourbyhour ba sis. Members of the National Association of Broadcast Em ployes and Technicians recent ly rejected a contract calling for a $55 a week raise over 3 years. Current scales run from $150 to $260.

title: German Company Joins Space Team
description: The Boeing Company has named MesserschmittBoel kowBlohm, GmbH, one of the major aerospace concerns in West Germany, as a team member of its studies of a reusable space shuttle trans nortation system.

title: Nixon Is Assailed On Cambodia Move At May Day Rally
description: About 800 people at a May Day rally in Union Square heard speeches yesterday at tacking the Nixon Administra tion's policy in the Far East.

title: Dividend Cut Announced
description: ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UPI) The American Investment Com pany today reduced the quar terly dividend on its common stock to 12 cents a share from 27 cents, with a dec laration payable June 1 to holders of record May 12. The company said earnings for the first quarter fell to 20 cents a share from 32 cents a share a year ago.

title: NICKLAUS SECOND, ONE STROKE BACK
description: DALLAS, May 1After card ing his 66 today, some specta tors asked Arnold Palmer why his putting had improved. I guess I just got tired of putting badly, he replied with a smile.

title: Sihanouk Is With Mao At Peking May Day Fete
description: PEKING, May 1Lnair man Mao Tsetung, making his first public appearance in more than six months, sat beside Prince Norodom Si hanouk tonight and held an animated session.

title: Henry Curtis 7th Plans to Wed Miss Elizabeth Kristin Mitchell
description: Miss Elizabeth Kristin Mitchell, a junior at Transyl vania College in Lexington, Ky., and Henry Curtis 7th, a Transylvania senior, plan to be married in Grace Epis copal Church here next month.

title: Trader Nardin, $31.20, Takes Yonkers Pace as Lucky Creed Finishes Last
description: YONKERS, May 1Lucky Creed of Australia, thus far the only horse invited to compete in the $150,000 International Pacing Series, which starts at Yonkers Raceway next Friday night, lost more than his left front shoe in the $10,000 Tor nado Cup Race tonight. The celebrated 6yearold bay lost a bit of face, a chunk of glam our and a lot ($114,762) of his backers' money, as he fin ished last in the mile tuneup won in 2:01 by the Billy Haugh tondriven Trader Nardin.

title: PNOMPENH GIVEN NO PRIOR NOTICE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 1  Premier Lon Nol said today that Cambodia had not been consulted in advance about the American and South Vietnamese military operations on her territory.

title: Mahagonny to Close
description: Mahagonny, the musical adaptation of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill's The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahogonny, by Arnold Weinstein, will close tomorrow night at the Ander son Theatre after its eighth performance. The show was produced and directed by Car men Capalbo.

title: Dodd Sets Hearings on Bills To Regulate Explosives' Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that he would hold hear ings this month on bills to regulate the sale of explosive devices.

title: Art: Sculpture Emphasizing Poetry
description: THE sculpture of Saul Bai zerman (18891957) is one of the strongest, most poetic, and most completely realized accomplishments in the Am erican art of this century. It is also one of the most im portant unacknowledged ac complishments in the Amer ican art of this century.

title: Clinton High Dinner May 13
description: DeWitt Clinton High School will hold its 73d anniversary dinner celebration on May 13 at the Statler Hilton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. The guest of honor will be State Supreme Court Jus tice Arthur Markewick of the school's class of '22.

title: 2 UPSTATE COLLEGES WIN ROWING TRIALS
description: Two visiting upstate crews Ithaca and Buffalo Statewon the heats of the seventh an nual Metropolitan Intercollegiate rowing championships on the Olympic Course off Orchard Beach early last night.

title: CurtainRaisers, 1970
description: The primary season is upon us, focusing today on the kind of fierce internal feud that makes the Demo cratic party of Texas even more suicidal if possible than its counterpart in New York. Ralph W. Yar borough, a dove on Vietnam and one of the few Southern Senators unable to detect Supreme Court qualities in Judge. Carswell, is being challenged by highly conservative exCongressman. Lloyd Bentsen, now a Texas banker and businessman, has the political support of former Governor John Connally and the financial support of the state's oil industry.

title: MARTHA BLANCHARD, CARTOONIST, WAS 54
description: Martha Blanchard, a car toonist, whose gag cartoons ap peared in The Saturday Eve ning Post, New Yorker, Pic torial Review, Look, and Punch and were also bought by King features, died Monday of a cor onary occlusion at her studio, 59 Fifth Avenue. Her age was 54.

title: R. Bruce Livie, Dies at 71; Football and Racing Figure
description: MIAMI, May 1 (AP)  R. Bruce Livie, a founder of the Baltimore Colts football team and former chairman of the Maryland Racing Commission, died here yesterday after sur gery.

title: Nixon Puts Bums Label On Some College Radicals
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 President Nixon referred today to some campus radicals who violently oppose his Vietnam policies as bums and, in con trast, he said American soldiers were the greatest.

title: Negro Suspension Upheld
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 1 (UPI)The State College Board upheld today the suspension of eight Negro students from the University of Mississippi on the around that the rights of others had been violated when the group allegedly disrupted a campus concert. The eight were expelled for one year for al legedly jumping on stage during a concert in February to drama tize demands that Negroes be given a greater voice in school affairs.

title: Drivers Kept Alert on Road By Signals of Electronic Device
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 After 12 months of extensive road testing of a wide variety of motor vehicles, a specially designed electronic driver alert ness device was shown here for the first time. The demonstra tion on Wednesday was at the International Truck, Trailer and Equipment Exposition at the Civic Center.

title: Spain Thwarts Protests
description: MADRID, May 1 (Reuters) The Spanish police were out in force today to thwart illegal May Day demonstrations called in central Madrid. At one point they brandished clubs to dis perse about 200 people.

title: RICHARD R. WOLFE
description: DEERFIELD, Ill., May 1 (AP) Richard Russell Wolfe, a lawyer, whom record books credit with having won the largest settlement in patent law, died Wednesday in his home here. He was 62 years old.

title: MRS. JULIUS KIRZON, AIDED HANDICAPPED
description: Mrs. Anna Balacaier Kirzon, president of the Ruth Kirzon Group for Handicapped Chil dren, Inc., died Wednesday, after a heart attack in Monte fiore Hospital. She was the wife of Julius Kirzon, a retired fur manufacturer. Her age was 70 and her home was at 1815 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Princeton Trackmen Score Over Columbia, 101 to 53
description: The Princeton track team won 13 of 18 events, including all 10 running events, to crush Columbia, 10153, in a dual meet yesterday at Baker Field.

title: MOREY, COWAN GAIN NORTHSOUTH FINAL
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 1 (AP)Dale Morey shot winning pars on the last two holes to day to beat Bill Hyndman on tile 19th hole and Gary Cowan set back John Birmingham, and 2, with fiveunderpar golf to gain the final of the North and South amateur tournament.

title: Holyoke to Hear Kennedy
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 1 (UPI)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Mas sachusetts, will deliver the commencement address at Mount Holyoke College May 31, it was announced here today.

title: Russians Drop Princeton Talks As AntiNixon Protests Erupt
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 1 An academic delegation of Russians canceled public panel discussions here today, admit ting nervousness that they might be accused of fomenting the protest and strike move ment that broke out at Prince ton University after President Nixon's speech on Cambodia.

title: Tours Will Aid City Gardens Club
description: Penthouse and ground gar dens will be on view Tuesday and May 12 at residences that will open their doors in behalf of the City Gardens Club of New York.

title: Fire in Bronx Forces 185 To Flee Apartment House
description: A fouralarm fire declared to be of suspicious origin drove about 185 persons from a Bronx apartment house early yester day as firemen used aerial lad ders to rescue at least 20 of the residents.

title: ROOTES REPORTS A 6MONTH LOSS
description: LONDON, May 1  Rootes Motors, Ltd., the beleaguered British subsidiary of the Chrys ler Corporation, reported today a record loss for the first six months of its fiscal year and suggested that its loss for the entire year might also be record.

title: Market Place:
description: AUNT JANE and all the other little people in the market appear to have an ally in Congress in their struggle to avoid higher commission charges.

title: JACK M. BLUMBERG
description: Jack M. Blumberg, founder and president of Fine Arts Lamps, Ltd., lamp manufactur ers at 230 Fifth Avenue, died of a heart attack Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 200 East 57th Street and in Atlantic Beach. L. I.

title: Education Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) President Nixon signed today a bill that provides up to $2.5 million in emergency funds to help educate children whose parents live and work on Fed eral property. One section of the bill renames the Federal Office Building and United States Courthouse in Chicago the Everett McKinley Dirksen Building, in honor of the late Senator, who served as Senate Republican leader.

title: Kentucky Derby Field
description: aMrs. Ethel D. Jacobs entry; fMutuel field.

title: Allied Chemical Increases Price of Coal Tar Pitch
description: The Allied Chemical Corpora tion announced yesterday it was raising the price of coal tar pitch by $2 a ton across the hoard, effective immediately.

title: Camera Measures Temperatures by Color
description: WASHINGTON, May 1A camera manufactured by a Connecticut company takes pictures that show tempera tures in color. The instrument scans the invisible infrared radiation that all objects give off. Robert W. As theimer, vice president of the Barnes Engineer ing Company, was granted Patent 3,509,345 this week for the equipment that makes infrared color photography possible. Infrared cameras such as previously made by Barnes have shown the radia tion in black, white and shades of gray. With color prints, the human eye can distinguish very small tem perature differences.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: PROGRESS REPORTED BY FAIRCHILD CAMERA
description: C. Lester Hogan, president and chief executive officer of the Fairchild Camera and In strument Corporation, told stockholders at yesterday's an nnual meeting at Palo Alto, Calif., that the rebuilding of the company would be com pleted by midyear.

title: F.A.A. Ordered to Stop Action Against Air Controllers Here
description: Federal District Judge Orrin G. Judd ordered the Federal Aviation Administration here yesterday to halt disciplinary action against some 300 New York air traffic controllers who participated in the recent na tionwide sickcall slowdown.

title: Auto Race Group Endorses Bid for 2d U.S. Grand Prix
description: The Automobile Competition Committee for the United States yesterday endorsed a bid to stage a second Grand Prix race in the United States in the world driving championship se ries.

title: TRANSIT PROGRAM FOR EAST WEIGHED
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)  Vertical takeoff and land ing aircraft plus highspeed ground transit would provide the widest choice of improved intercity passenger transporta tion in the nation's Northeast Corridor, according to a pro gress report on an unusual study project.

title: 3 Red Nations Won't Attend Asian Meeting on Cambodia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 1 North Vietnam, North Korea and Communist China have of ficially declined nvitations by the Indonesian Government to attend a twoday conference of Asian and Pacific nations on Cambodia in Jakarta on May 16 and 17.

title: Critics Honor 4 Offerings
description: The Outer Critics Circle, an organization of outoftown writers, has selected Child's Play, by Robert Marasco, and Company, the Stephen Sond heim and George Furth musi cal, as the best play and best musical, respectively, of the 196970 season.

title: New England Governors Protest Model Cities Cuts
description: BOSTON, May 1 (AP)The New England Governors Con ference has called on President Nixon not to cut any funds from the Model Cities program.

title: Mrs. Grant Supports NoFault Auto Insurance
description: The city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Bess Myer son Grant, testified yesterday in favor of the proposal for no fault automobile insurance in the state, saying that such a system would provide com pensation without dependency upon the caprices of a jury.

title: Yarborough in Tight Race In Texas Primary Today
description: DALLAS, May 1 (AP)Sen ator Ralph W. Yarborough, a liberal Democrat, faces a tight race for renomination in pri mary elections tomorrow. A light turnout is expected despite a heated campaign.

title: Minority Group Residents Form Protective Patrols
description: NEW HAVEN. May 1Wear ing a red and black armband, Vance Spruill and some 30 other young black and Puerto Rican men spread out today in this city's black communities to buffer permanent black and Puerto Rican residents from whatever might happen in the rally today.

title: Tornadoes Hit Missouri
description: NAYLOR, Mo., May 1 (AP) A series of small tornadoes swept through this southeast Missouri community and the surrounding farming area last night, leaving behind heavy property damage.

title: LIQUORI OUTLASTS DYCE IN MILE LEG
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 1 This was supposed to be a nice leisurely weekend of sun, fun and a few laps around Butler Stadium for Marty Liguori and Ron Stonitsch, a postPenn Relays, miltary style.

title: Bridge:
description: DUPLICATE players have more occasion than their rubberbridge counterparts to balance on a knifeedge be tween triumph and disaster.

title: DANIEL E. JESSEE, 69, EXCOACH AT TRINITY
description: VENICE, Fla., May 1Daniel E. Jessee, former head football and baseball coach at Trinity College, Hartford, Conn., was found dead apparently of a heart attack or hemorrhage, yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old.

title: PAL to Youngsters
description: The effort to involve adult New Yorkers in the activities of the Police Athletic League comes at the right moment. It is helpful to remind grownups and youngsters that the police are concerned with their welfare, that PAL exists as an independent organization sponsored by the Police Department but operated by professional civilians.

title: STOCKS IN TOKYO RISE MODERATELY
description: The Tokyo stock market closed only moderately higher yesterday as uncertainties over Cambodian developments checked the recovery from Thursday's sharp decline.

title: Kretchmer Sworn In
description: Former Assemblyman Jerome Kretchmer was sworn in by Mayor Lindsay yesterday as the city's $35,000ayear Envi ronmental Protection Adminis trator.

title: U.S. Indictments Say 7 Passed Bad F111 Parts
description: FORT WORTH, May 1 (AP) Three employees of the Gen eral Dynamics Corporation and four officials of two sub contracting companies have been charged in Federal indict ments with conspiring to pass defective parts for the con troversial F111 warplane.

title: CUNNINGHAM DANCES 2 WORKS AT JUDSON
description: James Cunningham is a witty and zestful choreographic con versationalist prone to change the subject and dither over de tails with infectious charm. Thursday night at Judson Me morial Church, he and his danc ers presented two of his works, the new Lauren's Dream Octo ber 8, 1969 and Evelyn the Elevator, a piece from reper tory.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: British Discount Rate Up
description: LONDON, May 1 (Reuters) The average rate of discount at today's tender of British treas ury 9day bills rose to 6.793 per cent from 6.772 per cent last week. This week's 80million offer met applications of 162, 450,000. Next week 100mil lion bills will be offered replacing 100millions of maturities.

title: Hijackers Give Up in Cuba; Abandon Flight to Africa
description: MIAMI, May 1 (AP)  A group of hijackers abandoned plans for a flight to Africa, a spokesman for British West In dian Airways said in Miami.

title: Unit Is Formed To Fight Pollution
description: The Dillingham Corporation has announced the formation of the Dillingham Environ mental Company to develop and implement programs for solving pollution problems.

title: Military Planners View Nixon Decision as Sound
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Sen ior military planners today viewed President Nixon's de cision to assault major sanc tuaries in Cambodia as strate gically important and tactically sound.

title: Dr. Enid Starkie, Author, Dies; An Expert on French Literature
description: LONDON, May 1Dr. Enid Starkie, an authority on French literature and poetry, died in Oxford on April 21. She was 67 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 2, 1970

title: NASSER WARNS U.S. ON AID FOR ISRAEL
description: CAIRO, May 1President Gamal Abdel Nasser cautioned President Nixon tonight to re frain from delivering more air craft to Israel, warning that such a move would have dan gerous consequences to Unit ed States interests in the Arab world for decades to come.

title: $108,064 IS DONATED TO DRAMATISTS UNIT
description: The New Dramatists Com mittee's fund drive to continue its program of aiding fledgling playwrights has already raised $108,064 this year. The contri butions, by representatives of the legitimate theater and al lied fields, were announced yes terday at a luncheon at the Piccadilly Hotel attended by more than 250 people.

title: ... Political DerringDo
description: President Nixon's televised explanation of why American troops are crossing the Cambodian border included a long peroration on history, morality and patriotism.

title: Youth Is Charged With Rape Of Woman, 55, in Subway
description: An 18yearold youth was charged with severely beating and raping a 55yearold woman yesterday on the storage tracks of the BMT at Canal and Centre Streets.

title: U.S. Action Linked To Drives by Foe
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  White House sources offered an expanded account today of President Nixon's decision to send American troops into Cambodia, asserting that it was based almost entirely on esti mates of dangerous enemy, activity in recent days.

title: State Ring Body to Permit QuarryFoster Bout Here
description: Jerry Auarry and Mac Foster will be licensed to fight in Madison Square Garden on June 17 even if they are sus pended by California. Edwin Dooley, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commis sion, said yesterday he would sanction the heavyweight con test here.

title: Muscovites but No Tanks Parade on May Day
description: MOSCOW, May 1  Musco vites today observed May Day, dedicated to international work ers movements, by strolling the streets of Moscow, staying home or going to the suburbs.

title: 65 of I.O.S. Staff In Geneva Let Out
description: GENEVA, May 1Investors Overseas Services announced today that it had dismissed 65 of its Geneva staff of 2,100. The 23man I.O.S. board of di rectors will meet here Sunday to consider the dismissal of an additional 100 Geneva employes and others in Munich and London.

title: 7 DANCES OFFERED BY MIMI GARRARD
description: I like Mimi Garrard's way with her own performing talent as shown in a solo dance like Sketch. She is easy, languid and confident, sure of herself and her audience. When she decorates her dances with a spate of properties some of the spontaneity goes out and a hurryup attack is substituted for the gliding smoothness that she uses so well. Last night at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse she presented seven of her dances.

title: GRAIN PRICES OFF ON CHICAGO BOARD
description: Commodity futures prices were unaffected yesterday by the announcement of the move of the United States into Cam bodia. That country's chief ex ports are corn, rubber and rice, and imports by this coun try from there totaled only $42.4million last year.

title: WEED KILLER CURB IS EXPANDED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) The Agriculture Department said today that it had started issuing 30day cancellation notices on permits for some interstate sales of 2, 4, 5T, a brush and weed killer that has produced birth defects in mice.

title: Puzzled by Nixon View
description: GODAUHA, South Vietnam, May 1Experienced observers both in and outside the Ameri can armed forces are voicing puzzlement over President Nix on's statement last night that American troops near the Cam bodian border have been en dangered by action of enemy troops in Cambodia within the last 10 days.

title: U.S. AND REPORTER FILE COURT PLEAS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1  Earl Caldwell, a New York Times correspondent, and the Federal Government each have filed actions involving attempts to get Mr. Caldwell before a Federal grand jury that is in vestigating the Black Panthers.

title: Editorial Comments on Move in Cambodia
description: Following were editorial com ments yesterday on President Nixon's announcement Thurs day night that he was sending United States combat troops into Cambodia for the first time to drive Communists from stag inz zones:

title: Reds at Paris Talks Denounce U.S. Aggression in Cambodia
description: PARIS, May 1North Viet nam and the Vietcong reacted angrily here today to the open and impudent American aggres sion in Cambodia and ap pealed for support of American public opinion and of foreign governments to stay the hand of the warlike and perfidious Nixon Administration.

title: NEW HAVEN POLICE SET OFF TEAR GAS AT PANTHER RALLY
description: NEW HAVEN, Saturday, May 2Policemen fired tear gas at bottlethrowing Black Panther sympathizers on the Town Green last night after a peace ful beginning to massive week end demonstrations in support of nine Black Panthers facing trial here.

title: TuneUps Begin for 500Mile Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 (UPI)  Indianapolis Motor Speedway's 2mile oval opened for 500mile auto race practice today, with a three car foreign contingent among the first to make shakedown runs.

title: Executive Changes
description: G. Edward Kattel, who recently announced his early retirement as an executive vice president of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York, has joined his son, Edward B. Kattel, to form Kattel, Inc., financial consultants, at 317 Minorca Avenue, Coral Gables, Fla.

title: United Fund Appeal
description: Business, labor and govern ment leaders joined with 150,000 volunteers yesterday to begin the second annu al campaign of the United Fund of Greater New York. The fund repre sents a merger of the money raising activities in the business community of the Greater New York Fund and the American Red Cross in Greater New York.

title: Fall Fashion Has Its Price ...
description: YOU have to be fairly well heeled to play the fash ion game these days. Though the fall collections shown on Seventh Avenue in the last few days aren't for the wildly extravagant woman, they're not for pennypinch ers either.

title: YANKEES CONQUER BREWERS, 6 TO 3
description: The Yankees had the pleasure of playing the team with the worst record in the major leaguesthe Milwaukee Brew ersand they responded with a 63 victory last night.

title: Quarter Productivity Fell; March Building Pace Down
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The slowdown in the economy had the normal effect of reducing productivity, or output per manhour, in the first quarter of this year, the Labor Depart ment reported today.

title: Cambodia's Army: A Force Long Used to Make Roads, Not War
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 1The fighting force in Indo china that American troops as sisted for the first time today is the 40,000man regular Cam bodian Army, long used primar ily to make roads, not war.

title: Joe Louis Is Admitted To Psychiatric Hospital
description: DENVER, May 1, (UPI) Joe Louis, the former world heavyweight boxing cham pion was ordered hospital ized today for examination at the Colorado Psychiatric Hospital.

title: A Meeting on War Moves Asked by Fulbright Group
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee, moving with intended restraint to challenge the Ad ministration's policy on Cam bodia, took the unusual step today of requesting a confer ence with President Nixon to discuss the American military involvement there.

title: Jean Mori, Swiss Leader Of Trade Unions, Dies at 67
description: GENEVA, May 1Jean Mori, Swiss tradeunion leader, died at ChauxdeFonds, his birth place in northwestern Switzer land of a heart attack last night. He was 67 years old.

title: C.A.B. Rejects Move For Higher 747 Fares
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today a request by Trans World Airlines to charge travelers premium fares for domestic flights aboard the Boeing 747 jumbo jet and to add a 5 per cent ticket surcharge for most longdistance flights on all jetliners during the summer.

title: H.E.W. SCIENTISTS SCORE DRUG BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Near ly 100 physicians and scientists who work for the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare have signed a letter oppos ing the Administration's drug abuse legislation, now before Congress.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Drive Opens to Name Negro As F.C.C. Commissioner
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  A National campaign was started today to get minority represen tation on the Federal Commun ications Commission.

title: Policeman Averts Peril in Steam Blast
description: A traffic patrolman acted quickly yesterday afternoon to save motorists and pedes trians from possible death or serious injury when a 16inch steam trunkline exploded at 55th Street and Madison Ave nue.

title: Sports of The Times
description: IN 1967, professional basketball players became a short commodity when the newly formed American Basket ball Association began competing for talent with the established National Basketball Association, said a lawyer in Federal Court yesterday. He continued: The entire wage level went up, rookies were offered large bonuses and several veteran stars such as John Havlicek of Boston and Earl Monroe of Baltimore were able to quintuple their sal aries by threatening to jump to the new league.

title: RAP BROWN LAWYER BARS HIGH COURT BID
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., May 1 (UPI)The defense for H. Rap Brown today decided not to ask the Supreme Court for an other delay in his riot and arson trial.

title: Cambodian Quagmire...
description: President Nixon's shocking decision to send Ameri can troops into Cambodia immediately raises the ques tion: Can they get out?

title: Jets Sign Maynard, Herman To MultipleYear Contracts
description: Don Maynard and Dave Herman will be playing for the New York Jets next sea son, and George Saimes could be.

title: HEWITT AND COX GAIN BRITISH TENNIS FINAL
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 1 (UPI)Bob Hewitt of South Africa defeated Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia today to reach the men's singles final of the Rothmans British hard court tennis championships for the third time in four years.

title: Czechs to Begin Flights From U.S.
description: An international airline with the cheerful insignia OK on the tailfin of its jets will enter service here on Monday. OK is the code identification established by the International Air Trans port Association for Czecho slovak Airlines, also known as CSA.

title: Allies in Asia Pleased; Others Critical
description: HONG KONG, May 1Presi dent Nixon's decision to send American forces into Cambodia was approved today by the United States' Asian allies but encountered varying degrees of criticism in other Asian coun tries.

title: FUND WASTE FOUND IN JOBLESS TRAINING
description: WASHINGTON, May 1, (UPI) A Government investigator said today there have been unreasonably high costs in training hardcore unemployed for jobs and some employers have claimed Government money for services not per formed.

title: Lady ViE, $15.20, Captures Kentucky Oaks by a Head
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 (AP)Lady ViE won the $63, 750 Kentucky Oaks at Chur chill Downs today in a finish in which the first four went under the wire less than length apart.

title: PHONE COMPANY IN PACT FOR VIDAR
description: The Continental Telephone, Corporation announced yester day an agreement in principle to acquire the Vidar Corpora tion, a manufacturer of tele communications and data processing equipment.

title: Women's Golf Rained Out
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May 1 (UPI)The first round of the $15,000 Shreveport invitation women's golf tournament was rained out today.

title: COLONELS TURN DOWN PACERS IN OVERTIME
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 (AP) Darel Carrier scored 6 points in the final two minutes to night in leading the Kentucky Colonels to a 114110 overtime victory over the Indiana Pacers in the American Basketball As sociation Eastern Division play off final.

title: Strike Brings Layoff of 215 At Maine Shipbuilding Plant
description: BATH, Me. May 1 (AP)  The strikebound Bath Iron Works Corporation said today that 215 employes, including some salaried and clerical per sonnel, would be laid off im mediately.

title: Small Oregon Sawmills Caught in a Profit Squeeze
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The Walter E. Kock Lumber Com pany, a small specialty pro ducer of lumber in Sandy, 22 miles east of here, spent $200,000 of its capital in the first three months of this year just to keep the 50 yearold family sawmill op erating.

title: RACISM SESSION HEARS DR. CLARK
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark told a meeting of clergymen, psychia trists, psychologists and educa tors this week that in the think ing of most white Americans, black children are clearly ex pendable.

title: SENATORS BLOCK WELFARE REFORM AND ASK REVISION
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  President Nixon's welfare re form program was abruptly de railed today by a rebellious Senate Finance Committee and sent off to a new highlevel group of Administration offi cials for a major reworking.

title: Theater: Midnight Fare
description: TO call any play The Dirt iest Show in Town sa vors just slightly of boasting. After all, this is a pretty big town, and we do have some pretty dirty shows. But Tom Eyen, the playwright of The Dirtiest Show in Town, really delivers what he threatens. This makes Oh? Calcutta? seem like Little Women, and it is also fun nier than both, with the only possible exception of Little Women. really delivers what he threatens. This makes Oh? Calcutta? seem like Little Women, and it is also fun nier than both, with the only possible exception of Little Women.

title: A Correction
description: The financial figures of UAL, Inc., were incorrectly stated by The New York Times in yester day's edition. The company, which operates United Air Lines, had a loss of $15,084,000 in the first quarter of 1970, compared with a loss of $1, 239,000 in the like period during 1969.

title: Amon, Cannon, Krisiloff Pass 500 Drivers' Tests
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 (UPI)  Three rookies passed the final phases of their 500 drivers' tests today as 10 driv ers took 12 cars out for prac time laps and activity picked up at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: Who Will Play Dolly in 2001?
description: NEW YORK CITY, JAN. 4, 2001: As most of you avid theatergoers know, Hello, Dolly! at the St. James. Theater is about to celebrate its 37th year of playing to standing room only. Octo genarian producer David Merrick was interviewed by this reporter and he furnished us with some of the high lights of the hit show's long and profitable run. The show opened on Jan. 16, 1964, and after a succession of Dollies, Mr. Merrick scored a coup in 1967 by per suading Pearl Bailey to head up an allblack version. Two years later he again revitalized the show's box office appeal by persuading Ethel Merman to take over.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.  Some peo ple come to Nantucket with the idea of building a house of con temporary design; others arrive here with long hair and unconventional clothes  and many of the islanders have a hard time deciding which the greater sin. Most of them shudder at the thought of homes that do not blend with the early 19thcentury archi tecture that is synonymous with Nan tucket, and their blood is apt to chill at a glimpse of a lifestyle that is both off island and way out.

title: Residential Builder Pushes On
description: AT a time when residential construction is nearly at a standstill in Man hattan, one builder is plung ing ahead.

title: Is Liquidity Crisis Near? Business World Worries
description: In Wall Street these days, the old timers are worried. The unrelenting pressure of the worst bear market since the Depression has already driven a number of financial houses to the wall, and the Street is full of talk that other, far more serious prob lems, are lurking just be neath the surface.

title: VENETIANS PLAN ECOLOGY PROTEST
description: VENICE, April 27A group of youths is preparing a nauti cal protest to dramatize the industrialage ills that threaten the survival of Venice.

title: OHIO COLLEGE BACKS CONSUMER PROJECT
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, May 2The Antioch College board of trustees voted its 1,000 shares of General Motors stock today in favor of two proposals supported by the Campaign to Make General Motors Rcspon Bible.

title: Vegetables Decline
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)Production of early spring vegetables is clown about I per cent from last year and 3 per cent less than in 1968, according to the Agriculture Department. The only increases from last year were reported for lettuce and strawberries, the Crop Re porting Board said. Declines were reported for asparagus cabbage, sweet corn, onions and tomatoes.

title: Museum Here Gets A FirstHand View Of Art of Protest
description: A toy pistol rattled, two live chickens quivered, a small smoke bomb erupted and three police radio cars with sirens screaming raced to the Mu seum of Modern Art yesterday afternoon when a mock protest demanding more displays of art by black and Puerto Rican artists was staged.

title: New School Ranked First in the Nation In Faculty Salaries
description: The New School for Social Research led all American col leges and universities in aver age pay to faculty members during the 196970 academic year.

title: Letters: Disappointment at Expo '70
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Worcester Editor Retiring
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 2 (AP)Forrest W. Seymour will retire as editor of The Wor cester Telegram and Evening Gazette July 1 and will be suc ceeded by Robert C. Achorn, as sociate, editor for the last three years, the publisher, Richard C. Steele, has announced.

title: King of Spades Triumphs In Virginia Gold Cup Race
description: WARRENTON, Va., May 2 (AP)Thomas H. McKoy Jr.'s King of Spades took command just past the halfway point today, survived a late challenge and breezed to a 15length vic tory in the 45th running of the Virginia Gold CUD.

title: Charles D. Estes Will Marry Barbara Schriever on Aug. 22
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 Miss Barbara Alice Schriever and Charles Dickson Estes have made plans to be married Aug. 22 in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Cornell Star Takes Over Hockey Team
description: ITHACA, N.Y., May 2  Dick Bertrand will be. 29 years old June 7, two days before he is graduated from Cornell University. Two weeks ago the tall Canadian was named head coach of Cornell's hockey team,

title: NIXON MOVE SCORED BY U.S. COMMUNISTS
description: The Communist party of the United States accused President Nixon yesterday of violating the Constitution and of defying the expressed will of the American people in ordering combat troops into Cambodia.

title: Miners Returning to Work After U.S. Restraining Rule
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 2 Many miners are returning to work in Tennessee, southwest Virginia and southeastern Ken tucky as mines reopen in the wake of a Federal restraining order issued by Judge H. Emory Widener at Abingdon, Va.

title: COMPUTER A TOOL IN MENTAL HEALTH
description: The computer is moving into the field of mental health care with a quiet efficiency.

title: Management Aid for Harlem Business
description: A group of small business es in Harlem  including a grocery store, a contractor, a limousine service and an apparel manufacturer  are utilizing the services of man agement consultants these days, as do the giant cor porations of American indus try.

title: TransAm Drivers to Race at Lime Rock Saturday
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., May 2 The TransAmerican Cham pionship for sports sedans comes east next Saturday with a twohour race over the 1,53mile road course of Lime Rock Park, in the Litchfield Hills of north Connecticut.

title: Soviet Publishes Works of Jewish Artist
description: Against a background of charges of official Soviet anti Semitism, an unusual collection of drawings including Israeli scenes and Jewish folk themes has been received from the Soviet Union.

title: Changes in Pact Sought by REA
description: REA Express has petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board to order extensive changes in the Air Express agreement. This is the arrangement un der which REA and 35 air lines jointly operate priority Air Express service.

title: MRS. HERMAN STEINLAUF
description: Mrs. Hannah Kerness Stein lauf, wife of Herman Steinlauf, president of Herman's Sport Goods, Inc., chain of stores, died yesterday in Doctors Hos pital. She was 65 years old and lived at 140 Riverside Drive. Surviving, besides her husband, are a daughter, Mrs. Phyllis Schriger; two sisters, and a grandchild.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Edgar Wallace died in 1932 at the age of 57, leaving 173 volumes ranging from poetry to tales of Africa and horseracing to more than 100 of that uniquely British phenomenon, the thriller. I daresay he was remarkably popular in his lifetime, but his current publishing statistics are in their way as incredible as those of Creasey and Gardner. Fifty of his thrill ers are still in print in England, more than half of them in hard covers. Some features of his writing  its sheer narrative impact, and its humor have kept his stories alive while those of most of his contempor aries have been forgotten.

title: EXHIBITIONS
description: IBM GALLERY16 East 57th St. First U.S. showing of photographs by Hans Fin sler, pioneer Swiss photog rapher; through Saturday. Hours, 10 to 5; closed to day.

title: Author's Query
description: For a dissertation on the role of the voluntary association in the society of nineteenth cen tury America, I would appreci ate any information as to the availability and location of manuscript records or minutes of the various volunteer fire companies of New York City between 1780 and 1865.

title: Seaborg Links Survival of Man To Science's Success or Failure
description: Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chair man of the Atomic Energy Com mission, in a speech to a scien tific convention here, predicted that the success or failure of science could determine man's survival as a species.

title: Platypuses Die in Nets
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 2 (Reuters)  Seven platypuses, Australia's rare egglaying mammals, which are protected by law, have been found dead in illegal fishing nets near here. Wildlife officials also found hundred of dead fish and water birds in the nets.

title: Thousands of Workers Are Laid Off as Result of Wildcat Teamster Strike
description: CLEVELAND, May 1Tens of thousands of workers have been laid off across the country and millions of dollars worth of production has been halted as a result of a monthlong teamster strike. The impact of the wildcat strike appears to be spreading rapidly, partic ularly in industries dependent on steel.

title: 21YearOld Sailor Ends Solo Voyage Around the World
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 2 (AP)Robin Lee Graham, who set out when he was 16 years old to become the youngest person to sail solo around the world, has come home nearly five years later tanned, thin, tired and happy.

title: Law and Order
description: At the heart of the American tragedy of growing civic unrest is the counterfeit slogan of law and order. The political perversion of those symbolic words permits a Machiavellian manipulation of public attitudes. It makes sound principles serve evil pur poses. It spreads distrust and divides the nation.

title: HURRICANE SEERS OFTEN MISS MARK
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) United States weather scien tists admit that predictions of hurricane movements often miss the mark by 100 miles for a 24hour forecast, according to a Congressional report.

title: Postelection Martial Law Is Relaxed by Colombians
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 2 (Reuters)The state of siege and martial law imposed after the presidential election April 19 was partly eased this week end, and soccer games were allowed.

title: Agostini Motorcycle Victor; British Driver Dies in Crash
description: ADENAU, Germany, May (UPI)  Giacomo Agostini of Italy captured the 350C.C. com petition for the second straight year at the international Grand Prix motorcycle races today. The event was marred by the death of Bruce Fitton, a British driver.

title: John Mayall Really Has the Blues
description: JOHN MAYALL was an hour and half late for dinner because he had to go out to Kennedy to meet Nancythe light of my lifewho was flying in from London on a 747 (It was awful, she groaned, no pri vacy), and when they went to their hotel to pick up their reservations, they found they had none. Mayall himself had just flown down from Toronto and had not had any sleep for two days.

title: Donna Proopis Plans Wedding
description: WOODMERE, L. I. May 2 Mr. and Mrs. William Proopis bave announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Donna Lynn Proopis, to Mr. Barnett Rukin, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rukin of Saddle River, N. J.

title: How to Solve Lawn Problems
description: FOR problem areas of the lawn, no one procedure will work, but a good maintenance program is right for a start. This, along with a single corrective measure or a combi nation of practices, will speed turf growth. These measures may range from use of a better grass to special methods of establishment, to controlling traffic and pest or soil improvement and water ing.

title: Confirmation
description: KATZMichael Barry. Mr. and Mrs. Ed ward Katz of Atlantic Beach loytully announce the Bar Mizyah of their son Michael Barry on May 2, 1970 at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst.

title: THE OPENINGS
description: MOD DONNATonight, Puh lic Theater, 7:30. A music with book and lyrics by Myrna Lamb; music by Susan Hulsman Bingham.

title: Birobidzhan
description: The Jewish Autonomous Province of Birobidzhan, established by the Soviet authorities in the twenties as a center of Jewish set tlement, culture and self government within the Soviet Union, failed com pletely as such. Greeted with enthusiasm not only by some Soviet Jewish Communists but by Jewish Communists the world over, it once attracted settlers even from America and Palestine as a rival to Zion ism, but never drew any significant number of Rus sian Jews. At the end of World War II the Jewish population of Birobidzhan reached a peak of some 30,000.

title: Clash at Rutgers Stadium
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 2Three Rutgers University, students were arrested and sev eral more were injured in a melee at Rutgers Stadium to day after spectators at an R.O.T.C. drill exercise left the stands and attacked a group of 150 student demonstrators.

title: PROBLEMS PLAGUE TAIWAN FARMERS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 23 Taiwan's agriculture, for years one of the island's economic success stories, is facing serious problems occasioned by the na tion's industrial growth.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
CARDIFF IS VICTOR OVER SWANSEA, 20
description: SWANSEA, Wales, May (AP)Cardiff won the Welsh Cup soccer final today with 20 victory over Swansea.

title: Marietta Wins 3 of 4 Races In MidAmerica Rowing
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, May 2 Marietta College won the var sity, junior varsity and light weight events and finished sec ond in the freshman race to day in the MidAmerica Colle giate Rowing Association re gatta on the Ohio River. Nine colleges competed in the event and Purdue was the winner in the freshman race.

title: Article 5  No Title
Duquesne Names Law Dean
description: PITTSBURGH, May 2 (UPI) Ronald Davenport, 33year old professor of law at Du quesne University, has been appointed dean of the school of law. He is the first black dean of the predominantly white law school.

title: Brown Crew Vanquishes Syracuse by 1 Lengths
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May Brown's heavyweight crew captured the second annual Robert S. Holding Cup regatta today, defeating Syracuse by a length and a quarter over 2,000 meters on the Seekonk River.

title: Delaware Candidate Quits
description: DOVER, Del. May 2 (AP) Attorney General David P. Buckson has withdrawn as a candidate for Republican nomi nation to Delaware's only seat in the United States House of ??.

title: Scientists Shun Confrontation on Causes of Differences in I.Q.
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The possible effect of race and environment on intelligence, the touchiest subject in social science, arose at a tense ses sion of the National Academy of Sciences meeting here this week.

title: MRS. PAUL A. KENNEDY
description: Mrs. Esther McKeown Ken nedy, former president of the Immaculate Conception Day Nursery in Brooklyn and the wife of Dr. Paul A. Kennedy, a retired assistant superinten dent of the Board of Educa tion, died of a thrombosis at the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn on Friday. She was 75 years old and lived at 55 92d Street in Bay Ridge sec tion.

title: Great Britain looked to France like America's Trojan Horse
description: Leaders of men, Charles de Gaulle has written, are later re membered less for the usefulness of what they have achieved than for the sweep of their endeavors. The refusal of his AngloSaxon allies and antagonists to believe these words became the history of a decade. The American grand design for Atlan tic partnership fell apart; successive British prime ministers made their Canossas to Paris only to find that their heresy  the special rela tionship with the United States would be neither forgotten nor ab solved.

title: Arrests at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 2 Four students were taken into custody by the Princeton Town ship police today in connection with a firebombing early this morning of a Princeton Uni versity armory used by units of the R.O.T.C.

title: Space Center Is Open to Visitors Even in a Crisis
description: HOUSTONThis is Mission Con trol, came the dry, unemotional voice over the loudspeaker. At rows of littered tables strewn with wires attached to tape recorders and microphones, dozens of news corre spondents abruptly stopped whatever they were doing. A chubby grayhaired man paused with his fingers in midair over his typewriter; others put down coffee cups, or stopped writing notes or chatting with each other.

title: Dust Commander Benefits From No. 2 Post, His Small Size and Large Field
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 The speed horses were gasping for oxygen, the closers were coming on and a groom along the outer rail at Churchill Dwns was screaming, It's Dust Commander. We're gonna win the Derby. suaaeniy, it was all falling into place. What had been just a clue in a wideopen mys tery Derby was standing out like a neon signpost. Dust Commander had won the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland 10 days ago, and horses who do well in the 1mile Blue Grass normally do well in the 1 mile Kentucky Derby.

title: PuttPutt Replaced by Purr
description: NEWLY developed lawn mowers, garden trac tors and other out door power tools that are driven by electricity rath er than gasoline have led some people to predict (or maybe hope?) that the silent whirr of the electric motor may some day replace the buzzsawlike roar of the gaso line engine in suburban yards and gardens.

title: CAROLINA IS TOLD: INTEGRATE BY FALL
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., May 2 Top Federal officials bluntly told South Carolina school of ficials this week that all South ern school districts must imple ment total desegregation plans by this fall.

title: Russell L. Carson to Wed Judith Mara
description: WEST NEWTON, Mass., May 2Miss Judith Mara will be married here July 25 to Russell Lloyd Carson.

title: Business Index Rises in Week
description: Business Index Rises in Week

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: May 8Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey rally school at Green Notch Fire House, Long Hill Road, Little Falls, N. J. Fee $1. School, open to all makes of cars, to be held May 15 and 22 also. Information: Jim De Young, phone (201)6977525.

title: Youth Is Now Served
description: ANOTHER breakthrough In tennis has shaken up a lot of oldtimers.

title: Bank Holdup Fails
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI)Two armed men who attempted to rob a Security Pacific National Bank branch fled when 25 cus tomers and employes ducked for cover after one bandit fired several shots in the floor.

title: Allied Search in Cambodia Yields Few Sign's of Foe
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 3United States and South Vietnamese soldiers have begun a painstaking search of the Fishhook area of Cam bodia amid increasing indica tions that many enemy troops fled in advance of the allied forces' arrival.

title: All American
description: If you want to be dressed up, but not done up, consider the shirtwaist. Paris couturiers have recently discovered what Am erican designers have always known: the classic shirtdress adapts itself with ease to contemporary partying. Cool or casual, demure or sophisticated, it's equally at home in a country club or on a houseboat in the Hudson.

title: Washington: The Heart of the Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, May 2In announcing his decision to ex pand the Indochina war, Presi dent Nixon said he was going to the heart of the trouble, and if you accept this as true, it is easy to approve his deci sion. But is it true?

title: 6TH GRADERS GET LESSONS IN LAW
description: Suppose I had a gun and it went off accidentally and killed someone. Is that murder? Do I get the electric chair?

title: Conservative Beats Yarborough In Democratic Primary in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Sunday, May 3 A millionaire businessman from Houston, using President Nixon's Southern strategy in a Democratic primary, yester day defeated Senator Ralph W. Yarborough, the Texas maver ick liberal who was bidding for a third term in the Senate.

title: In Many Cities, That Man on the Beat in a CrimeRidden Area May Be a Neighbor Assisting the Police
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 30  After 11 P.M. it gets very quiet in Dayton View, a racially mixed neighborhood in this southern Ohio city, and the crackling radio in Joe Wine's car semed uncomfortably loud.

title: Unemployment Up to 6.6% In Poorest Neighborhoods
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Labor Department says that unemployment in the poor est neighborhoods of the na tion's 100 largest cities rose to 6.6 per cent in the first quar tre of this year, reflecting in creasing joblessness in the na tion as a whole.

title: Parents of Quints Try to Avert Glare of Publicity on Children
description: Wherever they are in the world, the parents of quintu plets seem to have in common a determination to save their children from an abnormal ex istence based on too much public attention.

title: Public NuisanceSix Years
description: In South Carolina and elsewhere, criminals have been known to receive six years or less for man slaughter. State Circuit Court Judge E. Harry Agnew, in sentencing three owners of a coffeehouse catering to offduty soldiers from Fort Jackson, gave them six years for maintaining a public nuisance. This was not simply judicial overkill; it was a vindictive sen tence against peaceful antiwar dissent.

title: PACERS SET BACK COLONELS, 121110
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 (UPI) Roger Brown and Bob Neto licky combined for 63 points tonight to lead the Indiana Pac ers to a 121110 victory over the Kentucky Colonels and square their Eastern Division playoff finals in the American Basketball Association at one victory apiece.

title: New Movie Financing Deal Seen
description: Richard D. Zanuck, presi dent of the Twentieth Cen turyFox Film Corporation, who just completed four atypical financing arrange ments for lowbudget motion pictures his company will re lease, thinks that such deals are the wave of the future for the industry.

title: Twins Top Orioles, 42, as Killebrew's Double Scores Deciding Run in 8th
description: BALTIMORE, May 2 (AP) Harmon Killebrew's twoout dupble in the eigth inning drove in Minny Mendoza with the deciding run today as the Minnesota Twins posted a 42 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: DUNCAN GAINS FINAL IN AMATEUR BOXING
description: TRENTON, May 2 (AP) Eddie Duncan of Philadelphia a light heavyweight, stopped his fourth straight foe in less than three rounds tonight in the annual national Amateur Athletic Union boxing cham pionship by stopping John Martin of Washington, in the semifinals.

title: Prima Donna a Feature Of Bank Canine Exhibit
description: Ch. Arriba's Prima Donna, the boxer that won best in show at Westminster at Mad ison Square Garden in Feb ruary, will be among the dogs in the 10th canine exhibition of the Manhattan Savings Bank this week. The event will run from tomorrow through Friday from noon to 1:30 P.M. at the branch on Madison Avenue and 47th Street. There is no admission charge.

title: FOUNDATIONS SHY AT PLAN FOR G.M.
description: A campaign to persuade Gen eral Motors stockholders to ap prove two consumeroriented proposals this month over the objection of the company's management has aroused much interest but won few supporters among foundations holding G.M. stock.

title: RAP BROWN FACING DECISION TOMORROW
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., May 2 Unless he appears in court here Monday, H. Rap Brown will be declared a fugitive from justice for the second time in his tumultuous career as a black militant leader.

title: U.S. Education Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Grant Venn, an associate States Office of Education, has resigned to take a new post with the American Association of School Administrators.

title: Soccer TV in Garden Will Have $12.50 Top
description: Two matches in the World Cup soccer series will be televised in color in the main arena of Madison Square Garden, and the top seat price for each match will be $12.50. Other tickets are on sale at $10, $8 and $5. The World Cup, to be contested in Mexico, will begin May 31.

title: Mudge Considering Action To Void Chicago 7 Verdict
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI) United States District Court Judge Julius J. Hoffman has taken under advisement a mo tion by Chicago 7 defense at torneys requesting acquittal for the five convicted defendants in the riot conspiracy trial be cause of published reports by one of the jurors.

title: Contracts Listed
description: SEATTLE, May 2 (UPI) Boeing Company awarded $2.18billion in subcontracts to builders and suppliers in all 50 states and the District of Columbia last year. More than 15,000 companies parti cipated. California got 48 per cent of the total of $1.5bil lion. New York was second with about $292.8million; fol lowed by Connecticut, with $212.5million; Ohio, $75mil lion; Arizona, $67million; New Jersey, $36million; Ok lahoma, $33million; Penn sylvania, $30million, and Oregon, $20million.

title: Violence on Campuses
description: Demonstrations against President Nixon's decision to send troops into Cambodia turned violent yesterday.

title: NAVY NINE BEATS COLUMBIA TWICE
description: In an impressive pregame ceremony yesterday, Columbia rededicated its baseball dia mond in honor of its former coach, Andy Coakley, and then Navy contributed to the cere monies with a 21hit salute, taking both ends of the Eastern League doubleheader, 61 and 122.

title: Fleet Wing, $6.60, First In $21,100 Winn Handicap
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)Fleet Wing took the lead on the turn to home today and went on to win the $21,100 Matt Winn Handicap by threequarters of a length at Washington Park.

title: A HOME FOR AGED NOTES 100TH YEAR
description: One hundred years ago this month, with thanks to the many benevolent and charitable lad ies of Congregation B'nai Jeshu run, under the leadership of Mrs. Henry Leo, the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews first opened its doors on West 17th Street.

title: Science
description: If the oil companies have their way, a few winters hence Alaska, the nation's most gigantic and unspoiled state, will be bisected from north and south by a hot ar tery  a pipe four feet in diameter and close to 800 miles long, carrying a deluge of oil through the otherwise frigid terrain at a tempera ture of 150 degrees Fahren heit, or more.

title: For art's sake
description: An art collector demands more of an apartment than most people. He wants an attractive and comfort able place to live as well as a background to show off his pictures and sculpture. Arnold Glimcher, co owner of the Pace Gallery in Manhattan, achieved such a balance. A blackandwhite color scheme and steel, leather and marble furniture create crisp look that echoes the spirit of his collection.

title: New York Youth Wins $500 for Ship Poster
description: An upstate New York high school senior became $500, richer last week for having submitted the winning entry in the 1970 National Mari time Poster Contest.

title: By Erskine Caldwell out of Flannery O'Connor
description: There is something strangely askew in these stories, all of which are set in the hinterlands of Appa lachia. They seem to be written by someone who has heard of red hills, cornpone, bib overalls, and Tuberose snuff, but has never met the heady parorexia of the late Confederacy firsthand. Eleanor Glaze is ignorant,

title: Marlinda Bruno Becomes Bride Of Robert Cook
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., May 2  Miss Marlinda Ruth Bruno, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco D. Bruno of Danbury, was married this afternoon to Robert Francis Cook, son of Mrs. Francis C. Cook of Boone, N. C., and the late Professor Cook, who taught English at Appalachian State College in Boone.

title: New Zealanders Visit U.S.
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand Last year, New Zealand, in proportion to its population of 2.781 million, sent more tour fists to the United States than any other South Pacific coun try, the New Zealand News letter reports. Of 100,000 tour ists to the united States from the area, 21,000 were from New Zealand.

title: Diane Crump Gets to Winner's Circle, but Not in Kentucky Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 Diane Crump came back to her green  carpeted hideaway at Churchill Downs today wiping mud from her face and smiling.

title: POLL FINDS GAINS FOR INTEGRATION
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 2 The percentage of white South ern parents who would object to sending their children to schools where Negroes were enrolled has dropped from 61 per cent to 16 per cent in the last seven years, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: SEATO Names Plans Chief
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 2 (Reuters)Maj. Gen. Robert Patterson, of the New Zealand Army, has been appointed chief of the military planning office of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, SEATO headquar ters here announced yesterday. He will succeed Maj. Gen. Au trey Maroun, the first American appointed chief of SEATO mili tary planning, on July 1.

title: R. A. Scheer Weds Miss Killmer at Wednesday's
description: The marriage of Miss Susan Grace Killmer to Richard A. Scheer took place at Wednes day's restaurant on East 86th Street yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by Supreme Court Justice Jacob B. Grumet.

title: Personality:
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill.  In the quiet farmlands here just a short drive from Chicago, stands the new $25million home office of the Allstate Insurance Company.

title: COX BEATS HEWITT FOR TENNIS TITLE
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 2 (UPI)Mark Cox of Bri tain took only 74 minutes to day to beat Bob Hewitt of South Africa, 61, 62, 63, in the final of the $36,000 British hardcourt open tennis tourna ment today.

title: Miss Carolyn Wetlesen Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Wetlesen of Staten Island have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Wetlesen, to Wil liam K. Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hoffman of Darien, Conn.

title: Spotlight:
description: Spotlight:

title: Federalists Victors In Quebec For Now
description: QUEBECAfter the profed eralist Liberal party won a land slide mandate in last week's Que bec provincial election, many Canadians wondered whether the threat of Quebec's secession from Canada had passed for good or merely been delayed.

title: Movies
description: HELL, no, he's no revolutionary: he mightn't be too happy about Nixon in the White House but he wouldn't like to see Abbie Hoffman there either. The PR puffs call him an under ground filmmaker, but he's never been that. He's not one of the avant garde. And though he used to be one of the low budget, independent moviemakers who have started turning out moneyspinners like Easy Rider, that status ended re cently when he signed a contract with Warner Brothers.

title: Melanie Gordon Becomes Bride Of Gary Grimes
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 2  Miss Melanie Wilmer Gordon and Gary Sherman Grimes were married here this afternoon in St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor. A reception was given at the home of Ben jamin Wisner Bacon, a can didate for Congress from the Fourth District in Con necticut, and Mrs. Bacon, sister of the bride.

title: Rights Lawyer in Kentucky Gains in Fight Against Disbarment
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 A controversial criminal and civil rights lawyer here has won important procedural points from the Federal courts in a long fight to avoid disbarment or suspension by the Kentucky Bar Association.

title: Greece, Three Years After
description: GREECE has been a dictatorship since April 21, 1967, but most tourists visiting the country would have to look hard to see a dif ference. True, for the anniversary celebrations scheduled for today, the highways have been lined with signs reading: Long Live the 21st of April, Long Live the Army, Long Live the National govern ment. The symbol of the ruling junta the silhouette of an armed soldier against the outline of a phoe nix rising from flamesis every where, from giant billboards to the cover of every matchbox. But there are no more policemen or military men in the streets of Greece than there are in any other European country, and they are as helpful to strangers as Greek hospitality de mands. There are no restrictions on movement, so tourists can visit any part of Greece they want except for a few areas bordering on Communist countries.

title: Point of View
description: A year ago, in an article published by The New York Times (April 6, 1969), I noted that the Nixon Ad ministration and the Federal Reserve authorities recog nized that the expectation of continuing inflation had become a powerful destabil izing force in our economy, and that fiscal and mone tary restraints were being directed to dampen down the widespread belief that a per sistent high rate of inflation was inevitable.
