The purpose or this article is to examine how we stand today in our efforts to combat the expec tation of inflationhow much progress, if any, has been made toward cooling it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The wit and humor of Roger Starr's writing style [For a Housing Policy Shift, April 19] frequently conceal the bankruptcy of his argu ments. But, worse than bank rupt, they are a clever and effective pleading for those real estate speculators in this city who would profit from the city's desperate housing crisis.

title: Blaze Damages Freighter Coming Into Port Newark
description: A fire caused moderate damage in the engine room of a 436foot Korean freighter yesterday afternoon as she en tered the Kill Van Kull between Staten Island and Bayonne, N. J., on its way to a berth in Port Newark.

title: Art
description: THE dialectic of culture is often fecund with paradox. A civiliza tion may be dying, its social ethos drained of vitali ty and its political life driven to desperation and violence, and yet in the crucible of this extreme historical mo ment, when nearly all other signs point to dissolution and decay, an esthetic vision of great power and refinement may suddenly assert itself. Nor is it inevitably the case that such a vision draws its energy from a sense of par tisanship with the most rad ical or forward  looking ele ments of society. Sometimes it does, and sometimes it does the very opposite. The greatest paradox may lie pre cisely therein the fact that a great artistic accomplish ment may derive its energy and focus from its sense of the distance, if not the out right opposition, that sepa rates its own ideal of esthet ic reconstruction from that of the political forces that are intent upon radical so cial reconstruction.

title: FAVORITES ADVANCE AT WESTCHESTER NET
description: ARMONK, N. Y., May 2 Steve Ross of Brooklyn, the de fending champion, and Bob Bar ker of Sands Point, L. I., led an advance into the third round of the 37th annual Westchester County tennis championship to day at the Armonk Tennis Club. All eight seeded players, after getting firstround byes, won in straight sets.

title: AGNEW IS SCORED BY COLLEGE HEAD
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 2 (AP)The president of the Uni versity of Michigan criticized Vice President Agnew today for pressing what he described as superficial attacks on the na tion's colleges.

title: Sports of The Times
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2If the other jockeys had no high regard for the abilities of Dust Commander before the 96th running of the Kentucky Derby today, they ruefully admitted afterward that this compact chestnut had convinced them to the contrary.

title: Lorna Dale Is Wed To Robert Savage
description: Miss Lorna Alan Dale, an actress, was married yester day afternoon to Robert Heath Savage, a senior vice president of Ogilvy & Mather, the advertising agency. The Rev. James W. Crawford per formed the ceremony in the Central Presbvterin Church.

title: COLUMBIA AGREES TO HALT CLASSES
description: Columbia University agreed yesterday to a oneday mora torium on classes tomorrow to protest President Nixon's deci sion to send American troops into Cambodia.

title: MARINO OF N.Y.U. STOPS WAGNER, 10
description: Carl Marino pitched a one hitter yesterday as New York University edged Wagner, 10, on consecutive doubles in the ninth inning at Ohio Field in the Bronx.

title: Princeton Outrows Yale and Cornell and Takes Third Straight Carnegie Cup
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 2 It looked as if Cornell Univer sity's redshirted crews were going to sweep the annual Carnegie Cup regatta today un til Princeton's big varsity shell rowed away from the Big Red and Yale in the major event.

title: Not only later than Virginia Woolf, but even D. H. Lawrence
description: The novel as disguised lyric Herman Hesse's phrase has long ceased to sound paradoxicalis the work of fiction that is more con erned with emotional state than with visible events, whose language is in tensified and even metaphoric, like poetry's. Running Out, a first novel by Christopher Brookhouse, is, in fact, a little oldfashioned, by which I mean that, instead of being an experiment a la mode in surreal humor or grotesque picaresque, or some other current manner, it is more like something of Virginia Woowssay, Mrs. Dalloway, pub lished over 40 years ago. Almost academically, it employs the solipsis tic, restricted viewpoint and stream of consciousness which belongs to such older classics.

title: Beer Cans in Cambodia: A Sign G.I.'s Are There
description: PREY TATHOEK, Cambodia, May 1I'd like to see the look on Fulbright's face right now, said a rotund Ameri can lieutenant colonel as he stuck a plug of chewing to bacco into his right jowl. This is really something, ain't it?

title: Chinese Excerpts, and Text of Soviet Broadcast
description: Following are excerpts from an editorial entitled Lenin ism or Social Imperialism? which appeared April 22 in official newspapers of Com munist China, and the text of a Chineselanguage broadcast transmitted by the Soviet Un ion to China on April 25. The translations were supplied by Western monitoring services.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: O. J. Happy After a Year With Bills
description: This time a year ago, O. J. Simpson was unhappy. He was at an impasse in his ne gotiations with the Buffalo Bills and he was wishing that he had been drafted by one of the established National Football League teams, preferably the Los Angeles Rams or the San Francisco 49ers.

title: The Necessity of Restraint
description: While the search for ways to curb the nuclear arms race proceeded with agonizing deliberateness Vienna last week, the two major powers took actions in two sensitive trouble areas of the world that peri lously breached barriers of selfrestraint that have served as a vital safeguard against nuclear war.

title: PENTAGON BUDGET FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) A bipartisan group of 12 Senators announced plans to day for a rigorous examination of the $73billiart defense budg et to cut Pentagon spending anc reorder the relative priori ties between military security and domestic needs.

title: Intensive Talks Are Scheduled Tonight by Printers and Papers
description: Theodore W. Kheel an nounced yesterday that he had scheduled intensive bargaining talks between the printers union and the city's four ma jor newspapers to start to night.

title: 128 U.S. PLANES CARRY OUT ATTACK IN NORTH VIETNAM; SUPPLY LINES ARE TARGETS
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 The United States has carried out a heavy bombing raid against supply dumps and other targets north of the demilitarized zone in North Vietnam, wellplaced Administration sources said to day.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: TRAVEL

title: A system of law, tried and found guilty
description: Using Clemenceau's barbed com ment on military justice for his title and theme, Robert Sherrill has writ ten an immensely readable critique of the way the military dispenses justice. In the muckraking tradition, Sherrill provides a vivid account of outrageous conditions and abuses, strewn with examples of widespread brutality and sadism in military stock ades, command domination of trials, and denial of individual rights of serv icemen. The importance of his book is not so much in exposing these con ditionsfor they have filtered into the press over the last couple of yearsbut in indicating how exten sive they are and in challenging the basic features of the military justice system which permit them to con tinue.

title: Dance: Young Company
description: THE cancellation of the na tional tour planned for Birgit Cullberg's Dance Thea ter from Sweden, led, on Fri day night, to the first appear ance locally of the First Chamber Dance Company. This small, new company ap peared at Colden Hall of Queens College as part of its third annual dance series.

title: System at Fault in Auto Insurance
description: WASHINGTONThe sys tem, rather than those who run it, is emerging as the main target of the Govern ment's two  year, $2  million automobile insurance inves tigation.

title: U.S. Official's Plea On PeaceKeeping Stirs U.N. Interest
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2A statement by Under Secretary of State Elliot L. Richardson, appealing for a re vitalized United Nations capac ity for settling disputes, is re ceiving intensive attention here.

title: Best Seller List
description: GENERAL

title: Hebrew U. Names Ross
description: Daniel G. Ross, a New York lawyer, was appointed yester day chairman of the Interna tional Committee of the Insti tute of Contemporary Jewry of Hebrew University in Jerusa lem. The announcement was made here by the American Friends of Hebrew University of which Mr. Ross is a former ??

title: Music
description: MOVIE music is a bit in the news. Old mu sic for old movies. Friday night, at the Lincoln Center Spring Film Festival, Arthur Kleiner played the piano for the French film, Les Vampires. Kleiner, who was the silent film pianist for the Museum of Modern Art before he re tired, thinks that this seven hour, nonstop stretch at the keyboard may be a record of sorts.

title: Susan C. Petersmeyer Is Wed To 2d Lieut. Ben G. Henneke Jr.
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y. May 2 Miss Susan Calhoun Peters meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wrede Peter, meyer, was married here this afternoon to Second Lieut. Ben Graf Henneke Jr., U. S. A., son of Dr. Henneke, former president of Tulsa University, and Mrs. Henneke of Tulsa.

title: Brazil Eleven in Mexico
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Way 2 (AP)  Brazil's national soccer team, twice world cham pions and a favorite in the World Cup tournament, ar rived in Guadalajara today, Several thousand fans greeted the Brazilians, the first team to arrive in Mexico to prepare for the tournament, which starts May 31.

title: SAN DIEGO ROTS M'ANDREN IN 2D
description: SAN DIEGO, May 2  The New York Mets, who were un defeated and untied in San Diego for more than a year, finally lost a game in the Padres' ballpark today.

title: In The Nation: Further Into the Quagmire
description: WASHINGTONThe invasion of Cambodia ordered by Presi dent Nixon makes it clear that he does not have and never has had a plan to end the war. For this is another of those escalations of the South east Asian war that in every previous case had to be extend ed further than expected and still accomplished nothing.

title: Religion
description: Ecumenical dialogue, stepped up since Vatican II, may be producing its own idealistic lit tle world  a world in which churches which have been sep arated for centuries begin to erase differences and sound alike. But when it comes to im plementing the sometimes star tling changes proposed, dialogue experts often discover that there are wide gaps between them and the church decision makers who implement such changesto say nothing of the church membership who must accept such changes.

title: To a Green World
description: At this time of year, when the freshness of spring manages to penetrate even the depths of the city's slums, the deprived youngsters of New York must feel particularly the cheerlessness of their homes and the joylessness of their streets.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of the Ameri can author of adventure novels, Edgar Rice Burroughs (1875 1950), I am seeking copies of letters by Burroughs and any relevant published or unpub lished material about him.

title: State Lists Job Gains for Minorities
description: The number of Negroes on the state payroll increased from 11.4 per cent to 13 per cent of all state employees be tween 1967 and 1969 the De partment of Civil Service said yesterday.

title: What's New in the Theater
description: COMPANY, a musical with book and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and book by George Furth, got cheers from seven critics, a mixed reception from two and disapproval from two. Clive Barnes: Company, about which I have some personal reservations, de serves to be a hit in a lean season. It is a very New York show and will be par ticularly popular with tour ists. It is about the joys and pains of married love in New York City. Particu larly the pains. Creatively, Mr. Sondheim's lyrics are way above the rest of the show; they have a lyric suppleness, sparse, elegant vit, and range from the virtuosity of a patter song to a kind of sweetly lacon ic cynicism in a modern love song. Mr. Sond heim must be one of the most sophisticated compos ers ever to write a Broad way musical, yet the re sult is slick, clever and eclectic rather than ex citing. The conception has two difficulties. In the first place, these people are just the kind you expend hours each day trying to escape from. The second fault is a structural one. Here is a series of linked scenes, all basically similar to one an other, and it is left to the director to find a variety of pace and character, and to impose a satisfactory unity on the show. This Harold Prince has not done. The cast, apart from the lead ing man, Dean Jones, is ex cellent. I was antagonized by the slickness, the ob viousness of Company. But I stress that I really believe a lot of people are going to love it. For Walter 1.

title: Alabama Race: I Never Seen One Like This Before
description: BIRMINGHAM. Ala., May 2 By the standards of normal Ala bama Governor's races, this year's campaign has been about as exciting as a haircut.

title: 20 Millionth Copy of Bible Given to J. C. Penney Here
description: The 94yearold founder of the J. C. Penney department store chain received last week the symbolic 20 millionth copy of the American Bible Society's New Testament in today's English.

title: Satloo R. Gurbaxani Is Married To Dr. Benjamin L. Van Duuren
description: ?? Satloo R. Gurbaxani, a Pakistan born, Bombay educated research chemist at HoffmannLa Roche, Inc., in Nutley, N. J., was married here yesterday morning to Dr. Benjamin L. Van Duuren, professor of environmental medicine at the New York University Medical Center.

title: Egypt Says It Destroyed Israeli Halftrack at Canal
description: CAIRO, May 2 (Reuters)  A military spokesman said here that Egyptian heavy artillery shelled Israeli positions across the Suez Canal in a threehour exchange today, destroying one Israeli halftrack, damaging a tank and another halftrack, and hitting artillery bases and ammunition dumps.

title: Rumania Still Has Some Gypsy in Its Soul
description: BUCHAREST  When I was a boy growing up in Bucharest, a young intellectual here said to us, one of the big events of our lives was a visit to the Stalin Museum. It was composed almost exclusively of photo graphs, and I remember them vividly Stalin Sitting, Stalin with Pipe, Stalin Without Pipe, Stalin Standing Among Friends Now Stalin is dead and the museum is gone, and we are a differ ent country.

title: FORD GRANTS TO AID 3 PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: Aid for three public elemen tary schools that have pioneered in ways to involve students, teachers and the community in school affairs was announced yesterday by the Ford Foun dation.

title: COWAN TRIUMPHS IN AMATEUR GOLF
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May (AP)  Gary Cowan's power and finesse overcame Dale Morey and carried the Cana dian to a 5and4 victory today in the final of the North and South amateur golf tourna ment.

title: Meredith Gowdy Wed in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 2Miss Meredith Lee Gowdy was married here this afternoon to Harry Post Meislahn in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Laman H. Bru ner. The Rev. Robert C. La mar assisted.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Shimer And John W. Lea
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 2 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Shimer have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Gretchen Shinier, to John Whitney Lea, son of Mrs. Bertram Lippincott O'Neill and the late Sydney Long streth Wright Lea. Both fam ilies are of Chestnut Hill.

title: Roy Remmert Jr. Fiance Of Susan Perry Thayer
description: RYE, N. Y., May 2Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Thayer have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Susan Perry Thayer, to Roy Bertram Remmert Jr., a grad uate of the University of Oklahoma, where he is com pleting his final year at the Graduate School of Business and Finance.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ONCE I wanted to write a great lyric poem, make a million dollars and own the island of Naushon.

title: Mrs. Cooley Has Son
description: A son was born on April 22 in Kabul, Afghanistan, to Mr. and Mrs. Alford Warriner Cooley. Mr. Cooley is vice consul and chief of protocol at the United States Embassy there, and Mrs. Cooley is a staff writer for the English language newspaper, The Kabul Times. The child has been named Benjamin Hins dale.

title: The wrong reasons to have children
description: ONCE upon a time, when chil dren helped work the land to assist in supporting the family, every child was an eco nomic necessity. This situation no longer exists. Neither does the need for procreation to insure sur vival of the race. Social scientists, in fact, are saying in louder voices and larger numbers that survival of our species now is dependent on decreasing the birth rate.

title: Peril to ChineseSoviet Talks Is Seen in Diatribes
description: SovietChinese border talks in Pekingand possibly even formal SovietChinese relations have been imperiled, in the opinion of diplomatic special ists, by new and violent prop aganda exchanges.

title: Ashe, Graebner Advance To Kansas City Net Final
description: KANSAS CITY, May 2 (AP) Clark Graebner, the defender, turned back Bob Lutz, 26, 76, 64, today and advaned to the final of the men's singles against Arthur Ashe in the Glenwood Manor national in vitational tennis tournament.

title: Police in Baltimore Fighting Literature on Assassination
description: Police in Baltimore Fighting Literature on Assassination

title: May
description: May is a reminder, a restatement of facts of life that have been dormant since last October. The chlorophyll of the spreading leaf, the pollen of the opening blos som, the buzz of the hungry bee, the morning song of robin and orioleall are aspects of May; the May we know would not be May without them.

title: Aboriginal Complaint
description: A million people, including Queen Elizabeth, gathered around Sydney harbor one night last week to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the landing in Australia of the famed British navigator, Capt. James Cook. Five tons of fireworks were set off, horns tooted, bands played, illuminated fireboats sprayed fountains of water into the air and more than 20 warshipsin cluding 10 stately clipper sailing shipsfrom 12 nations displayed festive bunting.

title: 8Block Shubert Alley Extension Is Aim
description: Shubert Alleythe short pe destrian path a half block west of Broadway  would stretch nine blocks through the heart of a reconstructed theater dis trict, according to a design be ing fashioned by the City Plan ning Commission.

title: Job Changes:
description: Tom Kole, formerly execu tive vice president, has been elected president and chief operating officer of REA Ex press. He succeeds Spencer D. Moseley who becomes chairman of the board and chief executive officer. The latter had been president and chief executive officer and chief operating officer.

title: My name has never been Tom
description: Ever since the riot seasons began in the midsixties, most apparently since Stokely Carmichael issued the black power cry during James Mere dith's march into Mississippi, black extremists have attempted to divide their race in terms of positives and negatives. Claiming all the positives for themselves, they have charged the people they scornfully call Ne groes with negatives, such as: cow ardice, ignorance, and lethargy; neg ligence, selfishness, and pridelessness.

title: Dance
description: I HAVE no wish to sound alarms, or even to sound alarmist, but it does seem that 1970 might be the year we see our ballet companies sink gracefully down the drain one by one. I can see the gravestone now: American dance: Born circa 1920. Died 1970. R.I.P.

title: The first magazine of black writing
description: Amistad is a new paperback magazine, the first to be devoted to black writing, which will appear semiannually this year and quarterly thereafter. In Spanish, amistad means friendship; however, the publication takes its name from the slave ship that bore the appellation. That ship

title: Philadelphia Plan Fails Its Early Tests
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 2The Philadelphia Plan, which the Nixon Administration calls one of its major civil rights pro grams, has fallen short of ex pected minority hiring goals, according to initial progress reports.

title: Ochoa Gets Medical Post
description: Dr. Severo Ochoa, Nobel lau reate and chairman of the de partment of biochemistry at the New York University School of Medicine, was appointed Lila Motley Professor of Cancer Research by the medical school last night. Dr. Ochoa, noted medical scientist, received the Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology in 1959 for his work in nucleic acids.

title: Tours, Tours, Tours and Shows
description: ON Tuesday and the fol lowing Tuesday, May 12th, the City Gardens Club of New York will have its 24th annual tour of Manhattan gardens and pent houses. Different homes and gardens will be shown each day from 2 to 5:30 P.M. Tickets are $15 for both days; $8 for one day and are avail able from the club's head quarters, 829 Madison Ave nue. Proceeds benefit civic and welfare projects of the club.

title: Militants in Schools Form New Group For Administration
description: WASHINGTON May 2 (AP) A small group of school ad ministrators plans to form a new professional organization to help school superintendents become more militant on such issues as integration and stu dent activism.

title: Conferees Extend Jobless Pay Benefit And Increase Tax
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) House and Senate conferees have agreed to extend unem ployment compensation to an additional 4.4 million workers, mostly in small businesses and nonprofit organizations, and to raise the tax on employers from $12 a year a worker to $15.

title: Paperbacks Current Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Hospital Group Names President for 197071
description: Charles W. Davidson, exec utive director of St. Luke's Hospital Center since 1962 and a member of its staff since 1946, has been elected president of the Greater New York Hospital Association for the 197071 year.

title: 2 Airmen List Antiwar Unit As Insurance Beneficiary
description: CHICOPEE, Mass., May 2 (AP) Two airmen at Westover Air Force Base say they have lamed the Vietnam Moratorium Committee as beneficiary of their $10,000 G.I. life insurance policies.

title: AUSSIEINDIA TENNIS POSTPONED BY RAIN
description: BANGALORE, India, May 2 (UPI)Heavy rain washed out the Davis Cup Eastern Zone Tennis final between India and Australia today.

title: Gilbert Islands to Get More SelfRule
description: BAIRIKI, Tarawa Atoll, Gil bert Islands, April 11The quickening pace of political ad vancement among the largely unspoiled peoples of the more remote Pacific areas is over taking even the tiny, sunbaked atolls of the Britishruled Gil bert and Ellice Islands.

title: MaryFrances Cambere Engaged
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 2  Ara A. Cambre, vice chairman of the investment firm of Hayden, Stone, Inc., has announced the engage ment of his daughter, Miss MaryFrances Cambre, to George Peter Mumbach of Wilton. Miss Cambre is manager of data processing for the Chestnutt Corpora tion here, of which her fianc is assistant treasurer. An October wedding is planned.

title: Parish in Paris Plans to Build a Church Underground
description: PARIS, May 2  Franois Cardinal Marty, Archbishop of Paris, has grented permission to on of his wealthiest parish es to replace its church and school complex with three luit ury apartment buil??. A new church is to be built under ground, beneath the garden in the center of the new protect.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL ELECTION IS A HEATED RACE
description: MOUNT VERNON, May 2 Mount Vernon, where the pub lic schools have long been an object of intense political con troversy, is focusing its atten tion on the heated campaign for a seat on the ninemember board of education.

title: Lieut. S. R. Hotchkiss Weds Miss Wallace
description: ROCHESTER, May 2Miss Barbara Lynn Wallace and Lieut. (jg.) Sherman Robert Hotchkiss, U.S.N.R., were married here this evening in the chapel of the Colgate Rochester Divinity School by the Rev. Richard L. Kesel, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Andrea Gartlan Dykes Is Married
description: Miss Andrea Gartlan Dykes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Al bert F. Dykes of New York, was married here yesterday to James Haste Reid Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Reid of Rochester. The ceremony in St. James's Episcopal Church was performed by Canon William J. Chase.

title: Coins
description: VISITORS to Bermuda from the United States and Canada are finding shopping a lot easier since the popu far vacation island switched to the decimal monetary sys tem on Feb. 6, after 360 years of pounds, shillings and pence.

title: In the Footsteps Of Chaucer's Pilgrims
description: WINCHESTER, England  One day last summer, our Ameri can family of five shouldered our rucksacks and set off in the footsteps of Chaucer's pilgrims, fol lowing the Pilgrims' Way from this ancient seat of kings to the holy shrine of Canterbury. In our party were Susie, Jimmy and Bobby (7, 10 and 12, re spectively), my husband and I.

title: Senators Shocked by Resumption of Raids in North
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Two Democratic leaders in the Sen ate deplored today the newly disclosed bombing of North Vietnam as a step that could enjarge the war and compro mise plans for withdrawal of American troops.

title: Are Soul Stations Fair to Blacks?
description: THE words soul, black, freedom, brother, beau tiful and power took on new meanings in the sixties, as the plight and determination of 20 million Americans were dramatized for all the world for the first time. These words had a tre mendous impact on the broadcasting industry, espec ially that sector geared prim arily to the nation's Afro American communities  the scores of Negro, black oriented soul facilities.

title: NEW HAVEN RALLY ENDS A DAY EARLY; ATTENDANCE DOWN
description: NEW HAVEN, May 2Mas sive demonstrations in support of the Black Panthers ended to day with a call for a nation wide student strike, but a small group of white radicals stayed behind and tonight provoked the police into the second teargas attack of the generally peaceful protest weekend.

title: FIGHTING FLARES SOUTH OF DANANG
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 2, (AP)Overshadowed by the allied drive into Cambodia, fighting has raged for three days in South Vietnam's northern most tactical zone, the I Corps area. There has been houseto house fighting in an important district town and a United States Special camp has been subjected to enemy attacks.

title: Science
description: WASHINGTON  In a few weeks, beside the hamlet of Westerbrook in northern Holland, the world's largest radio tele scope will go into operation partially manned by American scientists. There is almost a brain drain in reverse, the Dutch observatory's director has told visiting Americans.

title: DARTMOUTH'S CREW WINS COCHRANE CUP
description: MADISON, Wis., May 2 (AP) Dartmouth crossed the finish line a halflength ahead of Wisconsin today and won the Cochrane Cup crew race. The start of the 10th annual event was delayed by choppy weather on Lake Mendota.

title: Headliners
description: Millionaire in Harlem

title: Philippine Aide Is Cautious In Endorsing Nixon Move
description: MANILA, May 2Foreign Secretary Carlos P. Romulo gave cautious endorsement to day to President Nixon's deci sion to send American troops to destroy enemy refuges inside Cambodia.

title: Sands Scores Double in Sprints, Austin in Hurdles at Englewood
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 2 Mike Sands of Sheepshead Bay High, a native of the Bahamas, scored two sprint victories to day in the 24th Englewood Me morial track games at White Stadium.

title: Boat Trips In the South Of Sweden
description: MALMO, SwedenThe emphasis here in the southern tip of Sweden is on leisure. The people are sun wor shipers, and after the long and dreary winters they savor the beautiful summer days and the long hours of day light. The slightly undulating countryside, with its yellowing cornfields, is restful to the eye. Blond children on bicycles wave as you pass by, and a feeling of relaxation pervades the atmosphere.

title: Flow of Chinese Arms Into Kashmir Reported
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, May 2  Giligit, a town in Pakistancontrolled Kashmir, has been turned into a mili tary base and a storehouse of Chinese military equip ment flowing in through the recently built sinkiang Gil git mountain road, according to reliable reports reaching here.

title: City Plans to Speed Housing for Poor
description: Simeon Golar, chairman of the city's Housing Authority, said last week that he planned to step up the turnkey pro gram, under which private de velopers build low  income housing projects and then sell them to the city.

title: What's Happening In Camera World
description: CONVENIENTLY tabin dexed for speedy ref erence, a new techni cal handbook recently issued includes abundant data for all photographers. Called the Amphoto Lab Handbook and written by John S. Carroll, it is pub lished by Amphoto, 915 Broadway, New York, N. Y. 10010, and is priced at $19.95. There are 576 pages in a looseleaf vinyl binder and the handbook is divided into nine sections to simplify finding specific subjects. Supplements will be issued four times a year.

title: Giving the Composer a Helping and Free Hand
description: TO a large extent the recording industry feeds off composers of the past. So it seems rea sonable that it should turn around and do something for the living. Some companies in the record business do well enough by current established composers: for example, Co lumbia has put on disks much of Stravinsky's music, and the same can be said for London with Benjamin Brit ten, Deutsche Grammophon with Hans Werner Henze. And RCA has just entered a longterm agreement for the recording by Luciano Berio of his works.

title: CARL E. GRIFFIN
description: ROSELLE P9RK, N.J., May 2 Carl E. Griffin, a realestate broker and developer and fi nancial secretary of the Ep worth Methodist Church in Elizabeth, died last night at the East Orange Veterans Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 405 East Grant Avenue.

title: Irish Dude Rallies from 8th To Take Suffolk Feature
description: BOSTON, May 2 (AP)  Irish Dude charged from last place in a field of eight to score an easy victory in the $20,000 Chicka dee Handicap at Suffolk Downs today.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Asia to Get Educational TV
description: The Singapore Government and the Friedrich Ebert Founda tion of West Germany are es tablishing a television center to produce educational tele vision films for distribution in Asia, the United Nations Edo cational, Scientific and Cultural ??

title: Los Angeles Area Is Shaken Over a Series of Violent Acts
description: LOS ANGELES, May 2The Los Angeles poiice this week arrested five men and charged them with planning to assas sinate Superior Court Judge Alfred Gitelson, the judge who ordered the city to integrate its public schools last February.

title: AIR DEFENSE RADAR INSTALLED BY SWISS
description: GENEVA, May 2The Swiss Defense Department has an nounced it Berne that it has installed an Americanmade earlywarning system that is equipped with computers to se lect the best means of repelling an air attack.

title: Challenge By the Church in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURYThe Government of Prime Minister Ian Smith has come up against the, first serious internal opposition to its policy of racial separation.

title: 25 years of Fluoride Cuts Tooth Decay in Newburgh
description: Twentyfive years ago yes terday, Newburgh, N. Y., a midHudson city with its roots in the 17th century and its eyes on the 20th, began a pioneering experiment that to day affects the health of more than 80 million Americans.

title: Coop Boards Grappling With Varied Challenges
description: A pair of mammoth dogs that bayed like the hound of the Baskervilles touched off an up rising by sleepless residents in 1020 Park Avenue a couple of years ago, and Raymond C. Johnson's tele phone began to ring.

title: SCIENTISTS SEEK A WORLD MEASURE
description: Twentyfive scientists from nine nations left Miami on a tropical cruise Thursday, with hopes of returning in 30 days with a new international stand ard for measuring phenomena of the sea and air.

title: Motel Expansion Found Leveling Off Nationally
description: THE national rate of growth in the motel industry leveled off last year and the probability is that It will slow down this year because of national economic conditions, a hotel and motel authority reports.

title: FOR THIS WEEK
description: Start lawn mowing; set mower to cut at one and onehalf inches.. . . Dicamba will control chickweed in the lawn but do not use within root zone area of trees and shrubs. ... Divide overcrowded mums; separate the small outer plants from the inner core and replant these... Rainy, cool springs encourage anthreenose which shows up brown areas and blighted spots on leaves of sycamore and white oak, sometimes on maple or linden. Twigs shrivel. Early spray now as buds are breaking and a sec ond and third at 10day intervals with Zineb for control.

title: James Hosted Jr. Weds Sandra Sloan
description: St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting yes terday afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Sandra Eleanor Sloan to James W. Husted Jr. The ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. John B. Coburn, was followed by a reception at the River Club.

title: Wire Making, an Old Art, Advances
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Re search engineers at the West ern Electric Company will disclose what is considered a revolutionary method of manufacturing wire this week. They say the technique is the first basic change in the process since mankind began making metal wire about 4,000 years ago.

title: Home Improvement
description: THERE are several ad vantages to building a raised wood deck similar to the one shown here: it drains immed iately after a rain; it picks up breezes that may not be felt at ground level; there will be less annoyance with in sects, especially the crawl ing species; it provides direct access from upstairs and in many cases it will provide a better view and more pri vacy. In addition, a raised deck is also the ideal solu tion to the problem of build ing a level terrace or patio on steeply sloping yards or grounds.

title: Ellin Schechter Plans Nuptials
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 2The engagement of Miss Ellin Schechter, a jun ior at Syracuse University, to Douglas Maxwell, who expects to graduate from Syracuse in June, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Schechter. The prospective bride's fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Maxwell of New York.

title: Wallace Battles For His Political Life
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.At the side of the interstate highway leading from Montgomery to Birmingham, there stands a faded sign, a relic of 1968, that says Wallace for President. Below it, several weeks ago, ap peared a footnotea smaller placard that bears the legend . . . but Brewer for Governor.

title: Lon Nol Calls U.S. Moves Response to Plea for Aid
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 2  Premier Lon Nol moved closer today to open endorse ment of the American military intervention in Cambodia when he told a foreign visitor that the action represented a posi tive response to Cambodia's appeal for help to restore her neutrality and repel the North Vietnamese and Vietcong in vaders.

title: A:
description: ANTHONY W. SHIPPS, Bloomington, Ind., writes: The passage quoted in Ed mund Pendleton's letter to James Madison and queried by A.L.H. on March 29 comes from a metrical version of Psalm XI included in a work first published in 1696, A New Version of the Psalms of David, Fitted to the Tunes Used in Churches, by Nahum Tate and Nicholas Brady.

title: BUSING FOUND AID FOR SEGREGATION
description: ATLANTA, May 2Segrega tionists will assail busing to achieve desegregation, but will often increase it to maintain the racial status quo, the Southern Regional Council has concluded after a study of 10 segregation academies.

title: Clues Sparse in Search for Professor
description: BOULDER, Colo., May 2 The hint of foreign intrigue is gone but the police have made little headway tracing a Uni versity of Colorado associate professor who has been miss ing for more than a year.

title: Students Ask Vote at 18
description: BATON ROUGE, La., May 2 (UPI)Student leaders from Louisiana college campuses met this weekend in the stale capi tal to push for legislation to allow 18yearolds to vote. The students are members of the Louisiana Intercollegiate State ??

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 games series)

title: CENTRAL OFFICE DIRECTS THE WAR
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2 If allied troops catch Pham Hung or any other top enemy leaders at the mysteryshroud ed headquarters known as the Central Office for South Viet nam during their current sweep across the Cambodian border, analysts of Communist affairs here will be very surprised.

title: Anne Horton Engaged to Robert Ladau
description: Miss Anne Marie Horton, who is with Adventures Un limited at Abercrombie & Fitch, plans to be married on May 30 to Robert F. Ladau, an architectural consultant here.

title: Pilar Suffers Fracture From Spill in Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 Hector Pilar, the rider of Holy Land in today's Ken tucky Derby, was in Sts. Mary and Elizabeth Hospital tonight with a compress frac ture of the first lumbar ver tebra and a possible fracture of the fifth vertebra.

title: THE BIG TEN OFF BROADWAY
Strip Mining Held Nuisance
description: HINDMAN, Ky., May 2 (AP) Knott County Fiscal Court adopted a resolution today de claring strip mining to be a public nuisance and against public policy.

title: Point of View
description: INDUSTRIALIZED housing is in again. Many large corporations have been stimulated and motivated by Secretary Romney's much publicized program Operation Breakthrough as a way of producing housing on a mas sive scale. They have teamed up with housing specialists to produce factory fabricated units via the systems ap proach. The Housing and Ur ban Development Agency, which Mr. Romney leads, will spend about $40million to initiate this program.

title: Klein Reports Heavy Support For Nixon on Cambodia Action
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The White House communications director, Herbert G. Klein, said today that the American peo ple overwhelmingly supported the forays into Cambodia and that the media's emphasis on criticism gives a misimpres sion.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1DENIS CAMERON

title: Miss Patricia Brown Fiancee of a Lawyer
description: CHAGRIN FALLS, Ohio, May 2 Miss Patricia Ann Brown of Boston, assistant to the manager of the college di vision of Little, Brown & Co., publishers, will be married Sept. 5 in Cleveland to James. Arthur Stiaraf, a lawyer of Cambridge, Mass.

title: Speaking of Commonplace Books
description: A fascinating literary form that has shown up intermittently over the past century is the commonplace book. Commonplace is not the best word for a book whose contents are usu ally far from commonplace. The quickest definition of the genre is an annotated personal anthology.

title: Tourism Goes to College
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  A dozen universities around the country are now training future genera tions of executives for the travel industry, executives who may never be able to boast that they started their ca reers washing dishes, smashing baggage or hustling ice water.

title: Explanations Leave Auto Race Telecast in Mixup
description: A PLAGUE o' both your houses: We still have not heard the last of that unfortunate telecast of the Alabama 500 stockcar race at Talladega. In the closing minutes, as you may recall, the A.B.C. Sports announcers Bill Flemming and Keith Jack son reported the official scor ers of the Na tional Association for Stock Car Auto Racing were uncertain wheth er the leader was Pete Hamilton or Bobby Isaac. Twice they said the scorers were in debate. At the end Flemming and Jackson osten tatiously avoided committing themselves until they saw the checkered flag given to Ham ilton. The next dayApril 13 Bill France, the president of NASCAR, telephoned an A.B.C. vice president to say he regretted the lastminute mixup.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Francesca E. Farr Is Fiancee Of Prescott Sheldon Bush 3d
description: CARMEL, Calif., May 2 Miss Francesca Emerson Farr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fredrick Sharon Farr, and the late Mrs. Janet Haskins Farr and Prescott Sheldon Bush 3d plan to be married here on June 27.

title: Nuclear Waste Site Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Federal Water Quality Ad ministration has recommended removal of a nuclear waste burial ground in Idaho, Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, reported Friday.

title: Jane A. Towne To Be Married To Clair Martin
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 2 Mr. and Mrs. James Thomp son Towne of Darien and West Hartford, Vt., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ab bott Towne, to Clair Joseph Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clair John Martin of River Vale, N. J.

title: Child to Mrs. Waldron
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Waldron on April 20 in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Wal dron is the former Miss Pamela Labouchere, daughter if Mrs. Pratt Labouchere of Wilton, Conn., and. Robert E. Labouchere of Paris and Ge neva. The child, who is a granddaugther also of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood Waldron of New York and Locust Val ley, L. I., is named Caroline Whitney. Her father is presi dent of F. C. Waldron & Co., investment managers.

title: Japan Steps Up Sales to Europe
description: PARISTo reduce what many Japanese fear may be an overdependence on the United States market. Japan has started a commercial in vasion of Western Europe that is already making pro found changes in world trade patterns.

title: Nixon Makes a Fateful Indochina Decision
description: WASHINGTONThe question that disinterested observers car ried in their minds as Richard M. Nixon began last year to come to grips with the Vietnam War was whether, in the end, his polit ical appreciation of the rising discontent in the nation would prove more persuasive than his residual views as a cold warrior and his longheld convictions about the strategic necessity of the war effort.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MAY 3, 1970

title: A Prosperous Future Is Seen for Iranian Province
description: ANDIMISHK, Iran, April 26  When the Shah of Iran talks about the development of Khuzistan, Iran's southwest ern province, his eyes light up and he raises his voice. Here was the birthplace of Pertian civilization, he said in a recent interview. He added:

title: A quill pen in the morning, a sixshooter in the afternoon
description: In the mid1920's, when Florence, Italy, was a center for literary ex patriates second only to Paris, the American writer Frederick Faust set tled there with his family in a 22 room villa surrounded by seven acres of olive trees. Aldous Huxley lived nearby; so did D. H. Lawrence. Ken neth Clark, Janet Flanner and Leonard Bacon came to dinner. The Fausts lived on a grand scale with the help of 10 servants, one of whom called for his master at the tennis court every afternoon at 4:30 on a motor cycle. The climb back was strenuous, and Faust, who had a fibrillating heart, and took digitalis in his orange juice at breakfast, roared up to his villa on the pillion.

title: Sirmione's Secret Revealed in Verse Of Poet Catullus
description: SIRMIONE, ItalyRuins the world over evoke a sustained mood of mys tery, an aura that hints of events long forgotten and deeds untold. So it is here in Lombardy for those who visit the ruins of Sirmione's an cient villa.

title: BERLINERS IGNORE HITLER'S LAST DAY
description: BERLIN, May 2  Twenty five years ago this week, two Soviet sergeants hoisted the hammer and sickle above the Reichstag here.

title: Can the Mark II Sing Happy Birthday?
description: IN a tiny room crowded with electronic equipment that virtually surrounded him, composer Mario Davidowsky was at work on a new piece. What was the next step?

title: M.I.T. CREW WINS NAVY GETS TROPHY
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 2  The Massachusetts Institute of Technology edged Navy, by onethird of a length today in the varsity race of the Rusty Callow Memorial Cup light weight regatta on the Schuykill. Penn, the favorite, finished third, two lengths back of Navy.

title: ARMY OVERRULES POLLUTION CURBS
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., May 2 The Department of the Army has overruled stringent new water pollution controls that a Federal agency had recom mended for a large DDT plant operated by the Olin Chemical Corporation at the Army's Red stone Arsenal.

title: Emigrant Prefers Bird
description: CANTERBURY, England (Ca nadian Press)Miss Elizabeth Coogan, 38 years old, set out to emigrate to Australia, but flew back from Sydney because her budgereegah Bonnie was put off the plane at Hong Kong. She picked up the bird on the return flight and brought her pet back to England.

title: Sihanoak's Son Leaves Hong Kong for China
description: HONG KONG, May 2 (Reu tersPrince Norodom Yuva neath, son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cam bodian Chief of State, left Hong Kong today for Com munist China.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: A levellingoff trend con tinues to be evident in the retail sales picture. Depart ment stores for the week ended last Saturday regis tered a 5 per cent gain over the level of sales in the cor responding week of the year before. Total retail sales were 4 per cent higher.

title: For Young Readers
description: Ruth Kirk's Desert Life is a straightforward introduction to the plants and animals of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. Color photographs (rather drably re produced) by the author and her husband, and a deceptively simple text impart a surprising amount of engaging information about pack rats, peccaries, ring tail cats, joshua trees, saguaro cactus, kangaroo rats and kit foxes. Having caught her read ers' attention with photogenic creatures and their habitat, Mrs. Kirk offers a useful ele mentary lesson in patterns of feeding and growth. An appeal ing, matteroffact book.

title: DYCE SHOWS WAY AT RELAY GAMES
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 2The first Saturday in May is rapid ly becoming Byron Dyce's Run for the Roses. For the second straight year, the Jamaica Olympian from New York re ceived the outstanding athlete award of the Ouantico Relays.

title: It's Hard to Despise Victorian Houses Anymore
description: IT MAY come as a surprise to the splitlevel dweller in Peapack and else where that the singlefamily American house is considered by experts to be one of the most noteworthy contibutions to architectural history. Well, maybe not exactly today's splitlevel. According to the historian Vincent Scully and other authorities the great age of American home build ing came to an end about the time of World War I.

title: Jane Nan Lisman to Marry Aug. 12
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jack Victor Lisman of New York have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Nan Lisman, to Robert James Katz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Katz, also of this city.

title: Walinsky Urges State Inquiry Of Police Corruption Charges
description: Adam Walinsky, Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to order Attorney General Louis J. Lef kowitz to start a state investi gation into charges of corrup tion in the New York City Police Devartment.

title: Which Is the Burma Road Ne Win or U Nu?
description: HIGH in the green, junglecov ered mountains of Southeast Asia, in the wild, all but im penetrable country on the frontier between Thailand and Burma, there are bands of armed men in rebellion against the Government in Rangoon. They live in remote camps; to reach them you must hike upwards for hour upon hour, or ride the ragged, sure footed Chinese ponies of the hills. An invitation is necessary, for there is no law to protect you in these regions. The woods are so thick you cannot even see the man who has you in the sights of his carbine.

title: Wall St. Chief Takes Command
description: While the stock market was tumbling last week and Wall Street's financial dis tress was deepening, a plush beigecarpeted office on the sixth floor of the New York Stock Exchange became a securities in dustry command post.

title: PRINCETON DOWNS PENN, 43 AND 10
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 2 Ray Huard pitched a threehit, 10 shutout today as Princeton scored a doubleheader sweep over the University of Penn sylvania. The Tigers won the first game, 43, on Bill Binder's pinch single in the seventh inning.

title: Braniff Opens Jetrail to Speed Dallas Passengers
description: DALLAS, May 2  A new monorail system called Jet rail, designed to separate an airline passenger from his car and baggage at a satellite parking terminal and deliver him relaxed and on time at the waiting door of his air craft, has been installed by Braniff International at Love Field.

title: South America's Kennel Clubs Helped by Airborne Advocate
description: THE peripatetic Dr. Antonio Barone Forzano is a Brazilian veterinarian and physician. He is also presi dent of the Brazil Kennel Club and one of eight allround judges in the South American nation.

title: Challenge Shaping Up Over President's Power
description: WASHINGTONShortly after the Pentagon announced last week that the United States was supporting a South Vietnamese incursion Into Cambodia, Sena tor Norris Cotton, a conserva tive Republican from New Hampshire, met Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee, In a Senate elevator. Bring that repealer of the Tonkin Gulf Resolution out, Bill, Senator Cotton said in indignation over the announcement, and I will vote for it.

title: Stamps
description: EXPO 70, the interna tional fair at Osaka, Japan, has not been overlooked postally. Japan, of course, issued stamps for the occasion, as did the United Nations and Canada, and all have been reported in these columns.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercialagricultural loans, carloadings, steel, oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding and latest available. *000 omitted.

title: Bread winners
description: Bread must come in more shapes and flavors than any other food. The two recipes given here are for loaves that were favorites of the early settlers who pushed our fron tiers westward. Sour dough starter was one of the most valuable supplies carried on the covered wagons. Saltris ing bread was the pioneer cook's choice when no fresh yeast was available.

title: Big O a Knick? It might Have Been
description: Would the Knicks have been willing to trade Cazzie Russell and Dave Stallworth for Oscar Robertson?

title: Photography
description: TOWARD the end of the 18th century, philos ophers and estheti cians were dividing ev erything into the Sublime and the Beautiful. It is a distinc tion worth remembering when looking at the old pho tographs of New York City now on display at The Pic ture Decorator, 740 Madison Avenue at 64th Street. Be cause whatever New York may be when dreams come true, it is not now and prob ably never has been beautiful. The Beautiful, said Edmund Burke, Immanuel Kant, and a host of lesser fry, evokes feelings of harmony and re pose. The Beautiful is neat, bright, orderly, and on a human scale. The Sublime, on the other hand, is vast, im measurable, astonishing, ter rifying, and fills the mind, wrote Burke, with a delight ful horror. The Parthenon is beautiful. So is a portrait by Raphael, a Mozart symphony, a Balanchine ballet. The Alps are sublime. So is Michel angelo's Last Judgment, the last quartets of Beetho ven, and (I hope I am not being facetious) the recent works of Merce Cunningham.

title: 54th Pulitzer Prize Winners Will Be Announced Tomorrow
description: Nearly 1,200 entries have been submitted for the 54th annual Pulitzer prizes in jour nalism, letters, drama and mu sic. Winners are to be an nounced tomorrow by Andrew W. Cordier, president of Co lumbia University.

title: U.N. TOLD BAHRAIN SEEKS TO BE FREE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2  Secretary General Thant has notified the Security Council that the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Bahrain wishes to be a fully independent and sovereign state when it ceases to be a British protectorate next year.

title: Colon Anchors Power Memorial to Distance Meddley Mark in New York Relays
description: Tony Colon, who has no show business ambitions, put on a great act yesterday during the anchor mile leg of the di stance medley at the fifth an nual New York Relays in Downing Stadium.

title: Mantle Chain's Losses
description: DALLAS, May 2 (AP)Mickey Mantle's, a restaurant chain that bears the name of the former New York Yankees base ball star, lost $1,279,777 in 1969. Reporting this Wednes day, Roy J. True, president of the Dallasbased concern, at tributed the bulk of the loss to the process of changing the or iginal country cooking concept to one of wider appeal. Mr. True said this would involve the disposal of a number of the chain's restaurants.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 350.6 from 348.5 a week earlier. A year ago it was 336.7.

title: Soviet Pilots Mean Peril for Israel
description: JERUSALEMA dramatic an nouncement at dawn last Wed nesday that Soviet pilots were flying operational missions over the United Arab Republic brought a flood of memories to Israelis nearly three years after the June, 1967, war.

title: Chess
description: THESE days, any runofthemill amateur knows enough opening theory not to be bowled over by a fast, brilliant mating attack springing from the debut. Perhaps this is the reason for the rare appearance of the King's Gambit, the Evans Gambit or the Danish Gambit in serious play.

title: Miss Crane Fiancee Of Burton Solomon
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., May 2Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hite have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan M. Crane, to Burton Solo mon, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Solomon of New York A June wedding is planned.

title: Warren Sees U.S. in Peril
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (UPI) Former Chief Justice Earl Warren says America has been brought to the brink of immin ent peril by the divisive force of racism. He made the com ment when he was presented the Philadelphia Fellowship Commission's National Fellow ship Award Thursday.

title: Nigerian Red Cross to Transfer Relief Operation to Government
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 2The Nigerian Red Cross Society, which has been feeding millions of refugees in the territory that was Biafra, announced today that it was ending the opera tion, and relinquishing respon sibility to Government agencies.

title: New York, N.Y.
description: In a statewide poll taken a little more than a month ago, 63 per cent of the enrolled Dem ocrats questioned could not name even one of their party's candidates for United States Senator  and few politicians think the people of New York are much more aware of the Senate race right now, with six weeks to go before the June 23 primary election.

title: Rep. Lowenstein Honored By Notre Dame's Seniors
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 2 Representative Allard K. Lowen stein, Democrat of Nassau Coun ty, L. L, an outspoken opponent of the Vietnam war, has been selected as the 1970 senior class Fellow at the University of Notre Dame.

title: ELIZABETH SEEKS SOCCER CUP TODAY
description: Croatia of Los Angeles, member of the California Soc cer Association, will try to take the United States Challenge Cup West today. The prize has been held by an Eastern club the last six years.

title: Old Flushing Field May Dive or Soar
description: Flushing Airport in Queens a field that opened to gen eral aviation the year after Charles Lindbergh flew the Atlanticis facing a tantaliz ing future.

title: Q:
description: Questions of literary interest should be addressed: Queries Editor, The New York Times Book Review, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036, and accompanied by a stamped, selfaddressed envelope. The editor will publish those of greatest interest. Others are answered by letter.

title: City Council to Hold Hearings On Use of Narcotics in Schools
description: Chargingthat drugs could be bought as easily as candy bars in most school play grounds and that education officials were turning their backs on the problem, the chairman of the City Council's Health and Education Commit tee announced yesterday that hearings on drug addiction in city schools had been sched uled for Thursday.

title: Advertising:
description: Late this month 20 million aboveaverageincome homes in the United States will re ceive a little booklet entitled Homemaking With a Flair. To most of them it will prob ably be just another piece of directmail advertising, even though it is rather handsome graphically and contains ads and centsoff coupons from some of the nation's betterknown pack agegoods companies as well as a selection of recipes.

title: Churches Feel Pressure of Women's Rights Drive
description: American churches are be ginning to come under pres sure from women who are de manding changes in policies and doctrines that they say place them in subordinate roles.

title: Article 4  No Title
Students at Columbia Undertake Programs on Narcotics Problems
description: Students at Columbia Uni versity have undertaken edu cational and rehabilitational programs in response to what many feel is a growing nar cotics problem at the univer sity.

title: AIMS EXPLAINED BY MORGENTHAU
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, one of three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor, says that he decided to enter the race because he believed the election of Arthur J. Goldberg could lead to in efficiency in state government, or possibly corruption.

title: BRUINS AND BLUES OPEN SERIES TODAY
description: ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) Boston's bruising Bruins, led by Bobby Orr, open the Stanley Cup playoff fourofseven series of the National Hockey League tomorrow against the St. Louis Blues.

title: EXGOV. HODGES AIDS A DRIVE FOR ISLAND
description: WINSTON  SALEM, N. C. May 2 (AP)Gov. Robert W Scott has turned to Nortl Carolina's widely respectec elder statesman, former Gov Luther H. Hodges, to raise the money needed to acquire ?? Head Island for the state in stead of letting private de velopers get it.

title: A Dead Style? Bluhm Seems Not To Have Heard
description: NORMAN BLUHM'S show at the Martha Jackson Gallery is his first In New York in nearly a decade, but, styl istically, his last show could almost have been yesterday. Just about alone among those painters touted, during the late 1950's  and thereafter mostly scornedas the sec and generation of Abstract Expressionism, Bluhm has re tained throughout the lean years an undiminished enthu siasm for the slash and splash of what Harold Rosenberg called Action Painting. It nay have helped that his rep utation never underwent the eclipse in Europe that it did here, and that he has contin ued to show frequently in Paris, but one must marvel at the sustained energy of his commitment, resistant at once to the succeeding waves of 60's fashions and to any mellowing process born of personal change.

title: Southern Integrationists Feel Betrayedby the North
description: ATLANTA.

title: Strange Way of Protecting Cambodian Neutrality
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia  Ad vising the Cambodian Govern ment slightly later than it did the world at large, the United States has intervened in this country to attack the North Viet namese and Vietcong in their sanctuaries.

title: Dot took her fun where she found it
description: A fine novel is a dangerous thing. It makes one impatient with all the talk, however gen uine, about the crisis of con fidence, the crisis of language, the crisis of character. It makes one realize that the novel's most traditional elements, the telling of the tale, the limning of character, the classic social settings and their attendant at mosphere, the unavoidable and sooftenboring sex scenes can be revolutionized when they are communicated in a lan guage that is just right, a lan guage that both describes and transcends these elements. Why dangerous? Because when it comes alongas it has in Paul West's new novelit looks so easy that one feels like blaming all the other novelists who don't wait until their material has found its right language:

title: National Insurance Of Health Backed By Panel's Report
description: The American Assembly is sued a report yesterday that called for a national health in surance plan.

description: WAREHOUSE SALE

title: List of Forthcoming Entertainment Benefit Parties
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:

title: Dance at City Museum to Benefit Theater Collection
description: Guests at a supper dance at the Museum of the City of New York on Thursday will be able to view five days before the public opening an exhibition of stage costumes and accessories dating from 1870 through the current Broadway season.

title: Israel Honors Nazi Victims
description: TEL AVIV, May 2 (Reuters) Memorial services were held throughout Israel tonight for six million Jews killed by the Nazis during World War Movie houses and many public places were closed. Two min utes of silence will he observed throughout the country tomor row morning to mark Holocaust Remembrance Day, followed by a ceremony in Jerusalem.

title: Williams College Letter
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 2The board Of trustees of Williams College has written a letter to the hoard of directors of the General Motor Corpora tine, naming G. M. as a major polluter of the environment.

title: Article 8  No Title
Mississippi Agency Votes for a TV Ban On Sesame Street
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 2  The State Commission for Edu cational Television has vetoed the showing of Sesame Street, regarded as one of the leading preschool educational tele vision series, on the state ETV system because of racial grounds.

title: Recommended New Titles
description: ALEXANDER POPE: THE EDUCATION OF A GENIUS, by Peter Quen nell. (Stein & Day, $2.95.) The first 40 years of the diminutive, crook back poet who dominated Queen Anne's London sympathetically portrayed in a firstrate literary biography.

title: HAITIANS DESCRIBE CONSPIRACY ROLE
description: MIAMI, May 2Haitian coast guardsmen who arrived today from Puerto Rico indicated that the recent shelling of Portau Prince was part of a larger but unsuccessful militarycivilian plot to overthrow President Frangois Duvalier. They are seeking political asylum in the United States.

title: Missile Plans Opposed
description: BOSTON, May 2 (AP)  The Massachusetts Senate passed a resolution Thursday calling on Congress to halt expansion of the antiballistic missile system.

title: U.S. Business:
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 2Some aspects of Pennsylvania's economy are showing signs of de terioration, according to busi ness analysts at the Pennsyl vania State University.

title: $350Million Airport Planned In St. Louis Metropolitan Area
description: ST. LOUIS, May 2  Gov, Richard B. Ogilvie of Illinois and Mayor Alfonso J. Cer vantes of St. Louis have an nounced plans to develop $350million major airport on the east side of the metropoli tan area.

title: BEEF CURB STIRS ARGENTINE CRISIS
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 27  Argentines will tolerate any thing, it has long been said here, as long as they can have firstclass beefsteaks and soccer teams.

title: A sort of Anzac Peter Ibbetson and family
description: Janet Frame is a New Zealand novelist and poet who is not well known in this country and whose eighth novel, Intensive Care, is unlikely to win her many new con verts among the novelreading public. The book is sprawling and inverte brate, overwritten at times in a vein of capricious prosepoetry and actual poetry, indifferent to problems of construction and coherence raised by its episodic, disjunctive plot, simplis tic and even careless with respect to the moral issues the lives of its prin cipal characters fitfully reflect. Al though it is arranged in three parts and employs the services of five nar rators, these compositional tactics re main pro forma and never work to gether to create form and a control ling perspective upon a world one can take seriously.

title: A mix of jargon, camp and verbal play
description: It is probably a mistake to read The OmniAmericans straight through, as I did. It's just too much. Its style, characterized by an unrestrained use of coordinate phrases and modifiers and long, loose sentences, is difficult. Though basically simple, the subject matter is made subtle. And the author's rhetoric is a dense mixture of pseudoscientific academic jargon, camp idiom, and verbal play. The book is just too much for the av erage reader to take in one uninter rupted dose.

title: News of the Rialto
description: ANOTHER chapter, this one perhaps the last, may be in store for The Girl Upstairs, a musical on which Stephen Sondheim and James Good man seem to have been work ing for ages and which pro ducers have flocked to only to retreat from for assorted reasons. Harold Prince thinks he'll be writing a different ending.

title: GIANTS' 2 HOMERS ROUT PHILLIES, 71
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (UPI)  Willie McCovey drove in four runs with a homer and a double and Dick Dietz added three more with a homer today as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Philadelphia Phil lips. 71.

title: FOR THE LORELEI: INCREASED LURE?
description: BONN, May 2  Lorelei, that elusive Rhine maiden whose golden tresses and plain tive voice have lured so many unlucky boatmen to the bottom of the river over the centuries, may soon be committed to stone or neon light or some other sculptured or fabricated, splendidly visible form.

title: Bhutan to Seek U.N. Seat
description: THEVIPU, Bhutan, May 2 (Reuters)The tiny Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan will apply to join the United Nations this year, King Jigme Dorji Wang chuk has announced. Bhutan, an independent state between India and Tibet, is guided by the Indian Government in con ducting its foreign relations. year, King Jigme Dorji Wang chuk has announced. Bhutan, an independent state between India and Tibet, is guided by the Indian Government in con ducting its foreign relations.

title: Kennedy: How Bad Is the Political Damage?
description: WASHINGTONLast Wednes day was to have been the day when the cloud lifted over Ed ward Moore Kennedy, the cloud that had shadowed both his pub lic and personal life since the dark midnight last July when Mary Jo Kopechne drowned off Chappaquiddick Island in the car he had driven off Dike Bridge.

title: Philadelphia Judge Convicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) Common Pleas Court Judge Stanley M. Greenberg has been found guilty by a Federal court jury of conspiring to defraud in a checkkiting scheme. He was acquitted Wednesday of 20 counts in a 21count indict ment. The other counts in volved use of the mails to de fraud. Judge Greenberg faces a maximum sentence of five years in jail and a $5,000 fine.

title: Nevada G.O.P. Gets Senate Candidate
description: RENO, Nev., May 2District Attorney William Raggio of Reno, saying he was respond ing to the call of President Nix on, announced today that he would run for the Senate on the Republican ticket.

title: MARGIN 5 LENGTHS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 Dust Commander earned the biggest trophy in American thoroughbred racing for his big gamehunting owner, Robert Lehmann, today.

title: Stewart Sets Trial Mark
description: OYAMA, Japan, May 2 (AP) Jackie Stewart of Scotland, the reigning world auto dirving champion, set a track record today and won the pole position for tomorrow's Grand Prix at the Fuji international Speed way. In time trials, Stewart covered the 3.72mile track in 1 minute 49 seconds, the fast est time ever on the course for a Formula One racer.

title: Recordings
description: SOMETIME after Claude Debussy had put his ineradicable stamp upon the evolution of Western music, he was asked what he thought the music of the future would be. He answered the ques tion with a statement some thing like this: It wil be what the next genius makes it.

title: ITALIAN REDS TERM CHINA THE 3D POWER
description: ROME, May 2The doctrinal weekly of the Italian Commu nist party said in an editorial today that Communist China became the third world power, at the side of the United States and the Soviet Union, when it orbited a space satellite eight days ago.

title: Mormons' Book of Abraham Called Product of Imagination
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 The Book of Abraham, which provides the theological basis for the Utah Mormon churches excluding Negroes from it's priesthood, has been described as simply the product of Jo seph Smith Jr.'s imagination by a leading scholar in a branch of the church Mr. Smith founded.

title: Derby Betting Below Mark
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (AP)The mutuel handle on the Kentucky Derby today was $2,383,972, a halfmillion dol lars below the record set in 1969. The total handle for Churchill Downs's 10race card totaled $5,811,127, also short of last year's mark.

title: Royal Visitors in the South Pacific
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH II of Britain, Prince Philip, Prince Charles, heir to the throne, and Prin cess Anne, have been visiting South Pacific Commonwealth areas and it was only natural that stamps were issued to commemorate the occasion.

title: Observer: Ted Agnew at Yale
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Why, you have undoubtedly asked, did Vice President Ag new take it upon himself to urge Yale University last week to fire its president, Kingman Brewster?

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Two large plants are being built for Houbigant Parfums, Inc., and Revlon, Inc., cos metic manufacturers, in New Jersey by the Mack Company, industrial real estate devel oper of Secaucus.

title: Airlines Pressing for CruiseShip Links
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board is facing decisions whether to let United States air carriers branch out into the lucrative operation of foreignflag cruise ships.

title: Pickett Davis Randolph Fiancee of John Hulley
description: BALTIMORE, May 2The engagement of Miss Pickett Davis Randolph to John Charles Lincoln Hulley has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Middleton Elliott Ran dolph, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Benjamin Mayham Hulley, a retired Foreign Service Offi cer, and Mrs. Hulley of Hyan nis, Mass.

title: Bank Embezzling At 20Year High
description: The nation's banks suffered $16.9million of losses from embezzlement last year, the highest level in 20 years, the American Bankers Associa tion reports. The previous peak in the last 20 years was in 1967 when such losses reached $13.7million.

title: Miss Christina Renckens Is Married
description: Miss Christina Cornelia Maria Renckens, an adminis trative assistant with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany, and Hugh Walter Mc Nulty Jr., a lawyer in the tax department of the Singer Company here, were married yesterday in Nijmegen, the Netherlands, where the bride's varents make their home.

title: NERVE GAS SHIFT STIRS NORTHWEST
description: SEATTLE, April 29Last De cember the Army routinely an nounced that It would shift its lethal nerve gas weapons from a base on Okinawa to an ord nance depot in Oregon.

title: Eye and Ear Infirmary to Mark 150th Anniversary With a Ball
description: The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, which boasts of being the first institution for eye care in the West ern Hemisphere, will cele brate its 150th anniversary this week with a Sesquicen tennial Ball and a special cocktail reception.

title: Reed, Despite Damaged Knee, Holds Up as Pressure Grows
description: Since Jerry West's injured thumb limited him to 37 points and 18 assists in the overtime victory the Los An geles Lakers scored Friday night what can the New York Knickerbockers expect from Willis Reed's ailing knee? The fourofseven series for the championship of the National Basketball Association is tied at 22.

title: When is a canal not a canal?; Vinh Long
description: Vinh Long is a province in the central delta of South Vietnam. It is bisected, north to south, by the Mangthit Canal, which links the Mekong and Bassac Rivers, the two major delta waterways. This book tells of the failure of a twoandahalf year campaign to clear the Viet Cong from the banks of the canal so as to reopen it to barges carrying rice to Saigon.

title: Saragat Undergoes Surgery
description: ROME, May 2  President Giuseppe Saragat underwent prostate surgery here today. A statement said that Mr. Sara gat, who is 71 years old, was in good condition.

title: West Point, Old Blue Gain Long Island Rugby Final
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 2 The West Point and Old Blue rugby clubs fought their way into the finals of the Shaefer Bowl tournament at the Hofstra University field today. Army de feated Amherst, 90, and George Washington, 100, while Old Blue defeated Cornell, 270, and the University of Virginia, 253.

title: TYRANT CAPTURES CARTER HANDICAP
description: The white and cherry colors of the Locust Hill Farm were brought into the winners' circle for the second straight year fol lowing a running of the Carter Handicap yesterday as Tyrant outlasted Calumet's Best Turn at Aqueduct.

title: Ban on Saccaharin Urged
description: MADISON, Wis., May 2 (AP) A researcher whose studies helped lead to the banning of cyclamates in food has called for the outlawing of another artificial sweetener, saccharin. Philip H. Derse, president of the Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation, told the Wisconsin Dietetic Association that rats on a saccharin diet were ex periencing the same loss of weight, increase of heart size and decrease of kidney size that rats on A cyclamate diet show.

title: Amphoras, lead anchors and antique coins
description: The message Peter Throck morton, research associate at the University of Pennsylvania Museum, brings us in this, his second book on underwater archeology, is is the nature of warning that the newly sprung art of recovering ancient arti facts from the sea, though hardly 20 years old as a sys tematic discipline, already is in sharp decline.

title: When You Just Give Money To the Poor
description: THEY were living a life of quiet esperation. The husband, 26, tall, very thin, darkhaired, was mired in a poor job; his wife, 22yearold brunette, was small, smiling and gracious. The couple and their children, aged 1 and 2, lived in what the wife accurately described as a dumpa $50amonth apart ment in a downatheels section of grimy Scranton, Pa. Behind it was a grim alleyway; the steps to the tiny back porch were broken; there was no yard in which the children could play; a coal stove in the living room furnished the only heat in their four rooms. In the bitter Pennsyl vania winters, the children suffered colds.

title: Article 1  No Title
Cannon Is Stolen
description: GRAND HAVEN, Mich. (UPI) A 106pound cannon given to the city by Coast Guard festival has been stolen from the City Hall lawn.

title: For U.S. The Pilots Are a Dangerous Challenge
description: From the start, the Nixon Ad ministration has looked upon the Middle East as a crucial testing ground of a postulated Soviet willingness to choose restraint over engagement in local con flicts, with the aim of averting a direct confrontation of the superpowers. It was a week of bad news for those who scruti nize the Kremlin for signs of restraint in the ArabIsraeli con flict.

title: Historic Craft Raised From the Deep
description: WILDWOOD, N.J., May 2 The historic threemasted schooner Atlantic is afloat again, thus ending 6 years in a watery grave at a dock in The Yacht Basin here.

title: BRONX BOMBINGS SCORED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay declared yes terday that no police resource would be spared to find the persons who planted bombs in two Bronx movie theaters Fri day night.

title: Police Advice Is Costly
description: BREDBURY, England (UPI) After thieves robbed his home three times, John Bates followed police advice to trim a tree outside the house so burglars would have less cover. But Mr. Bates was fined on a charge of damaging a tree protected under an 80yearold ministry of housing order.

title: Nathan Stern, Engineer, Dies; Served Board of Education
description: Nathan Stern, a retired civil engineer for the Board of Edu cation, died apparently of a massive stroke yesterday at the Flushing Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 6410C 186th Lane, in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: U.S. Job Adviser Selected
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) The Civil Service Commis sion has announced the selec tion of Helene Sylvia Markoff as Federal equal employment opportunity adviser with re sponsibility for coordinating Federal programs to improve job and promotion opportuni ties for women in government. Miss Markoff has worked 20 years in the Navy Department.

title: YOUNG QUEBECKERS AIDED SEPARATIST
description: MONTREAL, May 2A 21 yearold Frenchspeaking elec tronics technician said this week as he emerged from a polling place in downtown Montreal that he had voted for the Parti Qubeois because it was for change.

title: April, the Cruelest Of Months
description: April is the cruelest month, T. S. Eliot once wrote, and this line of po etry proved an accurate de scription of the stock mar ket in April of 1970.

title: World's Largest Sculpture To Be Dedicated by President
description: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga.The world's largest piece of sculpture, a monument to the Confederacy carved into the face of Stone Mountain, is sched uled to be dedicated here next Saturday by President Nixon. The overall carved area is approximately the size of a football field, and is dominated by the mounted figures of Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson.

title: Dartmouth's Lightweights Outrow Cornell First Time
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 2 Dartmouth's varsity lightweight crew defeated Cornell by a length on Lake Cayuga today. It was the first victory for any Indian boat against the Big Red.

title: U.N. YOUTH ASSEMBLY IS SHORT OF FUNDS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2The World Youth As sembly may be called off unless the funds to pay for it are pro vided before the end of the month.

title: Chargers and Broncos Face Roughest Schedules This Year
description: LIKE many of the coaches but not all, Weeb Ew bank of the Jets was irate when he took a look at the new schedule for pro football next season. The Jets are to play such powerful clubs as the Browns, the Colts twice, the Rams, the Vikings and the Raiders. Ewbank said the schedulemakers in Commissioner Pete Rozelle's of fice had made it hard for the Jets to win the cham pionship. Hold it, Weeb.
