The Jets are not necessarily so bad off and wait until you hear from Charlie Waller of the San Diego Chargers and Lou Saban of the Denver Broncos at the National Foot ball League's coaches meet ing here later this month.

title: SAIGON POLICE USE GAS ON PROTESTERS
description: SAIGON, May 2 (Reuters) The police used tear gas tonight to disperse students demon strating against the treatment of Vietnamese in Cambodia.

title: Nets' Records
MRS. HAROLD A. HATCH
description: Sharon, Conn., May 2 Mrs. Margaret Milliken Hatch, wife of Harold Ames Hatch, re tired executive vice president of Deering, Milliken Inc., tex tiles, died yesterday at her home here. Her age was 89.

title: Title Thistle Sailing Slated for Sound
description: The Thistle Class Association, representing the 3,000 sailors who race the onedesign sloops, has awarded its 25th national championship series to the championship of Long Island Sound. A bid from the Cedar Point Yacht Club of Westpoint, Conn., to hold the nationals during the week of Aug. 16 was approved at the group's recent midwin ter meeting in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Nixon Has Brief Visit With Mrs. Eisenhower
description: THURMONT, Md., May 2 (UPI)President Nixon inter rupted his stay at Camp David today to pay a half hour visit to Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower at Gettyburg, Pa.

title: Letters:
description: I am the president of Joseph H. Cohen & Sons, possibly the largest manufacturer of tailored clothing in the world. I am not an economistI am a theoreti cian, but I do think I am a sound businessman. I see no end to inflation, nor do I see the end of escalatory costs for business, or for the running of city, state and the nation until we have a wage control and a price control.

title: Saigon General Killed In Helicopter Collision
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2 (AP)Maj. Gen. Ngu yen Viet Thanh, commander of the South Vietnamese IV Corps tactical zone, which encompasses the Mekong Del ta, was killed today when his helicopter and a United States helicopter gunship col lided over Cambodia, official sources said.

title: U.N. LEAD URGED k ON ENVIRONMENT
description: An American planner for the United Nations is proposing that the United Nations reorganize its machinery so that it can lead the environmental pa rade.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Broncos Sign Colorado End
description: DENVER, May 2 (AP)The Denver Broncos signed Monte Huber, a pass receiver from the University of Colorado, as a free agent today.

title: SCHOOLLUNCH PLAN EXPANDED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Senate has approved a bill extending free or low price school lunches to more than eight million children from povertylevel families.

title: 40 of 63 on New York Jet Safe in Caribbean Ditching
description: A DC9 jet on a flight from New York to the Caribbean was ditched off St. Croix yes terday with 63 persons aboard. The Coast Guard reported 40 persons rescued last night, seven dead and at least 16 oth ers missing.

title: Pop
description: THE lion's share of the Tony Awards went to Applause, but, on the record, Purlie is, once again, victorious.

title: Insurers Raise Costs To Doctors
description: In San Francisco not too long ago, a woman filed a $1million lawsuit against a doctor on charges that he performed a legal abortion on her but that she gave birth to a baby anyway.

title: Plane Hijacked to Havana Returns Safely to Miami
description: MIAMI, May 2 (UPI)A hi jacked British West Indian Air lines jetliner returned safely to the United States today after a 24hour layover in Havana, where two hijackers tried to force the flight to Africa.

title: L.I.R. UNIONS REQUEST PENSION MEDIATION
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 2  The unions of the Long Island Railroad have asked the National Labor Relations Board to name a mediator for nego tiations with the railroad for improved pensions.

title: JOHNSON ACCUSES SOME OF '63 STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, May 2For mer President Lyndon B. John son has accused some holdover officials of undermining his Administration In the weeks and months after the assassina tion of President Kennedy.

title: LOUIS M. OPPENHEIM
description: MANHASSET, L. I., May 2 Louis M. Oppenheim, founder and retired owner of the Inter state Container Corporation, Glendale, Queens, died yester day in North Shore Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 15 South Drive, Roslyn.

title: Sevareid Urges the Expansion Of TV Network News to Hour
description: A leading television com mentator has proposed that network evening news tele casts be expanded to an hour to provide more balanced cover age and also time for rebuttals by listeners.

title: Susan Weisenberg to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Weisenberg of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Weisenberg, to Kenneth R. Auerbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Auerbach of Rye, N. Y. An August wed ding is planned.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The People Vs. Yosemite: Can Our Parks Be Saved?
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.It is the season when the snows of winter melt in the back country, when swollen rivers send their waters boiling across the rim of the great granite cliffs of Yosemite Falls to plunge, in a roaring, sunspan gled cascade, to the valley floor.

title: Heritage Slightly Damaged in Mishap at Launching in Florida
description: ST PETERSBURG, Fla., May 2An accident during the launching slightly damaged Heritage, Charles Morgan Jr.'s 12Meter America's Cup de fense hopeful today.

title: Urge Nation's Churches To Fight 2 Monsters
description: BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., May 2 (AP)  American churches have been urged at an ecumenical meeting here to use their wealth and nu merical strength to challenge racism and economic inequi ties in modern society and reshape its values.

title: T. N. Rothschild Marries Mary L. Berube
description: Miss Mary Louise Berube, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jo seph H. Berube of Lynn, Mass., was married here yes terday to Thomas N. Roth schild, son of Mrs. Sanford, of New York and Bethel, Conn., and the late Mr. Rothschild.

title: Police Warn Family of 10 In Flat Owned by Columbia
description: A Harlem mother of nine who took over a vacant apart ment of a building owned by Columbia University was warned by the police yesterday she could be arrested for trespassing.

title: 150 Expected to Take Part In Bike Race Uptown Today
description: More than 150 contestants are expected to compete today in the Axel Swenson Memorial bicycle race, sponsored by the Century Road Club Association.

title: AVIGNON SHOWS PICASSO'S WORKS
description: AVIGNON, France, May 1 An entire year's output of paintings and drawings by Pablo Picasso went on display today in this sunny southern city.

title: Inquest: Its Author Speaks For It
description: AT THE Music Box each night near the end of Inquest, hot lights flash from the stage, blinding the eyes of the audi ence. Then the lights go dim as Julius Rosenberg is pro nounced dead, electrocuted at Sing Sing on June 19, 1953. A moment later his wife Eth el is electrocuted. The Rosen bergs had been convicted of conspiring to steal atomic se crets for the Soviet Union.

title: A peephole in apartheid
description: There is some similarity be tween a confidence game and a novel: both depend, we know, on a willing suspension of dis beliefe.g., the case of Dug more Boetie, a black South Afri can who died in 1966 unknown and very nearly unmourned be yond his immediate family, who lived in a world in which anonymity was not just a fate but a legal condition, and self.

title: Joanna Bailie Married Here
description: Miss Joanna dePeyster Bailie and Warren Martin Gunderson were married here yesterday afternoon. Civil Court Judge Edward Goodell performed the ceremony at the bride's apartment.

title: THE BIG TEN
Talbot Perkins's Party
description: The Talbot Perkins's Chil dren's Services will give its 19th annual Mother's Day luncheon on Thursday in the Plaza's Terrace Room. Tick ets are $12.50 each and may be obtained at the nonsec tarian voluntary agency at 147 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

title: Kuha of Finland Captures AllJapan Steeplechase
description: TOKYO, May 2 (AP)Jouke Kuha of Finland, the world record holder, outraced 21 Japanese and won the 3,000 meter steeplechase today at the AllJapan track and field meet.

title: Inquest: Kerr Votes Against It
description: TNQUEST is unpersua sive even when it cheats, and to my mind it finally calls into questionand perhaps throws out of court altogetherthe whole possibility of a Theater of Fact. Donald Freed's frag mented reconstruction of the trial of Julius and Ethel Ro senberg, recently and well mounted at the Music Box, of course intends to plead the Rosenbergs' innocence of the charge of conspiring to steal atomic secrets. That is understood and accepted be fore enter the theater. But it does not mean to make a stump speech or to use fic tion, rhetoric, or stage melo drama to do the job. It purports to base its plea upon the record and upon nothing but the record so that, listen ing to the evidence offered, we shall be able to arrive at a valid judgment out front. It is here that the occasion explodes in our faces.

title: ARMY IS WINNER IN LACROSSE, 1211
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May Army's lacrosse team elimi nated Maryland from the race for the national championship today, rallying for a 1211 tri umnh before 4.000.

title: Education
description: Spring and rebellion were in the air on the university cam puses last week, and the two are probably not unrelated. The general pattern seems to be to put off major disruptions until enough of the course require ments are completed so that full credit can be expected, strike or no strike.

title: DATING BY COMPUTER NOW USED FOR DOGS
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP)Com puterized dating has gone to the doss.

title: Daniel L. Hasbach Weds Miss Hester L. Bakewell
description: GUILFORD, Conn., May 2 Miss Hester Livingstone Bakewell and Daniel Leon Hasbach, a communications technician, second class, in the Navy, were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Louis M. Hirshon, former dean of Christ Church Ca thedral in Hartford and past president of Hobart College. The Rev. Bradford B. Locke Jr. assisted.

title: A critic hoist by his own petard
description: For some time now, Wilfrid Sheed has been one of our best book and film critics. He has also (as if to keep his hand in) written occasional fic tion, distinguished more by the force of intellect he brings to it than by the force of genera tion. I mean his fiction seems often more thought than felt.

title: 147 Yachts in Bermuda Race
description: A list of entries for the New portBermuda race contained the names of 147 yachts, a fig ure that was likely to change before the start on June 20 be cause of additions and with drawals. The list was of entries to midApril. The total was 20 yachts fewer than the record starting fleet of 1966. There were 151 starters in 1968, the last time the event was held.

title: Despite China's Entry Into Space Age, Industry Is Still Backward
description: HONG KONG, May 2  Though Communist China has officially entered the space age by placing a satellite in orbit around the earth much of the country's industrial machinery is the product of an earlier age.

title: Mrs. Grant Bids Stores Stop Candy Pill Sales
description: Consumer Affairs Commis sioner Bess Myerson Grant has asked city retailers to remove candy pills from their shelves because chil dren should not be encour aged to make a game of pilltaking.

title: SCIENCE ACADEMY ADDS 50 MEMBERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The National Academy of Sciences at its 107th annual meeting here this week announced the election of 50 new members in recognition of their distin guished achievements In re search.

title: Spaced Out by Stanley
description: IN an IND subway station N on the upper West Side, a place so ancient and damp it has its own tiny gray stalactites hanging from the ceiling, there is a sort of house poster for the New York City Transit Authority (Moves Millions) on which one couple has published its bans (Sonia + Wade), and on which a closet revolution ary, a furtive futurist with magic marker pen, has pro claimed: We want anti gravity cars! The wheel is ob solete!

title: Trash Cleanup in Oklahoma
description: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP)  Gov. Dewey Bartlett has sched uled a statwide attack on trash for May 16. Mr. Bartlett pro claimed Environmental Aware ness Day and said he and his wife planned to spend the day picking up trash along country roads around their farm near Grove.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: WALL STREET was plainly and highly nervous last week over the dis couraging performance of the securities markets, the financial health of the invest ment community, the state of the economy and the increasing tension on the inter national scene.

title: Hunt Captures British Golf By Two Strokes With a 271
description: WORTHING, England, May (UPI) Bernard Hunt, posting four birdies on the last five holes of a final round 66, won the Penfold golf tournament to day to register his first major British golf victory in three years.

title: HANDFREE PHONE PERPLEXES USERS
description: Mrs. Benjamin Wisansky of Danbury, Conn., was a little confused when she stepped into the telephone booth and found nothing that she could really get a handle on.

title: Patient of Year Named
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 2 (AP)Darcy Jo Smith, 11 years old, who lost her left arm and left leg in an explosion in Ko rea, has been named Patient of the Year for the nation's 22 Shrine hospitals for crippled children. Darcy is one of three 11yearold Korean children adopted by Mr. and Mrs. De waine Smith of suburban West Linn.

title: Article 7  No Title
Leaders in Dahomey Agree On a Civilian Government
description: COTONOU, Dahomey, May 2 (Reuters)  Former President Hubert Maga has announced that he would head Dahomey's first civilian Government since President EmileDerlin Zinsou was ousted by a military coup last December.

title: ZARCO TRIUMPHS AT GARDEN STATE
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 2 (AP)Watermill Farm's Zarco ended his secondplace jinx and won the $29,925 Valley Forge Handicap at Garden State Park today by half a length.

title: Plymouth (Mass.) Gets With It
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass.By some alchemy that a New England Yankee could understand, but might not be able to explain, the idea of getting behind the celebration of the 350th anni versary of the landing of the Pilgrims seems to be catching fire here at last.

title: Bridge
description: IF one's brakes fail when going downhill it may be necessary to jump out of the car or to steer it off the road. In bridge, as in life, desperate measures may be needed for survival: resigning oneself to the inevitable never made anyone a win ner.

title: LOCAL BOARDS DUE FOR MORE POWER IN SCHOOL AFFAIRS
description: The Board of Education is taking steps to give the city's locally elected community school boards a voice in col lective bargaining matters, in cluding the current negotiations with the teacheraides, and in other school issues.

title: Burtis and Isdale Score Triumphs In Yacht Racing
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 2 Alan Burtis of Sea Cliff Yacht Club sailed Gauchero to victory on Long Island Sound today in the first race of the annual Western L.I.S. Star Class eyeopener series, and George M. Isdale Jr. of Ameri can Y.C. won with Rampant in the season's first Etchells22 Class race.

title: Trinidad Hanover Wins Great Lullwater Trot on Late Rally and Pays $17.80
description: YONKERS, May 2Trinidad Hanover, a Star's PrideTrinket Hanover trotter, who in less than a year has advanced from Class C1 to the junior freefor all plateau, was the surprise winner of $12,500 Great Lull water Trot tonight before 27, 593 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

title: COLLEGE TO ALLOW CHICAGO 7 VISIT
description: DURHAM, N, H., May 2The president of the University of New Hampshire announced to day that three of the defend ants in the Chicago 7 conspira cy trial would be allowed to speak on the Durham campus Tuesday despite opposition from the State House of Repre sentatives.

title: TRADE MAK WINS IN JUMPING CLASS
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 2Trade Mark, owned by Mrs. Linda Wycoff of Kingston, N. J., and handled by Tony Pettit, took a narrow lead for the jun ior jumper championship today during the second session of the 19th annual Junior Essex Troop horse show.

title: STANDARD POODLE IS BEST IN SHOW
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., May 2 Alekai Flowers of Mayfair, 19monthold white standard poodle owned by Mr. and Mrs. Terrance Levy of Huntington, L. I., and handled by Wendell J. Sammet, won bestinshow honors in a field of 2,157 dogs today at the 29th annual Bucks County Kennel Club event.

title: The World
description: CONTINUED

title: COLUMBIA'S CREW BEATS RUTGERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 2Columbia took a slight lead during a turn in the Raritan River at the 700meter mark today and held on to defeat the Rutgers heavyweight crew by half a length. The Lions cov ered the 2,000 meters in minutes 8 seconds to 6:10.1 for the Scarlet.

title: Cleaning Out a Sanctuary Is Not an Easy Task
description: The foray last week of Ameri can and South Vietnamese forces into Cambodia is unlikely, in the view of qualified sources, to have in itself more than a transi tory effect on, the course of the war.

title: DETERGENTS LISTED IN PHOSPHATE ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) The Government has identi fied 22 laundry and dishwash ing products it said contain pollution  causing phosphates and urged their manufacturers to promptly reduce or eliminate the phosphate content.

title: DRIFTER WITH KNIFE SLAIN BY POLICEMAN
description: A 42  year  old drifter was shot and killed in Brooklyn by a foot patrolman at midnight Friday, when he allegedly tried to attack the policeman with an eightinch clasp knife.

title: Copy of an Old Hawaiian Plantation Railroad to Begin Its 6Mile Run Saturday on the Island of Maui
description: The nation's newest railroad has a picturesque name not quite as long as its sixmile route and features gaudy turn ofthecenturystyle steam loco motives with funnelshaped smokestacks and teakwood cabs.

title: L. I. Cancer Unit to Gain
description: LIDO BEACH, L. I., May 2 The fifth annual luncheon, fashion show for the benefit of the American Cancer Soci ety; Nassau Division, will be held on Tuesday at noon at Carl Hoppl's here.

title: A.D.A. Asks Defense Slash
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Americans for Democratic Ac tion called today for a $34bil lion slash in the military budget by eliminating all major new weapons systems.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today Trenton Kennel Club allbreed show, Washington Crossing, State Park, Bear Tavern Road, Route 59, Washington Crossing, N. J.; 3,614 entries; 8 A.M.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: New YorkRodrigo Valdez, 156 pounds, Colombia, outpointed Cassius Green, 154, Dal las, 10 rounds.

title: DUST COMMANDER TAKES $170,300 KENTUCKY DERBY; YANKEES BEAT BREWERS, 76
description: The big home run glistening in the afternoon sun.

title: Prices Continue Drop On Amex and Counter
description: Most issues traded on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market continued to retreat last week in steppedup trad ing.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BALTIMORE, May 2 (AP) The Baltimore Police Commis sioner opened a drive against terrorist literature encouraging the assassination of policemen.

title: Papa Doc Hexes Another Haitian Rebellion
description: WASHINGTON  Springtime in Haiti brings a shock of red flowered African tulip trees against the green hills, migrating flocks of doves, Caribbean tour ists, and an annual political mini crisis for President Francois Du valier.

title: Margaret Schmitt Wed to L. J. Sterba
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., May 2  Miss Margaret L. Schmitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius H. Schmitt of Franklin Lakes, was mar ried here today to Leonard J. Sterba, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Sterba of Rye, N. Y.

title: Reader's Report
description: If the drug scene is as ex citing as depicted in this novel by Robert Stone Pry or (a pseudonym!), sarsapa rilla is due for a comeback as a stimulant. Like nothing, man. Cold Iron is the name of a rock group whose success is endangered by the tendency of its baritone, big Jim O'Leary,

title: An Anonymous Briefer Loses Some Anonymity
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  Government officials who brief reporters under an agreement of anonymity oc casionally risk exposure.

title: Smith, Ashe, Lutz, Graebner Again Named to 7Man U.S. Davis Cup Squad
description: CLEVELAND, May 2  Stan Smith and Arthur Ashe, whose two singles victories apiece led the successful defense of the Davis Cup last year, headed the, sevenman 1970 United States squad named today by Edward A. Turville, the new noriplaying captain.

title: Flat Yucatan Countryside Belies Merida's Vitality
description: MERIDA, Mexico  Could there have been a mistake? Had the plane been hijacked and was landing now somewhere out side of Mexico? The thought faded quickly as we rolled to a stop, but that it had occurred at all reminded me again of how different Merida and Yu catan are from other Mexican cities and states.

title: Galbraith: '29 Repeats Itself Today
description: BOSTONJohn Kenneth Gailbraith, who usually needs no prompter to play Cas sandra, warned last week that the insan ity of 1929 was repeating itself.

title: New Plants Announced In Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va., April 25 Fortyeight announcements of new plants and expansions came in Virginia during the first quarter, the state's Divi sion of Industrial Develop ment has reported.

title: The Times Opens Annual Plea For Fresh Air Fund Donations
description: Today marks the opening of The New York Times fourth annual appeal for The Fresh Air Fund, one of the city's old est youthserving philanthro nies.

title: All TV for Fifth Game Is on Closed Circuit
description: The fifth game of the Na tional Basketball Association playoffs between the New York Knicks and Los Angeles Lakers, at Madison Square Garden tomorrow at 7:35 P.M., will be shown on closed circuit theater television at Manhattan Center, 34th Street near Eighth Avenue, and by Manhattan Cable Television to its subscribers on Channel 6. It will be broadcast by WHN Radio.

title: Frank J. Lucia Is Dead at 58; ExCommissioner of Sanitation
description: Former Sanitation Com missioner Frank J. Lucia died Wednesday of a heart attack at the Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 22005 Hillside Avenue, Queens Village, Queens.

title: Nicklaus Leads With 135; Palmer Is 2 Shots Back
description: DALLAS, May 2A Jack NicklausArnold Palmer golf duel swung in favor of Big Jack today. Although he trailed Palmer by one stroke as they started the second round of the $100,000 Byron Nelson Classic, the Columbus, Ohio, pro fessional outscored Palmer, 68 to 71, and assumed the 36 hole lead with an aggregate of 135. Palmer dropped into a secondplace tie with Dan Sikes after a oneoverpar 71 at the Preston Trail Golf Club course brought his twoday total to 137. Although Nick. laus scaled golf heights in 1962 by winning the United States Open after he defeated Palmer in a playoff, and al though he finished onetwo with Palmer in the 1967 Open, seldom have these two ac credited stars been as close in a race on the tour as they were this sunny, cool Texas afternoon.

title: President Pierce's Home In New Hampshire Saved
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 2  Gov. Walter R. Peterson Jr. has signed into law a measure as suring that the home of Frank lin Pierce, the nation's 14th President, will not fall victim to urban renewal.

title: Kathleen Wallis Tener Betrothed
description: Miss Kathleen Wallis Te ner, an economist with the Chase Manhattan Bank, plans to be married on May 30 to Roger Davis Smith, the senior tax partner of the law firm of Jackson, Nash, Brophy, Barringer & Brooks.

title: The Black Man and His Architecture
description: IT becomes increasingly evident that there are as many facets of opinion In the black community as there are in the white community and that no one is going to have a very easy time tying them together in a neat ribbon labeled black powereither to wield, from the community end, or to use, from the government end. The biggest stumbling block for public agencies and pro grams is finding who speaks for whom, and who is repre sentative of what, as if some such magic formula would un lock the answer to the prob lems of the black and the poor.

title: Burma Wins Asian Soccer
description: MANILA, May 2 (AP)  Burma won the 12th Asian Youth soccer championship to night by defeating Indonesia, 30. Burma, which shared last year's championship with Thai land, led, 10, at halftime.

title: Hematologist Is Honored
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 (UPI)Dr. William H. Crosby Jr. was given the 1970 McCol Ium award of the American So ciety for Clinical Nutrition to day at the society's annual luncheon. Dr. Crosby, a hema tologist and professor of med icine at Tufts University School of Medicine, was cited for re search in the field of clinical nutrition. The award carries a ??.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Edge of the Knife
description: PARIS  President Nixon's decision to wipe out the Cam bodian bases of Vietnam Com munists has precipitated the greatest atmosphere of interna tional alarm since the Cuban confrontation. The reasons, however, are largely tangential to Southeast Asia.

title: Engagements
description: ANGELOWICZSILVERMANMr. and Mrs. Bernard Silverman of Long Beach, L. announce the engagement of their daugh ter, Mona Sue to Mr. Zachary Howard Angelowicz, sun of Florence Angelowicz of Brooklyn, N. Y.

title: GuerrillaJordanian Clash Is Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 2 (Reuters)  Two Palestinian guerrillas and eight civilians were wounded today during a 10hour battle between guerril las and Jordanian troops, the Palestine Armed Struggle Com mand announced tonight.

title: Easier Abortions Will Bring Problems
description: Though New York's legal prohibition against abortions will end July 1, major practi cal problems remain unre solved. Leading advocates of reform, such as Dr. Alan Guttmacher, fear the medical establishment Will find itself woefully unready to help tens of thousands of women desperately seeking to end their pregnancies. In New York City alone, Dr. Gutt macher expects a demand for 50,000 to 100,000 abor tions a year.

title: Harvards' 150Pound Crews Sweep Yale and Princeton
description: DERBY, Conn., May 2Har vard's lightweight crews con tinued their mastery over East ern rivals today by decisively defeating Yale and Princeton crews.

title: POETRY AWARD GIVEN AT N.Y.U. CEREMONY
description: The first Delmore Schwartz Memorial Poetry Award of $1,000 was presented Thursday night to Daphael Rudnik at a reception at La Maison Fran caise of New York University, 16 Washington Mews.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To Neutralize Cambodia

title: MARCHERS MARK LOYALTY DAY HERE
description: Bands, soldirs and children with flags marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday in the Vet erans of Foreign Wars 23d an nual Loyalty Day parade.

title: L.I. STUDENTS GET A NEW JOB GUIDE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 2A new guide for high school stu dents on Long Island who will be job hunting after graduation has been published by the Ca reer Resources Foundation.

title: Son to Mrs. Gastwirth
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., May 2A son was born April 7 to Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Law rence Gastwirth at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset. Mrs. Gastwirth is the former Miss Norma Blechman of New York, whose husband is partner in the Jericho law firm of Semon & Gastwirth. The child has been named David Eric.

title: The fox bagged the hunter
description: One version of the Revolu tionary War blames Britain's defeat on her slothful generals: Howe shut his eyes, fought his battles, drank his bottle, had his little whore, [and] ad vised with his counselors, Gage was criticized for the in activity and irresolution of his conduct, and Clinton, accord ing to his recent biographer, experienced a paralysis of command.

title: City Plan Aids SingleRoom Occupants
description: The first step in a city pro gram to alleviate the housing problems of the city's estimat ed total of 100,000 singleroom occupants has been completed, the Housing and Development Administration announced yes terday.

title: Company: Original and Uncompromising
description: PERHAPS you remember Alceste, that fellow in The Misanthrope who was dead certain that his friends and acquaint ances, one and all, were dolts and deceivers ever, and that the best he could do with them was bid them a firm goodby. Well, if he'd ever written a musical comedy, it would probably have looked like Company.

title: Auctions to Benefit Dance Collection
description: Balletomanes, ballet danc ers and others connected with ballet have donated material to be sold at auction Tuesday and Wednesday at the Parke Bernet Galleries to raise funds for new purchases by the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library. Duplicate items from the col lection also will be offered at the auction.

title: Docking to Seek Third Term As Governor of Kansas
description: TOPEKA, Kan. May 2 (AP) Gov. Robert Docking announced today that he would seek a third term because there is so much to be done. The 44 yearold Democrat said at series of news conferences across the state that he thought there had been significant prog ress in his first four years in office. series of news conferences across the state that he thought there had been significant prog ress in his first four years in office.

title: Marriages
description: CONSALAZIOKANTORMr. and Mrs. Da vid H. Youdelman announce the mar riage of their daughter, Barbara Youdel man Kantor to Mr. Joseph M. Consalazio Sunday May 3, 1970.

title: RUSSIANS DENOUNCE PRESIDENT'S ACTION
description: MOSCOW, May 2 (UPI)The Soviet Union today described President Nixon's decision to send United States troops into Cambodia as an act of undis guised aggression.

title: ACK ACK MOVED UP TO FIRST ON COAST
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May (UPI)Ack Ack was moved up to first place after finishing second to Right of Wrong to day in the 18th running of the $53,750 Los Angeles Handicap at Hollvwood Park.

title: Letters
description: DISORDER IN THE STREET

title: G. P. Garmany Jr. to Wed Miss Doremus
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Dore mus have announced the engagement of Mr. Doremus's daughter, Miss Catharine Doremus, to George Parker Garmany Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Garmany of Laurel, Miss.

title: Lower Voting Age Gains
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 2 (AP)The General Assembly has overwhelmingly approved a bill to lower the voting age to 1R. Before it can become law, the measure must be approved by the Legislature again next year, then get threefifths of the vote in a statewide referendum.

title: What happened to the attempts to clean up the majestic, the polluted Hudson?
description: CASTLETONONHUDSON, N. Y.

title: Beau: Am I Happy Enough? Am I Sad Enough?
description: HOLLYWOOD. UNLIKE his slightly old er contemporaries, Dustin Hoffman and Richard Benjamin, Beau Bridges might well have become a movie star in the days when movie stars were molded out of blond hair and dimples, instead of born out of dissonance and alienation. He has the sweet awkward ness of a young Jimmy Stew art that would have served him well a dozen years ago.

title: Reds Beat Pirates, 72, as McGlothlin Gives 6 Hits and Belts 3Run Triple
description: CINCINNATI, May 2 (UPI) Jim McGlothlin hit a bases lodded triple and stopped the Pittsburgh Pirates with six hits while pitching the Cincinnati Reds to a 72 victory today.

title: Singing Rain Wins by 8 Lengths in $32,950 Gallorette Handicap at Pimlico
description: BALTIMORE, May 2Walter M. Jeffords Jr.'s Singing Rain, the runnerup in the event a year ago, moved into the win ner's circle today as she easily outran six other fillies and mares to take the 1 1/16mile $32,950 Gallorette Handicap before a crowd of 13,856 at Pimlico Race Course.

title: CarLoving Italians Take to the Roads For Long Weekend
description: ROME, May 2The Italian love affair with the internal combustion engine reached a new peak on a long weekend officially consecrated to labor and blessed by brilliant spring weather.

title: Television
description: DISQUIETING develop ments in the field of television news, both commercial and non commercial, seem to be turn ing up almost daily and prob ably only the passage of time Will clear the atmosphere. Puzzling actions abound, but the most stupid move thus far was the action of the executive committee of Wash ington's noncommercial sta Eon WETATV in discharging William Woestendiek as edi tor of its newly developed program called Newsroom because Mrs. Woestendiek had accepted a job as press secretary to the outspoken wife of Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

title: Woman Power Focuses on the Ballot
description: IT'S easy to join; simply apply and be ready to pay dues of $8.50 a year.

title: Polo Pony Division Scheduled For Shallowbrook Show Today
description: Adivision for polo ponies almost unheard of these days, will be part of the pro gram at the Shallowbrook horse show today in Somers, Conn.

title: Ponza's New Role: A Jr. Isle of Capri
description: PONZA, ItalyYoung rebels, hippies or otherwise, have flowered in every age. They were a fact of life in ancient Rome; then, as now, they frequently irritated the establishment, and when that irritation boiled up into action, the establishment sometimes banished them Ponza.

title: BETSY RAWLS LEADS IN GOLF BY 2 SHOTS
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May (UPI)Betsy Rawls shot a three underpar 69 today and took a twostroke lead in the opening round of the $15,000 Shreveport women's invitation golf tourna ment.

title: A Garden That Cares for Itself, Almost
description: A WEDDING gift of a garden plan by a landscape designer started Mr. and Mrs. William R. Rob ertson of Boston off on the re warding adventures of gardening. Their most recent achievement is a 7year old country garden, deep in the heart of rural New Hampshire, with refresh ing views of a lake and mountains.

title: School Program to Explain Medicaid Benefits in City
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday an nounced the start of Medicaid School Year for all children en rolled in Medicaid in New York City.

title: Saigon Troops Visit Site Of Killings in Cambodia
description: PRASAUT, Cambodia, April 30  South Vietnamese troops who penetrated 19 miles inside Cambodia today to stop at Prasautthe little town where Cainbudran soldiers killed 89 Vietnamese civilians on April 10  took a symbolic revenge.

title: Laboratories Check Samples of Water and Sand to Find What Caused Death of 86,000 Birds in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE May 2  A half dozen laboratories from Alaska to Maryland are check ing samples of an estimated total of 86,000 birds killed on the western side of the Alaska Peninsula to determine the cause of their deaths.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: The Tying of Auto Races

title: Rev. Joseph Rooney, Prefect Of Jesuit High Schools Here
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., May 2 The Rev. Joseph J. Rooney, headmaster of Xavier High School in Manhattan from 1938 to 1940, and prefect general for high schools in the New York Jesuit Province from 1940 to 1946, died yesterday in Com munity Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at Loyola Seminary in Shrub Oak.

title: More Jitters In an Uncertain Economy
description: WASHINGTON  All of the confusion and uncertainty con nected with the Government's delicate effort to check inflation without pushing the economy in to a tailspinplus a dash of Cambodiacombined last week to send an already jittery stock market reeling to some big de clines.

title: The idiom of Stephen pedal us in rural terms
description: Miss O'Brien's new book is a novel in the guise of a memoir. An Irish girl, now a nun in Brussels, recalls her childhood, her family, the neigh bors, holy and pagan Ireland official ly neutral in the years of World War II, a trip to Dublin in search of an erring sister. No occasion is too triv ial to be invoked, a nun's dedication to God being apparently compatible with the exercise of an emigrant's total recall. The degree of accuracy is presumably high, though Portar lington is remembered as Port Dar lington, and Kinnegad as Kenigad. The heroine is a country girl, but not a peasant. Her parents have some of the marks of decayed gentry, notably an internal lavatory, a social point somewhat confused, however, by the fact that the father relieves himself in the open air. The mother earns some money by selling eggs, but on the other hand the father owns few horses in training. There are 30 pubs in the village, if a nun's recol lections are to be taken literally. As for the plot the erring sister Emma gets pregnant, the father gets drunk and the intending nun gets seduced.

title: Notes From the Field of Travel
description: TWO blocks from the Dawson County Court house in Dawsonville, Ga., is a 30x90foot log building known as The Moon shine Museum. Inside are four stills. They have never produced anything but curi osity in their present loca tion, swears the museum's owner, but he's confident they could.

title: On the Jewish Question in the Soviet Union
description: NOBODY, not even the Soviet Government, really knows how many Jews live in the U.S.S.R. The 1959 official census listed 2,267,814 persons who declared themselves Jewish. Unofficial esti mates run all the way up to 3.5 mil lion. In Moscow, different sources gave me figures ranging from 300,000 to 600,000 for the city's Jewish popu lation. All agreed that the true fig ure is higher than the present census figure. A new census has just been completed and many Soviet Jews are waiting eagerly to see how their numbers have grown over the last decade.

title: 15to1 Shot Wins Derby
description: Dust Commander, a 151 shot, won the 96th running of the Kentucky Derby at Church ill Downs yesterday by five lengths. With 17 horses run ning, the race was worth a record $170,300 and the win ner earned $127,800. 11e paid $32.60 for $2 to win. My Dad George finished second and High Echelon was third. De tails in Section 5.

title: ITHACA OARSMEN WIN SULGER CUP
description: Ithaca College, in its third year of varsity rowing compe tition, gave proof of steady progress yesterday as its heavy weight crew won the Metropol itan intercollegiate eightoared championship on Orchard Beach Lagoon.

title: Undefeated Navy Trounces Hofstra in Lacrosse, 9 to 4
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 2 The unbeaten Navy lacrosse team scored its eighth victory tonight, defeating Hofstra, 94, before more than 3,000 specta tors.

title: GOLDBERG URGING MIDEAST WARNING
description: Arthur J. Goldberg declared yesterday that President Nixon must make it absolutely clear to the Russians that they must not meddle in the Middle East and they must keep theeir men out.

title: Vadim's Pretty Maids
description: IT was bound to happen. Roger Vadim is Going Hollywood. The French director who con fected such sexy epics as And God Created Woman, Les Liaisons Dangereuses and Bar barella is all primed to focus his cameras on Pretty Maids All In a Row. William Hanley and Gene Roddenberry have done the adap tation of Francis Pollini's novel, and Roddenberry will produce the film for MGM release. Shooting begina In August.

title: Greek Warriors' Bones Found At Site of Battle of Marathon
description: MARATHON, Greece, May The burial place of Greek warriors who fell in the epoch making Battle of Marathon, defending Athenian civilization from Persian conquest in 490 B. C., has been discovered by Greek archeologists on this an cient battlefield.

title: Target Isle Off Puerto Rico Fights New Navy Plan
description: CULEBRA, P. R., May 2  Leaders of the small Caribbean community of 900 residents have vowed to resist a plan, now pending in Congress that would give the United States Navy twothirds of their island.

title: Marshals Seek Calm in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, May 2In a small room on the Yale Uni versity campus, about a dozen men, some of them wearing yellow armbands, met today behind a closed door to plan how to keep violence away from this tense city.

title: A Gala in Boston That's Like a Big Family Party
description: BOSTON, May 2  The more Boston society changes, they say, the more it stays the same. The 90th anniversary dinner and ball of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Symphony Hall earlier this week might prove the point.

title: Karen L. Sobol Is Future Bride Of M. P. Poriss
description: EAST ORANGE, NJ., May 2Nathan N. Sobol, presi dent of the North American Chemical Corporation, and Mrs. Sobol have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Lee Sobol, to Martin Peter Poriss, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward I. Poriss of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Wall Street Feels the Effect of a Year of Uncertainty
AUSTRALIANS TERM ROYAL TOUR SUCCESS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 3 The warm public reception given Queen Elizabeth II and other members of the royal family in a fiveweek tour of Australia that ended today has been interpreted here as a severe setback to any move ment to make this country a republic.

title: Tiriac Victor in Italy
description: FLORENCE, Italy, May 3 (AP) Ion Tiriac of Rumania de feated Boro Jovanovic of Yu goslavia 86, 64, 62, today for the men's singles honors in the Florence international tourna ment.

title: Scarves for Everywhere But the Neck
description: FOR several months, fashion models have been run ning around town with their heads tightly wrapped in scarves so that they look like Indians of the Old West about to go into a war dance. Then All MacGraw, who was a model before she became an actress, appeared on the Oscar awards show wrapped in similar fashion and clinched the fad. Actually, al most any oblong scarf will do the trick, but it helps to have one the right size and in the right mood. Kenneth, the hairdresser, has had some scarves made of Navajolike prints (by Julian Tornchin). He calls them Head Rags and would like to see them worn over the hairpieces he calls Put Ons, but has no objection if a girl chooses to tie them over her own hair. The scarves come in silk crepe ($20) and in chiffon ($18) and can he found at Bloomingdale's, along with the Kenneth wigs.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Santana Conquers Road
description: MADRID, May 3 (Reuters) Manuel Santana of Spain beat Lew Hoad of Australia, 63, 810, 63, 60, in the final of the Madrid international tournament today.

title: POLLS FIND FAVOR FOR ASIAN POLICY
description: Two separate public opinion polls yesterday reported con flicting results on the attitude of the American people toward sending United States troops into Cambodia.

title: QUEBEC ELECTION PLEASES BANKERS
description: MONTREAL, May 3Jubila tion prevailed in Montreal's predominantly Englishspeaking financial community following the Liberal party's sweep of the Quebec elections last week.

title: DUTCH PLANNING TAIWAN PROJECT
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Just 346 years after they became the first Westerners to establish settlement on Taiwan, the Dutch are back in strength again.

title: U.S. Five Loses in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, May 3Peru's national basketball team de feated the Chargers of Tulsa, Okla., 7463, last night.

title: Hanoi Hints Bombing Threatens Talks
description: HONG KONG, May 3  The North Vietnam Government im plied today that United States bombings in two North Viet namese provinces Friday and Saturday might disrupt the Paris peace negotiations on Vietnam.

title: REPORT TO SENATORS CHIDES JOB PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Sen ate investigators have charged that the job training program run by the National Alliance of Businessmen with Labor De partment support has fallen short of its promises.

title: TIMES PUBLISHER WARNS PRINTERS
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, pub lisher of The New York Times, warned yesterday that a plan by union printers to increase their economic pressure on the paper brings us face to face with crisis.

title: Mrs. Molotov Dies in Moscow; Wife of ExPremier Was 76
description: MOSCOW, May 3 (UPI)  Mrs. Pauline Zhemchuzhina Molotov, the wife of former Premier and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, died of cancer in a Moscow hospital on Friday, family sources re ported today. She was 76 years old.

title: GIRL BEATEN ON WAY TO WORK DOWNTOWN
description: An 18yearold Jersey City girl was severely beaten while on her way to work at the New York Telephone Company of fices at 140 West Street last night.

title: Combs, Derby Victor's Trainer, Ponders Filing for Preakness
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3  Despite his clear triumph yes terday in the Kentucky Derby, Dust Commander is not yet definitely set for the Preakness, or for the Belmont Stakes, Don Combs, the 31yearold former law student who trains Dust Commander for Robert Leh mann, said this morning, I never enter a horse in a race unless I'm dead sure about his condition. And I won't make any move with Dust Command er until I have satisfied myself that he is not sore.

title: Johnson Undermining Charge Denied
description: Pierre Salinger said yesterday that former President Lyndon B. Johnson had made another unfortunate attempt to rewrite history in his accusation that some holdover staff members had undermined his Administra tion in the months after Presi dent Kennedy's assassination.

title: 100 Pipers Assigned To William Esty Co.
description: From the usuallyquiet halls of the William Esty Company this morning you'll probably be able to hear the shrill skirl of 100 pipers. That's if the agency properly celebrates its new $3million account.

title: Quarry to Fight Foster In Garden on June 17
description: Jerry Quarry and Mac Fos ter, California heavyweights, will meet in a 10round bout at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night, June 17. Harry Markson, the Garden boxing director, in making the announcement yesterday, said the fight would he tele vised nationally but New York would be blacked out.

title: Campus Unrest Over War Spreads With Strike Calls
description: Calls for ending classes to allow college students to pro test the widening United States involvement in Southeast Asia were echoed yesterday on cam puses in many parts of the country.

title: Libyans May Marry Arabs
description: TRIPOLI, Libya (AP)Libyal announced that Libyans are now allowed to marry nonLibyan Arabs. Marriage with non Arabs by Libyans is forbidden.

title: Personal Finance
description: This is the last of a threepart series on consumer measures passed by the Legislature this season. The first two, reviewing bills the Governor was expected to sign, appeared on April 23 and 27. This is a review of the most controversial bill on the Governor's desk today. His deci sion to sign or not to sign it will have a broad impact on consumers everywhere.

title: U.S. Forces Employ Artillery and Aircraft to Strike Foe in Cambodia
RESERVE REJECTS PAYMENTS GAUGE
description: The Federal Reserve has bluntly repudiated the official Government measurement of the nation's international bal ance of payments.

title: Future Head of Columbia Willing to Die for Cause
description: Columbia University's presi dent  designate, William J. McGill, said yesterday that he was willing to die for the academic cause.

title: College Baseball
description: KNICKERBOCKER CONF.

title: City Record Sales Office Moves to New Location
description: The City Record sales office, which sells the Green Book of city departments and other, official publications, has moved to the Surrogate Court Building at 31 Chambers Street, the Mu nicipal Services Administration announced yesterday.

title: Walter B. Devereux, 60, Dies; President of the Horse Show
description: Walter B. Devereux, president of the National Horse Show died in Lenox Hill Hospital last night at the age of 60. He had residences at 1 East 66th Street and in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Fordham Wins Sailing Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Ford ham won the Jesuit College sailing championship today in competition with Holy Cross and Georgetown on the Poto mac River. The Rams had 21 points for the sixrace series. Holy Cross was second with 24 and Georgetown had 34.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW YORK bridge players bade farewell a week ago to two Australian experts who are undertaking a world bridge tour of recordbreak ing duration.

title: TOP JUDGES HERE CALL FOR REFORM
description: The Presiding Justices of the two Appellate Divisions here declared yesterday that condi tions in the city's Criminal Court were deplorable and called for reforms with more staffing and massive new funding.

title: THANT SEES THREAT OF INDOCHINA WAR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 3 (AP)  Secretary General Thant said today that the Viet nam war threatened to engulf Indochina and that he would present some ideas to pre vent that from happening.

title: Veteran Printers Honored
description: Typographical Union No. 6 distributed gold pins at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday to 243 present and retired printers who have been mem bers of the union for 50, 60 or 70 years. One of those honored was Wilson C. Lowery, father of Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery.

title: Sweep in Parrot's Beak
description: GODAUHA, South Vietnam, May 3The three task forces of Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri's III South Vietnamese Corps, which moved into the Parrot's Beak area of Cambodia on Wednes day, are now reported to be sweeping back in a semicircle toward the South Vietnamese border, after having reached Svevricng on Friday.

title: Hebrew U. Names Ross
description: Daniel G. Ross, a New York lawyer, was appointed yester day chairman of the Interna tional Committee of the Insti tute of Contemporary Jewry of Hebrew University in Jerusa lem. The announcement was made here by the American Friends of Hebrew University, of which Mr. Ross is a former president.

title: A.D.A. Calls for Amnesty For Men Who Evade Draft
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)  The Americans for Domo cratic Action voted today to call for amnesty for young men who have gone abroad or to prison to escape the draft be cause of their opposition to the war in Vietnam.

title: TEAMSTERS ENDING CLEVELAND STRIKE
description: CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP) Dissident teamsters in Cleve land voted today to end their 32day wildcat strike, and 6,000 truck drivers in the local were to 20 back to work tomorrow.

title: MERLE PARK EXCELS AS JULIET AT MET
description: Merle Park, one of the Royal Ballet's top ballerinas, is so good an actress that it is almost possible to forget that her ex cellent dancing contributes equally to the entrancing effect of her dramatic roles. Both qualities, however, were very much in evidence Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House in Kenneth MacMillan's Romeo and Juliet when Miss Park and Donald MacLeary stepped into the title roles.

title: Japanese Killed in Fall After Scaling Nepal Peak
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 3 (AP)Three members of a Japanese mountainclimbing expedition conquered 22,632 foot Tukucha in western Ne pal on Thursday but fell on the way down, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry reported to day. One was killed and two severely injured.

title: Susan Harris, Joel Lavenson Of Army, Marry
description: ELKINS PARK, Pa., May 3 At Congregation Rodeph Shalom Suburban here this afternoon, Miss Susan Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Miller Harris, was married to Joel Lavenson, who is serv ing with the Army in Heidel berg, West Germany. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Lavenson of Pel ham, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David H. Wice.

title: Jobless Rate Up in 10 Areas
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Unemployment has reached substantial proportions  6 per cent or more  in Grand Rapids, Mich.: Lowell, Mass.; UticaRome, N. Y., and seven smaller areas, the Labor De partment announced today. Businesses and industries in such areas became eligible last Friday for preference in Fed eral confracts if certain per ?? of jobless poor people are hired.

title: BOMBING OF NORTH CALLED DEFENSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The Nixon Administration today de scribed its large bombing raid against targets in North Viet nam as only a continuation of a longstanding policy of self defense for American forces.

title: The Stage: Mod Donna
Note to Readers
description: The box scores of all base ball games between nonlocal teams are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Irate Rhodesian Bishop
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 3If the Christian churches of Rhodesia force the Gov ernment to amend the recent ly adopted law segregating the nation's land on racial lines, it will be a victory for a worldly Roman Catholic Bishop.

title: 10,000Meter A.A.U. Run Is Taken by McAndrews
description: YONKERS, May 3  Arthur McAndrews of the Boston Athletic Association won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Assocition Eastern regional 10, 000meter championship today at Tibbets Brook.

title: Penn Beats Harvard by a Length in Adams Cup Rowing
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 A Pennsylvania crew that added audacity to ability, beat Harvard this morning by one length to retain the Adams Cup. It was the first of two meet ings between the nation's strongest college crews and Penn's victory proved so con vincing that the Red and Blue will be favored to beat Harvard again on Saturday in the East ern sprint championships at Worcester, Mass.

title: Sports of The Times
description: IT is more than three years now since Muhammad All refused to take the step forward that would have made him Pvt. Cassius Clay. Since then, Ali has starred in Broadway musical, begun work on an autobiography and served several days in the Dade County jail for an old charge of driving without a license. He became a father, a rather polished speaker on the campus circuit, and frequent guest on television talk shows. He appeared a grotesque comedy called a computer boxing match in which Rocky Marciano de feated him for the mythical heavyweight championship of all time. He recently filmed some interviews for a documentary of his career to be released later this year.

title: British Hoopla Honors Staid Pilgrims
description: PLYMOUTH, England May 3The voyage of the May flower 350 years ago from the granite quays of this ancient seaport to a land of hope across the Atlantic was cele brated here this weekend with bellringing hoopla that would have bewilderedperhaps even shockedthe austere Pilgrim Fathers.

title: Bearings on the Last Frontier
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  From the severe neatness of the vast oil complex strung out at great white intervals along the frozen margin of the Arctic Ocean, one might imagine for a mo ment that the industry was out to enhance the stark environ ment if even the bleakest scene can be enhanced by oil rigs. The superintendent of the Atlantic Richfield operation at Prudhoe Bay sends up a heli copter crew periodically to check the landscape for aban doned drums, which are then picked up along with other lit ter, giving an effect of tidiness rarely encountered in American communities and almost never in New York.

title: USE OF BIRTH PILLS CALLED JUSTIFIED
description: LONDONMay 3 The In ternational Planned Parenthood Federation said here today that, after drawing together the available evidence, it had found that the risks involved in the use of oral contracep tion were small and its contin ued use throughout the world was fully justified.

title: Bicycling: The Individualist's Mode of Transport
description: THERE is a growing group of people in town who don't have to elbow their way into subways, fight each other for cabs, or struggle to fish out the exact fare for buses.

title: In Memoriam
description: BROWNMoyer (Mike) Happy third birthday in heaven. Always with our love. Helcu, Sandra, Judi and little Mike.

title: Jack Stewart Wins Japan Grand Prix
description: GOEMBA, Japan, May 3 (AP) Jackie Stewart of Scotland, the world champion auto racer, led all the way at an average speed of 120.2 miles an hour today and won the Japan Grand Prix by 50 seconds.

title: DR. SPOCK SEIZED IN CAPITAL RALLY
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Seventyfive persons, including Dr. Benjamin Spock, were ar rested this afternoon across the street from the White House in a peaceful outdoor prayer service to protest the war in Vietnam and the United States involvement in Cambodia.

title: First Signs of a Backlash Emerge in Ecology Drive
description: Signs of a backlash against the crusade for a cleaner en vironment and restoration of the ecological balance are be ginning to appear.

title: Students Set for Chicago 7
description: DURHAM, N.H., May 3 (AP)  Mark Wefers, president of the University of New Hamp shire Student Senate, said to day that lawyers would seek an injunction tomorrow to pre vent the college and the board of trustees from interfering in any way with the Tuesday ap pearance of three members of the Chicago 7. The trustees have agreed to allow Abbie Hoffman, Jerry Rubin and Dav id Dellinger to speak on cam pus on condition they leave by 5 P.M., but they are not sched uled to arrive until 4:45 P.M.

title: Pacers Defeat Colonels, 114110, For 21 Edge in A.B.A. Playoff
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 (AP)Fred Lewis scored seven of Indiana's last 9 points from the freethrow line today to help the Pacers beat the Ken Itucky Colonels, 114110.

title: NEW YORK IS VICTOR IN GAELIC FOOTBALL
description: Mick Moynihan scored 6 points to lead New York to a 138 victory over County Offaly yesterday at Gaelic Park in the Bronx before a crowd of 6,241 in the windup of their two game totalpointGaelic football series.

title: Computer PrintOut Replacing Longshoremen's ShapeUp Here
description: The last vestiges of the once  notorious waterfront shapeup are being phased out in the Port of New York as a new computer hiring system is close to becoming portwide.

title: U.S. Business Has an Air Force: 24,000 Planes, Exceeding Lines
description: During the last 15 years, Unit ed States industry has built up ??ne of the world's largest air forces24,000 executive planes that now outnumber the na tion's airline fleet by 12 to 1, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board.

title: Ireland Wins, 30
description: MONDORF, Luxembourg, May 3 (AP)Ireland clinched its second round Davis Cup zone match with Luxembourg today as Mac Graft and John Brown routed Thierry Brasseur and Georges Logelin, 61, 61, 61. It was the third victory for the Irish.

title: Roundup: Bench Belts Home Runs and Ballads
description: Johnny Bench likes to sing ballads  songs with good lyrics that say something meaningful.

title: London: A Cast of Sporting Investors
description: LONDON  Every Sunday morning in winter, packs of passionate amateurs turn out in Hyde Park for a bout of casual but deadly serious soccer. There is an egghead team made up of critics, literary editors, publishers, and pots. There is also an other drawn from the worl of showbusiness, which includes actors, agents, directors and scriptwriters, oc casionally field ing an international star of two, such as Tom Courtney and Terence Stamp, unre gonizable in goose bumps and mud to the strollersby.

title: GUARD IS LEAVING CALM NEW HAVEN IN WAKE OF RALLY
description: NEW HAVEN, May 3  A force of 3,000 National Guard troops sent here to control a mass weekend rally in support of the Black Panthers began leaving the city today, and there was a general relaxation of fear as more of the students and young radicals attracted by the rally also departed.

title: German Soccer
description: Schalke 2, Bayern Munich 2.

title: PRIMARIES IN OHIO TOSSUP IN FINALE
description: CLEVELAND, May 3With the most exciting Ohio Senate primary election in years up for decision Tuesday, voters find themselves with not one but two races close enough to make forecasters wary.

title: Egypt Says It Destroyed Israeli Halftrack at Canal
description: CAIRO, May 2 (Reuters)  A military spokesman said here that Egyptian heavy artillery shelled Israeli positions across, the Suez Canal in a threehour exchange today, destroying one Israeli halftrack, damaging a tank and another halftrack, and hitting artillery bases and ammunition dumps.

title: KEN KLING IS DEAD; TURF CARTOONIST
description: Ken Kling, a former horse racing handicapper and car toonist, died yesterday after a long illness. He lived in Great Neck, L. I., and was in his 70's.

title: National Merit Scholars Named
Cable TV Here Outgrowing Its Rural Mission
description: For 40,000 Manhattan apartment dwellers, cable television is a way to see home games of the Knicker bockers and the Rangers and old movies without commer cials. For them, as well as for 500 others uptown in Riverdale, cable TV means interferencefree reception.

title: FRANKLIN S. BROWN, FEDERAL ENGINEER
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Franklin Stewart Brown, chief of the Bureau of Power and chief engineer of the Federal Power Commission, died today of cancer. He was 60 years old.

title: My Sweet Charlie Leads Emmy Race
description: My Sweet Charlie, a drama about the growth of under standing between an ignorant Southern girl and a militant black Northern lawyer that starred Patty Duke and Al Freeman Jr., walked of with eight Emmy nominations from the National Academy of Tele vision Arts and Sciencesthe highest number for any single dramatic program.

title: Old Blue Routs West Point In Rugby Final at Hofstra, 83
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 3 The Old Blue Rugby Club de feated West Point, 83, today in the final of the Schaefer Rugby Tournament at Hofstra Univer sity.

title: Neither Wallace, With Ad Blitz, nor Gov. Brewer Is Expected to Win Alabama Majority Tomorrow
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 Must politicians in Alabama have concluded that neither Gov. Albert P. Brewer nor for mer Gov. George C. Wallace is likely to gain a majority in the Democratic gubernatorial prim ary Tuesday.

title: DilworthLeslie Offers Tully Hall Piano Recital
description: Samuel DilworthLeslie's pi ano recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon came to gether best in Edward Mac Dowell's Tragic Sonata, No. 1 in G minor, a work now gen erally left on the shelf because its ideas recall so vividly those of better composers of the 19th century. Mr. DilworthLes lie, with a restraint that en hanced the music, searched out and often found the MacDowell behind the imitations of Liszt, Chopin and Brahms. The Dian ist managed the heroic finale in fine style, making musical sense of its faded rhetoric, and in the Largo he pulled the score taut with mesmerizing expert ness.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 games series)

title: DUROCHER IS FINED $200 FOR GESTURE
description: ATLANTA, May 3 (UPI)Leo Durocher, the Chicago Cubs' manager, was fined $200 and suspended for one day by Chub Feeney, the National League president, today for making an obscene gesture at ??n umpire in last night's game with the At lanta Braves.

title: U.S. SENDS LON NOL MERCENARY UNITS
description: Dispatch of The Times London

title: Amigo Takes Blue Ribbons In Three Pony Polo Events
description: SOMERS, Conn., May 3Hal Vita's Amigo won all three classes for polo ponies today at the Shallowbrook horse show. The mount was ridden by Vita's son, Frank. Eight horses competed.

title: Soccer Results
description: NATIONAL CHALLENGE CLIP

title: 5 MILLION VETERANS WERE INSURED IN '69
description: WASHINGTON  More than five million veterans were in sured during 1969 in five Gov ernment life insurance pro grams valued at $38billion, ac cording to the Veterans Admin istration.

title: ISADORE A. WYNER
description: Isadore Alfred Wyner, long prominent in the knitted fabrics industry, died here Saturday. He was 77 years old and lived at 290 West End Avenue.

title: Artful Exporters Juggle Papers To Evade Common Market Rules
description: BRUSSELS, May 3  With national borders in the Euro pean Common Market fading away, the oldfashioned smug gler has disappeared but the dishonest exporter who knows how to manipulate the new regulations has taken his place.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MAY 4, 1970

title: Bannister Criticizes Title Soccer Site
description: LONDON, May 3 (AP)Dr. Roger Bannister, the first man to run the mile under four minutes, said today Mexico should never again stage a major international sporting contest.

title: Gentry, Foy Spark 32 Victory After Padres Win, 43, in 10th
description: SAN DIEGO, May 3The New York Mets split a double header with the San Diego Padres today and ended their first visit to the West Coast with five victories, five de feats and a serious shortage of hitting.

title: C.A.B. Reimposes A Bag Weight Limit For Airline Riders
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board has reimposed a weight limit on baggage checked by airline Pas sengers.

title: Nicaragua Crash Kills 13
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 3 (UPI)Thirteen persons were killed and 1 were injured today when a bus collided with a truck about 15 miles south of Managua, the police said.

title: HENRY R. ASHTON, 71, PATENT LAW LEADER
description: Henry R. Ashton, a senior partner in the New York pat entlaw firm of Fish & Neave, formerly Fish, Richardson & Neave, died Saturday in Me morial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 28 Ridge Croft Road, Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Virginia 500 Off Again
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., May 3 (AP)The Virginia 50 NASCAR race at Martinsville Speedway was postponed today for the second time because of rain and was rescheduled for May 17.

title: Tokyo Buddhist Unit Apologizes for Bid To Stifle Criticism
description: TOKYO, May 3The Soka gakkai, Japan's fastgrowing neoBuddhist sect, publicly apologized to the nation and the people concerned today for the actions it took in trying to suppress a book critical of the organization.

title: CAL DRUMMOND
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, May 3 (UPI)Cal Drummond, former American league umpire, died today in a Des Moines hospital after he collapsed while work ing in an American association baseball game last night. He was 52 years old.

title: Italian Resort Town Declares Its Independence as Its Neighbors Cry Treason
description: LADISPOLI, Italy, May 3 Italy's youngest town was joy ously born today, and 100 carabinieri were on hand to protect it from irate neighbors and former fellow citizens.

title: British Hotel Chain In Catering Merger
description: LONDON, May 3A merger of Trust Houses, Britain's biggest hotel chain, and Fortes, the mass catering and restau rant concern, was announced here today.

title: After 100 Years, Bush League Baseball Survives by Subsidies
description: QUINCY, Ill.  Jessie Hill, a brawny bear of a pitcher, lathered in the first pitch of the Quincy Cubs' 1970 season. Rick Auerbach, the Clinton Pilots' scrawny shortstop, swung and the ball soared in a high arc over the black and gold Brockshmidt Plumbing and Heating sign on the centerfield fence. How's that for open ers? Bill Nieh woner gasped over the public address system.

title: LAKELAND TERRIER IS TRENTON BEST
description: WASHINGTON CROSSING, N. J., May 3The dog that to I day won best in show in the second of two events that have exceeded 3,600 dogs this year was the same Lakeland that had won the first. The terrier was Ch. Special Edition, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Far rell Jr. of Darien, Conn.

title: KoreanBorn Youth Wins WQXR Pianist Prize
description: Myung Whun Chung, a Ko reanhorn I7yearold student at the McBurney School in Manhattan, was named winner on Saturday of the fifth annual WQXR Young Artists Competi tion for Pianists. The finals, which were broadcast on, WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, present ed five young pianists in 20 minute recitals. Their performances were judged by a panel that included Artur Balsam, Claude Frank and Hilde Somer, pianists; Harold Schonberg, music critic of The Times, and Jascha Zayde, composer, pi anist and director of WQXR's educational activities.

title: A Confused Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  President Nixon's decision to send troops into Cambodia  and particularly the manner in which it was carried out  has transformed and troubled the spirit of this capital.

title: 3 Youths Killed and 2 Hurt In Rockaways Car Crash
description: Three young men were killed last night and two others criti cally injured when the car they were riding in crashed into a tree on Cross Bay Boulevard near North Channel Bridge in the Rockaways.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Nontraditional Approach to Fashion
description: SOMEDAY it will be great to do a collection of clothes without resorting to the sewing machine, Don Simonelli mused after the showing of his fall collection last week. It's the first he has not designed for some one else and it was made on sewing machines all right.

title: LARCHMONT RACE TAKEN BY KELLY
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 3 William E. Kelly of the host Larchmont Yacht Club, sailing Dowry, won the 7.4mile Etchells22 Class race today by 18 seconds and 2 boat more than 300 yards under poor sailing conditions on Long Island Sound.

title: MGM Begins Selling Its Memories
description: CULVER CITY, Calif., May 3A mantel clock used as a prop in the Greta Garbo movie Ninotchka was the star in the first hour of bid ding at the auction today of Metro  Goldwyn  Mayer. It went for $3,750 to a collector who refused to identify him self.

title: MRS. THOMAS J. M'GANN
description: Mrs. Mary H. McGann, a for mer secretary of the Ladies Auxiliary of Cathedral College of the Immaculate Conception in Brooklyn, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. Mrs. McGann, the widow of Thomas J. McGann, was Al years old and lived at 135 Buckingham Road, West Hempstead, L.I.

title: Romansky Scorns the Scoffers As He Sets Walk Race Records
description: Dave Romansky left the starting line for the onemile walking race to the usual ac companiment of giggles and whistles.

title: Accounts
description: Pharmaco, Inc., to Warwick & Legler, Inc., for the Sardo Line.

title: More Room in the Skies
description: The opportunity exists to turn Floyd Bennett Field, which will close down as a Navy base, into a supple mentary facility for civil aviation. There are problems of jurisdiction and still bigger problems of coordination with New York's two nearby major airports. But convenience, safety and congestion elsewhere require added facilities.

title: Medical Economics Revolution
description: The Administration proposal for extending Medicaid and Medicare lays the foundation for a complete restructuring of the economics and organization of the existing medical care system.

title: Martha K. Marston, Teacher, Wed to Dr. Sidney Robert Block
description: Miss Martha Katherine Marston and Dr. Sidney Rob ert Block were married yes terday afternoon. The cere mony at the Church Center for the United Nations was performed jointly by the Rev. Charles Koerber, a Roman Catholic priest, Rabbi Samuel H. Baron and the Rev. Dr. Carl Soule, a Methodist min ister who heads the center.

title: Laird Predicts an Extension Of Draft Until at Least 1973
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird predicted today that Congress would extend the draft for at least two years be yond the July 1, 1971, expira tion date for the Selective Serv ice, Art.

title: 2 Die as Soccer Fans Riot
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 3 (AP) Fighting broke out today be tween rival fans at a noceer garne in Eastern Turkey and two students were reported killed and 40 persons were in jured.

title: INDIA LEADS, 10, IN DAVIS CUP PLAN
description: BANGALORE, India, May 3 (AP)  Premjit Lall outlasted Ray Ruffels in a 66game match today giving India a 10 lead over Australia in their fivematch Davis Cup Eastern Zone final. The score was 62, 68, 63, 36, 1412.

title: MRS. CARL REICH
description: Mrs. Mildred Albright Reich, wife of Dr. Carl Reich, consult ing hematologist at Lenox Hill Hospital, who for many years assisted hirn in his hematology research there, died Saturday at the hospital, after a long illness. She was 58 years old.

title: Nicklaus Beats Palmer on First Hole of Playoff
MISS WRIGHT'S 140 LEADS GOLF BY SHOT
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May 3 (UPI)Mickey Wright, making her first tournament appear ance this year, shot a three underpar 69 today for a 140 total and a onestroke lead in the second round of the $15,000 Shreveport invitational wom en's golf tournament.

title: Settlement to Hold A Riverboat Ball
description: The philanthropic program of the Friends of the Henry Street Settlement will bene fit from a Riverboat Ball at the Pierre on Friday night. The decor and entertainment in the hotel's Grand Ballroom iwll stimulate the atmosphere of a 19thcentury Mississippi riverboat.

title: Chess:
TIME INC. ACCUSED OF BIAS BY WOMEN
description: A group of female editorial employes at Time Inc, charged last night that its magazines treat women as inferior em ployes in publishing. Women who work for Time, Life, For tune and Sports Illustrated magazines said legal action would he taken against the publisher.

title: Allegret Film Is Initial Entry At Cannes Fete
description: CANNES, France, May 3 The 23d Cannes Film Festival opened last night. Its initial offering  Marc Allegret's screen version of Raymond Radiguet's novel Le Bal du Comte d'Orgel  took the gala premiere audience back to 1923. This was the year of the book's publication and that of its youthful author's death.

title: BRITISH REPORT AIDE KIDNAPPED IN AFRICA
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 3 (AP)A British High Commis sion official, Brian A. Lea, was kidnapped here yesterday, Brit ish officials announced today.

title: Designer Vera Maxwell Admits a Partner
description: Vera Maxwell, the well known American designer who has always sought to make timeless clothes, is taking a step to capitalize on what she believes are the needs of the time.

title: Pampered Miss First
description: PARIS, May 3, (Reuters) Pampered Miss, the 1110 favor ite owned by Norman Bunker Hunt or the United States, won the French 1,000 Guineas at Longcham today. F. W. Bur mann's Prudent Miss was sec ond, a length hack and an English Filly, Popkins, finished third.

title: New Yachts Hit the Water as Season Gets Under Way
RICHARD E. STERNS
description: VALLEY, COTTAGE, N.Y., May 3  Richard E. Sterns, lawyer, died in his sleep early today. He was 44 years old.

title: Fantasticks Celebrates 10 Years With Matinee
description: The Fantasticks celebrated its 10th anniversary with a special matinee yesterday in off Broadway's Sullivan Street Playhouse. The mat inee marked the 4,194 per formance of the show, which opened at the same theater on May 3, 1960 with a capi talization of $16,500. Over the years, the New York pro duction has grossed $2,563, 347 and netted its backers a profit of $638,817.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: TRADE MARK WINS IN JUNIOR JUMPING
description: WEST ORANGE. N. J., May 3Trade Mark finished second in the final class today and won the junior jumper champi onship of the threeday Junior Essex Troop horse show.

title: Red Attack on Neak Luong
description: CHROI DANG, Cambodia, May 3  Vietnamese Commu nist forces were reported today to have attacked and at least partly occupied a key Mekong River crossing point in Cam bodia 35 miles southeast of Pnompenh.

title: KENNEDY SUPPORT SOLID IN HIS STATE
description: BOSTON, May 3Ladies, if you'll maintain your com ??, said Chairlady Edie O'Leary moments before Sena for Edward M. Kennedy arrived at a luncheon outing for Demo cratic women on the edge of Boston harbor, the Senator will visit each table on the boat. We certainly want to give him a standing ovation, but we don't want to crush him.

title: State Study of Police Graft Asked
description: Mayor Lindsay's special com mittee set up to investigatei alleged police corruption was criticized yesterday by two pro minent Democrtas, Howard J. Samuels and Basil A. Paterson. Both suggested that the state conduct an investigation.

title: SinoSoviet Hatred
description: The ferocious hatred the leaders of the Soviet Union and China harbor toward each other emerges vividly from the latest exchange of polemical blasts between Moscow and Peking.

title: Webster's New American Dictionary
description: Provocation (n.): Dispatch of Russian pilots, at Egyptian Government's request, to help defend Egypt against Israeli air attacks. Flying of actual combat mission by So viet pilots over Egyptian ter ritory is a dangerous provo cation.

title: McIver Woody, Physician Served Esso Standard
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 3 Dr. McIver Woody of 552 West minster Avenue, medical direc tor for the Esso Standard Oil Company from 1922 to 1944, died today at the Elizabeth General Hospital. His age was 84.

title: Yarborough Says Apathy, War and Prayer Issue Defeated Him
description: HOUSTON, May 3Senator Ralph W. Yarboroough said to day that he was defeated for renomination yesterday by voter apathy, war weariness and, primarily, the lastminute introduction as a campaign issue of his vote against a pub lic school prayer proposal.

title: Protest Staged in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., May 3 (AP)  Thousands of pro independence demonstrators marched today through old San Juan chanting Yankee go home and Cuba si, Yankee no. The march was sponsored by the proindependence move ment to protest United States draft laws and demand inde pendence for Puerto Rico.

title: U. S. TROOPS FIND ENEMY SUPPLIES IN CAMBODIA DRIVE
description: SATUM, Cambodia, May 3 Penicillin from Britain, surgical instruments from Germany, mortar shells from the Soviet Union and rice from China were the yield of the third day of the allied sweep of the Fish hook area of Cambodia.

title: Guards Posted on Airliners
description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) Korean Air Lines has begun posting a police lieutenant aboard all its international flights as a precaution against hijackers.

title: YearOld Reparations Demand By Blacks Echoes in Churches
description: Riverside Church marked an anniversary yesterday. But the sparkle of birthdays and mort gageburnings was lacking.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: EDWARD H. ECKFELDT
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 3 Edward Hooper Eckfeldt Jr., who retired in 1965 as an as sistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, died today of can cer in Princeton Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 97 Bayard Lane.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS FOCUS ON VIOLENCE
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 3Many mattersfrom pensions to politicshave come up for discussion here at the annual convention of the New York City school supervisors, but the topic that appeared to dominate the threeday meeting was violence.

title: But in Elmira, 21,000 of 25,000 Rate CATV a Necessity
