description: ELMIRA, N.Y.Cable tele vision is as familiar to this city as the clang of church bells on Sunday. Of a pos sible 25,000 household cus tomers, 21,000 pay $4.50 month to be on the cable.

title: Cairo Reports Commandos Cross Suez Gulf in Attack
description: CAIRO, May 3Egyptian commandos crossed 20 miles of the Gulf of Suez last night to attack Israeli positions near the southern end of the Sinai pen insula, a military spokesman said today.

title: Policies on Trade Divide U.S. Officials
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  A high official has disclosed an intense difference of opin ion within the Government over the future of the nation's trade and balanceofpayments poli cies.

title: Marine Fathers' Group Honors Vietnam Dead
description: The names of Marines killed in Vietnam were read in Bat tery Park yesterday at memorial service sponsored by the Marine Corps Fathers Association.

title: Times Mirror Ready to Acquire Control of Newsday This Week
description: Newsday of Garden City, L.I., the nation's largest circu lation suburban newspaper, will pass into new ownership this week under a plan pre pared by the prospective pro prietor, The Times Mirror Com pany of Los Angeles.

title: Stokowski Receives an Ovation For Beethoven's 9th Symphony
description: At the end of the American Symphony Orchestra concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, Leopold Stokowski, who had just conducted Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, received an ovation.

title: CATBIRD CAPTURES OPEN JUMPER STAKE
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 3Tricolor Farm's Cat bird, with Barney Ward in the saddle, won the open jumper stake today at the concluding, session of the threeday St. Cle merit's horse show at Saratoga Race Track.

title: RICHARD BRASFIELD, CANCER SURGEON, 50
description: Dr. Richard D. Brasfield, a cancer surgeon here, died yes terday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 935 Esplanade, Pel ham, N.Y. His office was for merly at 115 East 61st Street.

title: New Yorker's Ulysses Inching Along
description: In the unlikely event that all goes well, The New Yorker may finish reprinting Ulysses about 90 years from now.

title: B.B. King Enlists Friends, Enchants Carnegie Audience
description: An unusual group of veteran blues singers was assembled at Carnegie Hall Saturday night for a program called B. B. King and His Friends.

title: State Could Save $140Million Under U.S. Welfare Reforms
description: New York State may save about $140million a year in the first year of the projected Nixon Administration welfare reform, starting July 1, 1971, Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administra tor, said yesterday.

title: Diplomats in Moscow Gloomy on Mideast and Asia
description: MOSCOW, May 3  The chances for a negotiated set tlement in either the Middle East or Southeast Asiathe world's two most inflammatory spotsseem more remote than ever to Western diplomats here.

title: PACE QUICKENING IN BOND MARKET
description: The credit markets, which shrugged off President Nixon's Cambodia speech last Friday, face another period of heavy financing activity this week.

title: Judy Carne, the Actress, Is Wed in Central Park
description: Light fog and drizzle set the stage at dawn yesterday in Central Park for the wed ding of Judy Came, a regular star on television's Laugh In show.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Rath Elected Coadjutor
description: NEWARK, May 3  The Right Rev. George E. Rath, suffragan (assistant) bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New ark, was elected coadjustor bishop yesterday at the annual diocesan convention in Trinity Cathedral. As coadjustor. Bish op Rath will automatically ?? the Right Rey. Leland Stark as bishop of the ?? when the latter ?? in 1973.

title: The Proceedings In the U. N. Today
Hussein Says U.S. Causes Movement Toward Conflict
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan said today that the Middle East is moving toward a bigpowers conflict because of what he termed United States indiffer ence and a onesided policy fa voring Israel.

title: New Haven Panthers Preached Calm
description: NEW HAVEN, May 3Black Panthers, who have built their organization on slogans of violence, have shown them selves adept at keeping the peace.

title: Lack of Kennedy Case Evidence Cited
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May 3No additional legal ac tion was taken against Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the drowning last year of Mary Jo Kopechne because the Massa chusetts officials who might have acted were apparently convinced there were no wit nesses and no evidence that would substantiate a new charge against him.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Intermediate Jumper Title To Hollandia's Dutch Bomb
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., May 3 Hollandia Farm's Dutch Bomb won the touch class and fin ished second in the knockdown andout to pile up 8 points and win the intermediate jumper championship today at the Rice Farm's horse show. Harry de Lcyer rode Dutch Bomb.

title: Enemy Attacks in Vietnam Are Heaviest in a Month
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 3Enemy forces staged widespread attacks, the heaviest in a month, in South Vietnam this weekend.

title: Ross Beats Acker, 62, 60 In Westchester Amateur Net
description: ARMONK, N.Y., May 3  Steve Ross of Brooklyn, who heads the draw, continued the defense of his title in the 37th annual Westchester County amateur championship tourna ment at Armonk Tennis Club today by defeating Reynolds Acker of Weestport, Conn., 62, 60, in the third round.

title: Rescue Craft in Caribbean Seek 22 Missing From Ditched Plane
description: Coast Guard and Navy ships and helicopters searched the choppy Caribbean off St. Croix through the night last night for persons missing from the Dutch Antillean Airlines DC9 jet that ditched with 63 per eons aboard on Saturday.

title: WILLIAM P. O'CONNOR
description: William P. O'Connor, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange and New York Cotton Exchange, died Saturday at his home, 150 East 69th Street. He was 90 years old. He retired as a partner in McDonnell & Company, stock brokers, 10 years ago.

title: Screen: Rustic Romance
ARMY IN NIGERIA HAS LITTLE TO DO
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 3 Chanting an exuberant cadence, a platoon of soldiers blocked traffic for several minutes the other day as they marched down a dusty highway in rural Western Nigeria, ignoring the honking of horns.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for the week follows:

title: Europe's Militant Unions Leaving Leaders Behind
description: PARIS, May 3  From the stateowned iron mines of northern Sweden to the sprawl ing Fiat plants in Turin, West ern Europe is experiencing an epidemic of wildcat strikes that mark the growing disaffection of workers with their tradition al union establishments.

title: F.D.A. Probe Needed
description: It has often been observed in Washington that after an initial period of enormous activity, Federal regula tory agencies tend to become captives of the industries they regulate, and to be more concerned with the industry's interests than with those of the public at large. But even cynics sharing this widely held view must have been shocked by the latest charges against the Food and Drug Administration, charges leveled by Dr. Howard L. Richardson, chief pathologist in the agency's Bureau of Science.

title: ASHE VANQUISHES GRAEBNER, 76, 61
description: KANSAS CITY, May 3 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond, topseeded and secondranked nationally, defeated the defend ing champion, Clark Graebner of New York, 76, 61, to cap ture the $2,500 first prize in the Glenwood Manor national invitation tourney today.

title: Paterson Lays Race Issue to Ambro
description: State Senator Basil A. Pater son charged yesterday that his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Gov ernor had injected the race is sue into the campaign by mak ing repeated disclaimers that he was seeking white support.

title: Busing Opponents Win Election For Charlotte's School Board
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 3 Liberal and moderate members of the CharlotteMecklenburg school board suffered a crush ing defeat yesterday at the hands of a slate of candidates pledged to fight busing for racial balance in schools here.

title: EXECUTIVE SHIFT LOOMS FOR I.O.S.
description: GENEVA, May 3Changes in the top management of the embattled Investors Overseas Services financial empire are expected to result from a meet ing of its board of directors. The meeting began today and will continue tomorrow.

title: Bruins Vanquish Blues, 61, in Opening Game of Stanley Cup Title Series
description: ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) Johnny Bucyk, nine days short of his 35th birthday, celebrated early today by scoring three goals and leading the Boston Bruins to a 61 victory over the St. Louis Blues in the open ing game of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup championship series.

title: REED'S KNEES GET V.I.P. TREATMENT
description: Ninety  nine exhausting games after opening the Na tional Basketball Association season on Oct. 14, the Knicks begin their finaland decisive week of play tonight at Madison Sauare Garden.

title: ELIZABETH TAKES U.S. SOCCER FINAL
description: Elizabeth of New Jersey, trailing by 10 at the half, came back strongly in the second period to defeat Croatia of Los Angeles, 21, and capture the United States Challenge Cup for the first time. The game was played at Randalls Island be fore more than 2,000 fans.

title: Carruthers and Agostini Capture Motorcycle Races
description: ADENAU, Germany, May 3 (UPI)  Kelvin Carruthers of Australia, the defending cham pion, won the season's first event of the world 250 C.C. motorcycling championship on the Nuerburgring track.

title: Strength of Goldberg
description: The three Democratic candi dates for Governor are all tak ing quickie telephone polls this week and they are all in terested in the same question: Is Arthur Goldberg in trouble?

title: Compulsive Escalation
description: With terrifying speed all the tragic errors of esca lation are being repeated in Southeast Asia. Once again a President elected on a pledge of extricating the United States from the Vietnamese morass is em barked on a delusive quest for peace through widen ing the war. And each plunge down that road to dis aster is followed posthaste by another and still an other in a dismal replay of the futility ushered in by the initial escalation after Pleiku in February 1965.

title: Kiermaier Resigns From Channel 13 for Politics
description: John W. Kiermaier resigned yesterday as president of the Edcational Broadcasting Corpo ration, operator of Channel 13, to seek the Democratic nomina tion for the House of Represen tatives from the Fourth Con gressional District of Connec ticut. He makes his home in Westport, Conn.

title: Residency Rule Asked for Hospital Abortions
description: A residency requirement de signed to keep New York City from becoming the nation's abortion capital has been in troduced in the City Council.

title: PICKUP INDICATED IN STEEL ORDERS
description: PITTSBURGH, May 3New orders for steel are coming in much faster than shipments are going out.

title: JEWS IN MEMORIAL TO 6 MILLION DEAD
description: There was no applause for the speeches. During most of the threehour ceremony all heads were bowed. The most persistant sound was that of sobbing.

title: James Gould Plans to Marry Margaret Hausman on June 21
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., May 3 Mr. and Mrs. Leo Hausman have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ilausman, to James Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gould of Cincinnati.

title: Advertising: A Spate of New Happenings
description: One adman has decided to make a big change. Another one already has. A Connecti cutbased agency is opening a New York showroom and a New York agency is opening its mouth.

title: CARINA IS WINNER IN TUNEUP RACE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 3 Richard S. Nye's Carina, out of the nearby Indian Harbor Yacht Club, was the winner on Long Island Sound today in the Riverside Yacht Club's annual Tuneup race for cruising yachts. There were 38 starters.

title: TROOPS SUBDUE STUDENTS IN OHIO
description: KENT, Ohio, Monday, May 4 National Guardsmen and the police drove students into their dormitories at Kent State Uni versity ltae last night, the third night of campus unrest.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOWARD ZINN, historian and profes sor of political science at Boston University, has never ben one to wait around for history to decide its next move. In the nineteenforties he fought in World War II as an Air Force bombardier.

title: Seek $15Million
description: Nine investors in Leeds Shoe, Inc., filed suit yesterday in Fed eral Court here seeking $15 million in damages from Genes co. Inc., officials and former officials of Leeds, and under writing concerns that include Goodbody & Co. and Walston & Co.

title: Investigation Request
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 Gov. James A. Rhodes tonight sent a telegram to J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, that said:

title: Women's Strike Called
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) The he National Organization for Women announced plans today for a national women's strike Aug. 26. It will commemorate the day 50 years ago that Ten nessee ratified the suffrage amendment and assured its adoption and celebrate the rise of the new feminist movement.

title: 75 Legal Aid Lawyers Strike to Protest Crisis Conditions in City Courts
description: Threequarters of the Legal Aid lawyers assigned to the city's Criminal Courtabout 75 lawyerswent on strike yester day, leaving dozens of defend ants with no representation and dozens of others with hastily assigned private counsel or Legal Aid trainees.

title: Transportation Aide Named
description: The appointment of Austin H. Emery as director of the Baby lon Region, New York State De partment of Transportation, has been announced by T. W. Park er, State Commissioner of Transportation. The region in cludes New York City and Long Island. Mr. Emery previ ously had been in charge of the Watertown region.

title: Strasberg Classes Scheduled
description: The Lee Strasberg Theater Institute will conduct classes in body movement and voice train ing for children between the ages of S to 14, starting June 6. They will be taught by Irma Sandrey and Irwin Stahl. The institute also will operate act ing classes for youngsters be tween 14 and 18 under the guidance of Walter Lott.

title: SAM ROSENTHAL, DRESS IMPORTER
description: Sam Rosenthal, a largevol ume dress manufacturer and pioneer in the import of popu larpriced women's knitwear from France, died yesterday after a long illness at his home, 22 Oakdale Road, Rockville Centre, L. I. He was 60 years old.

title: Salute to Media Set for Monday By A.C.L.U. Fund
description: Walter Cronkite will be honored Monday when the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation holds a benefit dinner at the Hilton as part of the A.C.L.U.'s 50thanniversary celebration.

title: New Books
description: African Renaissance, by Leonard Barnes (BobbsMerrill, $6.95). An appraisal of the political and economic structure of the new African nations.

title: Ohio Teamsters End Strike; New England Drivers Go Out
description: The teamsters in Cleveland ended their wildcat walkout yesterday, but drivers in sec tions of New England joined the ranks of striking truckers in the Midwest and California, The Associated Press reported.

title: Biographical Sketches of Persons Chosen for 54th Annual Pulitzer Prizes
description: SERVED as United States Secretary of State in the Truman Administration from 1949 to 1953.... Recalls that King Alfonso X of Spain once remarked that if he had been present at the creation he would have given some useful hints for the better ordering of the universe. ... The quote served for the title of his awardwinning book, Present at the Creation: My Years in the State Depart ment, published by W. W. Norton & Co., Inc.... Book deals with the period from 1941, when Mr. Acheson joined the State Department, until he left office at the end of the Truman years.... Period covered World War U, the postwar reconstruction of Europe, the Korean War, the formation and develop ment of the United Nations and the discovery of atomic power.... Born April 11, 1893, in Middletown, Conn. ... Lives at 2805 P Street, N. W., Washington.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS CHURCHES' RIGHT TO TAX EXEMPTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  The Supreme Court ruled 7 to today that laws that exempt church property from taxation do not violate the Constitution's prohibition against state sup port of religion.

title: LEHMANN DELAYS PREAKNESS ENTRY
description: PARIS, Ky., May 4 (UPI) The owner of Dust Command er, the Kentucky Derby cham pion, said today he would wait until Wednesday to decide whether he would enter the colt in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on May 16.

title: WAR AND ECONOMY SPUR STOCK DROPS
description: Uneasiness over the United States involvement in Cambo dia and the bombing of North Vietnam, plus continuing un certainty about the nation's business outlook, created a mood of deep pessimism on Wall Street yesterday and sent the securities markets into a tailspin.

title: A.H.L. PLAYOFF
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAME

title: Slanted Oil Wells Drilled in Alaska to Save Costs
description: PRUDHOE BAY, AlaskaIn biting, winddriven snow, oil men of many companies here are drilling a succession of crooked wells.

title: Congress and the War ...
description: President Nixon's sudden extension of the Vietnam War into Cambodia, without consent of Congress and against the advice of many members including a major ity of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, brings sharply to the fore a constitutional crisis that has been long in the making.

title: F.T.C. CHALLENGES UNITED FRUIT DEAL
description: The United Fruit Company said yesterday it had received notice from the Federal Trade Commission indicating that the government agency considers the acquisition of United Fruit by the AMK Corporation as illegal.

title: Another 1929?
description: The sharp drop in the stock market yesterday was undoubtedly a reflection of the uneasiness over the Cambodian affair and international reaction to it. The continuing downslide of the market in recent months, however, has conjured up, in the minds of some observers, the specter of another 1929. Is there any justification for such an alarming comparison?

title: 37 COLLEGE CHIEFS URGE NIXON MOVE FOR PROMPT PEACE
description: The presidents of 37 colleges and universities urged President Nixon yesterday to demon strate unequivocally your de termination to end promptly the United States military in volvement in Southeast Asia.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT KILLING 21 ARABS
description: JERUSALEM, May 4Israeli military authorities announced today that an Israeli patrol sur prised and killed 21 armed Palestinian infiltrators shortly after they crossed the Jordan River into Israelicontrolled territory last night.

title: INCREASE FOUND IN MARGIN CALLS
description: The sharp decline in stock prices is forcing banks and brokers to make an increasing number of margin calls on their customers, but forced sales of collateral to meet outstanding debts do not appearup until now at leastto have been sufficiently large to have been a significant factor in the mar ket break.

title: Interior Agency Upgraded
description: WASEHINGTON, May 4 (AP) Secretary of Interior Walter J. Hickel is renaming and up grading the Office of Marine Resources and bringing it un der his direct supervision, he announced today. It will now be called the Office of Marine Affairs.

title: Astros Beat Cubs, 72
description: HOUSTON, May 4 (AP)  Jim Bouton stopped Chicago on six hits and scored two runs tonight, pacing the Houston Astros to a 72 victory while extending the Cubs' losing string to four games.

title: Child Sleeping in Back Seat Is Released by a Car Thief
description: A Florida automobile thief accidentally abducted a 4year old girl, but released her min utes later when he apparently discovered her sleeping in the back seat, The Palm Beach PostTimes of West Palm Beach reports.

title: SPONSORS DOUBT MEETS UNTIL 1971
description: The decline in the stock mar ket has affected the timetable for the start of a professional track and field tour, its or ganizers said yesterday.

title: Steady Growth Is Reported In AllNight Food Markets
description: Convenience fond stores  neighborhood markets that stay open long hours  should Mu be in number by 1975, accord ing to the president of the na tion's secondlargest chain, JacksonAtlantic, Inc., United Press International reports.

title: NIGERIA LOOKING TO CIVILIAN RULI
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 4 With their bloody civil war nearly four months behind them, some Nigerians are be ginning increasingly to think of politics, and the prospect of returning the country to civil ian rule.

title: PRISONER IN BRITAIN LEAVES WITH VISITOR
description: POOLE, EnglandColin Hon ey, governor of Dorchester Prison, reports that security at the prison has been tightened after a prisoner walked out through the main gate with vis itors.

title: Limits Predicted for Parks
description: CRYSTAL BAY, Nev., April 4 (AP)  Limitations may soon have to be placed on the num her of visitors to Yellowstone, the Grand Canyon and other national parks, the director of the United States Bureau of Outdoor Recreation predicted.

description: Mick Moynihan scored 6 points to lead New York to a 138 victory over County Offaly yesterday at Gaelic Park in the Bronx before a crowd of 6,241 in the windup of their two game totalpointGaelic football series.

title: TIME DENIES CHARGE BY WOMEN EMPLOYES
description: Time, Inc., the magazine and book publishing enterprise, de nied yesterday charges that it discfiminated against women employes on its editorial staff. The number of women working as editors, writers and corre spondents for its magazines, it asserted, has risen steadily over the past few years and we have every hope and expecta tion that this trend will be con tinued.

title: Merger of N.B.A. And A.B.A. Stayed By U.S. Injunction
description: A Federal judge signed a pre liminary injunction order yes terday barring a merger of the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association.

title: U.S. Track Teams Going Abroad for Two Meets
description: Two tracks of American track and field athletes will leave this week for meets over seas.

title: Blues, Despite Rout by Bruins, To Shadow Orr Again Tonight
description: ST. LOUIC, May 4 (AP) Scotty owman, coach of the St Louis Blues, said today that his stratedy to stop Bobby Orr would remain in effect for to morrow night's second game here in the bestofseven Na tional Hockey League Stanley Cup title series against Boston. Coach Harry Sinden of the Bruins isn't complaining about it one bit.

title: Brown Absent in Court: Arrest Ordered

title: PEKING'S DECLARATION
description: TOKYO, May 4 (AP)Fol lowing, in translation, are excerpts from a statement by the Chinese Communist Gov ernment on the United States troop movements into Cam bodia, as distributed by Hsinhua, Peking's official press agency.

title: Antimony Find Reorpted
description: John Lawrence, president of two small, affiliated mining companies, the United States Antimony Corporation and Agau Mines, Inc., said yester day that the former concern had intersected substantial mineralization of antimony through preliminary core drill ing and tunneling on property near Thomson Falls, Mont. An timony is a scarce metallic ele ment with applications in chemistry, medicine and aero space alloys.

title: Finch Says H.E.W. Outlay Will Soon Surpass Defense
description: Robert H.Finch, secretary of Health, education and Welfare, predicted yesterday that Fed eral expenditures for the na tion's wellbeing will some day overtake spending for defense.

title: Red Leaders Elude Sweep
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 4Senior United States military and civilian officials here are beginning to scale down their definitions of suc cess for the fourdayold Amer icanSouth Vietnamese sweep into the Fishhook area of Cam bodia.

title: GLENN DEPRESSED BY STUDENT RIOTS
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, May 4  The little plane bounced and wobbled In the turbulent air. John H. Glenn Jr., a passenger, sat next to his daughter, Mrs. Michael Power, looking grim and distracted.

title: Study of LSD Spurs Suspicions Of Drug's Link to Birth Defects
description: The first extensive, longterm study comparing the incidence of birth defects with parental use of LSD has concluded that the drug must be seriously considered as a possible muta genan agent that produces genetic changes In cells.

title: UNREST IS CURBED IN LAWRENCE, KAN.
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., May 2 What we're looking at here, quite frankly, is a microcosm of what's happening all over this country, says Leonard Harrison, a leader and the un hesitating spokesman of Law rence's black community.

title: Market Place:
description: ANTHONY GAUBIS, an in vestment adviser who had the good sense as a young lad to be bearish in early 1929 and then bullish in 1937, thinks the days of gloom and doom are about over.

title: No Economic Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 Norman F. Dacey, author of the onetime best seller How to Avoid Probate, was cen sured today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for attempting to sell mutual fund shares without making proper disclosures about them.

title: Fatah Says Fight Goes On
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 4 Al Fatah reported tonight that nineteen men had been killed or wounded in a continuingi battle in the northern Jordan valley.

title: Briton Is Found in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 4, (Reuters)  Brian Lea, the British diplomat who had been reported kidnapped on Satur day, has been found alive, the Internal Affairs Minister Basil Bataringaya, said today on television. He gve no details on the case of Mr. Lea, who is a first secretary in the British High Commission.

title: Rath Elected Coadjutor
description: NEWARK, May 3  The Right Rev. George E. Rath, suffragan (assistant) bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New ark, was elected coadjustor bishop Sunday at the annual diocesan convention in Trinity Cathedral. As coadjustor, Bish op Rath will automatically succeed the Right Rev. Leland Stark as bishop of the diocese when the latter retires in 1973.

title: STAR HURTS THIGH IN FIRST QUARTER
description: The completely subjective ex perience that basketball can be was demonstrated vividly last night as the New York Knick erbockers, after losing Willis Reed through injury, made up a 16point deficit and defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 107 100

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: War Baffles an Upstate Village So Much Its People Say Little
description: ALTAMONT, N. Y., May 4 There is a hesitancy about discussing the war in Vietnam in this little upstate village of 1,500 people. There is, even more, a feeling of futility in even trying to understand what is involved.

title: DYNAMIC QUEBEC NEW LEADER'S AIM
description: QUEBEC, May 2The new Premier of Quebec, whose elec tion victory on April 29 was a defeat for the province's sep aratists, regards them never theless as a fact of political life that must be given due recognition.

title: Five Nuns Hurt in Fires
description: LAWRENCE, Mass., May 4 (AP)Five nuns were hospital ized today, one in serious con dition, after a series of suspi cious fires broke out in the early morning hours. The nuns, members of the order of Gray Nuns of Montreal, were from the Protectory of Mary Im maculate Nursing Home in Lawrence, but were living in a private house because of in sufficient room at the nursing home.

title: A War-Waging Computer Is Hero-Villain of 'Forbin'
description: EARLY in "The Forbin Project," Colossus, a supercomputer that controls the United States's military defense system, goes into an unprogrammed rage and launches a missile toward the Soviet Union. The President of the United States turns to Forbin, the man who invented Colossus, and gives him a petulant look that seems to say: "There goes the stock market . . . . the urban vote . . . . my golf game . . . .my image. You've made a fool out of me."It's one of the appealing things about "The Forbin Project," an unpretentious science fiction film with a satiric point of view, that when the world is about to blow up, the President of the United States can only bring to the occasion something akin to embarrassment.The film, which opened yesterday at the Cinema Rendezvous, is no "Dr. Strangelove," but it's full of surprising moments of humor and intelligence, a practically perfect movie to see when you want to go to a movie and have nothing special in mind.It may also be a practically perfect movie for these times, since its villain, who may really be its hero, is a computer, roughly the size of the Astrodome, in the Rocky Mountains and so cleverly protected by electronic devices and radiation belts that it can never be disconnected, or put out of office, even when it mysteriously assumes the prerogatives of the men who made it.James Bridge's screenplay is based on D. F. Jones's novel, "Colossus," published in 1967, the year before Stanley Kubrick gave us "2001: A Space Odyssey," which also had to do a machine so brilliant that it goes positively ape. The time of "The Forbin Project" is never specifically stated, but everything suggests neo-contemporary. The President, who is always rather ostentatiously accompanied by a black aide, has the hairline and profile of the late John F. Kennedy, and the rhetorical gifts of his two successors.Joseph Sargent, the director, and Stanley Chase, the producer, earlier collaborated on "The Hell With Heroes" (1968), but nothing in that terrible little movie suggested they were capable of a film as nicely disciplined as this."The Forbin Project" has a bit of a personal story, but it's never meant to obscure its real concern: How Colossus and its (his?) Soviet counterpart, Guardian, link up memory banks to blackmail the world into an era of terrifying Orwellian, machine-monitored peace. On second thought, I'm not sure it's all that terrifying, in view of the alternatives. Both the American President and the Soviet First Chairman are represented as un-imaginative political hacks, capable only of managing the news.The movie is full of marvelous, absurd dialogue "This thing," says Forbin as he watches Colossus absorb information, "is deep in finite obsolutes!") and science fiction artifacts like TV screens, blinking warning lights, keyboards and all the other paraphernalia of places called command headquarters and situation rooms.The cast is headed by Eric Braeden (Forbin), Susan Clark (the beautiful scientist no sci-fi movie can do without) and Gordon Pinsent (the President). They take themselves seriously (as I do) which could not have been easy since most of the time they are only required to react to a mad, very photogenic machine. This must be worse than playing opposite a small child, or a dog, or a porpoise.

title: 2 TEAMS RESURVEY GULF COAST ISLES
description: WASHINGTON  The Coast and Geodetic Survey has an nounced the completion of the first phase of a Federal geo detic survey of Mississippi's Gulf coast and islands off Mis sissippi and Alabama. Addition al surveys in the area are planned for next year.

title: U.S. VISA IS DENIED TO WIDOW OF DUBOIS
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Justice Department has denied a request for a visa to enter the United States by the widow of W.E.B. DuBois after the State Department found no reason to deny the request.

title: Big Base Area Discovered
description: LANDING ZONE NORTH ONE, Cambodia, May 4Sol diers from this northernmost American outpost in the drive against enemy sanctuaries in Cambodia today reached the site of what is believed to be the largest North Vietnamese base area discovered in the operation, which began last Friday.

title: RESCUE BY BANKS OF I.O.S. RUMOREID
description: GENEVA May 4The 23 man board of Bernard Corn feld's beleaguered mutual fund empire, Investors Overseas Services, was locked in a se cret meeting for the third straight day today amid rumors that a group of European banks was being called on in a rescue operation.

title: U.S. Artists at Italian Show Protest Move in Cambodia
description: ROME, May 4Guests at the opening of an art show at the American Academy here to night found all but a few ex hibits covered with black cloth in a protest against United States military intervention in Cambodia.

title: U.S. Hopes to Continue Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Nixon Administration is eager to continue negotiations with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries despite the tensions in Indochina and the Middle East, State Depart ment officials said today.

title: HARVARD IS RATED STRONGEST RIVAL
description: The University of Pennsyl navia's newly acquired status as the No. 1 power in inter collegiate rowing received rec ognition yesterday when the Red and Blue varsity was seed ed No. 1 for Saturday's Eastern sprint championships on Lake Quinsigamond at Worcester, Mass.

title: In the Field: Grunts, Groans and Jokes
description: LANDING ZONE NORTH ONE, Cambodia, May 4The day after the grunts reached this roadside chunk of jungle they were cracking Cambodia jokes. And some reararea types put in an appearance to see if anyone wanted to reenlist.

title: Peking Assails U.S. on Cambodia
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, May 5The Chinese Communist Government denounced the United States yesterday for sending troops into Cambodia and pledged support for the three Indochinese peoples. in their patriotic struggle against American forces until complete victory.

title: Back in the Kremlin's Spotlight
description: IN denouncing United States policy in Indochina at an unusual news conference yes terday, Premier Aleksei Niko layevich Kosygin indirectly also affirmed the division of functions that has marked the collective leadership of the Soviet Union since Ni kita S. Khrushchev fell from power in 1964. Ever since Leonid I. Brezhnev, the party lead hews er, and Mr. Ko sygin divided the party and government leader ship jointly held by Mr. Krushchev. Mr. Kosygin, as the head of government, has been the chief Soviet spokes man on foreign affairs.

title: Simmon Company Accused Of Hospital PriceFixing
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Simmons Company of New York City, one of the na tion's largest manufacturers of hospital furnishings, was ac cused by the Justice Depart ment today of pricefixing.

title: A SCIENTIST FINDS ECOLOGY EXCESSES
description: WASHINGTON, May 4A nationally known population expert decried today what he termed the efforts of some angry ecologists and Johnny comelately's to scare the na tion into cleaning up the en vironment and slowing Amer ican population growth.

title: Washington: For the Record
News Summary and Index
description: Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union yesterday assailed President Nixon's decision to send American forces into Cam bodia and he charged the United States forces with using scorchedearth tactics. Mr. Kosygin cast doubts on Mr. Nixon's sin cerity in seeking negotiations and also hint ed that the American action imperiled chances for success of the talks in Vienna on limiting strategic arms. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: NewAuto Pace Is Seen Warming Up as Four Makers Issue Data
description: DETROIT, May 4New car sales warmed up in the final third of April, the car makers reported today, but even though they are better they aren't very good.

title: Correspondent Named To Military News Post
description: Drew Middleton, European affairs correspondent of The New York Times, was named the newspaper's military cor respondent yesterday.

title: Cahill Signs Mortgage Bill, Begins Test of Its Legality
description: TRENTON, May 4 (AP)  Gov. William T. Cahill signed into law today a measure cre ating a state mortgage finance agency. He said that he would seek an immediate court test of the statute's legality.

title: Villagers in Nepal Believe Infant Is Reincarnated God
description: KATMANDUN Nepal ZAPzI A baby born with an abnormald ly long nose in the Marang district of southeast. Nepal was immediately accepted by vil lagers as the reincarnation of the Hindu god Ganesh, the ele phantheaded son of Lord Shiva.

title: Baseball Hires GMan
description: Francis J. Gallant, a long time member of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation, has been added to the baseball security staff, Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: THE idea that a fourfour trump fit is automatically more desirable than alterna tives such as fivethree or fivefour has only limited validity. It is true that the fourfour fit will sometimes permit an extra trick to be made because the fivecard suit makes a discard or two possible in the opposite hand, but there are other consid erations.

title: A Witness for Look Contradicts Alioto
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4  Frank Greenleaf, who identified himself as a selfemployed truck driver from Sacramento, testi fied today that Jimmy Fratianno had taken him to see Joseph L. Alioto, who greeted Frati anno as a friend.

title: Books of The Times
description: Escape!

title: I.M.F. Did Not Buy Africa Gold in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The International Monetary Fund reported today that it bought no gold from South Africa in April.

title: 3 in Bombing Plot Plead Guilty Here
description: Samuel J. Melville, Jane L. Alpert and John D. Hughey 3d pleaded guilty yesterday as the selfstyled revolutionaries were about to stand trial on charges of conspiring to bomb Federal buildings here last fall.

title: Deborah Morris Bent Be trothed
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 4 The engagement of Miss De borah Morris Bent to Jerome Bowden Martin has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Horace Brook Bent of Bryn Mawr and Annisquam, Mass.

title: A Correction
description: The quotation for the stock of the Continental Materials Corporation in today's issue is incorrect. Late last night, it was confirmed that the company's stock closed yesterday at 2, un changed from its closing price on Friday. The correction was received too late in the Amex tables.

title: SHAKESPEARE PLAYS PLANNED AT LIBRARY
description: WASHINGTON  A bit of Shakespearre's England nestles among the jurists and legisla torrs on Capitol Hill.

description: An advertising man, con cerned that the country is falling apart, has formed an agency that will give a fifth of its time to organizations opposed to the war in South east Asia, racism, waste and poverty.

title: ART INSTITUTE BUYS PUPILS BOTTLE CAPS
description: KANSAS CITY, (AP)  The Kansas City Art Institute paid $25 for one million bottle caps collected by thirdgrade pupils, and the caps may appear in pop art.

title: Amex Prices Drop To TwoYear Low
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell to their lowest level in more than two years yesterday as de clines outnumbered advances by almost five to one in slow trading.

title: Setback to Sentimentality
description: THIS year's Kentucky Derby made about as much impact on public con sciousness as a soggy towel dropping to a lockerroom floor. No dent. The emo tional appeal was missing, except for that minority who had a few bob riding on the nose of the upset winnerDust Com mander. His background had little distinc tion and his owner, trainer and jockey were comparative strangers.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: Dayan Says Israel Wants Restoration Of the CeaseFire
description: HAIFA, Israel, May 4 (AP) Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said at a student rally here to day that the Israeli Government is ready to reestablish an un conditional conditional and unlimited cease fire even if this will enable Egypt to reorganize and put up SAM3 missile sites.

title: 91and 182Day Bill Rates Rise At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Treasury bill rates advanced to the highest levels since early February at today's auction, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: Grim Parents Recall Daughter's Comment
description: PITTSBURGH, May 4Less than an hour after learning that their 19yearold daugh ter had been shot to death by National Guardsmen at Kent State University, Arthur and Doris Krause and their 15yearold daughter, Laurie, emerged from their home in outlying Churchill Borough this afternoon.

title: Priests in France Over 40
description: PARIS (Reuters)More than 75 per rent of French priests are over 40 year of age, ac cording to the Nationat Inssti ture of Demographts Student.

title: US. STEEL CHIEF SEES PRICE RISE
description: HOUSTON, May 4 (AP)  The chief executive of the United States Steel Corpora tion said today higher steel orices are needed.

title: A.M.C. Reporfs Deficit of $10,067,000 for the Firsf Quarter
description: DETROIT, May 4  The American Motors Corporation plunged deeply into the red in, the March quarter, reporting today a net loss or $10,067,000 or 41 a share, contrasted to a net income of $735,000, 4 cents a share a year before.

title: Rhodes Urges Law and Order; Says Taft Is Soft on Violence
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio., May 4 With campus upheavals provid ing the opportunity, Gov. James A. Rhodes has seized upon law and order as a campaign issue in the closing days of a close Senate primary contest with Representative Robert Taft Jr.

title: Mrs. Stavros Niarchos, 44, Dies; Wife of Greek Shipping Tycoon
description: ATHENS, May 4Eugenia Niarchos, the 44yearold wife of Stavros Niarchos, the Greek shipping millionaire, died early today at Spetsopoula, her hus band's privately owned islet 56 miles southwest of Athens.

title: Ryan Will Face Dodgers As Mets Open Home Stay
description: If mathematical progression means anything, Nolan Ryan will pitch a four hitter and walk eight batters tonight when the Mets meet the Los Angeles Dodgers in the opener of an eightgame home stand.

title: Fanny May Results Announced
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Mortgage prices held essentially steady at this week's auction, the Federal National Mort gage Association said today.

title: Laughs Pepper Ghoulish Bluebeard
Reds Purchase Ward
description: CINCINNATI, May 4 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds purchased the contract of Jay Ward, 31yearold infielderoutfielder, from their Indianapolis farm team.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Threat of MIRV

title: Detroit to Show Gas Safety Bag at Auto Meeting
description: DETROIT, May 4The American automobile indus try will show the results of its research on the air bag, a radical but yet untried safety system, to the car makers of the world at a conference next week.

title: Trade Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, announced today that hearings would begin next Monday on trade legislation  the first move in what could be a momentous struggle over the nation's trade policy.

title: President Assailed By Fulbright Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee complained today that the Nixon Administra tion, by sending American troops into Cambodia with out the consent or knowledge of Congress, was usurping the warmaking powers of Congress.

title: Club Too Free for Parents
description: EASTLEIGH, England (UPI) Parents here, filed protests with the local vicar after teen agers told them drinking and drugtaking were part of the activities in the church's free expression youth club.

title: Catch Is First in 17 Years
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England (UPI)Miss Ruby Graves, presi dent of the local seafishing club, caught her first fish in 17 years.

title: Death of a Parkway
description: Once again the voice of the buzz saw is heard in the woodland; the insatiable mouth of the bulldozer is chewing up the countryside.

title: Javits Says U.S. Tolerates Repression
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  In his strongest criticism of the Nixon Administration to date, Senator Jacob K. Javits charged tonight that the threat of re pression in the country was for the first time being toler ated, if not actually condoned, at the highest level of our Federal Government.

title: Rate of Heart Disease Low In Rich Los Angeles Area
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)Bel Air, one of the most affluent residential sections of Los An geles, has the lowest heart disease rate among 76 Los An geles County areas studied by a university research team.

title: Decline in Opium Addiction Is Predicted in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE (UPI)  The opium problem in Singapore will be reduced by ninetenths in about two decades, accord ing to a customs narcotics ex pert.

title: A.T&T. IS AT 9.19%
Ford to Aid Research on Steam Engine for Autos
description: The Ford Motor Company and Thermo Electron, Inc., of Waltham, Mass., have an nounced the signing of a five year agreement under which Ford will invest in the develop ment of a prototype steam automobile engine.

title: DAVID WDOWINSKI, PSYCHOANALYST, 73
description: Dr. David Wdowinski, a psy choanalyst who was a leader of the resistance fighters in the Warsaw Ghetto, collapsed and died Sunday in Tel Aviv after delivering a speech marking the 27th anniversary of the War saw Ghetto uprising. He was 73 years old and lived at 27 West 72d Street.

title: Kosygin Is Grave at News Parley
description: MOSCOW, May 4In this capital where official events are often preceded by ru mors about them, there were no advance hints today that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin would hold the first news conference by a Soviet head of government here in almost 10 years.

title: Westchester County Center Has Spring Antiques Fair
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 4The spring edition of the Eastern States Antique Fair opened here today at the Westchester County Center with a bountiful supply of collectibles, from pri mitive folk art to elegant draw ing room furbishings.

title: School Board Warns of Arrests To Halt Disruptions of Meetings
description: The Board of Education moved yesterday to keep dis turbances from disrupting its public meetings, as they have in recent months.

title: Arabia Bans Miniskirt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP)King Faisal of Saudi Arabia has banned the miniskirt and other indecent dress for women such as shorts, trousers and the like, the Saudi Arabian press reports.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 game series)

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: KOSYGIN ATTACKS NIXON FOR MOVING G.I.'S TO CAMBODIA
description: MOSCOW, May 4Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin today as sailed President Nixon for hav ing sent American forces into Cambodia. He warned that the action might lead to a further complication in the interna tional scene and a worsening of SovietAmerican relations.

title: Music
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 4For the third annual Romantic Festival sponsored by Butler University at Clowes Hall, there have been some changes. Those changes are not in the musical approach the festival continues to present all kinds of forgotten music of the 19th century but in the forces involved.

title: TV Medics Too Perfect
description: LONDON (Canadian Press) Doctors have complained about the portrayal of their profes sion in a British Broadcasting Corporation soap opera: the television medics are too per fect. The magazine World Medi cine said the characters should be shown making mistakes, as they do in real life.

title: Telegrams on Cambodia
description: In the three days immediate ly following President Nixon's television address to the nation last Thursday night on the Cambodian situation, about 100,000 opinion telegrams were sent to Washington, the West ern Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday. The com pany said that about 52,000 telegrams were sent to the President and approximately 48,000 to members of Congress.

title: Phone Book Goes Long Way
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)The telephone directory in the na tion's capital devotes a full page to a hunch of tables, ena bling one to match dates with days of the month to the year 2050.

title: Brandt's Burdens
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt's effort to improve relations with West Germany's Communist neighbors was undertaken with the knowledge that it involved polit ical risksas well as possible gainsat home and abroad. But some unwelcome surprises are developing on the risk side, the latest being an administrative blunder that has weakened Mr. Brandt's essential coalition partner, Foreign Minister Walter Scheel.

title: Woman's Exchange to Meet
description: The annual luncheon meet ing of he Federation of Wo man's Exchanges will be held Thursday at the Scarsdale Golf Club. The meeting, to be spon sored by the Scarsdale Wo man's Exchange, will offer a display of handwork by needy and elderly people sold in Wo man's Exchange shops throughout the counry.

title: Tots Head for Fair
description: LONDON (UPI)Threeyear old Amanda Smith wanted her baby brother Georgia, 23 months, to see a local fair, so she set out with himboth dressed only in pajama tops. They were found a halfmile away, several hours later, cold and hungry.

title: Royal Family Back in Britain
description: LONDON, May 4 (UPI) Queen Elizabeth II, her hus band, Prince Philip, and their daughter, Princess Anne, re turned today to a warm and sunny Britain from a two month, 40,000mile tour of Aus tralia and New Zealand.

title: CAPTAIN PERFORMS MARRIAGE ON A JET
description: Miss Irene Hirsch and Rob ert F. Lucia planned to be mar ried in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, but their plans were continually frustrated by flights that were booked full, and the long waitingperiod re quired between the issuance of the license and the ceremony.

title: JUSTICES SUPPORT EROTICMAIL CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of a 1967 law that permits any private citizen to stop mail order com panies from sending advertise ments that he considers eroti cally arousing or sexually pro vocative.

title: Truckers Get Theft Manual
description: A manual on all types of theft prevention within the trucking industry has been produced by the National As sociation of Transportation Se curity Officers, the magazine Fleet Owner reports. The man ual can be obtained for $2 from Cecil D. Webster, secre tary treasurer of the National Association of Transportation Security Officers, Associated Transport, Box 619, Burlington, N.C.

title: Kosygin Conference Excerpts
description: MOSCOW, May 3 (UPI) Following, in translation dis tributed by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, are ex cepts from Premier Alehsei N. Kosygin's statement on the movement of American forces into Cambodia:

title: Reinsurer Fills Posts
description: Willcox, Baringer & Co., Inc., reinsurance brokers, yesterday named R. D. Scott and K. A. Hecken as senior vice presi dents. Mr. Scott joined the company in 1963 as a vice pres ident. Mr. Hecken joined it last month after nine years with Johnson & Higgins, insurance brokers.

title: Dyce Working Harder Than Ever For Distance Races Just Ahead
description: The two talents a success ful runner must develop thro ugh hard work are strength and speed. Right?

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: THE Environmental Defense Fund, Inc. a nonprofit organization of conservation ists, scientists and lawyers dedicated to the protection of our environment, needs assistance in its efforts to obtain working funds through public membership.

title: 4 Kent State Students Killed by Troops
description: KENT, Ohio, May 4Four students at Kent State Univer sity, two of them women, were shot to death this afternoon by a volley of National Guard gun fire. At least 8 other students were wounded.

title: FijiGetsIndependenceOct.10
description: LONDON, May 4 (Reuters) Britain will grant independence to the South Pacific colony of Fiji on Oct. 10. The decesion was made by a constitutional conference attended by Lord Shepherd, Foreign and Com monwealth Office Minister and the 36 members of the Fiji Legislature.

title: Executive Changes
description: Charles M. Trunz Jr., has been elected to the new post of executive vice president of the Horn and Hardart Company.

title: 5% Social Security Benefit Rise Clears Ways and Means Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The House Ways and Means Commit tee voted today to increase So cial Security benefits by 5 per cent for some 25.5 million Amer icans, effective next Jan. 1.

title: Judge Gives 3 Hitchhikers Choice of Getting Haircuts
description: EL CENTRO, Calif. (AP)  When three college students were brought before Municipal Court Judge Hugh Keating for thumbing rides, he looked them ver, and advised:

title: New Data Concern Formed
description: The Western Union Corpora tion, the Data Research Corpo ration and Western Union Computer Utilities, Inc., an nounced yesterday formation of a new company to be known as International Data Termi nals, Inc., which will engage in the development and manufac ture of a line of data terminal equipment. Western Union will acquire a 50 per cent interest for $500,000 and the two others will each hold 25 per cent in terests for $250,000 apiece.

title: 13 of 14 on Plane Killed In Crash Near Coast Base
description: HAMILTON AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 4 (UPI)A twinengine Air Force plane smashed into rolling hill coun try today minutes after it took off from this northern Califor nia base, and 13 of its 14 occu pants were killed.

title: HICKEL DENOUNCES OIL COMPANY HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Walter J. Rickel, Secretary or the Interior, exploded in anger today at what he called the arrogant attitude of an oil company president toward the pollution of coastal waters.

title: 2 INJURED BY BOMB IN BROOKLYN STORE
description: Two women were slightly in jured when a bomb exploded yesterday in the Sears, Roe buck & Co. store at Bedford Avenue and Beverly Road in Flatbush.

title: Theater
60 Years of Quiet at Kent State Are Shattered in Era of Protest
description: Political demonstrations, such as the one that resulted in the deaths of four students yes terday, are a relatively new phenomenon on Kent State University's attractive 790acre eampus.

title: MISS HAYNIE WINS SHREVEPORT GOLF
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May 4 (UPI)  Sandra Haynie shot a par 72 on the final round today and won her second consecu tive $15,000 Shreveport invita tion ladies golf tournament with a 214 total.

title: Israeli Slain in Attack At Embassy in Paraguay
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 4 (AP)Two men fired on Is raeli Embassy personnel to day, killing one secretary and seriously wounding another.

title: Data Processing Financial And Its President Cut Ties
description: The Data Processing Financial and General Corporation an nounced yesterday that the company and Archie J. McGill, its president and a director, have mutually agreed to sever their relationship.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: Apprentice.

title: Bonn Predicts Its G.N.P. Will Rise by 12% in 1970
description: BONN, May 4 (Reuters) The State Secretary in the Eco nomics Ministry, Klaus Dieter Arndt, said today that West Germany's gross national prod uct would rise this year by a nominal 12 per cent. This compared with an earlier prediction in the government's annual eco nomic survey for 1970 of 9 to 10 per cent.

title: In the Showrooms, It Was the Midi ...
description: DONALD BROOKS decided not to shilly  shally around. He simply made the most razzledazzle clothes in the most razzledazzle colors anybody could remember. And then he decided his own showroom wasn't big enough to show them off, so he hired a hall.

title: REDS WIN, 7 TO 3, FOR 6TH STRAIGHT
description: CINCINNATI, May 44 (UPI) Lee May and Pete Rose homered to give the unbeaten Gary Nolan his fifth victory tonight as the Cincinnati Reds boosted their winning streak to six straight with a 73 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Rent Rise Urged in Residential Hotels
description: The Rent Guidelines Board has recommended to the City Council that rents in residential hotels here be permitted to rise by no more than 8 to 10 pee cent a year.

title: Saigon Police Clear Cahthodian Mission And Major Pogada
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 5  Policemen cleared the Vietnam National National Pagoda and the Cam bodian mission building during curfew hours early this morn ing.

title: The Woman With Perfume Samples Was Rose Kennedy
description: IT'S her, it's her. She's so tiny. Look how beau tiful she looks. I touched her. She's the richest woman in the world.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED IN THE WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, May  Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices April 21, 1970, to April 28, 1970.

title: WEST OBOE RECITAL SHOWS HIS MASTERY
description: Philip West played the oboe so well, so consistently, in his recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall that right from the beginning it was possible to pay attention to the music. Since the oboe is one of the least tractable of solo instru ments, that is no small praise. Mr. West, one of the city's leading freelance professionals handled the oboe with a vir tually faultless technique, his tone as smooth in the top reg ister as in the bottom, and never forced into the usual reedy whines and honks. tone as smooth in the top reg ister as in the bottom, and never forced into the usual reedy whines and honks.

title: Leeds United Is Fined $12,000 For Fielding Weak Soccer Club
description: LONDON, May 4 (AP)The Leeds United soccer club was fined $12,000a British record today for fielding weak teams in league games at the peak of its hectic season.

title: WHEAT FUTURES STAGE A RETREAT
description: There was no indication that the commodities markets were affected to any great extent by the developments in the stock market yesterday. Volume con tinued at about the same pace it had been running lately and price movements varied in tra ditional patterns.

title: Horse Trough Is Monument
description: BULAWAYO, Rhodesia (AP) A castiron Victorian horse watering trough has been de clared a national monument here.

title: Nixon Says Violence Invites Tragedy
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  President Nixon today deplored the deaths of four students at Kent State University and said they should remind us all once again that when dissent turns to violence it invites tragedy.

title: BOARD RELNSTATES 7 HUNTER STUDENTS
description: Seven Hunter College ?? dents, suspended last week by Mrs. Jacqueline G. Wexler, president of the college, were reinstated last night by a judi cial hearing hoard composed of four students and three faculty members.

title: FANNY MAY SHIFTS ITS TOP OFFICIALS
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The Federal National Mort gage Association today shuffled some of its top officers in a move, A. Oakley Hunter, presi dent of the association, said was in anticipation of comple tion of reorganization from a Government agency to a pri vate corporation.

title: In The Nation: What Can Congress Do?
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Many members of Congress, in both parties, now are reacting to President Nixon's reescalation of the Vietnamese war with as much anger as the doves used to direct at Lyndon B. John son. One useful but limited re sult is already apparent.

title: Representation in Congress Urged for Capital Voters
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy pro posed today that a constitu tional amendment, authorizing representation in Congress for the District of Columbia, be at tached to the pending plan for direct election of the President.

title: Richardson Scores Soviet For Intervention in Europe
description: CHICAGO, May 3 (Reuters) A senior Government official asserted today that Soviet in terference in other Communist countries was holding up ef forts to reduce EastWest ten sion in Europe.

title: Sperry Rand Registers a Record In Quarter Revenues and Profit
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation had the highest revenues and earnings for any quarter in its history in the three months ended March 31, lifting the company's results for the year ended March 31 to records, J. Frank Forster, president, re ported yesterday.

title: Even in Alabama, Wallace Is Not Everybody's Hero
description: HOMEWOOD, Ala., May 4 There are 50,000 people in this suburban city just over the mountain from Birmingham and most of them are white, mid dleclass folks who have never voted for George C. Wallace.

title: Women Win Right to Vote At a Pueblo in New Mexico
description: ISLETA, N. M. (AP)For the first time in, their ancient his try, women at Isleta Indian Pueblo now can vote in pueblo elections.

title: Braves Win 7th in Row
description: ATLANTA, May 4 (AP)Jim Nash, a pitcher, and Orlando Cepeda hit home runs tonight as the streaking Atlanta Braves beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 53 for their seventh straight vic tory.

title: Consumer Credit Posts Smallest Gain Since May 1967
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI)The amount of con sumer installment credit outstanding increased by $198million, seasonally ad justed, in March, the Federal Reserve reported today. It was the smallest advance in almost three years.

title: Book Calls U.S. Merchant Fleet Weak
description: A warning that time is about to run out on the American merchant marine has been is sued with the publication of a new book, The U.S. Merchant Marine Today  Sunrise or Sunset?

title: Dow Jones Acquires 9 Daily Papers
description: A plan that will bring Dow Jones & Co.which has been servicing mainly the business and financial fieldsinto the daily general newspaper pub lishing field was announced here yesterday.

title: Shultz Says He Lacked Evidence To Intervene in U.M.W. Election
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Secretary of Labor George P. Schultz told the Senate today that he had no ground for in vestigating or intervening in the United Mine Workers' elec tion campaign last fall. He said that if the same circumstances were to present themselves again, he would pursue the same policy.

title: Market Summary
description: Monday May 4, 1970 (Volume Monday, shares)

title: DRAFT RESISTANCE IS HIGH IN OAKLAND
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 4 (UPI)The Oakland induction center, which processes draft ees for all of Northern Cali fornia and a portion of Nevada, says more than half of the young men ordered to report fail to show upand 11 per cent of those who do show up refuse to serve.

title: Ballet by Cole Porter to Be Danced Here
description: Cole Porter's sole sym phonic compositiona ballet score that was believed lost for more than 40 yearswill come to life again as a new ballet in the American Ballet Theater's new season. It will receive its premiere at the New York State Theater on July 1.

title: Cahill Bids Medical Schools End Scarcity of General Practitioners in Cities
description: TRENTON, May 4Governor William T. Cahill proposed to day, a drastic change in medical education in New Jersey, de claring that community health care in the slumridden cities must set priority over, research and the training of specialists in medicine.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mediator Is Accepted by Los Angeles Board in Effort to End Schoolteachers' 3WeekOld Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4The strike of Los Angeles school teachers has ended its third week with both sides apparently inching their way toward a settlement.

title: Red Troops Cut Highway 29 Miles From Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 4The pressure of North Viet namese and Vietcong troops against Pnompenh increased to day as the Communist forces cut the PnompenhSaigon high way at a point 29 miles from the capital.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Parking Saves a Life
description: AMERSHAM, England (Ca nadian Press)After Mrs. Kathleen Walker reported a re frigerator truck was parked dangerously outside her home, the police found her 31year old con, David inside, whore he had horn trapped in the deep ?? for three hours.

title: STEEL OUTPUT DOWN BY 4.2% LAST WEEK
description: Steel production last week took the sharpest drop of 1970, mainly because of a trucking strike, industry sources indi cated yesterday.

title: SHOWDOWN LOOMS IN PAPER DISPUTE
description: The printers' union an nounced early this morning that it had rejected as still insufficient an offer by the city's major newspapers of a threeyear contract that would have rasied printers' wages by 31.85 per cent by the start of the third year.

title: GREECE RELEASES FRENCH NEWSMAN
description: ATHENS, May 4The mili tarybacked regime fulfilled a pledge to the French Govern ment today by releasing Jean Sarrakis, a Greekborn French man sentenced to 18 years in prison by an Athens courtmar tial on April 12 on charges of sedition and setting off bombs.

title: Ladies' Home Journal To End One Discount
description: Against a background noise of voices muttering angrily against magazine advertising rate cutting, The Ladies' Home Journal is expected to tell its advertising staff today that the discounts for adver tising in the Poppy Cannon MealADay Menus will end with the December issue.

title: Report of Songmy Incident Wins a Pulitzer for Hersh
description: A report on the alleged Songmy massacre of Vietnam ese civilians by United States soldiers won the 1970 Pulitzer prize in international reporting yesterday for Seymour Hersh, a freelance reporter whose article was circulated through the Dispatch News Service.

title: MONSANTO RAISES PRICES ON VANILLIN
description: The Monsanto Company an announced yesterday it would raise prices by 50 cents a pound on vanillin, a flavoring agent used in soft drinks, candy and ice cream.

title: AUSTRALIA TRAILS IN CUP TENNIS, 21
description: BANGALORE, India, May 4 (AP)India held a 21 over Australia today in the Eastern Zone Davis Cup tennis final

title: Foreign Debt Repaid
description: LONDON, May 4 (AP)Brit ain's monetary reserves in creased by $50.4million last month. Despite heavy repay nient of foreign debts, to reach $2.76billion, the Treasury an nounced today.

title: Egyptians Claim Plane
description: CAIRO, May 4 (Reuters)  An Egyptian military spokes man said today that air defenders shot down an Israeli Sky hawk over the central sector of the Suez Canal.

title: BRITISH STUDY FINDS ACCENTS SYMBOLIC
description: LONDONBritish schoolchil dren are very conscious about accents and the status they im ply, Howard Giles, a postgrad uate research student at Bris tol University, suggested in a paper read at the annual con ference of the British Psycho logical Society in Southampton.

title: G.I. SUGGESTION BOX GETS BIG RESPONSE
description: FORT BELVOIR, Va.Letters from around the world have poured into the mail chute la beled The Army Sounding Board fnr the Individual Sol dier here.

title: A Correction
description: In a speech given by former State Supreme Court Justice Samuel S. Leibowitz Friday night, which was reported in one edition of The New York Times on Saturday, Mr. Leibo witz questioned the propriety of naming the present Investi gation Commissioner, Robert K. Ruskin, to a committee to inves tigate police corruption. Mr. Leibowitz questioned the pres ence of Mr. Ruskin on the com mittee, he said, because of alle gations that Mr. Ruskin's office failed to act in complaints of police corruption. The Times article did not make it clear that no allegations have been made against Mr. Ruskin or the current administration of his department.

title: North Vietnamese in Paris Renew Threat to Quit Peace Talks
description: PARIS, May 4North Viet nam reiterated today its threat to walk out of the Paris peace conference as a result of Amer ican military actions in Indo china. But Nguyen Than Le, Hanoi's principal spokesman here, continued in remarks at a news conference to keep the threat vague.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4017 games series)

title: 4 Men Arrested in Theft Of $575,000 in Bonds
description: Four men, including two clerks in major brokerage firms, were arrested by detec tives from the Manhattan Dis trict Attorney's office yester day and charged with crimes stemming from the theft last month of $575,000 worth of negotiable bonds.

title: CatholicEpiscopal Union Forecast by Joint Group
description: A joint commission repre senting the Roman Catholic and Episcopal churches in this country issued a report yesterday declaring that as a result of recent ecumenical gains the organic union of the two churches now ap peared to be a realistic pos sibility.

title: Richard Seaman Jr. to Marry Barbara Chapin Foote Aug. 29
description: MILWAUKEE, May 4Miss Barbara Chapin Foote of Bos ton and Richard M. Seaman Jr. plan to be married on Aug. 29.

title: Texas Planning to Scatter Population to Open Spaces
description: AUSTON, Tex. (UPI)Texas has begun a campaign to de velop small towns and villages and encourage migration out of the crowded metropolitan areas.

title: Raid Made Along Canal
description: TEL AVIV, May 4 (Reuters) Israeli Air Force planes raided Egyptian military tar gets along the Suez Canal for 45 minutes today, a military spokesman announced here.

title: JULIUS A, BROWN, TAUGHT IN BEIRUT
description: HANOVER, N. H., May 4 Prof. Julius Arthur Brown, a physicist and educator who spent 36 years in the Middle East, died Saturday in Laconia, where he lived. He would have been 90 years old next Friday.

title: Mrs. Kathryn Perry Is Remarried
description: Mrs. Kathryn von Stade Perry, the daughter of Mrs. F. Skiddy von Stade of West bury and Southampton, L. I., and the late Mr. von Stade, who was a trustee of the New York Racing Associa tion, was married on Friday to John H. Krumpe, a vice president and controller of the association.

title: U.S. SAYS BIG RAIDS IN NORTH ARE OVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Defense Department announced today it had terminated large scale air raids mounted in recent days against three areas of North Vietnam.

title: SIMULADO SECOND, BEATEN BY A NECK
description: A collegiate touch was added to the opening of the jumping season at Aqueduct yesterday when Chris Elser, a Johns Hop kins freshman, scored aboard The Critter with a superb rid ing performance that at least entitled him to a Ph.D. in judging pace.

title: ... and the Home Front
description: The tragic nature of the division of this country, exacerbated by escalation of the war, was underscored yesterday when four students were killed during a confrontation with National Guardsmen and police Kent State University in Ohio.

title: IBM for Free School Lunches Is Sent to Nixon by House
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The House passed and sent to President Nixon today legis lation to provide free or reduced price school lunches to all of the eight million poverty area children estimated to be eligible.

title: Harvard Sociologist Finds Male Love Exceeds Liking
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. (AP)  A young Harvard sociologist says women like men more than men like women, but the two sexes love each other equally, and maintains that he has found a way to prove it.

title: FARM AGENCY PUTS CURB ON PESTICIDES
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)The Agriculture Depart ment announced today a ban on 60 pesticides for some uses on food and livestock feed crops.

title: K. C. Jones Is Expected to Help Harvard Polish Basketball Team
description: PENNSYLVANIA'S strong basketball team should be favored to win the Ivy League title for the second straight year next season. But Har vard added an element to the situation last week when the Crimson hired K. C. Jones as an assistant to its head coach, Bob Harrison. The former Boston Celtics star became Bran deis's basketball coach three years ago. Now he is in a position to help build what could be the best basketball team in Harvard's history.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SLIP LATE IN DAY
description: After moving higher in morn ing and early afternoon trading, the London stock market slipped back to close only slightly above opening levels.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, May 5, 1970

title: Albany Rules Goldberg Can Run
description: New York's Secretary of State, John P. Lomenzo, accept ed the designation petition of Arthur J. Goldberg as a Demo cratic candidate for Governor yesterday on grounds that no public record had been pro duced to show he did not meet the fivyear residency require ment for the office.

title: Derby Spill to Keep Injured Pilar Idle For Seven Months
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 (UPI)  Hector Pilar, the jockey injured during a spill in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, will not be able to ride again for at least seven months, his physician said yesterday.

title: LOVELL SEES A GAIN FROM APOLLO FLIGHT
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 4 (AP)The Apollo 13 com mander, Capt. James A. Lov ell Jr. of the Navy, said today that the mission might have matured the space program in the eyes of the average Ameri can.

title: Air Pollution Level Is Hard to Gauge
description: The city's air pollution control experts, who have been accumulating an ever larger array of scientific in struments, are finding it in creasingly difficult to give a simple answer to this question:

title: British Minister Advocates Selling Churches for Funds
description: HUDDERSFIELD, England (AP)  The Rev. Stephen Hatcher, a 25yearold Method ist minister, wants to close down and sell off the churches, church halls and Sunday schools in Britain and give the money raised to Christian Aid.

title: Negroes in Office Expected To Double in Next 4 Years
description: The head of a civil rights training organization predicted Sunday that the number of black elected officials in the nation would more than double in the next four years.

title: Their Big Man Out Early With an Injury, the Knicks Fight Back to Overcome Big Deficit
description: We gambled and we got lucky, said Red Holzman, the coach of the miracle Knicker bockers, last night. On anoth er night, playing that gambling defense, we might have been killed.

title: Excellent Concert Closes 5th Season Of Marlboro Music
description: The Music From Marlboro series closed its fifth New York season last night at Tully Hall with chamber music perform ance as nearly perfect as these ears can imagine.

title: Traffic Goes Around Toads
description: STEVENAGE, England (UPI) The Wildlife Preservation So ciety Raid that it had saved the lives of more than 1,000 toads in one week by redirecting traf fice on a main load where the toads were ?? from one spawning pond to another.

title: Six East Harlem Residents Protest Liberals' Candidate
description: Six East Harlem resi dents participated in a sitin at Liberal party headquarters at 165 West 46th Street yes terday to protest the party's endorsement of Frank G. Ros setti for reelection to the State Assembly in the 68th Assembly District.

title: GUERRILLA EXPERT BACKS NIXON'S MOVE
description: SOMERSET, England, May 4 (AP)  Sir Robert Thompson, a British expert on guerrilla warfare and a special adviser to President Nixon, said today that the United States had no alternative to the thrust into the Fishhook area of Cambodia.

title: Trainmen on L.I.R. To Consider Strike On a Daily Basis,
description: Long Island Railroad users faced more uncertainty this morning as a result of a union's threat yesterday to decide on a day to day basis whether to strike over a pension issue.

title: Good Chase Is Among 6 Named To Yonkers Pace Friday Night
description: YONKERS, May 4 (UPI) Six pacers were named today as starters for the $50,000 In ternational Pace at Yonkers Raceway on Friday.

title: VOLUME EXPANDS
description: Investor fears over the in tensified war in Indochina sent stock prices spiraling down ward yesterday in the biggest singleday break since the as sassination of President Ken nedy on Nov. 22. 1963.

title: City Merges Units Serving Consulates And U.N. Delegates
description: New York, which is host to the world's largest diplomatic community, merged the city's separate programs for the con sular corps and United Nations delegates Into a single service yesterday.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLOCKAnna. May 5, 1965. In cherished remembrance of my mother's love and devotion.

title: Observer: Fuller Oriental Explanations
description: WASHINGTON, May 4And now, gentlemen, everything should be perfectly clear. Are there any Questions?

title: Pet Owl Hatches Hen Eggs
description: BOGATA, Tex. (AP)Barber, Newt Bryson's pet owl, Hooter, has hatched three hen eggs, and two of the foster chicks are living and doing well.

title: Costello Subpoenaed by Jury In Gambling Investigation Here
description: Frank Costello, once consid ered a major figure in the un derworld here, was subpoenaed yesterday to appear before a Manhattan grand jury that is believed to be investigating gambling in the metropolitan area.

title: MRS. F. C. BAKER, 82; AIDED WAR RELIEF
description: Mrs. Theresa Chalmers Baker, widow of Frederick Charles Baker, a former presi dent of the American Potash and Chemical Corporation, died, apparently of a stroke, at a friend's apartment here Thursday. She was 82 yearn old, and lived in Stuart, Fla. She had a summer residence in Shaftshurv. Vt., Her hus band, who retired in 1946 to establish a plantation at Stu art died in 1961.

title: ...But Outside, Battle for Mini Continued
description: TWO organizations protest ing the midi and advocat ing freedom in skirt lengths moved their operations onto the fashion industry's door step yesterday.

title: VIOLENCE CLOSES BROOKLYN SCHOOL
description: Disruptive students forced the closing of Samuel J. Tilden High School in Brooklyn yes terday after they set off stench bombs in the cafeteria, over turned benches, tables and chairs and broke windows. One 116yearold girl was arrested after she kicked and bit a po liceman.

title: Antiwar Strike Plans in the Colleges Pick Up Student and Faculty Support
description: Student sentiment in favor of shutting colleges to protest the United States role in Southeast Asia gained strengthand in creasing faculty supportin the New York metropolitan area yesterday.

title: Marion Knauss Wed in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, May 4Miss Marion Knauss, an editorial writer for The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times, and Nelson Poynter, board chairman of the Times Publishing Com pany there, were married here early this morning at the home of the bridegroom's daughter, Mrs. George Fea ver. The ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Robert Thomason, a chaplain at Emory University.

title: BrownCornell Game Saturday Will Decide Ivy Lacrosse Title
description: There will be an old fashion shootout Saturday when Cornell and Brown meet in Ithaca, N.Y., to decide the Ivy League lacrosse champion ship.

title: Small Czech Plane Is Hijacked to Austria
description: VIENNA, May 5An offi cial of a Czechoslovak ura nium plant hijacked a twin engined company plane today and forced the pilot to fly to Austria. He stabbed the pilot with a penknife, causing serious injuries.

title: HIGH RATES HALT SALES OF BONDS
