description: High interest rates halted yesterday the sale of more than $300million of corporate and taxexempt bonds as concern over Cambodia and inflation continued to impede normal operations in the credit mar kets.

title: CHARLES FETTER, 74, OF TIMING CONCERN
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., May 5 Charles H. Fetter, founder and president of American Time Products, Inc., in New York City, died Friday at Danbury Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived on Ox Hill Road.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Meaning of Cambodia

title: BLACKMUN BACKED BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Senate Judiciary Committee voted 17 to 0 today to send the Supreme Court nomina tion of Judge Harry A. Black mun to the Senate floor with a recommendation that it be confirmed.

title: STUDENTS STEP UP PROTESTS ON WAR; ASSAIL 4 DEATHS
description: College students across the country stepped up their pro tests, demonstrations and strikes yesterday against widening United States military involve ment in Southeast Asia.

title: Wise Synagogue to Gain
description: The Women's Organization of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue will give its 45th annual spring luncheon Tues day in the Crystal Ballroom of Delmonico's Hotel. Mrs. Harold Grabino and Mrs. Jasha Zayde are cochairmen of the event. Proceeds will he used to further the syna gogue's social services and charity work. Tickets at $18 each may he obtained at the synagogue, 30 West 68th Street.

title: RALLY IN LONDON HELPS TRIM LOSS
British Stars Will Aid Chamberlain's Hamlet
description: Richard Chamberlain, best known as television's Dr. Kildare, will be assisted in his nexte role by some of Britain's outstanding actors.

title: C. W. POST TRACKMEN ROUT ADELPHI, 9361
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 5 C. W. Post College won 12 of 18 events today to score a 93 61 track and field victory over Adelphi University at Hickox Field.

title: Saigon High Court Upsets Conviction Of Thieu Opponent
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, (AP) May 5Tean Ngoc Chau, a National Assembly member and foe of President Nguyen Van Thieu, was convicted un constitutionally by a military court, South Vietnam's Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Pilot, Low on Fuel, Fills Up At a Gas Station in Canada
description: PRINCE GEORGE, British Columbia (Canadian Press) While flying here from Fort Nelson, British Columbia, with two passengers. Warren Enzler of Kenai, Alaska, could not reach anyone on his radio and thought he was off course.

title: Death on the Campus
description: The four students, including two women, killed by M1 bullets fired by Ohio National Guardsmen, did not die on their campus because they were known to be committing acts of violence or engaging in illegal dissent. They were victims of panic, ineptness or worse on the part of National Guard officers and soldiers with loaded weaponsalmost as if Kent, Ohio, were Parrot's Beak, Cambodia.

title: Willis of the Durham Mob Pleads Guilty to Stealing
description: Frank Willis, the last of the Durham Mob to have his case decided, pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of con spiracy and three counts of grand larceny in the 1968 theft of almost $400,000 from the Neighborhood Youth Corps.

title: Review of Coffee Prices Is Scheduled in Canada
description: OTTAWA, May 5 (Canadian Press)The Prices and Incomes Commission announced today that it will review increases in prices for coffee, rubber tires, fine papers and duplicating services and supplies.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: DUST COMMANDER GOING TO PIMLICO
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 (AP)  Dust Commander, the Kentucky Derby winner, will leave tomorrow for Baltimore, where he may become a sup plemental entry for the 1316 mile Preakness.

title: Rhodes and Taft in Tight Race; Glenn Also in Close Ohio Fight
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednes day, May 6Gov. James A. Rhodes held a slim and incon clusive lead over Representa tive Robert Taft Jr. early today in Ohio's Republican Senate primary election after eight hours of a slow ballot count.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Is Granted Writ Barring Stoppages Here
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Ani mals obtained a temporary in junction Tuesday barring strike activity or work stoppages at its shelters in the city and on Long Island.

title: ALL 11 INCUMBENTS ARE SAFE IN INDIANA
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 5All of Indiana's 11 incumbent Unit ed States Representativessev en Republicans and three Dem ocrats appeared today to be assured of places on the No vember ballot.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY
description: Allied Maintenance

title: Printers and Papers Very Far Apart
description: The head of Typographical Union No. 6 said last night that the printers and the news papers were still very far apart despite a new offer of 31.85 per cent in additional wages over three years, which he rejected early yesterday.

title: Wall Street Transfusion?
description: Just as everything looked darkest and the stock market seemed headed nowhere but further down, the Federal Re serve Board acknowledged the strident call of Wall Street and slashed margin re quirements from 80 per cent to 65 per cent. Very fun damentally, the move is bullish. It means more buying power sud denly has been unleashed for investors, for they will be able to purchase more stock with the same money. Sixtyfive per cent margin, after all, mans that only 65 per cent of the purchase price of a stock has to be put up, instead of 80 per cent.

title: CUT IN STOCK PRICES DELAYS NEW ISSUES
description: Declining stock prices were instrumental yesterday in caus ing the postponement of a num ber of equity financings sched uled for sale this week.

title: Gulf Report Oil Find
description: PITTSBURGH, May 5 (UPI) The Gulf Oil Corporation an nounced today a wildcat oil dis covery 10 miles off the coast of Portuguese Angola. Full, evaluation of the discovery is expected later this year.

title: Lefkowitz Urges Mayor to Curb Coop Scheme
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz called on the Lind say administration yesterday to block attempts by groups of landlords in the Gramercy Park area to convert brown stones to cooperatives without first making offers to tenants of the building.

title: Ottinger Brands New Subway Coaches Death Traps
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger charged yesterday that the new subway cars the city, has ordered are potential death traps on the basis of a report that he said the Transit Authority had suppressed.

title: International Air Travel At Kennedy Sets Record
description: A record in inbound inter national air travel was set in March at Kennedy Interna tional Airport.

title: Soldiers Seize Pagoda In Fatal Saigon Clash
description: SAIGON, South Vietram, May 5 (Reuters)  Soldiers burst into the national pa goda before dawn today and opened fire on about 600 monks, nuns and students oc cupying the building, accord ing to a military spokesman.

title: Bruce and Denny Show Expects A Challenge on Road This Year
description: THAT muffled sound in the distance is the beat of drums. It will grow louder in a few weeks. The CanAm people are resuming where they left off last fall, when the message was Wait till next year. The hope then was that 1970 would bring some competition for the New Zealanders About Bruce McLaren and Denis Hulme, Motor otherwise known Sports as The Bruce and Denny Show, who since 1967 have been walk ing away with the Canadian American Challenge Cup. Well, next year has ar rived: the parts are beginning to fit together for the open ing of the $1million series on June 14 at Bowmanville, Ontario. The 11race compe tition for Group 7 sports racing cars is sanctioned by the Sports Car Club of Amer ica and sponsored by John Wax.

title: ANTIU.S. PROTESTS ARE STAGED ABROAD
description: BERLIN, May 5About 20 leftwing radicals early this morning hurled Molotov cock tails and rocks at Amerika House, the United States cul tural center, in protest against American involvement in Cam bodia. They smashed 22 win dows and the plateglass front door.

title: Democratic Reform for '72
description: Still smarting from the Chicago shambles of '68, and still hurting from the Presidential campaign, the Democratic party is moving toward badly needed reform of its system of selecting delegates for the national convention.

title: Pupils Study Ukrainian
description: MONTMARTRE, Saskatche wan (Canadian Press)Ukrain ian is being taught to pupils in the seventh and eighth grades as well as adults in tis south eastern Saskatchewan commu nity.

title: Lincoln Center Film Festival Has 'Sign of Leo'
description: TO be down and outor simply boredin Paris in the month of August is to face one of sanity's most awful survival tests. The weather is hot in a hopeless, dull way. The days are maddeningly alike, all Sundays. The interesting stores and shops, and the restaurants worth eating in, are closed. Friends vanish. The city is like a land locked Marie Celeste, abandoned, and the haggard tourists and those cranky Parisians who are too poor or too lazy or too venal to leave are no more substantial than ghosts. A month turns into an endless, sunlit nightmare.Eric Rohmer's first feature film, "The Sign of Leo," made in 1959, is about one man's soul as it endures its own private Paris in the month of August. Pierre (Jess Hahn) is a befy good-hearted, extroverted American expatriate without a sou. Like all American expatriates who somehow are marooned in Paris in the late nineteen-forties and nineteen-fifties, Pierre has an excuse for being there. He is a composer, but he dreams his best compositions and people are always waking him up, either before he finishes anything or in such an abrupt manner that he immediately forgets what he dreamed.One such morning in June, Pierre is forced out of bed by the arrival of a telegram that informs him his aunt has died. Because the lady, who sounds rather like Charley's aunt (she has such exotic possessions as "factories in Germany" and "villas in Guatemala") was fabulously wealthy, Pierre asumes himself to be rich. Borrowing money from a friend on Paris-Match, he throws a marvelous party for his Left Bank acquaintances, only to learn later that the entire estate has gone to a cretin of a cousin.Comes August, Pierre's friends disappear. With desperate dignity, he quietly becomes the bumsleeping on river banks, eating from garbage cans  he always suspected he was.Anyone who has seen Rohmer's much later, much more complex "My Night at Maud's" (at the 68th Street Playhouse will probably guess correctly that Pierre's story does not end quite that simply. Rohmer has a nice, old-fashioned fondness for the de Maupassant twins, which, in 'The Sign of Leo," is not very satisfactory. However, just about everything else about the film is, in a small, civilized, unspctacular way.Rohmer, the former Cahiers du Cinema critic and one of the principal intelligences of the old New Wave, is now to be recognized as one of the most interesting filmmaking talents to emerge from that long-ago period. Interesting and, in the context of that time, original. For Rohmer is a comparatively classical director who makes films about people of a certain worth and moral awareness, about people who talk well and respect each other's privacy, and who have within them the vestiges of now almost forgotten, established social orders.In much the same way, Rohmer reflects these things in the manner in which he tells stories, with a civilized wit and style that come close to seeming austere. Pierre is really a bit of a bore (a major fault of the film), but he's basically decent, as are his friends, and Rohmer respects them by avoiding tricks, narnative or visual.The last third of "The Sign of Leo" is one of the most effective, though unhysterical, depictions of emotional breakdown ever put on film. Pierre doesn't cry, or get drunk, or have hunger visions. Instead, he loses the sole of one shoe, which he has to tie with a string, and the world around him simply becomes increasingly clear and distant, as if seen through the wrong end of a telescope."The Sign of 'Leo," which was shown last night at Alice Tully Hall as part of Lincoln Center's spring film festival, is of unmistakable historical interest as the first work of the man who made "Maud."It is also something of a documentary record of the New Wave camaraderie that existed in 1959, and is now pretty well shattered. Look closely. There's Jean-Luc Godard, in dark glasses and, even then, shy, as one of Pierre's friends in a party scene. In another episode, the elegant, extraordinary Stephane Audran, plays (and beautifully too, haeven help me) an arrogant, franc-pinching concirge.

title: BIGSTORE SALES DROPPED IN APRIL
description: Bigstore sales in New York City last month continued to reflect the slow trend of recent months.

title: Volkswagen U.S. Car Sales Declined by 3.5% in April
description: Volkswagen car sales fell 3.5 per cent in the United States market last month, while Ren ault and MercedesBenz sales increased, the companies re ported yesterday.

title: WINNER IS RALLIED BY RUDY TURCOTTE
description: Three Martinis staggered out of the gate in the feature race at Acqueduct yesterday and those in the crowd of 26,555 who had made him the favorite just about gave up hope of vic tory. For the race was only a fivefurlong sprint for 2year olds and the chance of acquir ing momentum, in such a short race is remote.

title: Market Summary
description: Tuesday, Mar 5, 1970

title: Cargo Ship Conversions
description: The Todd Shipyards Corpora tion received yesterday a con tract from the Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc., of New Orleans for the conversion of nine conventional cargo ships into part container ves sels. The contract, valued at more than $30million, calls for the lengthening of each ship by 97 feet and for the providing of space for 162 containers for each vessel.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, May, 6, 1970

title: Strike at Parke Davis
description: DETROIT, May 4 (UPI) Members of Lodge 1288 of the International Association of Machinists, unsatisfied with the terms of a proposed new con tract, went on strike today against Parke Davis & Co. By a 170to50 vote yesterday. The members rejected a threeyear contract agreed upon by union and management negotiators Friday night.

title: EGEBERG EXPECTS AWARE PATIENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 The nation's ranking health of ficer said today that the medi cal profession was entering an era in which doctors must pro vide their patients with more information, allowing those pa tients to use their own judg ment on many things related to health and medical care.

title: Astronauts Give Thanks To Grumman Workers
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., May 5 (UPI)About 15,000 em ployes of Grumman Aero space Corporation received a brief holiday from work to day and the three Apollo 13 astronauts, who were visiting the plant here, told them they deserved it.

title: Port Authority Is Picketed
description: At least nine facilities op erated by the Port of New York Authority were picketed yes terday by members of the In ternational Union of Operating Engineers in a dispute with the authority over a change in schedules of six men at the La Guardia Airport heating and refrigeration plant. The facili ties included the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, George Wash ington Bridge, the agency's headquarters at 111 Eighth Avenue, marine terminals in Hoboken and Newark, and the La Guardia, Newark and Ken nedy airports. The agency said last night that a truce had been reached, deferring shift changes, and that picketing had ceased.

title: A Witness Says Alioto Sought Legal Aid for Alleged Mafioso
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5  Look magazine produced a for mer law secretary today to testify that Mayor Joseph L. Alioto once asked her employer to represent a man named in other testimony as the head of the Mafia in San Francisco.

title: Belden Elects 2 Directors
description: Two new directors were elected yesterday by the Belden Corporation at its annual meet ing in Chicago. They are Ev erett W. Blome, vice president corporate planning, and Wil liam C. Croft, president of the PyleNational Company.

title: Ronnie Robinowitz Prospective Bride
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., May 5 Mrs. Seymour R. Robinowitz has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss Ronnie Robinowitz, to John Henry Jankoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Janwoff of New York and Grotonon Hudson.

title: Good Chase Draws Outside Post For $50,000 International Pace
description: YONKERS, May 5Just as Ed Parker, the racing secre tary, had promised, there will be eight starters in Friday night's $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway. It must be reported, though, that Parker, in making good his avowal to have a complete field for the 1mile race, did not leave himself too great a mar gin of safety.

title: Phone Industry hit In Computer Parley
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 5The keynote speaker of the spring Joint Computer Conference. Sam Wyly, today charged the telephone industry with slowino the nation's economic and social Growth by failure to provide adequate datatransmission fa cilities.

title: Dance: Paul Taylor Back
description: AT a time when the world seems a sick mess, there is perhaps a special consola tion to be discovered in the linear and spatial mysteries of Paul Taylor. With his dance company, Mr. Taylor opened a week's season at the New York City, Center last night.

title: Piping Rock Forges a Big Lead In Women's Met Interclub Golf
NIXON PROMISES TO QUIT CAMBODIA IN 3 TO 7 WEEKS
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Pres ident Nixon sought to subdue mounting criticism from Capi tol Hill today by giving Con gressional committees what was described as a firm com mitment that American troops would be withdrawn from Cam bodia in three to seven weeks.

title: 4th Thrust Into Cambodia Is Made by U.S. Brigade
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 6  United States troops opened a fourth front in eastern Cambodia to day, thrusting across the border at a point 60 miles northwest of Saigon, the United States command announced.

title: CASHIN TOP SALES FOR SAVINGS BONDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Savings bond redemptions exceeded sales by $80million last month, the 17th consecu tive month of net decline, the Treasury Department said to day.

title: $240,000 for Soccer Player
description: LONDON, May 5 (AP) Chelsea, the winner of the Eng lish Soccer Cup, paid $240,000 for a Millwall forward, Keith Weller, today. The deal was completed too late for Weller to join Chelsea on a tour of South America.

title: Paying for the War
description: The United States economy is laboring under an inflation that has had damaging effect on consumers' real income, industrial profits and public and business confidence. While the war in Vietnam has not been the sole cause of the inflation, it has certainly inten sified it.

title: U.S. Pro Tennis Tourney Raises Purse to $50.000
description: BOSTON, May 5 (AP)  The prize money for the seventh annual United States profes sional tennis championship at the Longwood Club in nearby Brookline was increased today to $50,000, or $17,000 more than last year.

title: Thant Makes Appeal for Urgent International Conference to Seek Peaceful Settlement of Indochina War
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5  Secretary General Thant made a worldwide ap peal today for an international meeting to seek peace in Indo china.

title: Soviet Leaders Fly to Czechoslovakia to Renew 20Year Amity Treaty
description: PRAGUE, May 5 (AP)  Leonid I. Breshnev, the So viet Communist party leader, arrived today at the head of a delegation that will sign a new 20year SovietCzech oslovak treaty of friendship and mutual cooperation.

title: Berio Conducts 5 of His Works In Concert at Whitney Museum
description: Luciano Berio's original plan for last night's Composers Showcase concert at the Whit ney Museum had been to stage a new, chamber version of his theater piece This Means That. Evidently something fun ny happened to it on the way to the museum. Instead, Mr. Berio conducted five of his betterknown older works, with the assistance of that incom parable vocal magician Cathy Berberian, seven live instru mentalists and tape recorders.

title: Friends of Kent State Victims Say They Were Not Radicals
description: KENT, Ohio, May 5None of the four Kent State Uni versity students killed on Monday by National Guard rifle fire was a revolutionary or a hardcore radical, ac cording to many who knew them.

title: Closed Window Provides Ventilation Even in Storm
description: A window has been designed by the Kawneer Company of. Niles, Mich., to provide venti lation even in rainstorms with winds up to 110 miles an hour, the magazine Architectural Record reports.

title: A NEW CONTRACT IN SUGAR FUTURES
description: Trading in a new world sugar futures contract, known as the No. 11, was started yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange for delivery in July, 1970, and subsequent months.

title: Policeman Saves Woman
description: A young patrolman dived into the Hudson River near Pier 83, at .43d Street, shortly after noon yesterday and pulled out a 45 yearold woman who had jump ed into the water. Patrolman Brian Delaney, 22 years old, of the West 35th Street station, was treated at St. Clare's Hos pital for submersion. The wom an, identified as Grace Stewart of Norwich, N. Y., was trans ferred to Bellevue Hospital.

title: WOMEN FILL HEARING ON RIGHTS EQUALITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Women attired in everything from miniskirts to midifrocks filled the Senate Caucus Room today seeking equality with men under the Constitution.

title: Upstate Man Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that Specialist William J. Stieve of Leonards ville, N. Y., had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
3 U. S. GIRLS GAIN IN ENGLISH TENNIS
description: GUILDFORD, England, May 5 (AP) Three California girls advanced today to the third round of the Surrey hardcourt (clay) tennis championship

title: PLEAS INTERRUPT COLUMBIA TRIAL
description: Two students and two for mer students of Columbia Uni versity interrupted their trial yesterday and pleaded guilty to criminal contempt of court for violating injunctions against disruptive acts on the campus.

title: Dr. Loren C. Petry, Taught Botany at 4 Universities
description: YARMOUTH PORT, Mass., May 5Dr. Loren C. Petry, a teacher at several universities, died Sunday in his home here. He was 82 years old.

title: 22 Yachts Will Start Friday In 627Mile Race to Mexico
description: Twentytwo yachts have en tered the race from Galveston, Tex., to Vera Cruz, Mexico, which begins Friday. The race is 627 miles across the Gulf of Mexico and is sponsored by four yacht clubs and the Mexi can National Tourist Council.

title: Kennecott Will Hold Price Line; Plans Increased Copper Output
description: No further price increases are planned at this time by the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the country's largest producer of domestically minded copper, according to Frank R. Milliken, the company's president.

title: EXTENSION OF WAR FEARED BY WILSON
description: LONDON, May 5  Prime Minister Wilson expressed ap prehension and anxiety today that the American intervention in Cambodia might go beyond the limits declared by Presi dent Nixon and bring a change in his policy of troop with drawal from Vietnam.

title: Cheetah Bus Service Given Charter Rights by I.C.C.
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday upheld an examiner's findings and is sued an order authorizing the Cheetah Charter Bus Service Company, Inc., 40 West 135th St. in Harlem, to provide char ter bus service through 19 states.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 5 (AP)A nuclear bomb with a power of less than 20,000 tons of TNT was exploded toddy at the end of a tunnel 1,030 feet beneath Rainier Mesa in the remote northeast corner of the Nevada test site, the Atomic Energy Commission said. There was no leakage of radiation from the shot, conducted for the Department of Defense un der the code name Mint Leaf, the commission said.

title: ROBERT V. SABATINI OF STATE COURT, 58
description: State Supreme Court Justice Robert V. Sabatini died at the Long Beach, L. I., Hospital Mon day, apparently of a heart at tack. He was 58 years old, and lived at 412 East 115th Street.

title: U.S. Discloses a 4th Area In the North Was Raided
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Defense Department, which announced yesterday that it had terminated largescale air raids against three areas of North Vietnam, said today that a fourth area had also been attacked.

title: Shutting of Schools In the Saigon Area Is Ordered by Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 5 (UPI)President Nguyen Van Thieu ordered all schools in the Saigon area closed tonight because of unrest among South Vietnamese students.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Israel Gives Glimpse of New Navy Missile
description: JERUSALEM, May 5  The Israeli Navy today gave a glimpse of its fleet of swift missile boats equipped with an Israelideveloped surfaceto surface missile, the Gabriel. A full display is expected to be seen Monday, when Israel cele brates her 22d Independence Day.

title: Policeman Is Charged With L.I. Bank Holdup
description: A New York City police man was charged yesterday with robbing a bank Monday in Elmont, L. I.

title: TWORUN DOUBLES END RYAN STREAK
description: Nolan Ryan returned to the human race last night.

title: Red Cross Aide Seeks Data
description: GENEVA, May 4Henrik Beer, Secretary General of the League of Red Cross Societies, left today for a 10day visit to Saigon. He expects to bring gack the South Vietnam Red Cross Society's estimate of needs for its prereconstruc tion program.

title: Dell Manages U. S. Quartet
description: MADRID, May 5 (Reuters) Four American Davis Cup players have engaged the for mer team captain, Donald Dell to manage their tennis affairs as a group. The four are Arthur Ashe, Bob Lutz, Stan Smith and Charlie Pasarell.

title: Suit in U.S. Court Here Asks State Voting Age of 18
description: A suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court here in an at tempt to compel the state to lower the voting age to 18 years.

title: Washington: The President in Adversity
description: WASHINGTON, May 5In this sensitive and dangerous hour it would probably be a mistake to act on the assump tion that President Nixon is determined on some grand new strategy of smashing his way to victory in Indochina.

title: NET OF CERRO CORP. OFF 25% IN QUARTER
description: Robert P. Koenig, president and chief executive officer of the Cerro Corporation, told the annual meeting here yesterday that firstquarter earnings had fallen 25 per cent.

title: Exhibition Set for Next Week To Aid Artists in the Military
description: The second floor of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club at 283 Lexington Ave nue, at 37th Street, will become a gallery next week for a show and sale of 100 paintings by members of the armed services. Proceeds will go to the artists, some of whom are hospitalized.

title: R. C. BERKINSHAW
description: TORONTO, May 5 (Canadian Press)R. C. Berkinshaw, pres ident of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Canada, Ltd., from 1952 to 1959, and former chairman of the com pany hoard, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: Yonkers Drivers
SIR TOM O'BRIEN, 69; TRADE UNIONIST, DIES
description: LONDON, May 5 (AP)Sir Tom O'Brien, head of the big gest trade union in the British entertainment industry, died today after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS BILL ON WILDERNESS LAND
description: ALBANY, May 5Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill creating the State Nature and Historical Preserve Trust, his office announced today.

title: Roundup: 7 Brings Luck To Braves, Not to Phils
description: It took the Atlanta Braves 16 minutes last night to score seven runs in the second in ning, after which they went on to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 126.

title: U.S. Aide Named to City Post
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Edward V. Kline, the New York regional director of the General Services Administration, as dep uty administrator of the Municipal Services Administration. He also said that Alfred C. Maevis, the city Transit Au thority's chief engineer, would replace Frederic A. Davidson Jr. as Commissioner of Public Works, a branch of the Municipal Services. Administration. Mr. Kline will receive $32,500 a year and Mr. Maevis $35,000. They will take their posts early in June.

title: Note to Readers
description: Some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations are omitted from this issue because of com posing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: 7th Avenue Gets a Gallic Touch, and the Name Is Pierre Cardin
description: SEVENTH AVENUE is hav ing quite a flirtation with Paris these days. First off, there's the loving acceptance of longer clothes. (Tout Paris is doing it, is the standard answer to the ques tion of Why long?.) Then there are the bunatthenape hairdos surrounded by tiny braids, after Dior, and the Victorian sleeves and waist cinching belts after Saint Laurent.

title: BOARD REINSTATES 7 HUNTER STUDENTS
description: Seven Hunter College stu dents, suspended last week by Mrs. Jacqueline G. Wexler, president of the college, were reinstated Monday night by a judicial hearing board com posed of four students and three faculty members.

title: EDITOR WILL HEAD RESEARCH AGENCY
description: Dr. Philip H. Abelson, editor of the journal Science codis coverer of the element neptun ium and long a spokesman for American science, has been named to succeed Dr. Caryl P. Haskins as president of the Carnegie Institution of Wash ineton.

title: Cambodia Exhorts Troops As Foe Continues Advance
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia. May 5While Vietnamese Commu nist forces pushed into within 27 miles of Pnompenh today, the Government called on its troops to hold out 10 more days.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 6, 1970

title: BLUES AGAIN BOW TO BRUINS, 6 TO 2
description: ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP)  Eddie Westfall and Derek Sanderson scored two goals each and Bobby Orr and Phil Esposito established Stanley Cup scoring records as the Boston Bruins routed the St. Louis Blues, 62, tonight in the second game of the Stanley Cup hockey finals.

title: MRS. JOHN M. WOOLSEY
description: Mrs. John M. Woolsey, the widow of a United States Dis trict Judge, died yesterday at her home, 131 East 66th Street. She was 95 years old.

title: Pathet Lao Says It'll Attack Another South Laos Town
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 5 (Agence FrancePresse)  The proCommunist Pathet Lao has put up posters at Saravane, a major southern Laotian town, warning that its forces would attack shortly, military sources' reported here today.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Coed's Appendix Is Cut Out With Watch She Swallowed
description: CLEARWATER, Fla. (AP)A 21yearold coed received her watch back and had her ap pendix removed in the same operation.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SINK STILL LOWER
description: The American Stock Ex change took another beating yesterday as prices sank to their lowest levels in twoandahalf years in quiet trading.

title: Staples in Fonteyn's Diet: Exercise and Hearty Food
description: Nearing 51, an age she will attain without tears on May 18, Dame Margot Fon teyn is dazzling ballet audi ences these nights at the Metropolitan Opera House with the youthfulness of her renverses and her sissonnes and her grands jets. Her steps look so effortless.

title: FIVEGAME STREAK ENDS AT OAKLAND
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 5 The Yankees' winning streak came to an unlovely end to night as the Oakland Athletics headed them their worst defeat of the season, 113.

title: Bridge: 1 Club as Strong Forcing Bid Catches on With U.S. Experts
description: AFTER more than 40 years of complacent acceptance of standard bidding meth ods, tournament players in this country are now showing signs of believing that there may after be something in the idea of playing one club as a strong forcing bid.

title: Theater: Ionesco Triple Bill in French
description: EUGENE IONESCO makes such effective use of the visual aspects of theater that lack of linguistic comprehen sion need not be fatal to the appreciation or the enjoy ment of his works. Certainly the triple bill of Ionesco plays that ushered in the fourth and final program of contemporary French drama by Le Treteau de Paris, last night at the BarbizonPlaza Theater, proved stimulating stuff for this member of the audience, whose most recent exposure to concentrated French was a course at N.Y.U. in 1952.

title: Draft Chief Hopes No. 215 Is Cutoff in Lottery
description: WASHINGTON, May 5More than five months after the draft lottery drawing, Dr. Curtis W. Tarr, the new director of Selec tive Service, said this week he still could not predict with any certainty what the cutoff num ber in the lottery would be this year.

title: 3,500 Columbia Protesters March to City College
description: Some 3,500 Columbia Univer sity students attended a rally on campus last night that wound up with a march along Amsterdam Avenue to join stu dents who had occupied the South Campus of City College.

title: Knicks Pondering Availability of Reed
description: Can Willis Reed play to night for the New York Knicks against the Lakers in Los Angeles? Can the Knicks repeat, without him, the mi raculous victory they scored at Madison Square Garden Monday night? Can the Lakers pull themselves to gether after spurning such a golden opportunity Monday?

title: Houses in Snoul Burn as G.I.'s Battle Hanoi Troops
description: SNOUL, Cambodia, May 5 This is a reconnaissance in force to find out what's in there and also, if possible, to take the townwithout de stroying it.

title: Foreign Money Markets Stable Despite Plunge on Wall Street
description: Foreign exchange markets re mained stable and quiet here yesterday despite the recent plunge on Wall Street.

title: EAST ZONE FINAL CONCLUDES AT 31
description: BANGALORE, India, May 5 (UPI)India completed a Davis Cup upset over Australia today when Premjit Lall beat Dick Crealy, 86, 62, 62, in the Eastern Zone final for a 31 victory.

title: PATH Tries 30c Turnstiles
description: JERSEY CITY, May 4 Thirtycent exactchange turn stiles were put into operation today in the Port Authority Trans Hudson (PATH) stations at Journal Square and Grove Street. The new turnstiles, marked in green, are an experi ment, according to the Port of New York Authority. Other turnstiles accept PATH tokens only, as usual.

title: TIMOTHY F. KEATING
description: Timothy F. Keating, secre tarytreasurer of the New York Stereotypers Union No. 1, died Monday at the Holy Family Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 70 years old and lived at 150 Marine Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Mailer Calls Nixon Hypocrite
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 5 (AP)Norman Mailer, the au thor, started serving a threeday sentence today for his part in the war protest march on the Pentagon two years ago. Mr. Mailer used the occasion to de nounce President Nixon as the living embodiment of Uriah Heep, a Dickens character known for hypocrisy.

title: Federal and Capital Aides Confer on War Rally Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Federal and city authorities acted swiftly today to smooth the way for an antiwar rally scheduled here this Saturday.

title: HEATH ASKS CAUTION ON MARKET ENTRY
description: PARIS, May 5  Edward Heath, the British Conservative party leader, said in a speech here today that Britain should join the European Common Market only on terms which are clearly and visibly benefi cial in the long term.

title: OHIO GUARD FINDS NO PROOF OF SNIPER
description: KENT, Ohio, May 5Officials of the Ohio National Guard said today they were unable to produce evidence of sniper fire at the guardsmen who killed four Kent State Univer sity students here yesterday, but they said the soldiers had fired without orders because they feared for their lives.

title: SIHANOUK SETS UP REGIME IN EXILE
description: HONG KONG, May 5Prince Norodom Sihanouk, exiled for mer Cambodian Chief of State, announced in Peking today the formation of a new govern ment.

title: VLADIMIR HEIFETZ, PIANIST, DIES AT 76
description: DEER PARK, L.I., May 5 Vladimir Heifetz, a pianist, con ductor and composer, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack Sunday, while accom panying Sidor Belarsky in a concert here. He was 76 years old and lived at 351 West 24th Street, New York City.

title: Title Bout to Be Telecast
description: The 15round middleweight championship fight between the titleholder, Nino Benvenuti, and Tom Bethea at Umago, Yugo slavia, on May 23 will be seen on the American Broadcasting Company's Wide World of Sports program, Channel 7, A.B.C. officials said yesterday. Bethea defeated Benvenuti in nontitle bout in March.

title: Jersey City Youth Arrested In An Attempt ed Rape Here
description: JERSEY CITY, May 5The police here arrested a 15year old boy today in connection with the bludgeoning of a tele phone company worker Sunday night in downtown Manhattan.

title: Slayers in Paraguay Say Arab Guerrillas Hired Them
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 5 (Reuters)Two young Arabs who shot and killed the wife of the Israeli Embassy first sec retary yesterday said that they had been hired by the Al Fatah, an Arab guerrilla organization, to assassinate the ambassador, the police reported today.

title: Money Circulates in Ireland in Spite of Closed Banks
description: DUBLIN, May 3The day the money stopped, many of Ireland's 900 bank branches were crowded with worried customers.

title: Salomon Brothers Partner
description: Hans W. Kertess has been admitted as a general partner of the national investment firm of Salomon Brothers & Hutzler. He joined the organization in 1962 and was named a limited partner in 1969. He is a mem ber of the New York Stock Exchange and will represent Salomon Brothers on the floor of the Exchange.

title: Theater: Open Endgame
description: SAMUEL BECHETT'S End game is an apt mate for the Open Theater's own Ter minal. Terminal deals with death, Endgame with living death, or deathly living, or something deadly in between.

title: Protests on Cambodia and Kent State Are Joined by Many Local Schools
description: Tens of thousands of students in dozens of educational institu tions here and in adjoining states halted their studies yes terday to show their bitterness and anguish over the invasion of Cambodia and the killing of four Kent State University stu dents.

title: Mississippi Bishops Back Catholic and Anglican Union
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 5 The Roman Catholic and Epis copal Bishops of Mississippi hacked today the newly an nounced goal of full commu nion and organic union of the Anglican and Catholic commu nions.

title: RCA Sees a Future in Computers
description: The RCA Corporation told about 900 stockholders yester day that the era of most vigorous expansion in color television and broadcasting has passed. At the same time, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and president, predicted that by the end of the year the company should be in a firm No. 2 position in the com puter industry.

title: PANTHER MOTIONS DENIED BY COURT
description: NEW HAVEN, May 5De fense motions for an immediate pretrial hearing on the sup pression of state's evidence in the Black Panther murderkid napping case were denied to day.

title: Executive Changes
description: Earl R. Bramblett has been appointed vice presi dent of General Motors in charge of the personnel staff. He succeeds Louis G. Seaton, who is retiring after 42 years of service.

title: Army's Rules Tightly Restrict Deadly Force in Riot Situations
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Army instructions on the use of deadly force in a riot sit uation are explicitsuch force is justified only by extreme necessity and when lesser means have been exhausted or are unavailable.

title: Market Place
description: HOW much is a shareholder entitled to know about his company? It's hard to say. But whatever the answer to the question, it is manage ment who provides the an swer when it comes to the annual report.

title: Aid Seen in U.S. Links
description: Najeeb E. Halaby, the presi dent and chief executive officer of Pan American World Air ways, said yesterday that the troubled airline must have ac cess to domestic air routes if it is to become profitable again.

title: Israeli Historian Denies Jews Yielded to the Nazis Like Sheep
description: It has been 25 years since the liberation of Auschwitz, of Buchenwald, of BergenBelsen 25 years since the Nazi con centration camps imposed the final solution of death on six million Jews.

title: W.H.O. Assembly Opens
description: GENEVA, May 5Dr. Wil liam H. Stewart, a former United States Surgeon General today opened the annual as sembly of the 128nation World Health Organization. He then turned the chair over to Prof. Hippolyte Aye, Minister of Health of the Ivory Coast, who was unanimously elected presi dent of the threeweek session.

title: A West Side Story Is Still a Sad One
description: The latest scene in a vio lent Upper West Side story was enacted yesterday when three youths pleaded guilty to misdemeanors in Youth Part of Criminal Court.

title: Report on Corruption Due in 2 Weeks
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that a special fiveman committee investigating corrup tion in the Police Department would make some recommen dations to him within the next two weeks.

title: Electric Strike Settled
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) A tentative settlement has been reached in the 10weekold Sprague Electric Company strike in North Adams, Mass. J. Curtis Counts, the head of the Federal Mediation and Con ciliation Service, announced that negotiators for Sprague and the three striking unions reached the tentative settle ment yesterday.

title: POLLUTION BY CARS TARGET OF PETITION
description: The Environmental Defense Fund, a coalition of scientists and lawyers concerned with protecting the environment, began legal action yesterday seeking immediate action by the Federal Government to eliminate automotive lead pol lution from the air.

title: ROGATZ DECLINES CITY HOSPITAL JOB
description: Dr. Peter Rogatz, the physi cian Mayor Lindsay had hoped would run the city's public hos pital system, has turned down the position. He said he had all kinds of personal reasons.

title: Study of Congress Ethics Urges Law Practice Curb
description: An independent study of Congressional ethics, released yesterday, has found that there is significant room for improvement. It recommended that Senators and Representatives be required, among other things, to stop practic ing law and, if they hold stock in banks, to stay off Congres sional banking committees.

title: STOCK MARGIN CUT TO 65% FROM 80% BY RESERVE BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Federal Reserve Board reduced today the margin requirements on stock purchases from 80 to 65 per cent, effective tomor row.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Ronson loves Mothers ... and does all it can to make life easier and lovelier for them

title: Fugitive Put on F.B.I. List
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation added today the ac cused bomber of a Central In telligence Agency recruiting of fice to its list of 10 Most Wanted Fugitives Lawrence Robert Plamondon, 25 years old, minister of defense for the White Panther party, replaced James John Byrnes, who was arrested in Huntington Beach, Calif., last April 17.

title: SEATON IS RETIRING AS G.M. NEGOTIATOR
description: DETROIT, May (AP)Louis G. Seaton, dean of the auto mobile industry's labor negotia tors, will miss this year's bar gaining between General Mo tors and the United Auto Work ers for the first time since the midNineteenthirties.

title: HARVARD SUPPORTS G.M. AGAINST NADER
description: BOSTON, May 5 (UPI) The Treasurer of Harvard Univer sity supported General Motors today in its fight with Ralph Nader. The Harvard official said that in Nader's proposal to re organize the G.M. board of directors was an opening wedge in a movement to so cialize the traditional American way of doing business.

title: Big Four Meet on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5  The delegates of the Big Four  the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union  met this afternoon for the first time since April 15 in their efforts to achieve a settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Cruiser Decommissioned
description: BOSTON, May 5 (AP)The U.S.S. Boston, the world's first guided missile cruiser was de commissioned today at the Bos ton Naval Shipyard. The Boston recently returned from combat in Vietnam. The ship was in many World War II forays.

title: Auxiliary Bishop Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Appointment of the Rev. Mark Schmitt as auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Green Bay, Wic., was announced today. The Most Rev. Luigi Raimondi, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, said that Father Schmitt had been named by Pope Paul VI as titular bishop of Kells and auxiliary to Bishop Alysius J. Wycislo.

title: ROGERS AND LAIRD TERMED DOUBTFUL
description: WASHINGTON, May 5There is increasing evidence that Sec retary of State William P. Rogers and Secretary of De fense Melvin R. Laird had seri ous misgivings about the use of American troops in Cambo dia. And there are many indi cations that President Nixon's war decisions in the last two weeks have been reached in an atmosphere of confusion as well as dissension.

title: South Carolina Will Stay In Atlantic Coast Group
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., May 5 (UPI) Trustees of the University of South Carolina voted unani mously today to keep the uni versity in the Atlantic Coast Conference indefinitely.

title: Coast Firm Merges With Clark, Dodge
description: Clark, Dodge & Co., Inc., an nounced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Irving Lundborg & Co. of San Fran cisco. Both companies are long time members of the New York Stock Exchange and other ex changes.

title: Public Television Units May Merge
description: Twelve members of the pro duction staff of National Educa tional Television were dis charged Monday, and more dis missals are reported to be planned in a longpredicted re alignment of public television in New York.

title: Town Feels Threatened by a Giant Housing Project
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., May 5 Sooner or later almost everyone who comes into this small Pomperaug Valley town, with its white wooden Colonial churches, winding stone walls and hillside cem eteries of leaning tombstones, describes it as sleepy.

title: Moynihan Says Nixon Limits Welfare Bill Revision
description: The White House has decided to rewrite the Administration's welfare reform legislation somewhat less extensively than the Senate Finance Committee suggested last week.

title: HAMILTON LIFE DUE TO BE REVAMPED
description: An agreement for the recap italization of the Hamilton Life Insurance Company of New York, which the State Insur ance Department found to be insolvent in a review two years, ago, was announced here yes terday by Richard E. Stewart, State Superintendent of Insur ance.

title: Disposable PepsiCola Bottle Is Held Successful in Tests
description: A plastic bottle being tested by the PepsiCola Company in Las Vegas, Nev., has proven extremely successful and Pepsi plans to proceed with plans to produce and use it ex tensively next year, a spokes man said yesterday.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 games series)

title: Same Thing Happening, Negro Educator Says
description: ORANGEBURG, S. C., May 5The president of predom inantly Negro South Carolina State College, where three students were killed by the police two years ago, sent a telegram of sympathy today to the president of Kent State University.

title: DR. PAUL BIRDSALL, HISTORY PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Paul Birdsall, a former history professor at Williams College, and an employe of the Central Intelligence Agency, died Saturday of a heart attack at a hospital in Christiansted, in the United States Virgin Is lands. He was 70 years old, and had lived in Christiansted since retiring from the C.I.A. in 1962.

title: GOLDBERG MAKES PLEA TO LIBERALS
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, a candi date for the Democratic nomi nation for Governor, called yes terday for the reestablishment of the democraticLiberal coa lition in this state to achieve victory over the Republicans in November.

title: National Airlines Strike Has Little Impact on Public
description: A National Airlines clerk whose hobby is drag racing is trying to make money at it. A reservations agent tried a temporary meatpacking job but had to give up when she got to the liver. A co pilot, grounded by the strike of the Air Line Employes As sociation against National Airlines, is temporarily sell ing brushes door to door in Miami.

title: Harlem Bus Service Bid Wins Approval of I.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a bi dby a Negroowned company to operate a charter bus service between Harlem and 19 East ern states.

title: Williams AssaultCase Jury Gets Case Today in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., May 5  Both sides rested today in the trial of Bobby Lee Williams, a 24yearold Negro accused of assaulting a policeman during the July, 1967, riots in Plain field.

title: Frank S. O'Hara, 80, Leader In Realty Dealer Groups
description: Frank S. O'Hara, a former Queens realtor and appraiser, died at the Point Pleasant (N. J. Hospital Monday of an embo lism. He was 80 years old and lived in Lakewood, N. J.

title: State Democrats Unite in Protest Of Cambodia Move
description: New York State Democrats, badly divided in 1968 on the war in Vietnam, united yester day in an unusual drive to press for an end to the United States intervention in Cam bodia.

title: Dynamite Stolen Upstate
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., May 5 (AP)Thirtyfive cases of dy namite have been stolen from a powder storage room in the Town of Fort Edward near here, the state police reported today.

title: SOLOMON E. KALTER
description: Solomon E. Kalter, a clothing manufacturer, died Monday at his home, 507 Avenue F, Brooklyn. He was 65 years old.

title: Foreman to Fight Russell
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (UPI) The former Olympic heavy weight champion, George Fore man of Hayward, Calif., un beaten in 19 professional bouts signed today to fight Robert Russell of Philadelphia at the Spectrum on May 25.

title: MISS SOBEL RAISES ORDINARY IN DANCE
description: Sheila Sobel is specially skilled in producing the unex pected. She does not deal in the bizzarre nor in the spec tacular theatrical effect but in the unusual configurations of the human form, in rather or dinary circumstances. She ex amines the day to day with the eyes of a visitor from a different galaxy. Last night at at the Cubiculo she presented Island and After, a work in two parts for six girls and two men.

title: City Center Sets Up Loan Office in Strike
description: The City Center of Music and Drama has set up an emergency office to offer noninterest loans, legal as sistance and strike informa tion to all employes of the State Theater and the ballet who have been idled by the 16day strike by the orches tra of the New York City Ballet.

title: Advertising: LatePaying Clients Assailed
description: Money is very tight today, probably as tight as you and I have ever seen in our busi ness careers, said Barton A. Cummings, an ad man who remembers back to 1925.

title: 4 Projects Snagged
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration has made little prog ress on its contractual prob lems in four major Government, programs, Daniel J. Houghton, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meet ing in Burbank, Calif. How ever, he added, he is confident that the difficulties, one way or another, will be solved.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Schumann Critical of Nixon
description: PARIS, May 5  Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann said today that a speech made by Charles de Gaulle in Pnom penh, in 1966, when he was President, calling for the with drawal of American forces from Indochina contained something of an advance reply to the speech of President Nixon.

title: Foreign Affairs: A Dismal View From the Seine
description: PARISThe French Govern ment is convinced that United States entry into Cambodia has at least for the shortterm futurecompletely changed the international situation and set back a gradual inching toward political settlements in both the Middle East and Southeast Asia.

title: Slayer Denied Parole
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 (UPI)The State Adult Author ity rejected today a request for parole by Dr. Bernard Finch, convicted of slaying his wife in 1959. No reason was given, but Philip Guthrie, a spokes man, said it was the judgment of the authority, the parole board for state prisons, that the 52yearold former society osteopath is not yet ready to be returned to society.

title: Union Dispute Over Scenery Delays Revival of Orchad
description: The John Fernald Company production of The Cherry Orchard was unable to open last night at the ANTA Thea ter because its scenery had not been built by unionized workers.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: * Apprentice.

title: U.S. Office Is Bombed
description: ORLANDO, Fla., May 5 (AP)  A firebomb was hurled through the window of the Federal Office Building today, heavily, damaging a small of fice in the Social Security De partment, officials said. The fire began shortly after midnight in the building, which also houses offices for the military services, Veterans Administra tion and Selective Service.

title: Hanoi Reports New Raid
description: HONG KONG, May 6 (Wednesday) (Reuters) The Ha noi radio said today that the United States continued its air attacks on North Vietnam yes terday. A total of 13 planes were shot down in five days of raids, the North Vietnamese press agency said.

title: Wallace Fails to Win Majority, To Face Brewer in June Runoff
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Wednes day, May 6George C. Wallace failed to win a majority of the votes cast in yesterday's Dem ocratic gubernatorial primary and will meet Gov. Albert P. Brewer in a runoff election on June 2.

title: CokingCoal Sale to Japan Planned by Kaiser Steel
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said yesterday in Oakland, Calif., that it had agreed to sell $125million worth of coking coal to Japanese steel pro ducers. Supplies of United States coking coal have been scarce and prices have been rising.

title: Jersey Synods to Merge
description: WARWICK, N. Y., May 5 (AP) The Particular Synod of New Jerseeey Reformed Church in America voted overwhelmingly today to merge, effective Jan. 1, 1971, with the New Jersey United Presbyterian Synod to form a United Synod for New Jersey with a total of 560 churches.

title: Fresh Air Fund Starts Vacation Registrations
description: Registration for Fresh Air Fund vacations has started at more than 70 cooperating social agencies and hospitals here as the 93yearold philanthropy prepares to send 18,200 de prived city youngsters on free country vacations this summer.

title: PACERS SET BACK COLONELS, 111103
description: LOUISVILLE, May 5 (AP) The Indiana Pacers survived thirdperiod rally by the Ken tucky Colonels tonight and gained a 111103 victory. The triumph gave the Pacers a 31 advantage in the American Basketball Association's East ern Division blavoff.

title: Negro, Denied Apartment, Wins $500 Court Award for Trauma
description: TRENTON, May 5A young black minister has been awarded $500 in compensation for the psychological trauma he suffered when a Montclair landlord refused to rent an apartment to him because of his race.

title: I.O.S CHIEFS SPLIT ON OUTSIDE LINKS
description: GENEVA, May 5A classic power struggle was under way as the chieftains of Bernard Cornfeld's Investors Overseas Services split over future policy objectives and the alliances to be made with outside interests at a marathon board meeting that was continuing through tonight.

title: Syria Accords Recognition
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 5 (Reuters)The Syrian Govern ment tonight recognized Prince Sihanouk's government as the legitimate government of Cam bodia.

title: F.A.A. Barred From Action Against Sick AirControllers
description: A Federal Court Judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Federal Aviation Adminis tration could not take disci plinary action against air traf fic controllers who took part in a sickout that ended last month, United Press Interna tional reported.

title: SEASON HERE ENDED BY PHILADELPHIANS
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra's final local program of the sea son last night in Philharmonic Hall was conventional enough, but gave pleasure for the beauty of the playing. Under Eugene Ormandy's direction there were, to start off, vigorous and full toned performances of Beetho ven's Coriolanus Overture and First Symphony.

title: 2d Actor Involved In the Play, Dope, Is Killed by Heroin
description: A 24yearold actor whose death marked a bizarre and tragic replay for many of his friends and colleagues will be buried today.

title: BEAR MARKET HITS AUGUST '63 LEVEL
description: The worst bear market since the Depression clawed its way yesterday into the lowest terri tory since August, 1963, as stock prices kept falling along a broad front.

title: Council Approves Amnesty Plan For Reduced Parking Tickets
description: A proposal for an amnesty period for those with parking tickets30 days during which cutrate payments would be ac ceptedwas passed yesterday by the City Council.

title: 15 National Groups Ally to Study Crime And Court System
description: An alliance of 15 national organizations was created yes terday with the aim of finding new ways and processes to reduce crime and create a fair er and more effective criminal justice system.

title: Coca  Cola Report Shows Record Net; Austin Adds Post
Buick Cuts Opel Prices
description: The Buick division, General Motors Corporation, has an nounced price cuts ranging from $78 to $142 on all Germanbuilt Opel Kadett cars sold by its dealers in this country. The re duction has been made on the twodoor sedan now priced at $1,877 and the highest on the twodoor Opel GT now $3,328.

title: Ruskin Concedes Accident With City Car on Vermont Outing
description: The city's Commissioner of Investigation acknowledged yesterday that the cityowned Chrysler assigned to shim was involved in a collision while he was driving it on a holiday outing with his family in Ver mont last February.

title: Naval Research Official Warns on Alaska Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The head of the Naval Arctic Re search Laboratory has warned an Alaskan Senator that the proposed transAlaska oil pipe line might break and wreak great damage to the environ ment.

title: Books of The Times
description: MY LAI 4. A Report on the Massacre and Its Aftermath. By Seymour M. Hersh. 210 pages. Random House. $5.95.

title: The Pulitzer Awards
description: If the winning news stories in this year's Pulitzer awards seem a trifle more grim than usual, they are only a reflection of this grim era. Seymour Hersh's account of the killings at Mylai and Newsday's expo sure re of local corruption can stand as symbols of the foreign and domestic ills with which the United States is wrestling. Taken as a whole, the awards show that newspapers and individual reporters are still searching out and reporting the facts, however unpalatable and shameful they can sometimes be.

title: Sesquicentennial for Darien
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 5This community is planning to cele brate its sesquicentennial with a fiveday festival from May 20 to May 24. The observance will open at noon on May 20 with a memorial service at the grave of Thaddeus Bell, known as the Father of Darien, in the now unused Slawson Cemetery. Darien was founded as a sec tion of Stamford in 1641 and in 1820 became a separate com munity.

title: Thant Asks Youth Corps For Aid Projects of U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 5An international corps of young volunteers to serve abroad on United Nations de velopment projects was pro posed today by Secretary Gen eral Thant.

title: Hogan, With New Swing at 57, To Rejoin Pros for Houston Golf
description: HOUSTON, May 5  Ben Hogan plans another come back. In 1949, after a near fatal automobile crash, the golfing experts said he would never be able to play golf again. They were wrong.

title: Stoph Raises Conditions for New Brandt Meeting
description: BONN, May 5  Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany confronted Chancellor Willy Brandt today with a list of reservations about their plan ned meeting two weeks hence raising doubts about its chances of success.

title: Business Magazine For Europe Planned
description: A French and a Latin American publisher are form ing a partnership to publish a business magazine to be distributed solely in Europe. Each monthly issue will be published in separate Italian, German, English and French editions.

title: Reworking Workfare
description: The abrupt decision by the Senate Finance Com mittee to send back to the Nixon Administration its proposal for reforming the nation's malfunctioning welfare system must not be allowed to prevent approval of all reform at this session of the Congress. The need for reform is too great.

title: Greece Orders Inquiries Into Mrs. Niarchos's Death
description: ATHENS, May 5  Judicial authorities continued official Inquiries today into the death of Eugenia Niarchos, the 44 yearold wife of Stavros Niar chos, the shipowner.

title: Institution Cancels Award to Rockefeller
description: The board of directors of the University Settlement House has reversed a decision to give the institution's annual human itarian award to Governor Rockefeller.

title: Holmes Bust to Join Hall
description: A bronze bust of Jus tice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. will be unveiled Sunday at the Hall of Fame for Great Amer icans at New York University. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger will take part in the ceremony and Whitney North Seymour, former president of the Ameri can Bar Association, will pre sent the bust, which was cre ated by the sculptor Joseph Kiselewski. Justice Holmes, born in 1841, served on the Supreme Court from 1902 to 1932. fie died in 1935.

title: Hillman Fund Honors Four For Communications Work
description: The annual Sidney Hillman Foundation awards of the Amalagamated Clothing Work ers of America for outstanding achievements in 1969 in mass communications have been awarded to a freelance writer, a reporter, a television producer and a Congressman.

title: Fashion Show Fit for a Princess
description: What does one do to repay the hospitality of a Moroccan princess? Should the question ever arise, one might note that the Princess in question, Lalla Nezha, and her husband, Ahmed Osman, Moroccan Ambassador to the United States, were obviously im pressed with the thank you gesture showered on them Monday night by Mr. and Mrs. Jean Louis of Los An geles.

title: Sports of The Times
description: IN an uncomprehending daze the crowd slowly headed for the exits at Madison Square Garden Monday night after the KnickLaker playoff game. In essence, everyone was saying, I still can't believe it. The shellshocked Lakers couldn't be lieve it, either. But the jubilant Knicks could believe it. They had made it happen.

title: Democrats Differ on Effect of Yarborough's Loss
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The defeat of Senator Ralph W. Yarborough in the Texas Demo cratic primary last Saturday has been greeted with mixed emotions by leading members of his party here.

title: STENNIS SAYS COURT IS UNFAIR ON RACE
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Senator John C. Stennis, Dem ocrat of Mississippi, said today that the Supreme Court, by conscious and deliberate inac tion, had dodged its duty to pass on the question of the le gality or illegality of segregat ed schools out side the South.

title: GEORGE NYE, 89, HOUSING EXPERT
description: George Gove, a housing ex pert who as a vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, overstfm the con struction of Peter Cooper Vil lage, Stuyvesant Town and Parkchester, died of cancer at his home in Peter Cooper Vil lage on Monday. He was 89 years old.

title: Met Defers Ticket Sale
description: Boxoffice sale of tickets for the Metropolitan Opera's June season will begin at Lincoln Center on Sunday, May 17, rather than next Sunday as originally announced. The postponement was made to allow additional time to fill mailorder ticket requests. The Metropolitan ill offe seven performances weekly for four weeks beginning June 1.

title: Cambodian Prince in Exile
description: IN the past, in times of crisis, Norodom Sihanouk has abdicated as King, re signed as Premier and has gone into political exile to convince his friends and ene mies that he is needed in Pnompenh to restore order. Also in the past he has al ways reemerged in control.

title: Dr. Gero Gaevernitz, 68, Dead; Had Role in German Surrender
description: Dr. Gero von Schulze Gaever nitz, a former member of the Office of Strategic Services who helped to arrange the negotia tions for Germany's surrender in Italy during World War II, died of a heart attack April 6 in the Canary. Islands, where he had been recuperating from an earlier heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: PROFITSADS LINK EXPLORED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  A study by Government econo mists shows that when rela tively few companies dominate the market for a specific line of food products, they are able to increase their profits sig nificantly by increasing their advertising.

title: Washington: For the Record
CHEVRON INDICTED IN GULF OIL SPILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Chevron Oil Company was in dicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of knowingly and willfully fail ing to install safety devices that, according to some Federal experts, could have prevented the fire and subsequent oil spill last winter at several of the company's wells in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Mets Defeat Dodgers, 54, as Seaver Gains 6th in Row This Year
description: Tom Seaver pitched his sixth straight victory last night as the New York Mets survived the wind, the cold and the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Total earnings of the Cana dian Pacific Railway in the first quarter fell to $12,462,000, or 81 cents a share, from $14, 460,000, or 95 cents a share, in the like period of 1969, Ian B. Sinclair, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Montreal.

title: HERMIONE SESSLER
description: Hermione Sessler, a retired teacher and president of the Edith Stein Guild, which pro motes JewishChristian rela tions, died yesterday in her home at 420 East 86th Street Her age was 68.

title: Canadian Pacific Earnings Declined in First Quarter
description: Canadian Pacific Earnings Declined in First Quarter

title: Jersey Mayor Indicted With 3 Alleged Mafiosi
description: TRENTON, May 6  The state grand jury indicted the Mayor of West New York and three reputed Mafia fig ures today in what New Jer sey law enforcement officials described as the beginning of a concerted drive against or ganized crime and corruption in Hudson County.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and the American Stock Exchanges, yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock holdings by major shareowners, directors and officers of listed companies. The lists include the following:

title: Article 8  No Title
CHILD ADVOCATE IN KEY U.S. POST
description: The children of the country have a new advocate in gov ernment in Dr. Edward F. Zig ler, a psychologist who was ap pointed as the first permanent director of the Office of Child Development. The announce ment was made last week by Robert F. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Personal Finance: Wedding Insurance
description: When a girl says yes to a marriage proposal, she faces a new set of financial problems.

title: ROCKEFELLER SIGNS BILL ON RAIL LINES
description: Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday that will pro vide the major financing $44.4million from the state bond issue  for modernizing the Penn Central's Harlem and Hudson commuter lines.

title: CONFIDENT BRUINS RELISH HOME ICE
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP) I Harry Sinden, coach of the Bos ton Bruins, shepherded his Na tional League Hockey club back home today and the players were flying as high as the plane that carried them here for the next game tomorrow night.

title: Observer: One Way to Measure a Lifetime
description: WASHINGTON, May 6It was April, 1954, when Richard Nixon, then Vice President of the United States, first made news by suggesting that Ameri cans make war in Indochina.

title: Roundup: Aaron Is Star As Braves Win 9th in Row
description: While Willie Mays cele brated his 39th birthday by watching seven inches of snow fall in Montreal yester day, Hank Aaron, another of baseball's elite corps of senior citizens, continued heading for milestones of his own.

title: Teachers' Leader Jailed, Union Is Fined in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)  The president of the striking Boston Teachers Union was sentenced to 30 days in jail and the union was fined $4,000 today after the union was found guilty of criminal contempt.

title: Dr. Louis Cornell, Taught Music for Many Years
description: Dr. Louis Cornell a pianist and mustic professor at Bostor. University, died at the Lawrenc Hospital in Bronxville, N. Y. Tuesday. He was 82 years old and lived at 125 Brown Road Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: 2 Soviet Embassy Men Called Spies by Dutch
description: THE HAGUE, May 6Two members of the Soviet Em bassy were named today as spies by the Dutch Govern ment. They had attracted of ficial attention after they ran their automobile into a canal.

title: Thirst Drives Man to Drink
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca (AP)Patrolmen in suburban Rosettenville found the glass door of a liquor, store smashed and Ronald Pattison inside taking bottles from tte shelves. Mr. Pattison explained, may bay, I was a bit thirsty. He was given a suspended nine month sentence.

title: Musical Legend ReCreated in Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 There are certain legend ary pieces of music, and one of them is the Violin Concerto in D Minor, the socalled Hungarian Concerto by Jo seph Joachim. Its reputation is high. So eminent an au thority as the English anal yst Sir Donald Tovey ranked it with the Brahms Violin Concerto.

title: Vatican Aides Assert Prague Is Harassing Church Again
description: ROME, May 6Vatican offi cials report that harassment of the Roman Catholic Church is being accelerated again in Czechoslovakia.

title: Persons With Skills of the 1800's Sought for Restoration in Nassau
description: OLD BETHPAGE, L. I., May 6Wanted: Blacksmith, weav er, candlemaker, whittler, story teller and a tailor who can fit and alter men's clothing of the preCivil war era.

title: Owner Takes Pains and Time To Coat Lakeland Terr6iers
description: THERE is a great deal of work in getting the coats of Lakeland terriers into ex actly the right show condi tion, but is spread over a long period of time go the task is not too demanding, said Mrs. Vellmer Brewin, who owns the Petercrest Kennel with her husband at Agawam, Mass. She was discus sing coats at the noncompeti tive dog show of the Manhattan Savings Bank, 47th Street and Madison Avenue. It's a two hour event starting at noon. The show ends to morrow.

title: Drive Meets Resistance
description: PLEIDJERENG, Cambodia, May 6American and South Vietnamese troops made slow progress today in the second day of their efforts to find and destroy Communist bases in the rugged Se San area of north eastern Cambodia.

title: City and State Used 191 Wiretaps in '69 Against 33 by the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  Policemen and prosecutors in New York State used almost six times as many wiretaps last year as the Justice Department did in the entire country, it was disclosed today.

title: Wharton Esherick, a Sculptor And Furniture Designer, Dies
description: PAOLI, Pa., May 6Wharton Esherick, a furniture designer and sculptor, died of an infec tion today at the Paoli Memo rial Hospital. He was 83 years old and had lived here since 1916.

title: Chess:
description: THE Esthonian Paul Keres of the Soviet Union, long a thorn in every grandmas ter's side, was the high scorer for his 10man team during its recent match against players from the rest of the world at Belgrade. Keres defeated Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia by two wins and two draws. Only Bobby Fischer of the United States reached a similar plus, when he defeated the former world champion, Tigran Petrosian.

title: PAKISTAN TO SPEED END OF ENGLISH USE
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  A commission will work out the phased program for replacing English with Urdu and Bangla (Bengali), the two national lan guages for state business in Pakistan.

title: Vietnamese in Cambodia on the Road to Nowhere
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6Monsieur, asked the small Vietnamese woman in perfect French, do you know the Mai son de France?

title: HighLevel Panel Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate majority leader, urged President Nixon today to appoint a highlevel commission to investigate the fatal shooting of four Kent State University students and other campus violence around the nation.

title: DOUBT ON POLICY DENIED BY LAIRD
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Sec retry of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he had supported fully Presiden Nixon's decision to employ American ground troops agains Vietnamese Communist sanctu aries in Cambodia.

title: HOUSE BARS CURB ON THE PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 The House of Representatives, in a confused climax to an increas ingly emotional debate on Cam bodia, refused today either to sanction President Nixon's in tervention in Cambodia or to place restrictions on his au thority to undertake military operations in Southeast Asia.

title: Eulogy for Black Actor: He Lived Role Too Well
description: Yesterday, Richard Mason's family and friends came to the Unity Funeral Home in Harlem to say goodbye to him.

title: Books of The Times
description: STEP up and shake the cold hand of Max Jamison, if you dare. He's six feet two with a face like an English police sergeant. His mind has a spigot at the peak of its dome that drips muriatic acid on all that enters therethe plays and movies he sees, the women he beds and boards, the children he breeds, the feelings he feelsreducing them all to their false premises. He writes theater reviews for Now, the weekly newsmagazine, and movie criticism for Rearview, the intellec tual journal. He is the dean of American critics. He is Wilfrid Sheed's latest fic tonal study in agonized selfconsciousness.

title: 9 Get Jail Terms for Destruction at Offices of Dow
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  The nine men and women who overturned furniture and poured blood on files at the Washington offices of the Dow Chemical Company in March, 1969, were sentenced today to jail terms ranging from three months to six years.

title: CREDIT MARKETS STAGE A REBOUND
description: The credit markets, hardhit earlier this week, appeared to regain their health yesterday as the Treasury moved past its $3.5billion new cash note of fering and its $16.6billion re financing.

title: Pickets Ask State Urban Agency to Override L.I. Zoning Laws
description: The State Urban Develop ment Corporation encountered its first demonstrators yester day when 60 welfare mothers and college students from Suf folk County picketed and oc cupied the agency's Fifth Ave nue offices.

title: RESERVE DENIED 9 RATE RISES IN '69
description: WASHINGTON, May 6On nine different occasions last year the Federal Reserve Board unanimously rejected requests from individual Reserve banks for a higher discount rate, it was disclosed today.

title: 3 Men Leave Irish Cabinet in Crisis On Charges of Arms Flow to Ulster
description: DUBLIN, May 6The Irish Government was plunged into crisis today amid rumors that senior Cabinet ministers had been implicated in arrange ments to smuggle arms across the border to dissident Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland. three ministers left the Cab inet. The governing Fianna Fail (Soldiers of Destiny) party was badly shaken, the Prime Minis ter was challenged and a gen eral election was widely dis cussed.

title: Five Towns Luncheon
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I. May 6The Five Towns Music and Art Foundation will hold its scholarship luncheon on Tuesday at the Seawane Club here. Larry Rivers, the artist, will be the guest of honor and recipient of the foundation's 1970 Award of Distinction for his contribution to American modern art. Mrs. Emanuel Schaeffer is luncheon chair man.

title: F.B.I. Puts Rap Brown On MostWanted List
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation yesterday expanded its mostwanted list from 10 to 11adding H. Rap Brown, the black militant.

title: Julie Eisenhower Treated
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 6 (AP)Julie Nixon Eisen hower, daughter of the Presi dent, was released from Cooley Dickinson Hospital today after an overnight stay for what hos pital officials called a minor medical problem. Mrs. Eisen hower, a senior at Smith Col lege, was due to leave this weekend for Washington, re turning May 31 for graduation. Her husband, David, is a sen ior at nearby Amherst College.

title: Article 10  No Title
Dynamite Stolen Upstate
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., May (AP)Thirtyfive cases of dy namite have been stolen from a powder storage room in the Town of Fort Edward near here, the state police reported Tues day.

title: TIMOTHY SIMON
description: Timothy Simon, coowner of the publishing house of Gerald Duckworth of London, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 41 years old, and was here on business trip.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: FINER FUTURES BEGIN WITH FRESH AIR FUND.

title: Nominations in Soviet Show Brezhnev Ahead of Colleagues
description: MOSCOW, May 6  The Soviet Union has indicated, as it does every four years, the relative importance of the eleven members of the Politburo, the Communist party's ruling body.

title: Two State Systems Shut; City Road TieUp Planned
description: Two State Systems Shut; City Road TieUp Planned

title: NOJIMA DAZZLES IN PIANO DEBUT
description: Musiclovers who specialize in pianists should make space on their must hear list for Minoru Nojima, the 25yearold Japanese pianist who recently won the Van Cliburn Interna tional Piano Competition.

title: ATHLETES JOINING CAMPUS PROTEST
description: College athletes have joined the campus protests against the widening United States military involvement in Southeast Asia. Individual teams at four eastern colleges  Princeton, Columbia, Williams and Dartmouthhave withdrawn from competition and several events have been canceled.

title: SovietCzech Pact Signed; Backs Brezhnev Doctrine
description: PRAGUE, May 6 (Reuters) Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union today signed a new trea ty of friendship that endorses the socalled Brezhnev Doctrine used to justify the 1968 inva sion by Warsaw Pact nations.
