title: Leaders Prepare U.N. Event
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. May 6A convocation of lead ers to make preparations for the 25th anniversary of the United Nations is to open here May 20 under the chairmanship of retired Chief Justice Earl Warren. Included in the speak ing program are Governor Rock efeller, Mayor Lindsay and Arthur J. Goldber, former United States representative in the United Nations; Secretary General Thant and Ambassador Charles W. Yost, present chief United States representative.

title: Fountain House Ball on Tuesday
description: Friends of Fountain House are looking forward to their 14th annual Fte Champtre Tuesday, a dinner dance that helps support the rehabilita tion center for former pa tients of mental hospitals.

title: Stram of Chiefs to Be Cited As Super Bowl Super Man
description: Hank Stram of the Kansas City Chiefs will be honored by the New York Chapter of the Pro Football Writers' As sociation as the leading per former in the 1970 Super Bowl, the organization yesterday.

title: Mayor Reports Promotion Of 112 on Police Force
description: With a sharp attack on the confusion that can be caused by legal challenges to police promotion examinations, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the promotion of 90 men to captain and 84 to lieutenant.

title: Alessandro Serenelli, Murderer Of Girl Who Became Saint, Dies
description: MACERATA, Italy, May 6 (Reuters)Alessandro Serenelli, who in 1902 murdered a girl who later became a saint, died today in a Capuchin monastery here with a picture of his vic tim by his bedside. He was 88 years old.

title: HICKEL, IN NOTE TO NIXON, CHARGES ADMINISTRATION IS FAILING YOUTH; PROTESTS CLOSE OVER 80 COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  In an extraordinary letter of pro test, Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel complained to President Nixon today that the Administration was turning its back on the great mass of American youth and thereby contributing to anarchy and re volt.

title: INDICTMENTS NAME 6 CITY DETECTIVES
description: Six New York detectives have been indicted in connec tion with the alleged extortion of money from persons involved in narcotics.

title: Text of the Hickel Letter
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Following is a copy of the letter that Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel sent to President Nixon today:

title: Topless Shows May Test Coast Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 Ie's unconstitutional, Dave Rosenberg declared. What are we supposed to say: Come see the girls with their clothes off? Or, see the uncovered girls?

title: Copper Range on Prices
description: James Boyd, the newly elected chairman of the Copper Range Company, told share holders at the annual meeting in Boston yesterday that copper prices may rise again this year.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: THE late Ray Bergman meant a great deal to me, even though I never met him. Bergman, who died in 1967, was angling editor of Outdoor Life for more than a quartercentury and his authoritative advice in that publication was read by mil lions.

title: India Gets World Bank Loan To Raise Foodgrain Output
description: A $35million loan to India to help a substantial increase of foodgrain production was announced yesterday by the World Bank.

title: Controller's Job Once a Happy One
description: It is satisfactory to know that the city government oc cupies a sound financial po sition, both at home and in foreign countries.

title: SENATE APPROVES BIG CITY RAIL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  The Senate passed over whelmingly today and sent to the House a bill that would give limited Government back ing to a new quasipublic cor poration to run the nation's essential passenger trains.

title: 25 Guard Trucks Burn
description: LEWISTON, Idaho, May 5 (AP)Fire broke out Tuesday in rows of National Guard trucks parked at an armory here, and firemen said that at least 25 vehicles were destroyed. Police Chief Bill Siler said that it could not be determined im mediately what had started the blaze.

title: Old Papers Collected
description: BARNET, England (Canadian Press)John Frost is Britain's top news gatherer: he has a col lection of 10,000 newspapers dating back to 1630. His Hert fordshire home is bursting with the newsprint he has been hoarding for more than 30 years.

title: N.Y. U. Law School Is Focusing On Unifying Nationwide Protest
description: New York University Law School became a focal point yesterday for a coordinated na tional effort to mobilize student and faculty protests against the expanding war in Southeast Asia.

title: In The Nation: The Dead at Kent State
description: WASHINGTON, May 6It was obtuse and heartless for President Nixon to say of the dead at Kent State only that when dissent turns to violence it invites tragedy. It was in decent for Spiro Agnew to call this awful event predictable and avoidable, then to go on with one of his standard de nunciations of students, as if he and the President, pledged as they are to bring us together, had not instead done as much as anyone to drive us into con flict. No one has less right than they to murder the mankind of these senseless deaths with grave truths about violence and dissent.

title: Sihanouk May Visit Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, May 6News dispatches from Peking report ed today that Prince Norodom Sihanouk was planning a trip to North Vietnam next week. If he does make the trip he will be leaving Chinese Communist hosts who have lavished atten tion and support upon him re cently.

title: U.S. Reconsidering Possibility of Sale Of Planes to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 The State Department today termed unsatisfactory the Soviet explanation for the com mitment of Russian pilots to combat missions in the United Arab Republic. Then Washing ton promptly revived considera tion of the sale of additional aircraft to Israel.

title: JEAN HOXIE IS DEAD; EXTENNIS COACH, 71
description: MIDLAND, Mich. May 6 (AP) Jean Hoxie, whose tennis pupils included royalty and heads of state, died today in an automobile accident on the Northwood Institute campus in Midland. She was 71 years old.

title: 6 Ugandans Get Life Terms In Attempt on Obote's Life
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 6 (Reuters)  A court today sen tenced six men to life imprison ment on charges of having at tempted to assassinate Presi dent Milton Obote.

title: Owners Offer a Rent Plan Raising Controlled Units
description: Asserting that rent control caused housing decay, the As sociated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, Inc., pro posed a plan yesterday to in crease rents in most of the city's 1.3 million controlled apartments.

title: OIL CONSORTIUM SETS IRANIAN PACT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 6After three rounds of concentrated bargaining, the consortium of Western oil companies that ex port most of Iran's oil appeared today to have conceded vir tually the whole of the Iranian demand for payments this year of $1,155,000,000. A brief state ment from the Ministry of Finance here said the two sides had reached complete agree ment. No details or figures were officially given.

title: Wood's 'In Search of Gregory' Opens
description: WITH "In Search of Gregory," true love again eludes Julie Christie ("Darling" 1965, "Petulla" 1967, etc.) and leaves her with little more than a wealthy lover and a cup of sweet despair in yet another city (Rome) near a sun-kissed sea (Mediterranean) of that warm south in whichever hemisphere, where she generally repairs to savor her sadness.She has come to Geneva for her father's fifth wedding, to renew incestuous ties with her ne'er-do-well brother, and to seek the secret Gregorya wild young American, friend of father and brother, whose free spirit has made him a legend in his own time. He loves her because he's seen her picture. She probably loves him, and throughout her visit she keeps fantasizing him, though she hasn't even seen his picture. So you can imagine her surprise when she finally goes to bed with a fellow she thinks is Gregorysoundlessly, the way they do in some great movie seductionsand she finds out afterward, when he starts talking, that he has a slight German accent and is, in fact, a medical student named Gunter.At the end she almost meets Gregory, the real Gregory, in a telephone booth in the Geneva airport, but by a series of unlikely non-coincidences Unkind Fate keeps them apart. All of which makes Unkind Fate seem rather a nitwitperfect type casting for this movie."In Search of Gregory," fails not so much from the stupidity of its plot as from the dim timidity of its inventions. From the fantasy Gregory's demonstrations of personal uniqueness to Gunter-Gregory's climactic game of "Autoball" (a form of soccer-field pollution that looks like lacrosse played out of the back seats of little cars) every crucial incident dulls and strains, and does not excite, the imagination.It turns out, for example, that the real Gregory has a business, a garage-factory where he cans a little nothing that he labels "Air des Alpes." One might grant the symbolism if the cans weren't vacuum sealedso that the only reasonable interpretation is consumer fraud.Among the principal actors, John Hurt (the brother) survives the best because he is very talented and because his role allows him at least the hint of a characterization in the question of whether he's queerer for his sister or his best friend. Michael Sarrazin falls the hardest because his role allows him nothing on which to build a characterization.And Julie Christie, who is now old enough, and whose lovely mobile face is now drawn fine enough to add poignancy to her sense of wistfulness  she is being destined by her movies to pass from anticipation to nostalgia for a life that she has never been allowed to live at all.

title: All Eyes on Hogan Today in Houston Champions' Golf
MARKETS ABROAD IN TECHNICAL RISE
description: Most stock markets abroad closed higher yesterday in what appeared to be mainly a tech nical reaction to the low price levels reached in recent sharp declines.

title: WakeUp Service Ends
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca (AP)South Africans can no longer ask for a cheery wake up call from their tele phone operator. The early morning alarmclockbyphone program has been discontinued because it was getting out of hand.

title: CITY HIGH SCHOOLS JOIN IN PROTESTS
description: Demonstrations, protests and boycotts hit at least 20 of the city's 90 public high schools yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
Legal Aid Society Lawyers End 3Day Job Action
description: Striking lawyers employed by the Legal Aid Society voted yesterday to return to work this morning, Steven Bernstein, chairman of the lawyers' nego tiating committee, announced las night.

title: Cambodian Troops Move Up
description: PNAMPENH, Cambodia, May 6 (AP)The Cambodian Army moved about 2,000 soldiers into position today near a ferry crossing on the Mekong River held by the enemy, 37 miles southeast of Pnempenh.

title: WALLACE SECOND TO GOV. BREWER IN PRIMARY VOTE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 6 The support of Negroes and affluent whites put Gov. Albert P. Brewer over former Gov. George C. Wallace in Alabama's Democratic gubernatorial pri mary yesterday.

title: House Honors Celler
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The House honored its dean, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, with a standing ovation today on his 82d birthday. Although many members have served in Con gress beyond that age, only two in the history of the House have topped his long service, which began in 1923.

title: Rogers Welcomes Appeal By Thant for Indochina Talks
description: Rogers Welcomes Appeal By Thant for Indochina Talks

title: Mississippi Bishops Back Catholic and Anglican Union
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 5 The Roman Catholic and Epis copal Bishops of Mississippi backed Tuesday that newly an nounced goal of full commu nion and organic union of the Anglican and Catholic commu nions.

title: INDIANA NOMINATES 11 REPRESENTATIVES
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 (UPI) Indiana's 11 representatives were renominated in yester day's primaries.

title: SESSION IN PARIS CANCELED BY REDS
description: PARIS, May 6North Viet nam and the Vietcong today called off the 66th plenary ses sion of the Vietnam peace talks almost at the last moment.

title: L.I. Town Mourns a Kent State Victim
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., May 6 This community has drawn to gether out of a sense of confu sion and bereavement over the death of Jeffrey Glenn Miller, one of four Kent State Univer sity students killed by National Guardsmen on Monday.

title: Bridge:
description: ONE of the bestknown players in the Middle West, Edwin J. Smith of De troit, died last month at the age of 55. Bud Smith, as he was known throughout the tournament world, won two national titles, many regional titles and a reputation as a charming opponent.

title: Christian Scientist Editor
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)The Christian Science Church Board of Directors announced today the election of Carl J. Welz of San Francisco as editor of The Christian Science Journal, The Christian Science Sentinel and The Herald of Christian Sci ence. Mr. Welz succeeds Mrs Helen W. Bauman.

title: Dutch Team Wins Europe Soccer Cup
description: MILAN, Italy, May 6Per severance and plodding stam ina paid off tonight as the Fiejenoord team from Rotter dam gained a 2 to 1 victory in overtime over Glasgow Celtic and possession of the European Soccer Cup.

title: PREMIERES OFFERED IN ELECTRONIC WEEK
description: The ColumbiaPrinceton Elec tronic Music Center was to have started its Electronic Music Weew, celebrating its 10th an niversary, on Tuesday night, with a concert for the Columbia community. That one was called off, a casualty of the current wave of student protest.

title: EXOFFICIAL GUILTY IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)A Suf folk Superior Court jury con victed George L. Brady of con spiracy today in the theft of $400,000 from the Boston Com mon Underground Garage proj ect.

title: Luxury Liner Is Basis Of Bankruptcy Petition
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (UPI)  The former luxury liner Queen Elizabeth, a tour ist attraction at Fort Lauder dale, Fla., is the basis of a bankruptcy petition filed at Federal District Court here.

title: Workers' Buying Power Lags Despite Wage Increases Here
description: An average factory produc tion worker's pay check in the metropolitan area has gone up in dollars but has lost 3.9 per cent in buying power in the last two years, including 1.9 per cent eroded in the last year.

title: Demonstrators Abroad Denounce U.S. Over Cambodia, and Support Students
description: Demonstrations against the United States advance into Cambodia and in support of American student protests broke out in a number of countries yesterday as fresh antiwar sen timent appeared to be growing abroad.

title: Fonteyn's Ballet Hans
description: Sol Hurok, who brougnt the Royal Ballet to New York for its current appearance, said yesterday that Dame Margot Fonteyn wasexpected to dance with the company again in future saesons. The British company is scheduled to visit the United States again in 1972.

title: PIANO, CLARINET BLEND IN BENEFIT
description: They made an incongruous pair last night at Alice Tully Hall, each in flight from his past but coming together mo mentarily like conjoining stars. Benny Goodman, gray and dis tinguishedlooking in black tie and dinner jacket, could have been mistaken forwhat did they used to call it, again?a longhair? And Peter Serkin, scion of the Serkins, in long, white maharishi tunic and shoulderlength tresses, could have been taken forwhat do they call it?a hippie?

title: Accidents Come Double
description: YORK, England (AP)  Ste phen Thornton, 22 years old, was treated at a hospital for facial injuries after his auto mobile and a truck collided, and returned with a broken leg after the police cruiser taking him home struck another car.

title: Cambodia Ending Neutralist Stance
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6  Communist China, North Vietnam and North Korea broke diplomatic relations with Cambodia today. At the same time the new Government here agreed to the establishment of relations with South Vietnam in the near future and prepared to abandon its recognition of the Vietcong.

title: 7 City Employes Receive Awards for Their Work
description: Mayor Lindsay presented awards yesterday to seven city employes for excellence of per formance at a City Hall cere mony in the Board of Estimate chambers.

title: Dam Moratorium Gains
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The Senate Interior Commit tee approved today a bill to ban construction of nonFederal power dams in the Snake River bordering Idaho and Oregon. The bill calls for an eightyear moratorium against the licens ing of dams by the Federal Power Commission in the mid dle reach of the Snake River.

title: Plantation Workers Pull Out With Enemy
description: SNOUL, Cambodia, May 6 (AP)The French manager of a rubber plantation caught in the fighting here said to day that the North Viet namese had armed most of his 1,600 workers and had taken them along as they fled from United States tank and air attacks.

title: DUST COMMANDER REPORTED AILING
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 (AP) Don Combs, trainer of the Kentucky Derby winner, Dust Commander, said today the swelling in the horse's foreleg had gone down and it appeared he would be able to race in the Preaknees a week from Saturday.

title: DutchShell Cites 4.9% Profit Drop
description: Net income of the Royal DutchShell Group or Compa nies in the first quarter de clined 4.9 per cent to $222.5 million after depreciation, from $234million in the correspond ing three months last year, it was reported yesterday. Net sales, however, increased to $2.55billion from $2.37billion, bringing total revenues to $2.68 billion, up from $2.48billion.

title: A WARNING SYSTEM ON ECOLOGY URGED
description: GENEVA, May 6Dr. Mar colino G. Candau, director gen eral of the World Health Or ganization, urged today the creation of an international detection and warning system to protect man against harm ful changes in his environment Dr. Candau, a Brazilian, said the projected system should hey/permit the study at the leve of the city, nation, and even continent, the factors which modify our environment.

title: WINDSHIELD BREAKS ARE 'BROKEN DOWN
description: PITTSBURGH (UPI)  West Coast drivers are more likely to get a broken windshield or a cracked window than motorists in New York, Dallas or Cin cinnati.

title: NADER IS SUPPORTED BY HARVARD FACULTY
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 The Harvard faculty of Arts and Sciences urged the uni versity's governing board yes terday to vote Harvard's 270,000 shares of General Motors stock in support of Ralph Nader's plan to reorgan ize the G.M. board.

title: BIG BOARD TIGHTENS WATCH ON MEMBERS
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday it had informally adopted a new procedure for obtaining early warnings of possible financial distress of member concerns. A spokesman said a firm would he considered approaching a danger area when its capital ration reached one to 12.

title: MARGIN CUT CALLED WRONG MEDICINE
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Reprsentative Henry S. Reuss, a member of the Joint Congressional Economic Com mittee, said today the Admini stration was using the wrong medicine to help the economy

title: Trade Center to Get Huge Sculpture
description: A sculpture that is ex pected to be the largest free standing stone carving of modern times has been com missioned by the Port of New York Authority for the plaza between the two super skyscrapers of the World Trade Center, now under construction.

title: RUSSELL J. APGAR
description: ROSELLE, N. J., May 6  Russell J. Apgar of 205 Martin Street, former president of the First National Bank of Roselle for 20 years, died yesterday at his home apparently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: All Out for Safeguard
description: The emphasis with which President Nixon urged Republican Congressional chiefs to go out and fight for Safeguard ABM expansion suggests that the auth orization bill is in serious trouble and that the Presi dent is committing his personal prestige in a battle to save it. Mr. Nixon's vehemence is unlikely to con vince many Senate critics that Phase II of the antibal listic missile system is needed now to defend the nation; but it may persuade some to come to the defense of their party's leader.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 12% LOGGING CUT IS DUE IN OREGON
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Sec retary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel announced today a plan for a 12 per cent cut in logging operations on Oregon forest lands under his jurisdic tion.

title: COOP CONVERSION FROZEN BY STATE
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday froze all processing of applications to convert rental apartment houses to cooperatives where the build ings are subject to the city's new Rent Stabilization Law.

title: Aurelio and 20 Students Weigh the Fine Art of Governing
description: Using the city's rentcon trol controversy as a case in point, Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio and 20 college students discussed the art, practice and philosophy of government and its response to political pressures and the changing needs of city dwellers.

title: Boyle Replacement Named
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP) Samuel M. Flaksman, a resi dent of Oaks Bluff on the island of Martha's Vineyard, was selected today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent to replace Judge James A. Boyle on the bench of Dukes County District Court. Judge Boyle, who retired May 1, presided at the inquest in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne.

title: Competition Loss Seen
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Justice Department said today that more would be lost to the public tha gained by further mergers among giant electric companies and, because of this, it was opposing two such mergers that were pending be fore the Securities and Ex change Commission.

title: William M. Lichtenstein, Former Bridge Champion
description: William Mason Lichtenstein, a consultant and former vice president of Wullschleger & Co., Inc., textile manufacturers of 1450 Broadway, who won several major bridge cham pionships, died of a heart at tack Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He lived at 5 West 86th Street.

April was a big month in New York for museum birthdays: 100 years for the Metropolitan, 50 years for the Frick, and ten for the Guggenheim. The Met cele brated its centenary with formal hoopla, the Frick marked its half century with quiet dignity, and the Guggenheim put out some of its hidden treasures on its gogo ramp as a salute to its institutional maturity.

title: Making Protest Count
description: President Nixon's decision to expand the Vietnam war into Cambodia and the killing of four university students by National Guard bullets have produced swelling tide of protest that has united many disparate elements on campuses all over the country.

title: Illinois Deploys Guard
description: More than 80 colleges across the country closed their doors yesterday for periods ranging from a day to the remainder of the academic year as thou sands of students joined the growing nationwide campus protest against the war in Southeast Asia.

title: War Protesters and Government Are at Odds Over Site of Capital Rally Saturday
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Despite a more conciliatory at titude by the Justice Depart ment than it has shown in the past, the Government and pro test leaders remained at logger heads today over the plans for the antiwar demonstration scheduled here for Saturday.

title: Article 7  No Title
Washington: For the Record
Taft Beats Rhodes in Ohio, Faces Metzenbaum in Fall
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6 Representative Robert Taft Jr., who campaigned on a platform of integrity, defeated Gov. James A. Rhodes by 3,165 votes yesterday to win Ohio's Re publican nomination for the Senate.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW SHARP DROP
description: Futures pricet of wheat and soybeant dropped sharply yes terday on the Chicago Board of Trade while the prices of other grains also closed lower.

title: Former Laborite M.P. Wins Acquittal in Espionage Case
description: LONDON, May 6  Will Owen, a former Labor party member of Parliament, was cleared today of charges that he had given Czechoslovak dip lomats secret information from Parliamentary files.

title: J. JAY HODUPP, 59, OF ADVERTISING FIRM
description: J. Jay Hodupp, president of Hodupp Kansler Associates here, a marketing and adver tising concern, died Sunday at his home, 333 East 46th Street. He was 59 years old.

title: Magnavox Expands
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 6  The Magnavox Company plans to enter the home color video recording and cabletele vision studio equipment fields, Robert H. Platt, president, told 150 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.

title: Membership Age Lowered
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The League of Women voters decided today to lower its (minimum age for membership from 21 to 18. The action came on an overwhelming vote at the league's national conven tion, where the organization is observing its 50th anniversary.

title: WITNESS DENIES ALIOTO PRESSURE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 A former officer of the First San Francisco Bank testified to day that Joseph L. Alioto, the bank's board chairman, never put any pressure on me to make any loan from the bank.

title: Lindsay Assails War Policy
description: Mayor Lindsay assailed Presi dent Nixon's Cambodian policy last night and called for a new notsosilent majority of dis senters to move this country to end the war in Indochina.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RIFE IN MOROCCO
description: RABAT, Morocco (UPI)The Kingdom of Morocco, inde pendent for 15 years, has a serious and seemingly insoluble problema high rate of unem ployment.

title: Theater: Zoe and Colette
description: STANLEY met Livingstone. Emlyn Williams met Charles Dickens. Last night at the Ellen Stewart Theater, Zoe Caldwell met Colette. It was quite a meeting.

title: Diamond Jubilee For Boy Scouts Set for Monday
description: The Boy Scout Gala Dia mond Jubilee Dinner Dance, to be held in the Grand Ball room at the WaldorfAstoria on Monday, will mark the 60th anniversary of the Boy Scouts of America and bene fit the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts.

title: Browns Put Keys on Staff
description: CLEVELAND, May 7 (AP) The Cleveland Browns named Howard Keys, a former Oklaho na State University and Phila delphia Eagles player, as back field coach today.

title: Riders Minus Exact Fares Will Miss Birmingham Bus
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  Drivers of oneman buses can make passengers without the correct fare wait for the next bus, the West Midland Pas senger Transport Authority has disclosed.

title: Article 6  No Title
Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, May, 6, 1970

title: War and U.S. Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Al though money market operators, as well as the general public, are understandably skeptical, there is good reason to believe the Government's assurances this time that the foray into Cambodia will have only a neg ligible effect on defense spend ing and hence the Federal budget. The issue of the budget is of major import ance to the future course of the mar ket and interest ratesand hence, indirectly, to the stock market.

title: Bergen Detective Figure In De Carlo Tapes Resigns
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., May 5 (AP)Bergen County Chief of Detectives Walter H. Spahr sub mitted his resignation Tuesday effective July 15.

title: City Says It Did Not Ratify Police Pay Contract
description: An assistant corporation coun for the city, warning that in creased pay demands by police men threaten the financial sta bility of the city, said yesterday that the recently approved con tract between the city and the police on which the pay in creases are based had not been officially ratified by the city.

title: Son of Mr. Republican
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  When he first ran for Congress in 1962, Robert Al phonso Taft Jr. frequently spoke disdainfully of the Kennedy dynasty and its power grab in Washington. This prompted one Democrat to say indignantly: Let me tell you about a real dynasty.

title: President Orders Report on Shooting
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  President Nixon ordered a com plete report on the fatal shoot ing by National Guard troops of four students at Kent State University after he had con ferred for nearly an hour with six of their fellow students.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Go quickly and report they have taken me away, she said. Tell them what hap pened. Tell them Madame Ne ung was taken away.

title: 3BILLION FOR SPACE IS VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Senate approved today a $3.3billion space agency budg et, rejecting liberal protests that it was spending more for astro naut playthings than for pressing education and health needs.

title: Manchester United Downs Bari, 2 to 1, At Randalls Island
description: George Best, to many the most exciting soccer player in the world, dropped in for 45 minutes at Randalls Island last night and stored a goal for Manchester United, which de feated Bari of Italy, 21. Some of the 7,000 fans on hand 5,823 paidbuilt fires in the stands to keep themselves warm in the chilly night.

title: FACELIFTING DUE FOR BIRMINGHAM
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 1 To the casual visitor, the face of Birmingham is still white.

title: Jackson Assails Fans and Says Oakland Is No Baseball Town
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 6 The sound may be the wind, the vicious hawk circling noisily in the Oakland Coli seum. It is cold enough to be the wind.

title: 13 Guard Rifles Taken to Kent State Police Office as F.B.I. Agents Study Shootings
description: KENT, Ohio, May 6  Thir teen M1 rifles were brought to the campus police office at Kent State University today as agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation looked into the deaths of four students in a volley of National Guard rifle fire on Monday.

title: Chester Weinberg's Designs That Fashionable Melancholy
description: THERE are hundreds of little tired dresses on Seventh Avenue. They've been around a long time, and the extra length they're carrying around for fall hasn't eased their spirits.

title: Fight for Wage Stability
description: Chicago has become the pivotal battlefield in a fight that may determine whether some brake can be put on the wageprice spiral. Dissident truck drivers that city are spearheading an effort to upset the national agreement negotiated a month ago by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the employers of 450,000 truckmen.

title: Soviet Aide Back in Peking
description: PEKING, May 6 (Agence FrancePresse)  Vasily V. Kuznetsov, leader of the Soviet delegation at the ChineseSo viet negotiations, has returned to Peking after an absence of 17 days.

title: Pulsar Electronic Watch Introduced by Hamilton
description: The Hamilton Watch Com pany introduced yesterday a computerprogramed electronic wristwatch that has no hands and no moving parts.

title: Ohio Guardsmen Defend Shooting of Kent Students
description: KENT, Ohio, May 6If they wouldn't have shot, they would have been killedkilled with their own weapons, said the sergeant of the Ohio National Guard.

title: McCulloch Oil Finds Gas
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 (UPI) The McCulloch Oil Corpora tion and Investors Diversified Services announced today third natural gas discovery in the Anadarko Basin, Okla., under their joint oilexplora tion program of 1969.

title: June Draft Call Is 15,000, All Slated for Duty in Army
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today a draft call of 15,000 for the month of June, the same as in May.

title: Cairo Seeks Arab Unity
description: CAIRO, May 6Senior Egyp tian officials began flying from Cairo today on urgent missions to seek unified retaliation by the Arab world against any move by the United States to deliver more military aircraft to Israel.

title: NIXON PRESS AIDE TV GUEST TONIGHT
description: Herbert G. Klein, the Nixon Administration's director of communications, is going on a television talk show to explain the Administration's viewpoint on the Cambodian situation.

title: Mothers' Group Urges War Protest on Sunday
description: A dozen wellknown moth ers, including Shirley Mac laine, Shelley Winters and Betsy Palmer, the actresses, called yesterday on women to celebrate Mother's Day by protesting the expansion of the war into Cambodia.

title: World Labor Meeting Set
description: Plans for a conference on worldwide labor problems to be Iheld in Brussels by multina tional companies' executives Sept. 2025 were announced yesterday by Human Resource Services, Inc., New York man agement consulting concern.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: GIVE A KID A CAMP. VIA FRESH AIR FUND.

title: Dow Fights Pollution
description: MIDLAND, Mich., May 6 Herbert D. Doan, the president of the Dow Chemical Company, told 1,000 stockholders at their annual meeting today that the corporation would play a vigor ous role in improving the en vironment.

title: Son of Hicket Joining Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6  John Hickel, a son of Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel, plans to join a student strike at the University of San Francisco tomorrow in protest against United States policy in Vietnam.

title: PrudentialGrace Names Executive
description: A specialist in containeri zation, Mr. Camuti joined Prudential Lines as vice president for traffic in 1962 from American Export Lines where he had served as gen eral freight and traffic man ager.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Mr. Sinclair said that 1970 will not be one of our best years. He added, We are fairly confident, however, that it will be better than is indi cated by the firstquarter re sults and reasonably hopeful it will be better than 1969. He said that railway expenses were bearing the additional costs of wage increases pro vided for in various union contracts.

title: Pressmen Threaten Job Action To End Paper Talks Stalemate
description: The pressmen's president warned last night that his union would take job action at The New York Times and possibly at the city's other newspapers as long as there was no prog ress in contract negotiations.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: A sharp rally in the first hour of trading highlighted the activity on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and gave the list enough momentum to finish the session higher al though selling pressure in the early afternoon erased some of the gains.

title: Economists Charge Unions Lead Move To Protectionism
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI)  Two economists charged to day that labor unions were leading a move toward more trade protectionism in this country.

title: WNDT to Remain Independent, Chairman Vows
description: WNDTTV, Channel 13, the New York area's public televi sion outlet, reacting to reports that it might emerge with Na tional Educational Television, said yesterday that there are no plans for Channel 13 in any sense giving up its inde pendence.

title: James Robert Bedell Is Fiance Of Miss Judith A. M. Costello
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. John J. Costello have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Judith Anne Miriamne Costello, to James Robert Bedell, son of Mrs. Clarence Aloysius Bedell of Mineola and the late Mr. Bedell. An August wedding is planned.

title: RAMPAGE CLOSES WASHINGTON HIGH
description: George Washington High School was forced to close at noon yesterday after students went on a rampage in the lunchroom, set fires in lockers and smashed their way into the principal's office, where they overturned furniture and cabi nets.

title: Activity Stepped Up Here
description: The tempo of student pro test over United States involve ment in Cambodia and the shootings at Kent State Uni versity quickened yesterday in the metropolitan area, and the scope of demonstrations broad ened, moving off the campus and into the streets as the em phasis shifted from strikes at colleges to activities involving the nonacademic world.

title: VIENNA ARMS TALKS PROCEED SMOOTHLY
description: VIENNA, May 6Soviet and American negotiators continued their search here today for an agreement on nucleararms lim itation as if nothing had hap pened in Cambodia or in the Middle East.

title: Pacers Set Back Colonels, 117103, for Eastern Title
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 (AP) Indiana defeated the Ken tucky Colonels, 117103, tonight to capture the American Bas ketball Association Eastern Di vision playoff final 4 games to 1.

title: Predictable and Royal Signal Take Divisions of Comely Stakes at Aqueduct
description: The Wheatley Stable's Pre dictable and Mrs. Lawrence W. Knapp Jr.'s Royal Singal took the honors in the Comely at Aqueduct yesterday. The seven furlong event for 3yearold fil lies proved a popular one with owners and trainers and had to be run in two divisions.

title: From Teachers to Soldiers in Two Weeks, With Eight Bullets
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6The First Battalion of Commandos of the Teach ing Profession came un evenly to attention and pre sented arms, using World War I rifles.

title: Auto Dealers Here Elect
description: Harold Stern, president of Rambler Freeport of Freeport, L. I. has been elected president of the Greater New York, Long Island and Westchester Auto mobile Dealers Association. He succeeds Henry D. Spielman.

title: JERSEYAN GUILTY IN POLICE DEATH
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., May 6 (AP)Bobby Lee Williams, a Negro, was found guilty by a jury tonight of assaulting Pa trolman John V. Gleason during the 1967 Plainfield riots. The policeman was slain by an angry crowd.

title: Bangkok Sees U.S. Move in Cambodia as Vindication of Its Policy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 6 Some part of Thailand's long border with her eastern neigh Thor, Cambodia, are only 150 miles from the new fighting fronts opened against the Com munists there, but if the Thais are suffering any nervousness about the prospect the war will reach them, they are conceal ing it.

title: Thrysler Expanding Force At Its Los Angeles Plant
description: DETROIT, May 6 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation said to day it was recalling 450 laid off workers and employing 150 more at its Los Angeles as sembly plant, effective May 18.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Defense Department to day identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Myth of Supremacy

title: Arlene Wilck To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Arlene Sue Wilck to Gilbert Gold has been announced by Mrs. Irving Wilck, mother of the future bride. Mr. Gold is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben jamin Gold. Both families are of New York.

title: FIVE ARE INDICTED IN YABLONSKI CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., May 6  The five persons named as suspects in the conspiracy to Skill Joseph A. Yablonski, the deader of an insurgent faction in the United Mine Workers of America who was shot to death last December, were in dicted here today for first degree murder.

title: United Fruit Link Hit
description: The Federal Trade Commis sion issued a proposed com plaint yesterday challenging the AMK Corporation's ac quisition of United Fruit Com pany in 1969 on the ground that it violated Federal anti trust laws.

title: Alaska Curbs Hunting of Bears, Decimated by Oilmen and Killing From Air
description: Oil prospecting activities on the treeless North Slope of Alaska have so decimated the grizzily bears of that region, one of the last large reservoirs of the species, that Alaskan officials have eliminated this year's spring hunting season. The season world have run from May 15 to May 31.

title: BLUES ERA REVIVED BY LARRY JOHNSON
description: The fading era of blues before instruments became electrified was explored last night by Larry Johnson, a singer and guitarist, at the Washington Square Church, 133 West 4th Street.

title: DR. DUDLEY DEGROOT, EXFOOTBALL COACH
description: EL CAJON, Calif., May 6 (AP)Dr. Dudley S. DeGroot, a former rugby and football star and National Football League coach, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Pharmacy Award Presented
description: ALBANY, May 6The Fran cis J. O'Brien Award for out standing service to the pharma ceutical profession was pre sented here tonight to S Charles Savio, executive secre tary of the Pharmaceutical So ciety of the State of New York. The award is made annually by Kappa Psi Fraternity, which represents both students and alumni of pharmacy colleges. The award Is named for the dean emeritus of the Albany College of Pharmacy and Union University.

title: A Blood Substance Made in Test Tube
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Sci entists have made hemoglobin  the oxygencarrying sub stance fucnd is red corpuscles in a testLobe system free of intact living cells. The key achievement of the research was the discovery of three initiation factorssub stances that living cells must have to produce any new pro teins. The initiators are believed to he the first ever discovered in mammalian cells.

title: MARGIN CUT STIRS RALLY IN MARKET
description: The stock market, performing in almost textbook fashion, staged a dynamic rally yester day in its initial response to slashing of margin require ments by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: HARRIES A. MUMMA
description: Harries A. Mumma, a lawyer, died at the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N. Y., on Mon Iday, after a short illness. He was 84 years old and lived on Hawthorne Road in Bronxville.

title: Bloody Mama, Gangster Film, Begins Its Run
U.S. Court in Boston Bars Prosecution of Hair Cast
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP) A threejudge federal court in a split decision today barred Suf folk County District Attorney Garrett H. Byrne from prose cuting the producers of Hair, the ock musical show, on the ground of obscentity.

title: A SOVIET ZIONIST, 37, LEAVES FOR ISRAEL
description: MOSCOW, May 6Yuli Tele sin, an avowed Soviet Zionist who had been attacked in the press, was permitted today to leave the country.

title: Thant Appeals for Funds For World Youth Meeting
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6  Secretary General Thant appealed today for funds for the United Nations World Youth Assembly and said that cancellation of the nineday meeting would have damaging effects on the relations between generations for a long time to come.

title: AUGUST MERZ, 96, CHEMICAL OFFICIAL
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., May 6 August Merz, former presi dent of the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturers Asso ciation, died yesterday in his home at 333 South Harrison Street. He was 96 years old.

title: Healey Bets Week's Pay On U.S. NATO Forces
description: LONDON, May 6Defense Secretary Denis Healey con fidently bet a week's salary, the equivalent of $392, that the United States would not withdraw 25,000 men from its armed forces in Europe during the next year.

title: NEW U. S. THRUSTS IN CAMBODIA OPEN TWO MORE FRONTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6  Fresh American combat troops pushed into Cambodia at two new locations today, widening operations there to six fronts and bringing to near ly 50,000 the number of allied troops committed to the Cam bodia forays.

title: GOLDMANN HECKLED BY STUDENTS AGAIN
description: TEL AVIV, May 6  Heck ling students drove Dr. Nahum Goldmann off a campus plat form today for the second time in a week. Dr. Goldmann, Pres ident of the World Jewish Con gress, left the rostrum at Bar Ilan University in Ramat Gan today without having complet ed the first sentence of his lec ture. Last week he abruptly left an auditorium at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem because of disturbances by students.

title: Oscar Wegelin, Bookseller And Bibliographer, Dead
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., May 6 Oscar Wegelin, a bibliographer and former rare book dealer, died Sunday at his home here. He was 93 years old and lived at 149 Harrison Avenue.

title: NEW STAMPS ISSUED AT HISTORY MUSEUM
description: The American Museum of Na tural History, closing its ob servance of the centennial of its funding, was the site yester day morning for the issuance of four United States stamps commemorating America's ef forts in the natural history sci iences.

title: Blast Off Louisiana Kills 3 on Oil Drilling Platform
description: MORGAN CITY, La., May 6 (AP)Three men were killed and six were injured today when an explosion ripped the living quarters at an oil drill ing platform about 50 miles off the southern Louisiana coast.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert D. Mulholland, vice chairman of the Bank of Montreal, has been elected chairman of the British Newfoundland Corporation (Brinco), suc ceeding Henry Borden. Mr. Mulholland retains his post with the bank.

title: Reagan Closes Campus System in Face of Disorders
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 6Gov. Ronald Reagan ordered today that all 28 University of California and state college campuses be closed for four days in the face of spreading disorders over the killing of four Kent State college stu dents in Ohio and American in volvement in Cambodia.

title: American Brands Meets
description: The American Brands, Inc., annual meeting here yesterday, was enlivened by a variety of subjects, ranging from mari juana, cyclamates, crushed cookies, pesticides, AM and PM juices, the Sunshine Bus, and acquisitions.

title: MRS. NIARCHOS DIED OF SLEEPING PILLS
description: ATHENS, May 6Eugenia Niarchos, 44yearold wife of the Greek shipping magnate, Stavros Niarchos, died of an overdose of sleeping pills, ac cording to a death certificate issued by the Athens coroners office today.

title: Stage: Fernald's Cherry Orchard
description: THEATERGOERS are in debted to ANTA for invit ing the John Fernald Company of the Meadow Brook Theater at Oakland University, to give the group its full title, for a twoguestweek engage ment at the ANTA Theater.

title: Advertising: Ketchum Buys a London Shop
description: Having gotten its feet wet on the international scene in Japan, Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove of Pittsburgh and New York has now moved to England.

title: Mayor Reports Promotion Of 112 on Police Force
description: With a sharp attack on the confusion that can be caused by legal challenges to police promotion examinations, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the promotion of 90 men to captain and 84 to lieutenant.

title: ROMNEY IN PLEDGE ON MODEL CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, assured Congress today that the Administration would not divert money from Model Cities to President Nixon's spe cial program for school deseg regation without first seeking Congressional approval.

title: Miss Seward Plans Nuptials
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 6The engagement of Miss Virginia Anne Seward to Dr. William French Woods has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Se ward. The prospective bride groom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Woods of Valley Stream and Wood stock. Vt.

title: YANKS' 6 IN FIFTH DEFEAT A'S, 7 TO 6
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 6 Jean Stottlemyre and her two older boys traveled down from Mabton, Wash., to watch their favorite righthander achieve his 100th major league victory tonight.

title: Artist Barred by Stalin Is Honored
description: MOSCOW, May 6Leading Soviet ballet personalities paid homage today at the funeral of an influential choreographer who spent most of his creative life in artistic exile during the Stalin era.

title: Lakers Overwhelm Knicks, 135113, to Square Title Playoff Series at 33
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6Wilt Chamberlain scored 45 points and got 27 rebounds tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers reduced the National Basketball Associ ation's championship series to a single deciding game by beat ing the New York Knickerbock ers, whose Willis Reed was un able to play because of a leg injury.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Trades Secrets Suit Filed By Genesco Is Dismissed
description: A Middlesex County Superior Court in Boston has dismissed a trade secrets suit filed by Genesco, Inc., against three former officers of a subsidiary, the Berkshire Apparel Corpora tion.

title: JAMES W. ESCHER, HEADED BUILDERS
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 6 James W. Escher, honorary chairman of the White Con struction Company, New York builders, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 179 Lin coln Street.

title: British See Growing Shipping Demand
description: LONDON, May 6A Govern ment committee predicted to day that there would be grow ing world demand for shipping and urged changes in Britain's industry to enable it to remain competitive.

title: Bourbon Sale by the Glass Is Barred in Bourbon Land
description: FRANKFORT, Ky. (AP)  Kentucky's Nelson County has another form of the problem facing the Ancient Mariner Bourbon, bourbon everywhere but nary a drop to drink, in public.

title: BENNETT OPPOSES BANKHOLDING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Senator Wallace F. Bennett of Utah, the ranking Republican on the Senate Banking Commit tee, expressed strong opposition today to the Administration backed, onebank holding com pany bill.

title: Market Place:
description: EVERYBODY feels for the specialist. As the stock exchange member charged with making a market in a given stock, he must buy when nobody in his right mind would want to and he must sell when the shares are going like penny whistles.

title: Harrington Plans to Quit Governorship Race and Give Support to a Democrat
description: The Rev. Dr. Donald S. Har rington is planning to with draw as the Liberal party's can didate for Governor and urge the party to endorse a Demo crat.

title: Basketball Signings
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: 9 Women Demonstrators At Grove Press Acquitted
description: Nine members of the Wom en's Liberation Movement who staged a fivehour sitin on April 13 at the offices of Grove Press, at 214 Mercer Street, were acquitted yesterday of misdemeanor charges by Crim inal Court Judge Amos S. Basel.

title: Primary Gains and Losses
description: A defeat for George Wallace in his own state Alabama must be considered an event of some magni tude. Since his opponent in the Democratic primary, Gov. Albert P. Brewer, failed to get a majority in field of seven, Wallace still has all too good a chance to win nomination for the governorship in the runoff.

title: Dushock Gains Tennis Final
description: Mike Dushock of Monsignor Clancy High School defeated Don Goebel of New Forest, 62, 60, in the semifinal of the an nual Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis cham pionship at the West Side Club in Forest Hills yesterday. In the other semifinal Dave Landers of Fordham Prep beat Ed Staun ton of Stepinac of White Plains, 64. 63.

title: Article 3  No Title
National Stock Exchange
News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 7, 1970

title: Senator Young's Account
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Senator Stephen M. Young of Ohio said today that the first shot at Kent State was fired accidentally by a National Guardsman who was hit by tear gas canister thrown back by a student.

title: College Consortium Appoints Head
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 6 Educational Testing Serv ice announced today that Henry Chauncey would re sign June 30 as president to become president of EDU COM, a consortium of about 100 coleges and universities dedicated to advancing the use of computers and infor mation systems in higher ed ucation.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Volcano Erupts in Iceland
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 6 (Reuters)Icelands biggest vol cano, Hekla, rained rocks and ashes over a wide area today in its first eruption in 23 years. The 4,747foot volcano, 75 mlies southeast of here, burst into life last night.

title: Skillet in Car, the Cooking Buff Went Traveling
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS L. I. If you can really cook well, Mrs. Ralph Wilkinson said, you can cook under any and all circumstances.

title: TIMES COMPANY IS SUED IN SOUTH
description: CHATTANOOGA, May 6A $10.5million damage suit against The Times Printing company, publisher of the Chat tanooga Times, was filed in Federal District Court today by The Chattanooga NewsFree Press.

title: Chicago's Science Museum Set '69 Attendance Mark
description: CHICAGO (AP)  Chicago's Museum of Science and In dustry, frequently termed the Windy City's leading tourist attraction, set a new attend ance mark in 1969, with 3, 261,983 people viewing its exhibits.

title: Parents Will Meet in 2School Boycott
description: Parents who have kept more than 2,000 children away from classes for nine days at Public Schools 11 and 73 in the Bronx will meet tonight to decide whether to return their chil dren to school.

title: Pathet Lao Claims 198 Craft
description: HONG KONG, May 6 (Reu ters)The Chinese Communist press agency, Hsinitua reported today that the proCommunist Pathet Lao armed forces shot down or destroyed on the ground 198 United States air craft in the first four months of this year.

title: TROPICAL OPENS SUMMER RACING
description: MIAMI, May 6  South Flo rida introduced a virtual year round horse racing season to day when a Fort Lauderal in dustrialist, Steven Calder, open ed a 121day summer meeting at Tropical Park.

title: Dr. Anita Paine, Verne Vance Jr. Engaged to Wed
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., May 6Mrs. Hebard Miller Paine, formerly of New York, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Anita Paine, to Verne Widney Vance Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vance of Omaha.

title: Molotov, at Wife's Funeral, Is Joined by Bulganin, Another ExPremier
description: MOSCOW, May 6 (Reuters) Vyacheslav M. Molotov, a former Soviet Premier, made a rare public appearance here today for the funeral of his wife.

title: PACE WILL HONOR LATE PRESIDENT
description: Tomorrow night's $50,000 In ternational Pace at Yonkers Raceway has been renamed the Martin Tananbaum Pace in honor of the track's late presi dent.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: USV Is Leaving Bates For Klemtner Casey
description: It is understood that the USV Pharmaceutical Corpora tion is moving its passel of products from the medical advertising group of Ted Bates over to Klemtner Casey. It is further understood that the BatesUSV relationship is ending by mutual agreement.

title: Coalition JOBS Names Smiley
description: Donald B. Smiley, chairman of the board of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., had been named to the steering committee of Coa lition JOBS, it was announced yesterday by Walter N. Roths child Jr., chairman of the New York Urban Coalition. Mr. Smiley is an alumnus of Augus tana College and Northwestern University Law School.

title: Sports of The Times
description: AFTER the Columbia baseball team voted to cancel its game last Tuesday with Manhattan College, one the players tried to explain his feelings to Kevin DeMarrais, the Columbia sports information director. He had played baseball all his life, the player said, he loved and on this beautiful day there was nothing he would rather do than play: Thus, he felt, the sacrifice was a valid expression for him, it was his way of protesting the ex pansion of the Vietnam War. For the college athlete, protest is very often more costly than for the average student; he must weigh his moral commitments against the goals he may have been training toward for a se mester or a lifetime. At Stanford yesterday, a youth who lost two high school friends in Vietnam cut spring football practice, an act that had meaning only for himself and his chances of making the team. At Princeton, Herman Steven son, the track team cap tain, called for a boycott of Saturday's Heptagonal Games, and at Dartmouth, Steve Tourek, the crew captain, urged oarsmen to wear black headbands in Saturday's Eastern Sprint championships as a symbol of mourning for the Kent State dead. In a letter to rival crew captain. Tourek wrote: The question should not be to row or not to row but how to make meaningful our feelings. We can accom plish more by competing and by showing our commitment to what is happening in the world divorced from crew.

title: CASH OUTFLOW UP FOR 18 I.O.S. FUNDS
description: GENEVA, May 6  Flagging confidence has begun affect ing the operating results of Bernard Cornfeld's mutual fund empire, Investors Overseas Services.

title: Cerdan Is All Jake With La Motta
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 6When he saw the young man in an orange sweater approaching through the vast dining room of the Concord Hotel today, Jake La Motta stared at the brokennosed face with its brown eyes flashing under shaggy black hair.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. May, 6Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers today welcomed Secretary Genearl U Thant's ap peal for an international con ference on Indochina.

title: MOONSHOT PUT OFF AT LEAST TO DEC. 3
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The next American attempt to land men on the moon will aim for a site in the Fra Mauro high lands near the intended site of the Apollo 13 landing, and the launching will take place no earlier than Dec. 3.

title: Ortis Wins Italian Derby
description: ROME, May 7 (AP)Ortis, an Italianbred horse ridden by a British jockey, won the Italian Derby, Italy's richest race, to day. Ortis took the approxi mately 1mile test comforta bly, beating Alcamo, Jerome was third. Brian Taylor rode the winner. The race for 3year olds had a $160,000 gross in prize money.

title: Westinghouse Wins Contract
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday it had been awarded a contract for a 600,000kilowatt nuclear power plant at Aguirre on the south coast of Puerto Rico. The company would not disclose value of the contract, but nu clear plants of comparable size have cost about $100million.

title: Dayan Warns Lebanese Face Retaliation
description: JERUSALEM, May 7Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned today that Israel might makes retaliatory attacks across her northern frontiers. He spoke after a day in which enemy ac tion across the Lebanese bor der killed five Israelis and wounded eight.

title: Aluminum Claims New Inroads In Competition for Boat Dollar
description: Now, in a census of pleas ure boats built in the United States last year, the Aluminum As sociation has hap pily come up with this statistic: Over 60 per cent of the boats were aluminum.

title: Kent State in Flux but Still Attuned to MidAmerica
description: KENT, Ohio, May 7  A white bulletin board stands alone on the silent campus of Kent State University not far from the grassy slope where four students were killed and nine wounded Monday by a volley of shots from National Guardsmen.

title: Offenbach Scores With Note(s) of Hilarity
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 7 Last year the Romantic Festival at Clowes Hall gave a performance of Felicien David's symphonic ode, Le Desert. Last night the fes tival presented a hilarious parody of that work by Of fenbach, and it left at least one member of the audience completely limp.

title: Senate Democratic Chiefs Seek Early Vote on Cambodia Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The Senate Democratic lead ership moved today toward a confrontation with President Nixon by pressing for action next week on legislation that would cut off funds for future military activities in Cambodia.

title: JAMES DYER DIES; OIL EXECUTIVE, 75
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 7James E. Dyer, a leader in the petroleum industry for many years, died today in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 75 years old and lived at 33 Lyncroft Road.

title: Ohio Guard Was Authorized to Load
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  In his first public statement since the Kent State University inci dent, the commander of the Na tional Guard said today that Ohio guardsmen were author ized to load and lock their weapons when committed to action.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: S. ELIOT'S observation that April is the cruelest month has relevance for the East Coast fisherman.

title: Mauro Named Indiana Aide
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 7 (UPI)Harold Mauro, a center on Indiana's Rose Bowl and Big Ten cochampion football team of 1967, was appointed to the Indiana University staff today as an assistant freshman coach.

title: LongRange Optimism
description: Three oil company executives addressing annual meetings across the country yesterday were bullish over the industry's long range prospects but bear ish about the nearterm.

title: OFFER FOR I.O.S. REPORTED RAISED
description: GENEVA, May 7John M. King, the Denver businessman who wants control of Bernard Cornfeld's mutual fund com plex, Investors Overseas Serv ices, was reported to have sweetened his offer today to try to ward off a competing bid from a European banking con sortium led by the Rothschilds.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon yesterday summoned all 50 state Governors to meet with him Mon day on the growing protests against his Asia policies. Mr. Nixon promised eight vis iting college presidents that he would re strain all hostile comments about students from Administration figures. It was re ported, meanwhile, that two Administration officials were resigning in protest over the President's actions. [Page 1, Columns 58.]

title: Mrs. de Montmollin Is Wed to Robert M. McKinney
description: Mrs. MarieLouise de Mont mollin, widow of Henry de Montmollin, who was in the Swiss diplomatic service and was an officer of the Ciba Pharmaceutical Com pany, was married yesterday to Robert M. McKinney, pub lisher of The Santa Fe New Mexican and former Ambas sador to Switzerland.

title: Combined Insurance Co.
description: The Combined Insurance Company of America yesterday reported a first quarter profit of $4.97million, or 28 cents a share, up from the yearearlier, $4.46million, or 26 cents a share. Total income rose to $54.07million from $46.43mil lion. W. Clement Store, chief executive officer, said he had recommended a stock dividend of at least 20 per cent in the third quarter. Cash dividends last year totaled 55 cents a share, including a 15cent extra.

title: Major Brokerage Houses Tighten Belt Some More
description: A new series of operational cutbacks is taking shape on Wall Street in response to con tinuing adverse conditions in the securities markets.

title: Amax Chief Critical
description: Ian MacGregor, chairman and chief executive officer of Amer ican Metal Climax, Inc., charged here yesterday that the Justice Department and a White House committee were displaying con flicting and confusing attitudes on the development of new cop per resources.

title: Nixon's News Parley To Be Aired at 10 P.M.
description: President Nixon's news conference is scheduled for 10 o'clock tonight. It will be carried live from Washing ton on television and radio.

title: City Seeks to Shut 5 Jersey Plants for Pollution
description: The city's department of Air Resources yesterday called for the shutting down of five in dustrial plants in Linden, N.J., because it said concentrations of sulphur dioxide gas in the air over western Staten Island had reached dangerous levels during the last two days.

title: Work on 63d Street Tunnel Sets Off a Cacophony on East River
description: The East River at 63d street area reverberated yes terday with the staccato sound of air compressors, punctuated by the splash of a huge steel clamshell bucket dredging the sand compacted river bottom.

title: RELIEF MOTHERS TEST STATE LAW
description: Nine mothers who are wel fare recipients brought suit in Federal Court yesterday on be half of their 44 children, chal lenging the constitutionality of the state's Social Services Law in denying extra funds for schoolrelated expenses.

title: Captain on the Burning Bridge
description: LIKE the cavalry thunder ing over the hilltop at the moment the beleaguered frontier fort is about to fall, or like Superman exploding from a telephone booth when Lois Lane is face to face with villainy of the worst order, Willis Reed (in the fantasies of thousands of fans of the New York Knick erbockers) will bound onto the court of Madison Square Garden to night and save his team from worse than death.

title: Article 2  No Title
General Host Man Elected at Armour; Greyhound Objects
description: Harris J. Ashton, president of the General Host Corporation, was elected chairman of Ar mour & Co. yesterdayan ac tion that immediately came un der attack from the Greyhound Corporation.

title: VE Day + 25: The Hostilities Are at Rest
description: PARIS, May 7The coun try northeast of Paris is placid, smug and monotonous these days. Wide roads run through prosperous villages and past smoking industrial plants alive with activity. Gasoline stations are bright with paint and pennants dot the highways.

title: Sibley Glitters in the Royal Ballet's Sleeping Beauty
description: WATCHING Antoinette Sib ley dance Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty at the Met ropolitan Opera House last weekend, it suddenly occur red to me that this young Royal Ballet ballerina is ap proximately the same age (a year or so older, in fact) that Margot Fonteyn was when she made her New York debut in 1949.

title: Sports of The Times
description: IT was unreal, said an awestruck Walt Frazier after the Knicks had made their miraculous comeback on Monday to beat the Lakers in the fifth game of their championship playoff series. What had made it such a fantasy was the fact that it had been achieved without the help of the injured Willis Reed, their cap tain and key performer.

title: War Referendum Voted
description: BOSTON, May 7 (UPI)The Massachusetts Senate has passed a resolution calling for a state referendum on United States intervention in Cam bodia. The resolution, intro duced by the Senate President, Maurice A. Donohue, Democrat of Holyoke, was adopted on a voice vote yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: EXPERT players are com firmed spotwatchers. They know that if they watch the small cards they will improve their prospects of finding winning lines of play.

title: Ban on thermal Pollution Is Set for Lake Michigan
description: CHICAGO, May 7The Federal Water Quality Admin istration startled the pollution control officials of four Lake Michigan states today by announcing a thermal pollution policy that would forbid the dumping of virtually any heated water into the lake.

title: Irish Leader Backed After Dismissal of 2 Aides
description: DUBLIN, May 7Prime Min ister John Lynch emerged in strong control of his party and the Irish Government today after dismissing two Cabinet ministers implicated in a gun running scandal. Rumors and uncertainties persisted, how ever.

title: Greece Refuses a Passport To Seferis, Nobel Laureate
description: ATHENS, May 7  george Seferis, the Greek poet who won the Nobel Prize for Litera ture in 1963, has been refused passport by the militarybacked regime.

title: Reston Appointed to Board Of American Press Institute
description: The appointment of James Reston, a vice president of The New York Times, to the advis ory board of the American Press Institute at Columbia University, was announced yes terday by Dr. Andrew W. Cor dier, president of the univer sity.

title: SILVER FUTURES SHOW AN ADVANCE
description: After dropping on Wednes day, silver futures prices bounded back yesterday and advanced 2.5 to 2.6 cents an ounce on the New York Com modity Exchange.

title: Factory Workers Differ on Protests
description: MAHWAH, N.J., May 7 It's just too had, but it had to happen sometime. They should have kept the protest peaceful.

title: Foreign Affairs:
description: MADRIDVE Day officially ended World War II in Europe on May 8, 1945more than twentyfour hours after the formal German surrender. The delay convenienced Moscow's sense of protocol in wanting to formalize Soviet participation in the armistice ritual, a demand wellwarranted by the Russians' incalculable suffering.

title: Eisenhower's Papers Detail Concern Over a Premature VE Day
description: While German armies were collapsing along all fronts in April, 1945, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Supreme Commander in Europe, em phatically warned against the announcement of VE Day before certain conditions were met, including steps that would prevent German forces from fighting the Red Army after an armistice.

title: Brooklyn G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that Pvt. Milton PerezRivera of Brooklyn, of the Army, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: WHITE WALLOPS TWO3RUN HOMERS
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 7 Roy White, the promising young executive of the Colum bia Broadcasting System, dis played a proper impartiality toward the left and right wings tonight. He hit a threerun homer off each of them.

title: Lemon Sky to Open May 17
description: Lemon Sky, a new play by Lanford Wilson, will open. May 17 at the new Playhouse Theater, 357 West 48th Street. Haila Stoddard, Mark Wright and Duane Wilder in associa tion with Neal DuBrock are the producers. Christopher Walken heads the cast that in cludes Charles Durning, Bon nie Bartlett, Kathryn Baumann and Lee McCain. The play has been staged by Warren Enters.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALL right, what happens to you if you chance to feel that the Parrot's Beak and the Fishhook aren't worth dying for? If you can't quite bring into reasonable approximation the rhetoric of Mr. Nixon and the reality of Southeast Asia? If you choose three to five years in prison instead of killing Vietnamese? As Dr. Willard Gaylin says, This was a politically volatile subject, war re sistance; in a soci ologically vulner able area, the prisons; conduct ed by a question ably respectable researcher, a psy choanalyst. Wrong. At least on the last count: Kenneth Keniston, Robert Coles, Rob ert Jay Lifton and, of course, Erik Erikson stack up as a library that for respectability, intelligence and pertinencemazes most recent sociology look like comic books written by computers. Dr. Gaylin belongs on their shelf. At some length, over a con siderable period of time, he interviewed young men who refused induction into our armed services; who chose instead to go to jail. In the process, he learned a great deal not only about prisons and the draft, but also about himself. A significant countertransference occurred, leading him to ask crucial questions about psycho analytic theory and therapeutic practice, as well as the war.

title: Tricia Nixon Confers With Two Protesters
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)Tricia Nixon met for an hour today with two Finch College war protesters.

title: Harvard Weighing PostPusey Years
description: Harvard University has be gun wide consultations in pre paring to select a successor to its president, Nathan M. Pusey, who has announced he will re sign as of June, 1971.

title: Ample Supply Through '73 Seen by Brooklyn Union Gas
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Com pany believes it is in a better position than the rest of the natural gas industry to meet demands for service, John E. Heyke Jr., chairman, told some 200 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at the com pany's headquarters, 195 Mon tague Street.

title: Israel and the Russians
description: JERUSALEM, May 7  After having carefully analyzed the presence of Soviet pilots in the United Arab Republic, Israel is expected to takes steps that will admittedly test the re straint of the Russians.

title: CHUBB ACQUISITION OF BELLEMEAD IS SET
description: The Chubb Corporation, an insurance holding company, yes terday announced it has agreed in principle to acquire the Belle mead Development Corporation for stock worth about $17,576, 000.

title: LETHAL NERVE GAS IN VIETNAM CHARGED
description: BOSTON, May 7A former Army officer said today that he had seen lethal nerve gas stored at a United States air base in Bienhoa. South Viet nam, while on duty there in 1967 and 1968.

title: Nixon Plan to Shuffle Executive Rejected by a House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The House Committee on Gov ernment Operations dealt blow today to President Nix on's plans for increasing effi ciency in the Executive office by rejecting Mr. Nixon' s pro posal to create a domestic council and an office of man agement and budget.

title: ROBERT J. SCHNEIDER
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., May (AP)Robert J. Schneider, vice president and business manager of Wellesley College, died in his sleep last night at his home. He was 64 years old.

title: Hirshhorn Transfers Funds to Help Gallery
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)Joseph H. Hirshhorn, the uranium magnate who gave his $50million art col lection to the United States government, has, in effect, donated an extra $1million to make possible prompt constructiion of a gallery to house it.

title: Bronx Man Held on Charge Of Possessing Heroin Cache
description: A 48yearold laborer was held in $250,000 hail in Bronx Supreme Court when he was arraigned on a onecount in dictment charging him with pos session of almost 21 pounds of heroin.

title: Dr. Gerald D. McDonald, Chief Of Library Division Here, Dead
description: Dr. Gerald D. McDonald, Chief of Special Collections for the New York Public Library, died Wednesday in Paris, where he was on a buying trip for the library. He was 64 years old and lived at 36 West 19th Street.

title: Manufacturers' Tax On All Solid Waste Urged by Proxmire
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Sen ator William Proxmire proposed a special Federal levy today on almost all manufactured items that wind up as solid waste.

title: Seamen Held Not Gourmets
description: LONDON (AP)In debate on a measure to let British mer chant seamen file complaints about their sea cooks and the chow they offer, the House of Commons was told by R. Bon ner Pink, a Conservative Mem ber, that sailors were not gen erally gourmets.

title: Britain Lends $14.4Million To Save Major Shipbuilder
description: LONDON, May 7 (AP)The Government agreed today to lend $14.4million to one of Britain's major shipbuilding concerns to save it from total collapse.

title: Roundup: Colbert's Clouts Help Padres Rout Phils
description: Nate Colbert is the San Diego Padres' most danger ous homerun hitter, but he frequently provides verbal punch, too.

title: PATRICK V. VERNAGLIO
description: Patrick V. Vernaglio, a mid dleweight fighter and trainer in the nineteenthirties, died Monday in French Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 523 Ninth Avenue.

title: National Stock Exchange
MORRIS MILLER, 61, WASHINGTON JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Morris Miller, chief judge of the District of Columbia Juvenile Court, died here today. He was 61 years old. He was appoint ed to the court in 1962 by Pres ident Kennedy, filling one of two judgeships authorized by Congress that year.

title: Bank of America Acts
description: The Bank of America an nounced yesterday that it was reducing the points it charges on F.H.A.insured and V.A. guaranteed mortgages to 2 from 4, effective immediately.

title: POPE WARNS ON WAR; CANCELS ASIAN TRIP
description: ROME, May 7Pope Paul VI lamented today that these were days filled with sad events and sadder portents, and warned against further escalation of in ternational conflicts.

title: SALES OF NEW ISSUES SET HIGH IN QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, May 7A record $7.9billion of new stock and bond issues were sold by United States corporations in the first quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

title: RUMANIA LEADING IRAN IN DAVIS CUP
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 7 (AP) Ilia Nastase of Rumania was extended to five sets in defeat ing Taghi Akbari of Iran today is the first round of the Euro pean Zone Davis Cup tennis competition. The scores were 108, 60, 68, 57. 63.

title: In Border Town, CambodianVietnamese Hatred
description: SVAYRIENG, Cambodia, May 5  No one here bothers to flick away the cockroaches that, in the thick heat of May, move across sidewalks, walls and ceilings.

title: Dr. Herman B. Zurrow, 62, Bronx Hospital Director
description: Dr. Herman B. Zurrow, an internist, medical director of the Hebrew Hospital for the Chronic Sick in the Bronx, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 679 West 239th Street.

title: Washington:
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 One of the most surprising things about the violent oppo sition in the Congress and the universities to the invasion of Cambodia IS that President Nixon was genuinely surprised by it.

title: Banks and Oil Companies Nationalized by Somalia
description: MOGADISCIO, Somalia, May 7 (Reuters)  The Government of Somalia today nationalized all foreign banks and oil com panies but said that compensa tion would be paid.

title: Garvey's Papers Found in Harlem
description: More than 10,000 docu ments that belonged to the late Marcus Garvey, founder of modern African national ism, have been found in an abandoned building in Harlem.

title: NORTH VIETNAMESE RETAKE LAOS POST
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 7 (Agency FrancePresse)North Vietnamese troops in a counter attack today recaptured the key government artillery post at Phou Saphong, a strategic posi tion in southern Laos only three miles from an airfield used by American planes, diplo matic sources said.

title: Marcher Felt She Had to Do Something
description: Miss Shirley Fadim stood in the street outside the River side Memorial chapel yester day morning. Her dark glasses could not hide the tears that wetted her face.

title: Dining Out Japanese Style
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vicin ity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

title: Irish Look Eagerly to Common Market
description: DUBLIN, May 6  Ireland is looking to membership in the European Common Market as a means of lessening its eco nomic dependence upon Britain.

title: Dushock School Net Victor
description: Mike Dushock of Monsignor McClancy High School won the final of the Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis cham pionship yesterday, beating David Landers of Fordham Prep, 62, 60. The doubles title went to Jim Dolphin and Andy Ellis of McBurney, who defeat ed Bob Broderick and Charlie Schelz of Stepinac, 62, 75.

title: Inmates' Mother's Day Gifts
description: On Mother's Day, Sunday. 200 young men inmates of the New York City Reformatory on Rik ers Island will present Rotted plants to their visiting mothers, George F. McGrath, Commis sioner of Correction, announced sinner of Correction, announced yesterday. The plants were gown in the reformatory's greenhouse as a Mother's Day ??

title: Ann Haven Cummings Affianced
description: Miss Ann Haven Cum mings, an account executive with Batten, Barton, Durstirre & Osborn, Inc., plans to be married in August to Clifton Iverson Jr., who is on leave from the Chemical Bank while studying for a master's degree at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsyl vania.

title: City Submits 3 Slum Programs to U.S.
