description: Budgets for three Model Cit ies projects in slum areas were approved by the Board of Esti mate yesterday and forwarded to the Federal Government, which pays the costs.

title: Refusal to Assist Policeman Costs Restaurant Man $50
description: XENTA, Ohio (AP)  Robert M. Phelps, 44 years old, was fined $50 and court costs for refusing to help the police make an arrest.

title: Businessmen Urged to Participate
description: Abraham S. Venable, director of the Office of Minority Busi ness Enterprise of the Com merce Department, urged an au dience of businessmen here yes terday to consider participation in Minority Enterprise Small Business Investment Companies (MESBIC) not for profit moti vation but as an opportunity to assist the economic develop ment of minority groups.

title: Note to Readers
description: The weekly table of Fed eral Reserve statistics on the condition of major commer cial banks in New York and Chicago, the Treasury state ment and some of the Mid west and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations are omitted from this issue be cause of composing room de lays caused by union meet ings.

title: Triborough Approves Funds for City's Transit
description: The last obstacle to the use of Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority surpluses to offset operating deficits of the city's subways and buses has been removed.

title: Vote at Rockefeller U. Asks Pressure on General Motors
description: Faculty members, students and employes of Rockefeller University voted overwhelm ingly yesterday to urge the trustees to vote the univer sity's 65,000 shares of General Motors stock for the cam paign to make General Motors responsible.

title: BOND NOTE ISSUE IS BARELY SOLD
STOCKS IN LONDON DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Prices fell sharply on the London stock market yesterday in a reaction to Wall Street's failure to sustain an opening rally on Wednesday. Trading was dull.

title: Photographers Win Awards For Pictures of the Year
description: COLUMBIA, May 7 (AP) Presentation of the 27th an nual pictures of the year awards sponsored by the School of Journalism at the University of Missouri, the World Book Science Service and the National Press Photo graphers Association, marked Journalism Week's session today.

title: Role of Mafioso in Bank Is Denied in Alioto Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 The State Banking Superintend ent who chartered the First San Francisco Bank in 1964 testified today that the bank's orga nizers had been investigated thoroughly and had not in cluded a group of Mafiaasso ciated hoodlums.

title: UNEMPLOYED RATE CLIMBED IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The nation's unemployment rate rose substantially in April to 4.8 per cent of the labor force, it became known tonight.

title: Coalition JOBS Names Smiley
description: Donald B. Smiley, chairman of the board of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., has been named to the steering committee of Coa lition JOBS, it was announced Wednesday by Walter N. Roths child Jr., chairman of the New York Urban Coalition. Mr. Smiley is an alumnus of Augus tana College and Northwestern University Law School.

title: Turnabout in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The confidence of just a week ago euphoria, some called itis suddenly gone from this capi tal, and in its place there is fear and the anxious activity inspired by fear. There is fear of violence this weekend as tens of thousands of antiwar demonstrators prepare to parade just as close to the White House as nervous offi cialdom will allow. There is fear that the psychological value of that determined show of strength on the Cambodian battlefield is being dispelled by the turmoil on the home front. There is fear of further dissen sion inside the Government What if Vice President Agnew fails to take the hints to taper down the assaults on young people? And there is fear of the political consequences for the Nixon Administration, the Republican party and the na tion as a whole.

title: Balky Gambler Held In City Graft Inquiry
description: A man described by the po lice as one of the city's top professional gamblers was ar rested yesterday and accused of criminal contempt of a grand jury investigating police corruption charges.

title: Geraldine Bond, Vassar Alumna, Engaged to Wed
description: MARTINSVILLE, N. J., May 7Miss Geraldine Ann Bond, a granddaughter of Charles G. Bond, chairman of the New York City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board and a former United States Rep resentative from Brooklyn, will be married here June 28 to Lawrence Christopher Nes bit Laybourne.

title: Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Retail Store Chains List Slight Gains In Sales for April
description: Seven of the country's larg est retail chains, including Sears, Roebuck & Co., whose volume is by far the largest, reported yesterday only mod 1 crate sales gains in April, de spite a marked pickup in the month's final days.

title: City Urged to Put Narcotics Counselors in Schools
description: To combat what he called a severalhundredfold increase in the number of students who are taking drugs. The acting Superintendent of Schools asked yesterday for City Coun cil help in placing coordinators to combat narcotics in the schools.

title: Blacks Liken Kent Slaying to Own Oppression
description: Balancing a worn cloth shop ping bag on her lap, a middle aged black woman who works as a domestic rode the No. 10 bus north to Harlem late yes terday and told a stranger.

title: Swedish Girl Jockey Finishes 6th in Aqueduct Debut
description: Another female jockey, Irene Osterlund, made her de but at Aqueduct yesterday, and the young lady had something extra going for her. She had what amounted to an escort in the person of Johnny Ruane.

title: Amex Asks Report By Four Seasons
description: Jack L. Clark, president of Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., said yesterday that the American Stock Ex change and the Securities and Exchange Commission had questioned the company about some aspects of its financing, including a $4million loan in March from the state of Ohio.

title: Dodgers Beat Mets, 74, With 3 Runs in 10th
description: The New York Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers did some strange things for 3 hours last night in chilly Shea Sta dium before the Dodgers scored three times in the 10th inning and won the game, 74.

title: Youth's Faith . . .
description: The loss of faith by countless thousands of young Americans in their Government will not be easily remedied. More is required than President Nixon's promise yesterday that he and his associates will henceforth refrain from hostile comments on campus Personalities and events. Students deeply concerned about issues of war and human dignity are not likely to be satisfied by reluctant silence or benign neglect.

title: Irving Golub, ExDirector Of Labor Department Office
description: Irving Golub, former area di rector of the Manhattan Up town Office of the Labor Department's Wage and Hour Division, died of cancer yester day at New York Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 230 Hendrickson Avenue, Lyn brook. L. I.

title: Dance Wednesday to Assist SloanKettering Society
description: The Plaza's Grand Ball room will become a garden of potted palms for Wednes day's 24th annual dinner dance of the Society of Memorial SloanKttering, an auxiliary of the Memorial SloanKetter ing Cancer Center.

title: PRONIXON DRIVE BY PHONES SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 Evidence mounted today of a drive by Republicans urging telephone calls to the White House to express support for President Nixon's decision to expand the war into Cambodia.

title: 4 Massapequa Schools Shut By Union Teachers' Strike
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., May 7 Seventyfive hundred of the 16,600 students in the Massa pequa school district were sent home today after a strike this morning by the Massapequa Federation of Teachers.

title: Blue Leaves Signs Cast
description: The John Guare comedy, The House of Blue Leaves, will be presented by Warren Lyons and Betty Ann Besch in September at an Off Broadway house to be announced later, Harold Gould has been signed to play one of the leading roles and Mel Shapiro to direct.

title: PROFITS ADVANCE AT QUAKER OATS
description: The Quaker Oats Company reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the nine months ended March 31, with indicated thirdquarter results slightly ahead of the compar able period last year.

title: CONGRESS IS WARNED OF FEMINIST STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) Betty Friedan warned Con gress today that it must vote to give females legal equality with men or suffer the consequences of a womn's general strike this summer.

title: The Joneses Have It
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash. (AP) Winner of the Miss Walla Walla 1970 title at the Jay cees' pageant was Meredith Jones. The first runnerup was Shelly Jones. Miss Walla Walla 1969 was Shelley Smith.

title: Art Group Is Set Up To Judge Attribution
description: How many art experts would tell a collector his Caravaggio was a fake? Help the government fight a tax case involving an overvalued painting? Come forward with information about mislabeled works in a cityowned mu seum?

title: SAIGON FLOTILLA POISED TO BEGIN DRIVE IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 7Official sources said today that a flotilla of South Vietnamese gunboats, many of them with American advisers aboard, is scheduled to begin an assault tomorrow up the Mekong River to the Cambo dian capital of Pnompenh.

title: MRS. JESUS COLON
description: Mrs. Clara Colon, a member of the National Committee of the Communist party, died of cancer yesterday at Adelphi Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 63 years old and lived with her husband, Jesus, at 850 St. Marks Place, Brooklyn.

title: House Subcommittee Votes Measure to Buoy Housing
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) Legislation to pump billions of dollars into housing by means including compulsory in vestment by private founda tions and pension funds was approved today by the House Subcommittee on Housing.

title: SIIIANOUK SAYS CHINA IS HIS NO. 1 FRIEND
description: HONG KONG, May 7 (Reu ters)  In a letter to Premier Chou Enlai and quoted by the Peking radio, Prince Noro dan Sihanouk said China was Cambodia's No. 1 friend be cause it was the first to recog nize his government in exile formed in Peking Tuesday.

title: Panther Lawyer Says Dynamite Was Gift From Ally of F.B.I.
description: An agent or informer for the Federal Dureau of Investiga tion made an unsolicited gift of dynamite to an alleged co conspirator of the 13 Black Panthers who are accused of conspiring to bomb public places here, a defense lawyer declared yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Kent's Townspeople Back Guardsmen
description: KENT, Ohio, May 7  It's a shame it had to take killing to do it, but all those kids were someplace they shouldn't have been, said Dick Rich ards, a florist lunching at the weekly meeting of the Lions Club at the Brown Derby just outside town.

title: Dan Wagoner Dances Westwork
description: One of the most provoca tively interesting aspects of Dan Wagoner's pieces is the way the dance energy splash es off quiet but concurrent nondance activities. He is in terested in two aspects of time: that of the stressed per former and that of the unac cented civilian. On Wednes day evening at Judson Church he presented the New York premiere of Westwork, which sparklingly contrasted the two.

title: Good Chase EvenMoney Choice in $50,000 Yonkers Pace Tonight
description: YONKERS, May 7  None of drivers or trainers of the seven standardbreds that will oppose Good Chase of New Zealand in tomorrow night's Martin Tan anbaum International Pace was bold enough today to predict an upset in the $50,000, 1 mile invitation event at Yonk ers Raceway.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ARABIAN PIPELINE CLOSED FOR 5TH DAY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 7 Tapline, the Americanowned oil pipeline from Saudi Arabia to the Mediterranean, was closed for the fifth successive day today because the Syrian Government has refused to allow a break to be repaired. The pipeline was reported to have been damaged when a bulldozer hit it accidentally on Sunday in the Dera region, near the SyrianJordanian border.

title: JOANN KELLY SINGS BLUES AT GASLIGHT
description: JoAnn Kelly may be a girl folk singer, but Joni Mitchell she is not.

title: Reed Is Given 5050 Chance of Playing for Knicks Tonight Against Lakers
description: One more game, with the key factor unknowable in advance that's what the National Bas ketball Association champion ship has come down to, after 100 games played by the New York Knickerbockers and 99 by the Los Angeles Lakers, the last six against each other in the fourofseven final round.

title: PROFESSORS SPUR POLITICAL ACTION
description: A nationwide effort to get student and faculty delegations to go to Washington to lobby in Congress against the war in Southeast Asia has been started at Columbia and Yale.

title: Miss Deshler To Be a Bride
description: POTTERSVILLE, N. J., May 7Miss Elaine Deshler, who expects to be graduated this month from Sweet Briar College, plans to be married in September to William Martin Woodson 3d, who served as an Air Force ser geant in Vietnam.

title: LINDSAY PRESSES FOR BALLET PACT
description: Members of the New York City Ballet orchestra voted last night to accept factfinding in their 18dayold strike, as pro posed earlier in the day by Mayor Lindsay, but they reject ed his plea that thgy return to work during the factfinding period.

title: Note to Readers
description: The box scores of all base ball games between nonlocal teams are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Earnings Register a Loss At Cowles Communications
description: The company report of Cowles Communications, Inc., for the first quarter disclosed yester day a net loss of $445,000 after a tax credit of $1,103,000 and an extraordinary credit of $709, 000, from sale in January of stock of the Television Com munications Corporation. In the initial three months of 1969 the company had a net income of $32,000, or 1 cent a share, after a tax credit of $336,000 and an extraordinary credit of $384, 000, or 10 cents a share, Rev enues were $35,515.000 com pared with $39,677,000.

title: Hickel's Advisers Tell Why He Acted
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 Why Wally Hickel?

title: PERSONNEL CHIEF OF CITY TO RETIRE
description: Solomon Hoberman, the city's Personnel Director and chair man of the Civil Service Corn mission, will retire on July 3 after 30 years in government.

title: Store Sates Increase
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $708million, up 5 per rent from the year earlier $673million.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS ASK LIBERAL SUPPORT
description: The three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor again solicited the endorsement of the Liberal party yesterday as the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington withdrew as the Liberal candidate for Governor.

title: Blood Foundation To Gain at Dance
description: The Friends of the Chil dren's Blood Foundation plan a champagne supper dance at the Pierre on. Wednesday after their benefit at the Royal Ballet that night. The group has taken 500 orches tra seats at the Metropolitan Opera House for the pre miere here of The Ropes of Time with Rudolf Nureyev and the presentation of La Bayadere and Birthday Of fering.

title: Executive Changes
description: Philip O. Geier Jr. has been elected chairman of the board of Cincinnati Milacron, Inc., succeeding Swan E. Berstrom, who recently retired. Mr. Geier had been president since 1963.

title: BRITAIN BACKS THANT ON INDOCHINA TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 7Britain gave strong support here today to Secre tary General Thant's call for conference to end the war in Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam.

title: Program for Rehabilitation Of Criminals in U.S. Begun
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger and Bernard G. Segal, presi dent of the American Bar Asso ciation, opened a nationwide program today to promote the rehabilitation of criminals.

title: I Ballet Fragments Sent To F.B.I. for Testing
description: KENT, Ohio, May 7The bullet fragments taken from the bodies of four students killed here Monday have been turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the sheriff's department said to day.

title: Fashions That Take the Focus Off the Hemline
description: YOU couldn't blame Oscar de la Rents if he had acted a bit smug yesterday. A prophet is entitled to a bit of complacency, and Oscar's been preaching long skirts for years. Everybody on Seventh Avenue has caught up with that story in the last two weeks, so his long hems didn't cause the buzzing.

title: Senate Unit Hears U.S. Bombed Civilians in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) A former employe of the Agency for International De velopment said today that Unit ed States pilots flying over Laos had carried out what can in many instances only be char acterized as indiscriminate bombing of civilian population centers.

title: Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, ExVassar President, 89, Dies
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 7  Dr. Henry Noble Mac Crabken, president of Vassar College from 1915 to 1946, died today, after a long illness, in his home at 87 New Hackensack Road here. He was 89 years old.

title: Truman, 86 Today, Says He's As Good as Ever
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 7 (UPI)Harry S. Truman said with a tip of his dark grey fedora on the eve of his 86th birthday, I'm feeling as good as ever.

title: Industrial Nations Seek Accord on Loans to the Poor Lands
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The United States and other indus trial countries are moving to ward agreement on a new round of easy loan contri butions of $800million to $1 billion a year to the World Bank.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
10 SCHOOL BUDGETS REJECTED IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 7 Nassau County residents reject ed 10 out of30 proposed school district budgets yesterday, all of which called for higher tax rates. The voters also elected school boards.

title: College Strife Spreads
description: Strikes, demonstrations and occasional violence continued yesterday in the collegiate pro test against the war in Indo china and the fatal shooting of four Kent State University students.

title: Washington: For the Record
U.S. Industries Officer Is Named to Presidency
description: The election of Charles E. Selecman as president of United States Industries, Inc., was announced yester day by I. John Billera, chair man and chief executive of ficer.

title: ALEKSEI V. SHUBNIKOV
description: Aleksei V. Shubnikov, a lead ing Soviet crystallographer, died last week in Moscow at the age of 83, according to press reports received here.

title: Rockets Kill 7 in Danang
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Friday, May 8 (AP)Several rockets smashed into Danang early today, killing seven Viet namese and wounding 18. Most of the casualties occurred when three rockets struck a housing area near the center of the city.

title: Columbia Split on Strike As Buildings Are Blocked
description: The Columbia University campus was filled yesterday with hundreds of students blocking doorways and chant ing, On strike! Shut it down! but there were hundreds of others, both teachers and stu dents, who held classes any way.

title: Demonstration Leaders Accent Site on H Street
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Gov ernment officials privately as sured today the organizers of the antiwar demonstration scheduled here for Saturday that a rally on H Street, sepa rated from the White House by Lafayette Park, would be allowed to go on as long as it remained peaceful.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: The American Stock Ex change made its second con secutive advance yesterday as prices rose in very quiet trading.

title: Mayo Hints Tax Rise If Budget Shows a Gap
description: One of the Administration's chief fiscal officers hinted broadly yesterday that the Fed eral budget would slip into defi cit in the fiscal year beginning July 1, and that higher taxes could well be required to re store it to balance.

title: Y.W.C.A. Board Elects 3
description: The nuational heard of the Young Women's Christian As sociation announced yesterday the election of three new trus tees: Clarence B. Jones, direc tor and vice president of Cogan, Berlind, Weill & Levitt, invest ment bankers and brokers; Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Fed eral judge for the Southern District of New York, and Miss Cornelia Gross of Hartford, a former member of the board. Laurance S. Rockefeller was re elected president of the board.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Strike Ends
description: Employes of the American Society for the Preventation of Cruelty to Animals voted last night to end their strike in the metropolitan area. A spokes man said the union and the A.S.P.C.A agreed to a consent election hearing before the State Labor Relations Board on Monday.

title: Rep. Roudebush of Indiana Seeks Senator Hartke's Seat
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind. May 7 (AP)United States Represent ative Richard L. Roudebush an pounced today that he would run for the Republican nomi nation for the United States Senate in the Indiana G.O.P.'s state convention June 18.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Your editorial on Congress and the War (May 5) goes right to the heart of the crisis facing the American Govern ment.

title: Rep. Reuss Assails Superjet as Peril To the Environment
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)  Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the supersonic transport would be an environ mental outrage.

title: Reserve Open Market Purchases Came to Aid of Treasury Notes
description: The Federal Reserve System was forced to make mas sive purchases of securities in the open market to prevent the Treasury's $3.5billion sale of notes on Tuesday from failing, banking data published yesterday showed.

title: Spock Delivers Eulogy
description: The president of the Board of Education announced yester day that the city's 900 public schools would be closed today as a memorial to the four students who were tragically killed at Kent State University.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
F. C. C. PUTS LIMIT ON NETWORKS' TV
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Federal Communications Com mission, concerned about in creasing domination of local television by the networks, ruled today that stations in the 50 top markets must fill at least one of their four nightly prime time hours with independently produced material.

title: Harassed Surfer Quits U.S. Team in Australia
description: LORNE, Australia, May 7 (Reuters)  David Nuuihwa, the top American surfer, withdrew today from the world surfing championships, saying he was sick of being treated like a secondrate person.

title: MOSABURO SUZUKI, SOCIALIST LEADER
description: TOKYO, May 7 (AP)Mosa buro Suzuki, former chairman of Japan's Socialist party and one of the country's most out standing labor movement lead ers, died of a liver ailment here today. He was 77 years old.

title: Note to Readers
description: Reviews of last night's dance and music perform ances are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings. They will appear in tomorrow's editions.

title: Advertising:
description: Next week from Bangor, Me., to Wheeling, W. Va., TV viewers, radio listeners and newspaper readers will be getting the story of the Story of Life.

title: Bomb in Club in Little Italy Slightly Damages Building
description: An eightinch pipe bomb ex ploded early yesterday in a storefront social club in Man hattan's Little Italy.

title: U.S. WAR DEATHS AT 123 FOR WEEK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 7 (Reuters)  American casualties in Southeast Asia last week included 123 killed in action, 29 more than the previous week, a military spokesman reported today.

title: Saigon Feels War's Strain and Chaos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 7Every school in this city is shut. It is yet another sign, after weeks of disturbances, of the chaos that touches the lives of South Vietnamese of all ages.

title: BRUINS TOP BLUES FOR 30 LEAD, 41
description: BOSTON, May 7 (AP)The Boston Bruins, moving toward their first Stanley Cup in 29 years, got two goals from Wayne Cashman tonight and notched their third straight vic tory over the St. Louis Blues, 41, in the bestofseven game National Hockey League series.

title: Royals Sign 7Footer
description: CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Association signed Charles Bishop of Lou isiana Tech today. Bishop is a 7foot1inch 250pounder.

title: TRACKMEN STUDY FORM OF PROTEST
description: Track and field captains from the 10 Heptagonal colleges have been asked to ttend a meeting at Yale University tonight to consider the adoption of un fied symbols of protest at the outdoor championships tomor row in New Haven.

title: Christian Scientist Editor
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)The Christian Science Church Board of Directors announced Wed nesday the election of Carl J. Welz of San Francisco as edi tor of The Christian Science Journal, The Christian Science Sentinel and The Herald of Christian Science. Mr. Welz succeeds Mrs. Helen W. Bau man.

title: EDWARD E. HOENIG
description: Edward E. Hoenig, a lawyer here 60 years, died Wednesday at his home, 965 Fifth Avenue. He was 8.1 years old. His of fice was at 36 West 44th Street.

title: Brezhnev Predicts Failure O U.S. Drive Into Cambodia
description: PRAGUE, May 7 (AP)The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, predicted today that the United States would achieve no more success with its Cambodian campaign than it has in Vietnam.

title: Humphrey Assures Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, May 7 (Reuters) Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he would do all in his power to see that Israel received ad ditional war planes. He told reporters that he would raise the matter with United States leaders when he returned to Washington.

title: Bulls Name Webb, First Negro To Coach a Pro Football Team
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 7 Pro football named its first black head coach today. Allan Webb, the 37yearold former New York Giants' back, was eleyated to the post by the Long Island Bulls of the Atlantic Coast Foot ball League. Webb has been the defensive coach of the Bulls since they became a Giants affiliate three years ago.

title: HANOI REPORTS GAINS BY CAMBODIA REBELS
description: HONG KONG, Friday May 8 (Reuters)The North Vietnam ese press agency reported today that Cambodian guerril las had killed, wounded or cap tured more than 10,000 enemy troops during the last month.

title: Staff to Own Watts Co. Under Plan
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7The ownership of the Watts Manu facturing Company, which is managed and manned by mi noritygroup employes, will be transferred to them under a plan announced today.

title: Private Group Lauds Vietnamization
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Al private group whose members support the war in Indochina handed President Nixon a re port today concluding that the socalled Vietnamization pro gram was working well, but warning that withdrawals of American troops must be pru dent and flexible and closely geared to improvement of South Vietnamese capability.

title: Jersey Legislature Approves Series of Stiff Anticrime Measures
description: TRENTON, May 7Brought on by the furor over charges that New Jersey was one of the most corrupt states in the nation and a stronghold for organized crime, a series of tough measures aimed at the Mafia and corrupt public officials cleared the Legisla ture here today.

title: GOLAR CRITICIZES NIXON ON HOUSING
description: The head of the country's largest publichousing pro gram charged yesterday that under President Nixon the Fed eral program for housing the poor was being dismantled and destroyed as part of a socalled Southern strategy that has allied public policy with ancient bigotry and ra cism.

title: Market Place
description: IT BEGINS to look to a num ber of observers as if the Cambodian conflict will be solved in financial rather than military circles. One of the latest to voice this view is the Argus Weekly Staff Re port, which speaks of new uncertainties for already badly unsettled financial markets.

title: Bernard LeSage, 47, Dies; Official of Sports Illustrated
description: Bernard R. LeSage, circula tion director of Sports Illus trated magazine, died Wednes day of a heart attack in Mid town Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 351 Copse Road. Madison. Conn.

title: Talking Typewriter Made
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) The newspaper Daily Politika reported experts in Slovenia had developed a talking type writer for blind people that identified punctuation marks with such comments as pim, pum and pam.

title: More Dollars Sent Abroad Last Year Despite Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 Despite the Government's con trols, United States Corpora tions sent $3.7billion abroad for direct investment last year, the Commerce Department re ported today. Almost $3billion went to the countries covered by the program of controls and a little more than $700million went to Canada.

title: Arts Centers Urged to Rent Some of Their Space
description: The Twentieth Century Fund Task Force on Perform ing Arts, in a report issued yesterday, said performing art centers would have to rent part of their space to commercial ventures if they are to avert the financial plight so many of them now face.

title: Village's Recapture Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 7 (Reuters)Cambodian forces recaptured the village of Koki thorn today and advanced to within four miles of the Neak Leung ferry crossing, seized by the Vietcong five days ago.

title: CoOp Leaders Plan To Move for Terms With Service Union
description: Presidents of some coopera tive apartment houses here are planning to break ranks with landlords of rentcontrolled buildings in the negotiations with doormen, elevator opera tors, porters and handymen, whose interim contract expires May 20.

title: MRS. JOHN DEWEY, EDUCATOR'S WIDOW
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 7 Mrs. Roberta Lowetz Grant, Dewey, widow of Dr. John Dewey, the philospher and ed ucator, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital of a a subdural hematoma.

title: Mrs. Niarchos Is Buried; Autopsy Report Due Today
description: ATHENS, May 7  The wife of Stavros Niarchos, the ship owner, was buried today, but Mr. Niarchos was notified not to leave Greece pending the district attorney's investigation into her sudden death early last Monday at the age of 44.

title: Disorder in Miami School
description: MIAMI, May 7 (UPI)About 100 black students went on rampage at the MiamiPalmetto High School today, injuring security guard and a student. The trouble apparently started when the blacks congregated on an upper floor wing and began brawling with white stu dents and throwing furniture around a classroom. Security officers and sheriff's deputies restored order.

title: Base Complex Captured
description: Base Complex Captured

title: Turning Tribute to Mothers to Boycott for Peace
description: THE movement to boycott the commercial aspects of Mother's Day and to turn it into a peace protest snow balled yesterday under the gathering force of antiwar feeling throughout the nation.

title: Hogan Cards a 71, Trails by 3
description: HOUSTON, May 7Ben Ho gan came back to tournament golf today and smiled at par. With a 71 that equaled regula tion figures, the 57yearold Texan returned to the pressure of competition in the $115,000 Houston Champions Interna tional tourney after an absence of almost three years.

title: Urban League Cites 2 Black Actors
description: Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis, the black acting and writing team, were awarded the Fred erick Douglass Award by the New York Urban League last night at a dinner at which, the Nixon Administration was scored for attacks on college students.

title: Artists' District Plans A Weekend of Shows
description: More than 100 art shows, dance, music, theater and multimedia performances will take place this weekend in the streets and lofts of the downtown artists' district in lower Manhattan.

title: NIXON WILL BAR HOSTILE COMMENTS ON STUDENTS BYA GNEW AND OTHERS; SUMMONS 50 GOVERNORS TO MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  President Nixon moved today on a variety of fronts to repair his lines of communication with the campuses amid fresh evi dence of revolt against his policies within the Administra tion and among his academic advisers.

title: Students Tidy Up Image To Lobby in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 7De scribing himself as Mr. Nixon's burn, Merrick Thomas of Haverford College sat in a Con gressional hearing room today and pondered aloud: How can we keep the pressure on the President to end this war with out demonstrating, without be ling obnoxious?

title: 7 City Employes Receive Awards for Their Work
description: Mayor Lindsay presented awards Wednesday to seven city employes for excellence of per formance at a City Hall cere mony in the Board of Estimate chambers.

title: Times Says Printers' Tactics Make Heavy Cut in Production
description: The accelerated pressures placed on The New York Times by the typographical union are having an increasingly serious impact on composingroom op erations and production of the paper, a spokesman said yes terday.

title: Chairman Cites Crisis; Harriman Scores Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Republican Governors Confer ence, scheduled to begin this evening in Santa Fe, N. M., was abruptly canceled this afternoon by its chairman, Gov. Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania.

title: Thieu Asserts Lon Nol Agrees on Troops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that he and Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia had worked out agreements in principle for South Vietna mese troops to conduct con tinuing military operations in eastern Cambodia.

title: Maj. Gen. Henry B. Sayler, An Eisenhower Aide, 76
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., May 8 (AP)  Maj. Gen. Henry B. Sayler, a West Point classmate of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and chief ordinance officer on Gen eral Eisenhower's staff during World War II, died here yes terday at the age of 76.

title: N. B. A. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: No Place Like Home
description: Top of the world, said a contented, champagnedoused young man named Walt Frazier.

title: Badillo Proposes Agency to Handle Dissent Problems
description: Herman Bodillo, former Bor ough President of the Bronx, called yesterday for the estab lishment of an Office of Com munity Disputes to cope with problems arising from civil dissent.

title: Knicks Take First Title, Beating Lakers, 113 to 99
description: The New York Knickerbock ers, displaying their finest qual ities with the limited physical but important spiritual aid of a limping Willis Reed, won the championship of the National Basketball Association last night by routing the Los Ange les Lakers, 11399, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Note to Readers
description: The box scores of all base ball games between nonlocal teams are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Antiwar Offices Ransacked In Union Sq.
description: Intruders early yesterday ransacked the Union Square of fices of the New York Student Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam and stole office equipment and cardindex files listing members, accord ing to the police of the East 21st Street station.

title: 7 in Newark Mayoral Race Wage Confident Campaigns
description: NEWARK, May 8Is there really national interest in the campaign for Mayor here? asked a chic young woman who works in a downtown Newark office building but, like many, lives in a com fortable suburh.

title: A Correction
description: In the obituary of Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College from 1915 to 1946, published in yesterday's New York Times, the name of a second son, James Mac. Cracken, executive director of Church World Service here, was inadvertently omitted from tthe list of survivors. Dr. Mac Cracken died Thursday in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., at the age of 89.

title: Former Biafran Army Chief Believed to Be Under Arrest
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 8 (Reuters)Philip Effiong, the former secessionist leader who surrendered Biafra last Jan. 12, has disappeared from his home near Owerri and is believed to be under arrest.

title: Pope to Meet the Head Of Armenian Church
description: ROME, May 8The Su preme Catholicos, the spiritual head of the Armenian church, who resides in Soviet Ar menia, arrived here today for a fourday ecumenical visit to Pope Paul VI.

title: City Sues 3 Drug Concerns As Ampicillin Monopolists
description: The city filed a tripledam age, antitrust suit yesterday in the District of Columbia against the BristolMyers Com pany, Beecham Group, Ltd., a British corporation, and Beech am, Inc., its American subsidi ary, charging a conspiracy to monopolize the sales and dis tribution of ampicillin, a new broadspectrum antibiotic.

title: Hairdresser Courting Royalty for a Wedding
description: The latest entry for party oftheyear honors will be submitted in St. Tropez, France, on May 23 when 400 of the titled heads, film stars and merely rich who make up the jumbo jet set gather for the wedding of 26yearold Michel Rainon and Miss Evelyne de Beschart, the daughter of Viscount and Vis countess Alain de Beschart.

title: 250 in State Dept. Sign a War Protest
description: WASHINGTON, May 8More than 250 State Department and foreignaid employes have signed a letter to Secretary of State William P. Rogers criticiz ing the United States military involvement in Cambodia.

title: Wedding June 14 For Miss Schwartz
description: Miss Elizabeth Anne Schwartz and Peter Allan Small will be married here June 14.

title: Cornell 52 Victor
description: ITHACA, N.Y., May 8Tom Faber hurled a fourhitter to lead Cornell to a 52 victory over Brown today in an East ern League game.

title: Retailers Duck Credit Issue for Welfare Recipients
description: Almost a year ago the Na tional Welfare Rights Organ ization took aim at the na tion's leading retailers, insist ing that they should extend credit to welfare recipients. Ever wary of delinquent bill payers in this age of instant credit, the stores mainly ducked the issue.

title: Time Fastest on Schuylkill
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 8 More than 700 crewminded collegians representing three dozen campuses from as fax west as Indiana and as far south as Florida turned out for the opening phases of the two day Dad Vail Regatta oday.

title: House Unit Votes TV Entry
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) The House Rules Committee voted Thursday to open House committee hearings for the first time to coverage by television and radio and still pictures. The decision is subject to approval by the House.

title: Santos Bows in Soccer
description: CARACAS, May 8 (AP)The Setubal soccer team from Por tugal defeated Santes of Brazil, 31, in an exhibition match be fore a crowd of 12,000 last night.

title: Blast Hits Envoy's Home
description: BRUSSELS, May 8 (Reuters) An explosion smashed the en trance of the Yugoslav Ambas sador's residence in a Brussels suburb early today. The Ambas sador was unhurt.

title: Blacks Get Journalism Grant
description: Grants totaling $21,412 have been awarded to 45 Negro jour nalism students at 28 universi ties and colleges across the na Lion, the American Newspaper; Publishers Association Founda tion announced yesterday.

title: ALBERT KUSHINSKY
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., May 8 Albert Kushinsky, formerly an assistant Ocean County prose cutor for more than 20 years, died yesterday after apparently suffering a heart attack at his law offices here. His age was 66.

title: What Is a University?
description: Suddenly, in just about week's time, national trauma has catapulted colleges and uni versities into an active, over riding political role that raises with new urgency the question, What is a university?

title: Chinese Said to Aid Revival of Cambodian Red Group
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The composition of the government in exile formed in Peking by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, ousted Cambodian Chief of State, is being viewed here as confirmation of intelligence re ports that the Cambodian Com munist movement has been re activated with Chinese aid.

title: Dr. Henry Hammer Is Dead; Radiologist at Beth Israel
description: Dr. Henry Hammer, a con sulting radiologist of Beth Israel Medical Center, died Thursday in New York University Hos pital, after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 245 East 21st Street.

title: Nurses Association Elects
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 8 (AP) Dr. Hildegard Peplau, interim executive director of the Amer ican Nurses Association, was elected its president today at the close of a national conven tion. Dr. Peplau has been on, leave from her post as director of the graduate program in psychiatric nursings at Rutgers University.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Mother Held in Sale of Baby
description: PALERMO, Sicily, May 8 (Reuters)The police today dis closed the arrest Of an impov erished mother of five children who sold her newborn son for 50,000 lire, about $80. The mother, Mrs. Elizabetta Mina sola, and the buyer, Mrs. An gela Olivieri, were charged with illegally altering the child's civil status.

title: Brezhnev Meets Hanoi Aide
description: MOSCOW, May 8 (Reuters) The Soviet Communist party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, dis cussed the war in Indochina today with the North Vietnam ese party leader, Le Duan, it was officially announced here. The announcement said the two men also discussed measures to strengthen cooperation between Moscow and Hanoi, but gave no details.

title: Linens With Cardin Imprint
description: PROBABLY Emilio Pucci knew what he was start ing in 1967 when he de signed a line of bed and bath linens. Since then he has been joined by Hanae Mori, Yves Saint Laurent and now Pierre Cardin in the name conscious linens field. The three Fieldcrest patterns that bear Cardin's name are an out sized floral that looks vaguely like daffodils and is called Florialc, a circle motif called Rondo and an abstract known as Visa Vis. The latter is said to re semble the embossed designs on Cardin's clothing fashions. The association between Fieldcrest and Carlin began last October when Field crest's chief designer went to Paris to show Mr. Cardin a few things, according to a spokesman for the linens concern.

title: Police Were Told of Plan
description: City Hall and the Police De partment received warnings yesterday morning that several hundred construction workers, organized into a band on Thursday, would attack peace demonstrators in lower Man hattan.

title: Administration Will Permit Rally Today at Ellipse, South of the White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 The Nixon Administration agreed today to permit a mass anti war rally tomorrow on grounds immediately south of the White House, an area it had previous ly declared out of bounds.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed a seesaw week yester day on a quietly steady note.

title: Agnew T ones Down His Speech After Viewing President on TV
description: BOISE, Idaho, May 8Vice President Agnew, delivering a speech tonight, toned down a text that came down hard on America's dissenters, saying he wanted in some small way to help cool the temper of the nation.

title: 9% Decline Is Estimated In Size of '69 Cotton Crop
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The Agriculture Department, in a revised estimate, today placed the size of the 1969 cot ton crop at 10,015,000 bales, down 9 per cent from 1968 in spite of Government efforts to spur increased production.

title: DONOHUE GAINS POLE FOR LIME ROCK RACE
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., May 8  Mark Donohue of Media. Pa., won the pole position for tomorrow's 2hour trans American sedan race. He earned the top spot by getting his American Motors Javelin aroun the 1.5mile Lime Rock Park circuit in 58.8 seconds, an aver age speed of just over 93 miles hour.

title: Bridge:
description: ACCIDENTS at the bridge table are not as rare as one might suppose, and gen erate their own brand of luck.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended May 5.

title: Brandt Commemorates Defeat
description: BONN, May 8  Chancellor Willy Brandt warned the young people of West Germany today against forgetting the lessons of history so painfully taught their fathers: that unrestrained radicalism by a few and a lack of interest and action by the rest can lead to ruin.

title: NONMILITARY WOUND IS REPORTED AT KENT
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 8 (UPI)An Ohio National Guard official said today that a frag mentary report showed that one of 10 students wounded on the Rent State University campus on Monday was struck by a nonmilitary bullet.

title: In Memoriam
description: KESSELMANAnthony. In cherished memory of our beloved father, May 9th, 1942

title: Mexico Soccer Victor
description: MEXICO CITY, May 8 (AP) The soccer team that will rep resent Mexico in the World Cup championship games de feated Borussia of West Ger many. 10, last night.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Fund Benefit
description: Former Chief Justice Earl Warren will be the guest of honor at a luncheon on Fri day in the Americana for the benefit of the National Asso ciation for the Advancement of Colored People Legal De fense and Educational Fund, Inc. Tickets are $15 each.

title: Glen Alden Reports a Decline In Its First Quarter Earnings
description: The Glen Alden Corporation reported sharply lower first quarter earnings, despite higher sales and revenues, according to the report issued yesterday.

title: Jubilant Knick Fans Halt Traffic With Cries of No. 1
description: A group of several hundred exuberant funs of the New York Knicks team celebrated the end of 24 years of frustra tion by marching against traf fic in Yorkville last night.

title: Change of Heart...
description: It has taken the awful toll of four young lives to create an atmosphere in Washington receptive at last to the voices of youthful protest. But the irony which should not be lost on the campuses of the nation is that it was not the fruitless violence of students that softened the Administration's attitude; it was the vio lence of authority itselfand the nationwide wave of revulsion it created.

title: BRUINS' ORR WINS 3 HOCKEY AWARDS
description: BOSTON, May 8 (AP)Bobby Orr, the Boston Bruins' spectac ular 22yearold defenseman, became the second player in National Hockey League his tory today to win three league awards in one season.

title: Rinfret Clarifies His Role In Negotiations Over I.O.S.
description: Pierre A. Rinfret, president of the economic consulting firm of RinfretBoston Associ ates, denied yesterday reports in Friday's editions of The New York Times that he had played a role in the bid by John M. King, chairman of King Re sources Company of Denver, for control of Bernard Corn feld's mutual fund complex, Investors Overseas Services.

title: Saints Sign Burrough
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 8 (UPI) The New Orleans Saints to day signed their No. 1 choice in the college draftKen Bur rough, a wide receiver from Texas Southern.

title: GOVERNMENT FUNDS DECLINE IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, May 8 (AP)Funds in the Government accounts de clined again last week under the pressure of buying foreign currency flowing into Canada.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Murray, Judith H. Taylor Wed in London
description: Miss Judith Hanson Taylor, daughter of Mrs. Earl Stough Taylor of Princeton, N. J., and the late Dr. Taylor, physician, was married yes terday in London to Peter Guiler Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. George McGibbon Murray of Little Walding field, England.

title: MARCUS A. ZENOBIA
description: Marcus A. Zenobia, who re tired in 1964 as president of the Railway Equipment and Publishing Company of New York, died Thursday in Hal landale, Fla., at the age of 79

title: The Manhattan Slowed By Heavy Arctic Ice
description: DARTMOUTH, Nova Scotia, May 8 (Canadian Press) Heavy ice north of Baffin Island has stalled the United States tanker Manhattan and her Canadian escort in their attempt to move through arctic waters, a Transport Department official said to day.

title: Former Secretary of Commerce Scores Move Into Cambodia
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8 John T. Connor, chairman of the board of the Allied Chemi cal Corporation, said today that President Nixon's decision to send United States troops into Cambodia shakes the confi dence of many Americans in lus judgment and intentions.

title: In the Ozarks, Some Nixon Backers Give Him the Benefit of the Doubt
description: ROGERS, Ark., May 8As recently as last fall, the people of this relaxed, conservative, allwhite town were less con cerned about the Vietnam war than about the fortunes of the razorbacks football team at the nearby University of Arkansas.

title: Market Place:
description: ANYONE who has seen the official ballot of the New York Stock Exchange can readily predict the result. For the printed ballot contains socialclub fashionone name for each position at stake.

title: White House Once a Place That Belonged to Public
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The White House, the focus of tomorrow's antiwar protests, is surrounded by an aura of power plus gates, fences, guards, flood lights and a chain of legal documents designed to keep out intruders and discourage dem onstrations.

title: LABOR MAKES GAINS IN BRITISH ELECTIONS
description: LONDON, May 8  A big swing to the Labor party in local voting yesterday in creased the chance of an early general election in Britain.

title: Harvard Eight a Threat
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 8 The Eastern college sprint championships on Lake Quin sigamond will involve 73 crews in a ninehour program of qual ification, consolation and final races here tomorrow.

title: U.S. CHARGES 14 MEN WITH PORT THEFTS
description: NEWARK, May 8 (AP)  United States Attorney Fred erick B. Lacey announced today the arrest of 14 men in con nection with an alleged water front theft ring.

title: INFORMERS FUND OF $439,000 ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) The Federal Government says it may, in some cases, pay an informer more than $50,000 in its drive to curtail illegal drug supply conspiracies.

title: Sonus Corp. Wins Suit
description: NATICK, Mass., May 8 (UPI) The Sonus Corporation said today it had been awarded more than $210,000 in damages in a breach of contract suit against the Matsushita Electric Com pany of America, a subsidiary of the Japanese Matsushita Company. The action was initi ated by Matsushita, alleging nonpayment of bills by Sonus. In a counter calim, Sonus al leged a number of contract breaches, including late deliv ery of merchandise, and claimed damages of $600,000.

title: Voter League in Nixon Plea
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)  Delegates to the national convention of the League of Women Voters urged President Nixon today to listen to the voices of all the people. In a letter to the President, the dele gates said:We urge you to lis ten with close attention to the voices of all the peoplethe young and the mature, the poor and the affluent, the farms, the suburbs, the cities, and the campus.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS TURNOVER SAGS
description: Prices finished lower on the American Stock Exchange yes terday in the lightest trading in almost threeandonehalf years.

title: Saigon Reports Battle
description: SAIGON, May 8 (AP)North Vietnamese forces, which launched a series of attacks in the northern reaches of South Vietnam today, were reported to have suffered a defeat in the biggest battle there.

title: Liquor Store Applications Are Dwindling
description: Consumers have been bene fiting from lower prices since the passage of the socalled liquor reform law in 1964, but on the other side of the counter many owners of re tail package stores have been experiencing problems.

title: SPENCER DRIVES IN 2 RUNS ON HOMER
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 8 The New York Yankees switched starters before to night's game, using the right handed Ron Klimkowski in stead of the lefthanded John Cumberland.

title: MEMORIAL TUESDAY FOR JEROME ADLER
description: A memorial service for Jerome H. Adler, a lawyer and trustee of the Music Perform ance Trust Funds of the Re cording Industry, will be held at 11 A.M. Tuesday in the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street.

title: Bipartisan Senate Group Maps A 3Pronged Antiwar Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  A group of Democratic and Re publican Senators have devised a threepronged strategy for challenging President Nixon's policies in Southeast Asia and for placing legislative restric tions on his powers as Com mander in Chief.

title: Nixon Critics Complain Of Rejected Telegrams
description: Several people complained to The New York Times this week that Western Union operators refused to accept telegrams ad dressed to President Nixon that were sharply critical of his Cambodian policy.

title: A Merging of Faiths
description: When Pope Paul VI met with Arthur Michael Ramsey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, in Rome in December, 1966, he gave his guest a papal ring and reportedly remarked, This is not vet a ring of marriage, but it is a ring of engagement. This week a joint commission or the Roman Catholic and Episcopal Churches in this country issued a report declaring that merger be tween the two churches should now be seen as a realistic ob jective rather than a faroff dream.

title: New Problem Over So. Africa Confronts U.S. Tennis Leaders
description: Less than two months after the banning of South Africa from Davis Cup participation, another delicate political prob lem confronts American tennis officials.

title: Dance on Thursday To Benefit Nurses
description: The Lower East Side Com mittee of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York plans to hold its invitational dinner dance Thursday at the Pierre. Mrs. H. Harding Isaacson heads the event to help the agency continue its program through 14 neighborhood cen ters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

title: AntiU.S. Protests Held From Britain to Taiwan
description: Demonstrations continued around the world yesterday in protest against the United States' intervention in Cam bodia and the killing of four, students at Kent State Univer sity by Ohio National Guards men.

title: SCOVILL RESCINDS METALPRICE RISE
description: Malcolm Baldr ige, chair man and chief executive offi cer of the Scovill Manufactur ing Company, said yesterday in Waterbury, Conn., that the con cern had rescinded price in creases this week on some aluminumsheet items because the salesmen couldn't write or ders at the higher prices.

title: Demoralized and Tired
description: Keith Erickson sat in the Los Angeles Lakers' dressing room last night, rubbing his hands and pausing to stroke his brow. He was tired and beaten.

title: New Family at the US. Embassy in Paris
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn. When Arthur Kittredge Watson, chairman of the I.B.M. World Trade Corpora tion and vice president of I.B.M., presented his creden tials as American Ambas sador to France to President Georges Pompidou on Tues day, it signaled a changed way of life for his wife, Ann, and their six children.

title: MARKETS' VOLUME SACS TO 1970 LOW
description: Trading on the New York Stock Exchange slowed yester day to 6.93 million shares, its slowest pace of 1970, as clashes between antiwar demonstrators and helmeted construction workers suddenly became the focus of attention in the Wall Street area.

title: Artists' District Plans A Weekend of Shows
description: More than 100 art shows, dance, music, theater and multi.media performances will take place this weekend in the streets and lofts of the downtown artists' district in lower Manhattan.

title: Opera: Grimm Fairy Tale
description: BOSTON, May 8An opera for children is a risky project. To be worth doing it has to find the right bal anre between simplicity for the young and at least some sophistication for parental endurance.

title: ARTHUR M. KARL, 60, LED A MAILING FIRM
description: Arthur Martin Karl, president of Names Unlimited, Inc., 352 Park Avenue South, a direct maillist brokerage firm, died Thursday here of a heart at tack. He was 60 years old and lived at 26 Norman Drive, Rye, N.Y.

title: Synagogue Is Planning Luncheon on Thursday
description: The sisterhood of the Park East SynagogueCongregation Zichron Ephraim will hold its annual spring luncheon and fashion show at the Pierre on Thursday to celebrate the synagogue's 80th anniversary and the 22d anniversary of the independence of Israel.

title: SCHOOL ELECTION ATTACKED AGAIN
description: A second legal challenge was instituted yesterday against the local school board elections scheduled for May 28 in Man hattan's six new decentralized school districts.

title: 2 Conquer Peak in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 8 (AP)Two members of the Himalayan expedition of Keio University in Japan conquered the 21,890foot Bauddha Peak in western Nepal last Saturday, the Nepal Foreign Ministry an nounced today.

title: Dance: Visit to Amherst
description: AMHERST, Mass., May 8 The American Ballet Theater Players, an author ized splinter group from the parent Ballet Theater, has three functions. The first is to provide ballet of high pro fessional standard in towns where no facilities are avail able for the complete com pany. Second it is designed to give performing experience and better employment con tinuity to the company's soloists. And finally it is to encourage the first steps of young choreographers from within the company.

title: Rima Beth Doner to Become Bride
description: GREAT NECK, L.I. May 8 The engagement of Miss Rima Beth Doner to Peter J. Calderon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Calderon of Ros lyn Heights, has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Max M. Doner. A wedding next month is planned.

title: CANADIAN UTILITY SEES HIGH '70 NET
description: The Canadian International Power Company looks for 1970 earnings to expand by about 10 per cent to $15million, from the $13.5million, or $4.55 a share, reported in 1969. William M. Hickey, president said after yesterday's company annual meeting at Montreal. He said his company, which recently acquired controlling interest in a Venezuelan data processing company, plans to expand this business over the whole Latin American area.

title: U.S. Health Official Will Head New City Hospitals Corporation
description: Dr. Joseph T. English, a 37 yearold psychiatrist, was named yesterday as the first president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Cor poration, the largest nonFed eral health system in the na tion.

title: News Summary and Index
description: At his first news conference in three months, President Nixon said that the first American troops would start pulling out of Cambodia by the middle of next week and all American troops would be out by the middle of June. He said that the Cambodian operation gained time to train the South Vietnamese and thus shortened the United States role. [Page 1, Columns 48.]

title: Trade Group Chief Predicts Enactment Of Quota on Imports
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Nelson Stitt, head of the United StatesJapan Trade Council, predicted today that Congress would enact im portquota legislation cover ing textiles and footwear.

title: WISCONSIN U. HEAD RESIGNS HIS POST
description: MADISON, Wis., May 8 The University of Wisconsin president, Fred Harvey Harring ton, his campus scarred by four days of antiwar strife, today resigned his post, effective Oct. 1.

title: OutofTown Exchanges
description: MIDWEST

title: 2 Convicted Here for Trying To Sell Stolen Securities
description: Two men who were accused of trying to sell $1.6million in securities stolen from the Chase Manhattan Bank for $250,000 were convicted by a Federal Court jury yesterday of extor tion and conspiracy.

title: For Souvenir Hunters in Fishhook, A Case of Beer Buys a Soviet Rifle
description: NEAR THE TABOL RIVER, Cambodia, May 8You could trade a case of beer for a Soviet designed rifle around here today, and lots of sol diers were doing it.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, May 9, 1970

title: MEXICAN ROOKIE PITCHES 7HITTER
description: The Mets didn't produce much applause last night at Shea Stadium, but Willie Mays and the Knicks did.

title: War Foes Here Attacked By Construction Workers
description: Helmeted construction work ers broke up a student anti war demonstration in Wall Street yesterday, chasing youths through the canyons of the financial district in a wild noontime melee that left about 70 persons injured.

title: Cannes Impressed As Bergman Film, Passion. Is Given
description: CANNES, France, May 8 Passion, Ingmar Bergman's latest film, had its premiere at the Cannes Festival and as all superior films seem to be, it was presented out of competi tion.

title: STUDENTS GIVEN OPTIONS ON MARKS
description: Many colleges and univer sities, facing long closures dur ing the current wave of cam pus disruptions and strikes have begun offering their stu dents a wide range of improm ise choices to receive academic credit.

title: Stoph Assails Bonn
description: BERLIN, May 8  Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany accused West Germany of maintaining aggressive venge ful attitudes toward Eastern Europe.

title: Hicksville G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The Pentagon today identi fied 23 servicemen as having been killed in Southeast. Asia, including Specialist 4 Stanley D. Wilenski of the Army, of Hicksville, L. I.

title: Memorial Seruires
description: CLARKIsabel T. A memorilal service will be held at 11 A.M. Monday, May 11, 1970, for Isabel T. Clark (Isabel Barringer) in the Poling Chhapel of the Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Avenue and 29th Street, Man hattan. Please omit flowers. Contributions may be made to the Marble Collegiate Church or to the Churchh of the Truth, 154 West 57th street, Manhattan.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: The Reds hit more homers than the Cubs, 5 to 4, but didn't score as many runs and lost, 107. Billy Williams drove in four runs with a pair of homers. J. C. Martin and Jim Hickman also con nected for Chicago. Hal Mc Rae and Tony Perez socked two homers each for the Reds. Johnny Bench hit the fifth.

title: COMPANIES HOLD ANNUAL MEETINGS
description: the transaction that often it doesn't look as attractive after closer scrutiny.

title: Upstate Village Backs Nixon Policies
description: GLEN AUBREY, N.Y., May 7Mrs. Betty Welch, whose son. Leon, is serving in the Army along the VietnamCam bodian border, was talking to iday in the local post office about fears for her son's life land the violence on college campuses in behalf of the with drawal of United States troops from Vietnam.

title: New Greek Power Project
description: ATHENS, May 8Premier George Papadopoulos opened a new $72million hydroelectric power project today on the Achelous River, which runs 136 miles through central Greece. The project was built with American financial assistance, and the United States Ambassa dor, Henry J. Tasca, attended the ceremony.

title: Chinese Acclaim Continues
description: HONG KONG, May 8Mili tary men and civilians have held rallies throughout Com munist China hailing the Cam bodian government in exile formed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and pledging full sup port for the regime and the peoples of all the Indochinese countries in their struggle against U.S. aggression.

title: Decline Reported In Foreign Trade By Port Authority
description: Foreign trade movements through the Port of New York last year were 5.1 per cent be low the 1968 totals; substan tial gains in airborne exports and imports were unable to offset losses attributable to the 56dav longshoremen's strike.

title: Who Will Be on Stage Of Met With Tommy
description: Verdi and Puccini will take a back seat to The Who, when the British rock group presents their opera, Tom my, in two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday, June 7, at 2:30 and 8 P.M.

title: Ray Says Lawyer Promised Pardon After Guilty Plea
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 8 (AP) James Earl Ray said in a peti tion for a new trial that his for mer lawyer promised to get him a pardon within two years if he pleaded guilty to a charge of murdering Dr. Martin Luther King.

title: SIDNEY J. FINLAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Sid ney J. Finlay, who retired in 1950 as controller of the Com pania Azucarera, a subsidiary of the West Indies Sugar Cor poration, died today. His age was 88 and his home was at 2200 19 Street N.W.

title: Why Are We in Vietnam?
description: LONDON, May 8President Nixon's action in Cambodia has had at least one constructive effect: it has dramatized the flawed character, not to say illogic, of his declared plan to get the United States out of Vietnam.

title: Jones Joins Addiction Unit
description: Howard A. Jones of New Rochelle was sworn in here yes terday as a member of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Com mission. Mr. Jones, since 1963 a member of the State Board of Parole, fills the vacancy created when former Commissioner Irv ing Lang was appointed to the Criminal Court bench in New York City. Mr. Jones will serve the remainder of a fiveyear term ending Dec. 31, 1974, at a salary of $30,690 a year.

title: FULLA NAPOLEON TAKES RICH PACE
description: YONKERS, May 8The bur sitis in Fulla Napoleon's right shoulder did not slow the 5 yearold son of Dale Frost Sarah Napoleon tonight as he registered a twolength, going away victory over Rum Cus tomer in the $50,000 Martin Tananbaum International Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: New Affront to Prague
description: Soviet Communist party chief Leonid 1. Brezhnev administered a strong dose of additional humiliation to Czechoslovakia this week when he visited Prague to sign the socalled SovietCzechoslovak friendship treaty.

title: NIXON DEFENDS CAMBODIA DRIVE AS AIDING STUDENTS' PEACE AIM; SAYS PULLOUT WILL BEGIN SOON
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Strongly defending the United States troop movement into Cambodia, which has evoked a storm of protest by students and others throughout the coun try, President Nixon said to night that the operation would win six to eight months of time for the further training of South Vietnamese forces and thus shorten the war for the Ameri cans.

title: Wisconsin's Loss
description: The resignation of Fred H. Harrington from the presidency of the University of Wisconsin adds an other victim to the honor roll of those who have tried in vain to fight the twofront battle against extremism on the left and on the right. Radical students have repeatedly terrorized the campus, provoking in turn not only armed occupation but also the repressive hostility of community and legislature.

title: Hoover Holds Panthers' Hatred Causes Clashes With the Police
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation, says law enforcement agencies were not to blame for confrontations between the Black Panther party and the police.

title: Seoul Aide to Visit Saigon For Talks on Cambodia
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 8 The South Korean Defense Minister, Nae Hyuk Chung, will visit Saigon later this month to discuss with American and South Vietnamese officials what role South Korea can play in Cambodia, it was reported here today.

title: Customs Court Is Playing a Role of EverIncreasing Import
description: The United States Customs Court, according to its judges, is entering a new era in its role as arbiter of the nation's tariff disputes.

title: Outspoken Businessman
description: THEN the prestigious Busi ness Council, a group of the nation's top industrialists, invited John Thomas Connor to address its spring meeting yesterday about the situation in Southeast Asia, its mem bers probably could not have anticipated the intensity of his remarks. But by the time that the chairman of Allied Chemical Corporation a n d former Secretary of Commerce end ed his talk in Hot Springs, Va., there was no doubt about his opposition to the movement of American troops into Cambodia and his belief that the Vietnam dis engagement should be quick ened.

title: Patients Challenge V. A. Hospital's Ban On Peace Petitions
description: A group called the Vietnam War Veterans Against the War, said Yesterday that it woud file a suit against administrators of a Veterans Administration Hos pital here for allegedly for bidding patients from signing Ian antiwar petition.

title: BIG LINE IS WINNER IN 5HORSE JUMPOFF
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., May 8Mrs. H. H. Morris's Big Line, a longtype power in the divi sion, captured the first open jumper class today in a five horse jumpoff at the opening session of the threeday Chil dren's Services horse show.

title: NEW ISSUES ROSE 4.6% BY END OF '69
description: Investors paid a record total of $2.6billion for the common stock of 1,026 privately held companies that went public during 1969, a study published yesterday disclosed.

title: In San Diego, Trust Has Weakened While Public Division Has Increased
description: SAN DIEGO, May 8Nixon) says he will be a oneterm Pres ident, and I agree, said a bar ber in the shabby North Park section of town. He hasn't lived up to his promises. He said he would get out and bring the troops home, but he hasn't done it.

title: College Radio Hookup Will Give Only AllDay Report of Protests
description: A network of college radio stations, with New York Uni versity's WNYU as the coordi nating flagship, will provide broadcasting's only sustained coverage of today's antiwar activities in Washington and of weekend protests across the country.

title: Echoes of Protest Will Be Heard Today at 36th Heptagonal Meet
description: NEW HAVEN, May 8Amid much speculation over team titles, individual performances and symbols of social protest, the 36th annual Heptagonal Games will be held here tomor row

title: Air Polluter Identified
description: The Warner plant of the American Cyanamid Company in Linden, N. J., was identified yesterday as the source of what the city said were dangerously high levels of sulphur dioxide in the air over Staten Island this week. Herbert H. Hofmaier, the manager of the plant, said old equipment to manufacture sulphuric acid would be re placed by a new plant with much tighter pollution controls later this month.

title: The CigaretteCancer Dispute
description: An overwhelming volume of evidence suggests that cigarette smoking is harmful and can lead to lung cancer, emphysema, and various heart and circulatory problems. In the current dispute between The Tobacco Institute and the American Cancer Society, however, the latter organization made an error of judgment which it has now only partially rectified.

title: Antiques: Hunting at the Flea Market
description: FLEA markets are the place for serious search ing and frivolous wandering by people who like old things.

title: State National Guard to Study Its Regulations on Riot Control
description: The New York National Guard has decided to review its methods of riot control follow ing the killing of four students by National Guardsmen at Kent State University in Ohio earlier this week.

title: Sports of The Times
description: THE International Olympic Committee, which has been described by an admirer as a selfperpetuating oli garchy, will decide in several days on the site of the 1976 Games. The leading candidates are Los Angeles and Moscow and I.O.C. watchers maintain the decision will have nothing to do with logic and little to do with the expensive promotional campaigns each city has mounted.

title: W.R. Grace Meeting Shows Optimism
description: Negotiations with the Peruvi an Gosernm.nt on the amount of payment for the expropriat ed sugar properties of W. R. Grace & Co. continue, but some decision is expected to be reached in a month or two. J. Peter Grace, president, made the disclosure in response to a stockholder at yesterday's two hour annual meeting in the Cen tury Plaza Hotel at Los Ange les.

title: McGee Equals Dash Mark
description: HOUSTON, May 8 (AP)  Willie McGee of Alcorn A. and M. College equaled the world's record of 9.1 seconds tonight in the 100yard dash in the preliminaries of the Southwest Athletic Conference champion ship track meet. McGee achieved his unofficial record with a trailing wind of 3.75 miles an hour, well below the maximum allowed.

title: Computer Aids in Cartoon Animation
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 The Xerox Corporation received a patent this week for a method of producing animated cartoons with the aid of a computer. Von Haney, a scientist in the Patents Xerox plant at of the Rochester, was granted Patent Week 3,510,210. In the procedure, a live actor goes through the mo tions that are expected of the cartoon character and the performance is recorded. The actor may wear reflectors or characteristic images of Bugs of his body as reference points to make the move ments clearer.

title: ExMinister Assails Lynch Over Dublin's Gun Scandal
description: DUBLIN, MAY   Kevin Boland, the Government min ister who resigned after reports of gun smuggling into Ireland, asserted today that the British Secret Service was behind the allegation.

title: Evacuation of Saravane Is Planned by Laotians
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 8 The Government has begun to take measures to evacuate the civilian population of Saravane following the fall of Attopeu last week. Savarane, with a pop ulation of 5,500, is about 60 miles northeast of the Mekong River town of Pakse and is on the eastern rim of the Boloven Highlands. Attopeu fell to Pa thet Lao guerrillas and North Vietnamese troops on April 30.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: PRICES OF SILVER SHOW INCREASE
description: The dwindling prices of silver got a booster yesterday from a news story. Prices for most contracts were nudged up, and in terms of the September de livery the close was $1.76 910 an ounce, compared with $1.75 710 the previous day.

title: Article 6  No Title
RESERVE OFFERS TO BUY U.S. NOTES
description: The Federal Reserve quickly jumped yesterday to support the Government securities mar ket in the wake of the Govern ment's narrow squeak this week as it barely sold a $3.5 billion note issue.

title: Chrysler Begins to Recall 20,458 Darts and Valiants
description: DETROIT, May 8 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it had begun a re call campaign of 20,485 Dodge Dart and Plymouth Valiant passenger cars for replacement of the brake master cylinder on cars equipped with standard drum brakes.

title: Art: Two Great Shows on 64th Street
description: LET'S get thessential in formation into the first sentence The exhibition of Mir sculptures at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East 64th Street, and the 10th Anniver sary Exhibition at Asia House. 112 East 64th Street, ?? Masterpieces of Asian ?? in American Collections, ?? quite wonderful, both of them. They differ in that the Asia House show is serene while the Miriffs are ebullient, but each in its own way is good enough to take your mind off the front page for a while. What better recom mendation? You may then return refreshed to the job of coping with the next 24 hour installment of current history.

title: Former Biafran Army Chief Believed to Be Under Arrest
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 8 (Reuters)Philip Effiong, the former secessionist leader who surrendered Biafra last Jan. 12, has disappeared from his home near Owerri and is believed to be under arrest.

title: Columbia Concerts Canceled
description: The final two concerts in the ColumbiaPrinceton Electronic Music Center's 10th anniver sary celebration, scheduled for tomorrow afternoon and eve ning at Columbia University, have been canceled. They will be rescheduled in the fall. A spokesman for the concerts said it was felt unwise to give them now because of the tense situation on the campus.

title: A Correction
description: The date of the emergency peace meeting at which Jean nette Rankin is scheduled to speak was incorrectly given in yesterday's editions. It will take place tomorrow at I P.M. at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Two Groups From Manhattan To Visit Garden in the Bronx
description: A landscape of tulips, tu lip trees, flowering quince, cherry trees and lilacs will greet guests Wednesday at the New York Botanical Gar den in the Bronx. On June 10 the garden's landscape will change to roses, sum mer lilacs, Japanese dog wood, mock orange and field lilies.

title: Vatican Says Watching TV Mass Isn't Enough
description: ROME, May 8 (Reuters) The Vatican said today that Roman Catholics do not par ticipate in a Mass by watch ing it on television.

title: Topics: Women as Chattels, Men as Chumps
description: My cup of tea has never been poured from a vessel of wrath, and the brew currently being served up by the group known colloquially as Fern Lib is strong enough to float a crow bar or to dye white curtains the color of Mississippi mud and to give a body the pip bad enough to call the doctor.

title: F. D. Roosevelts Separated
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr. announced yester day that they had separated. A spokesman for the two said they had started negotiations to settle their property rights. They were married in 19491 after Mr. Roosevelt's divorce that year from the former Ethel du Pont, whom he married in 1937. Mrs. Roosevelt is the for mer Suzanne Perrin. The couple have two daughters, Nancy and Laura Roosevelt.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Treasury statement and some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations are omitted from this issue because of compos ing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Truck Driver Cheered By Antiwar Protesters
description: A truck driver who was given a ticket when he re fused to move his delivery van through a street clogged with antiwar demonstrators was rewarded yesterday with the cheers of the demonstra torsand about $100 in dol lar bills collected from the crowd to Day his fine.

title: Article 2  No Title
LEBANESE REPORT ISRAELI ATTACKS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 8  Israeli soldiers were reported to have attacked four Lebanese villages today after Palestinian guerrillas in the area had blown up an Israeli Army personnel, carrier near Metulla, close to the Lebanese border.

title: Lindsay Salutes Knicks For a Feast of Victory
description: After the New York Knicks' victory last night, Mayor Lindsay, who was not at the game, sent a telegram to the team's locker room.

title: 27.377 See Cavity Win
description: Cavity, a 5yearold gelding owned by David Shaer took the main event on yesterday's card, a 11/16mile turf event. With Jacinto Vasquez riding, Cavity made a fine surge in the stretch to overtake the leaders and post a threelength triumph over Close Attention, with Liai son third.

title: DARTMOUTH NINE DOWNS NAVY, 98
description: HANOVER, N.H. May 8 (AP) Bruce Saylor's tworun dou ble capped a fourrun rally in the ninth inning and lifted Dartmouth to a 98 victory over Navy today in an Eastern Inter collegate Baseball League game.

title: PANEL ON POLICE MAY BE REPLACED
