description: Mayor Lindsay plans to dis band the special fiveman com mittee established two weeks ago to investigate corruption in the Police Department and replace it with a larger panel, sources in the Lindsay admin istration reported yesterday.

title: Jersey's Transportation Head Is Cautious
description: TRENTON, May 8  The man named by Gov. William T. Cahill to help find ways that the Port of New York Author ity can aid mass transportation takes a somewhat cautious at titude toward how much the authority can really do.

title: WouldBe Seller of Letters By Mrs. Onassis Fined $100
description: Theodore Donson, a 31year old lawyer who tried to sell let ters written by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis to former Deputy De fense Secretary Roswell Gil patric pleaded guilty to a mis demeanor charge yesterday in Criminal Court and was fined $100.

title: CUTBACK IN STAFF ORDERED BY G.M.
description: DETROIT, May 8  The General Motors Corporation said today it had ordered a cutback in its whitecollar staff from clerks to managers, to help offset declining sales and profits.

title: A. B. A. Playoffs
description: (4of7 games series)

title: TV Helped a Winner in Ohio
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The scene is an outdoor marketplace. The camera zooms to a mound of vege tables and a pudgy hand picking up some cucumbers. It then pans to a grocer's winsomely ugly face. The soundtrack picks him up in midsentence: ... he should stick to astronauting. I'm a salesman. You're a Senator.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS PUSHED BY KHEEL
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, increased his efforts yesterday to break the dead lock in the contract negotia tions between the printer's union and the city's major newspapers.

title: Lindsay Statement Backs AntiDrug Telecasts Today
description: Mayor Lindsay has pro claimed today Drugs? Don't! Day, in conjunction with Channel 11's 24hour antidrug, broadcasting program.

title: Paul Taylor Group Stresses Contrasts In Dance Program
description: The second program of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which will be at the City Cen ter through tomorrow, provides a view of two major but con trasting Taylor works.

title: Ethel G. Stringfellow, 82, Dies; Principal at Chapin 25 Years
description: Ethel G. Stringfellow, a for mer headmistress of the Chapin School, died apparently of a stroke in her home at 136 East 79th Street yesterday. She was 82 years old.

title: Schools Shut, Pupils Combine Protest and Recreation
description: Olympio Matos, a sadfaced, 16yearold highschool sopho more, ended his first clay as an antivist yesterday by silting alone on the steps of St. Pat rick's Cathedral clutching large homemade black flag.

title: Warnings of a Recession Follow April's 4 Million Jobless Figure
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Total unemployment climbed sharply in April to nearly 4 million, raising renewed warn ings from Democratic and union officials that President Nixon's antiinflation policies were push ing the economy into a reces sion.

title: 6,000 Tires Recalled
description: WASHINGTON May 8 (UPI) Uniroyal, Inc., in compliance with a request from the De partment of Transportation, has recalled more than 6,000 pas songer car tires manufactured in 1968, The tires are of the Uniroyal Tiger Paw series, size 85514, having serial numbers beginning with the letters U or M and ending with the let ter V. The department said the tires did not meet minimum fatigue requirements.

title: Southdown Extends Offer
description: Southdown, Inc., said yester day it has extended its offer to acquire up to 625,000 shares of ??s outstanding common stock in exchange for its tenyear subordinate debentures until May 26. Southdown said its di rectors have indicated they may tender some or all of the shares owned by them. Zapata Norness, Inc., which owns near ly 25 per cent of Southdown's 2,367,000 common shares out standing, has indicated it may tender up to 350,000 of its shares, Southdown said.

title: Dust Commander, Termed Fit, Heads for Preakness at Pimlico
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 (AP) Dust Commander, winner of the Kentucky Derby, left Churchill Downs by van today for Pimlico and the second jewel of racing's Triple Crown: the Preakness a week from to morrow.

title: SENATE APPROVES SHIP SUBSIDY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The Senate voted an $81 million increase in shipbuilding subsidies yesterday as the first instaliment on President Nixon's program to build 300 new merchant marine ships during the next 10 years.

title: Sinatra Enthralls 3,000 at a Concert in London
description: LONDON, May 8They ap plauded and applauded. They jumped from their chairs. And they stayed up until the early hours of the morning. Frank Sinatra was in town giving his first of two charity concerts and about the only calm one in the Royal Festi val Hall was the singer him self.

title: AUSTRALIAN CARDS A 3UNDERPAR 68
description: HOUSTON, May 8  Bruce Crampton of Australia led with an aggregate of 137 today while Ben Hogan trailed him by nine strokes at the halfway mark in the $115,000 Houston Champions International golf tournament.

title: Bullet Fragments Sent To F.B.I. for Testing
description: KENT, Ohio, May 7The bullet fragments taken from the bodies of four students killed here Monday have been turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the sheriff's department said to day.

title: T. C. WETTERAU, 80, LED GROCERY CHAIN
description: T. C. Wetterau Sr., chairman of the board of Wetterau Foods, Inc., of St. Louis, died Thurs day .at Jackson Memorial Hos pital in Miami after emergency heart surgery. He was 80 years old, and had been living in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., since last summer.

title: Westinghouse Franchise Set
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., plans for franchising dealers in the nation's top 100 metro politan centers to sell and serv ice electronic crime and fire protection systems and devices for homes. The operation will be directed by Westinghouse Security Systems, Inc., a whollyowned subsidiary.

title: STUDENTS STEP UP PROTESTS ON WAR
description: College students across the nation intensified the renewed antiwar movement yesterday with mass marches and rallies, widened school strikes and scattered incidents of violence.

title: Entry of Buzkashi and Hagley Favored in 95th Withers
description: The Withers Stakes, a race that is older than the Kentucky Derby, will occupy the feature spot on the card at Aqueduct today. First run in 1874, one year before the Kentucky clas sic, the Withers will have its 95th running. Antiracing laws interrupted its continuity in 1911 and 1912. The Derby has had 96 uninterrupted runnings.

title: Ohio Lends $8Million to King, A Bidder for Control of I.O.S.
description: A battle for control of the ailing mutual fund complex, in vestors Overseas Services, took a new turn yesterday with the surprise disclosure that the Ohio State Treasury had loaned $8million to the King Re sources Company of Denver, one of the principal bidders for I.O.S.

title: ...Violence on the Right
description: The assaults by construction workers on students in downtown Manhattan yesterday were a tragic reflection of the polarization brought by the Vietnam war, campus turbulence, racial tensions and an Administrationfostered mood of political repression. Even more, the clashes in the financial district and at City Hall were a frightening lesson in the ease with which rightwing vigilantism finds in leftwing extremism an excuse for pushing aside constituted authority and enforcing its own brutal form of injustice.

title: Astros Drop Mayberry
description: HOUSTON, May 8 (AP)The Houston Astros optioned John Mayberry, a rookie first base man, to Oklahoma City today, and recalled Don Bryant, a catcher, from Columbus.

title: Someb Protests Heckled; Fires Reported at Colleges
description: The surge of protest result ing from the United Staes mili tary action in Cambodia and the student deaths at Kent State swept up a growing num ber of New York metropolitan, area residents yesterday, both on and off the campuses.

title: PETER CALTAGIRONE
description: Peter Caltagirone, who re tired in the 1940's after many years as foreman in charge of masonry work at The New York Times, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: TransCaribbean and American Amend Agreement on a Merger
description: TransCaribbean Airways an nounced yesterday that it and American Airlines, Inc., have amended slightly the terms of their previously announced mer ger agreement.

title: 7 PANTHERS FREED IN CHICAGO CLASH
description: CHICAGO, May 8  All criminal charges were dropped today against the seven Black Panthers who survived a shoot ing incident with Chicago po licemen last December.

title: Thursday Night Fights
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J.Ed win Viruet, 131 pounds, New York City, knocked out Eddie Rivera, 124, Puerto Rico, 5 rounds.

title: Along With a French Lesson, a Lesson on Cooking, Too
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.Mas tering the French lan guage and learning to cook French dishes are a natural combination for the women who've just completed a course called Conversational French for Gourmets, Bon Vivants and Travelers.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's televised news conference last night, as record ed by The New York Times:

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: San Francisco at New York (2:15 P.M.)Robertson (22) vs. Roos man (02).

title: AUSTRIA SETS PACE IN DAVIS CUP, 21
description: LONDON, May 8 (AP)Brit ain salvaged a doubles match to trail Austria 21, in a first round European Zone match of the Davis Cup at Edinburgh to day.

title: GRECHKO ASSAILS U.S. IN VEDAY TALK
description: MOSCOW, May 8  Defense Minister Andrei A. Grechko to day marked the 25th annivers ary of VE day with a denunci ation of the United States and an assertion that if there were a third world war, imperial ism would be crushed as a world system.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS RIGHT TO DISSENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Pres ident Nixon told the nation to night that he shared the goals and concerns of student pro testers.

title: Pitcher's Hit Decides
description: Bob Files, a relief pitcher, singled in the ninth inning to drive in the winning run as Long Island University beat Pratt Institute, 87, yesterday at the winner's field in Brook lyn.

title: Books of The Times
description: JUDGING by what we have been seeing and hearing, the guitar must benext to the microphonethe most ubiqui tous of instruments. Whatever else varies,

title: Saigon Navy's Gunboats Reported Inside Cambodia on the Mekong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8Gunboats of a South Vietnamese Navy flotilla bound for Pnompenh were reported today to have crossed the bor der into Cambodia on the Me kong River while the bulk of the fleet of about 60 river craft appeared to be massing just in side South Vietnam.

title: BLACKMUN OPINION SCORED DISRUPTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) Judge Harry A. Blackmun, whoe nomination to the Su preme Court is to be taken up Monday by the Senate, has said that disruptive campus tactics might he expected of a spoiled child but not of a college stu dent.

title: West Point's String Quartet Is Adventurous in Its Debut
description: The official United States Military Academy String Quar tet made its New York debut Thursday night at Carnegie Re cital Hall with a program that surely made John Philip Sousa turn over in his grave.

title: Kent State to Be Closed Until at Least June 13
description: KENT, Ohio, May 8 (UPI) Kent State University's presi dent Robert I. White said today the school would re main closed at least until June 13 because he could not guarantee the safety of stu dents if they were allowed to return to campus.

title: COSTELLO QUITS RACE FOR SENATE
description: Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello withdrew yesterday as the Liberal party candidate for United States Senator and urged his party to endorse Sen ator Charles E. Goodell, the Republican who is seeking elec tion to a full term.

title: ARMY MAY TRY FIVE ON MUTINY CHARGES
description: PLEI DJERENG, South Viet nam, May 8 (AP)The Army said today that it was consid ering courtmartial proceedings against five American soldiers who allegedly refused to partic ipate in a combat assault into Cambodia. [In Saigon, military authorities professed no knowl edge of the incident.]

title: Roundup: Dodgers Profit On Grabarkewitz Injury
description: It was a painful night for Billy Grabarkewitz of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Bill Melton of the Chicago White Sox. The only difference was that the pain Grabarkewitz suffered wound up helping the Dodgers last night.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Army Routs Yale, 156
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 8 Pete McCall and Tom Peter son hit home runs today to pace a 17hit attack as Army routed Yale, 156, in an East ern League contest today.

title: Bill Rate Off in London
description: LONDON, May 8 (Reuters) The average rate of discount at today's tender of British treas ury bills fell to 6.776 per cent from 6.793 per cent last week.

title: 2 ExSS Men Imprisoned For Roles in War Crimes
description: ESSEN, West Germany, May 8 (Reuters)Two former Nazi SS warrant officers were sen tenced today to a total of 16 years for crimes committed at Dora  Mittlebau concentration camp.

title: NATION IS WARNED TO RETAIN ITS LEAD IN SCIENCE FIELDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The White House released today Presidential study group report that calls continuing leadership in science and technology a vi tal national goal.

title: 3 Soviet Naval Vessels Sighted Entering Caribbean
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 8 (Reuters)The United States Navy said today that three So viet naval vessels had entered the Caribbean west of Puerto Rico.

title: Purser Aboard France to Retire
description: For the last 33 years, Roger Joubert has been sail ing as a purser on French Line passenger ships, an oc cupation that involves a great deal of listening to passenger complaints.

title: MRS. OLIVER W. TOLL
description: Mrs. Merle d'Aubigne Toll, wife of Oliver W. Toll, a re tired Federal Chief Attorney, and mother of Dr. John S. Toll, president of the State Univer sity Center at Stony Brook, L. I., died yesterday of a heart attack in Neustift, Germany. Her age was 77 and her home was in Tolland, Colo.

title: CRISES FACTFINDERS URGED AT U.N. BY U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8  The United States has suggested the creation of a panel of United Nations factfinders who could be sent to the scene of impending crises to find out the facts as a means of averting the trouble.

title: Argentina Expects to Hit '70 Export Goal, Aide Says
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 8 (UPI) The Argentine economy and Labor Minister Jos Maria Dag nino Pastore said today the country expects to meet its goal of $1.8billion in exports in 1970.

title: Insurers Assail Lawyers For Fight on NoFault Plan
description: The American Insurance As sociation, a group representing large publicly owned insurers who favor Governor Rockefel ler's nofault automobile insur ance program, challenged the legal profession yesterday to propose its own plan if it didn't like the Governor's.

title: Hickel Lauds President For Remarks on Youth
description: WASHINGTON, May S (AP)Secretary of the In terior Walter J. Hickel to night praised President Nix on's news conference re marks about the nation's youth.

title: Cambodia Seeking Help on Refugees
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 8Security officials said today that they would welcome a largescale effort by the South Vietnamese Navy up the Mekong River to evacuate Vietnamese residents from Pnompenh.

title: Steve Reich Presents a Program Of Pulse Music at Guggenheim
description: Listen. Unless you live in a rorklined room like Proust, chances are good that at the moment you read this, if you prick up your cars, you will hear two or more motors throb bing away, each in its indi vidual, fixed pattern. Aircon ditioner heating against refrig erator, ticking clock syncopat ing against hanging radiator, and so on For some reason. probably related to the fact that your own engine, the heart, is simultaneously pump ing away at its own peculiar rate, your car will inevitably try to discover an overriding pulse or even a rhythma rhumba, maybe.

title: HitandRun Driver Leaves Misleading Note
description: SHAMOKIN, Pa. (PA) A hitandrun driver fooled several witnesses who saw him hit another automobile.

title: Aaron Zeroes In on 3,000th Hit
description: ATLANTA, May 9 (AP)Henry Louis Aaron, on the threshold of one of base ball's greatest achievements, says, I only hope it's a clean hit.

title: Past and present
description: Each room shown here in a North Carolina, 18th centurystyle house has undergone subtle but important changes since the owners moved in 40 years ago shortly after the house was built to their demanding specifica tions, which included handmade brick. Although the antique furniture remains the same, the walls and furnishings are freshened periodically. Colors and fab rics may be changed, but the Southern taste for warm, bright splashes of color remains

title: New Housing Units Up 5%
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)  The Government reported yesterday that 1,432,900 new housing units were completed in 1969, a 5 per cent increase over 1968.

title: Gallup Poll Finds 57% Support President on Cambodian Policy
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 9 A majority of Americans, 57 per cent, gave President Nixon a vote of confidence for his handling of the Presidency in a Gallup Poll survey conducted immediately after his April 30 speech in which he announced his decision to send United States troops into Cambodia.

title: Hamburg's Integrated Transportation System Is Viewed as a Model by Officials
description: Hamburg, West Germany May 9The citystate of Hamburg  West Germany's largest metropolitan area stretching 40 miles from one side to the otherhas be come a mecca for public transport officials from all over the world. They come to this North Sea port to see the world's first integrated transport community.

title: The Week in Finance:
Captain Cook's Discovery of Australia
description: CAPTAIN James Cook landed in Australia on April 29, 1770, after an eventful voyage from England aboard Endeavor. The 200th anniversary of that landing was observed by Eng land's Queen Elizabeth, Prince Philip and Princess Anne as the climax of their tour of South Pacific British areas on April 29.

title: INVENTION APPEARS AT FILLMORE EAST
description: There is a genius of some sort at work in the Mothers of Invention, but you have to sit through a fairly outrageous display to find it.

title: Prosecutor Gets Report On the Niarchos Autopsy
description: ATHENS, May 9The Athen's coroner's report on the post mortem performed on Mrs. Stay ros Niarchos, the Greek mil lionaire's wife who died last Monday, was submitted today to Constantine Fafoutis, the prosecutor in charge of the pre liminary investigation.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Department store sales in April registered a slight gain compared with the year be fore, despite the fact that Easter came in the last week of March this year as against the first week in April a year ago. Sales in the first week of April this year were substantially lower than in the corresponding week of 1969, but moderate gains ranging from 3 to 7 per cent in the ensuing weeks helped the stores to break even or go ahead by a fraction of 1 tier cent.

title: Packing for a Trip?
description: OUR timetables now read daylight saving time, and the lemming instinct of the great American tourist is rising like the sap in the flowering spring shrubbery, which makes this the appropriate time for a final word of advice to those travelers not so set in their ways that they cannot reorganize their luggage and their travel habits for their own and the general good.

title: Point of View
description: THE principle that mini mum standards of de cent, safe and sanitary housing must be im posed by governmentfor the benefit not so much of the individual tenant as of the whole communityhas been generally accepted ever since 19thcentury eyes were opened to the septic horors of the slums. Standards for New York City have been es tablished by law, attacked, defended, and gradually raised. Enforcement of these standards is another story.

title: The Boat Who Wouldn't Float
description: The best boats float. Ask Farley Mowat, who bought one that wouldn't. Oh, his floated all right, after he'd had her hauled from the muck of a Newfoundland harbor and re built her somewhat (from stem to stern, that is); but there was something about the Happy Ad venture (sic) that made her more interesting than most pleasure craft (sic). She loved to fill herself with water and head for the bottom. Perhaps she really wanted to be a sub marine. God knows, she tried often enough, the miracle being that Mr. Mowat lived to tell the tale.

title: Of Banyans, Missionaries And Resorts
description: LAHAINA, Maui, HawaiiThe mid day sun is hot, but it's cool and pleasant in the shade of what he sign says is the world's big gest banyan tree. The banyan, like a gargantuan creeper, extends long limbs and aerial roots in all directions, and this one covers about a quarteracre.

title: Tours, Talks and Shows
description: THE Three Village Garden Club of Stony Brook, Setauket and Old Field will hold its annual tour of homes and gardens on Saturday from 1 to 5:30 P. M. Five homes exemplifying the Early Amer ican character will be open. There will also be a horticul tural exhibit at the Garden Club Sanctuary in Setauket and a plant sale on the Vil lage Green. Tickets are $2.50 and may be purchased at the Garden Club Exchange, Three Village Inn, Stony Brook, N.Y. Proceeds will benefit the club's scholarship fund.

title: Score on Blackmun: 17 too
description: It looks as though Presi dent Nixon  who failed twice before  will finally get a Supreme Court justice to fill the seat Abe Fortas resigned a year ago. Tomor row afternoon, if all goes as expected, the Senate will con firm the President's nomina tion of Judge Harry A. Blackmun, a 61yearold Min nesotan who now sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir cuit.

title: MAYOR TO ASK RISE IN SANITATIONMEN
description: Mayor Lindsay plans to rec ommend thatt he city hire 1,400 additional sanitationmen during the fiscal year that begins July 1, at a cost of $17.5million.

title: BRITISH UNIT BARS CURBS ON POLICE
description: LONDON, May 9An offi vial advisory committee has rejected changes in a British, law that allows policemen to stop and search drug suspects but urged that people not be harrassed merely because they are wearing long hair, uncon ventional clothes or heads.

title: 71 CIVILIANS KILLED IN VIETNAM ATTACKS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 (Reuters)A Govern ment spokesman announced today that 71 civilians have been killed and 78 wounded in Vietcong attacks in Northern areas of the country since Thursday.

title: MOOD IS CHANGING AT BRONX SCIENCE
description: A few years ago, when the Bronx High School of Science was a sanctuary of placidity amid the city's blackboard jungle, teachers there some times boasted of the worst problems they had with stu dents:

title: Criminals At Large
description: On May 1 In New York, the Mystery Writers of America, some 300 strong at the annual awards banquet, passed out the honors for 1969 in a variety of criminous categories. Dick Francis's Forfeit (Harper Row) was pronounced the best mystery novel of the year. Re ceiving scrolls as runnersup were Dorothy Salisbury Davis for Where the Dark Streets Go (Scribner's), Shaun Herron for Miro (Random), Chester Himes for Blind Man With a Pistol (Morrow), Emma Lath en for When in Greece (Si mon & Schuster) and Peter Dickinson for The Old English Peep Show (Harper & Row). The latter was my personal choice and the winner of the top award from England's Crime Writers Association (the second year running Mr. Dick inson has been so recognized by the C.W.A.).

title: Author's Query
description: I am writing an account of the life and philosophy of my uncle, Elbert Hubbard (1856 1915), American writer, editor, publisher and lecturer, and would appreciate receiving let ters and other items of interest.

title: MISS CONWAY GIVES DANCE SERIES TWO
description: Sheer disciplined dance ener gy can often carry a limited choreographic conception across arid spots and did in Two on Friday night. It was presented by Carol Conway in New York for the first time as part of the ChoreoconcertsWorkshop Spring Series at St. Peter's Church. Miss Conway and Su san Cherniak moved in tight formation in a pattern of diago nals and circles alternating brusque and deliberately slow movements with knowing skill.

title: In Memoriam
description: GREENBERGLouis H., May 11, 1936. Beloved and devoted father. Always re membered, always cherished. DOROTHY HAUSMAN and MARTIN

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: Channel 4: What Makes a Good Teacher? with Dr. Hans Rosenhaupt, president, Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation, Prince ton, on Dorothy Gordon's Youth Forum. 12:30 P.M.

title: Home Furnishings Industry in Hope and Despair
description: In the home furnishings in dustry, following the end of trade shows at which fall merchandise was shown to retailers, there were some bitter comments last week about the psychological blue funk into which consumers have fallen.

title: Sweepida Is Dead at 33
description: STOCKTON, Calif., May 9 (AP)Sweepida, winner of the Santa Anita Derby in 1940, is dead at the age of 33. Sweepida earned more than $100,000

title: Religion
description: Three years ago Frederick Walz, a semirecluse lawyer who rarely emerges by day from his fourroom apartment In the Bronx, purchased a weedchoked 22by29 foot plot of land near a Staten Island junk yard for $100. Shortly afterwards Mr. Walz filed suit against the New York City Tax Commission, charging that the $5.24 he paid in prop erty taxes was unduly high be cause tax exemptions granted to church property forced him to contribute to religious groups against his will.

title: Bells in the Woodlands
description: MAY is the month for bells, when wild flowers with characteristic bellshapes appear. They can be found in open woods and thickets, beside shaded streams, along old fence lines. They are the solomon's seals, the bellworts, the mandarins and clintonias with yellow or greenyellow flowers. Additional colors are provided by the pink mandarins, blue Greek va lerians and Virginia bluebells.

title: PREAKNESS LOOMS
description: Stubbornness earned Hagley of the Hickory Tree Stable the victory in the $59,700 Withers mile at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: The Florence Few Americans Have Ever Seen
description: FLORENCE, Italy  In a jewelry shop on the Ponte Vecchio, a prizewinning designer draws a gold lion, sketches in two emer ald eyes and adds a few diamond teeth. In a leather shop on Via Montebello, a tall young man, moviestar handsome, spreads a tissuethin sheet of gold on the lid of a redleather box and then presses against it a metal stamp with a fleur de lis design ....

title: Canaan College Saved
description: CANAAN, N. H., May 9 (AP) Canaan College has rescinded its plan to close next month be cause it has affiliated with the Florida Institute of Technology. Dr. Charles Cummings, who will become the school's new presi dent June 30, said Tuesday that a student publicity campaign had resulted in the agreement.

title: Moves in Congress To Curb Power of President
description: WASHINGTON  For all the talk in recent years about re storing the warmaking powers of Congress, nobody, not even the ardent champions of Con gressional authority on the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee, ever really expected that Congress would take any spe cific steps to curb the powers of the President at Commander inChief.

title: Mercury Climbs to 90, Sending Many Outdoors
description: New Yorkers by the thou sands flocked to parks and beaches in the metropolitan area yesterday in an exodus from sweltering apartments and asphalt streets on the warmest day of the year.

title: Battle of Faubuses Stirs Arkansas
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ark., May 8 The voters of Arkansas are titil lated over the prospect of choosing between former Gov. Orval E. Faubus and his former wife, Alta, for the Democratic nomination for Governor this summer.

title: MICHENER OFFERS AID TO RACIAL PROGRAMS
description: James Michener, the novelist, says he will give $100,000 over a fiveyear period to Swarth more College, his alma mater, for blackstudies and racerela tions programs.

title: Is It Necessary to Spray?
description: THE nation is going through a much need ed period of environ mental awareness in which many questions are be ing asked, among them how necessary are cretain chemi cals to our own welfare? There seems  no doubt that many of the garden chemi cals now is use can cause irreversable damage to the environment when used im properly. In the final analy sis, people are the polluters and not necessarily chemi cals per se. This seems to apply to giant corporations as well as backyard putter ers. Conversely, technology and ecology can be compat ble and when the proper garden chemicals are used in accordance with labelled di rections, by responsible indi viduals, the net results can only be positive. apply to giant corporations as well as backyard putter ers. Conversely, technology and ecology can be compat ble and when the proper garden chemicals are used in accordance with labelled di rections, by responsible indi viduals, the net results can only be positive.

title: Curb on Pollution For a Great Lake
description: The Federal Water Quality Administration, which has the responsibility for developing rules and regulations to control pollution in the nation's rivers and lakes, had a surprise for conservationists last week. The conservationists have been plead ing for some controls over ther mal pollution in Lake Michigan the dumping of hot water into the lake which could raise the lake's temperature and thereby irreparably harm marine life. And they came to a Lake Michi gan Enforcement Conference in Chicago determined to renew the battle.

title: Purchasing Agents See Difficulties
description: The wildcat trucking strike is having its effect on the ability of purchasing agents to obtain goods according to the National Association of Purchasing Management. Inc.

title: Charges in Coops May Vary Widely
description: THE morning sun reflecting off the East River in a glorious golden blaze has at least one odd, un pleasant effect on the owners of co operative apartments in the East Tower at 870 United Nations Plaza.

title: Child to the Changs
description: LLOYD HARBOR, L. I., May 9A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs, David PC Chang of Lloyd Harbor and East. Barnard, Vt., on April 27 in Huntington Gen eral Hospital.

title: Army, Admitting an Error, Reverses a CourtMartial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 (AP)The Army, admitting a technical error, has given an honorable discarge to a lieu tenant who had been court marshialed for refusing to go to Vietnam.

title: The Hip Baroness Wootton Of Abinger
description: LONDON. IN January of 1969, a report to the British Government sug gested that the penalties attached to the use of marijuana be substan tially reduced. There followedin side and outside Parliamenta co lossal outcry against what came to be called the Junkies' Charter.

title: Theater: An Evening With Gordone
description: GORDONE IS A MUTH AH, which was per formed Friday night at Car negie Recital Hall, is almost a oneman show. Playwright, actor, Pulitzer Prizewinner Charles Gordone is assisted by Marge Eliot and Julius Harris (both from his No Place to Be Somebody) and they are occasionally accom panied by a bass player. But all of the words and most of the acting is by Gordone.

title: The Taste of Abalone, Pleasing Alike to Man and Otter, Has Conservationists and Fisheries at Odds
description: MORRO BAY, Calif.In San Francisco, a waterfront diner raises a bite of the ?? delicately flavored she?? to his mouth and chews dreamily as he gazes out at the boats bobbing in the swells.

title: Linda Ann Daniels Is Engaged To Fred B. Finley, Realty Man
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., May 9Mr. and Mrs. Richard DeVoe Daniels of West Hart ford and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Linda Ann Daniels, to Fred Butler Finley. He is the son of James D. Finley, board chair man of J. P. Stevens & Co., textile manufacturers, and Mrs. Finley of Red Bank, N. J. The future bride's father is president of the Richard Dan iels Cadillac Company in Hartford.

title: Brewers Top Senators
description: MILWAUKEE, May 9 (AP) Ted Kubiak drove in the win ning run with a basesloaded, twoout single in the 10th in ning today as the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Washing ton Senators, 32.

title: Miss McKisson Engaged to Wed Hunter Marvel
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, May 9 Mr. and Mrs. John Clay Mc Kisson have announced the engagement of their daugh ter. Miss Camilla Sutherland McKisson. to Hunter Marston Marvel, son of Mrs. Howard B. MacAdams of New York and Robert Marvel of Green ville, Del.

title: The Delightsand Costs  Of Buying a Car in Europe
description: LIKE many American travelers, you have probably thought about buying a car the next time you go to Europe. Before succumbing to the tempta tion, however, you should give careful thought to the pros and cons of picking up an automobile overseas.

title: SelfMade Surgeon
description: ROME, May 9 (Reuters) Dario Martini, a medical stu dent, was sentenced to 9 months and 20 days in jail here today after a 7year mas querade as a surgeon, during which he performed hundreds of successful operations.

title: NO. 1 FOR KOOSMAN
description: Jerry Koosman, who had suf fered through six games this season without winning, saw a remarkable and comforting thing yesterday afternoon in Shea Stadium: the New York Mets scored eight runs for him in the fifth inning against the San Francisco Giants.

title: DEVREX, $3.80, WINS TROPICAL PARK RACE
description: MIAMI, May 9 (AP)F. P. Dyer's favored Devrex cap tured the $10,000 Key Biscayne Handicap at Tropical Park today.

title: RACE AT LOUISVILLE TO GALLANT MOMENT
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 9 AP)Circle M. Farm's Gallant Moment galloped to a five length victory in the Louisville Handicap today at Churchill Downs. The triumph broke the fouryear reign of Mrs. Joe W. Brown's horses in the race.

title: Long Island Line Clears the Tracks For Excursionists
description: THE Long Island Railroad, emerging from a winter of discontent for its thousands of commuters because of frequent poor and erratic service, is ready once again to make up for its lapses with a summer of leisurely travel. For the 15th consecutive year, the world's busiest commuter line has prepared a cornucopia of weekend, holiday and weekday excursions to scenic, cultural and historic sites on Long Island and in Connecticut.

title: Young Manhattanite Finds Happiness in Woodside
description: FOR many people Manhattan is New New York City. In their view only Manhattan reflects the sophistica tion and prestige, the glamour and ex citement, the fame and fortune tradi tionally associated with the City. For one groupmainly people in their early 20's and recent college gradsManhat tan is where the action is, and so where they must live.

title: Article 4  No Title
HARNESS REPORTERS TO HONOR OVERCALL
description: Mrs. Helen R. Buck's Over call, who finished his racing career with 22 straight vic tories, has been selected as the winner of the New York har ness writers' 1969 Achieve ment Award. Mrs. Buck, of Fat Hills, N. J., will receive the trophy during the New York chapter's annual dinnerdance at Yonkers Raceway next Sun day.

title: Point of View
description: I am optimistic for those companies on our [textile] industry that are strongly marketoriented and have diversified and expanded into growth fields. These companies have the flexibil ity to be able to respond quickly to the changing de mands of the consumer. We have seen, in recent years, significant changes in our in dustry, requiring an alert ness in anticipating and meeting the challenge of the changing market conditions.

title: Naked I Leave
description: There is a kind of furor scri bendi about Michael Novak. Long, lively articles in the re ligious journals and a set of books about the events of the Second Vatican Council and the resultant state of the church attest to the energy of his search for order. There is some suspicion that industry has diluted quality, even that none of his recent books has come up to his excellent Belief and Unbelief. No matter. The book in hand is a novel  and so must be considered apart from the mainstream of Novak's works. His first novel. The Tiber Was Silver, was the story of a young man's (clear ly Novak's) religious selfdisci pline and his final exodus from the noonday fervor of the sem inarist's vocation to the paint er's hour of modern Rome. It did not receive the notice its sensitive and breathing pages deserved.

title: Beyond Apollo 13
description: With the hazardous jour ney of Aquarius fresh in our memories, the question which everyone must now ask is: What human inter ests are served by the con tinuation of manned space flights?

title: General Visits G.L's in Fishhook
description: PHUOCVINH, South Viet nam, May 8 Troops are just like children, they need praise, to be told when they are doing a good job, Brig. Gen. Robert M. Shoemaker said here today at the base of the First Cavalry Division (Ai rmobile).

title: News Summary and Index
description: A crowd of between 75,000 and 100,000, drawn mostly from the nation's campuses, demonstrated peaceably near the White House yesterday. After the rally ended, small bands of militants crashed through barricades on nearby streets, disrupting traffic and throwing missiles. The police used tear gas to break up the most threaten ing crowds. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Ilonka Tumelairs to Wed June 13
description: ACTON, Mass., May 9 Miss Ilonka Johanna Tume laire plans to be married here June 13 to Shelton Pitney 3d, greatgrandson of Mahlon Pitney and great greatgrandson of Joseph P. Bradley, both Associate Jus tices of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Agnew Mellow in Talk Hailing Confederate Heroes
description: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga., May 9Honoring the heroes of the Confederacy but quoting Wood row Wilson, Vice President Ag new came to Georgia today to dedicate the granite carvings of Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jack son and Jefferson Davis.

title: Ballet at Met to Benefit Hebrew Arts School
description: The Scholarship Fund of the Hebrew Arts School for Music and Dance will benefit from a gala champagne din ner at the Grand Tier Res taurant at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday, to be followed by the Ameri can premiere of the Royal Ballet's The Ropes of Time with Rudolf Nureyev. The other ballets on the program are La Bayadere and Birthday Offering.

title: William Niles Marries Ann Boughton Thorne
description: The marriage of Miss Ann BoughtonThorne to William Freeman Niles took place here yesterday afternoon in the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev, Walter Kring, assisted by the Rev. Richard Kuenkler, performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: And Then 150 Arrows Will Go Thunk! Thunk!
description: DAN CURTIS has a fantasy that even the busiest analyst in town would surely drop everything to get to work on. Curtis dreams of killing a whole lot of people. Soon. And horribly.

title: Article 9  No Title
As Spiro Agnew Sees It
description: [A constitutional republic] cannot for ever withstand continual carnival in the streets of its cities and the campuses of the nation. Unless sage debate replaces the bel ligerent strutting now used so extensively, reason will be consumed and the death of logic will surely follow.May 3, 1969.

title: TRUDEAU OFF TODAY FOR FAR EAST TOUR
description: OTTAWA, May 9  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau will leave by plane tomorrow on a threeweek Pacific tour to demonstrate Canada's rising in terest in the Far East.

title: BERKELEY FACULTY OPPOSES U.S. TIES
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 9 The Berkeley Faculty Senate contends that the relationship between the University of Cali fornia and the two nuclear research laboratories it oper ates for the Government is antithetical to the purposes of a university dedicated to free exchange of knowledge.

title: Elizabeth Gerard Is Wed
description: RUMSON, N. J., May 9 Miss Elizabeth Jean Louise Marie Gerard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henri Gerard of Brussels, was married here this afternoon to Pfc. Hayden Smith Jr., U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Locust, N. J.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: We believe that President Nixon's recent actions in Indo china constitute a disastrous and indefensible reescalation of the war. We do not think that any tactical, shortterm advan tages could possibly justify the catastrophic reversal of Ameri can policy since 1968, and we condemn his reckless disregard of the effects of his futile poli cies abroad on the fabric of our life at home.

title: Miss Barbara Wilcox Fiancee Of G. M. Thompson Jr., Banker
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 9 Miss Barbara Wilcox, who expects to be graduated from the University of Colorado on May 23, and Gerard M. Thompson Jr., a 1967 grad uate of Yale, plan to be married here on June 13.

title: Article 6  No Title
A Wide Swath Through Time
description: ORION Records is a small West Coast company, concentrating largely on musicians of the area, but In a recent release of four disks it manages to cut a wide swath through time. One disk is devoted to four keyboard Sonatas by the 18thcentury composer Fried rich Wilhelm Rust (ORS 7023), while another includes contemporary works involv ing tape, Ralph Swickard's Sermons of Saint Francis and Hymn of Creation and Ken neth Heller's Labyrinth (ORS 7021).

title: NIXON TOO ALOOF, OFFICIALS CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, May 9. The White House has paid damned little attention to our report or to working with those who wrote it, a member of the staff of the National Commis sion on the Causes and Pre vention of Violence asserted recently.

title: Dutch Elm Fight Aided
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) A $1,000 research grant to help find ways to control Dutch Elm Disease has ben made to Ohio State University by the Agriculture Department.

title: In Praise Of Colombia's Salt Cathedral
description: BOGOTA, Colombia  Gabriel Garcia Marquez, whose One Hundred Years of Solitude (just published in the United States) is the most discussed novel in Latin America these days, recently confided to a columnist on Bogota's El Tiempo that, in the four years he spent as a student in the nearby town of Zipaquira, the thing that gave him the most satisfaction was that he had never visited the Salt Cathedral.

title: Welfare: Not Going According To the Script
description: WASHINGTON  The Nixon Administration's pioneering ef fort to establish a minimum so ciallyacceptable income level for poor families has run aground in what had previously been regarded as wellcharted and untroubled waters: the Sen ate Finance Committes.

title: NASSAU IS SEEKING HALFWAY HOUSES
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 9  Three halfway houses to be used as alternatives to incarce ration of young people convict ed of crimes was proposed this week by the Nassau County Crime Council.

title: Recordings
description: THERE was a time when it seemed that Ameri can popular music like Coca Cola, Lucky Strikes and the DC3would conquer the known world. Someone even came up with the utterly bizarre fact that there wasn't a minute during the day when a Bing Crosby record wasn't being played, somewhere.

title: An Award For the Trauma Of Bias
description: Like many another black American, the Rev. William Gray, senior minister of the Baptist Church of Montclair, N.J., has not always found it easy to find a decent place for his family to live. But when Serruto Builders, Inc., of Montclair advertised an apartment in 1967 which seemed to meet all his needs, he decided to try to rent it. At the office of the builders he was met with a familiar rebuff. The apartment, he was told, had already been rented.

title: ROLE OF NEGROES IN RALLY SMALL
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Stepping across several white youths sprawled on the grass near the Ellipse, Reginald Wil son, a 19yearold Negro, ex plained the paucity of black participants in the antiwar rally.

title: The Apartado: Last Hurrah Before the Ole!
description: SALAMANCA, SpainShort of turn ing matador, the closest an aspiring aficionado can get to the fighting bulls in Spain is by attending an apartado, the backstage ritual at which the animals are selected for the day's corrida (bullfight). It is an exciting, colorful event that is open to the public, but it is virtually unknown to tourists.

title: Exiles
description: One of the queerest things in the world is the way talent can wane. It's one of the saddest too, of course, for the gifted man who feels his power dwindling, but overall, it's the sheer oddity of it that's so arresting. How is it that someone who, one fine day, seems to catch and reflect the glinting world around so that the picture he makes of it enchants all eyes  how is it that on another day, 10 years later, 20 years later, he has nothing to say? Or when he speaks, he seems so outofdate, so wrongheaded and uncomprehend ing and irrelevant, that we groan and refuse to listen.?

title: Article 12  No Title
CRAMPTON AHEAD BY TWO WITH 209
description: HOUSTON, May 9A drive out of bounds and a triple bogey 7 failed to deter Bruce Crampton of Australia in the third round of the $115,000 Houston Champions interna tional golf tournament today.

title: Teacher Quits in Homosexual Dispute
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 9A teacher who created a contro versy in Phoenix by inviting a homosexual to speak to her so ciology students charged today that members of her profession generally are quick to judge a person negatively, based on sur face impressions.

title: The Politicians
description: Booth Mooney might have used as a subtitle for The Politicians the tagline on the package of a popular cigarette: 'there's something about them you'll like. It is logical. The author is a newspaperman and newspapermen are, as a class, addicted to politicians. At worst, politicians are amusing frauds, preferable to shysters, quacks and Elmer Gantrys (who are pompous frauds), but with whom the gentlemen of the press are forced to asso ciate professionally.

title: Long Island A.C. Trounces Philadelphia in Lacrosse
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 9 The Long Island Athletic Club, defending champion of the United States Club Lacrosse Association, remained in first place in the northern division by walloping the Philadelphia Club, 174, today at Hofstra University.

title: Dominican Police Kill Two As Election Unrest Mounts
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, May 9 (Reuters) Policemen shot two men to death with machine guns today in the latest in a series of kill ings in the Dominican Republic where tension is high, only a week before the May 16 presi dential election.

title: U.S. Chemical Exports Rise
description: Japanese imports of chemi cals from the United States in creased 25 per cent in 1969, to a value of $304million, accord ing to the United States Japan Trade Council, the magazine Chemical Week reports. Amer ican imports of Japanese chem icals last year totaled $121 million.

title: TEXANS SEEK END TO U.S. FOOD ROLE
description: DALLAS, May 9A suit filed in Federal Court here has asked that the task of distributing free food to the poor in Texas coun ties be removed from the Gov ernment and turned over to a federally funded private organi zation.

title: Viondrian's View With a Room
description: INSPECTING the Mondrian roomthe most unusual and interesting feature of the current Mondrian ex hibition at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Streetis like ly to raise a few mental or esthetic reservations. The room10 by 12 by 14 feet in sizeis a new threedim ensional rendering of an old twodimension sketch. Orgin ally designed by the Dutch NeoPlasticist artist in 1926 as Salon for Madame B.it was never executed during his lifetime. For the current exhibition it has been made to order by the Formica Cor poration in laminated plastic with an overall design of the primary colored rectangles supplemented by black, white and gray that were the trade mark for Mondrian's austere and difficult art.

title: GARELIK WOULD AID PRENATAL ADDICTS
description: Efforts to help the most piti ful victims of drug addiction babies who, born to addicted mothers, are addicted them selveswere urged yesterday by City Council. President San ford D. Garelik.

title: Country Folk Crowd Dublin Farm Show
description: DUBLIN, May  The writer Brendan Behan called them Horse Protestants, and this was their week as they came up from the country, along with simpler folk, for the agricultural event of the year, the Royal Dublin Society's Spring Show.

title: Letters
Quotes
description: R. P. CLINTON, president of an oil company planning to build a refinery at Bruns wick, Ga.: We are going to pollute. It's only a question of how much. But, I think, with proper marketing and proper construction we're not going to pollute this area. What we're going to do is contribute to the pollution of the world.

title: IRISH PARLIAMENT APPROVES CABINET
description: DUBLIN, May 9 (Reuters) Prime Minister John Lynch to day won approval of Ireland's parliament for his new Cabinet.

title: Poly Prep Wins Track Title As Montrose Takes 3 Firsts
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 9  Lennex Montrose won three events and set the lone meet record today in pacing Poly Prep to the team title in the 25th annual Ivy Prep School League track and field cham pionships at Hofstra University.

title: OPPOSITION URGES NEW LESOTHO VOTE
description: MASERU, Lesotho, May 9 The leader of the oposition in this small black nation in south ern Africa confirmed today that he had agreed to disregard the election last January that be asserts he won. But he in sisted that Prime Minister Le abua Jonathan call new elec tions as soon as possible, or within a year.

title: Business Index Rose in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 352.2 from 350.6 a week earlier. A year ago it was 341.0.

title: Touring the Kennedys House on the Potomaca Private View
description: MCLEAN, Va., May 9Most days at the Edward M. Ken nedys' new house, the quiet is broken only by the roar of the Potomac splashing over the great rocks and the laughter of the children playing on the trampoline.

title: Knick Championship Culminates 24 Frustrating Years
description: Today it is a simple, indelible fact: the New York Knicker bockers are champions of the National Basketball Association, and therefore the highest ranked basketball team on Earth. But it didn't become fact until Friday evening, May 8, 1970, when in such exhili rating and melodramatic cir cumstances, the Knicks crushed the Los Angeles Lakers, 11399, at Madison Square Garden.

title: ERDMAN PROGRAM SPANS 2 DECADES
description: Jean Erdman offered some thing of a retrospective of her choreography at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Friday night where the Jean Erdman Theater of Dance presented four dances, ranging from The Perilous Chapel (1949) to a world premiere and a local premiere.

title: Television
description: CHARLES J. CURRAN, the new DirectorGen eral of the British Broadcasting Corpora tion, is a man with a refresh ing outlook on many familiar problems of television both here and abroad. During a recent stay here. Curran, who succeeded Sir Hugh Greene as active head of Britain's noncommercial broadcasting organization, naturally es chewed dabbling in the af fairs of the country in which he was a visitor, but his opinions clearly had an inter osting domestic applicability.

title: Police Assailed by Mayor On Laxity at Peace Rally
description: While Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary sat grim faced at his left, Mayor Lind say charged yesterday that New Yorkers had witnessed breakdown of the police as the barrier between them and wan ton violence on Friday.

title: OneWorld Trading Seen
description: In the not too distant future, there will he one world market operating on 24houraday basis dealing around the clock in securities and commodities from all over the world.

title: Hungary's Ikka Helps Westerners
description: BUDAPEST, May 9  Ikka is the acronym assigned to a bustling little private exportimport business here that finds more customers in the United States than in any other country.

title: Frustration Is Mounting in Italy As Chessboard Strikes Go On
description: ROME, May 9A traveler motoring on the superb auto strada across the gentle bills of Tuscany gets hungry and pulls up at a roadside inn, only to see a sign, ClosedStrike.

title: Pakistani Court Sentences Leftist Politician to 7 Years
description: KARACHI Pakistan May 9 A military court today sen tenced Masihur Rahman, a leader of a proPeking faction of the leftwing Awami party to seven years at hard labor.

title: Job Changes:
description: Mrs. G. G. Michelson has been appointed vsenior vice president in charge of labor relations and consumer rela tions and Alfred P. Niemann has been named senior vice president, personnel at Macy's New York. Both will report to K. Wade Bennett executive vice president.

title: A Correction
description: The first trip in the annual summer program of excursions offered by the Long Island Railroad is scheduled for next Sunday, May 17, to Planting Fields, the estate of the late William R. Coe near Oyster Bay, and to the Bayard Cutting Arboretum, near Great River. It is erroneously reported in to day's Travel Section (Section 10, Page 24) that the trip would he held today.

title: Fate of Cambodia Now in Hands of Others
description: PNOMPENH  If the average Cambodian were not endowed with an unmatched gift for total serenity  some call it obvious ness in the face of dire adver sity, the people of Pnompenh would look worried. Their city is threatened from without and within, and a foreigner would like to know whether they are aware of it.

title: PENN STATE ROUTS ST. JOHN'S IN TRACK
description: Penn State's balanced track team humbled St. John's here yesterday, 11539. The Nittany Lions placed first in 15 of the 18 events.

title: POLICE IN LONDON HALT PROTESTERS
description: LONDON, May 9Five thou sand demonstrators protesting United States involvement in Vietnam marched on the United States Embassy today, struggled with the police, broke several car windows and then went home singing We'll Meet Again.

title: FINCH CRITICIZES AGNEW REMARKS
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Rob ert H.Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told student demonstrators today that the public rhetoric of Vice President Agnew and Gov. Ron ald Reagan of California had contributed to heating up the climate in which the Kent State students were killed.

title: ARMBRO HARVEY PACES A 1:5945
description: YONKERS, May 9Armbro Harvey posted the first sub twominute mile of the Yonkers Raceway spring meeting to night when he won the $15,000 White Plains Junior FreeFor All Pace in 1:5945 before a gathering of 27,613.

title: D. C. Taylor Weds Jeanne Carnevale
description: The marriage of Miss Jeanne Carnevale to D. Chris topher Taylor took place in the chapel of Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church yes terday morning. Capt. Vin cent Lonergan, a Navy chap lain, performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass.

title: Architecture
description: ON the bulletin board at Westbeth artists' hous ing, there are notices for karate, kittens, baby sitters, tenants' meet ings, day care petitions and announcements ranging from temperate to militant of the need for more work space for all. There are moving and settlingin pains, unfinished construction and delays in the provision of promised studios and storage. But be cause it is an artists' commu nity, the pangs and problems have already been documen ted in an allegory by a resi dent writer. Robert Paget.

title: Liberals' Choice May Swing State Races
description: The Liberal party, with only 100,000 enrolled members among New York State's 7 million Voters, has survived for 26 years on its wits, the wits of a brilliant politician named Alex Rose. In fact, some persons believe the Liberals are thrivinglast year the party's grateful candidate for Mayor was a rejected Re publican named John V. Lindsay and this year some formidable candidates from both major par ties have spent a lot of energy trying to win the Liberal nomina tion.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: As a friend and great ad mirer of Irving Howe, holding a similar political point of view  if anything a more nonviolent one  I am sad dened by his analysis of the present terrorism by the left (Political Terrorism: Hysteria on the Left, April 12).

title: New System Cuts Civil Court Backlog
description: The judge who administers the city's Civil Courts reported last week that the use of three judge teams had cut their case backlog in three months by 20, 000 and promised to make the court virtually current in two years.

title: Auto Racing Body Rejects Bid For a Second U.S. Grand Prix
description: SCRATCH one Grand Prix. The Commission Sportive Internationale, the competi tion arm of the Federation Internationale de l'Automo bile, declined the other day to approve a second Grand Prix of the United States for 1971. The C.S.I. rejected the pro posal because it had not been submitted in tune for the scheduled March meeting in Geneva. This seems chicken, but that's the way the Europeans run their store. The regular United States Grand Prix for For mula One cars is held in October at Watkins Glen, N. Y. Last week Ontario and the Sports Car Club of Amer ica proposed an additional race for May 2, 1971, at the new California facility. The proposal was endorsed by the Automobile Competition Com mittee for the United States (ACCUS), the American arm of the F.I.A., and relayed to the C.S.I. meeting in Florence.

title: In Memoriam
description: ST. GEORGEAlfredo. Always remembered with loving thoughts. Wife Sylvia

title: A Gigantic Ego Trip For Dennis Hopper?
description: THE actors were sitting on a rock, high in the Andes in Central Peru, strumming guitars, singing softly. It was Eden and the only other sounds were those of the birds. Den nis Hopper was also perched on this giant rock like some great bald eagle, watching and waiting. He was directing a scene from his new film, The Last Movie.

title: Pin Lanes Here Strike the British Fancy
description: The first thing about United States howling that impressed Mrs. Eunice Grant were the long lines of lanes, such as the 48 strung in a row at Madison Square Garden.

title: U. of Maine Dissent Channeled Through Student Government
description: ORONO, Me., May 9  The Flag is back at the top of its tall steel pole today, catching sunlight in a gentle May breeze above the old iron cannon aimed impotently at the Stillwater River from the shady front lawns of the University of Maine's campus here.

title: Mark Spiegel to Wed Barbara Ellen Cohen
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 9 Mr. and Mrs. Bernard O. Cohen have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Barbara Ellen Co. hen, to Mark Alexander Spie gel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Spiegel of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Prague Liberation Parade Boycotted by U.S. Envoys
description: PRAGUE, May 9 (AP)The Czechoslovak Army paraded missiles, big guns and tanks today at a Liberation Day cere mony boycotted by United States diplomatic and military representatives in Prague.

title: Education
description: The campus dissension that erupted over the Cambodia is Sve and the Kent State Univer sity slayings led to a new role for university presidents last week as spokesmen for the stu dents in their strained dialogue with the Government.

title: Marcia Willis Engaged
description: WAYZATA, Minn., May 9 Miss Marcia Jean Willis and Paul Warren Frankel will be married May 23 in the Appleton Chapel of Har vard University.

title: A.H.L. PLAYOFF
KLASSY POPPY FIRST AT SUFFOLK ON RALLY
description: BOSTON, May 9 (AP)Harry Minassian's Klassy Poppy surged from last place in a field of seven to win the $22,725 My Fair Lady Stakes today at Suffolk Downs.

title: Devereux Worked Tirelessly For NationalHis First Love
description: WALTER DEVEREUX would never hold still to hear a complimentary word said about him. He was modest to a fault.

title: Good for Gourmets
description: THE sweetest, mildest onion is the leek. (Al lium porrum) a fleshy scallion, tall and stately. Its leavesblades in stead of the hollow tubes of some onions  droop like plumes. Welsh warriors wore leeks for identification in sixthcenutry battle (which they won), and the vegetable is now the emblem of Wales.

title: To Copy a Paper in RussiaXerox It
description: Xerox copying and duplica ting equipment is finding in creasing use in the Soviet Union and other Communist nations.

title: Crisis of Leadership
description: America, in the spring of 1970, has become a nation of doubts, fears and recriminations. The once magic New World faith in a better future has fallen victim to a war that, despite all official rhetoric, cannot be won.

title: WORLD CHAMPION GAINS POLE BERTH
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 9  The Grand Prix of Monaco used to be a simple affair  take the best racing drivers in the world and match them against a narrow, twist ing, hilly course that reduces their Formula One cars to pedestrian speeds.

title: Leslie M. Hailand to Be Married
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., May 9  Miss Leslie Meacham Hailand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Garfield Hailand Jr., and Thomas Glynn Walker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker of New Vernon, N. J., plan to be married on June 13.

title: Louisiana Governor Sues Life Over a Mafia Article
description: BATON ROUGE, La., May 9 (AP)Gov. John J. McKeithen of Louisiana filed a $10million libel suit yesterday against Life magazine in connection with an article that said a Mafia leader controlled state government in Louisiana. The suit was filed in State District Court.

title: The Rest Is Done With Mirrors
description: There are only two hundred people in the world, muses one of the principals here. The rest is done with mirrors. If you think about the aphorism for a few seconds it will evap orate, as does almost every thing else in this miasma of impressions, confessions and fantasy.

title: ST. PAUL'S PREP TO ADMIT COEDS
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 9 The rector of St. Paul's School said today the 115yearold all male boarding institution will become coeducational, possibly in January of 1971.

title: 76 Students Held in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 (AP)The South Vietnamese police today arrested 76 high school and college students who tried to occupy the Ministry of Education building in Saigon. The students were protesting the closing of their schools by the Government and continued detention of student leaders.

title: Taft: A Name And an Issue Spell Victory
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  A week ago Robert Taft Jr., the shy, mildmannered Congressman who represents the Cincinnati area, lost his temper in public. The sixfoot 53yearold patri cian was debating Gov. James A. Rhodes in the crowded grand ballroom of the SheratonCleve land Hotel. He shouted repeat edly at the burly Governor, called him a liar, and rose to his feet in a fingershaking demonstration of emotion after Mr. Rhodes questioned his in tegrity, his dedication to duty and his allegiance to the Nixon Administration.

title: BALTIMORE STRING REACHES 5 GAMES
description: BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles, held hit less by Tommy John for five innings today, scored four runs off the Chicago lefthander in the sixth after an error by Gail Hopkins and went on to defeat the White Sox. 43 for their fifth straight victory.

title: BOOK PUBLISHERS ACT AGAINST WAR
description: A group of executives and editorial employes of many of the nation's leading publishing houses has started a protest movement against the war in Indochina through a sustained campaign and lobbying in Con gress.

title: SHOEMAKER ABOARD 2 DIVISION WINNERS
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 9 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker, held to only one winner in two weeks, made a smashing return to form today when he captured both $44,175 divisions of the Argonaut Stakes at Hollywood Park with Western Welcome and Colorado King Jr.

title: Mighty Knicks: N.B.A. Champions and New York's Newest Sports Heroes
description: Returned to pro basketball this season after a twoanda halfyear absence because of heart attack ... His speed and sturdy 6foot7inch frame make him a valuable player on offense and defense . . . Like Russell, can turn a game around with explosive scoring bursts, a perfect reserve per former with a fine attitude....

title: Penney Predicts More Expansion
description: The J. C. Penney Company has announced that its an nual store expansion program through 1974 will equal or exceed the average of more than five million square feet for the last three yetrs. For this year the big retail chain already has announced plans to increase store space by ahout six million gross Squnits feet.

title: The Papers Of Dwight David Eisenhower
description: In 1963 Dwight Eisenhower made arrangements with The Johns Hop kins University for the editing and publication of his papers and, from that time until his death, showed the keenest interest In the work of those charged with locating, collating, se lecting and annotating the documents that were to appear, reading them carefully and making comments on many of them. If be were still alive, he would doubtless be pleased with the first tangible results of these collective labors, and he would have every reason to be so.

title: ONEDAY GOLF WON BY MRS. CHADSEY
description: During the last week, three Women's Golf Associations opened their seasons with one day tournaments.

title: New Publisher Named
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 9 (AP)Gerald T. Tache, gen eral manager of The New Bed ford StandardTimes, has been named publisher of the after noon daily and Sunday news paper, effective July 1. He will continue to serve as general manager. The announcement was made Monday by James H. Ottaway Jr., present publisher of The StandardTimes, who to become president of Ottaway Newspapers, which will be a wholly owned subsidiary of Dow Jones and Company, Inc., under a merger reported Monday.

title: Crime Jury in Jersey City Calls Whelan and Aides
description: JERSEY CITY, May 9Mayor Thomas J. Whelan, seven leading officials of his administration and one county official have been subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury that is inves tigating crime and alleged corruption in Hudson County.

title: How Nixon Made the Fateful Cambodia Decision
description: WASHINGTON  During his campaign for the Presidency, Richard Nixon stopped in Dallas one October night and, in a local television interview, offered a preview summary of how foreign policy was to be run under his dispensation.

title: RCA Announces Service Center
description: The RCA Corporation has named its new service organ ization Service America and plans to open its first service center in the Philadelphia area by midyear. A. L. Con rad, executive vice president for services, said the new company would be operated independently of RCA Serv ice Company branches and would he expanded to a na tionwide operation.

title: RUNNER BETTERS TWO MEET MARKS
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 9 Ron Stonitsch set meet records of 4 minutes 9.1 seconds in the onemile run and 14:13.7 in the 3mile event in leading C. W. Post College to a decisive team victory in the Collegiate Track Conference outdoor champion ships on the victors track here today.

title: New YorkOwned Somaten Wins Nashville Steeplechase
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 9 (AP)George Sloan of Nash ville, riding his third winner of the day, guided favored So maten to victory today in the 29th annual Iroquois Memorial Steeplechase.

title: Athletes' Statement
description: We, the athletes assembled before you, members of the Ivy League teams competing here today, seek to call atten tion to our belief that busi ness as usual is not sufficient. As athletes and trackmen we understand that our sport is not, and must never become a hideout from our basic re sponsibilities as human beings.

title: REBEL 400 RACE WON BY PEARSON
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., May 9 (AP)David Pearson drove a Ford to victory today in the Rebel 400, a stockcar race in which Aichard Petty suffered injuries in a crash.

title: How to Pay for 15,000,000 Auto Accidents a Year
description: JUST as the automobile sharply affects the lives of most Ameri cansfour out of five families own oneso, too, does automobile insurance.

title: Chicago Draft Defendant Gets 20 Days for Contempt
description: CHICAGO, May 9 (UPI)One of 11 persons charged with de stroying draft records here was sentenced to 20 days in jail for flontempt of court yesterday be cause he refused to stand when the judge entered the court room.

title: Thurmond Seeks Court Curb
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)  Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, has introduced a bill to take away from the Supreme Court and other Federal courts the power to rule on cases involv ing decisions on public schools.

title: Thant Asks Aid for Event
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 9  Secretary General Thant has asked governments to request their national air lines to provide air travel without charge or at reduced rates for the participants in the United Nationts' World Youth Assembly. The nineday assembly is to open here July 9.

title: LSD Trips May Injure Offspring
description: The doctors' case against LSD gained new ammunition last week when the results of a two year study on birth defects in relation to parental use of LSD were announced.

title: Observer: Behind the Hickel Leak
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Among other events, America learned this week who Walter J. Hickel is. He is the Secre tary of the Interior. America probably would have gone on not knowing who Walter J. Hickel is for several more years, maybe forever, except for publication of Mr. Hickel's leaked letter to President Nixonthe letter in which Mr. Hickel suggested the Govern ment was out of touch with its young, and so forth.

title: Wallace Faces a Runoff And Maybe Oblivion
description: WASHINGTON  The day after the election, said an old foe of George C. Wallace in 1968, the other candidates, win ners and losers, will go fishing or do something to relax. Not George, He'll be out on the street in Montgomery shaking hands, right back campaigning. He doesn't know anything else.

title: A STATEWIDE ISSUE
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.Beaches are for the people. Or are they? The Florida State Cabinet has de cided to ask the courts to determine to what degree the public is entitled to use the state's oceanfront.

title: DESSOFF CHOIRS GIVE TOWN HALL CONCERT
description: The great tonal canvases of Giovanni Gabrieli and Heinrich Schtz, framing hyms of praise to the Lord, provided the high points of a concert by the Dessoff Choirs in Town Hall on Friday night. The program, unified in content in the man ner common to the veteran group's presentations, dealt with music in the Venetian style, and it ranged from a vesper psalm of Adrian Wil laert, the Netherlander who was maestro di cappella at St. Mark's Cathedral in Venice, to a brief piece for brass quartet by Anddzej Rohaczewski, a Pole who wrote in the Venetian manner.

title: HARRISBURG PLAN INCLUDES BUSING
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 9 The Harrisburg school board has adopted a desegregation plan, to go into effect in Sep tember, under which approxi mately 3,700 of the city's 13,000 public school children will be bused.

title: I Was Crowned Before I Was King
description: NEW YORKERS who like Mascagni's sweet little opera, L'Amico Fritz, will have chance to hear it under rea sonably professional auspices on Friday and Saturday. The Manhattan School of Music's John Brownlee Opera Theater is staging it at the Borden Auditorium. By coincidence, there was also a performance last April 25 by the Ruffino Opera Company at Town Hall. These performances seem to be the first by any opera company in New York since the Metropolitan Opera last staged the work, in 1924.

title: Reds' Advance Threatens Royal Capital of Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 9 Informed Western sources re ported today that Communist forces were exerting greater military pressure on Luang Prabang, the royal capital of Laos, than ever before.

title: KATHY WHITWORTH LEADS CIVIT AN GOLF
description: DALLAS, May 9 (AP)  Kathy Whitworth carded a one overpar 72 today to take a onestroke lead after the sec ond round of the Dallas Civitan open golf tournament with 143, while Sherry Wilder, a co leader after the opening round, lost four shots on the last three holes to fall two strokes off the pace.

title: Disruptions at Meetings Aid One Business: Security Police
description: Bring hack the compara tively quiet days when Lewis Gilbert, Evelyn Y. Davis and Wilma Soss were the only irritants at annual meetings. Who needs the war and en vironmental protesters?

title: Saints Acquire Gambrell
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 9 (AP) The New Orleans Saints ac quired Billy Gambrell, a wide receiver, on waivers from the Detroit Lions, today. Gambrell was idled last year by a back injury.

title: Miss Cochrane Becomes Bride Of J. S. Boynton
description: BALTIMORE, May 9Miss Caroline Foster Cochran and James Stephen Boynton were married here this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer by the Rev. Robert P. Patterson.

title: Headliners
description: Once he was one of the most powerful men in the Soviet Union. After Stalin's death he fell into political disgrace and obscuritya nonperson to his countrymen. Last week, in one of his rare public appearances, he stood at a Moscow graveside at the funeral of his wife, Polina Zhem chuzhina, who was once a political star in her own right. A sallow 80yearold figure minus his wellknown pincenez, he was still unmistakably the upright, hardy Vyacheslay M. Molotov, the man they called molot (the hammer) for his driving forcefulness at countless diplomatic conferences with the West. Solemn and dryeyed, the former Premier and Foreign Minister supported his weeping daughter Svet lana. Another disgraced Old Bolshevik, Marshal Nikolai Bul ganin, 74, was among the 100 or so persons at the simple ceremony. But no one from the present Soviet power elite was there.

title: Bishop Moore Installed as Episcopal Coadjutor
description: The Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. was installed yesterday as coadjutor bishop of the Episco pal Diocese of New York in a twohour ceremony in the Ca thedral Church of St. John the Divine.

title: CITY ARRANGING YOUTH PROGRAMS
description: Once a source of controversy, political histrionics and con fusion, the city's package of programs to keep youths busy during the summer is being put together this year in un accustomed calm.

title: Naked Kids Unnerve Cedar Rapids Folk
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, May 8A new sign in the Butterfly Cafe advises those without shoes or shirt to stay out.

title: 9 LATIN COUNTRIES AFFIRM COAST RIGHTS
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 9 (Reuters)  Nine Latin American countries with 200 mile territorial water limits have issued a declaration up holding all countries' rights to establish their own sea limits and control their coasts' natur al resources.

title: My Mother, The Doctor
description: We can generally assume that My Mother, the . . . (or My Greataunt, the . . . or Our Godson, the . . .) will describe an eccentric, forceful but lovable charac ter, the occasion of many a humorous story, whose way out occupation naturally makes any relationship to the writer seem farfetched, if not bio logically aberrant. Joy Daniels Singer's mother certainly ful fills most of our assumptions, though let us hope it is not as odd as all that, nowadays, for a woman to be physician and parent too. (Would My Father, the Doctor be a sale able title?) This is very much an affectionate family por trait, and Mrs. Singer has gone to some pains to include the reader in the family with glossary of every single Yid dish expression (wunder, won der; kibitz, give unwanted ad vice).

title: Massachusetts Picks Juice
description: BOSTON, May 9 (AP)Cran berry juice now is the official state drink in Massachusetts. Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed a bill Monday giving the juice that status.

title: JOHN JAY COLLEGE GETS PROTESTS TOO
description: A few days ago, Ivonne Hughes went to a gathering of militant students from the City University of New York and saw a banner reading John JayCollege or Pig School?

title: U.N. LISTS 19 STATES AS LEAST DEVELOPED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 (UPI)The United Na tions has listed 19 nations, 16 of them African, as the least developed nations of the world.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: THE earth began its existence 4.6 billion years ago, circling around the newborn sun. Formed out of inert atoms of gas and grains of dust, our planet was surely a sterile body of rock at the begin ning. The waters of the primitive oceans were devoid of life; their waves lapped at barren shores, un carpeted by vegetation. Yet today plants grow everywhere; 20,000 kinds of fishes inhabit the seas; the con tinents crawl with a million varieties of animal life; three billion human beings cover the planet.

title: Soviet Replaces AntiParasite Law, Which Permitted Exile of Dissidents to Remote Areas
description: MOSCOW, May 9  The Soviet Union has quietly re placed its controversial anti parasite law with a new crim inal regulation that forces peo ple to engage in socially use ful work or face up to a year in prison or labor camp.

title: BIG CAPITAL RALLY ASKS U.S. PULLOUT IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: WASHINGTON, Sunday, May 10A great crowd of youths, most from the troubled college campuses across the country, demonstrated peaceably yester day at the rear of a barricaded White House, demanding the withdrawal of United States military forces from Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam.

title: A wait Selling Climax To End Market Drop
description: The stock market's retreat is now more than a year and a half old and pessimism reigns on Wall Street. Where the tailspin will end nobody knows, but an in creasingly prevalent view is that an oldfashioned selling climax is the needed ingre dient.

title: Article 7  No Title
Cambodia Stirs Up AntiFrench Feeling
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 9With the passion of an un requited lover, Cambodia has turned against France, the country that most influenced presentday Cambodia and then rejected her.

title: My Travel Diary: 1936
description: Between Two Worlds. By Paul Tillich.

title: New Design Set In Nuclear Plant
