description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. May 9 (Reuters)A magistrate today charged Christian Belon, a young Frenchman, in connec tion with the hijacking of an United States airliner to Beirut at gunpoint on Jan. 9.

title: Marriages
description: PINSTEINCOHENMr. and Mrs. Bernard Cohen of Hartsdale, N. Y., happily an nounce the marriage of their daughter, Judy Lynne, to Arnold Mark Pinstein, son of Sol Pinstein of West Newton, Mass, S. the late Sylvia Pinstein, Mar 9, 1970.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: May 15Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey rally school at Great Notch Fire House, Long Hill Road, Little Falls, N. J. Fee $1. School, open to all makes of cars, to be held on May 22 also information: Jim DeYoung, phone (201)6977525.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WHEN Willis Reed stepped onto the court, said Bill Bradley, his voice reflecting all the excite ment and delight that still churned within him, it gave us a 10foot lift just to have him.

title: RISE IN JOBLESS CALLED PUZZLING
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9 The recent sharp rise in un employment puzzles Adminis tration economists somewhat because the economy is other wise performing just about as they had expected. Herbert G. Stein, a member of the Presi dent's Council of Economic Advisers, said today.

title: BOSTON TERRIER GAINS TOP AWARD
description: LUDWIGS CORNER, Pa., May 9A 19monthold Boston terrier, Ch. Star Q's Brass But tons, owned by Dr. K. Eileen Hite of New York and handled by Harry N. Clasen, defeated 1,356 rivals today to take best inshow honors at the 27th an nual Chester Valley Kennel Club fixture.

title: In Brief
description: In 19thcentury, manifest destinyhaunted America the buffalo was clearly an enor mous pest. There were some 40million of them thundering about the Western plains, tak ing up perfectly good grazing and farming land. The warlike Plains Indians depended upon them for food and fought fiercely to protect the hunting ground. The Army, anticipat ing the defoliation strategy in Vietnam, did all it could to debuffalo the West and starve the Indian out. Further, there was a profit (for a time) to be made from buffalo hides and meat. Obviously a job for the exterminators; and they came and, using longrange rifles with which a man could leisurely pick off an entire herd, wiped out six million of the animals between 1871 and 1873. By the 1880's the buffalo was on the verge of extinction.

title: DECIDING SINGLES IS TAKEN BY KARY
description: LONDON, May 9 (AP)Aus tria eliminated Britain in the first round of the Davis Cup today as Hans Kary beat Britain's John Clifton, 63, 62, 64 for a 32 victory.

title: Coast Town Drives 450 Protesters Back Into Canada
description: BLAINE, Wash., May 9 (UPI) About 450 Canadians invaded this border city today to pro test against the Cambodian sit uation but were driven back across the border in a running fist fight with townspeople. One city policeman was in jured. Three persons were ar rested. The invaders shattered several windows in the down town area and pelted rocks at a passing freight train carrying new automobiles. Windows of half of the new cars were broken.

title: Memorial Services
description: CLARKIsabel T. A memorial servint will be held at 11 A.M. Mnrday, May 11 1970, for Isabel T. Clark (Isabel Barringer) in the Poling Chhapel of the Marble Collegiate Church or to the Church of the Truth, hattan. Please omit flowers. Contributions may be made to ins Marble Collegiate Church or to the Churchh of the Ttrufh, 154 West 57th Street, Manhattan.

title: Miss Hazzard Bride of Broker
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., May 9 Miss Elizabeth Taylor Hazzard and Martin Berke Freedland were married here today in a civil ceremony at the Oak Knoll Farm, home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr and Mrs. C Tay lor Marshall Judge Richard T. Wentley of the Allegheny County Court of Common Pleas officiated.

title: Cavaliers Sign Vidnovic
description: CLEVELAND, May 9 (AP) The Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association signed their No. 4 draft choice. Glenn Vidnovic of Iowa, last night.

title: Dog Show Calendar
Little Red Schoolhouse Is Yellow
description: EASTHAM, Mass.The local ver sion of the little red school house, 100 years old on June 27, is painted a lively yellow and trimmed with white. This color scheme once caused children from the other Cape Cod towns to nickname the East ham pupils Yellowbellies.

title: Gypsy Rose Lee 191470
description: GYPSY ROSE LEE had no major talents. And I'm (rioting her. She sang fairly well; she danced a little better. She was statuesque, but not beau tiful. She acted with author ity, but without inspiration. What, then made her a leg end?

title: BOWER WINNER IN FIELD OF 1,338
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 9A 5yearold silver gray Bouvier des flandres, Ch. Naris du Posty Arlequin, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Chester F. Collier of IrvingtonontheHud son, N. Y., won his fourth best inshow award today at the 43d annual Springfield Kennel Club show on the Eastern Exposi tion grounds. There were 1,338 dogs in this first outdoor show of the season in Massachusetts.

title: Journalism Awards Given Four Persons And Three Papers
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., May 9 (AP)Four persons and three newspapers have been presentfi ed with Missouri honor awards for distinguished service in journalism by the University of Missouri.

title: Sara Lawrence Engaged to Wed
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 9  Ruddick C. Lawrence, vice president of the Con tinental Oil Company, and Mrs. Lawrence of Bronxville and Shelter Island, have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Hil ary Lawrence, to Dean Lee Engelhardt, an assistant pro fessor of biology at the Uni versity of Connecticut at Storrs. The wedding is planned for June 20.

title: PIRATES TOP ASTROS AS CLEMENTE STARS
description: HOUSTON, May 9 (AP)Ro berto Clemente got four straight hits and Bob Moose won his first game of the season as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated Houston, 63, today.

title: Tours of Homes Planned to Help Many Charities
description: The Manhattan League for the Industrial Home for the Blind will benefit from two tours of nine residences and two studios. The first, this Thursday, will be to the Cecil Beaton Suite at the St. RegisSheraton, the bornes of Mr. and Mrs. Jahn A; Friede, Mr. and Mrs. Steven R. Jacobson, William Pahl mann and Mr. and Mrs. Rob ert A. M. Stern, and the studio of Chaim Gross.

title: The Great Persuader
description: He had a beard. He called his ad versaries pigs. And he was quite contemptuous of contemporary pro cesses of government. But he ante dated today's radicals by a century. His name was Collis Potter Hunting ton, and he was, ironically, one of the great economic pirates of his era.

title: Major League Baseball
description: National League

title: Elizabeth Morris Jack Is Wed To H. Williamson Ghriskey Jr.
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., May 9  Miss Elizabeth Morris Jack and H. Williamson Ghriskey Jr. were married here this afternoon in St. Michael's Episcopal Church by the Rev. S. David Gur niak and Elbert Hamlin.

title: U.S. BASE'S FUTURE DISTURBS AZORES
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, the Azores, April 30 This 15th century town, which was twice the capital of Portugal, is anxiously awaiting the opening of negotiations between Lisbon and Washington on the future of United States military installa tions in the Azores.

title: DRIVE IN CAMBODIA TERMED A SUCCESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  As serting that success in the first nine days of the allied military sweep in Cambodia exceeded all expectations, the White House said today that American and South Vietnamese forces had already captured more enemy ammunition than the North Vietnamese and Vietcong had fired in Vietnam in the first four months of this year.

title: Steve Has Stopped Collaborating
description: THE ambience of Stephen Sond heim's east side duplex ought to seem lighthearted. Its walls are lined with the antique games he collectsloto dauphin, and The Games of the Goose, and Transformation Cards. When you're tired of those, you can play the 19thcentury bicycle game, or SkittlesBilliards, or the genuine har monica (musically  tuned drinking glasses), or Sky Jump, or the 1945 Las Vegas slot machine. Or you can sit and listen to Steve, doubtless one of the most articulate men in contemporary theater, if not its most frolicsome.

title: Nixon, in PreDawn Tour, Talks to War Protesters
description: WASHINGTON, May 9President Nixon left the White House shortly before dawn this morning, drove to the Lincoln Memorial and spent an hour chatting with young people who had come to pro test his war policies.

title: Chess
description: HE recent chess match between the Soviet Union and the rest of the world at Belgrade, a 10board, fourround epic battle, was a So viet victory by the narrowest of mar gins: 201A191A. Except for a strange occurrence during the last round, the result might have been 2020.

title: West Berlin Demonstration
description: BERLIN, May 9Three per sons were wounded by a police man's bullets during an antiwar demonstration here today when a crowd of militant demonstra tors surged toward Amerika House, the United States cul tural center in downtown West Berlin, hurling stones and gaso line bombs. Some 5,000 police men battled thousands of leftist radicals for several hours.

title: Never Complain, Never Explain, Never Apologize!
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The British Secret Service has an old rule: Never complain, never explain, never apologize. That was roughly the line Presi dent Nixon took in his latest news conference: He invaded Cambodia to achieve all the goals the students want, he said, almost as if he had done them a favor. They didn't un derstand, of course, but he would be generous about it. Father forgive them, for they know not what they do.

title: D. G. Willoughby Weds Miss Bondy
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., May 9  Miss Susan Ann Bondy and David Gordon Willoughby were married here this afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Robert B. Hybel.

title: Sportsmen Discover Riches That Miners Overlooked
description: CONEJOS, Colo. Residents of this region were pretty glum a year ago, when the trains of the Den ver & Rio Grande Western Rail road finally stopped running between Antonito, Colo., and Chama, N.M. As one of the last narrowgauge routes in the nation, the run  it crossed state lines many times in 92 miles of scenic mountain countrybrought in a lot of tourist business on summer and fall weekend excursions.

title: Mariner Tests an Einstein Theory in Space
description: A manmade planet, Mari ner 7, will pass almost di rectly behind the sun tomor row, enabling radio astro nomers to make another attempt to resolve one of the most basic debates in modern physics.

title: Horse Owners Vote Boycott
description: BOSTON, May 9 (AP)New England horse owners voted today to boycott Suffolk Downs Tuesday unless new jockey pay scales at the East Boston track are changed back to the lower 1969 scales. The owners said their refusal to enter horses at the track events would cost Massachusetts $80,000 daily.

title: Quarter Horse Dashing to Starting Gate
description: He's heavily muscled, compact, built closer to the ground than a thoroughbred, and his short, broad head is carried lower.

title: Rabin, Here, Asserts Israel Would Answer Soviet Attack
description: Itzhak Rabin, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, said last night that his nation would not be another Czechoslovakia and would de fend itself if attacked by Sov viet pilots or gunners.

title: ST. MARY'S CAPTURES CANOEING LAURELS
description: St. Mary's College of St. Mary's City, Md., swept six of the eight canoeing events con tested yesterday on the Orchard Beach Lagoon to score a lopsided victory for the team championships. The regatta was sponsored by the American Canoe Association and drew en tries from six metropolitan high schools and three colleges.

title: New Look On Issue Of Planes
description: When the Nixon Administra tion refused last March to sell 125 more warplanes to Israel, it did so on the ground that the Israelis did not need the addi tional aircraft to maintain a bal ance of power in the Middle East. President Nixon said he would take another look at the Israeli request if that balance was threatened.

title: Gomulka Asks Bonn Conciliation
description: WROCLAW, Poland, May 9 Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist leader, addressed gentle appeal to Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany today to close the book on the past of hostile relations be tween Poland and Germany.

title: Campbell's Waste Water Irrigates Texas Prairie
description: PARIS, Tex.To the resi dents of this small city in northeastern Texas, the sight of 700 sprinklers spewing water on 500 acres of grass land has become a common one, although many wondered initially why the sprinkling continued during winter months.

title: Lima Drive Seeks to Eliminate Begging
description: LIMA, Peru, May 9 (AP)In one day, Mrs. Haydee Nadal de Benavente, backed by a number of police officers and vans, cleared all beggars from the streets of this city of three million people.

title: Evelyn Irving, 1966 Debutante, To Be Married
description: UNIONVILLE, Pa., May 9 Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Duer Irving of Unionville and Southampton, L. L, have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn duPont Irving, to Craigh Leonard Jr., son of Mrs. Robinson Simonds of New York and the late Mr. Leon ard, who was a New York lawyer. The ceremony will be performed on June 27 in Southampton.

title: Army Names 6 Who Balked At Moving Into Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 10The United States Army's Fourth Division, based near Pleiku, announced today the names of six soldiers who refused to join a combat assault into Cambodia and who are being held pinding possible courtmartial charges.

title: Lindsay Asks 25c As S.I. Ferry Fare
description: Mayor Lindsay has proposed a fivefold increase in one of the last things of value that nickel will buya ride on the Staten Island ferry.

title: 4 IBERIAN AIRLINERS TARGETS OF BOMBS
description: GENEVA, May 10 (UPI)  Fire bombers believed to be po litical enemies of the Spanish chief of state, Generalissimo Francisco Franco struck today at planes of the Iberia Air Lines of Spain in four European cities in what appeared to be a con certed attack.

title: Lili Kraus Plays Beethoven Concerto
description: It may have taken the Bee thoven bicentennial to do it, but Lili Kraus finally played one of the composer's piano concertos in New York. The odd omission (Miss Kraus has long been a noted Beethoveni an) was rectified in Philhar monic Hall on Saturday night when the pianist and the Brooklyn Philharmonia under Siegfried Landau addressed themselves to the Third Con certo.

title: U.S. Riders Off to Europe
description: The United States Equestrian Team  six riders, 16 horses and Coach Bert DeNomethy  left by chartered KI.M airliner from Kennedy International Airport last night for a tour of six European horse shows. Bill Steinkraus a member of five Olympic squads and the indi vidual Gold Medal winner in the 1968 gemee, led the group.

title: Italy Wins in Soccer, 21
description: LISBON, May 10Italy de feated Portugal, 21, today in an exhibition soccer match in preparation for the Italian na tional team's participation in the World Cup tourney in Mexico.

title: Rome: Looking Forward to the Past
description: ROMEThe Portuguese no longer represent the serious threat to the pros perity of opera theaters in Italy they once did. They still cost money of course, the more money the farther you travel south, but not nearly enough to endanger presentday budgets. Other and infinitely more complicated problems keep sovrintendenti, or general directors, in charge of opera theaters in Italian cities, awake at night.

title: Why Block Reform?
description: Unless Congress takes action this week to block President Nixon's proposal for streamlining the Execu tive Branch of the government, an effective reform will automatically go into operation this summer. The plan was developed by an advisory council, drawing on the work of earlier commissions. The need to give more form to what has become an administrative sprawl is glaringly apparent. And the recommenda tions themselves appear to make excellent sense.

title: Article 5  No Title
CHINESE REACTION DISCOUNTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The Under Secretary of State, Elliot L. Richardson, said to day that when the Administra tion decided to send United States troops into Cambodia, it believed the possibility of Chi nese Communist intervention in Indochina was remote enough to constitute an ac ceptable risk.

title: French Tourist Office Names Aide
description: The French Government Tourist Office has a new Di rector General for the United States, Jacques Ditrie. His headquarters here are at 610 Fifth Avenue.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Advertising: Magazines Within Magazines
description: Magazine Networks, Inc., which is to national maga zines somewhat like what Sunday supplements are to newspapers, is preparing to level its guns on two of the top 10 markets.

title: N.Y.A.C. Captures Cup Race for Eight At Orchard Beach
description: The New York Athletic Club won the Whelan Cup for senior eights in the sixth annual Fa ther Knickerbocker regatta on the Orchard Beach Lagoon yes terday. St. John's University was second after leading for the first 500 meters.

title: Questions for the Police
description: New York policemen are as entitled as anyone else to a presumption of innocence until they are found guilty. But from Mayor Lindsay's angry comments on their failure last Friday to contain marauding con struction workers bent on mayhem, it is clear that some members of the force have a lot to explain.

title: Florida Route Shifted To Spare Eagle Nest
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 The Federal Highway Ad ministration has decided to locate Interstate Highway 75, now being planned, some 300 feet farther west near Tampa to avoid disturbing an eagle's nest in the top of a 50foot pine tree.

title: Washington's Weekend: The Tumult and the Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Everything that happened in Washington this weekend didn't happen in the streets or on television. The public demon stration by the students against the Government's war policies made the news, but on the side there were a lot of private conversations that may prove in the end to be far more important than all the public tumult.

title: Figure Skater Retires
description: BERLIN, May 10 (UPI)  Gabi Seyfert, the world figure skating champion, reired today from active sports, the East German press service ADN re ported.

title: GAUCHERO SCORES IN SOUND SAILING
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 10 Alan Burtis of Sea Cliff Yacht Club won his second race of the Western Long Is land Sound Star Class Eye Opener series with Gauchero today when a fleet of 70 sailed in the fourth event of Larch mont Yacht Club's sixrace spring series. The series is an prelude to the Yacht Racing As sociation championship season.

title: Georgians Planning Dinner Dance Here
description: Georgians whose native state is in the south of the Soviet Union will escort friends and relatives to a dinner dance on Friday in the Pierre's Cotillion Room. The party, arranged by the Georgian Association in the United States of America, will recall May 26, 1918, when Georgia enjoyed brief independence before being made a republic of the Soviet Union.

title: SIDNEY A. LICHTMAN, ASSEMBLYMAN, 47
description: Assemblyman Sidney A. Lichtman of the 44th District, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, died Saturday of pancreatitis in New York Hos pital. He was 47 years old and lived at 1094 East 18th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Valerie B. Hobart Wed to Robert Peck
description: Miss Valerie Brooke Hobart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Da vid Jay Hobart of Englewood, N. J., was married at the Plaza yesterday afternoon to Robert Peck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Peck of Bergenfield. Rabbi Edward Klein performed the ceremony.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: This effort gave him an eightoverpar 218 for the two day 54hole tournament as he paced Dartmouth to its first team championship. As a result, the Big Green, coached by Bill Johnson, gained a spot in the National Collegiate tournament scheduled for Ohio State next month.

title: WARREN DECRIES DENIAL OF RIGHTS
description: Earl Warren said last night that it was deplorable that there were more than 20 mil lion Americans, mostly black, who are still denied basic rights of American citizenship.

title: Orioles Reject Proposal
description: BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles voted, 1411, yesterday to reject threeyear basic agreement with the Major League Baseball Players' Association proposed by the 24 major lbague club owners.

title: Trinidad Revamps Cabinet As Three Ministers Resign
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, May 10 (Reuters)Prime Min ister Eric Williams announced a major cabinet reshuffling to night to infuse new men and the ideas they can offer into the Gnvernment of Trinidad.

title: Jets Can Park Unassisted Under New Airline System
description: Crew of United Air Lines will be abl eto park their jets unas sisted at 12 airports during 1970, the Airline Management and Marketing maga zine re ports.

title: Chess:
description: IMMEDIATELY following the windup of the recent Bel grade match, the Soviet Union against masters from the rest of the world, the Yugoslavs organized an 18 man international round robin at Rovinj and Zagreb.

title: Rotterdam, Marking Liberation, Sadly Recalls Nazis' Bombing
description: ROTTENDAM, The Nether lands, May 10  The pigeons flocked today around the bronze statue of death in the heart of Rotterdam. Herman Hordyk sat alone on a bench gazing at the statue and run ning his fingers through his white hair.

title: $200,000 in Gems Stolen, But How Poses a Mystery
description: About $200,000 in jewelry and precious stones was re ported stolen yesterday morn ing from a downtown dealer, but investigators were unable to explain how the theft was accomplished.

title: 11 Participants at Kent
description: Some of the Kent State students who participated in the discussion with The New York Times were selected because it was thought they represented a particular point of view or element in the student body. Others were selected at random. The participants were:

title: Giants' Defense Produces Gems, but Mets' Fielders Find It Somewhat Tougher to Hang On
Defendants in Criminal Court Say Arraignment Is Confusing
description: It Is 3 P.M. now, and Alvin, who was arrested for burglary at 11:30 the previous night, has not slept for 31 hours. He hunches forward and hides his face in his hands to shut out the sight of the iron bars, the guard and the door to the courtroom.

title: $5Million in Rubella Vaccine
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Contracts totaling approximate ly $5million have been awarded two manufacturers for 6,850, 000 doses of rubella vaccine to he delivered between May and September this year, Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, an nounced today. Mr. Finch said that more than seven million children had been vaccinated against German measles since June, 1969, and that by fall half the goal of 40 million children would he reached.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: But Britain Did Not Die at Yorktown
description: LONDONJudging by the re action of the educated Briton, the United States faces a crisis of confidence among her friends in Europe. The Cambodian in vasion and its consequences have aggravated the longstand ing worry that America, in her obsession with Southeast Asia, will forget Europe. To that has been added a new uneasiness about the predictability and the judgment of the most powerful man in the world, the President.

title: Operations at 3 Airports Here Are Off 13% From Last Spring
description: Airline operations at the three airports here are down 13 per cent this spring from 1969, in an unusual downturn for an industry accustomed to setting records year after year.

title: Theoni Wins Slalom
description: TOYAMA, Japan, May 10 (AP)Gustavo Theoni of Italy and Walter Tresch of Switzer land finished one, two in an international slalom ski cham pionship on the Raicho Valley slopes in central Japan today.

title: Warsaw and Bonn Hopeful on Border
description: WARSAW, May 8  Both Polish and West German offi cials involved in political talks between the two countries ap pear to feel that Poland will achieve West German accept ance of the OderNeisse line as a final boundary within a year.

title: Reuther Dies in Jet Crash With Wife and 4 Others
description: DETROIT, May 10  Walter P. Reuther, the president of the United Automobile Workers, and his wife, May, died last night in a plane crash in north ern Michigan. Mr. Reuther was 62 years old, and his wife was 59.

title: G.O.P. Found Hurt by Cambodia Drive
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 President Nixon's decision to send American troops into Cambodia and the protests that followed have hurt the Repub lican party's standing with the voters, Republican and Demo cratic politicians agreed this weekend.

title: Bonn Aide Back in Moscow For Talks on Peaceful Ties
description: MOSCOW, May 10 (Reuters) Egon Bahr, a West German State Secretary, arrived here tonight to continue exploratory talks about a nonaggression treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Students Call on Congressmen Here About War
description: The facultystudent senates of Columbia and New York universities jointly confronted New York City members of Congress yesterday with calls for ending the war in South east Asia.

title: Article 6  No Title
NIXON POLICY FOUND TIED TO STOCK DROP
description: A poll taken last week by Louis Harris reports that 78 per cent of the businessmen questioned believe President Nixon's policies have contrib uted to the decline of the stock market.

title: LaFayette R. Blanchard Dead; ExChief Editor for Gannett, 81
description: OJAI, Calif., May 10 (AP) LaFayette R. Blanchard, former chief editor of Gannett News papers, died today of pneu monia. He was 81 years old.

title: The View From Kent State: 11 Speak Out
description: Like many of the nation's rapidly expanding state univer sities, Kent State University, until last Monday, was flourish ing in an obscurity out of all proportion to its size. In an in stant, the obscurity was ended by a volley of rifle fire that killed four students.

title: SAIGON GUNBOATS ON MEKONG PLAN 55MILE INCURSION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10  The commander of the South Vietnamese gunboats thrusting into Cambodia said today that the boats would sail up the Mekong River as much as 55 miles past the border of South Vietnam. Military sources reported that the American ad visers aboard the fleet's 110 Vietnamese boats would make the trip with them.

title: Hattie Carnegie Sparkle Lingers in Gem
description: Hattie Carnegie, born Hen rietta Koenengeiser, was a scrappy, fourfoot, nineinch entrepreneuress, who built the country's most successful fashion empire before her death in 1956.

title: Allied Boats Help Remove Refugees From Cambodia
description: ON THE MEKONG RIVER, in Cambodia, May 10The stars and stripes and the red and yellow flag of South Vietnam flutter up and down the Mekong River as the Sai gon navy goes about the big gest mission it has ever tackledbringing back Viet namese refugees from Cam bodia and assuring their se curity in transit. From the South Vietnamese border to the ferry crossing at Neak Luong, 24 miles upstream, the Mekong looks like an arm of South Vietnam rather than the principal waterway of an independent Cambodia. Swift United States and South Vietnamese patrol boats flash up and downstream. Some times a South Vietnamese boat calls a civilian sampan loaded with people over for investigation before permitting it to continue. Not a single Cambodian flag is in sight. Cambodianstyle houses on stilts along the west bank of the river look deserted; the in habitants have fled inland.

title: Royal Ballet Performs La Fine Mal Gardee
description: ON Saturday at the Metro politan Opera House the Royal Ballet came up with what might well be its ideal program: Frederick Ashton's La Fille Mal Gardee and the final act of Rudolf Nure yev's restaging of the old Petipa ballet Raymonda. It is an explosive but beautiful combination.

title: M'WILLIAMS WINS IN COLLEGE GOLF
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10 Sandy McWilliams, a Dart mouth senior, carded birdies on the four parthree holes of his final 18 on the Yale Golf Course today and soon the in dividual championship of the 43d annual Eastern Intercolle giate Golf Association tourna ment.

title: Comedy Reduces Prices
description: The Engagement Baby, a new comedy by Stanley Shapiro, starring Barry Nelson, will be gin a series of special reduced price previews tonight at the Helen Hayes Theater, prior to its official opening on May 21. Tickets for all Mondaythrough Friday performances will be $3, $4 and $5, with Saturday eve ning performances at $4, $5 and $6.

title: Personal Finance: Incorporation Advice
description: New York State may soon give doctors and lawyers a chance to give some serious thought to one of their fav orite subjectsmoney.

title: HAULERS' STRIKE HOLDING UP STEEL
description: PITTSBURGH, May 10  Transportation problems have piled up close to a million tons of steel at the shipping docks of producers.

title: Cards Halt Braves At 11 Straight, 65, With 4 Runs in 9th
description: ATLANTA, May 10 (AP) Jose Cardenal's tworun single off Hoyt Wilhelm, who was making his 1,000th pitching ap pearance, capped a fourrun rally in the ninth inning to day as the St. Louis Cardinals scored a 65 victory over At lanta. The loss snapped the Braves' winning streak at 11 games.

title: SPENDING IS ISSUE NEBRASKA RACE
description: LINCOLN. Neb., May 10An uncompromising conservative has seized on the nationally troublesome issues of spending, crime and education to throw Gov. Norbert Tiemann the big gest political challenge of his career in Tuesday's Republican primary.

title: Ashe Victor on Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 10 (AP)Arthur Ashe of Gum Springs, Va., won the Central California tennis tournament to day by defeating Barry MacKay of Ross in a grueling battle, 64, 62, 36, 108.

title: Article 2  No Title
Policemen Star in Drama of Court Graft
description: A cast dominated by 17 po licemen staged a play in the Police Academy on Friday and Saturday nights on the theme of corruption among law enforcement officials.

title: Campus Dissent in Saigon
description: The closing of the University of Saigon and of all the city's elementary and secondary schools for an indefinite period adds a poignant footnote, not only to the issues of the war but to the outcry against on America's campuses. The shutdown was ordered by the Thieu Government in answer to a rising tide of student protest against both the war and the Government's often repressive policies. Students Saigon, moreover, appear to agree with those in the United States in viewing the invasion of Cambodia as a postponement of prospects for peace.

title: Court Tells U. of Miami to Open After 2 Students Contest Closing
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., May 10An unusual University of Miami law class was held here today after a court ordered sus pended university classes re sumed immediately.

title: Pipes and Chants Blend In 5th Ave. Israeli Salute
description: The floats sparkled, the bands blared, bagpipes skirled and youngsters danced under a blazing sun as 70,000 men, women and children marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday to mark Israel's 22d anniversary as a nation.

title: Blaze, Possibly Set, Kills 10 in Chicago Apartments
description: CHICAGO, May (AP)A fire swept tthrough a fourstory apartment building on Chicago's West Side today, killing nine persons.

title: Reds Beat Cubs, 7  6, on Rose's Homer
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI)  Pete Rose walloped a tworun homer in the top of the ninth inning today, the team's 50th in 31 games this year, to give the Cincinnati Reds a 76 tri umph over the Chicano Cubs.

title: PEKING BOLSTERS POSITION IN ASIA
description: HONG KONG, May 10  Communist China's position in the sphere of Asian commu nist countries and movements has dramatically improved in the last two months.

title: ORR'S GOAL WINS FINAL SERIES, 40
description: BOSTON, May 10  Although unable to leap over buildings with a single hound. Bobby Orr flew through the air in over time today, rapped home Derek Sanderson's pass and gave the Bruins their first Stanley Cup since 1941.

title: Textile Dispute Hurts Mills in Japan
description: SABAE, JapanUntil a few weeks ago the 26 looms of the Yoshida textile mill, a small wooden shed on a quiet street lined with blossoming cherry trees, had been busily spinning out nylon fiber.

title: An ActressModel Who Has the Face of Now
description: IN a city of unusual faces, Jane Forth stands out. Hers is a cadaverous face, a high fashion face, half Garbo, half moon child. The lips are bright red, the pale checks rouged. The eyebrows are shaved off until only the be ginningslooking like two apostrophesremain. The dark hair is slicked back with Wesson Oil to form a tight bun at the nape of the neck.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To Cut War Budget

title: MRS. P. BRADLEY CLARK
description: Mrs. Katharine Benjamin Clark, wife of P. Bradley Clark, partner in the investment banking firm of Clark & Co., died Saturday In Roosevelt Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 112 Park Avenue.

title: War Dominates State's Politics
description: The Governor of South Caro lina, Robert E. McNair, talked with a group of New York Democrats for three hours one evening last week in a Central Park West apartment. He came away from meeting with one impression: They're only in terested in one thing up here, the warit's different at home and in the rest of the country.

title: Jewish Unit Assails Soviet; Urges Emigration Be Eased
description: GENEVA, May 10  The European executive body of the World Jewish Congress con demned today what it termed the Soviet Union's antiJewish policy and propaganda. It urged Moscow to assist Jews wishing to emigrate to Israel or to join their families in other countries.

title: TALKS RECESSED IN PAPER DISPUTE
description: Contract negotiations between the printers' union and the city's four major newspapers remained stalemated yesterday, although the positions of the parties were reported as not far apart.

title: Israel Pays Tribute to War Dead
description: TEL AVIV, May 10 Israelis observed a day of remembrance today for sol diers who have fallen in three wars with the coun try's Arab neighbors, in prelude to tomorrow's holi day marking the 22d anniver sary of independence. Two nationwide siren blasts brought traffic and work to a stop in a tribute to the dead.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: 20 Hurt as Train Derails
description: MODESTO, Calif., May, 10 (AP)The Santa Fe's San Fran cisco Chief, on the way from Chicago to San Francisco, hit a stalled cannery truck eight miles north of here today de railing the entire 12unit train and injuring at least 20 pas sengers.

title: 3 CORRESPONDENTS MISSING IN CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) Three American news corres pondents  two men and a womanwere reported missing today after failing to return from a trip across the Cam bodian border near Svayrieng.

title: Florida's Hyacinths Tested As Cattle and Chicken Feed
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. (AP) Charlotte County may solve its hyacinth problem by turn ing it into chicken feed.

title: BETSY RAWLS TAKES CIVITAN GOLF AT 214
description: DALLAS, May 10 (AP)  Betsy Rawls survived 30mile anhour winds that blasted across the Glen Lakes Country Club course today, carding twounderpar 69 to win the Dallas Civitan women's open golf tournament with a 54hole total of 214.

title: Note to Readers
description: The box scores of all base ball games between nonlocal teams are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Specialist Assists Absentee Owners
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 10When a business man can't find a business to go into, he invents one. And that is exactly what Robert V. Drouillard did two years ago.

title: Wages Up 13.1 % in 2 Years
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) American workers' total com pensation for an hour of labor averaged $3.89 in 1968, an in crease of 45 cents or 13.1 per cent from the revised 1966 level, the Department of Labor announced today.

title: Perot Honored as Patriot
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP) About 1,000 personsamong them Vietnam War veterans, wives of prisoners of war and college students turned out last night at a dinner to honor H. Ross Perot, the Texas mil lionaire, as patriot of the year for his efforts to obtain thenames of prisoners of war being held by Hanoi.

title: Ustinov Clowns for Youth Concert
description: Peter Ustinov, who has been known to dabble also in films and the theater, made his con ducting debut yesterday after noon at Philharmonic Hall.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. to discuss control of Bahrain after Brit ish departure.

title: Pope Says the News Media Are Making Life Passive
description: ROME, May 10(AP)Pope Paul VI said today that the in formation media were making modern man's life increasingly superficial and passive.

title: OSKAR STONOROY, ARCHITECT, KILLED
description: Oskar Stonorov, architect, city planner and sculptor who died Saturday night in the plane crash that also killed Walter P. Reuther, was the designer of the $14million United Auto Workers Family Education Cen ter near Onaway, Mich., the destination of the plane's pas sengers. The center is to open in July.

title: George Washington High Will Stay Closed Today
description: George Washington High School will remain closed to day while all other schools reopen, the Board of Education announced early today.

title: N.E.T. Wins Cannes Award
description: CANNES, France, May 10 Bob Fresco's coverage for the National Educational Television network of the Denver trial of Laureen R. Watson, a Black Panther, was awarded first prize today for a televised news film of the international television news competition held in con junction with the Cannes Film Festival. The British Broadcast ing Corporation's television cov erage of the investiture of Prince Charles as Prince of Wales was awarded first prize for the best live broadcast.

title: Interpublic Is Poised For a Public Offering
description: Good to its word, the Inter public Group of Companies, which last month said it would be going public, has taken the first step in that di rection. It has filed with the Securities and Exchange Com mission.

title: Orioles Sweep White Sox; Indians Defeat Twins, 54
description: Orioles Sweep White Sox; Indians Defeat Twins, 54

title: Rindt Captures Monaco Grand Prix as Brabham's Brakes Lock on Last Turn
description: Rindt Captures Monaco Grand Prix as Brabham's Brakes Lock on Last Turn

title: O'Donnell to Aid Rockefeller
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday that Harry J. O'Donnell, who participated in all of his three prior races for Governor, would he director of public relations in his hid for a fourth fouryear term in Albany. Mr. O'Donnell, former press secretary to Thomas E. Dewey as Governor and to Mayor Lindsay, will take a leave of absence without pay from his current post as Dep uty Commerce Commissioner in charge of the state Division of Economic Development.

title: Mexico Loses in Soccer, 21
description: TOLUCA, Mexico, May 10 (AP)  Borussia Dortmund of West Germany defeated Mexi co's national team, 21, today. Mexico led, 10, at halftime.

title: AMERICAN NEARS CONTROL OF I.O.S.
description: GENEVA, May 10John M. King, the Denver businessman who wants control of Investors Overseas Services, sought today to bring European banks into an international consortium he is forming to give the ailing mutual fund company new life.

title: AIMED LIGHT AIDS NEWARK TRAFFIC
description: A new type of traffic light designed to simplify complica ted intersections, where mo torists are often confused by psychedelic nightmare of signs apparently telling them simul taneously to stop, go and turn, has passed muster in Newark.

title: CERDAN TO MEET PADUANO TONIGHT
description: With a very heavy name to carry, Marcel Cerdan Jr. will make his American boxing debut tonight in a 10round welterweight bout with Donato Paduano at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sacramento Policeman Shot
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 10 (AP)A policeman was crit ically wounded in the head by a sniper's bullet last night as he drove his patrol car through the predominantly Negro neigh borhood of Oak Park, the po lice said. According to the police the bullet, one of six fired, passed through the roof of the squad car before strik ing patrolman Bernard Bennett, 25 years old.

title: Church Dedicated
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)  The National Presbyterian Church, of whose congregation former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was once a mem ber, was formally dedicated to day, The cornerstone of they $8.5million church was un veiled by Mr. Eisenhower in 1967.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: DualPurpose Funds

title: SLUGGER DRIVES IN 6 RUNS ON CLOUTS
description: Six home runs flew out of Shea Stadium yesterday  in cluding a grand slam by Willie McCovey  as the San Fran cisco Giants downed the New York Mets. 117.

title: Credit Policy Was Tightened in April; Bond Rates Expected to Remain High
description: Interest rates, affected by a jumble of conflicting forces, are likely to stay close to the high levels they reached last week.

title: Parley of Christians Calls for Palestinian State
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 A world conference of Christians in support of Palestine's Arabs closed today with a demand for the evacuation of occupied territories and disappearance of Zionist structures as in dispensable steps toward peace.

title: Norton Simon, Inc., Is Planning To Purchase Simon & Schuster
description: The billiondollar Norton Simon, Inc., conglomerate an nounced an agreement in prin ciple yesterday to buy the publishing house of Simon & Schuster, Inc., for $23.5million in cash.

title: 33 G.I.'s Killed Last Week In 21 Helicopter Crashes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (UPI)  The United States command announced to day that 33 Americans were killed and 30 injured last week as 21 helicopters were lost in the Indochina war.

title: NEW GROUPS HELP EXILES IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, May 10On the eve of what United States draft resisters and deserters in Canada hopefully predict will be a heavy summer influx of newcomers, two new Toronto committees to assist the exiles have been formed, one has dis banded and one is fighting an eviction notice.

title: Mansfield Sees Filibuster If 18YearOld Vote Fails
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate majority leader, cautioned the House today that failure to approve the vote for 18yearolds could lead to a Senate filibuster and the death of the Voting Rights Act extension.

title: CARTY IS SNUBBED IN ALLSTAR VOTE
description: Rico Carty of the Atlanta Braves, the National League's leading hitter, was left off the ballot yesterday in nominations in the AllStar Game.

title: CAPETOWN MYSTERY FOCUSES ON U.S. AIDE
description: CAPETOWN, May 10 (Reut ers)  An American military attach here has emerged as the central character in a grow ing mystery that may involve ??.

title: Nixon Family Prays Together at Mother's Day Services in White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)  The Nixon family worshiped together at Mother's Day services in the White House after Mrs. Nixon got a big box of choco late candy from daughters Julie and Tricia.

title: Article 4  No Title
Mercury Spills Imperil Erie Fisheries
description: RENO BEACH, OhioFor 40 years, George Frank has set his nets in Lake Erie each spring and has brought in up to $50,000 worth of white bass, perch and walleye.

title: Operators Stage Stoppage In Phone Company Dispute
description: Local and long distance oper ators for the New York Tele phone Company staged a one day work stoppage yesterday to put pressure on the company in a wage dispute.

title: Fleming Wins A.A.U. Run
description: Toni Fleming of Peterson State College won the sixmile Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union development run yester day at Van Cortlandt Park in 31 minutes 51 seconds.

title: N.L. AllStar List
description: First basemenRichie Allen, St. Louis; Ernie Banks, Chicago; Orlando Cepeda, At lanta; Lee May, Cincinnati; Willie McCovey, San Francisco; Wes Parker, Los Angees.

title: BOUVIER IS BEST A 2D DAY IN ROW
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 10An 85pound silver gray Bouvier des Flandres, Ch. Naris du Posty Arlequin, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Collier of Irvington  on  the  Hudson, N. Y., today won his second bestinshow award in two days at the 26th annual Windham County Kennel Club show and obedience trial at Recreation Park. There were 1,398 dogs in the show.

title: U.S.C. WILL ALLOW NOPENALTY PROTEST
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (UPI) The University of Southern California has approved a plan for students to drop out of classes and protest United States policies in Indochina without being penalized aca demically.

title: NO MASS RALLIES SEEN LIKELY SOON
description: WASHINGTON, May 10In the aftermath of the disorgan ized, almost spontaneous anti war rally here yesterday, plans were being made here and elsewhere for further acts of protest.

title: Reuther's Successor in Doubt as Auto Talks Near
description: DETROIT, May 10Emil Mazey, the 56yearold sec retarytreasurer of the United Auto Workers, assumes the duties of the late Walter P. Reuther within the union, but no sucessor is clearly visible yet.

title: Title Surfing Postponed
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, May 10 (AP)The men's and wom en's world surfboard riding championships at Bells Beach were postponed today because pf unsatisfactory surf.

title: Walter Reuther: Union Pioneer With Broad Influence Far Beyond the Field of Labor
description: Walter Philip Reuther went to work as a bench hand at the age of 16 and rose to be come a labor leader who had a major impact on the eco nomic, social and political af fairs of his time.

title: Campus Communicator
description: The man President Nixon has chosen as his adviser on campus problems for the next two months is regarded as especially adept at open ing channels of communica tion among students, school administrators and public of ficials.

title: Planned Parenthood Names Chief Executive Officer
description: John C. Robbins, an oil com pany executive and former newspaperman and writer, has been named chief executive of ficer of Planned Parenthood World Population.

title: Irish Sports Results
description: FOOTBALL

title: Changes in Rent Control Urged by Business Group
description: The Economic Development Council of New York City, an organization of businessmen concerned with urban problems, called yesterday for major changes in rent control to ease the city's housing shortage. It said the shortage represents a serious threat to economic growth and employment.

title: U.S. Officer Near Ferry
description: KOKI THOM, Cambodia, May 10A South Vietnamese hell copeter, carrying two generals and an American colonel, landed in a field near this vil lage 30 miles southeast of Pnonmpenh this morning and established the first contact west of the Mekong between South Vietnamese and Cam bodian troops driving toward the river from opposite direc tions.

title: C.B.S. FUND AWARDS JOURNALISM GRANTS
description: Five broadcast journalists have been named C. B. S. Foun dation News Fellows for the 197071 academic year by C. B.S. Foundation, the organi zation through which the Co lumbia Broadcasting System makes educational, cultural and philanthropic contributions.

title: YORKIE IS SELECTED REST AT LANCASTER
Record Heat of 93 Jams Traffic Here; High 80's Due Today
description: The temperature soared to 93 degrees, a record for the date, here yesterday, creating major highway tieups from over heated cars and sending thou sands of sweltering New York ers to nearby beaches.

title: 27 STATES RELAX MARIJUANA LAWS
description: In about twothirds of the 50 states, drug abuse laws cov ering the possession of mari juana have been or are in the process of being revised to ease the penalties for first of fenders.

title: AntiU.S. Protest in Paris
description: PARIS, May 10A throng of Parisians filled a great meadow in the park of Vincennes today to protest the American inter vention in Cambodia. Sharing the platform with Communist and Socialist leaders were Xuan Thuy, head of the Notrh Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks, and Vietcong and Cambodian supporters of Prince Novodom Sihanouk.

title: Arbitrator Shares Soot, Perils And Cold Meal With Firemen
description: We got a run, let's go, cried the lieutenant. The bells clanged, the siren wailed, 10 firemen climbed aboard Engine No. 59 and Eric J. Schmertz was still struggling to put on his boots.

title: Herbert Hoff, Psychiatrist, ExArmy Officer, Dies at 62
description: Herbert Hoff, Psychiatrist, ExArmy Officer, Dies at 62

title: AUSSIE TAKES 2D, GAINS POINT LEAD
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 10In this land of movie land princesses and makebe lieve castles an automobile race had a storybook finish today. For Jack Brabham, the ending wasn't happy.

title: Insurance Acquisition Set
description: The Beneficial National Cor poration announced this week end that its offer to acquire the Beneficial National Life Insur ance Company had become ef fective. Over 80 per cent of the stock of Beneficial National Life has been deposited under the exchange offer, which expires tomorrow.

title: Gospel Group Leaves 8th Ave. For East Side After 80 Years
description: The Gospel Tabernacle, for more than 80 years a place of worship at Eighth Avenue and 44th Street, has moved cross town to new quarters on the East Side.

title: Mannes College to Raise Funds At Concert and Reception Friday
description: When the Mannes College of Music holds its benefit at the Institute of International Education on Friday the ap petizer will be a Grieg sonata, the dessert will be a piano quartet by Gabriel Faure and the champagne will be, well, champagne.

title: New Books
description: Babel. by Alan Burns (John Day, $4.95). A novel depicting confu sions of current language.

title: '69 GAINS LAGGED AT BIG COMPANIES
description: While 1969 was a record year for the nation's economy, it was not a great year by any conventional standard for the 500 largest industrial corpora tions according to information made available today by the Fortune Directory.

title: College to Honor Israeli
description: Shoshana Damari, the Israeli singer, will receive a citation from Gratz College of Philadel phia on Friday for her dedica tion to Israel at a reception at the college. The citation will be presented by Mrs. David J. Dean, chairman of music and a member of the board of over seers of the college, which offers a Bachelor of Arts degree in Hebrew and Hebrew literature.

title: GEN. ERIK NELSON, EARLY FLIER, DIES
description: Brig. Gen. Erik Henning Nel son, an aviator whose career spanned the years from the barnstormers to the B29s and who won fame in the first roundtheworld flight in 1924, died Saturday of cancer in Honolulu. His age was 81.

title: A House That Divides A City May Not Stand
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont.  It may look more historic in 100 years, but today Charles M. Russell's house just look old. The twostory, plain wooden building sits empty and cold, its white paint peeling, next to the more glamorous log cabin where Mr. Russell once painted his scenes of cowboy and Indi an life. And next to that is the even more strik ing modern build ing that houses the C. M. Russell Gallery.

title: Print Festival to Aid TeenAgers
description: The Print Festival, a sup per dance, will be held on Thursday in Rockefeller Cen ter's lower plaza. The Amer ican Printed Fabrics Council has taken over both Promen ade restaurants for the even ing. A tent will be set up for dancing.

title: Samuels and O'Dwyer Call Liberal Party's Endorsement Rigged
description: Two Democratic hopefuls, despairing of being chosen, charged yesterday that the spe cial Liberal party meeting to night to fill two vacancies on its slate was rigged for Arth ur J. Goldberg and Senator Charles E. Goodell.

title: Catholic Actors Award
description: The Catholic Actors Guild will present its first George M. Cohan Award to the Rev. Gil bert V. Hartke, chairman of the speech and drama department of the Catholic University of America, Washington, at its an nual Communion Brunch next Sunday at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

title: Books of The Times
description: NEAR the end of this memoirauto biography, the author recalls an afternoon in New York City in the nineteenfifties. He was down from Har vard, and he joined his father for lunch at the St. Regis. Afterwards, they spent a few hours shopping, then decided to stop for a drink at 21. They talked about this and that for a while: the son's sister's boyfriends, an old story of the father's that Es quire was about to publish. One of the restaurant's owners stopped to ask why the father didn't drop in any more. As they were leaving, a voice boomed out, calling the father. It was Hemingway. They stopped and the father talked with him for a while. The son remem bers a kindness that seemed to exist between the two men, in the resonance of the voices, in the eyes, in the echoes that moved back and forth across the tablecloth. As they parted, Hemingway said to the father, I still owe you a favor, Michael. Out on 52d Street, the son asked his father what Hemingway meant about the favor. Oh that, he said he laughed. A nice laugh. An old private joke, he said. One autumn in Paris I introduced Ernest to a girl I was with, he said. Duff Twysden. Ernest later made that book around her. You know: Lady Brett. We turned on Fifth and headed north, uptown. At some time or other everybody was in love with Duff Twysden, he said.

title: Students in Washington

The leaders of the demonstration assisted by raising their voices effectively for moderation, while the numerous young marshals from the ranks of the demonstrators helped snuff out sparks of trouble before they could spread. President Nixon, too, aided the cause of orderly protest by his wise change of tone and rhetoric toward those who dissent from his Cambodia and Vietnam policies.

title: Nascent Liberal Played By Mastroianni in 'Leo'
description: JOHN BOORMAN'S "Leo the Last" begins as comedy of elegant sensibilities, ends as reasonable imitation of guerrilla theater and touches a few more bases along the way than it needs or has really earned. From "Prufrock" to protest; from individual alienation to community action  its themes sound, and indeed feel, like the material for a study in the dilemma of modern man. And like many such studies, "Leo the Last" indulges in a certain measure of intellectual opportunism.Leo (Marcello Mastroianni), living in London, the last remnant of some unspecified European aristocracy, watches through a spyglass from behind his windows the tough and vital life of the largely blackslum immediately outside his front door. Much inhibited by his own tendency to inaction and restrained by the attentions of his fiance (Billie Whitelaw) and a household full of ancien rgime servants, advisers and hangers-on, he nevertheless leans toward the slum people, especially toward the Madi family, their neighbors, and their daughter (Glenna Forster Jones).A series of crises, observed and experienced, finally enable him to break free, to champion the slum people (he discovers with horror that he is their landlord), and to fight with them in a glorious street assault against his own stately mansion.Involved as it is with the esthetics of commitment, the film's plot remains a liberal's wish-fulfillment fantasy to the endthe wicked patron becoming the good patron, the voyeur becoming the activist without ever really violating the shell of his own impotence. But some fantasies are better than others, and those in "Leo the Last" manage to pick up a lot of life along the way.Boorman has set his film largely in tones of black, blue and grayin everything extending from the stock of the local supermarket, to the pigeons overhead (nature's gift to the moviemaker), to the dcor of Leo's highly theatrical mansion. Because it proclaims itself theater, the film keeps discovering theatrical and cinematic sources of vitalityespecially in the streets, in the dumb-show joys and miseries of the distantly observed Madi family, and in the incredibly elaborate and often shockingly beautiful program of optics that accompanies Leo's secret life as voyeur.Also accompanying that life is a most engagingly shy and sensitive Marcello Mastroianni, in a performance of great self-effacing intelligence. Everybody around him is good, but the black family across the way, that is not even heard until near the end, is superb. Glenna Forster Jones  skinny, sexy, bright and toughwould by herself be reason for going to any movie. And Boorman seems to excel in sensing where his actors most vividly and subtly meet the characters he has in mind.Boorman, who won aknowledgeable cult following for crime in "Point Blank" (1967) and then lost with allegory in "Hell in the Pacific" (1968), should get some of it back with "Leo the Last."It is worth remembering that, unfashionably, he prefers big to small subjects, that he is a persistent and sometimes overbearing moralist, and that, together with Peter Suschitzky, the cinematographer, he has developed a visual technique that might be more moving if it were less dazzling. But even where he fails, and sometimes most excitingly where he seems bound to fail, in his newest movie he reveals a taste for profitable risk-taking that is a characteristic of the very best directors.

title: BANK HOPES TO RAISE LATINAREA LENDING

He renewed his re cent appeal to the Pathet Lao for serious peace negotiations.

Conn., and Tannah Hirsch of Stam ford, Conn., and the league's operations manager, Alan Oaks at Stamford, combined with Chuck Lamprey of White Plains and went through the competition unbeaten.

title: Striking Nurses and Doctors Protest at St. Peter's in Rome

description: The Treasury statement and some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations are omitted from this issue because of compos ing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Housing Gets Narcotic Unit
description: Simeon Gular, the Housing Authority chairman, announced yesterday the formation of a I4member narcotics squad within the 1,500men Housing Authority police department.

title: Japanese Banks to Loan $50Million to Philippines
description: TOKYO, May 11 (AP)A consortium of 15 Japanese banks extended a standby credit line of $50million to the Philippine Central Bank today.

title: NIXON EXPLAINS CAMBODIA POLICY TO 45 GOVERNORS
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Nixon conferred today with 45 state and territorial governors to press his search for ways of improving commu nication with the academic com Msiunity and to explain his deci on on Cambodia.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Common Market Cuts Executive To Nine, With Italian to Be Head
description: BRUSSELS, May 11  The six European Common Market countries decided today to re duce the Executive Commission from the present 14 members to 9 and replace its president, Jean Rey of Belgium, by an Italian, still to be named.

title: Coast Guard Rise Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill that would increase from 400 to 600 the number of cadets who may be appointed to the Coast Guard Academy at New London, Conn.

title: ADAPTOR TO MISS GOOD TIME PACE
description: YONKERS, May 11  Next Friday night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway will have to get along without Irving W. Berkemeyer's Aus tralianbred Adaptor. The 7 yearold stallion, acquired last season for $125,000, was de clared out of the Good Time today and replaced by Abra ham Schultz's Armbro Harvey.

title: Princeton and Columbia Hit by Rule on Athlete Protests
description: The Eastern Intercollegiate Tennis and Baseball Associa tions, consisting of the eight Ivy League colleges, Army and Navy, decided yesterday that any team refusing to play a league engagement as a result of current student strikes and protests must forfeit that match.

title: Mrs. Theodorakis And Two Children Escape to France
description: PARIS, May 11  The wife of Mikis Theodorakis, the Greek composer, and their two chil dren have escaped to Paris from Greece, it was announced here tonight.

title: Tea for 2 Saves 2 Britons
description: LONDON (Canadian Press) A cup of tea probably saved the lives of Jim Miller, 60 years old, and his wife Ivy, 58. They had taken a break for tea from painting their front parlor when a heavy truck crashed through a wall and wrecked the room seconds after they left it.

title: Wholesale Prices Held Steady In April After 18Month Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)Wholesale prices held, steady in April for the first) time in IS months, the Govern ment reported today.

title: 4 Nassau Food Stores Agree To Labeling Plan for Meat
description: Four major food retailers in Nassau County consented yes terday not to continue an al leged practice of mislabeling cuts of meat.

title: Indian Riot Deaths Put at 90
description: NEW DELHI, May 11The death toll in HinduMoslem riots in Maharashtra state last week end has risen to 90, officials reported today. Home Minister Y. B. Chavan announced that a judicial inquiry had been or dered.

title: High Court in India Upholds Election of Giri as President
description: NEW DELHI, May 11The Supreme Court today upheld the election of V. V. Giri as President of India. Five judges, dismissed a petition for inval idating the election last August on the ground that Mr. Giri, wh is 76 years old, had won be cause of malpractices.

title: Denver Enterpriser Carries Big Ideas in a Big Frame
description: Denver has numerous claims to fame, but high among them is the fact that it has two famous John Kingsboth oil millionaires.

title: Belgian Cardinal Criticizes Pope on Celibacy Stand
description: PARIS, May 11Leo Car dinal Suenens of Belgium criti cized Pope Paul VI today for having refused to submit the question of priestly celibacy to free discussion among the Roman Catholic bishops.

title: Israelis Celebrate 22d Independence Day in a Joyful and Prankish Hubbub
description: JERUSALEM, May 11 Mayor Teddy Kollek elbowed his way up Salmon Street, hung with strings of lights and jammed with people celebrating Israel's 22d inde pendence day. In this country, holidays begin the night be fore, and Jerusalem started celebrating at 7 o'clock last night with a long siren blast.

title: COLLEGIANS WARN CONGRESS ON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Student protests against the war in Southeast Asia moved from the noisy streets to the quieter confines of Congres sional hearing rooms and the State Department today.

title: Knicks Vote Doctor's Family $7,400
description: During the National Basket ball Association playoffs the New York Knicks received a sentimental letter from Dr. Eu genia Yanagisawa and her five children, wishing the team well. Mrs. Yanagisawa, a gynecolo gist, is the widow of Dr. Kazuo Yanagisawa, the Knicks' phy sician who died Feb. 22 of heart attack. The club displ played the letter prominently in the dressing room.

title: Lead Poison Worst Ever At 260 Cases
description: Physicians have reported 260 cases of lead poisoning in chil dren to the New York City Health Department during the first four months of this year  more than for any other comparable period.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS VOLUME EASES
description: I should have stayed in bed. This comment by a floor broker on the American Stock Exchange neatly summarized its activities yesterday as prices continued to decline while volume dropped to its lowest level in almost three and a half years.

title: Many Colleges Reopen, but Students at 158 Schools Are on Strike Indefinitely
description: Many of the nation's colleges and universities reopened for classes yesterday, but students at 158 institutions were report ed still on strike indefinitely.

title: TONE STAYS FIRM IN LONDON STOCKS
Actress Held at Fort Hood
description: KILLEEN, Tex., May 11 (UPI) Jane Fonda, the actress, was arrested today by a military police lieutenant for trying to disctribute antiwar handbills at Fort Hood. Lieut. John T. Hoff man arrested her at the east gate of the tankers' training center, put her in a military po lice car and drove her to the provost marshal's office, where she was read a letter perma nently barring her from the post. Then she was escorted outside and released.

title: JACKSON REBUFFED BY SEATTLE PARTY
description: SEATTLE, May 11  The King County Democratic Con vention has refused to endorse Senator Henry M. Jackson for reelection to his fourth term.

title: JERSEY VOTE PUTS WATERFRONT UNIT INTO AIRPORT ROLE
description: TRENTON, May 11  In another move against organ ized crime, the New Jersey As sembly voted today to extend the anticrime jurisdiction of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to the major jet ports in the New York metro politan area.

title: Computer Pairs Old Mates
description: BUDAPEST (AP)The com puter in the Budapest marriage bureau whirred and slipped out a card to an applicant seeking a wife, but the suggestion was rejected. This is the woman I married three years ago, the applicant told a clerk. We qarreled and parted.

title: 5 Police Groups Rebut Critical Mayor
description: The leaders of five Police Department organization yes terday accused Mayor Lindsay of undermining the confi dence of the public in its Po lice Department.

title: Yorkshire Is Not Wonton
description: LEEDS, England (UPI) Judges have declared Tin Sung Chan, a Chinese immigrant, the champion chef of Yorkshire Pudding. It's shamful, pro tested Mrs. Doris Marshal, one of Yorkshires own, who com plained that Mr. Chan had spiced his huge round pudding with an oriental herb.

title: Lasker and DeNunzio Reelected at Big Board
description: Bernard J. Lasker, senior partner of Lasker, Stone & Stern, was reelected yesterday as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange to serve his second oneyear term.

title: In Memoriam
description: PENSIGDr. Arnold W.Eleven long sad years, darling since you left us. We miss you so.

title: Fanny May Results Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Mortgage prices declined at this week's auction of the Federal National Mortgage Associ ation for the first time since January, the association disclosed today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DURING the closing stages of a bas ketball season that lingered with distracting persistence into the month of May, Walter Alston tiptoed un obtrusively into town with his Dodgers last week and just as unobtrusively tip toed out again. No one noticed him espe cially, probably because he's the kind of guy who just blends into the scenery.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: The New York Athletic Club won the Whelan Cup for senior eights in the sixth annual Fa ther knickerbocker regatta on the Orchard Beach Lagoon yes terday. St. John's University was second after leading for the first 500 meters.

title: Ballet: Antoinette Sibley in Giselle
description: IT is amazing that Antoinette Sibley had never danced Giselle for the main company of the Royal Ballet until Sun day afternoon at the Metro politan Opera House. She had danced a couple of perform ances with the Royal Ballet's smaller company during a South African tour about nine years ago and a little later made a guest appear anc ewith Walter Gore's Lon don Ballet but she has vet to dance Giselle in London.

title: Andretti Is Uninjured After New Car Crashes
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 11 (UPI)Mario Andretti, win ner of the Indianapolis 500 mile race last year, narrowly escaped injury today in a crash that occurred at the same place as the one that forced him to use his backup car in the 1969 race.

title: Withdrawal of One Candidate Reduces the Field to Six for Mayoral Election in Newark Today
description: NEWARK, May 11With the field of candidates suddenly narrowed from seven to six, 85,000 Newark voters are ex pected to go to the polls to morrow in the city's mayoral election. And for the first time, it is possible that the Mayor will be a black man, al though he might have to face a runoff election on June 16 in the event that no candidate gets 50 per cent of the votes tomorrow.

title: NATO Weighs Proposal To Soviet on Troop Cuts
description: ROME, May 10The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is considering a proposal that the Soviet Union reduce its forces in Central Europe by 30 per cent in return for a 10 per cent cut in Allied troop strength.

title: M'GINN TRIUMPHS ON THREEHITTER
description: Not even Torn Seaver, super symbol and charismatic leader of the New York Mets, can win a game if his team doesn't scoreand he can't even get a tie if he doesn't pitch a shut out.

title: BarBending Is a Reducer
description: PETERBOROUGH, England (Canadian Press)Wally Cor nelius, a muscleman, has come out of retirement on doctor's orders. His specialty was smash ing 2inch slabs of concrete on his head. When he put on too much weight, he was ordered to bend a few iron bars again to keep slimmer.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
JOHN M. RUGH
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., May 11 John M. Rugh, a chemist, for merly general manager of the American Cyanamid Company, Linden, died yesterday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived at 864 Boulevard. He re tired several years ago.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) The Pentagon today identi fied the following men from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SUIT BY LEFCOURT
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a suit by a lawyer, Gerald B. Lefcourt, against the Legal Aid Society for dismiss ing him, allegedly because he criticized its handling of indi gent defendants' cases.

title: Anvelings
description: GOLDMANNicholas N. The unveiling in memory of Nicholas N. Goldman will be held PROMPTLY at 1:30 P.M., Sunday, May 17, 1970, at Beth Israel Memorial Park, Rte 1, Woodridge, N.J., block 10A, section 6. His friends are asked to attend. No postponement.

title: 4 Dead, Guard Called In Augusta Disorder
description: AUGUST, Ga., Tuesday, May 12Four Negroes were re ported shot to death and 20 persons wounded today in ra cial violence marked by burn ing, looting and sniper fire.

title: Lindsay Says 5c Ride To S.I. Costs City 43c
description: Mayor Lindsay released yesterday a study asserting that every passenger ride op the Staten Island ferry is sub sidized 43 cents by the city's taxpayers.

title: SOUTH AFRICA FACES NEW CURB IN TENNIS
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP) South Africa, already suspended from the Davis Cup, faces a new struggle to keep her tennis stars on the world tournament circuit next year.

title: LAIRD REAFFIRMS PULLBACK DATES
description: DETROIT, May 11  Secre tary of Defense Melvin R. Laird emphasized today that Ameri can troop withdrawals from Cambodia would follow Presi dentn Nixon's schedule despite complaints from officers in the field that all occupied territory might not be searched in time.

title: U.S. Auto Census Projected
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI)There will be 158.6 million auto mobiles, trucks and buses regis tered in the United States by 1990, the Keystone Auto Club predicts, a 51.4 per cent in crease over the estimated 1969 total of 104.7 million.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, May 11, 1970

title: Railroad Official Foresees Women in Executive Posts
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. (UPI)Tomorrow's rail road executives will come in large measure from the ranks of women, according to Emil Jesse, a railroad official, speak ing at the annual meeting of the National Association of Railway Business Women.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: INQUIRY IN JERSEY MAY BE EXPANDED
description: JERSEY CITY, May 11The United States Attorney's office is expected to increase the number of subpoenas served on officials of Mayor Thomas J. Whelan's acrministration in an inquiry into crime and al leged corruption in Hudson County informed sources said here today.

title: Market Place
description: BACK in the exhilarating bull market days of 1967, the gogo fund could do no wrong, and investors eagerly sought out the hottest per formers in their quest for overnight riches.

title: French Draft Wide Environment Plan
description: PARIS, May 11  French Government authorities have made public wideranging plans to improve their country's en vironment  including a cam paign to rid Paris streets of excessively noisy cars.

title: Corrigall Spurns N.F.L.
description: TORONTO, May 11 (AP) Jim Corrigall, a former Kent State star who was drafted sec ond by the St. Louis Cardinals, rejected the National Football League club today and signed two oneyear contracts with the Toronto Argonauts of the East ern Football Conference.

title: Roundup: Veale Throttles Reds for Pirates by 41
description: The way the Cincinnati Reds have been hitting plus the way Bob Veale has been pitching figured to add up to an easy Cincinnati victory over Pittsburgh last night, even in new math.

title: Dr. Pepper Moves Into New York
description: Although Dr. Pepper has been promising for a week on television and radio that it will be bringing its soft drink to the New York market on May 18, it really didn't become official until yesterday. That's when they had the press lunch.

title: Japan Exports Rose in April
description: TOKYO, May 11 (Reuters) The Japanese Trade and Indus try Ministry said here today that, according to figures on bank certificates of export declarations, Japanese exports rose to $1,542,620.000 in April from $1,298,370,000 in April, 1969. The Ministry also said that Japan's imports, based or import licenses during April amounted to $1,364,070,000 ur from $1,308,404,000 in imports in the corresponding month of 1969.

title: Hanoi's Chief Delegate Leaves Paris for Home
description: PARIS, May 11  Xuan Thuy, the chief North Viet namese representative at the Paris peace talks, left for Hanoi today, declaring that settlement could not be reached until President Nixon abandoned his policy based on a position of strength.

title: Hearing Set on 3d Ave. Zoning Plan
description: The City Planning Commis sion will conduct a public hear ingat City Hall tomorrow on its controversial proposal for a Special Lower Third Avenue Development District.

title: Customs Courthouse Is Opened
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger dedicated the United States Customs Courthouse here yesterday, praising the building's design and calling it an inspiration to the people who worked there.

title: ITALY ELIMINATED IN DAVIS CUP, 32
description: TURIN, Italy, May 11 (UPI) Czechoslovakia advanced to the second round of the European zone Davis Cup eliminations by winning the final two singles today for a 32 victory over Italy.

title: Senator Brings Out Cattle  for a Party
description: CARTHAGE, Tenn.Mrs. Albert Gore, wife of the Tennessee Senator, is used to giving dinner parties without knowing whether 100 or 1,000 will sit down to eat.

title: Goldberg and Goodell Backed By Liberals' State Committee
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, a Demo cratic candidate for Governor, and Senator Charles E. Goodell, a Republican seeking election to a full term in Washington, were endorsed last night by the Liberal party's state committee.

title: Writers to Hear Gerstacker
description: The New York Financial Writers' Association will hold its annual spring dinner on Wednesday, June 3, at the Americana Hotel. The speaker will be Carl A. Gerstacker, chairman of the Dow Chemical Company. He will analyze the disruptions facing corporations lat their annual meetings.

title: Kansas Students Plan To Thank Taxpayers
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 11 (UPI)A group of Washburn University students is plan ning an appreciation day Friday to thank taxpayers for the privilege of going to col lege.

title: Children's TV Programing Heads for F.C.C. Test
description: A survey of what is called excessive commercialism on children's TV programs has been filed with the Federal Communications Commission by Action for Children's Television, a Bostonbased group of women who are seeking to upgrade children's network programing.

title: LLOYD BURNS DIES; TV FILM EXECUTIVE
description: Lloyd Burns, executive vices president of the Screen Gems division of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., died in London Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 565 Park Avenue.

title: ROBERT E. BAKER
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 11 Robert Elmer Baker, the for mer president of Baker Perkins, Inc., died yesterday at his home here at 50 Popham Road. He was 85 years old.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ADVANCES IN WEEK
description: Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,618,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute re ported yesterday.

title: In The Nation: Mr. Nixon's Scary Dreams
description: WASHINGTON, May 11In his televised address on the war last Nov. 3, President Nix on declared that a precipi tate American withdrawal from South Vietnam would inevi tably allow the Communists to repeat the massacres which followed their takeover in the north fifteen years before. They then murdered more than 50,000 people and hundreds of thou sands more died in slave labor camps.

title: Haliburton Fates Is Dead at 85; Partner in Wall Street House
description: Halihurton Fales, former se nior partner of Hay, Fales & Co., investment brokers at 71 Broad way, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the Miami Heart In stitute. Mr. Fales, who was re tired, lived in Key Biscayne, Fla., maintained an apartment in New York at 1075 Perk Ave nue and had a summer resi Idence in Branford, Conn. He was 85 years old.

title: Nixon Designates 17 As Special Fellows At the White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Seventeen persons ranging from military officers to lawyers and teachers were ap pointed today to be White House Fellows for a year as special assistants to the Presi dent's staff and Cabinet mem bers.

title: Miss Lawson To Be a Bride
description: William V. Lawson, presi dent of the George A. Fuller Company, construction, and Mrs. Lawson of New York have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Crandall Lawson, to Kenneth Mark Lewis 3d, son of Mrs. Lewis Jr. of New York and the late Dr. Lewis, a physician. The wedding is planned for June 13.

title: Books of The Times
description: SASHA JANSEN is that woman in the fur coat, somewhat over 40 years old, sitting at the bar of a Paris tabac, drinking pernod and pretending she will soon be off to the cinema.
