Perhaps she is a tourist: on the surface, une femme con venable; inside, a mind full of helpless ness, compulsions, selfloathing, moth eaten memories and violence. If Sasha's mind is not a nice place to visit, imagine what it's like for the woman who must live there.

title: SCOA Plans to Modernize
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11 (UPI)  SCOA Industries, Inc., announced today a $6.5million, 30month program to modern ize 300 shoe stores. The pro gram includes changing the name of the stores from the Schiff Shoe Stores to the Gal lenkemp Stores. This will put all of the company's 480 stores under the same name and per mit national advertising, SCOA said.

title: Taft Margin Is Put at 4,347
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11 (UPI)  Representative Robert Taft Jr., Republican of Ohio, defeated Gov. James A. Rhodes by 4,347 votes in the primary last Tuesday, final unofficial figures showed today. Secre tary of State Ted W. Brown, released figures giving Mr. Taft 470,294 votes and Mr. Rhodes, 465,947.

title: Martha Rockefeller Music Fund: Story of Quiet Help
description: A glimpse at one of the most generous, flexible and sustained musical philan thropies by an individual in America has become possible with the publication of the first report by the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music, Inc., since its founding in 1962.

title: Britons Fight for Love Path
description: BECK ROW, England (UPI) Two hundred villagers signed a petition to a local land com mission, protesting that a 12 acre park about to be sold by the commission included a path used by generations of Beck Row residents as a lovers' lane.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: GLADSTONE HODGE, BROOKLYN SURGEON
description: Dr. Gladstone Hodge, a sur geon, died, apparently of a heart attack, Saturday in his home at 1267 Carroll Street, Brooklyn. He was 55 years old.

title: U. S. SST Commitment May Increase by $3Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 James M. Beggs, the Under Sec retary of Transportation, said today that he would ask for Governmentbacked loans to start production of the super sonic transport if ordinary pri vate financing were unavailable.

title: JOHNNY HODGES, JAZZ SOLOIST, 63
description: Johnny Hodges, a longtime alto saxophonist with Duke El lington's band, died yesterday in Manhattan. He had collapsed in a dentist's office. He was 63, years old and lived at 170 West End Avenue.

title: SENATE UNITVOTES TO RESTRICT FUNDS IN CAMBODIA WAR
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 Over State Department ob jections that Congress was proposing to restrict the Presi dent's constitutional powers as Commander in Chief, the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee approved an amendment today to cut off funds for fu ture American military activi ties in Cambodia.

title: Maddox Scores Media
description: ATLANTA, May 11 (UPI) Gov. Lester G. Maddox charged today that news media cover age of campus protests had served to cause violence and a continuation of disturbances at the nation's colleges. He called on the news media to cover the activities of decent, re sponsible students instead of devoting energies to activities of what he called the hippies, parasites, and anarchists and long hairs.

title: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)
description: TAMINENT, Pa., May 10Al Merrill, the Nordic Program Di rector for the United States Ski Association since 1968 and a national head coach since 1963, resigned today effective July 1.

title: WITNESS FOR LOOK SCORED AT TRIAL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 Final arguments were made to day in Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's libel action against Look maga zine and it was expected that the jury would be instructed in law and begin its delibera tions tomorrow.

title: Common Market to Meet With Britain and Others
description: BRUSSELS, May 11 (AP)  Foreign Ministers of the Euro pean Economic Community countries have agreed in princi ple to hold their first negotia tions with Britain and other membership candidates in Lux embourg June 30, Foreign Min ister Joseph Luns of the Neth erlands said today.

title: Park Ave. Fire Halts 37 Trains; Riders Get Off and Add to Delay
description: A rubbish fire on the Penn Central tracks at Park Avenue and 96th Street yesterday morning snarled rail traffic in and out of Grand Central Ter minal.

title: Hanoi Party Chief Begins Peking Talks
description: HONG KONG, May 11Le Duan, the head of North Viet nam's Communist party, ar rived in Peking today from Moscow to pursue what was believed here to be a new ef fort to promote unity of ac tion on Indochina by the So viet Union and Communist China.

title: Opposition Party in Seoul Ends Boycott of Assembly
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 11  The Opposition New Demo cratic party ended a seven month boycott of the National Assembly today when its mem bers attended the opening meet ing of a special 30day session.

title: American Regitel System
description: The American Regitel Cor poration introduced yesterday a new electronic pointofsale transaction system aimed at mediumsize retail stores. The system consists or a network of electronic cash registers with their own local minicomputers.

title: GLEAMING SWORD WINS AT AQUEDUCT
description: Gleaming Sword made a pow erful bid for handicap consid eration in taking the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5yearold colt, owned by Sarah Hall, staged a strong stretch rally to take the 1mile con test by a head over Barometer, who had five lengths on Never Bow, next in the field of five.

title: Brewer Leads by 5,908
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 11 (AP)Gov. Albert P. Brewer's margin over former Gov. George C. Wallace in the Democratic, primary apparently is the small est in a Governor's race in Ala bama in 40 years. Unofficial returns today gave Mr. Brewer a lead of 5,908 votes in the party election May 5. In 1930, B. M. Miller won the Demo cratic nomination with a margin of 5,421 votes over W. C. Davis.

title: Market Averages
description: Monday, May 11, 1970

title: Impatient City Judge
description: IN his unsuccessful 1962 I campaign to become New York's Attorney General and the first statewide Negro of ficeholder, Edward R. Dudley characterized himself as an impatient man. I'm impa tient with the affairs of the world, he said. I don't think they're moving fast enough. For most Man of his varied ca in the reer, Mr. Dudley's impatience has been an asset, en abling him to work decisively and move on. Over the years, he has been a teacher, lawyer, civil rights worker, ambassador, bor ough president and judge.

title: Union to Picket City U. Branches Over Dismissal of Lecturers
description: The United Federation of College Teachers, collective bargaining agent for about 6,000 untenured faculty mem bers of the City University, plans to set up picket lines to day a three colleges and the Graduate Division in a contract dispute with the Board of Higher Education.

title: Kuhn Supports College Coaches In Desire to Change Draft Rule
description: Bowie Kuhn, Commissioner of Baseball, promised yesterday that he would put his weight behind ending the professional draft of college players.

title: Hospital for Special Surgery Plans Benefit
description: The Hospital for Special Surgery has arranged theater party at the Royal Ballet's performance next Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Cen ter.

title: Woman Sues Mt. Kisco Hospital After Being Denied Sterilization
description: A Westchester woman filed suit in Federal Court here yes terday against a hospital in Mount Kisco which allegedly refused to allow a sterilization operation, even though she had requested it and her doctors were ready to perform it.

title: 2 Auto Makers Contend Air Bag Tests Need Years
description: MILFORD, Mich., May 11 Air bags, the major innovation to protect auto passengers from injury since the seat belt, will require many more years of laboratory testing before they become standard equipment, representatives of two major. United States automobile mak ers said today.

title: 58 IN MICHIGAN HELD IN BIG GAMBLING RAID
description: DETRIOT, May 11 (AP) More than 200 F.B.I. agents staged a series of raids in De Itroit and Flint, Mich., today in an effort to smash what Federal officials described as a numbers operation with a daily handle of $250,000.

title: Expos' Britton Faces Surgery
description: MONTREAL, May 11 (AP) Jim Britton of the Montreal Ex pos will enter a hospital in Houston tomorrow for surgery on his right elbow. The right bander was put on the disabled list April 7 and has not pitched for Montreal since spring train ing.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Seeks to Calm Indian Parliament Members Who See Insult in Agnew Remark
description: NEW DELHI, May 1Prime Minister Indira Gandhi pleaded with angry members of Parlia ment today to ignore remarks of Vice President Spiro Agnew about Cambodia and the Inter national Control Commission, of which Indira is chairman.

title: Nader Brands Ads Of Large Concerns As Massive Lying
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 Ralph Nader, the advocate of consumers' rights, today criticized some of the largest American corporations, in cluding General Motors, for indulging in what he called massive lying in their ad vertising in order to give major stress to areas in which they are weakest.

title: Designed Here, Made in Haiti
description: THOSE who recall Gretta Plattry's sure hand with sportswear may remember that when she first started in business back in '41, her forte was handcrocheted dresses she designed and had made by European im migrants. Now, nearly 30 years later, Miss Plattry's daughter, Gabri elle Spellman, has a new yen ture called Ga bretta Boutique, at 355 East 61st Street (between First and Second Avenues) featuring her mother's designs hand crocheted in Haiti.

title: Perot Honored as Patriot
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP) About 1,000 personsamong them Vietnam War veterans, wives of prisoners of war and college students  turned out last night at a dinner to honor H. Ross Perot, the Texas mil lionaire, as patriot of the year for his efforts to obtain thenames of prisoners of war being held by Hanoi.

title: Paduano Gets Unanimous Decision Over Cerdan in 10Round Bout at Garden
description: In his American boxing de but, Marcel Cerdan. Jr. showed himself to be a thoroughbred son of a thoroughbred father. But even a thoroughbred loses sometime.

title: FINE ARTS QUARTET PLAYS BEETHOVEN
description: It is always an interesting ex ercise in historical perspective; to hear Beethoven's B flat String Quartet (Op. 130) with the Grosse fuge finale that the composer originally meant it to have, instead of the rela tively uncomplicated Allegro that he was persuaded to sub stitute. And as the Fine Arts Quartet presented it Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, it was also quite convincing, in spite of the strain that the great fugue's difficulties put on the ear at times.

title: Policeman Says Panther Shot at Him
description: A black policeman testified yesterday that he was shot at when he approached a car in which one of 13 Black Panthers accused of conspiring to bomb public places was seated. The bullet hit a summons pouch over his hip, he said.

title: Observer: This Very Final Kind of Game
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 President Nixon says he is not going to be the first President to lose a war. Before him Presi dent Johnson said the same. This is sports talk. Easy to make fun of, but not so easily disposed of because the notion of war as the ultimate game is a big piece of mental luggage in Atlantic society.

title: Official of RightWing Party Put on Trial in South Africa
description: CAPETOWN, May 11 (Reu ters)The deputy leader of the rightwing Reconstituted Na tional party, Jaap Marais, went on trial in the Supreme Court here today on charges under the Official Secrets Act. The judge ordered the press and public excluded.

title: AntiDefamation League Elects U.S. Chairman
description: The election of Seymour Graubard, a lawyer in New York, as national chairman of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith was announced yesterday at the 57th annual meeting of the league at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Thousands Assail Lindsay In 2d Protest by Workers
description: Several thousand hardhatted construction workers and long shoremen, demonstrating in support of the American war, policy in Vietnam, roamed the financial district yesterday, chanting tirades against Mayor Lindsay.

title: Note to Readers
description: The U. S. Government & Agency Bonds table is omit ted from this issue because of composing room delay caused by union meetings.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To Mobilize Sanity

title: ST. JOSEPH EXPECTS DROP IN USE OF LEAD
description: Lead consumption this year probably will be slightly below last year's record level, Law Irason Riggs 3d, president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, said at the annual meeting at the Barbizon Plaza yesterday.

title: Professors Asked to Contribute to Fund for Antiwar Candidates
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11 A national antiwar fund, to which every college professor in the country is being asked to contribute at least one day's salary, was created here today.

title: TV Moves Youth to Violence, Agnew Writes
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 Vice President Agnew believes there is a danger that young Americans may be carried away by mob psychology be cause they see so many ex amples of confrontation on television.

title: A.B.A. Play off
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Shouts of Bravo for Bill Blass's Long Look
description: BILL BLASS finally did it. He made the long look palatable to a lot of women who were clinging defiantly to short clothes. Women such as Mrs. William F. Buckley, who said before his fall show ing of Maurice Renter clothes at the Hotel Plaza yesterday afternoon, I look like the Prime of Miss Jean Brodie in long skirtsI'm going to wear mine very shortor stick to pants.

title: Easier Path To Algebra For the Poor
description: Long before William F. Johntz succeeded in teaching algebra to elementary school children from poor families, he had become convinced that all childrenuntil they come to hate mathematics in schoolhave a lust for and high facility in abstract thinking.

title: FOREIGN DEPOSITS FACE DISCLOSURE
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 American taxpayers who keep bank accounts in foreign coun tries will be required to dis close that fact on their 1970 tax returns, Randolph W. Thrower, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today.

title: Shifting of Debt To Longer Term Found by Rinfret
description: American industry has ap parently begun a massive re funding operation in which the large amounts of shortterm debt it incurred in the last year or two are being paid off with the proceeds from longterm debt and equity financings.

title: Exams May Keep Some Crews From Competing at Syracuse
description: The college crew season has another month to go and it will be a miracle if the schedule is fulfilled as planned. The con cluding events are the Inter collegiate Rowing Association's regatta at Syracuse on June 1113 and the HarvardYale race at New London on June 13.

title: Ames Takes Helm at Lincoln Center
description: There was much shuffling of official chairs yesterday at Lincoln Center. Amyas Ames took a new seat, and he drew up new chairs for at least nine other people.

title: U.S. COLLEGE AID OPPOSED IN SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Supreme Court was asked today to halt the flow of millions of dollars of Fed eral construction grants to churchrelated colleges and universities.

title: Doctor Challenges West Virginia Political Dynasty
description: BECIMEY, W. Va., May 11 There is a saying here that you could take a fence post, call it a Kee and enter it in any election in the Fifth Con gressional District, and it woul win.

title: NOMINEE IS SOUGHT FOR DYNAMICS BOARD
description: Henry Crown and Nathan Cummings, the Chicago finan ciers who have been offered six places on the board of di rectors of the General Dynam ics Corporation to be elected at the annual stockholders' meeting on May 27, are faced with the problem of selecting a sixth nominee to succeed the late Homer Livingston.

title: UNION AND PAPERS REASSESS STANDS
description: Both sides in the city's news paper dispute reassessed their positions yesterday as the stale mate continued.

title: Note to Readers
description: Reviews of last night's music performances are omitted from this issue be cause of composing  room delays caused by union meet ings. They will appear in tomorrow's editions.

title: CITY JUDGE ASKS NEW ASSIGNMENT
description: The Administrative Judge of the city's Criminal Court said yesterday that he will ask to day to be relieved of his duties because he doesn't have any faith in any political structure helping him reform the court.

title: DOW CUT BY 7.66 AS TRADING LAGS
description: Stock prices crunched down ward yesterday with the trad ing pace, hobbling along at a mere 6.65 million shares, the slowest since the summer doldrums of 1967. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.66 points to 710.07, or only a whisker above its lowest level since August, 1963.

title: U. S. STEEL SETS BASIC PRICE RISE
description: The United States Steel Cor poration announced yesterday that it would increase prices for hotand coldrolled steel sheets and galvanized sheets by about 4.7 per cent effec tive June I.

title: Church Dedicated
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)  The National Presbyterian Church, of whose congregation former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was once a mem ber, was formally dedicated Sun day. The cornerstone of the $8.5million church was un veiled by Mr. Eisenhower in 1967.

title: Latins at Nevada Air Show
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 11 LatinAmerican air force gen erals will see a demonstration here tomorrow at a Nellis Air Force Base gunnery range. F4 and F105 aircraft will use bombs, rockets, napalm and missiles to destroy specially ar ranged targets.

title: Old Rugby Players Never Die
description: SYDNEY, Australia (AP) Former rugby players have formed Athletes Anonymous to dissuade aging colleagues from attempting to make a sporting comeback. They say that, when a member feels the urge to play rugby again, he telephones another member who stops by with half a dozen bottles of beer and words of discouragement.

title: Federal Hall, a Natural Podium, Attracts Protesters on Wall St.
description: They say there's going to be a demonstration Tuesday at Wall and Nassau Streets'and we know that's us, said a National Park Service ranger after Friday's prowar and anti war battles in front of Federal Hall National Memorial.

title: BACHE TO ACQUIRE STEIN BROKERAGE
description: Bache & Co., the nation's second largest brokerage house, disclosed yesterday that it plans to acquire Stein Brothers & Boyce, a mediumsized regional member of the New York Stock Exchange doing business since 1853.

title: South Korea's Economy Booming With Cheap Labor
description: PUSAN, South Korea, April 24Running 24 hours a day on three shifts, the big Tong Myung plywood factory in this port is a fitting symbol of South Korea's increasingly vital economy.

title: Students in South Africa Protest Detention Law
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 11 South African students dem onstrated peacefully through out the country today in pro test against a law that pro vides for the indefinite deten tion of political prisoners. The protests were expressed by absenteeism from Iectures, placardbearing pickets and campus meetings.

title: ATTENDANCE IS OFF AT COLLEGES HERE
description: Most colleges and universi ties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut officially re sumed classes yesterday after a week of protest, but attendance on a number of campuses was marginal as students continued strikes and antiwar activities.

title: Xerox Computer Sigma 6 Is Built for Business Uses
description: The Xerox Corporation an nounced yesterday its first com puter designed specifically for business applications. The new machine, called the Sigma 6, is a mediumsize generalpurpose computer. It will lease for $12, 000 to $18,000 a month, de pending on complexity.

title: Army Studies Charge 6 Balked on Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 11 (AP)Six American soldiers are under restriction pending an investigation of charges of refusal to make a combat assault into Cam bodia, a spokesman for the Fourth Inflantry Division said today. They are obtaining le gal counsel, he said.

title: Mercury in Transit Across Sun
description: On Saturday morning Mer cury crossed the face of the sun. In telescopic photo graphs the planet appeared as a dot that was small rela tive to several sunspots, even though Mercury was 52 mil lion miles from the earth and the sun was 94 million miles from the earth at the time.

title: Advertising: The New Yorker's New Image
description: When The New Yorker switches to its new ad agency on July 1, the move will be part of a changing promotion al posture begun two years ago that was aimed at letting the advertising community know that The New Yorker is not the magazine it was 15 or even 10 years ago.

title: DUST COMMANDER IN SHARP WORKOUT
description: BALTIMORE, May 11Dust Commander and My Dad George, onetwo in the Ken tucky Derby, and two other candidates for Saturday's 95th running of the Preakness Stakes turned in sharp workouts today at Pimlico Race Course.

title: U.S. DISCOUNTS DELAY OF SHOW IN SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  United States officials said to day they saw no reason to re gard the postponement of the opening of an American cul tural exhibition in the Soviet Union as an officially inspired sign of protest against Ameri can military actions in Cam bodia.

title: Cheerleaders Star in Court
description: DENVER (AP)  Six cheer leaders at Ranum High School went to court and got a judg ment of $120 against a knitting company on the complaint that sweaters they had ordered were the wrong shade of green and that the company had refused to refund their money.

title: INDUSTRY MISSES REUTHER'S HAND
description: DETROIT, May 11Auto In dustry executives are beginning to worry about the fate of their new contract negotiations with out Walter P. Reuther's strong hand on the United Auto Workers.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Capital Kite Flying Gets House Blessing; Bandy Is Still Taboo
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)  House members voted today to legalize kite flying in the nation's capital. They did not tamper, however, with other ancient restraints on lo cal public behavior, including the playing of bandy and shin dy or tying horses to trees.

title: At Smith College, It's NoStrike Strike
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 9  The nostrike strike has come to Smith.

title: Article 1  No Title
Easing by Reserve Was Voted Feb. 10
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted 9 to 3 to ease monetary policy at its meeting last Feb. 10, it was disclosed today.

title: Costly School Delays
description: A study by an anonymous independent researcher working under the auspices of the City Planning Com mission asserts that long delays in public school con struction are adding tens of millions of dollars to the eventual price tag in an inflationary economy. In an exercise of irrelevance, an official reply from the Budget Director's office questions whether the rela tionship between delay and cost can be so readily pinpointed.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER IN WHEAT FUTURES
Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, May 12, 1970

title: 47 SAIGON VESSELS REACH PNOMPENH
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 11Fortyseven vessels of the South Vietnamese Navy moved up the Mekong River here late this afternoon and tied up in the heart of Pnompenh.

title: Birds Get Epitaph
description: TAMPA, Fla. (AP)Here lie the remains of 10 birds killed recently by the oil spill, says a sign tacked up near the spot where oilsoaked sea birds died as a result of oil dumped in Tampa Bay.

title: Philips Lamp Widens 3Month Profit
Washington: For the Record
2 Chase Officers Promoted
description: Barry F. Sullivan and Wil liam H. Siddons Jr. have been promoted to senior vice presi dents of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Mr. Sullivan is deputy executive of the bank opera tions department, a new post. Mr. Siddons is group executive of the general operations group.

title: Car Kills L. I. Cyclist. 15
description: ST. JAMES, L.I., May 10A 15yearold boy riding his bi cycle here on Route 25A was struck down and killed by a hitandrun driver early today. The police said the victim's companion identified the hit andrun vehicle as a light blue Volkswagen sedan. The victim. Thomas Sullivan, of 44 East Hill Drive, Smithtown, died at Smithtown General Hospital at 4:31 A.M., about three hours after he was injured. The police said the two boys had been fishing and were riding their bicycles home when the acci dent occurred.

title: 28th Scandi Ball Set for Saturday
description: The Scandi Ball, 28th an nual dinner dance of the Dora Butler Leagu efor Underpriv iledged Children, will be held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Saturday. Mrs. Arthur Roth is chairman for the event, which will have dec orations from Norway. Swe den, Denmark and Finland. Proceeds will go to a number of charities, among them the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital, the Hebrew Day Nursery, also in New Rochelle, and the Hartley House Day Nursery in the Bronx.

title: SOHIO SEEKS A CUT IN ACQUISITION PRICE
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced yesterday that a subsidiary, the BP Oil Company, had asked the United States District Court in Cleve land for a declaratory judgment cutting the price paid for prop erties purchased from the Sin clair Oil Corporation by $35.37 million.

title: The Liberals' Choices
description: By designating Democrat Arthur J. Goldberg and Republican Charles Goodell as its nominees for Gov ernor and Senator, the Liberal party has given the candidacies of both a long push forward. The half million or more votes the Liberals are likely to attract to their line could well determine the outcome of the two principal statewide contests this November.

title: When It's Not a Hot Dog You're After ...
description: ACCORDING to Robert En gelhardt, the man who does most of the cooking, the food wouldn't knock a con noisseur dead but to thou sands of New Yorkers who have sampled the menu of the Oola Carts in the last month, the offerings are a happy me dium between a hot dog and a hefty lunch bill.

title: Article 1  No Title
Aqueduct Jockeys
description: *Apprentice

title: Japanese Ferry Hijacker Captured on the Inland Sea
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Wednes day, May 13 (AP)Police shot and captured today an armed man who had commandered a ferryboat and ignored pleas to surrender while sailing in Ja pan's Sea.

title: Sports of The Times
description: SONS of famous fathers carry uncon scionable burdens throughout their lives because they are always being compared with their more renowned sires. The greater the stature of the father the more difficult it is tor the son to escape from the smothering shadhow that blood lines have imposed on him. Ty Cobb's son, for instance, didn't even try. The offspring of baseball's finest hitter became a tennis player at Yale. Sic transit gloria mundi.

title: $50,000 Is Awarded Conservation Groups
description: The American Heritage So ciety, whose members include readers and editors of Ameri can Heritage magazine, yes terday announced the win ners of 12 conservation awards totaling $50.000.

title: Mr. Justice Blackmun
description: If anything were needed to demonstrate to President Nixon that the Senate is not out to humiliate him in the matter of Supreme Court appointments, it is the 94to0 vote by which it has confirmed Judge Harry Blackmun. At the happy conclusion of a needlessly long process, the President must be aware that regional politics was no consequential factor in the contrast between the Senate's slow agony over the rejected candidates from South Carolina and Florida and its swift approval of the man from Minnesota. Judge Blackmun's record and his conduct before the Judiciary Committee show clearly that the difference was one of quality, not geography.

title: Bridge:
description: A TYPE of contest that is popular in Europe but rarely played here is that between teams representing clubs, towns, countries or districts. American organiza tions are reluctant to plan such events because they lead to thorny selection problems. They should be more enter prising and risk a little of the odium that always afflicts selectors.

title: Adams Keeps Winning Ways at Big A
description: When Navy No charged into contention in the second race at Aqueduct yesterday, Camille Radice knew she had made a mistake.

title: Washington: For the Record
ABORTION GUIDES OFFERED BY STATE
description: Guidelines for abortions, set yesterday by the State Health Department, recommend that the operation be performed only in a hospital or a hospital affiliated clinic.

title: VANN IS ACQUITTED IN OCEAN HILL CASE
description: Albert Vann, president of the AfricanAmerican Teachers Fed eration, won a directed motion of acquittal yesterday on charges arising from the Ocean Hill Brownsville school dispute in 1968.

title: Macy's Reports Promotion Of 2 of Its Vice Presidents
description: The promotion of two execu tives of R. H. Macy & Co., was announced yesterday. Warren H. Simmons Jr. has been ad vanced to vice president for personnel and labor relations, succeeding Frederick G. Atkin son, who will retire Aug. 1, but will continue as a consult ant. S. Lester Block has been promoted to senior vice presi dent, government relations and labor counsel.

title: The Nuns Postponed
description: The Nuns, originally sched uled to open Monday night, now will have its local premiere June 1 at the Cherry Lane. The post ponemenet was caused by the illness of Thayer David the role he had will be played by Sydney Walker, known for his work with the APA Repertory Company.

title: AMEX PRICES SLIP AS VOLUME SOARS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended slightly lower yesterday in steppedup trad ing, although a brief afternoon rally erased some of the earlier losses.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
The Forgotten Students
description: In the wake of Cambodia and Kent State, many colleges and universities have apparently written off the remaining weeks of the semestersome undoubt edly as much to avoid confrontations as to enable politically concerned students to exert their energies in offcampus lobbying and organizing.

title: Money and Credit
description: Rack in January the Federal Reserve Board decided to change its tactics in fighting inflation, and the shift seemed sensible enough since the old tactics had not been much of a success.

title: General Public Utilities Cancels Some Gas Turbine Generators
description: Electric utility customers in parts of New Jersey and Penn sylvaniaalready plagued by precautionary voltage reduc tions over the last two days were put on notice yesterday that 1971 may be even worse.

title: BLIND JIM BREWER IN GUITAR PROGRAM
description: Blind Jim Brewer, a big, chunky man who has been singing and playing his guitar on street corners in Chicago, St. Louis and Fayetteville, Ark., reached New York Monday night, not on a street corner but in the shelter of the Wash ington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: UNION CONTRACTS BIND NEW OWNERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)The National Labor Re lations Board has ruled that, when a company is purchased, the new owner must abide by any existing union contracts ne gotiated by the previous man agement.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Treasury statement and some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Ex change quotations are omit ted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Reed of Knicks Gets an Auto as Top Star in Playoffs
description: Willis Reed accepted a 19970 Dodge Charger from Sport Magazine yesterday as the most valuable player in the National Basketcball As sociation playoff and said, Any guy on the team that wants to use my car can have it.

title: Cubs Top Braves in 11th, 43; Banks Hits 500th Home Run
description: CHICAGO, May 12 (AP)  Ron Santo's scratch single with the bases loaded in the 11th inning gave the Chicago Cubs a 43 victory over the Atlanta Braves today in a game in which Ernie Banks hit his 500th career home run and Rico Carty stretched his con secutivegamehitting streak to 30.

title: STANS WINS DELAY ON IMPORT QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  The Secretary of Commerce, Maurice H. Stans, asked for and won today from the House Ways and Means Committee a delay of one more month to negotiate voluntary limitations on textile imports into the United States.

title: WEBSTER PRESENTS A CLARINET RECITAL
description: Rhythmic certainty, personal aplomb and a sense of musical ease were some of the charac teristics that made Michael Webster's clarinet playing such a pleasure to hear Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Truman Dam Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The House passed and sent to President Nixon today a bill to name a dam on the Osager River in Missouri for former President Harry S. Truman. The dam is now named the Kay singer Bluff Dam.

title: JOINT VENTURE SET BY CEMENT CONCERN
description: DALLAS, May 12The Gen eral Portland Cement Company of Dallas took its first step to ward diversification when it announced here yesterday that it will enter a $72million joint venture in Florida.

title: 2 PROTEST GROUPS MEET ON WALL ST
description: Policemen in massive force prevented a noonday confron tation on Wall Street yesterday between a thousand antiwar college students and an equal number of construction work ers and longshoremen marching in support of the war and de manding the impeachment of Mayor Lindsay.

title: 3,500 in Mekong Town Board Boats for Vietnam
description: KOMPONG CHAM, Cam bodia, May 12  Under the cover of a daylong artillery and mortar barrage against the opposite bank of the Mekong River, about 3,500 Vietnamese boarded the boats of a South Vietnamese flotilla today and headed downstream toward Vietnam.

title: Along the Mekong, the Wailing of Exile
description: LO GACH, Cambodia, May 9This village, the home of 600 Vietnamese Catholics in Buddhist Cambodia this morning, was empty and de serted tonight.

title: Guerrillas, Lebanese and Syrians Join to Meet Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 Palestinian commandos, Leba nese guns and the Syrian Air Force combined today in op posing an Israeli sweep into guerrilla stronghold in south western Lebanon.

title: Market Place:
description: LET'S pretend we're still in the beginning weeks of the notorious bear market of 1969.

title: 4 HOTEL COMPANIES INDICTED IN OREGON
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 12 A Federal grand jury today in dicted four major hotel corpo rations, a convention associa tion and five of their officers on charges of violating the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: APAWAMIS VICTOR IN WESTCHESTER
description: Somerset Hills, the Metro politan cnampion, rallied to re tain the New Jersey district title as the Women's Metropoli tan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed yesterday.

title: Roundup: Merritt Earns Another Badge
description: You'd never catch Lucy Van Pelt helping Charlie Brown rescue one of his kites from one of the many kite eating trees they encounter, but Jim Merritt is more corn passionateat least where his son is concerned.

title: Two Architects Cited By National Arts Club
description: Tribute was paid last night to Gilmore David Clarke, civil engineer and landscape archi tect, and Karel Yasko, archi tect, at the annual awards dinner of the National Sculp ture Society held at the Na tional Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. For contribution to the alliance of art and architec ture, Mr. Clarke received the society's highest award, its Medal of Honor, and Mr. Yasko received the Herbert Adams Memorial Medal.

title: Cannes: Focus on the Screen and Off
description: CANNES, France, May 12 The weather has been so cold and rainy so much of the time that movie produc ers, who ordinarily sport tans 12 months of the year, have turned as blue as the Carlton Hotel beach umbrel las that are going unrented.

title: Vorster Shuffles Cabinet in South Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, May 12 (Reuters)Prime Min ister John B. Vorster an nounced some changes in his Government today and at the same time issued an apparent rebuke to one of his ministers.

title: United Book Publishers Deplore War
description: POCONO MANOR, Pa., May 12The American Book Pub lishers Council and the Amer ican Educational Publishers Institute, whose members ac count for almost all books published in the United States, have merged into a single trade organization to be known as the Association of American Publishers.

title: JURORS GET CASE OF ALIOTO VS. LOOK
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's $12.5 million libel suit against Look magazine was in the jury's hands tonight.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 13, 1970

title: Comsat Foresees No Rise in Year for Circuit Use
description: However, neither Mr. Charyk nor James McCormack, chair man, would make any predic tions of sales or earnings. The actual volume of satellite traf fic has a direct bearing on Comsat's earnings.

title: U.S. Officials Skeptical
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  United States officials ex pressed strong skepticism to day over Prince Sihanouk's as sertion that some of his minis ters were operating from lib erated areas in Cambodia.

title: YANKEES WIN, 95, MOVE TO 2D PLACE
description: MILWAUKEE, May 12  Yankee pitchers can't complete their games and the Milwaukee ground crew can't cover the field during a thunderstorm.

title: Gibson Outpolls Addonizio But Faces Newark Runoff
description: Kenneth A. Gibson, a Negro running for Mayor of Newark, won more than twice the votes cast for his closest contender yesterday, the incumbent, Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio.

title: State Orders Premiums Reduced By 60% for Air Travel Insurance
description: The State Insurance Depart Intent ordered sellers of airtrip accident insurance yesterday either to reduce rates by 60 per cent or increase benefits by similar amount because, it said, the premiums charged were unreasonable.

title: Steel Shipments Rise
description: Domestic steel producers shipped 24,344,000 tons of steel in the first quarter this year, up from 22,550,000 tons in the corresponding period last year, the American Iron and Steel In stitute reported yesterday. In March shipments were 8,244, 000 tons, against 7,242,000 tons a year earlier. Shipments to the automotive industry in the first quarter dropped 19.9 per cent from the yearearlier total.

title: Roswell L. Gilpatric Weds Mrs. Paula Washburn
description: Mrs. Paula Methado Wash burn was married here yester day afternoon to Roswell L. Gilpatric, who was Deputy Secretary of Defense in the Kennedy Administration. Only members of the immediate families of the couple at tended the ceremony, per formed at the bride's apart ment by the Rev. William A. McQuoid of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. A few close friends came in for the reception that fol lowed.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE AGE OF AQUARIUS. Technology and the Cultural Revolution. By William Braden. 306 pages. Quadrangle. $7.95.

title: OPERA ORCHESTRA ENDS ITS SEASON
description: The Opera Orchestra of New York's fourth and final presen tation of the season, given in Alice Tully Hall Monday night, was Offenbach's Les Contes d'Hoffmann. It is a work that exposes the inadequacies of the singers and orchestral players as much as a Mozart score does and is equally, if not more, demanding vocally. So it was not surprising that this per formance, by an ensemble be ing trained in the opera reper tory, was decidedly mixed in quality.

title: Step Is Held Unlikely
description: Conditions in the money mar ket call for an increase in the prime rate and probably will continue to do so for the next three to six months, one of the chief lending officers of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday.

title: MUSKIE CRITICIZED BY NADER GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, May 12A report on air pollution control, prepared under the direction of Ralph Nader, the consumer ad vocate, said today that Sena tor Edmund Muskie had provid ed politically expedient plati tudes rather than real leader ship in the field of environ mental protection.

title: UNIVERSITY OFFICER QUITS ARTS COUNCIL
description: BUFFALO, May 12 (AP)Dr. Albert BushBrown announced his resignation today from the National Council on the Arts, citing what he called bank ruptcy in our national leader ship.

title: 5 Chicago Panthers Shun Grand Jury
description: CHICAGO, May 12Five of the seven Black Panthers who survived a shooting incident with the Chicago police last December refused today to tes tify before a Federal grand jury investigating the incident.

title: War Protests Continue; Colleges Poorly Attended
description: The State Court of Appeals hi Albany ruled yesterday that law students must complete the specified number of classroom hours and take final examina tions to be eligible for the State Bar examinations.

title: COLLEGE PRESIDENT ASKS TO BE RELIEVED
description: SAN JOSE. Calif., May 12 Dr. Hobert W. Burns, acting president of San Jose State Col lege, asked today that he be relieved of his administrative duties, and that his name be withdrawn from consideration for appointment as president of the 24.000student institution.

title: Fire in Draft Offices
description: DETROIT, May 12 (AP)De troit Fire Department officials said today that arson was sus pected in a fire early this morn ing at two Selective Service of fices. Local Boards 186 and 187, both in the same building, re ported heavy damage after a fire burned an hour and a half. Fire Department spokesmen say that a gasoline can had been found near the scene.

title: 2 Industrial Teams Win Contracts for Design of Reusable Space Shuttle
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded contracts yesterday to two aerospace industrial teams for the preliminary design of a reusable shuttle vehiclea short of space airplane to op erate between the earth and earthorbiting space stations.

title: SUICIDE RATE HIGH IN KIDNEY DISEASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 Suicide among chronically ill kidney dialysis patients is 400 times more prevalent than suicide in the general popula tion, a team of doctors from the University of Virginia School of Medicine reported here today.

title: MAYOR PROPOSES RENT RISE JULY 1 OF MORE THAN 10%
description: One million of the city's 1.3 million families in rentcon trolled apartments would pay rent increases averaging more than 10 per cent on July 1, and additional rises thereafter, un der a vast reform of the rent control law proposed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Inflation, Decline in Industry and High Loan Cost Cited
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12  The Penn Central Company have to hold its capital expendi Lures this year to $166million down from $266million in 1969 end $331million in 1966, stock solders were told here today at their annual meeting.

title: Goldberg Assails Costly Campaign
description: Arthur J. Goldberg described modern multimillion dollar political campaigns as out rageous yesterday, then pledged to spend far less than $2million on his own camnaign for Governor.

title: Moscow's Goal: Isolation of U.S.
description: MOSCOW, May 12The So viet Union appears to have chosen, for the moment, to mask in ambiguity its course of action in both the Middle East and Southeast Asia. Western diplomats have no firm infor Imation on what the sending of Soviet pilots to the United Arab Republic portends nor what, if anything, the Kremlin will do to counter the American troops in Cambodia.

title: U.S. to Check Campus Raid
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 12 (UPI) The Justice Department granted today the request of former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey to investigate a police raid at the home of University of Minnesota profes sor, David Lykken, who held a party to raise funds for a pro test against an antiballistic missile site. Nineteen persons were arrested and charged with keeping or frequenting a dis orderly house, based on the fact that beer was dispensed and donations were taken to raise money.

title: Executive Changes
description: Melvin Intriligator, a director of the Anchor Cor poration, has been named senior vice president and will be succeeded as treasurer by Arthur White. James E. Preifer has been named treasurer of Anchor's subsidiary, Anchor National Life Insur ance Company.

title: 2 L.I. DOG SHOWS ARE CALLED OFF
description: The unrest on college cam puses led yesterday to the can cellation of both of the all breed dog shows scheduled for Long Island during the week end. The 64th event of the Ladies Kennel Association of. America, which was to have been held Saturday on the Hofstra University grounds in Hempstead, was called off in the early evening. The 68th Long Island Kennel Club fix ture, at C. W. Post College of Long Island University listed for Sunday was canceled earlier in an action prompted by, a let.

title: Market Summaries
description: Tuesday, May 12, 1970 (Volume 3,099,950 shares)

title: POLICEMAN DENIES BEATING PANTHER
description: The policemen who arrested Joan Bird, one of 13 Black Pan thers accused of conspiring to bomb public places, denied re peatedly yesterday that he had beaten her the night of her arrest.

title: Hearing for Louis Canceled
description: DENVER, May 12 (AP)A medical examination in court for Joe Louis, former world heavyweight boxing champion, who was committed to a psychi atric hospital May 1, has been called off by agreement of at torneys. The lawyers also said that the former fighter, who has a home in Denver, will be transferred from Colorado Psy chiatric Hospital to the Vet erans Administration Hospital.

title: Note to Readers
description: Reviews of last night's dance and music perform ances are omitted from this issue because of composing robin delays caused by union meetings. They will appear in tomorrow's editions.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER IN SILVER FUTURES
description: Although higher prices were obtained at the Government's silver auction in Washington yesterday, the price of silver futures dropped on the Com modity Exchange here.

title: Washington High Reopens Today; Parents Divided
description: The Board of Education an nounced yesterday that trouble plagued George Washington High School would be reopened this morning with precautions taken to assure the safety of students and the staff.

title: Unions Differ on Indochina War
description: The construction workers, who have so firmly and, in some cases, violently confront ed antiwar demonstrators here, are members of building trades unions that have been tradition ally conservative, strongly anti Communist and unswerving in supporting the Government's war policy in Vietnam.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES DROP ONCE MORE
description: Stock prices enjoyed a brief Melvin Laird rally early yes terday afternoon. But, like most good things in the market these days, it did not last very long.

title: STATE SUES CON ED TO PROTECT RIVER
description: The state has charged the Consolidated Edison Company with serious violations of state conservation laws in the opera tion of its nuclear generating plant at Indian Point and asked that the plant be closed until suitable methods to protect the Hudson River can be de veloped.

title: Rules Committee Approves Bill to Reform House Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, May 12A bill to reform creaky legislative machinery was approved today by the House Rules Committee after more than a year of deli cate negotiations.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, May 13, 1970

title: Bangor Punta Shows Net Loss In Quarter Against '69 Profit
description: The Bangor Punta Corpora tion reported yesterday a sharp drop in earnings for the six months ended March 31 and a net loss for the second fiscal quarter. As a result, directors took no action on the common stock dividend for the rest of fiscal 1970.

title: Boston Mayor, Democrat, Enters Race for Governor
description: BOSTON. May 12 (AP) Mayor Kevin H. White for mally announced today he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor of Massachusetts, criticized Gov. Francis W. Sargent, a Repub lican.

title: Russians Are Bitter At Rejection, See A Blow to Ideals
description: MOSCOW, May 12Bitter ness marked the first official Soviet reaction tonight to the selection of Montreal as the site of the 1976 Summer Olym pics.

title: Three U.S. Tennis Players Advance in Belgian Open
description: BRUSSELS, May 12 (UPI)  Three Americans moved into the second round of the Belgian open tennis championships to day as Cliff Richey and Marty Riessen won firstround men's singles matches and Wendy Overton gained in the women's competition.

title: ABlast Test in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. May 12 (AP)An atomic device de signed to test methods of de tecting and locating under ground today at the test sits in the desert north of here, the Atomic Energy Commission re ported. The last, codenamed Project Vela, was described as having an explosive force equiv alent to less than 20 kilotons of TNT.

title: Naumberg Concert Series To Start on Memorial Day
description: The 65th season of free Naumburg Orchestra concerts on the Mall in Central Park will begin on Memorial Day at 8:30 P.M. with a program of works by Schubert, Bizet, Vaughan Williams and Falla conducted by Boyd Neel. Elaine Bonazzi will sing Falla's Seven Popular Spanish Songs and excerpts from Bizet's Carmen.

title: U.N. ASKS ISRAELIS TO LEAVE LEBANON
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12The Security Coun cil demanded unanimously to day that Israel withdraw the armed forces that she moved into southern Lebanon this morning in a reprisal raid.

title: Next School Chief
description: MURRY BERGTRAUM'S three children offered him some advice Monday night when they learned he was about to become presi dentelect of the Board of Education.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The Communications Satellite Cor poration (Comsat) does not foresee any significant increase in the use of satellite circuits in this country this year. Joseph V. Charyk, president, told stock holders at the annual meeting in l'Enfant Theater here today.

title: PURSE CAN REACH RECORD $201,800
description: BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) The addition of Hickory Tree Farm's Buzashi today in creased to 13 the list of starters for Saturday's $150,000added Preakness and further padded the already record purse.

title: Wood Expected to Head The U. of Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, May 12Dr. Rob ert C. Wood, director of the Joint Center for Urban Stud ies of the Massachusetts In stitute of Technology and Harvard University, is ex pected to be elected president of the University of Massa chusetts tomorrow.

title: President Briefs Top Labor Leaders On Cambodia Push
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 President Nixon gave a sym pathetic audience of labor lead ers a fresh report today on what he called the enormous success of American and South Vietnamese military operations in Cambodia.

title: Atomic Bomb in Japan Is Focus of Photo Show
description: Hiroshima and Nagasaki, an exhibition of more than 100 photographs by Japanese cameramen on the atomic explosicns in those cities, will be on display at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, Tuesdays through Sundays through lone 2 from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Negro Named in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, May 12 (AP)The Buffalo Board of Education elected its first Negro president today. He is Dr. George E. Blackman, a surgeon who has been vice president of the board for the last year.

title: JUDGE DUDLEY ASKS FOR REASSIGNMENT
description: Edward R. Dudley, Adminis trative Judge of the city's Crim inal Court, said late yesterday that he had submitted his re quest to be relieved of his duties and to be reassigned to the State Supreme Court. He had announced his intention to do this a day earlier, saying that the low priority assigned the courts prevented him from accomplishing any further court reform.

title: Lubbock Tornado Kills 20, Destroys Buildings and Derails a Train
description: LUBBOCK. Tex., May 12 The storm that devastated much of downtown Lubbock on the South Texas plains last night was so powerful that it blew a freight train off its track and left a 21story down town office building gashed its supports weakened.

title: CAMBODIAN COAST UNDER BLOCKADE BY ALLIED FLEET
description: NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, May 12  Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Viet nam said here today that allied naval vessels had begun blockading a 100mile stretch of Cambodian coastline to pre vent enemy forces from re supplying their troops by sea.

title: Brewer Leads by 5,908
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 11 (AP)Gov. Albert P. Brewer's margin over former Gov. George C. Wallace in the Democratic primary apparently is the small est in a Governor's race in Ala bama in 40 years. Unofficial returns Monday gave Mr. Brewer a lead of 5,908 votes in the party election May 5. In 1930, B. M. Miller won the Demo cratic nomination with a margin of 5,421 votes over W. C. Davis.

title: More U.S. Inspectors Hired To Check Gulf Oil Operations
description: WASHINGTON May 11 (AP) The Interior Department has begun hiring more men to in spect offshore oil operations in the Gulf of Mexico, with the goal of doubling the number of inspectors by the end of this month.

title: OUTLAY RISE URGED FOR JUSTICE AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) A $267.3million rise in funds for the Justice Department's fight against crime, racial dis crimination and pollution of natural resources was recom mended today by the House Appropriations Committee.

title: Senators Differ on OneBank Holding Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Members of the Senate Bank ing Committee disagreed with each other today over the ad visability of trying to pass legis lation this year restricting the activities of onebank holding companies.

title: CAR SALES DOWN IN MAY 110 PERIOD
description: DETROIT, May 12New car sales in early May continued at slump levels, with the four averaged 22,025 deliveries deliveries of Americantype cars, down from 257,206 sales a vear before.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED IN I.O.S. TAKEOVER
description: GENEVA, May 12There are a number of unanswered ques tions, some of which raise the possibility of conflict of inter est, in the arrangement that has given John M. King voting control over the Investors Over seas Services mutual fund em pire.

title: SPARMA YIELDS 4 IN A 1INNING STINT
description: A threepour baseball game can be, sometimes, an exciting event, but the 84 victory the New York Mets scored over the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadi um yesterday wasn't, largely because Montreal pitchers is sued 13 bases on balls.

title: Drug AbuseII
description: Dr. Stanley F. Yolles of the National Institute of Mental Health calls drug misuse an epidemic sweep ing the nation. It has rippled in, from the port cities across the hinterland plains.

title: Closing of Sears Point Plant Puts Holes in Auto Race Card
description: NO. VIRGINIA, it is not necessarily true that there's a quick buck for any body who invests in a race plant, even in a sport that claims to be No. 2 in paid attendance. Without good management  and good breaks  the prospect of failure is alweys there. Several well  known tracks are in trouble. And now a dismal develop ment: Sears Point in California has abruptly canceled all race activities, and the next you hear of Sears Point it may be a housing development or some such. Only last week Filmways, Inc., of Hollywood, which owns the track, re ported an operating loss of $300,000 in 14 months and said Sears Point was avail able for sale. But on Monday Filmways took the ultimate step: it simply shut down the track to prevent any future drain on company earnings.

title: 2 Democratic Incumbents Win In West Virginia House Contest
description: CHARLESTON. W. Va., May 12A former football star and a young physician fell far short today in their efforts to unseat incumbent Congressmen in West Virginia's Democratic primary election.

title: Washington: President Nixon's Three Theories
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  In explaining President Nixon's sudden decision to invade Cam bodia, his foreign policy aides point to three Nixon theories about how to deal with the Communists in general and the Soviet Union in particular. These are worth examining.

title: Nixon Meets With Heard
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Chancellor G. Alexander Heard of Vanderbilt University met with President Nixon for more than an hour today in their first session since Mr. Nixon picked Dr. Heard May 8 to advise him on communicat ing with the nation's campus youth. White House spokes men gave no account of the meeting.

title: Morgenthau Leaves Governorship Race
description: Robert M. Morgenthau with drew at 11:45 last night as a candidate for Democratic nomi nation for Governor.

title: Lucky Creed Is Out Of Good Time Pace At Yonkers Friday
description: YONKERS, May 12Austra lia will be without representa tion in Friday night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway. In the wake of yes terday's declaration of Adaptor, the $125,000 Aussie pacer who suffered a broken splint bone in last week's $50,000 Martin Tananbaum International Pace Lucky Creed of Australia was withdrawn this morning.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Militant Students

title: Sihanouk Asserts Followers Almost Seized Pnompenh
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, May 13 (Reuters)Prince Nor odom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian chief of State, has said that forces backing his cause had surrounded Pnom penh and were on the point of taking the city before United States and South Vietnamese troops began their offensive into Cambodia, it was reported today.

title: Believing Price of a Wine Rack Is One ThingBut Caviar From a Street Cart?
description: MODERN plastic, wood ceramic and metal fur nishings at believable prices. That's the way Blooming dale's is billing its Casa Idea shop, which opens today on the store's fifth floor. Believ able means $5 for a plastic sixbottle wine rack, $38 for a plastic stool that has a re versible topone side for sitting, the other for serving$95 for a plastic shelving unit more than 7 feet tall and $18 each for two innovative lamps, small though they may be. The boutique's name is as Italian as the merchandise on view, all of which is imported by Beylerian Limited. The name, Ideas for the House, de rives from a shop in La Ri nascentc, an Italian depart ment store based in Milan, where most of the same fur nishings are also sold.

title: The More Perilous Crisis
description: Israel's largescale raid against guerrilla sanctuaries in Lebanon calls attention once more to a continuing crisis in the Middle East that is even more perilous than the escalating Indochina conflict on which national and international concern has focused in recent weeks.

title: Occidental Plans Move
description: BEVERLY HILLS. Calif., May 12The Occidental Petroleum Corporation is close to obtain ing an oil exploration conces sion in the United Arab Repub lic, Armand Hammer, chairman, said at the annual stockholders' meeting here today.

title: Nixon Proposes Owens For New S.E.C. Term
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 President Nixon announced today his intention to nomi nate Hugh F. Owens to an other fiveyear term as member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 1,200 Guardsmen Ring Augusta Area
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., May 12  A dusktodawn curfew was imposed on this nervous city today after a night of looting and shooting that left six Ne groes dead and brought 1,200 National Guard troops with fixed bayonets into the streets.

title: CANADA'S BANK RATE REDUCED TO 7%
description: OTTAWA, May 11 (Reuters) The Bank of Canada an nounced last night a reduction in the bank rate to 7 per cent from the 8 per cent in force since last July.

title: Police Get Bad Image From a Jury Panelist
description: MIAMI (AP)The prosecu tor was going to introduce police witnesses, so he asked prospective jurors if they had ever been robbed or victim ized.

title: Black Church, Too, Has Widening Generation Gap
description: MEMPHIS, May 12  One hundred years ago today a little band of black churchmen, tired of being treated like second class citizens in a predominant ly white church, withdrew from the old paternalistic Methodist Episcopal Church. South.

title: Bates Gets Prudential Account
description: Ted Bates & Co., Division, New York, has been named the ad agency for the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the country's largest. Last year the Newarkbased insurance company spent 55.1million for advertising.

title: Some Discount Stores Are Wary of Credit Cards
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  Discount store merchants, who have taken to bank credit cards much more readily than their conventional store competitors, expressed some fear at their convention here today over pos sible monopolistic behavior by the issuers of the cards.

title: 6 Years After Topless Bathing Suit, Gernreich's Latest Plunge
description: WHEN Rudi Gernreich made his topless bathing suit six years ago, it stirred up a storm. Everybody talked about it. Stores bought it, some women even wore it, and topless restau rants sprung up all along the West Coast. But his model, Peggy Moffitt, never ap peared in it publicly, and the photograph of her wearing it was taken by her husband, William Claxton.

title: Nelly Sachs, Poet, Dead at 78; Won Nobel Prize for Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, May 12Nelly Sachs, the Germanborn Jewish poet who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1966, died in St. Grans Hospital here today after a long illness. She was 78 years old.

title: TaxExempts Get a Mixed Reception
description: Taxexempt securities took the bond market spotlight yes terday as three large new offer ings vied, with mixed results, for investor favor.

title: Garden Seeking Urtain as Frazier's Foe
description: He's famouss throughout Europe where he's known simply as Urtain. His name is Jose Manuel Ibar, but that's longer than his oppo nents usually last.

title: Total Inventories Up a Bit in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Total business inventories rose by the unusually small amount of $150million in March, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: U.S. 6th Fleet Concerned Over Soviet Navy in the Mediterranean
description: ABOARD U.S.S. LITTLE ROCK, in the Mediterranean, May 8In the view of the commanders of the United States Sixth Fleet, the Soviet naval squadron in the Mediter ranean has matured from presence to a challenge.

title: National Issues Raised
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 12  Republicans in this tradition ally conservative state went to the polls today to decide the political future of Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann. They had the choice of renominating him for another fouryear term or of replacing him with his most persistent and vocal critic, State Senator Clifton B. Batchelder.

title: House Passes $429Million For U.S. Merchant Marine
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The House sent to President Nixon today a bill authorizing $429million for merchant ma rine activities, including the start of a 300ship construction program.

title: Dinner to Help Columbus Gallery
description: The Columbus (Ohio) Gal lery of Fine Arts will benefit from a dinner at the St. RegisSheraton next Monday night and the preview after ward of the first exhibition in New York of the Ferdinand Howald Collection at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East 64th Street.

title: Hog Butcher for the World No Longer
description: Thus Carl Sandburg began his lusty tribute to Chicago in 1916. But were he to write it today, he would have to find a different opening.

title: DENVER TRIUMPH A 7YEAR EFFORT
description: DENVER, May 12The elec tion of Denver as the site of the 1976 Winter Olympics to day crowned an effort that be gan in 1963.

title: G.O.P. Counters Plan in Senate To Bar War Funds in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The Senate Republican leadership countered a bipartisan move to cut off funds for future mili tary activities in Cambodia by suggesting legislation today that would sanction actions taken under the President's power as Commander in Chief.

title: U.S. MOOD GAUGED BY PSYCHIATRISTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 Excessive talk, threats and ag gressive violence by legitimate authority, coupled with a feel ing of American superiority over the peoples of the world, have contributed the great political divisiveness now ap parent in this country, psychia trists said here today.

title: GEORGE VIVIAN, 85, ACTORS' TEACHER
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 12George Vivian, an actor, director and producer, died at his home here Sunday of a stroke. He was 85 years old.

title: Backed by Mitchell
description: WASHINGTON, May 12At torney General John N. Mitchell said tonight that he would ac cept a Federal law guarantee ing the confidentiality of a re porter's notes or television film.

title: Paris's American Library to Grow
description: A sixyear 50th anniver sary expansion plan for the American Library in Paris, to cost $6million, was an nounced yesterday by Robert H. Blake, Paris banker and board chairman of the library.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Bull and the Bear
description: MADRIDPerhaps the most interesting and certainly the most gingerly diplomatic nego tiations now going on in Europe are those between Spain and the Soviet Union. Contacts have existed for sixteen years, on and off, but they have re cently been renewed at Mos cow's initiative.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Births Drop in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM (UPI)  The number of babies in Sweden is 1969 is estimated at 107,000, a record low, compared with 113,000 in 1968.

title: Nixon Drops Plan to Abolish Tea Testing Board
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  The Nixon Administration retreated today in the dispute over Federal tea tasting.

title: Moyers Resigns Post at Newsday
description: Bill D. Moyers, a former White House press secre tary, resigned yesterday as the publisher of Newsday after more than three years with the Long Island news paper, which was purchased recently by The Los Angeles Times.

title: Mayor Forms Citizens' Group To Step Up Fight on Pollution
description: A citizen commitee to work on specific antipollution pro grams rather than simply serv ing as a forum against pollu tion was convened at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: PRINTERS REPORT PAPERS DISAGREE
description: The head of the local typo graphical union said yesterday that differences between the publishers of the city's four major newspapers were holding up a contract settlement with the printers.

title: Governor Signs Bill To Give Newsmen A Right to Silence
description: Governor Rockefeller signed what he called the freedom of information bill for newsmen here yesterday, saying that it clearly protects the public's right to know and the First Amendment rights of all legiti mate newspapermen, reporters and television and radio broad casters.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The following servicemen from the New York area were identified by the Defense De partment today as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: Indonesian Pledges Troop Aid If Reds Threaten Neighbors
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 12 Foreign Minister Adam Malik has declared that his country will send troops abroad to fight Communists of the Indochina war spreads to Malaysia and Thailand and represents a danger to Indonesian security.

title: Giants Make Roster Shifts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (UPI)  The San Francisco Giants put a pitcher, Don Mc Mahon, on the disabled list to day and brought up a reliever, Bill Faul, and an infielder, Frank Johnson, from Phoenix.

title: AVERAGES DECLINE ON STOCKS ABROAD
South Carolina Students Clash With Guard Again
description: Antiwar demonstrators bat tled the police and the National Guard yesterday at the Uni versity of South Carolina in Co lumbia and at several other col leges around the country.

title: Lykes to Pay Dividend
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 12 Directors of the Lykes Youngstown Corporation de clared a dividend of 15 cents a share on the common stock today, payable June 10 to shareholders of record May 22.

title: Advertising: J.W.T. Is Lighting Up L&M
description: Liggett & Myers is moving its L&M brand of cigarettes from Young & Rubicam to J. Walter Thompson, where it will join Chesterfield and Lark. Although measured media figures show that L&M was supported by some $10.49million in advertising, the actual figure is under stood to be closer to $6.5 million. But that's still a lot of smoke.

title: Montrealers Elated as Mayor Pulls Off Another Spectacular
description: MONTREAL, May 12  For Montrealers, today's announce ment that this metropolis had been awarded the 1976 Sum mer Olympics couldn't have come at a better time.

title: A PAROLEE LOSES GUNSEIZURE PLEA
description: A threejudge panel of the Federal Courtof Appeals ruled here yesterday that the con stitutional protection against in crimination by unlawfully seize evidence did not apply to a prisoner whose parole had been revoked.

title: 4 Killed as Cargo Plane Crashes on 6th TakeOff
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 12 (AP)A C101 cargo plane crashed on its sixth takeoff during tests today, killing all four on board.

title: Sammy Davis Jr. Weds Dancer
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) Sammy Davis Jr., the enter tainer and Altavise Gore, the captain of his dancing troupe, were married yesterday at the municipal courthouse here. The ceremony was performed by Judge Joseph Gold in his cham bers. Mr. Davis married Mai Britt, the Swedish actress, in November of 1960. They were divorced in December of 1968. The 44yearold entertainer had previously been married to Lor ray White. That marriage also ended in divorce. It was the first marriage for Miss Gore, whose not disclosed.

title: Perahia Harnesses Virtuosity To Sensitivity in Piano Recital
description: There were times during Murray Perahia's recital Mon day night at the Metropolitan Museum's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium when the young pianist's performance put the listener in mind of the late Dinu Lipatti, an artist who mingled virtuosity and sensibil ity in rare degree. Particular was that true in four Im promptus of Chopin, when Mr. Parahia spun out the notes scintillatingly while keeping a certain aristocratic distance from their flashy surfaces.

title: Odyssey Addicts to Assist TV Program on Narcotics
description: A daytime serial on the American Broadcasting Coln pany will become the first regu larly scheduled program to, heed a White House request, made last month, to use com mercial television entertain ment to carry a warning on narcotics abuse to viewers.

title: GROWING PRESSURES AWAIT FINANCINGS
description: Capital markets in the United States could suffer greater pres sures in the next decade than they did in the late nine teensixties, Maurice A. Mann assistant director of the Budg et Bureau, said yesterday.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: We understand.

title: Brian London to Quit Ring After Losing by Knockout
description: LONDON, May 12 (AP)Joe Bugner, a British heavyweight, Pummeled Brian London with Flurry of right hands and knocked out the former world title contender at 1 minute 25 seconds of the fifth round to night. London announced after the fight that he would retire from boxing.

title: EXCHANGE EASES OFFBOARD RULE
description: The New York Stock Ex change has quietly altered a controversial regulation that goes to the heart of the Big Board's role as an exclusive central auction market for se curities.

title: GENERAL ANDERS, POLISH WAR HERO
description: LONDON, May 12 (Reuters)  Gen. Wladyslav Anders, who commanded Polish troops who fought with the Allies in World War II, died in a hospital here early today after suffering an apparent heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: PRICE RISES ARE SET BY REPUBLIC STEEL
description: CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP) The Republic Steel Corporation announced today that effective June 1, it was increasing the prices of certain products to bring them in line with the competition.

title: Tuesday Baseball
description: BatteriesMerritt and Bench; Blass, Giusti (8), Walker (9) and Sanguillen.

title: Blackmun Approved, 940; Nixon Hails Vote by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  Harry Andrew Blackmun, a 61 yearold Federal appellate judge from Minnesota, was unanimously confirmed by the Senate today as the 99th Jus tice of the United States Su preme Court.

title: In Memoriam
description: BERGHattle. In memory of our wife mother, grandmother & greatgrandmother. Always in our hearts. Jack Berg & family.

title: '70 AMERICAS CUP IN GOLF DROPPED
description: The Americas Golf Cup match has been discontinued by mu tual agreement of the United States Golf Association the Royal Canadian Golf Associa tion, and the. Mexican Golf Association. The 1970 match was to have taken place July 24 and 25 at the Broadmoor Golf Club, Colorado Springs, Colo.

title: Parents Receive Letter
description: LORAIN, Ohio, May 12  The family of William K. Schroeder, one of the four stu dents killed at Kent State, re ceived a letter of sympathy from President Nixon today.

title: Prince Calls for Support
description: HONG KONG, May 12Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the ousted Chief of State of Cambodia, has asserted in Peking that patri otic armed forces loyal to him are dealing severe blows to the United States invaders of Cam bodia.

title: NURTAGH JAILS 2 LINKED TO GRAFT
description: State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh sentenced two convicted gamblers to pris on yesterday in a case, he said, that clearly demonstrated widespread police corruption by gamblers.

title: ALLIES TERM DRIVE BIG BLOW TO REDS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12Allied officials said to lay that two weeks of opera tions in Cambodia had frag mented the Vietnamese Com munist military and had pushed its major fighting units off bal ance. The officials also said that allied troops had captured enough munitions for a five month enemy attack in South Vietnam.

title: Susan Gordon Will Be Bride Of G. D. Venable
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 12 Miss Susan Brooks Gordon and Gene Dubois Venable plan to be married in August in New London, N. H.

title: U.S. Issues Affect Governor's Race
description: Governor Rockefeller de clared yesterday that national issues might well be involved in the gubernatorial cam paign because they infringe on the life of the state.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: By ROBERT A. WRIGHT Special to The New York Times

title: Pressure on President
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The Nixon Administration has now reached a critical period of its tenure as it tries to pull the nation, and itself, back together again after a momentous fort night of strain and tumult. In the wake of the outcry over Cambodia and Kent, there is evident throughout the top of the Government strong desire to unite in defense of the Presidency, to guard its powers against dismem berment in Congress and to guard its authority against dis credit abroad. But there are also signs of a new battle for the ear and favor of the Presi dent, a battle that may reopen many of the yearold argu ments here about the direction of Government, about youth and blacks and civil liberties and economic priorities.

title: Kosygin Vows Support to Sihanouk but Is Silent on Recognition
description: MOSCOW, May 12The So viet Union has welcomed the formation of Prince Norodom Sihanouk's United National Front of Kampuchea, but so far continues to refrain from grant ing his governmentinexile for mal recognition.

title: Summary of Rent Plan
description: Following are details of Mayor Lindsay's proposed changes in the city's rentcontrol law:

title: Voloshen Appeal Denied
description: BALTIMORE, May 12. (AP) A Federal judge has refused to dismiss fraud charges against Nathan M. Voloshen, 72years old Mr. Voloshen, Darwin C. Brown, a Washington lawyer and Mervin C. Clark are ac cused of defrauding a Balti more canvas manufacturer of $10.000.

title: Midtown Bank Robbed
description: Two bandits, one with a gun, took $1,000 from a teller yes terday, in the Empire Savings Bank, 2 Park Avenue, near East 32d street, the police re ported.

title: ACQUITTALS CALLED A SPUR TO CRIMINALS
description: Dispatch of The Times, London

title: Directed Acquittal Is Denied In Jersey Bribery Trial
description: NEWARK, May 12 (AP)A Federal judge denied today a motion by lawyers for Walter Zirpolo, former Woodbridge Township Mayor, for a directed verdict of acquittal in his briberyconspiracy trial here.

title: German Money Reserves Up
description: FRANKFURT, May 12 (Reu ters)The central bank said West Germany's liquid mone tary reserves rose by 200mil lion marks to 22,982million marks in the week ended May 6. The West German mark is quoted at approximately 27.54 cents. Foreign deposits and foreign moneymarket invest ments rose by 200million marks to 8.285million marks.

title: MOSCOW BEATEN ON SECOND BALLOT
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, May 12Montreal was awarded the 1976 Summer Olympic Games and Denver the Winter Games today.

title: Gov. Tiemann in Close Nebraska G.O.P. Race
description: OMAHA, May 12 (AP) Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann and an Omaha businessman, Clif ton B. Batchelder, waged closed battle today for the Re publican governorship nomina a tion in Nebraska's primary election.

title: June Election Probable As Wilson Leads in Poll
description: LONDON, May 12A fresh public opinion poll tonight appeared to make an early general election in Britain a near certainty.

title: ISRAELIS STRIKE GUERRILLA AREA WITHIN LEBANON
description: JERUSALEM, May 12Israeli tanks and other armored forces struck across the Lebanese bor der early today in response to a growing wave of guerrilla at tacks on Israeli frontier settle ments.

title: Laird Says Thousands Have Already Left Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that several thousand American troops had already been with drawn from Cambodia and that more would be with drawn this week. Mr. Laird also predicted that all ground combat in Vietnam would be taken over by South Viet namese forces by July, 1971. Some United States ground forces would remain in Viet nam, he said, but they would not be assigned to combat missions. Testifying before the Senate Armed Service Committee, Mr. Laird also said that the major portion of our forces will be ?? drawn from Cambodia by June 15. Mr. Laird reiter ated President Nixon's pledge that all American troops would leave Cambodia by the end of June. In answer to a question, Mr. Laird said he would not rule out the further use of American air power in Cambodia to strike at sus pected enemy supply routes. He refused to exclude the pos sibility that South Vietnamese forces might go back into Cam bodia on their own in the fu ture if Communist forces move back into the sanctuary areas.
