title: Theater: Leibman Checks In With Room Service
description: WHEN I consider most new plays, I thank God for old ones. Of course, new plays are vital to the theater, but it must also be remem bered that if you have not actually seen a play, then it is new to you. And if you have seen it perhaps you will be able to welcome it back as an old friend.

title: No. 1 in Newark Vote
description: IN the 1966 mayoralty elec tion in Newark, the incum bent, Hugh J. Addonizio, ex pected to defeat his principal opponent, former Mayor Leo P. Carlin, by a comfortable majority. But a spoiler named Kenneth A. Gibson polled 20 per cent of the vote, forcing Mr. Addonizio into a runoff with Mr. Carlin. In Tuesday's elec tion, Mr. Gibson aimed to be not the spoiler, but the winner. And he led the field of six with more than 42 per cent of the vote. He is a Negro, and since 1966 much has happened in Newark to make it possible for a black man to be elected mayor, even though Mr. Gib son still faces a runoff before achieving that goal. The Negro population has grown, for one thing. For another, Mr. Addonizio's popularity declined after the 1967 riots in Newark, and he went into Tuesday's election under in dictment for extortion, con spiracy and income tax evasion.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt.Estab lished conservationists should not look down their noses at those newly con cerned with environmental quality, Sydney Howe, presi dent of the Conservation Foundation, told members of the Connecticut River Water shed Council, Inc., at their recent annual meeting at the Woodstock Inn.

title: 12Area City of 300,000 Proposed for Staten Island
description: A proposal to create a $6.5 billion new city within a city on vacant and underdeveloped land on the southwestern end of Staten Island was suggested yesterday by consultants hired by the city.

title: ATTACKS REPORTED IN RICE AREA OF LAOS
description: VIENTIANE. Laos, May 13 (AP)North Vietnamese forces, which informants said appar ently had moved in from Cam bodia, are reported to be at tacking Laotian military posi tions on the Bolovens Plateau, a ricegrowing area in southern Laos.

title: 1,000 Leaders of High School Strike Plan as They Camp in 5th Ave. Center
description: Moe than a thousand high school students have moved their guitars, their posters and their anger into the graduate center of the New School for Social Research. There, for the last week, they have been talk ing, singing, sleeping and eat ing as they coordinate their citywide strike activities pro testing conditions in the high schools, in America generally and in Indochina.

title: San Marino Seeks Funds
description: SAN MARINO (AP)  This republic of 18,181 people is calling for higher assessments on motor travel, land tenancy, liquor and imported wines to offset an indicated $2,289mil lion deficit in the 197071 budget.

title: DDT PRODUCTION BANNED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 13  The Ministry of Agriculture dis closed today that it had banned the further production of the pesticide DDT which is used to protect food and fodder crops.

title: Anita M. Schenck Will Become Bride
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 13Miss Anita Mitchell Schenck and Juraj Zednik, students at the Technische Hochschule in Aachen. West Germany, have made plans to be married Aug. 29 in Scars dale.

title: MORE AMERICANS OUT OF CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13Several companies of American troops withdrew from Cambodia today after only a partial search of a sus pected North Vietnamese base area in the Sesan region of the Central Highlands west of Pleiku.

title: Publishers Report a Decline in Sales of Textbooks
description: POCONO MANOR, Pa., May 13Textbook publishing in America is facing a multitude of troublestroubles with the Federal Government, with a sizable segment of the student population that is demanding more relevant books and with students who, to some extent, are forsaking reading for po litical action.

title: PANTHER JURY BARS CONTEMPT CHARGES
description: CHICAGO, May 13  A Federal grand jury declined today to seek contempt cita tions against two Black Pan thers who refused to testify in its investigation of possi ble violatons of the civil rights of Panthers who sur vived a raid by the Chicago police last December.

title: Brig. Gen. Joel G. Holmes Dead; World War II Ordnance Officer
description: Brig. Gen. Joel G. Holmes, a former Army ordnance offi cer, died at his home in Toms River, N. J., Tuesday of a head attack. He was 77 years old.

title: Attack Repulsed by G.I.'s
description: FIRE BASE BROWN, Cambo dia, May 13North Vietnamese saboteurs snipped the wires of warning flares and mines this morning and slipped through the barbed wire protecting this exposed American artillery base three miles inside Cam bodia and 95 miles north of Saigon.

title: Youth Shot in Leg As Gang Terrorizes Syracuse Hospitals
description: SYRACSUE, May 13 (AP) A black youth was shot in the leg tonight while a gang of vandals roamed a 10block area here firebombing at least four stores, smashing windows and terrorizing two hospitals, the police reported.

title: PIANIST AND FLUTIST DISPLAY THEIR SKILLS
description: Jayn Rosenfeld, flutist, and Cheryl Seltzer, pianist, put to gether an absorbing program seldomheard works for the concert they gave at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night.

title: BAPTIST HEAD ASKS UNITY FOR CHURCH
description: CINCINNATI, May 13The Rev. Dr. Thomas Kilgore Jr., president of the American Bap tist Convention, called today upon his denomination to take the lead in forming a pan Baptist movement, under which more than 20 million churchgoersblack and white could make common cause against racism, war and secu larism.

title: F.T.C. HEAD URGES BETTER PRODUCTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission told a re tailers' convention here today that a lot of people are using the mask of spreading con sumerism to try to prove that capitalism is not working.

title: PERSONNEL DIRECTOR IS NAMED BY LINDSAY
description: Harry I. Bronstein, who en tered city service in 1935 as $15aweek clerk, was named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as the city's $41,000ayear per sonnel director and chairman of the City Civil Service Com mission.

title: STANS SEEKS AID OF U. S. BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)The Government ap pealed to American business men today for help in finding and eliminating the bottlenecks that impede exports and hin der a balanceofpayments sur plus. We in the Commerce De partment are convinced that the only way we can do an effective job for the nation and for business is to establish a much closer working relation ship with business on interna tional economic matters, the Secretary of Commerce, Mau rice H. Stans, told 500 busi nessmen.

title: Ingenuity Helps to Hail Scarce City Cabs
description: On a recent morning Cathy Field, a greeneyed brunette who works as a film editor, stood in the street outside her East Side apartment, placed two fingers of each hand in the corners of her mouth and emitted an earsplitting mega whistle that brought a taxi to an abrupt halt.

title: Pittsburgh Court Orders Public Hearings on LTV
description: Judge Louis Rosenberg of the Federal District Court in Pitts burgh ordered yesterday that public hearings be held before any decision on a settlement proposal made by LingTemco Vought, Inc., and the Justice Department.

title: The Theater: Hanley's Slow Dance
L.I. High School Students Relate Drug Use to Habits of Parents
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. L, May 13Parental habits drinking habits, in particular were found to significantly af fect drug use among high school students, according to a survey made by the students themselves.

title: Turnaround in Rent Policy
description: The overhaul of rent control proposed by Mayor Lindsay represents a basic turnaround in a 27yearold system that has contributed to the grievous decay the city's housing supply.

title: AvantGarde Moscow Theater Scored
description: MOSCOW, May 13The head of the theatrical union has accused Yuri Lyubimov, director of a Moscow avant garde theater, of failure to show proper concern for the ideological battle with the West.

title: Books of The Times
description: ABOUT five years ago, the Committee on Science and Public Policy of the National Academy of Sciences de cided bravely to attempt a survey of the life sciencesthe state of the art, pros pects for the future, problems tractable and intractable. Comparable surveys had been published on the fields of mathe matics, computer science, astrono my, physics and chemistry. The trouble with try ing it on the life sciences (or, more specifically, biolo gy) was that so many subdisci plines were in volved, each dis tinct yet all inter dependent. To divide was to dis tort; to grasp the whole seemed Herculean. The academy neverthe less persisted, as signing almost 200 scientists to 21 panels. Each panel's report was roasted on a spit by the Survey Com mittee to get rid of its fat, and then sub mitted to the chairman, Philip Handler, for the final application of editorial sauce. (Mr. Handler, professor of biochemistry at Duke University, has since been elected president of the National Academy, per haps in gratitude.)

title: Goldfield Corp. Discloses Resignations of 2 Directors
description: Two former officers of the Goldfield Corporation resigned as directors, it was disclosed yesterday. They are Herman BeckerFluegel, who was suc ceeded last March 13 as pres ident by Ralph G. Worster, and George F. Warnock, former vice presidentmining. Mr. BeckerFluegel, a mining engi neer, had been appointed pres ident just a year ago.

title: PRINCE CHARLES ASSAILS PLANE
description: CAMBRIDGE England, May 13 (UPI)Prince Charles struck at pollution in unusually out spoken comments last night an said the multimillion dollar BritishFrench supersonic trans port, the Concorde, threatened the environment with sonic booms.

title: PANTHER'S CHARGE DENIED BY POLICE
description: Joan Bird, a Black Panther defendant who has said that she was beaten into making admissions at a police sta tion, was described in State Supreme Court yesterday as a very cooperative witness by an assistant chief inspector who saw her 10 hours after she was taken into custody.

title: Muskie Replies to Nader Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)Senator Edmund S. Muskie, under criticism from a team of Ralph Nader's stu dent investigators, gave to day a detailed defense of his efforts to clean the air and said, We intend to strength en the law this year.

title: Bond Club Nominates Chief
description: Avery Rockefeller Jr., presi dent of Dominick & Dominick, Inc., has been nominated for the presidency of the Bond Club of New York. He will suc ceed Robert A. Powers of Smith, Barney & Co., Inc. Nom ination is tantamount to elec tion, scheduled at the club's annual field day, June 5. The new slate also includes Robert M. Gardiner of Reynolds & Co., vice president; Robert F. Sha piro of Lehman Brothers, sec retary, and J. Squier Reimer of the First Boston Corporation, treasurer.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: PLANNERS SCORED ON LOWER 3D AVE.
description: The City Planning Commis sion's proposal for luxury hous ing on lower Third Avenue was assailed by neighborhood groups yesterday during a lengthy public hearing marked by raucous comments and shouted insults.

title: Magnuson Is Pleased
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI)  Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Wash ington, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, hailed the bill today as marking a new era for aviation  one in which the users of the airways paid more toward their cost, He predicted that President Nixon would sign the bill soon.

title: Gentry Yields One Hit, a Single by Banks in the 8th, as Mets Rout Cubs, 40
description: CHICAGO, May 13Gary Gentry came within four outs of pitching a nohitter today as the New York Mets returned to the scene of last year's crime and defeated the Chi cago Cubs. 40.

title: 6 DEAD IN AUGUSTA WERE SHOT IN BACK
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., May 13  The six Negro men killed in rioting here Monday and yes terday were all shot in the back, a physician who ex amined their bodies said today.

title: RHODESIAN OUTWITS CROC IN TUG OF WAR
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia (AP) A Rhodesian and his wife fought a grim tug of war with a crocodile in the Musarangadhli River and emerged alive.

title: A.A.U. Prize Winners
description: MEN'S AWARDS

title: TALK BY GARDNER BARRED IN ILLINOIS
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  The Illinois Constitutional Con vention refused today to let John W. Gardner deliver a scheduled speech in which he had planned to say that no ad vantage gained by force in Southeast Asia could compare with the damage that the war was inflicting at home.

title: UNION CHIEF SAYS THE CITY IS FILTHY
description: Never in the recollection of any city resident has the city been as dirty as it is today, John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association said yesterday.

title: Joins G.M. Reform Drive
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  Mr. Rockefeller gave his sup port today to the Campaign to Make General Motors Respon sible.

title: F. J. LEERBURGER, 67, ENGINEER AIDED U.N.
description: Franklin J. Leerburger, a consulting engineer who was an adviser to the United Na tions development program, died here Monday. He was 67 years old and lived at 301 East 66th Street.

title: Drug AbuseIII
description: The response to the drug problem in this state and city, where it is more acute than anywhere else in the nation, has been shockingly slipshod and worse. Engaging in an internecine struggle among themselves, state and local officials have failed, first, to alert society to the growing dimensions of the drug prob lem and, second, to move responsibly to take remedial action. They even denied for awhile that there was teenage addict problem, until the rising death toll among teenage addicts made further denial impos sible. Their utter ineptitude has caused the wasting of millions of tax dollars.

title: Calling of Kriegel and Fraiman Not Discussed in Graft Inquiry
description: The special committee in vestigating police corruption in New York has discussed the possibility of calling policemen to testify, but has not dis cussed calling either Jay Krie gel, an assistant to Mayor Lind say on law enforcement or Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman, the former Inves tigation Commissioner.

title: Goldberg's Stand on Reform And War Scored by Samuels
description: Howard J. Samuels, one of the two Democrats remaining in the race for Governor, said yesterday that he did not know whether he could support the organization designee, Arthur J. Goldberg, if Mr. Goldberg won the June primary.

title: Fire in Draft Offices
description: DETROIT, Allay 12 (AP)De troit Fire Department officials said Wednesday arson was sus pected in a fire early this morn ing at two Selective Service of fices. Local Boards 186 and 187, both in the same building, re ported heavy damage after a fire burned an hour and a half. Fire Department spokesmen say that a gasoline can had been found near the scene.

title: Bayonne Goes Dry 18 Hours
description: BAYONNE, N. J., May 13 This city of 71,000 was al most entirely without water today for more than 18 hours as a result of two main breaksone at about 11:15 o'clock last night and an other at 3 this morning.

title: Martha Oates to Be Married To Harry C. Schaub on July 11
description: Miss Martha Jane Oates and Harry C. Schaub, both of Philadelphia, plan to be mar ried on July 11 at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Cyril Jack Oates in Stinnett, Tex.

title: 28,000 BRITISH JOBS FOUND FOR DISABLED
description: LONDONRemploy a com pany set up after World War II to provide jobs for the severely disabled, has celebrated its silver jubilee.

title: Nonprofit Hospitals Fear Patient Costs Nay Go Up to $140
description: The city's private nonprofit hospitals warned yesterday that the average cost of hospital carenow $98 a day for each patientwould rise to $140 a day if they were forced to meet union wage demands.

title: 6th U. S. General Killed in War; Copter Shot Down Near Pleiku
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13 (AP)Maj. Gen. John A. B. Dillard, head of the United States Army Engineer Com mand in South Vietnam, was killed yesterday when the heli copter in which he was flying was shot down, the United States Command announced to day.

title: President of Bank in Miami Is Told to Keep Her Miss
description: MIAMI (AP)  Miss Agnes Barber has changed her name since becoming a bank presi dent, but she remains the only woman bank president in the Greater Miami area.

title: Expos Option Qualls
description: MONTREAL, May 13 (AP) The Montreal Expos optioned an infielderoutfielder, Jim Qualls, to the Buffalo Bisons of the International League on a 24hour recall basis today.

title: Dyce to Get Metropolitan A.A.U. Award Here Tonight
description: Byron Dyce, outstanding New York University running star, will be the recipient of the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's mertiorious award tonight as the out standing athlete in the area at the A.A.U.'s 16th annual awards dinner at the Down town Athletic Club.

title: Arab Guerrillas Elated, See Battle as a Victory
description: RASHEIYA, Lebanon, May 13  Palestinian commandos who rushed from refugee camps throughout Lebanon yesterday to defend their stronghold In the Arkoub area against Israelis were streaming homeward again today.

title: Acquisition by Armco of Hitco Cleared by Justice Department
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday that the Justice Department had cleared its acquisition of Hitco of Los Angeles, a producer of non metallic composite materials and reinforced plastics.

title: Greek Group Plans To Cite Van Fleet
description: Gen. James A. Van Fleet will be honored Sunday at a testimonial dinner sponsored by the United Greek Ortho dox Charities to raise money for Hellenic College in Brook line, Mass.

title: Thant Denies He Suggested Asian Parley on Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13  Secretary General Thant has denied that he sug gested Asian countries hold the forthcoming conference on the Cambodian problem. Reports from Jakarta published in The New York Times and elsewhere have quoted Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia as saying that Mr. Thant made the suggestion to him during a meeting last month in Manila.

title: 50 $5 Bills Adorn Jacket
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio (AP) On his 39th anniversary as pas tor of the Mount Zion Baptist Chruch, the Rev. W. A. Clark was presented with a new black lounging jacketfestooned wit 50 $5 bills.

title: House Backs Nixon on Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 President Nixon's plan for re organizing the budgetary and domestic policy operations of the White House narrowly survived a challenge in the House today.

title: Problems of a Cambodia Pullout
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13The Saigon Government's determination to continue and expand its military operations inside Cambodia may well complicate the Nixon Adminis tration's announced goal of withdrawing all American forces from Cambodia by the end of June. In separate remarks during the last few days. President Nguyen Van Thieu and Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky have made unmis takably clear their intention to carry on militarily inside Cam bodia after the deadline for the American withdrawal. For the Nixon Administration, this rais es a basic question: Will it be militarily feasible for the Amer icans to quit Cambodia by July 1 as Mr. Nixon has pledged, if the South Vietnamese insist on operating across the border after that?

title: Seminoles Awarded $12Million For Florida Lands U.S. Seized
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)  The Seminole Indians, who owned most of Florida 150 years ago, were awarded $12, 347,500 today for land taken from them by United States military forces.

title: Antiwar Protests Disrupt Many High Schools Here
description: Tens of thousands of city high school students continued to stay out of classes yesterday as antiwar demonstrations and other protests took place in and around many schools here.

title: Chess
description: THE Soviet chess cha pionship in Moscow last October, between former world champion Tigran Pe trosian and Lev Polugayev sky, ended in a tie for first place. As a result, a playoff match of six games was ar ranged, which resulted in a victory for Petrosian with two games won and three drawn, 31. The two Petrosian victories appear below.

title: SINKS TO 693.84
description: The DowJones industrial averaged plummeted 10.75 points yesterday to 693.84  thereby carving out a new low for a period of nearly seven yearsas investors and bro kers reeled under the impact of the worst bear market since the Depression.

title: Modern Merchandising Format Makes Animal Shelter Success
description: HOW to make a small mori bund animal shelter, no tably the North Shore Animal League of Port Washington, L.I., into a lively, successful organization through the ap plication of modern merchan dizing methods was told yes terday by Alexander M. Lewyt, North Shore's president. He spoke at the season's final meeting of the Dog Fanciers Club at the Overseas Press Club.

title: U.S. Acted in November
description: The United States Governmen announced last November that it planned to phase out most domestic uses of DDT over a twoyear period. It began by ordering the halt of the use of DDT in residential areas by the end of 1969.

title: Mets BooksI
description: IN the spring of 1955 an owner of the New York Giants flew to San Francisco for the baseball team's opening game in its new home. Once back in New York she found that life was not the same. She still had her stable, her art gallery, her private railroad car, her homes in Maine, Kentucky, Florida, Long Island and upper Fifth Avenue. She still had her Gauguins, Renoirs and Van Goghs on the wall, and she had a certain attachment to the Re publican party (she had donated $65,000 to the G.O.P. 956). But now she had to fly 3,000 miles if she want ed to watch her favorite baseball team. Even for a Whitney, that can be a drag.

title: Briton Finds Ancient Cave
description: WOOKEY HOLE, England (AP)A huge cave has been discovered by John Parker, a 22yearold skin diver, in the Wookey Hole complex of cav erns, one of the earliest known habitats of man in England.

title: Brundage Said to Seek Extra Power to Bar Olympians Found Not Amateurs
description: AMSTERDAM, The Nether lands, May 13It appeared today that the 69th Interna tional Olympic Committee congress would again defer action on the biggest prob lem facing the Games professionalism and com mercialism.

title: Army Eleven to Stress Air Power in Fall
description: IMAGINE Army throwing passes on more than 50 per cent of its plays next foot ball season and doing so with a passer who was the second string quarterback a year ago when that posi tion was not one of the Black Knights' strong points. This be came more than a slight possibility when Coach Tom Cahill's forces went through their squad game at the conclusion of spring prac tice recently. That game turned into a footballstyle air raid.

title: TEACHERS OFFER TO FORGO RAISE
description: LOS ANGELES, May 13 (A)Striking teachers voted today to return to workand to forgo an offered 5 per cent raise so that the money could go for smaller classes and improve reading programs.

title: Jersey City's Political Scene Viewed as an Old Show
description: JERSEY CITY, May 12The toothless old man com plained of a bum leg and spat repeatedly and insistently onto the street until a bat tered red bus pulled up to the curb. Before he painfully monted the steps, he turned to a questioner and said: Everybody's crooked today nobody's hon est. They caught some official in a gambling joint the other night. So what? Two matrons, their years relent lessly showing through care fully applied makeup, were strolling along Journal Square, which is to this city what Times Square is to Manhat tan. They stopped to answer a reporter's question and one said philosophically, while the other nodded in assent: These things happen all over. It's inevitable that it'd hap pen in Jersey City.

title: IT'S USUALLY CALLED VICTORY BY EYELASH
description: Fractions of a second often separate defeat from triumph in highly competitive track and field events. But who would have envisioned 5/100ths of a second determining the out come of a sixmile foot race?

title: A High Court in Italy Rules Bankruptcy Can Cost Vote
description: ROME (AP)Italy's Consti tutional Court has ruled that an Italian can he deprived of his vote if he is bankrupt.

title: Young Lobbyists Push War Funds Ban
description: WASHINGTON, May 13A bipartisan group of young, liberal political activists an flounced today the formation of an organization to coordinate the lobbying effort for a Con gressional amendment that would withhold funds for mili tary operations in Southeast Asia.

title: Cambodian Withdrawal
description: The debate that has opened on the CooperChurch amendment now gives the Senate a chance to vote a proposal that would bind President Nixon to his promise of withdrawing American troops from Cam bodia. It would also make sure that he did not send them back without Congressional consent.

title: Hunting Accidents Decline For Fourth Straight Year
description: ALBANY (AP)Hunting ac cidents in New York state in 1969 declined for the fourth straight year, reports the Con servation Department.

title: COFFEE PRICES RISE AT GENERAL FOODS
description: The General Foods Corpora tion announced yesterday that it would raise the prices of its institutional roasted coffees, decaffeinated instant coffees and some regular instant cof fees, effective tomorrow.

title: Tokyo Cuts Factory Sites
description: TOKYO (AP)In an effort to reduce industrial smoke and noise, Tokyo has built 8,266 houses, 39 parks and 11 play grounds since 1964 on former factory sites purchased by the Government.

title: POSTAL REFORM GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 Acting under the threat of second mail strike, key Senators worked out a compromise with the Nixon Administration to day and predicted quick pas sage of a bill combining postal reform with an S per cent pay increase.

title: Woes End Way of Life
description: GENEVA, May 13A way of life has ended at the company that Bernard Cornfeld founded, and no one is quite certain what will take its place. The scenes today at Investors Over seas Services are those of total confusion, which is about what to expect in a period of revolu tion, corporate or political.

title: Observer: President's Big Break
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  Question: Having advised the President as to the conduct of the Asiatic war, dilated upon the sundry excellences of youth, condemned the excesses of violence regardless of its perpetrators' purity of political purpose, and publicly urged upon the Vice President a more temperate oratorical policy, what beverage did our narra tor consume, in what quantity did he consume it, and what emotion predominated in his breast during his consumption?

title: ISRAELIS' FORCE LEAVES LEBANON AFTER 32 HOURS
description: TEL AVIV, May 13  An Israeli armored force ended its thrust into southeast Lebanon this morning and returned to Israeli soil by midday after a 32hour operation described as a drive against Arab guerrilla positions.

title: Top Fives Lose One Each
description: The University of California, Los Angeles, the National Col legiate basketball champion, and runnerup Jacksonville lost only one player from their starting lineups via graduation this year. The are John Vallely, a Bruin guard, and Rex Morgan, a Dolphin guard.

title: MRS. MILTON A. SKAATES
description: YONKERS, May 13Mrs. Abbie Dubois Skaates, wife of Milton A. Skaates, a retired railroad man, died yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 77 Walsh Road.

title: BOND RATES RISE
description: Bond yields continued to reach record levels yesterday. These milestones were set dur ing a day of heavy financing activity:

title: When in Doubt, There's Always Chanel
description: WITH true believers having trouble making long clothes for next fall look in viting, what's an infidel to do? Turn to Chanel, for one thing.

title: A Chef May Re tire From the Business but Never From Kitchen
description: YOU are an artist, perhaps, and want to do something more for the wife than send a greeting card. So you create something.

title: Access to the President
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 Some months ago, after a formal dinner at the White House in honor of Prince Philip, Kingman Brewster, Jr., President of Yale University, encountered a reporter he knew outside the mansion. I talked to the President and Henry Kissinger [the President's na tional securtiy adviser] he said. I tried to get through to them about what's happening on the campuses. I don't think I did. Kissinger was mainly worried about what the right wing would do if we failed to get an honorable settlement in Vietnam.

title: Edmonton Invites Visitors
description: EDMONTON, Alberta (Cana dian Press)In a move designed to attract more visitors, Mayor Ivor Dent has decided to send a personal invitation to rela tives and friends of Edmonton residents who telephone the visitor's bureau with names and addresses.

title: Outrage Gives Way to Confusion Among U.C.L.A. War Critics
description: LOS ANGELES, May 14 Lyra Halprin was wearing a blueandwhite button on her pink, sleeveless dress. It said, simply, Enough.

title: Ford to Manufacture a Small Car to Compete With the Volkswagen
description: DETROIT, May 14The Ford Motor Company con firmed today that it would build a Volkswagensize car this fall called the Pinto with no styling changes likely in the future.

title: Capital's Constitutional Problem: Does Power to Make War Belong to President or Congress?
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The students who have left the campus to lobby in the Con gress this week obviously thought they were leaving aca demics for politics, but they are caught up now in one of the most difficult intellectual prob lems of American constitutional law: the power to make war.

title: JACKSON POLICE FIRE ON STUDENTS
description: JACKSON, Miss., Friday, May 15Two persons were killed and 12 wounded early today after the police opened fire on a women's dormitory at Jackson State College here.

title: Samuels Regards Party as Disgrace
description: Howard J. Samuels, a Democratic candidate for Governor, described his party as a disgrace yesterday and said he was considering supporting selected Republi cans for Congress to begin reforming the Democratic party.

title: Commuters Asked to Help
description: The United Fund of Great er New York, is making a special appeal to suburbanites this year to help support 425 com munity services and the Red Cross, which helps nearly four million people annually. The commuter has a vital stake in the city wellbeingeven though he does not live there  because his contribution helps to maintain a favorable economic climate for business and industry and makes New York a better place in which work.

title: AMEX PRICE INDEX CONTINUES TO SLIP
description: It was just as dreary inside the American Stock Exchange yesterday as outside, where the sun scarcely shone, as prices continued to drop and shares finished at their lowest level since August, 1967, in slightly steppedup trading.

title: Jersey Will Ballot on Vote at Age 19
description: TRENTON, May 14Bend ing under intense, lastminute pressure from Gov. William T. Cahill, the Republican majority in the Assembly reversed itself this evening and gave final leg islative approval for a Novem ber referendum on lowering the voting age in New Jersey from 21 to 19.

title: Richard A. Irwin, 74, Broker In Big Offshore Oil Deals
description: KINGSTON, Tenn., May 14 Richard A. Irwin, an oil mil lionaire, died today at his home overlooking Watts Bar Lake in Ten Mile community near here. He was 74 years old.

title: GAMMA RAYS TIED TO CRAB NEBULA
description: PARIS, May 13Clear plas tic balloons soaring into the stratosphere over the flatlands of southern France have sent back data indicating the pres ence of a source of gamma rays in the remote Crab nebula.

title: Dining Out: Argentine Fare in Colorful Setting
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vi cinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Purged Scholar

title: REUTHER IS LAUDED AT LASKER LUNCH
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy described the proposal for na tional health insurance yester day as the single most im portant, imaginative and far sighted legislation to be in troduced in the 91st Congress.

title: Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: LOUIS PENSAK, HELD TELEVISION PATENTS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 14 Louis Pensak, physicist of RCA Laboratories, who de veloped an aluminized pictures, tube used in television receiv ers, died yesterday in Princeton Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 119 Random Road.

title: Women's Federation Elects
description: ELLENVILLE, N. Y., May 13 Mrs. Alonzo Quinn of Hunt ington, L. I., was elected and installed as president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs today at the Hotel Nevele. The federation is a philanthropic organization with more than 10,000 women members in the state.

title: Jane Alpert's Bail In BombPlot Case Declared Forfeited
description: Jane Lauren Alpert, who pleaded guilty May 4 to being part of a conspiracy to bomb Federal office buildings here last fall, was declared yester day to have forfeited her $20, 000 bail. The reason was that she violated the conditions of bail by not checking in with the United States Attorney's of fice this week.

title: TRINIDAD OWNERSHIP OF INDUSTRY URGED
description: The TrinidadTobago Govern ment's present trend is to en courage the development of Trinidadianowned industry, Sir Ellis Clarke, TrinidadTobago's ambassador to the United States, told a group of Ameri can, British and Canadian bankers and industrialists yesterday.

title: PRICES PLUMMET IN WHEAT FUTURES
description: Wheat futures dropped sharply again yesterday in ad vance of what appears to be another large winter wheat crop. Commercial interests were on the selling side to commission houses and local professionels, among others.

title: For Weekend Chef
description: IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: TRADE PAYMENTS DROPPED SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The United States balance of inter national payments worsened sharply in the first quarter by both means of measurement, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Letter Carriers Postpone Strike Action Until June 12
description: Possible strike action by members of Branch 36 of the New York Letter Carriers was postponed yesterday until June 12 after a noisy meeting at Manhattan Center.

title: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at PhiladelphiaSeaver (61) vs. a Jackson (14).

title: DR. FRANK MAZZOLA, CARDIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Frank R. Mazzola, car diologist and internist, who had practiced medicine in Queens for 48 years, died Monday of a heart attack at Mary Immacu late Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 73 years old and lived at 8629 Eton Street, Jamaica Estates.

title: Roundup: Shannon's Debut Is More Than Routine Out
description: Mike Shannon has provided St. Louis fans with a little medical education this sea son, and now they're hoping he can give them a lot of baseball excitement.

title: Harvest of Unreason
description: Violence and physical coercion are never acceptable ingredients of political action. Whether lawless forays against free speech and legitimate dissent are carried out by radical students or by angry construction work ers, the appropriate answer is the enforcement of the laws to maintain civic peace, protect civil liberties and prevent physical iniuries.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus Showed a Decline in April
description: TOKYO, May 14 (Reuters) The Finance Ministry said to day that Japan had a trade surplus of $58,498,000 in April, down from $88,609,000 in March. The Ministry's customs clearance statistics showed that exports in April totaled $1,533, 045,000 clown from 1,617,681, 000 in March.

title: Houseboats Solving Shortage of Yugoslav Hotels
description: MARJAN, Ljubo, Jurij, Ro mano, Slobodan, Ivica and Nevenko are seven young Yugoslays who are helping their country, get a jump on the United States. The group recently completed a tour of American marinas and boatyards that is ex pected to lead to Yugoslavia having the world's largest houseboat rental fleet. By the end of next month, a consor tium of Yugoslav resort hotels, operating three houseboat marinas along the Adriatic coast, will he using a fleet of 40 houseboats and sport fishing craft. By the end of July, the total is ex pected to reach 98.

title: Yields Set Record For TaxExempts
description: The Bond Buyer Index, the most widely used measure of yields on taxexempt state and city bonds, climbed yes terday to 6.96 per cent, the highest level in the 75year history of this indicator.

title: Military Will Curb Ceremonies Noting Armed Forces Day
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 Fear of campusstyle antiwar demonstrations by offduty troops and civilians at major military posts this weekend has forced the cancellation or revi sion of traditional Armed Forces Day ceremonies at bases across the country.

title: BUSINESS INDICES INDICATE UPTURN IS STILL TO COME
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  Basic economic statistics for April, made public today by Government agencies, offered no support for the argument that business activity is already on the upturn. But they showed no significant worsening in the economy, either.

title: From Brazil Comes Film About Poet
Trevino, Player Share Lead
description: FORT WORTH, May 14 (AP) Lee Trevino carded a four underpar 66 today and tied Gary Player of South Africa for the firstround lead in the $125,000 Colonial National in vitation golf tournament.

title: ARMCO SEES DECLINE FOR SECOND QUARTER
description: William Verity, president of the Armco Steel Corporation, said at a news conference in Paris yesterday that the con cern probably would show a decline in secondquarter earn ings from the yearearlier level.

title: SWIRSKY OF ADELPHI TAKES COLLEGE GOLF
description: HARRISON, N. Y., May 14 Dennis Swirsky, an 18yearold freshman from Adelphi Univer sity, scored the first major tournament victory of his career today by winning the Metropol itan Golf Association's 21st intercollegiate tournament.

title: Loss in Quarter by Rails Cited in FreightRate Plea
description: With 27 of the nation's 72 big Class 1 railroads (those with operating revenues of more than $5million annually) operating in the red, the na tion's railroads ended the first quarter this year with a net loss of $2million. This was the worst showing for the indus try since 1961 and compared with a $94.4million profit re corded in the first quarter of 1969.

title: WEDNESDAY NIGHT FIGHTS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.Manuel Avitia, 148 pounds, of Mexico City, knocked out Hernando Vallegas, 151, Monterrey, Mex ico, 4 rounds.

title: 7 Comecon Nations Back Joint Investment Bank
description: WARSAW, May 14 (Reuters) The Premiers of the Soviet Union and six other Communist countries endorsed here today a draft agreement to set up an investment fank to finance co operative projects in Comecon, (the East European economic alliance.

title: David F. True to Wed Miss Katharine Emmet
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I., May 14  Mrs. Richard Stockton Emmet has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katharine Temple Emmet, to David Fulmer True, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. True of Marietta, Ohio. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: DePaula, Indicted Boxer, Shot Twice in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, May 14 Frank DePaula, once a light heavyweight boxing contender, was shot at 2:45 A.M. today as he left an apartment house on Harrison Avenue near West Side Avenue here.

title: French Rider, Here for a Day, Winds Up 4th to $38.40 Victor
description: Jean Claude DeSaint, one of France's leading jockeys, was brought all the way from Europe just to guide Mrs. Raymond R. Guest's Arvids jaur in yestterday's $18,000 Hichcock hurdles at Aque duct.

title: Boston Police Raid Investigated
description: BOSTON, May 14At least three official investigations were under way today into what one city official described as the worst case of police overreaction in recent Boston history.

title: MRS. WILLIAM CROCKER
description: Mrs. Eleanor Farrington Crocker, widow of the Rev. William T. Crocker, former rector of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, died Tuesday in her home, 30 Sutton Place. She was 92 years old.

title: Keino Out to Show Liquori Who's No. 1
description: In the language of Kip choge Keino, a worldclass runner who has seen his share of competitive mo ments and is traditionally cautious, it is going to be a good test.

title: Equity Library Revives Me and Juliet
description: IN Me and Juliet, the Rodgers and Hammerstein backstage musical that is being revived at the Master Institute by the Equity Li brary Theater, there is a scene in which a new girl, Betty, auditions for the sexy second lead. She just hap pens to know the song, the arrangement, and the dance and she is terrific. She wins the part (immediately) and also the stage manager (in the second act).

title: MAILMEN IN CANADA TO VOTE ON STRIKE
description: TORNOTO, May 14 (AP) Canada today faced the pros pect of a national postal strike following suspension of nego tiations between the Federal Government and postal unions over a wage increase.

title: Institution Insiders Blamed in Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that many of the recent acquisitions by conglomerate companies were made possible only with the help of large in stitutional Investors who had bought stock in the acquired companies. These investors, in turn, became interested in the deals only because they had re ceived illegal inside information about them, according to Hamer H. Budge the S. E. C chairman.

title: Alioto Jury Still Out
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 The jury considering Mayor Joseph L. Alioto's $12.5million libel suit against Look maga zine continued its deliberations today. The case went to the jury Tuesday.

title: Kennedy Center for the Arts To Seek Federal Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) The Federal Government may be asked to provide subsidies so the poor, the elderly and students can attend public service performances at reduced prices in the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: City Ballet Musicians' Strike Is Settled
description: Musicians of the New York City Ballet voted to end their 24day strike last night by ac cepting a factfinder's recom mendations for a fouryear con tract that will cutt he number of weekly performances from eight to seven in the fall of 1971.

title: President of Finland Names New Coalition Government
description: HELSINKI, Finland, May 14 (Reuters)President Urho Kek konen tonight appointed a new coalition Government, with Teuvo Aura, a Liberal who is Lord Mayor of Helsinki, as Premier.

title: Portuguese Will Investigate Clash at Coimbra University
description: LISBON, May 13The Portu guese Government acted today to forestall a new university crisis that might delay urgently needed reforms.

title: Lesotho Looks for a Way Out of Crisis
description: MASERU, Lesotho, May 11  Lesotho's Prime Minister, Chief Leabua Jonathan, said in an in terview this week that he was unique among African leaders because he was the only one who had put his opposition in jail and then opened political negotiations with them.

title: GONZALES UPSETS GIMENO BY 86, 64
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 14 (UPI)Pancho Genzales moved into the semifinals of the $50,000 Howard Hughes invi tation tennis tournament today by upsetting fourth  seeded Andres Gimeno of Spain, 86, 64.

title: 863 Saigon Soldiers Die In 2d Highest Weekly Toll
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 14Military officials an nounced today that 863 South Vietnamese soldiers were killed in battles in South Vietnam and Cambodia last week, the second highest weekly death toll of the war for the South Vietnamese. American losses168 killed and 1,001 woundedwere the highest in eight months.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE WITHDRAWS FUNDS
description: The Federal Reserve System last week withdrew a major portion of the massive amount of funds that it had injected into the money market the pre ceding week to support Treas ury financing operations, bank ing data published yesterday showed.

title: Soviet Flotilla Visits Cuba
description: CIENFUEGOS, Cuba, May 14 (Reuters)  A sevenvessel So viet vessel flotilla, including a nuclear submarine, arrived in this southern Cuban port today on a courtesy visit expected to last at least a week.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Commerce Department report ed today that department store sales for the week ended May 5 were an estimated $740million, 3 per cent above the $720mil lion sales for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $7.14billion, 3 per cent above the $6.96bil lion for the corresponding pe riod last year.

title: Rhodesia Withdraws From Davis Cup Play
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 14 (Reuters)Rhodesia withdrew today from further Davis Cup competition this year, tennis officials an nounced.

title: Sister Trinita, 75, Directed Maryknoll in Philippines
description: OSSINING, N. Y., May 14 Sister Mary Trinita Logue, re gional superior of the Mary knoll Sisters working in the Philippines from 1911 to 1946, died Monday at Bethany, Mary knoll's house for sick and elder ly sisters. She was 75 years old.

title: Hannah Butler Plans Nuptials To Alfred Steel Jr. on Sept. 12
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 14 Miss Hannah Dee Butler and Alfred Steel Jr. plan to be married here Seat. 12.

title: Italy Says Israeli Attacks In Lebanon Menace Peace
description: ROME, May 14An official in the Italian Foreign Ministry said today that Israeli attacks this week against Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon's Mount Hermon region constitute menace to peace, to the in tegrity and very existence of Lebanon and aggravate tension in the Middle East.

title: Bethea Predicts He Will Stop Benvenuti and Capture Title
description: At a quick glance, Torn (The Bomb) Bethea does not possess the credentials of a challenger for the world mid dleweight boxing champion ship. His brief record is mediocre10 victories, five defeats and one draw, with five knockouts. Scar tissue over his eyes make him vul nerable to a sharp puncher.

title: Rep. Moss Says Funds' Tactics In Congress May Stir Reprisal
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The way the Mutual Fund In dustry has gone about oppos ing legislation to regulate its fees has turned many members of Congress against the entire Securities Industry, in the opin ion of Representative John E. Moss. Democrat of California.

title: Advertising: Campaign Evaluation Taught
description: There's a lot more to ad vertising than meets the eye and meets the eye and meets the eye.

title: Labor Conflict Is Key Issue Facing Baseball Owners in Meeting Here Today
description: Baseball business will get a thorough airing from several directions today when all 24 major league club owners or their representatives hold a joint meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

title: Foreign Affairs: Breakfast or Supper?
description: MADRID  There are great expectations in Spain that the next month or so will see Gen eralissimo Franco begin to en gineer a political shift in the direction of what might be called an opening to the cen ter. The hope is that some of the bleaker vestiges of right wing autocracy can be shed, permitting at least a hint of democratization during the re gime's final moments.

title: Haitian Sailors in Shelling Of Capital Are Flown Here
description: About 60 refugees, crewmen aboard three Haitian Coast Guard cutters that shelled Port auPrince last month, arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night.

title: High Echelon and Personality, Jacobs Entry, Draw 1 and 2 Preakness Posts
No Time for Recrimination
description: After a mudslinging session Wednesday that did nothing to advance the cause of Middle East peace, the United Nations Security Council turned yesterday to somewhat more constructive debate on the real issues underlying the most recent flareup of ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: ISRAEL SAYS U.A.R. SANK FISHING BOAT
description: TEL AVIV, May 14  An Egyptian navy missile boat sent a 70ton Israeli fishing vessel with a crew of four to the bottom of the Mediterranean last night, the Israeli defense forces said today.

title: A LATE RECOVERY CUTS STOCK LOSS
description: The stock market toppled yesterday to a new low since April, 1963, as measured by the DowJones industrial average. A rally led by glamour issues in the final half hour on expand ing volume, however, reduced the day's loss markedly from its poorest level.

title: CONCERT REVIEWS STRING QUARTETS
description: To whom does the com poser of string quartets speak today? The question was raised by implication at Tully Hall Wednesday night, when the Fine Arts Quartet gave the first New York performances of three works commissioned and written for it within the last three years. The composers, Sey mour Shifrin, Karel Husa and Milton Babbitt, are men of skill known for the thought fulness and seriousness of their work, and Mr. Husa's Quartet No. 3 won the 1969 Pultizer Prize. Yet the au dience for the concert was small.

title: Market Place:
description: WHEN Electronic Data Sys tems made a bid for Collins Radio a little over a year ago, the scrappy little computer management com pany was well on the way to becoming a light blue chip holding for what Wall Street commonly refers to as ag gressive investors.

title: Centenary Planned
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia (Canadian Press)  The British Columbia Centennial '71 Com mittee has announced it will honor next year all British Columbia residents who have at tained or will attain their 100th birthday during 1971. The cen tenary marks the 100th anni versary of B.C.'s entry into Confederation.

title: DODD IS STRICKEN BY HEART ATTACK
description: NEW HAVEN, May 14Sena tor Thomas J. Dodd suffered a mild heart attack last night at a key point in his battle for a third term.

title: WARRANT FOR SEALE SUSTAINED BY COURT
description: NEW HAVEN, May 14 Superior Court Judge Haroid M. Mulvey today denied a mo tion to dismiss murder and kid nap charges against Bobby G. eale, a national chairman of the Black Panther party.

title: LEBANON ENTERED BY SYRIAN TROOPS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14  Several hundred Syrian troops entered Lebanon today and President Charles Helou called his Defense Minister and senior army officers to an urgent conference at the Presi dential Palace here to discuss what steps to take.

title: WALTER F. GAMMON
description: PALM BAY, Fla., May 14 Walter F. Gammon, a retired pressman at The New York Times, died today at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: Text of Letter to the Mayor by Committee Set Up to Investigate Charges of Police Corruption
description: May 14, 1970The Honor able John V. Lindsay Mayor of the City of New York, City HallNew York, N.Y. 10007. My Dear Mr. Mayor:

title: ACTION IS URGED ON ONEBANK LAW
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The Federal Reserve Board told Congress today that action was needed this year on legisla tion to regulate onebank hold ing companies.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Homosexuals Disrupt Psychiatrists' Parley
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (AP)  Twenty members of the Gay Liberation Front and Women's Liberation Move ment attempted today to take over an American Psychi atric Association session on sex problems.

title: Wilson Expected to Set June 18 for British Vote
description: LONDON, May 14  It now appears almost certain that June 18 will be the date of the next British general elec tion.

title: DENNIS C. MAHONEY
description: Dennis Curtis Mahoney, a lawyer here and in 195556 an Assistant United States Attor ney for the Southern District of New York, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital, after an illness of several months. He was 45 years old and lived at 16 East 80th Street and at Lily Pond Lane, East Hampton, L.I.

title: STOCKS IN TOKYO DECLINE SHARPLY
description: TOKYO, May 14The Tokyo stock market suffered another sharp decline in prices today, echoing the news that Wall Street's DowJones industrial average dropped below 700 yesterday.

title: Iraqi Diplomat Slain
description: NEW DELHI, May 14The Bombay police reported today that the Iraqi Consul General, Hammad Alhardan, had shot and killed the former Iraqi am bassador to Afghanistan, AIIM Said, in a personal quarrel.

title: President Bars Diversion of Model Cities Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  President Nixon decided today not to divert money from Mod el Cities and other programs under the Department of Hous ing and Urban Development for his special effort for school de segregation.

title: Policeman Says He Killed Youth With Accidental Shot
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 14 (AP)A 31yearold policeman says an uninten tional shot from his riot gun killed a student peacemaker in antiwar disorders last April at nearby Isla Vista.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MAY 15, 1970

title: Miller Tops German, 63, 64, In Eastern Hard Court Tennis
description: WOODBURY, L. I., May 14 Sixteenyearold Jeff Miller of Scotch Plains, N. J., upset Lieut. Harold German, the second seeded player, 63, 64, today in the quarterfinals of the East ern men's hard court tennis championships at the Wood bury Country Club.

title: Times Printers Lengthen Union Meetings in Effort to Break Labor Deadlock
description: Printers at The New York Times extended their nonwork ing chapel meeting sessions to 18 hours a day yesterday in an effort to break the deadlock in contract negotiations with the city's four major daily news papers.

title: Governor Says the State Guard Won't Have Guns on Campuses
description: BUFFALO, May 14Gover nor Rockefeller assured stu dents picketing his appearance here today that there could he no repetition of the Kent State University shooting on a New York campus.

title: WORLD SKI GROUP TO RULE ON PROS
description: AMSTERDAM, May 14  Many leading Alpine skiing stars will be disqualified from the 1972 Winter Olympics, not by Avery Brundage and the International Olympic Commit tee, but by the Federation In ternationale de Ski.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
Washington: President and Congress A Limited Battle
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  It is clear now that there is a de termined move in the Congress, and particularly in the Senate, to limit the President's war making powers by denying him funds to carry on the Indo china war as he pleases.

title: Big 4 Meet Again on Berlin
description: BERLIN, May 14The four power conference on Berlin went through its third, largely ceremonial, round here today. A highranking Western offi cial said the Western Allies planned to submit an agenda at the next session, scheduled for June 9, for a start on deal ing with road tolls and other measures bearing on access to West Berlin. The meeting was attended by the ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, May 15, 1970

title: Books of The Times
description: THERE was of course a time when Israel was not the strongest military power in the Middle East. In fact there was a time, Leonard Slater informs us, when David BenGurion stood before a small gathering of wealthy American Jews in a Manhattan penthouse and pleaded the unpopular view that the only hope for European Jewry was to set tle in Palestine and fight. We'll take care of the settling, Ben Gurion told his audience, but you must supply us an asenal. The date was July 1, 1945; the weather was stifling; the pros pects seemed dim. For how was one to ship arms out of a country that forbade doing so, and deliver them to a people that were forbidden to have them? Where was one to hide an antiaircraft gun, for instance? Yet three years later, when the British pulled out of Palestine and the Arabs invaded, the new nation was to stand its ground and beat the invaders back. The State of Israel was to survive its violent birth with guns blazing.

title: RAID BY EXTREMISTS WOUNDS 3 IN BERLIN
description: BERLIN, May 14Four poli tical extremists, two of them women, shot their way into a West Berlin scientific institute today, wounding three persons, to fre a 28yearold prisoner. The four escaped with the pris oner.

title: HARRY L. SIDE
description: Harry L. Side, a lawyer who retired last year as an assistant with corporation counsel, died yesterday in New York Hospi tal. He lived at 1044 East 19th Street, Brooklyn.

title: VANCE LAUDERDALE
description: CRESSKILL, N. J., May 14 Vance Lauderdale, a former partner in Hewitt, Lauderdale & Co., brokers, died Monday in a nursing home here. He was 80 years old.

title: WOMEN BAPTISTS WARN OF '71 FIGHT
description: CINCINNATI, May 14  A dispassionate revolt by church women raised its well coiffured head here today after a man was nominated for the presi dency of the American Baptist Convention.

title: Frederick E. Shoninger Dead; ExDirector of Yardley Was 69
description: RYE, N. Y., May 14Fred erick E. Shoninger, who retired last year as senior vice presi dent and director of Yardley of London, Inc., died today in St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 81 Park Drive North.

title: Miss Crowder, Jonathan Meyer Engaged to Wed
description: Miss Cynthia Susan Crow der, a pianist and composer, and Jonathan Eben Meyer, a flutist, plan to be married May 23 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy H. Hurlbert of New York, stepfather and mother of the bridetobe.

title: Text of Lindsay's Message Submitting His $7.8Billion Expense Budget
description: GentlemenI herewith sub mit the Executive Expense Budget for the fiscal year 197071.

title: Sant' Angelo's Fashions A Tribute to the Indians
description: FORGET about Ruritanian peasants, Alpine yodelers and 18thcentury milkmaids. The inside words to drop in fashion circles this minute are Aztec, Sioux, Maya, Inca, Carib, Eskimo. The trium phant showing of fall fash ions that Giorgio di Sant'An gelo unleashed in the confer ence room of the Seagram Building at noon yesterday was a paean of praise to the great American civiliza tions, from the Arctic to the Antarctic.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: DEL INSKO HOPES FOR FAST TRACK
description: YONKERS, May 14  All hands were rooting today for a fast track for tomorrow night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway. The prospects for precisely that were bright, in view of the Weather Bureau's forecast that the precipitation probability for tomorrow was only 10 per cent.

title: AGNEW IS ASSAILED BY EDITORS' LEADER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (UPI)The president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors said today that Vice President Agnew's attacks on the news media were a calcu lated campaign to weaken the credibility of the press.

title: Orthwein Is Named Chairman of D'Arcy
description: The D'Arcy Advertising Company has named James B. Orthwein, formerly an executive vice president, as chairman of the board. The 46yearold ad man replaces Harry W. Chesley Jr., 61, who has become chairman of international operations.

title: ExTeacher Pleads Guilty In 1968 Hijacking of Plane
description: MIAMI, May 14 (AP)  A former college teacher pleaded guilty in Federal court today to a charge that he hijacked light airplane to Cuba in 1968.

title: Metropolitan Museum Is Given Tabernacle as Centennial Gift
description: The Metropolitan Museum has received its first centen nial birthday gift of art, from a refugee couple grateful for a chance to live in liberty and equality. The gift, a gilded silverandmotherof pearl tabernacle, dating from 1494, was made by Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Blumka, New York art dealers and collec tors, who fled the Hitler re gime in the early nineteen forties.

title: $13,020 DAMAGES AWARDED CONVICT
description: A Black Muslim prisoner in the Green Haven State Prison won $13,020 in damages yes terday for being unconstitution ally punished by 372 days of solitary confinement. He also obtained a Federal court order forbidding prison officials from isolating him again without a hearing.

title: Mills Seeks to Curb Cost In Hospital Care Plans
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is pro posing sweeping changes in administering Medicare and Medicaid aimed at controlling skyrocketing hospital costs. A package of 20 specific changes that would plug cost ly loopholes in the medical services programs and create methods for holding down hospital charges is regarded as having an excellent chance of passage by Congress.

title: Soviet Five Routs Egypt
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 14 (Reuters)The Soviet Union beat Egypt, 12156, in a group C qualify game of the men's world basketball championship at Kar lovac last night.

title: Abacus May Vote Shares
description: Abacus Fund, Inc., which earlier this year acquired a 22 per cent interest in Security National Bank of Long Island, may vote its shares, it was an nounced yesterday by the New York State Banking Depart ment. The Superintendent of Banks, William T. Dentzer Jr., did not disapprove the Abacus application within the 90 days prescribed by law.

title: SEAVER TO OPEN AGAINST PHILLIES
description: CHICAGO, May 14  The New York Mets and Chicago Cubs were rained out today, and the Mets immediately switched their pitching rotation to put maximum pressure on the Cubs when they meet next in Shea Stadium in nine days.

title: Regents Tests Set for June Despite Strife
description: The State Education Depart ment said yesterday that Re gents examinations would be given next month as scheduled despite the current antiwar strike by high school students here and their threatened boy cott of the state examinations.

title: Penn Picks I.C.4A Team
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (UPI)The University of Penn sylvania, host school for the 94th annual I.C.4A outdoor track and field championships, named today a 33member squad to take part in the event May 29 and 30 at Franklin Field. The championships were last held at Franklin Field in 1968 and 10 meet records were broken on the allweather Tar tan track.

title: Article 1  No Title
Drug AbuseIV
description: The figures constantly need upward revision. The Medical Examiner's Office in New York City reports that it has recorded about thirty additional drug deaths within the past week, fifteen since this series began Tuesday. Mayor Lindsay and other top admin istration spokesmen have often referred grimly to the city's daily death toll. It is a toll that merits even deeper attention than the Mayor or the City Council or other officials have given it.

title: Lincoln Savings Planning To Absorb Broadway Bank
description: The Lincoln Savings Bank, a $1.17billion Brooklynbased institution, would absorb the $163million Broadway Savings Bank of Manhattan under plans announced yesterday by the two concerns.

title: Canadian Turbotrains to Resume as Overhaul Ends
description: MONTREAL, May 14 (Cana dian Press)  Canada's finest first turbinepowered passenger train will return to service on May 25 as a result of a decision by Canadian National Railways to give the streamlined carrier a second trial on the Montreal Toronto run.

title: DISORDER CALLED A ROOKIE'S FAULT
description: The commander of a police precinct on the Lower East Side where angry crowds have been involved this week in two nights of street incidents met with community residents yes terday and singled out a rookie patrolman as a major cause of the trouble.

title: GREYHOUND BACKED ON ARMOUR BY I.C.C.
description: The Interstate commerce Commission approved yester day the Greyhound Corpora tion's plan to buy control of Armour & Co. through the ac quisition of a large block of Armour stock from the General Host Corporation.

title: Thursday Baseball
description: BatteriesEllis, Dal Canton (6), Garber (6), Walker (8), Guisti (8) and Sanguillen; Cul ver, McCool (5), Campisi (6), Johnson (7) and Torre.

title: Reed Collects Third Award in Week
description: Willis Reed, captain of the World Champion New York Knickerbocker picked up his third award in four days yesterday at the Pan Ameri can building where he was awarded the trophy as the National Basketball Associa tion's Most Valuable player.

title: SIR WILLIAM DOBELL, AUSTRALIAN PAINTER
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 14 Sir William Dobell, well known Australian portrait painter, was found dead of natural causes in his home at Wangi, 80 miles north of Syd ney, today. He was 70 years old.

title: Jakarta's Adroit Foreign Minister
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 14The Indonesians have a nickname for Adam Malik, their Foreign Minister. It is Kantjil, the name of a small, graceful deer of this archi pelago nation.

title: REV. A. R. M'KECHNIE, GREAT NECK RECTOR
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., May 14 The Rev. Alexander R. Mcd. Kechnie, rector emeritus of All, Saints Episcopal Church, died of a heart ailment yesterday in his home at 37 Brompton Road. He was 74 years old.

title: The Governor and the Tiger
description: The fate of the Bengal tiger and other rare wild animals may be decided in Albany early next week when Governor Rockefeller is expected to choose for signature one of two measures offered to protect endangered species.

title: 3 Companies to Increase Sheet and Towel Prices
description: Cannon Mills, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it would increase prices for sheets by 3 to 5 per cent and for towels by about 5 per cent. The higher prices become effec tive Monday for deliveries after Aug. 7.

title: Dance: Ropes of Time
description: THIS sixweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House Britain's Royal Ballet is offer ing only one American pre miere, Rudi Van Dantzig's The Ropes of Time, seen for the first time here on Wednesday night.

title: Cowles Meeting Told of Look's Ad Losses
description: Gardner Cowles, chairman of Cowles Communications, Inc., told a stockholders' meeting yesterday that the company's cornerstone publi cation, Look magazine, lost advertising pages in the first quarter of 1970.

title: Whale That Averts Oil Spills Tested
description: LITTLE CREEK, Va., May 14 A new airborne system for preventing or at least reducing maritime oil spills from dam aged tankers is expected to be ready for operational use on the East Coast this fall.

title: Museum: Mother of Film Generation
description: The Museum of Modern Art's Film Department, which will celebrate its 35th an niversary next month, is tak ing time out for a little well bred selfcongratulation.

title: RENT RISES HERE OUTPACE NATION'S
description: Residential rents in the New York metropolitan area rose more rapidly than in any other major urban region in the coun try in the last decade, despite the great proportion of rent controlled apartments here, the Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported yesterday.

title: U.S. WARNS REDS AT PARIS SESSION
description: PARIS, May 14The United States told the Vietnamese Communists today that their intransigence at the bargain ing table and heightened activ ity on the battlefield had be come intolerable.

title: ORCHESTRA SERIES SIGNS 5 NEWCOMERS
description: In the 197071 season, five symphony orchestras will make first appearances in the Inter national Festival of Visiting Orchestras sponsored by Car negie Hall. They are the Mel bourne Symphony, Willem van Otterloo conducting; the Za greb Philharmonic, Milan Hor vat conducting; the Atlanta Symphony, Robert Shaw con ducting; the Los Angeles Phil harmonic, Zubin Mehta con ducting; and the New Jersey Symphony, Henry Lewis con ducting. The New Jersey Sym phony gave a concert at Car negie Hall in the season just ending, but not under Interna tional Festival auspices.

title: U.S. SCORES SOVIET ON MIDEAST RISKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14Charles W. Yost, the United States representative, accused the Soviet Union in the Security Council today of caus ing very grave risks and dan gers by sending military per sonnel to bolster the United Arab Republic's defense forces.

title: SOVIET TRUCK BID REJECTED BY FORD
description: DETROIT, May 14A Soviet proposal that Ford trucks be built in Russia has been re jected, Henry Ford 2d disclosed today. Public criticism, partic ularly by Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, was a major influence in the Ford Motor Company's decision, its officials said.

title: A Town Is Occupied
description: BANAM, Cambodia, May 14 South Vietnamese marines peacefully occupied this pros perous market town on the (Mekong River yesterday after noon in an operation mainly designed to restore the Cambo dian Government's presence here.

title: Stage: Beggar on Horseback Returns
description: Revivalism is a tricky busi ness. This New York drama season must have seen more revivals than any in recent memoryand, yet, the course of these revivals has not al ways run true to form.

title: Museum Is for Mothers
description: MADRAS, India (AP)A Mu seum for Mothers has been set up at the children's hospital here to guide mothers bringing up their children.

title: GOLF QUALIFIERS LED BY CHAPMAN
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 14It's a little early in the season, said Dick Siderow, the Metropolitan amateur golf champion and a Walker Cup team player, after posting a twooverpar 74 today in the William D. Richardson Memo rial Tournament.

title: LINDSAY SUBMITS EXPENSE BUDGET OF $7.8BILLION
description: Mayor Lindsay submitted a $7.8billion expense budget to the Board of Estimate and City Council yesterdayan increase of $1.1billion above the cur rent year's budget.

title: Dust Commander Takes Siesta As Fans Fancy a Triple Crown
description: BALTIMORE, May 14It was siesta time in the Pim lico stable area, time for the horses in Saturday's Preak ness to relax after the hustle and bustle of today's work.

title: Sports of The Times
description: THIS is a bigger upset than the Mets winning the World Series, said one dismayed American Olympic official. He was still in a state of shock after learning that the International Olym pic Committee had bypassed the two more obvious candidates, Los Angeles and Mos cow, and settled on the unlikely third choice of Montreal as the site of the 1976 Olympic Games.

title: Party to Aid World Education Group
description: The international and cul tural exchange programs of the Institute of International Education will benefit from a Swiss winetasting session Wednesday. The event will celebrate the American open ing of Bucherer, Swiss watch and jewelry firm, in the sunken plaza of the General Motors Building, 767 Fifth Avenue, where the wine tasting will take place. Mrs. Ronald Tree is chairman of the committee. Tickets, at $15 each, are available at the institute, 809 United Nations Plaza. Avenue, where the wine tasting will take place. Mrs. Ronald Tree is chairman of the committee. Tickets, at $15 each, are available at the institute, 809 United Nations Plaza.

title: Goldberg Terms Governor Inactive
description: ROCHESTER, May 14Ar thur J. Goldberg criticized Governor Rockefeller today for alleged inaction and si lence on civil disorders in New York State.

title: Bahnsen, the Complete Pitcher, Faces Tigers for Yanks Tonight
description: Stan Bahnsen says that complete games are not so greatwinning games are much better. But, of course, Bahnsen can afford to be so cool about completing a game since he is the only Yankee pitcher to do so in this decade.

title: Trade Official Cautious on Japan Talks
description: The Assistant Secretary of Commerce, Kenneth N. Davis Jr., said yesterday that he was not overly optimistic that an agreement could be reached with Japan for voluntary re duction of her textile exports to this country.

title: Barry Farber, of WOR, Seeks to Unseat Farbstein
description: Barry Farber, the host of a radio discussion program, said yesterday he would run for the House of Representatives from Manhattan's 19th District, now represented by Leonard Farb stein, a Democrat.

title: SHOT BEFORE VOLLEY AT KENT IS REPORTED
description: KENT, Ohio, May 14 (UPI) The commander of a National Guard unit whose members shot and killed four Kent State University students says the authorities have evidence a single shot was fired before his troops opened fire.

title: A Crisis of Confidence
description: The gloom that enshrouds Wall Street today is perhaps the heaviest since the early days of the Great Depression. The stock market keeps skidding day after day, with only feeble at attempts at recovery, and the bond market is equally de pressed.

title: MOURNERS VISIT BIER OF REUTHER
description: DETROIT, May 14The eld erly black woman hobbled dow the steps, away from the white slab building.

title: Mrs. Betty N. Gerhard Is Married
description: Mrs. Betty Newell Gerhard and William Juhring Broad burst, both of New York, were married in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Pres byterian Church yesterday. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the cere mony, which was attended only by members of the im mediate families of the cou ple.

title: IMPACT OF KNITWEAR IS FOUND GROWING
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 The increasing impact of knit wear on the apparel industry was highlighted here today at the annual convention of the American Apparel Manufactur ers Association.

title: Sinden Quits as Bruin Coach, 4 Days After Cup Victory, to Go Into Business
description: Harry Sinden, whose Boston Bruins gained their reputation as teamwreckers under his dy namic leadership, quit the Na tional Hockey League club yes terday to go into the building business.

title: Garden Audience Dances and Sings To Creedence Rock
description: Creedence Clearwater Re vival, a heavyrocking rock band from Berkeley, Calif., kept most of the nearcapac ity crowd at Madison Square Garden on its feet Wednesday evening.

title: O.E.O. TO TEST PLAN TO AID EDUCATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The Office of Economic Op portunity disclosed plans today for a twopart experiment that, if successful, could revolution dze education for all, not just poor chidren.

title: Urban Group To Show Art
description: The New York Coalition will receive the proceeds of Monday's preview of a series of 12 oil paintings by Palmer Hayden illustrating the Bal lad of John Henry. The show at the Community Art Gal lery, 28 East 35th Street, will be open free to the public from Tuesday through June 20.

title: NIXON AIDES URGE G.O.P. SENATORS OPPOSE WAR CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The Administration sent three top officials to the Capitol today to warn Republican Senators that proposed legislation cut ting off funds for future mili tary involvement in Cambodia could impair the credibility abroad of President Nixon.

title: House Unit to Seek Action To Ban Chemicals in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 14A House Foreign Affairs subcom mittee plans to issue a report tomorrow urging President Nix on to make good on his prom ise of nearly six months ago to send to the Senate for rati fication the Geneva Protocol of 1925 prohibiting chemical  bio logical warfare.

title: Panel on Police Corruption Asks Mayor to Supersede It
description: A special committee investi gating police corruption in New York City recommended yester day that its task be turned over to an independent citizens group with a fulltime profes sional staff.

title: Augusta Orders Autopsies on 6; Snipers Open Fire in Riot Area
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Friday, May 15  Autopsies were ordered yesterday on six Negroes kil led here in rioting Monday and Tuesday.

title: A. & P. 12Month Profit Grows By 17.8% as Sales Set a Record
description: Earnings at the Great At lantic and Pacific Company rose 17.8 per cent in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, as sales set a record. The report issued yesterday also showed fourth quarter profits up 32.1 per cent on a 12.1 per cent sales gain over the yearearlier period.

title: Stewardess, 1930Style
description: WHEN Mrs. Richard J. Fuite of San Diego hears air line stewardesses griping about sore feet and grumbling that they are nothing but flying waitresses. she smiles and thinks of the good old days.

title: BURNS RULES OUT CREDIT CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today that there was no need for controls to allocate credit. The chair man, Arthur F. Burns, told the Senate Banking Committee that the only credit area which was even a potential candidate for choking off the credit flow was business investment in plant and equipment, and he added:

title: Appellate Court Asks Resentence In Extortion Case
description: The Appellate Division yes terday ordered resentencing of a convicted extortionist be cause of the intimation that a plot was afoot to bribe the sentencing judge who had im posed a 7to14year jail sen tence on the defendant.

title: Democrats Will Help Volunteers Find the Right Man to Work For
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The Democratic party moved today to try to mobilize the rising tide of youthful protest behind its candidates for state and Congressional offices.

title: Stock Prices Plunge
description: The stock market plunged yesterday to its lowest level since April, 1963, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.05 points to 684.79. The leading market indicator has declined slightly more than 300 points since peaking out in December, 1968. Details on Page 51.

title: FUND SEEKING GAIN IN BLACK LAWYERS
description: A program to double the number of black lawyers in the United States within the next seven years was announced yesterday by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal, Defense and Educational Fund. Inc.

title: Bank Burglary Ring in 14 States Reported Smashed by the F.B.I.
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 14 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today that it had smashed a 14state bank and loan office burglary ring and won indictments against 15 persons, including a former football star and an escape artist who listed his occupation as a burglar alarm salesman.

title: Suppressing Rationality
description: The nation slides toward isolation in irrationality when politicians at a convention called to draft state's basic law can suppress as irrelevant a carefully reasoned appeal to halt the disintegration of American society. This is precisely what happened when John W. Gardner was barred from telling the Illinois Constitu tional Convention that America is being torn apart by the arowine tendency to tolerate violence.

title: 1,000 Establishment Lawyers Join War Protest
