description: More than 1,000 New York City lawyers announced yes terday they would stop work next Wednesday to meet legis lative and administration offi cials in Washington to urge immediate withdrawal from Indochina.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Photographs Show Mars Moon Is One Of Darkest Bodies
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)  Photographs of Mars taken by the Mariner 7 spacecraft indicate that Phobos, one of two moons orbiting the planet, may be the darkestcolored body of any size yet observed in the solar system.

title: Rhodesia Quits Cup Play
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 14 (AP)Rhodesia, faced with the refusal of other countries to play against it, withdrew today from this year's Davis Cup tennis competition.

title: Trowbridge Quits as Chief Of Management Association
description: Alexander B. Trowbridge, a former Secretary of Commerce, announced yesterday that he had resigned as president and chief executive officer of the American Management Associa tion.

title: Dominicans Crowd 3 Roads Leading Out of Poverty
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 14Three ways to escape poverty  a win ning lottery ticket, presidential patronage or a visa to travel to the United States  drawl swarms of people each day to three different buildings here.

title: U.S. Says Foe in Cambodia Did Not Heed Combat Order
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)  Enemy troops in the Cam bodian sanctuary areas failed to follow a standandfight ceder a Pentagon spokesman said to day.

title: A Correction
description: In the May 11 editions of The New York Times, J. Rich ardson Dilworth was incorrect ly associated with the Rocke feller Brothers Fund. Mr. Dilworth, who is chairman of the board of Rockefeller Center, Inc., is not an officer or a trus tee of the fund.

title: INDRA NEELA IS SEEN IN DANCE AND MIME
description: Indra Neela presented a soundly conceived program of solo dances in the In dian Sharata Natyam style Wednesday night at The Cubiculo. The solo recital presented formidable prob lems in pacing, among other things, and Miss Neela smoothly alternated pure dance works with interludes of mimed recitation.

title: MRS. JOHN J. BERGEN
description: Mrs. Mary Bergen, wife of retired Rear Adm. John J. Ber gen, died Wednesday at the Mayo clinic in Rochester, Minn., after a long illness. She was 73 years old.

title: 1918 Wound Found
description: EALING, England (Canadian Press)John Philp, 75 years old, thought a pain in his hip was caused by arthritis, but an Xray showed a rifle bullet that had been there for 52 years without his knowing it. He was shot during the First World War.

title: Moving and Rodgers Share in Program Of Modern Dances
description: The Lucas Hoving Dance Company and the Rod Rod gers Dance Company shared the second program Wednes day night in the final week of the City Center's modern dance season.

title: Allocations, Agency by Agency, in Proposed City Expense Budget for 197071
Japanese Team Climbs Everest 2 Days in a Row
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 14 (AP)A Japanese expedi tion reached the summit of Mount Everest on two con secutive days this week, placing four men atop the world's highest mountain, the Nepal Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Bridge:
description: AT the international level it can be argued that bridge is a game for young men. After the age of 50 many experts become slightly less effective. Even if their will to win remains intact, their stamina is severely tested by the need to con centrate fiercely for day after day.

title: TaySachs Gala Set for Tuesday
description: Miss Patricia Nixon is hon orary chairman of the Spring Fever Gala to be held at the Rotunda of the West 779th Street Boat Basin on Tuesday to benefit the National Tay Sachs and Allied Diseases Association.

title: Harvard Subdues Yale on a 5Hitter By Collins, 4 to 0
description: NEW HAVEN, May 14Har vard kept alive its slim chance for a share of the Eastern In tercollegiate Baseball League title today by beating Yale, 40.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) The Defense Department an nounced today the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been billed in action in South east Asia:

title: NIXON CONFIDENT ON WAR SKEPTICS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 President Nixon told a group of Medal of Honor winners to day that the war in Southeast Asia was often not under stood and not supported in this country but that eventu ally the American people would join him in honoring their valor.

title: Saigon and Pnompenh Set De Facto Military Alliance
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 14  Responsible Cambodian and South Vietnamese sources say privately here that South Vietnamese troops will fight in Cambodia until the defeat of their common enemy  the Vietcong and North Vietna mese.

title: Saigon Units' Role In Cambodia Viewed As Bar to Sihanouk
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 Concern over a possible Com munist attempt to install the headquarters of the exile re gime of Prince Norodom Siha nouk in Cambodia after the departure of American troops was reported today to be one reason for a growing expecta tion here that South Viet namese forces will stay in Cambodia.

title: Youth Mural Shows Life on East Side: Drugs and Crime
description: A 55by26foot mural painted by 12 Lower East Side teenagers and showing drugtaking, crime and street violence was unveiled yester day.

title: Football Writers Cite Sayers for Comeback
description: Gale Sayers, who made a remarkable recovery from knee surgery, will receive the George Halas Award as pro football's most courageous player at the annual dinner of the New York chapter of the Pro Football Writers As sociation at the Americana Hotel on May 25.

title: BLACKS IN REBUKE TO BROADCASTERS
description: The broadcasting industry was told with emphasis yester day that it is a major contribu tor to the black rage sweeping the country, and warned that it will either surrender some of its power or have it torn from it in increasingly harsh confronta tions.

title: Nuptials Called Grace of Mao
description: HONG KONG (AP)Travelers arriving here from Communist China report rural couples there are instructed to have revolutionary marriages  dressing shabbily, having Mao Tsetung's grace, and feeding their guests grass, tree roots and bark.

title: Suez: Another Day of War
description: SUEZ, United Arab Republic, May 15This shellbattered town at the southern end of the Suez Canal underwent an other day of warfare today. Bomb explosions rumbled in the distance. Nearby artillery pieces barked in the direction of Israeli positions in the Sinai. Puffs of white smoke appeared briefly high in the cloudless sky as Egyptian jets fired rockets in an attack across the canal.

title: Ithaca College Names Head
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 15 Ellis L. Pillips Jr., professor of law at Columbia University Law School, was named fifth presi dent of Ithaca College today by the board of trustees, Mr. Phil lips will assume his new posi tion Sept. 1, succeeding Dr. Howard I. Dillingham, who is retiring after 13 years as head of the college, which has 3,600 students.

title: Spartans Unit to Spur Executive Incentive
description: In an effort to reverse profit erosion, Spartans Industries, Inc., plans to restructure its $150million apparel manufac turing division on a new incen tive basis, probably a joint venture nature with a dozen key divisional executives.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the ended May 12:

title: Boston Teachers Summoned
description: BOSTON, May 15 (AP) Judge Harry Kalus today or dered 36 striking Boston school teachers to appear in Suffolk Superior Court next Wednes day on contempt of court charges. The order is in con nection with a teachers' strike that is in its 11th day.

title: Holidays for State Workers
description: ALBANY, May 15Because Memorial Day and Independence Day both fall on Saturdays this year, Governor Rockefeller has designated May 29 and July 3 as holidays for state employes, Mrs. Ersa H. Joston, president of the State Civil Service Com mission, announced yesterday.

title: City's Newest Sports Heroes Attend Official Fete at Gracie Mansion
description: Short ceremonies, scotch, salami and Dixieland jazz were the order of the after noon yesterday at Gracie Mansion as Mayor Lindsay acted as host for the Na tional Basketball Association champions, the New York Knickerbockers.

title: Billie Burke Dead; Movie Comedienne
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15 Billie Burke, a great Broad way beauty when the century was young and later renowned as a movie comedienne, died last night at the age of 84.

title: Whither the Economy?
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 What are the Government's economic officials worried about as they contemplate the current confusing witches' brew of collapsing stock prices, higher unemployment, continu ing inflation? And how woried are they? The fact is that, while officials do not have monolith ically identical views, they are on the whole about as confident over the condition of the nation's economy in pri vate as they are in public. But that is not the same as saying they have no worries. Essenti all, they have three.

title: F.A.A. Seeks to Discharge Two Involved in SickOut
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 15 (AP)Plans to dismiss two air traffic controllers and to sus pend three others for their part in a sickout at the Olathe Traffic Control Center have been disclosed by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Census Deadline Delayed
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 15 (AP)Census takers in West Virginia have been granted seven additional days to com plete their work as a result of complaints that floods and im passable roads had made it im possible to meet the deadline of last Wednesday.

title: Laotian Aide Sees Need For Saigon Army's Help
description: VIFNTIANE, Laos, May 15 (Agence FrancePresse)A Lao tian Defense Ministry spokes man expressed today the grow ing concern of the military command over the situation in southern Laos and suggested that, from a military point of view, it was necessary that South Vietnamese forces inter vene to help clean up Laos.

title: POWELL SAYS CITY MISUSED O.E.O. FUNDS
description: Representative Adam Clayton Powell accused the city yester day of having mishandled anti poverty funds, and called for investigations by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Justice Department and the Of fice of Economic Opportunity.

title: Steelworkers Sign a Pact For Incentive Pay at Inland
description: CHICAGO, May 15 (AP)  The United Steel Workers of America said today it had signed the first agreement with a steel producer on an incentive pay issue that had been stalled for several months in industrywide bargaining.

title: Lindsay Campaign Gift in Dispute
description: A wealthy Cincinnati lawyer has testified under oath that he made a very substantial contribution to Mayor Lind say's campaign for reelection in return for legal services per formed by the Mayor's twin brother, David.

title: ExJersey Mayor Convicted in Case Of Pipeline Bribe
description: NEWARK, May 15 (AP)  Walter Zirpolo, former Mayor of Woodbridge Township, was found guilty today in a bribery conspiracy trial.

title: SANASARDO JOINS FALCO IN CONCERT
description: In our age of affluence, the core problem is one of isolated individual bravery, not collec tive heroism, which is the re sponse more appropriate in a deprived time. One would not have guessed it Thursday night at the City Center from the dance program shared by Paul Sanasardo and Louis Falco. Mr. Sanasardo presented the premiere of Footnotes, a piece full of statuesque yearn ing in physically spectacular terms, and Mr. Falco offered Caviar for the first time.

title: Top Field for 400Meter Race Heads King Track Meet Today
description: All winter, during the indoor track and field season. Lee Ev ans chased Martin McGrady at McGrady's specialty, 600 yards. The races were fun, but fu tile for Evans. No one beats McGrady at 600 yards.

title: From Arabian Nights  Clothes by 2 Sisters From India
description: Based on the assumption that in every crisp, tailored woman there is a mysterious enchantress yearning to come out at night, two young women from India have set up a couture design house for the sort of femi nine, seductive dress that immediately separates the girls from the tomboys.

title: South African Teams Expelled From All Olympic Competition
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, May 15  South Africa was expelled today from the International Olympic Commit tee. That means the country cannot compete in the Olympic Games.

title: Metropolitan Opera House Set To Greet Tommy and the Who
description: The Who, the British rock group, is preparing to present its rock opera Tommy at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 7, and at least one Met fan has suggested that, in keeping with the elegant am bience the Who become the Whom for the evening.

title: WARCURB MOVES IN SENATE SCORED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 15The White House strongly asserted today its view that a move in the Senate to cut off funds for future military in volvement in Cambodia would be an infringement of the Pres ident's constitutional powers as Commander in Chief.

title: Police in Chicago Demote Three Involved in Panther Raid Inquiry
description: CHICAGO, May 14  Three highranking Chicago police officers were demoted last night, apparently as a result of a controversy over a police raid last Dec. 4 on a Black Panther apartment in which two Panther leaders were killed.

title: Clark Shaughnessy, Grid Coach Who Revived TFormation, Dies
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 15 (AP)Clark Shaughnessy, one of the leading coaches of football, who revived the T formation, died today. He was 78 years old.

title: Derby Trial to Meadowville
description: LINGFIELD, England, May 15 (AP)Meadowville scored an impressive victory today in the Derby Trial Stakes at Lingfield Geoff Lewis brought Meadow vine home in front by two lengths over Long Ti. Anaval was third; another three lengths behind.

title: Field for Preakness Stakes
description: aMrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's entry; mutuel field.

title: Two Men Die on Turnpike
description: BORDENTOWN, N. J., May 15 (AP)Two men were burned to death and two were injured today in a threevehicle colli sion on the New Jersey Turn pike near here. The dead were listed by the police as Douglas Billman, 22 years old, of Mata moras, Pa., and Ronald E. Devoe, 21, of Schuylerville, N. Y. Admitted to St. Francis Hospital in Trenton with in juries were Richard Schu macher, 25, of Callicoon, N. Y., and Vernon Varnadore, 42, of Milford, Conn.

title: Stock Exchange Shifts Its Stand on Yarmulke
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it had decided to rec ognize an employe's right to wear a religious skullcap during working hours.

title: DAKOTA MINISTER TO HEAD BAPTISTS
description: CINCINNATI, May 15  The Rev. Dr. Roger L. Fredrikson of Sioux Falls, S. D., was un animously elected president of the 1.5millionmember Ameri can Baptist Convention here today.

title: Market Summary
description: Friday, May 15, 1970

title: HOUSING VENTURE MEETS FUND GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 15At 12:05 this afternoon, Carter Burgess broke into an expan sive smile and handed George Defranceaux two tens and a twenty.

title: The Isle of Giant Statues
description: HANGAROA, Easter Island An American military jet slipped in from the sea past the grim old monoliths that ring Easter Island and roared to a short and dusty stop on the new airstrip.

title: Bonnie Brae Farm Schedules Benefits
description: MILLINGTON, N. J., May 15The auxiliary for Boys here has arranged luncheons and fashion shows for Mon day and Tuesday at Mayfair Farms in West Orange. Tick ets at $6 each are available from the beneficiary's office at 605 Broad Street in New ark.

title: Radical Jews Disrupt Service At EmanuEl; 2 Are Arrested
description: Two members of the Radical Jewish Union of Columbia Uni versity were arrested yesterday after they disrupted services at Temple EmanuEl to protest the war in Southeast Asia.

title: ... Death in Maddoxland
description: When four white students were killed on their campus by the Ohio National Guard last week, some black leaders expressed sympathy but not surprise. They noted that their people had been shot, hanged and burned for many decades by Guardsmen, police and selfappointed vigilantes, rarely with any great national outrage afterward.

title: Metromedia to Give TV Station To KNEW of San Francisco
description: Metromedia, Inc., a diversi fied communications conglom erate, announced yesterday that it would give its $3mil lion San Francisco television fa cility, KNEWTV, to that city's public television station, KQED TV.

title: Successor to Reuther Will Be Picked Friday
description: DETROIT, May 15  The executive board of the United Automobile Workers said today that it would pick a new president at a special meeting a week from today.

title: WARREN DECRIES DIVIDED SOCIETY
description: Former Chief Justice Earl Warren said yesterday that the United States was in a crisis greater than any within the memory of living Americans.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today the names of the following servicemen for the New York area as having been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: Drug AbuseV
description: The Federal Government has the largest responsi bility for dealing with the drug problem and, at the Federal level, the leadership of the President is most crucial. President Nixon has changed his position on the nation's drug crisis, but even more change is needed.

title: Jewish Council to Hold Dance Next Saturday
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., May 15 National Council of Jewish Women, Peninsula Section, will hold its annual spring dinner dance at the Middle Bay Country Club here next Saturday.

title: Mr. Nader's Lapse
description: One more sign, though hardly a welcome one, that the state of the environment is a major national issue is the infighting among its champions. A report on air pollution control just released by a student task force under the direction of Ralph Nader aims its most caustic criticism at Senator Edmund S. Muskie, charg ing him with failure of leadership, political expediency and behindthescenes capitulation to industrial pol luters. Mildly enough, in view of that onslaught, Sena tor Musitie has accused Mr. Nader of distortion and invited him to join in constructive efforts to strengthen the 1967 air pollution control law.

title: Large Field Is Preakness Woe
description: BALTIMORE, May 15 Baseball makes its teams qualify for the World Series, auto racing bans slow cars from the Indianapolis 500 and golf wouldn't think of letting a weekend duffer play in the Master's tournament.

title: Ulbricht, in Soviet, Holds Talks Linked To Policies on Bonn
description: MOSCOW, May 15  Walter Ulbricht and other East German leaders made an unexpected trip to Moscow today for talks with top Soviet officials. The discussions were presumed to have dwelt on East German and Soviet policies toward West Germany.

title: HOUSE PANEL ADDS TO POLLUTION FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee added millions of dollars Thursday to a Nixon) Administration money bill toy combat air and water pollution.

title: Eastern Air Lines to Sell Boeing 747 Jets to T.W.A.
description: Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell four Boeing 747 jumbo jets, which the airline was scheduled to receive from Boeing next fall and in late 1971, to Trans World Airlines. T.W.A. said it would pay approximately $88 million for the four Jets.

title: Bridge
description: OPENING bids of three no trump represent a zone of mystery in bidding theory. Many experts use the Gam bling Three NoTrump, in which the bid shows a long solid minor suit together with a degree of outside strength from nothing to all suits stopped according to partnership understanding.

title: Fathers With Understanding to Spare
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. Robert Mitchell is a 45year old black dynamo who runs Project Action, a job training program here. At home, he has 13 children. He is not a man with a lot of time on his hands.

title: Parade Today
description: The annual Armed Forces Day Parade is scheduled to start at 2 P.M. today at Fifth Avenue and 96th Street and proceed to 62d Street. The reviewing stand will be at 69th Street.

title: Missing Reporters' Papers Found in Cambodian House
description: WITH TASK FORCE 318 IN CAMBODIA, May 15 (AP) South Vietnamese forces, bat tling through a tiny hamlet, have discovered the press cre dentials of three American correspondents missing and be lieved captured by the enemy.

title: Moynihan Says Social Science Finds his but Not Their Cures
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, an adviser to President Nixon, crit icized social scientists yester day for analyzing social ills without at the same time dis playing a similar competence at offering solutions.

title: Pride, Prejudice and Persuasion
description: LONDON, May 15In one of the great Supreme Court opin ions on freedom of speech, Mr. Justice Brandeis wrote that those who won America's inde pendence thought the delib erative forces should prevail over the arbitrary in society. They wrote into tne tion what they thought would be the path of safety for the Republic: The opportunity to discuss freely supposed griev ances and proposed remedies. They believed in the power of reason as applied through pub lic discussion.

title: 6 KUPFERMAN WORKS PLAYED AT CONCERT
description: Take any slice out of the music of the composer Meyer Kupferman heard at Carnegie Recital Flail Wednesday night and it would he fresh and idiomatic in sound and dra matic in concept.

title: Arts and Letters, Nodouble Top Field On Coast Today
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 15 (AP)Arts and Letters, 1969's Horse of the Year and No double, the highweight and last year's winner, head a field of nine entered in the $100,000 added Californian at Hollywood Park tomorrow.

title: Card of Thanks
description: HILLEBRANDThe family of the late Cath erine B. Hillebrand, wish to thank the clergy, their many friends and neighbors for their Mass cards, expressions of sym pathy, flowers and generous contributions to various charities.

title: Frank Costello Testifies Here; Gambling Reported to Be Topic
description: Frank Costello, the dapper gambler once known as the Prime Minister of the Under world, testified for an hour and a half yesterday afternoon before a New York County grand jury that is believed to be investigating gambling in the metropolitan area.

title: Excerpts From the Grand Jury's Report
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  Following are excerpts from the report of a grand jury to the United States Court of the Northern District of Illi nois, Eastern Division, on a raid on members of the Black Panther party in Chicago last Dec. 4:

title: Stage: Fantasies Lace 2 OneActers
Czech Defects in Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 15 (Agence FrancePresse) The first secretary of the Czechoslovak Embassy in Ethi opia, Vladimir Krula, has de fected three days before he was due to return home, informed sources disclosed here today. The sources said that he would probably apply to France or the United States for political asy lum.

title: Energetic Rights Chief
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Proudly displayed on the wall of Jerris Leonard's of fice is a newspaper clipping quoting his teenage daugh ter as telling a testimonial dinner that her father, the head of the Justice Depart ment's Civil Rights Division, is far from perfect, but he is only human. In a capital di vided and some times confused by the Nixon Admin istration's poli cies on race relations and school desegration, it is easy to find supporters on either side of this instant analysis by Mary Alice Leonard.

title: PACERS BEAT STARS FOR 10 LEAD, 10993
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (UPI) Mel Daniels hit 16 of his 18 points in the final period to spark the Indiana Pacers to a 10993 victory over the Los Angeles Stars tonight in the opener of the American Basket ball Association title playoff. The Pacers outscored the Stars in the last period, 3622.

title: North Vietnamese Storm A U.S. Base in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 16 (UPI)A force of about 200 North Viet namese infantrymen attacked a United States base inside Cam bodia early today, and field re ports said that five Americans had been killed and 14 wound ed. Eight North Vietnamese were reported killed.

title: Washington: For the Record
SEAWANHAKA LEADS INTERCLUB REGATTA
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 SeawanhakeCorinthian Yacht. Club of Oyster Bay. L.I., repre sented by James Miller, had the only undefeated record today after the first four rounds of the opening interclub match racing regatta for the Green wich Cup were sailed on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

title: Law of the Jungle ...
description: The uncontrolled use of firearms by police and National Guardsmen has become a menace to internal security. The deaths at Kent State University have now been followed by killings in Augusta's ghetto and at Jackson State College in Mississippi. Within hours after the Kent State tragedy, Kentucky guard units were ordered to the state university campus with loaded rifles, and in Ohio itself authorities con tinue to sanction the use of live ammunition for cam pus policing.

title: Drivers Facing Loss of Licenses To Get Chance at Rehabilitation
description: Some New York State driv ers about to be forbidden to drive because they had three convictions for speeding are to eet another chance.

title: Hijacker Gets 25Year Term Alter Losing Plea on Insanity
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 15 Ronald T. Bohle, 22 years old, was sentenced today to 25 years in prison on his conviction for aircraft piracy.

title: DePaula Has Surgery
description: JERSEY CITY, May 15 Frank DePaula, the 30yearold Jersey City former light heavy weight boxing contender who was shot yesterday, underwent surgery this morning at the Jersey City Medical Center. His condition was reported crit ical. Mr. DePaula was shot in the arm and back early yester day as he was escorting a friend home, the police said.

title: Designs for Theater
description: Designs for Music, an ex hibition of set and costume de signs for operas and ballets, will be displayed at Philhar monic Hall from May 27 through June 20, the period of the New York Philharmonic's Promenades.

title: Rockefeller U. Campus Dispute Gentle
description: Political activism has flared at Rockefeller University here without igniting the turmoil that has been troubling many other campuses throughout the city and nation.

title: Beirut Aide Who Reported Entry of Syrian Troops Says He Was Mistaken
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 15 A. Lebanese official who re ported yesterday that Syrian regular troops had entered the southeastern Lebanese district of Arkoub said today that he had been mistaken.

title: A PERFECT COUPLE IN ROYAL'S ROMEO
description: The Royal Ballet's production of Kenneth MacMillan's Ro meo and Juliet permits vari ous interpretations from its protagonists. Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Antoinette Sibley and Anthony Dowell, perfectly paired as the young lovers, left their highly personal stamp on the title roles.

title: C.N.A. Financial Makes Bid To Philadelphia Exchange
description: An affiliate of the CNA Financial Corporation, a major insurance organization with interests in mutual fiords, has applied for membership on the Philadelphia  Baltimore  Wash ington Stock Exchange.

title: RECORD REPORTED IN DRUG ARRESTS
description: The Police Department an nounced yesterday that it had made 76.7 per cent more nar cotics arrests this March than in March, 1969. The total rose to 4,887 from 2,765 in March of last year.

title: U. S. Stand on Japan's Exports Is Scored
description: American demands that Ja pan limit exports of textiles and other products to this country while simultaneously admitting more American in vestment and exports were termed schizophrenic yester day by George W. Ball, former Under Secretary of State.

title: Townsmen Try to Flee
description: SARAVANE, Laos, May 15 As the 105mm howitzer in the Government military com pound kept firing at the advanc ing North Vietnamese troops, who are now less than four miles away, the frightened res idents of this town in southern Laos appealed yesterday to a group of visitors to help them get evacuated.

title: Clark Shaughnessy
description: Clark Shaughnessy, who re vived and revolutionized foot ball's Tformation at Stanford University in the nineteen forties, died yesterday at the age of 78. He switched to the professional ranks with the Los Angeles Rams in 1948. (Obit nary on Page 25.)

title: Students at Syracuse Dedicate Bach Mass to 4 Slain at Kent
description: If there is one work that no college musician should be al lowed to graduate without be ing introduced to, it is Bach's B minor Mass. Not that it is a student work; anything but, of course. You may, if you are lucky, hear one or two entirely acceptable performances of the B minor Mass in a lifetime of professional concertgoing.

title: Exhibit's Better Exercise Than the Gym
description: For one laughfilled hour, hundreds of people somer saulted, danced, fell, stumbled, and crawled about on the white plasticwrapped air mound in front of 29 West 53d Street as if they were cavorting in snow drifts.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 16, 1970

title: U.S. Riders 8th, 10th, 11th in Wiesbaden Jumping Test
description: WIESBADEN, Germany, May 15 (AP)  Joe Fargis placed eighth for the best United States finish today in the open ing jumping event in the Wies baden international equstrian tournament.

title: Market Summaries
description: Friday, May 15, 1970

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT emerges from this extensive and too solidly academic biography is the gap between the creative force and the public life. This fantastic manwhose imagination traveled like jagged lightning, whose swift and sinewy intellect pushed witty extravagance to its limits, the beauty of whose lines were so often expressed in a condensed harsh neaathis man picked his way through a career that demanded re finement, prudent loyalty, trimming, gentlemanly graces, suavity, urbanity. This new study deals exclu sively with the life, but from the life it is impossi ble for a reader to know what kind of poet Donne is. Only occasionally in the selections from the sermons or the Devotions do we get a flash of the other Donne, the one who is the bold est, the most adventuresome and sustain edly interesting poet of the 17th century.

title: TRANSLATOR GETS P.E.N. CLUB PRIZE
description: Sidney Alexander, an Amer ican author who lives in Flor ence, has received the 1970 P.E.N. Club prize for his trans lation into English of the 16th century text of Francesco Giuc ciardini's History of Italy.

title: F.D.I.C. IS SEEKING A ONEBANK LAW
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Federal Deposit Insur ance Corporation urged the Senate Banking Committee to day to approve legislation bringing onebank holding com panies under Federal regulation.

title: INDIANA TRACKMEN LEAD IN BIG 10 MEET
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 15 (AP)Although Larry High baugh was dethroned in the long jump, his teammate, Val Chandler, captured the discus Ito move the favored Hoosiers into the team lead in today's opening session of the 70th Big Ten outdoor track and field championships.

title: Colombian at U.N. Urges A New Unit on Middle East
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15  Colombia's delegate, Joaquin Vallejo Arbelaez, sug gested to the Security Council today that it create a three power committee of countries not previously connected with the Middle East question to tak a fresh look at possible solu tion of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: 34 AIRLINES MEET ON ATLANTIC FARE
description: DIVONNE  LES  BAINS, France, May 15Thirtyfour major airlines completed today a first look at the possible con tents of the next package of passenger fares for North At lantic flights.

title: NEWISSUE TRADE TURNS SLUGGISH
description: The newissue market ground to nearly a standstill this week as no companies found the in vestment climate sufficiently receptive to attempt a first pub lic stock offering.

title: Letter Carriers Postpone Strike Action Until June 12
description: Possible strike action by members of Branch 36 of the New York Letter Carriers was postponed Thursday until June 12 after a noisy meeting at Manhattan Center.

title: Market Place
description: YOU'RE a thoughtful small investor and you've watched the stock market slide lower. You have much cause for reflection.

title: Slain Youths Lacked Time for Politics
description: As their families and friends remembered them, neither of the two students killed by po licemen at Jackson State Col lege Thursday night was active in what Mississippi blacks call Politics.

title: COUNCIL PLANNING INQUIRY ON POLICE
description: The Public Safety Committee of the City Council will begin an investigation next week of alleged corruption in the Police Department.

title: WEAPONS ARE FOUND IN A SEARCH AT KENT
description: KENT, Ohio, May 15 (UPI) A search of dormitory rooms vacated after four Kent State University students were shot to death turned up a small number of guns, knives and drugs, the Portage County Prosecutor, Ronald J. Kane, said today.

title: 2 Delafield Men to Confer With King on I.O.S. Move
description: Two executives of the Dela field Capital Corporation, in vestment bankers for the King Resources Company in its plan to take over control of Inves tors Overseas Services, left last night for Geneva to confer with John M. King, chairman of King Resources.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The New York Stock Ex change and American Stock Ex change issued this week their latest reports on changes in ownership by major stockhold ers, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Mansfield Defends R.O.T.C
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Senate Democratic lead er, Mike Mansfield, defended the Reserve Officers Training Corps program today as one that provides a significant and farreaching civilian influence in the military services.

title: REUTHER PRAISED IN FUNERAL RITES
description: DETROIT, May 15  Hank Ghant, a union man, the vice president of Local 212 in De troit, stood behind the stage curtains at the Ford Audito rium and sang the last goodby to Walter P. Reuther.

title: Roundup: Orioles Dispel LastOut Idea
description: Everybody knows the game is never over until the last man is out, but Ted Williams and the Washington Senators can't even he sure the game is over when the last man is out.

title: Thousands in City March To Assail Lindsay on War
description: Several thousand construction workers, longshoremen and whitecollar workers marched through the financial district yesterday in a clamorous demonstration against Mayor Lindsay.

title: Rum Customer, on Early Move, Wins $50,000 Good Time Pace
Pole Position at Stake for 500 as Trials Start Today
Syphilis Shows Sharp Rise In Most Sections of U.S.
description: ATLANTA, May 15 (UPI) A marked rise in syphilis cases in the United States was noted in the first four months of this year the National Com municable Disease Center said today.

title: Memorial Services
description: STONOROVOskar. A Memorial Service will be held at the Friends Meeting House, 15th & Race St., Phila., Pa., at 4:00 P.M., Saturday, May 16. Please omit flowers.

title: Note to Readers
description: The box scores of all base ball games between nonlocal teams are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Tokyo Motorists Get Taste Of Foreign Traffic Control
description: TOKYO (AP)  Policemen from 15 nations took over the control of road traffic, each for two minutes, at one of the busiest intersections in Tokyo.

title: First S.D.R. Use By U.S. Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 The Treasury disclosed today that the United States had made its first use of Special Drawing Rights, or paper gold.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
TEAMSTER STRIKE DISRUPTS COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 (UM)  Teamsters out to shut the whole town down today halted most trucking service stopped buses from leaving the city and shut down both major newspapers.

title: New FiveYear Tin Pact Is Completed in Geneva
description: GENEVA, May 15A new international tin agreement was completed here tonight under the auspices of the United Na tions Conference on Trade and Development. The fiveyear pact for stabilizing interna tional trade in tin is to replace the present accord that expires on June 30. 1971.

title: Parley on Cambodia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 15 Although the Asian confer ence on Cambodia does not begin until tomorrow, it already seems destined to be neither a failure nor a success.

title: Gunman Shots 2 at Airport And Then Commits Suicide
description: A man shot and wo8nded a man and a cab driver and then killed himself in front of the Eastern Airlines terminal at La Guardia Airport yesterday aft ernoon, according to the police.

title: Heavy Mail to Congress Opposes Cambodia Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Congress is virtually staggering under an avalanche of mail, telegrams and petitions, heavily opposed to use of United States troops in Cambodia.

title: U.S. JURY ASSAILS POLICE IN CHICAGO ON PANTHER RAID
description: WASHINGTON, May 15A special Federal grand jury in Chicago reported today that the police there had grossly exag gerated Black Panthers'resist ance in a shooting incident last Dec. 4 in which two of the militants were killed and four others wounded.

title: AMEX REBOUNDS ON HIGH VOLUME
description: The American Stock Ex change made its first advance in more than a week yesterday as most of the list ended in the plus column in fairly active trading.

title: Stockholders Groups Fight 5th Ave. Line Liquidation
description: Two groups of shareholders in Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., sought yesterday to pre vent liquidation of the bank rupt former bus company.

title: DOW RISE OF 17.43 IS BEST SINCE 1968
description: Stock prices surged in a dra matic turnabout yesterday to register their best advance in more than two years. The Dow Jones industrial average, closing at its highest level of a busy ses sion, boomed to 702.22 with a gain of 17.43 points.

title: American Motor Inns Set Plan for Note Placement
description: American Motor Inns an nouncement yesterday comple tion of negotiations for the direct placement of $14.5mil lion of 7 per cent senior notes, due 1991.

title: Stock Rise of 17.43 Is Best in 2 Years
description: Stock prices moved ahead along a broad front yesterday to register their best oneday advance in more than two years. The DowJones indus trial average gained 17.43 points at 702.22.

title: Appeal by Weatherman
description: CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) Linda Sue Evans, one of 12 Weathermen charged with riot conspiracy, asked Thursday that her $75,000 bond be reduced so she could return to her parents' home in Fort Dodge, Iowa. The court delayed a ruling. Miss Evans, 23 years old, told Judge Julius J. Hoffman in Federal District Court that she wanted to return to her family because she was pregnant. She said she was receiving inadequate medi cal care in the Cook County Jail.

title: Carrier Open to Visitors
description: The 898foot aircraft carrier Intrepid will be open to public visiting from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. today and from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. tomorrow. The carrier, here for an Armed Forces Day visit, is berthed at Pier 92, Hudson River, at West 52d Street.

title: First 2 Women Generals In Nation Picked by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  President Nixon nominated to day the first two women gen erals in United States history.

title: POPE REPROACHES BELGIAN CARDINAL
description: ROME, May 15Pope Paul VI today sternly reproved members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy who have criticized his way of dealing with important theo logical issues. He mentioned no names, however.

title: TIGHT MONEY HITS SOFTWARE FIELD
description: Tight money claimed its first major victim in the computer software field, as John A. De Vries, president and chairman of Computer Applications, Inc., the nation's second largest computer software concern re signed yesterday from the com pany he founded.

title: ARKADY BELINKOV, EXSOVIET WRITER
description: NEW HAVEN, May 15Ar kady V. Belinkov, a Soviet writer and literary critic, who, with his wife, received asylum in the United States in 1968, died last night of a heart ail ment in YaleNew Haven Hos pital. He was 48 years old.

title: ShortFilm Contest Names 30 Winners At Annual Festival
description: Blue Ribbon awardwinners in 30 shortfilm categories were announced last night at the concluding banquet of the 12th annual American Film Festival at the New York Hilton.

title: Arms Session in Vienna
description: VIENNA, May 15 (AP) American and Soviet negoti ators continued their talks here today on limiting strategic arms. The meeting, the eighth since the talks began here April 16, were held at the American Embassy and lasted for 65 min utes. The next meeting is sched uled for Tuesday at the Soviet Embassy.

title: SCHOOL IS CLOSED TO BALK WALKOUT
description: A planned walkout by stu dents and teachers to protest the slaying of two Negroes at Jackson State College in Missis sippi forced the closing yester day morning of George W. Wingate High School in Brook lyn as antiwar demonstrations hand other protests continued at many schools here.

title: Art: For the American Museum, a Gem
description: The American Museum of Natural History, which is that big red building on Cen tral Park West between 77th and 79th Streets, the one with all the dinosaurs, is by second nature one of our first art museums. The latest demonstration of its emi nence in the field is a new permanent installation, Hall of Mexico and Central Amer ica, which opens to the public today. Except on Mondays, when the hall will be open free, it will cost you a dollar to get in (40 cents if you are a child) but it is worth it, and you will be defraying one fourhundredthousands of the cost of installing a gem in the crown of this institu tion in its 100th anniversary year.

title: 6MONTH EARNINGS CLIMB AT KINNEY
description: Net income of the Kinney National Service, Inc., rose in the quarter and six months ended March 31. Although the company did not release quar terly figures, observers estimate the earnings at $9,069,000 or 52 cents a share, up from $7. 817,000, or 46 cents a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: JENKINS MOUNT WINS AT LANCASTER SHOW
description: LANCASTER, Pa., May 15 Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill's Brandan, a new mount on the circuit, captured the first open jumper class today at the open ing session of the threeday Lancaster spring horse show at the Lancaster Riding and Ten nis Club.

title: Colchico of Saints Retires
description: CONCORD, Calif., May 15 (UPI)Dan Colchico, a defen sive end of the New Orleans Saints, announced his retire ment today from pro football. I would like to remain in pro football in some capacity, may be as a scout or a coach, said Colchico.

title: In Memoriam
description: FERGUSONWilliam V. Died April 16, 1970. In his memory a mass will be siad on Monday, May 18, 1970 at ?? P.M., at the main after of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Iconoclast Heads Apparel Association
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 Norman M. Hinerfeld, the new ly elected president of the American Apparel Manufactur ers Association, is a man with a reputation as an iconoclast in a traditionbound industry.

title: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION
description: THURSDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: P. S. Wild Jr., Jane L. Batten To Wed July 12
description: MANHASSET, L. I., May 15 Miss Jane Louise Batten and Payson Sibley Wild Jr. plan to be married July 25 Both are graduates of Mon mouth (Ill.) College.

title: Siderowf Defeats Courville to Gain Semifinals in Richardson Golf
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 15  Dick Siderowf, the Metropolitan amateur golf cham pion, indicated he was back in form today as he gained the semifinal of the William D. Richardson Memorial tourney.

title: Tight Control Seen for Soviet Economy
description: MOSCOW, May 15A prom inent Soviet economist in dicated today that the much debated national economic plan for the next five years would place continued stress on tight, centralized direction but would rely increasingly on computers and other technological innova tions to help run the economy more efficiently.

title: HOUSING STARTS DROPPED IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) New housing starts dropped sharply in April after two monthly increases, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: Princeton's New Militants Intervene in House Race
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Every day they drive up here from Princeton University60, 70 and sometimes 100 newly militant students in clean shirts, neckties and slacks to do volunteer work for an anti war Congressional candidate.

title: TIGERS SET BACK 4TH GAME IN ROW
ABORTIVE MERGER RAISES QUESTIONS
description: A merger that failed almost at the last minute was the sub ject of intense discussion at the annual meeting of North Ameri can Sugar Industries, Inc., yes terday.

title: Nixon Gas War Stand Called TradeOff
description: WASHINGTON, May 15A Library of Congress study de picts as a tradeoff President Nixon's decision to limit Amer ica's use of chemical and bio logical warfare but to continue to use tear gas and defoliants in war.

title: Automated Rail Yard
description: WASHINGTON May 15A V computerized system au tomatically controls the move ment of freight cars as they roll into place in a railway classification yard. Called the Electronic Yard master, the equip ment is operating in the 65track Inman yard of the Southern Railway system in Atlanta. Patent 3,515,867, covering the meth od and apparatus, will be is sued June 2 to the Reeves Instrument division of the Dynamics Corporation of America, Garden City, L. I. The inventor is Perry A. Seay of Northport, L. I., formerly chief engineer for Reeves.

title: 2 Britons Seriously Injured In World Auto Rally Crash
description: LAVINA, Argentina, May 15 (UPI)  Two British drivers, Andrew Cowan and Brian Coyle, were injured today when their car crashed on a moun tainous portion of the World Cup auto rally. Cowan was re ported to have suffered a frac tured skull and Coyle was badly shaken inthe accident. Both were reported to be in serious condition.

title: Article 1  No Title
Alioto's Look Suit Declared a Mistrial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 15  A mistrial was declared tonight in the libel trial involving Look magazine and Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco.

title: ECUMENICAL RULES FOR SCHOOLS ISSUED
description: ROME, May 15  The Vati can's ranking prelate in charge of interfaith relations, Jan Car dinal Willebrands, presented guidelines today for ecumenism in higher education.

title: Neighborhoods: Astoria's Relaxed Melting Pot
description: A visiting detachment of evzones, the famed skirted warriors of Greece, will be on hand in the Astoria section of Queens today for cere monies accompanying the demolition of an old man sion.

title: Council to Modify Mayor's Rent Plan
description: The chairman of the City Council's Housing Committee declared yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's proposed revisions of the rentcontrol law would not be approved without substan tial changes and refinements.

title: 2DIVISION ACORN DRAWS 25 FILLIES
description: Two weeks ago, Tommy Trot ter, the racing secretary at Aqueduct, thought today's fea ture race, the Acorn, might at tract a dozen fillies. Last week, he increased his estimate to 18. Five days ago, he increased it again to 22.

title: PENTAGON SHUTTING MANY BASES TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Defense Department extended today the list of military bases across the country at which, tomorrow's traditional Armed Forces Day ceremonies and open house visit by civilians have been canceled to avoid confrontations with antiwar protesters.

title: Cahill Terms an Exchange On Students Educational
description: A meeting between Gov. Wil liam T. Cahill and 200 student leaders from New Jersey cam puses turned into a shouting match yesterday as several stu dents pressed the Governor for answers to questions on the war in Vietnam and the Black Panther party.

title: W.H.O. Asks World Anticigarette Drive
description: GENEVA, May 15Members of the World Health Organiza tion called today for a world wide campaign against ciga rette smoking, including re strictions and advertising.

title: 200 Seized in Athens
description: ATHENS, Ga., May 15 (UPI) More than 200 Negro and white demonstrators, chanting soul power, were arrested for parading without a permit tonight and hauled away in Na tional Guard trucks.

title: Alcoholism Curb Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) Senator Harold E. Hughes, Democratic of Iowa, introduced Thursday, legislation for a Fed eral campaign to treat, prevent and control alcoholism. The bill would establish a national in stitute for the prevention and control of alcohol abuse and al coholism and would establish programs of prevention, treat ment and rehabilitation for Fed eral employes and members of the armed services.

title: De Vicenzo, Trevino and Smith Tied for Lead in Colonial Golf With 136's
description: FORT WORTH, May 15 (AP) Roberto de Vicenzo of Argen tinaa carded a fourunderpar 66 today to tie Lee Trevino and Bob Smith for the second round, lead in the $125,000 Colonial National invitation golf tourna ment with an aggregate of 136.

title: 7 Complaints Filed As Table Is Opened In Washington High
description: A controversial student com plaint table was opened in George Washington High School yesterday, but it attracted few complainants.

title: Armco to Lift Steel Prices
description: The Armco Steel Corporation said yesterday in Middletown, Ohio, that it would match the actions of other major produc ers by raising the prices of flat rolled products an average of about 4.7 per cent, effective June 1. Details of the Armco move varied slightly from those of competitors. However, the move generally followed the pattern of raising prices sharply but eliminating many long standing extra charges.

title: France Begins Series Of 8 Nuclear Explosions
description: PARIS, May 15  France began a new series of nuclear tests today with a low power explosion over the la goon of Mururoa atoll in the Tuamotu Archipelago in the South Pacific, the Ministry of Defense announced in a brief communiqu.

title: Bridal Is Set By Miss Sard
description: BEDFORD HILLS. N. Y., May 15Miss Susannah El len Sard and Robert Wallis Ward Jr., son of Mrs. Ward of Georgetown, Ky., and the late Mr. Ward, will be mar ried here on June 27.

title: Stringency or Profligacy?
description: The recordbreaking $7.8billion general expense budget proposed for New York City for the next fiscal year is a stringent budget in the view of Mayor Lindsay's aides. To the extent that the budget fails to meet many of the city's most urgent needs, that is a supportable view. The budget is $1.1 billion more than the current one, a jump of 16 per cent, but it takes an increase of this magnitude just to meet builtin escalators in this time of rampant inflation.

title: Philip, Cutting Costs, Will Drop Secretary
description: LONDON, May 15 (AP) Prince Philip, who said six months ago that the royal family was going into the red, is getting rid of his private secretary to cut costs, a Buckingham Palace spokes man said today.

title: Nippon Steel Corp. of Japan Called Biggest Producer Now
description: The Nippon Steel Corpora tion, a newly formed Japanese producer, has supplanted the United States Steel Corporation as the world's largest steel company and the Japanese con cern will be twice the size of the American leader within five years.

title: Excerpts From an Address by Warren About Crisis of the Nation
description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by former Chief Justice Earl Warren to the N. A. A. C. P. Legal Defense and Educa tional Fund, Inc.:

title: F.B.I. Investigating Killing Of 2 Negroes in Jackson
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 15A barrage of police gunfire that lasted 30 seconds and consisted of at least 140 shots left two students dead and nine other persons wounded here last night. All the dead and wounded were Negroes. and wounded were Negroes.

title: Music: A Pianist's Debut
description: Two opposing poles of pianism, the Haydn D major Concerto and the Burleske by Richard Strauss, were played last night by the so loist with the New York Philharmonic. Israela Mar galit was the pianist, and it was her New York debut is the wife of Lorin Maazel, who conducted the orchestra as part of his cur rent Philharmonic engage ment.

title: Texas Panel Investigating Tarlike Substance in Gulf
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 15A state government interagency, committee is investigating the appearance of an oily tarlike substance along the Gulf of Mexico coast from the tip of Texas to western Florida.

title: Bomb Suspect Is Indicted For Not Appearing in Court
description: Jane Lauren Alpert, who was declared to have forfeited her $20,000 bond after she disap peared last week while await ing sentence on a bombing con spiracy conviction, was in dicted yesterday for failing to appear in Federal Court.

title: Samuels Criticizes Goldberg, Conditions in State and War
description: BUFFALO, May 15 Howard J. Samuels charged today that his rival for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Ar thur J. Goldberg, was not in volved in the issues of the day and is the candidate of the old politics.

title: 400 Children to Participate In a Suzuki Violin Festival
description: About 400 children are ex pected to participate in a Su zuki Violin Festival to be held in the Columbia University Gymnasium on Sunday, May 24, at 2 P.M. The event is being sponsored by more than a dozen schools and private mu sic studios that use the violin teaching method developed by Shinichi Suzuki, the Japanese pedagogue.

title: POST TO INCREASE NEWSSTAND PRICE
description: The New York Post an nounced yesterday that the newsstand price of its daily paper would he increased from 10 cents to 15 cents starting Monday.

title: Concert to Aid War Victims
description: A concert to benefit Vietna mese children wounded and or phaned by the war in Vietnam will be presented at the Ethical Culture Society on May 26 at 8:30; P.M. by Richard Goode, pianist, with members of the Casals Festival Orchestra and the City Center Opera Orches tra. The program will he de voted to chamber music by Beethoven, including the Quin tet for Piano and Winds (Op. 16) and the Septet in E flat (Op. 20). Tickets can he ob tained from the American Friends Service Committee, 15 Rutherford Palce, New York, 10003.

title: U.S. BRIEF BACKS TAXEXEMPT ROLE OF WHITE SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 The Justice Department con tended today that the segregat ed private schools that have grown up recently in the South should be allowed to keep their taxexempt status. It said that the exemption did not consti tute any form of Government support for these schools.

title: Dust Commander, My Dad George Head Field in $203,800 Preakness Today
description: BALTIMORE, May 15  A Real dark horse only a month ago, Robert Lehmann's Dust Commander enjoys the status of favorite at 5 to 2 for the Preakness tomorrow. At least, the Illinoisbred son of Bold Commander and Dust Storm rates that eminence on the overnight line, but there is much likelihood that My Dad George, owned by Raymond Curtis, will be the people's choice when the 14 entrants line up for the 13/16 mile event at 5:40 P.M. On the overnight line, My Dad George is 3 to 1.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Role for Mayor

title: Missing Sports Boat Found Off L.I. With Owner Dead
description: CASTLE HILL, R. I., May 15 (AP)The Coast Guard said to day it had found the missing sports fishing boat Mary Jane off the eastern tip of Long Is land with the body of its owner, Angelo De Spirito Jr. of North Smithfield. R. I. aboard.

title: WARHOL'S SOUP CAN SELLS FOR $60,000
description: A painting of a can of Camp bell's vegetable beef soup by Andy Warhol, the pop artist was auctioned Thursday for $60,000 to a European bidder who wished to remain anony mous.

title: The Program
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Lorin Maazel conducting, with Israela Mar gala, piano. At Philharmonic Hall.

title: Trade Surplus Set Record for Canada In First Quarter
description: OTTAWA, May 15 (Canadian Press)Canada's trade surplus soared to $655million (Cana dian funds) in the first quarter of 1970, the highest seasonally adjusted surplus on record, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

title: 3 EGYPTIAN JETS REPORTED DOWN
description: JERUSALEM, May 15The air war over the Suez Canal intensified today as the Israelis reported that they had shot down three Egyptian jet fighters.

title: U.S. Favors Joint Defense By Saigon and Pnompenh
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The United States publicly en couraged South Vietnam and Cambodia today to produce a joint plan for the defense of the regime of Premier Lon Nol in Pnompenh from Com munist attacks.

title: Beame Disputes Optimism of Lindsay on City Budget
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had submitted an unbalanced budget because of overly optimistic projected revenues from offtrack betting and the state lottery.

title: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: ADDONIZIO LOSES TRIAL DELAY BID
description: TRENTON, May 15  A Fed eral judge rejected Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio's request today for a delay of his trial here on extortion and income tax eva sion charges until after the June 16 mayoral runoff election in Newark.

title: Bonn Eases Protest Curbs
description: BONN, May 15 (AP)  The West German Bundesrat, or upper house, gave final approval today to a new law granting greater freedom to demonstra tors and amnesty in some cases after conviction for violent pro test. Under the law, the police will be barred from random ar rests of persons not directly in volved in violence at demon strations.

title: 35 Counties in Four States Join Federal Food Programs
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  Federal food programs for needy persons have been ex tended to 35 additional coun ties in Kansas, Texas, Nebraska and Virginia, Secretary, of Agri culture Clifford M. Hardin an nounced today.

title: Kidney Foundation Planning Its First Mystic Ball May 25
description: The first Mystic Ball spon sored by the National Kidney Foundation has been sched uled for the Rainbow Room on May 25; and if the inter est shown so far in its occult themes is an indication of things to come, the event could become a fixture on the crowded spring benefit calendar.

title: W. and M. Enters IC. 4A
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (UPI)William and Mary Col lege, led by Howell Michael, a miler, today entered a 14man team in the 94th annual Inter collegiate Association of Ama teur Athletes of America out door track and field champion ships to be held at Franklin Field on May 29 and 30.

title: Licensing of Process Servers Upheld
description: State Supreme Court Justice Ivan Warner has upheld the right of the City Consumer Af fairs Department to license process servers and process serving agencies.

title: Paris Air Traffic Delayed By Action of Controllers
description: PARIS, May 15 (UPI)Doz ens of passengers slept on makeshift beds through the night at Orly Airport, where a job action by air traffic con trollers delayed arrivals and de partures for periods up to sev eral hours.

title: Dillingham Will Dissolve Land Development Venture
description: The Dillingham Corporation has announced that it and its partners, Eastern Air Lines, Inc., and Laurance S. Rockefel ler's Olohana Corporation, have decided to dissolve the Dilrock Eastern Company, a land de velopment joint venture that had proposed to build a conven tion hotel and resort complex on the Kohala coast of Hawaii.

title: Combustion Gets Contract
description: The Pacific Power and Light Company and the Idaho Power Company have announced the award of a $50million contract to Combustion Engineering, Inc., for two 500,000kilowatt steam generating systems. The two units will be coalfired and will be installed as the first two units in the Jim Bridger steam plant, a jointly owned station to be situated east of Rock Springs, Wyo. The first unit is scheduled to be in operation in 1974 for Idaho Power and the second unit a year later.

title: This Week in Business
description: On Monday, the first day of the business week, they didn't break up the Knicks. On that day, the National Basketball Association's 14 teams contributed 33 of their players to stock the new teams in Buffalo, Cleveland and Portland, Ore. The N.B.A. called this redistribution an expansion draft and announced that it would work like this: Each team would be allowed to protect seven of its 12 players from the draft, and after one of the unprotected five was picked, it could protect one of the remaining four.

title: Note to Readers
description: Reviews of last night's dance and music perform ances are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings. They will appear in tomorrow's editions.

title: Soviet Ends Postponement Of U.S. Cultural Exhibition
description: MOSCOW, May 15 (UPI) Soviet authorities have lifted their temporary ban on the first United States traveling exhibi tion in Siberia, the United State Embassy said today.

title: Tully Hall Plans a Series Of Music and Ballet Films
description: Lincoln Center will present seven programs of seldom heard music, traditional jazz and ballet films at Alice Tully Hall beginning June 12.

title: MERGER STOPPED AT WHITE MOTOR
description: The White Motor Corpora tion and the Ethyl Corporation terminated yesterday their pre viously announced merger talks because of present eco nomic conditions and the seri ously depressed state of the stock market.

title: Autopsies Show Buckshot Felled Six in Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., May 15 Coroner Nathan F. Widener reported tonight that autopsies showed that six Negroes killed in Augsta during riots on Mon day and Tuesday were all shot in the back and all killed with O O buckshot.

title: Strahan Accepts Ram Pact
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15 (UPI) The Los Angeles Rams today signed Arthur Strahan, a 260 pound defensive tackle. Stra han was a free agent.

title: President Is Designated As Churchman of Year
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)Religious Heritage of America, Inc., announced to day the selection of President Nixon as its churchman of the year. He was cited for creating an atmosphere for a return to the spiritual, moral and ethical values of the Founding Fathers and for inaugurating ecumenical Sunday worship services at the White House.

title: New Navy Chief in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15 (AP)  Vice Adm. Jerome H. King Jr. assumed command of United States naval forces in Vietnam today from Vice Adm. Elmo R. Zum walt Jr., who will become Chief of Naval Operations on July 1. Gen. Creighton W. Ab rams, commander of Unite States forces in Vietnam, pre sented Admiral Zumwalt with the Navy Distinguished Service Medal and the Navy Unit Com mendation.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Treasury statement and some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations are omitted from this issue because of compos ing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Mississippi Head Start Gains
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Secretary of Health, Edu cation and Welfare, Robert H. Finch, overrode today a veto by Gov. John Bell Williams of Mississippi and announced a $190,000 Federal grant for that state's Head Start Training Co ordinating Council. The grant is for the calendar year 1970.

title: Topics: Israel at 22  A New Zealand View
description: TAURANGA, New Zealand Last May I chanced to be in Israel at her twentyfirst birth day party: blueandwhite flags whooping it up on pasteltinted buildings and the young of the country celebrating in a coat of many colors. In New Jeru salem a daylong procession of the combat forces in coats of even more colors, converging from the countryside, marching and singing to circle the Old Jerusalem. All on their way somewhere.

title: RENE PAYOT
description: GENEVA, May 15  Rene Payot, a Frenchspeaking Swiss journalist and radio commen tator whose broadcasts won him a wide audience in France during the German occupation of World War II, died in a hos pital here today at the age of 75.

title: SHANKER STARTS 15 DAYS IN JAIL
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Tech ers, flew here yesterday after attending the funeral of Walter P. Reuther in Detroit to begin serving a 15day criminal con tempt sentence for having led illegal school strikes in the fall of 1968.

title: Antiques: Pennsylvania Painted Chests Reflect Styles From All Over the World
description: OVEROPTIMISTIC collet tors are pinning the Pennsylvania label on a wide variety of painted chests that were made either too late or too far away.

title: Ohio University Closes And Guard Takes Over
description: ATHENS, Ohio, May 15  Ohio University was closed at 3:10 o'clock this morning.

title: SUGAR FUTURES MOSTLY STEADY
description: Although one large producer announced an increase in list prices for industrial grades of refined sugar by 35 cents a hundred pounds in all terri tories, the No. 8 world sugar futures involving raw sugar were unchanged to down 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday.

title: Leary Vows No Reprisals To Police Telling of Graft
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary modified yester day a rule that policemen must report corruption to their commanding officers and encouraged them to give information directly to him, a District Attorney or the Department of Investigation.

title: THREE PIGEONS WINS DASH AT LOUISVILLE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16  (AP)  J. W. Greathouse's Three Pigeons took command late in the stretch today and won the first Regret Stakes at Churchill Downs by 2 lengths. She was piloted by Tommy Barrow.

title: Mail: This Little Piggy Went to Yosemite
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Texan Again Nominated as Envoy
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 16 (AP)President Nixon to day nominated John G. Hurd, a member of an oil and cat tle investment company in Texas, to be United States Ambassador to South Africa.

title: Advice on Tax Return Delay
description: The Internal Revenue Service said here yesterday that tax payers expecting refunds should wait at least 10 weeks from the date of filing before writing about the delays For those filing on the last day, that would mean waiting at least until June 30.

title: House Votes to Triple Funds For Water and Sewer Lines
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) The House has voted to more than triple to $500million the money for helping small com munities build water and sewer lines.

title: Americans Are Emigrating To Australia
description: MELBOURNE. A CHICKEN farmer from Michigan explains that he became fed up with government Interference; all he wanted to do, he says, was grow more wheat on his 100acre farm, and when he did he was fined $5,000. A former employe of the New York Department of Health re calls bitterly how his daughter was molested on a subway, and how his son had his school lunch money stolen by in the Bronx. A head master from North Carolina says he can't accept forced integration of American schools; a builder from Cali fornia asserts that after the oil slick hit Santa Barbara, I knew I just couldn't stay there any longer; a pipeline executive from Ohio claims he couldn't contend with American unions. A travel agent from Indiana says he had to get away from the rat race, before it devoured me. Some of the complaints are less specific: talking with a housewife from Nebraska, you get the impression that in some vague, illogical fashion, Jackie Kennedy's decision to become Mrs. Onassis con vinced her that it was time to pack up and leave the United States.

title: Spanish Sahara to Vote On Mauritania Merger
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, May 16 (AP)President Moktar Quid Daddah of Mauritania an nounced yesterday that his country had agreed to a referendum to decide whether Mauritania should take over control of Spanish Sahara from Spain.

title: In Detroit, a Search for Confidence
description: DETROIT, May 16 The automobile business may not be getting much better, but at least it has stopped get ting worse.

title: 2 U.S.Owned Horses Sweep Irish Classics
description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, May 16 (UPI)  American racehorse owners swept both the 1.000 and 2,000 Guineas classics today at the Irish Guineas meeting.

title: I've Taken Risks for 30 Years
description: OF course, Barrault is a presence. But you are made to feel it in ways that become just slightly preposterous. For one thing, he gazes into your eyes with a look that suggests the longsuffering man, the spirit crushed, the flower trod up on. There is something hand wringing about the allen compassing gaze that sup posedly understands and in tuits all.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Questions of literary interest should be addressed: Queries Editor, The New York Times Book Review, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036, and accompanied by a stamped, selfaddressed envelope. The editor will publish those of greatest interest. Others are answered by letter.

title: Architecture
description: IT is not without a certain parochial pleasure that we point out that major architectural shows have been part of the centennial celebrations of both New York's Metropolitan and Bos ton's Fine Arts museums.

title: John Cage's Words Were Prophetic
description: I BELIEVE that the use of noise to make music will continue and in crease until we reach a music produced through the aid of electrical instru ments. ... Whereas in the past, the point of disagree ment has been between dis sonance and consonance, it will be, in the immediate fu ture, between noise and so called musical sounds. Pro phetic words; doubly so when one realizes that they were spoken by John Cage In 1937 as part of a talk on The Future of Music: Credo. But even the visionary Cage imagination could hardly have foreseen that some 30 years later his words would be as applicableperhaps even more soto popular music as to the music of the concert hall.

title: THE OPENINGS
description: LEMON SKYTonight, Play house, 7. A play by Lan ford Wilson.

title: Letters
description: RE: KUNSTLER To THE EDITOR: I was very much impressed with Victor S. Navasky's article of April 19 about William M. Kunstler (Right On! With Lawyer William Kunstler). However, Mr. Navasky's statement that my husband, Rap Brown, is said to have languished in a New Orleans jail on a hunger strike for weeks until Kunstler finally got around to filing a bond applica tion is totally false. Not only did Mr. Kunstler succeed on appeal in reducing Rap's Louisiana bonds from $100,000 to $30,000, but he managed, after months of effort, to obtain his ultimate release on bail in both Virginia and Maryland, where he was subsequently detained after his release from Louisiana.

title: Boycotts Must Work
description: My view is that just as blockades need to be effective in order to be licensed by international law, so boycotts ought to be effective. I remember participating in the development of the Hungary Pledge, which a group us circulated after Hungary was overrun in 1956. We pledged to have nothing to do with any representative of the tyrants who suppressed the Hungarian freedom fighters, or with any of the products that were being manufactured by the enemy satellites, so as to isolate him [the enemy] and bring the force of world opinion bear against him.

title: Great Mystery, $3.80, First By Neck at Suffolk Downs
description: BOSTON. May 16 (AP) B. A. Dario's Great Mystery surrendered the lead at the top of the stretch and then moved again o defeat Big Time Bill by a neck in the $15,000 Senior Handicap at Suffolk Downs to day in his first attempt on the grass course.

title: HARRY H. NEUBERGER, STOCKBROKER, DEAD
description: RED BANK, N. J., May 16 Harry Hobson Neuberger, a member of the New York Stock Exchange from 1925 to 1967 and a former partner in the brokerage firm of Hilson & Neuberger, died today of a heart attack in Riverview Hos pital. He was 73 years old and lived at Sunnyside Farm, Lyn croft.

title: Remington didn't like the way Custer was dressed
description: Last summer I visited the Gilcrease Collection of West ern Art in Tulsa, and found myself thrilled by the Indian battle paintings of a man I had never heard of, Charles Schreyvogel. I had thought that Frederic Remington and Charles Russell were the great painters of the postCivil War West. Now here was their unknown equal. Who was he?

title: Camp Unit Lives On In Aid to Children By Fresh Air Fund
description: Although the Camp Place ment Center of the West Side closed its doors last February, it is still making it possible for hundreds of underprivileged youngsters to go to camp this summer.

title: Little League Week Set
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., May 16 (UPJ)Little League Baseball Week will be observed June 8 to 14, Peter J. McGovern, presi dent of the league, Announced today. The annual week fie Little Leagues cane by proc lamation of lale President Dwight D Eisenhower in 1955.

title: SHORT ALONE WINS HORSE SHOW BLUE
description: LANCASTER, Pa., May 16 Chuck Ackerman's Short Alone moved into contention for the preliminary jumper champion ship by winning a time class to day at the Lancaster spring horse show.

title: NEW LAWS URGED FOR EXCONVICTS
description: A committee of the New York County Lawyers' Associa tion recommended last week that laws that prevent former convicts from holding certain fobs should be changed.

title: Colonel Killed in Air Crash
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) One of the 82 Army colonels nominated for promotion to brigadier general yesterday was killed in a helicopter crash in Vietnam last Tuesday. He was Col. Carroll E. Adams Jr., 46 years old, of Pawtucket, R. I. Colonel Adams was com manding the 937th Engineer Group when he and nine others, including Maj. Gen. John A. Dillard, died in the crash.

title: On a Clear Day in Milan, It's About 40 Per Cent Clearer Than It Used to
description: MILAN, Italy, May 11On a clear day here you can see about 40 per cent farther than you could a year ago. Italy's smoggiest city is also getting about twice as many clear days as it used to.

title: I.O.S.: Cracks in a Symbol
description: GENEVAWhen the cracks first appeared in Bernard Cornfeld's financial empire. the conservative bankers of Europe chuckled quietly to themselves and said in ef fect, We told you so.

title: Liberals Back Barry Farber
description: Barry Farber, 40yearold Re publican candidate for Repre sentative from the 19th Dis trict, yesterday received the endorsement of the Liberal party, it was announced by Arthur N. Brook, the party's New York County chairman. Mr. Farber, a radio broadcaster and linguist, is expected to campaign in English, Spanish, Chinese, Italian, Swedish and Yiddish. Leonard Farbstein, a Democrat, holds the Congres sional seat.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Babe Ruth never made it. Neither did Rogers Hornsby nor George Sisler nor Lou Gehrig. The mere fact that these and so many other outstanding batters failed to qualify for membership in the Three Thou sand Hit Club emphasizes the exclusivity of this group of the baseball elite.

title: A 150Game Winner
description: GULFPORT, Miss. (UPI)  Dizzy Dean won 150 major league games and lost only 83 though troubled with a sore arm through most of his major league baseball career.

title: Ford Funds Will Be Used For PantherPolice Study
description: The $50,000 that the National Association for the Advance ment of Colored People is giv ing to help finance a commis sion to study clashes between the police and the Black Panth ers was given to the N.A.A.C.P. by the Ford Foundation.

title: City Works to Freshen Up Its Main Streets
description: RICHMOND Avenue is one of New York City's Main Streetsand it's in trouble.

title: Law Group Picks Director
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  John Lawrence Hargrove, for mer senior adviser for inter national law to the United States Mission to the United Nations, was today appointed director of studies of the Amer ican Society of International Law. Mr. Hargrove, who also served in the office of the Le gal Adviser of the State De partment, is a Texan.

title: Jack In the Pulpit
description: EARLY American settlers called Indian turnip because Indians col lected its acridtasting bulblike roots to boil and eat. Most of us know it by the more piquant name jack inthepulpit.

title: L.I. CONSERVATIVES BACK REPUBLICAN
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I., May 16 The Conservative and Repub lican parties in Suffolk County joined forces this week to try to win the First Congressional District seat held by a five term Democratic incumbent, Otis G. Pike.

title: Charges in Ceylon Against Opposition Dominate Election
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 16 The campaign for Ceylon's elec tion of a new Parliament on May 27 has been dominated by Government charges that the Opposition United Front may be seeking to seize power by force.

title: Super Crans: Up, Up and (Some Wish) Away
description: MONTANACRANS, Switzerland During the two years of ani mated discussion that preceded the building of Super Crans, many people here shouted angrily, This is not New York. They opposed the construction of a 19story skyscraper in an Alpine meadow above Montana.

title: U.S. AIDES EXPECT SAIGON TO REMOVE UNITS IN CAMBODIA
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 16The White House said to day that it had every reason to believe that South Vietnam would withdraw its combat forces from Cambodia around July 1, the date given for the completion of the pullout of all American troops.

title: Martha Beard Plans Nuptials
description: RYE, N. Y., May 16Mr. and Mrs. Josephus Simmons Beard 2d have anounced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Martha Lyndley Blaine Beard, to Peter Will liam Retchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Retchin of Greenwich. Conn.

title: Activity Nearly Evaporates on Amex and Counter
description: Activity in the overthe counter market and on the American Stock Exchange has virtually dried up in re sponse to investor fears that the Vietnam war will not be over as soon as expected, the nation will become embroiled the Middle East conflict and the economy is in trouble.

title: Religion
description: A joke currently making the rounds of liberal Roman Catho lics holds that bishops attending the next Vatican Council will be accompanied not only by their theological advisers but by their wives. At the council after that, it runs, some bishops may bring along their husbands.
