description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:

title: Brooklyn Net Streak at 49
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., May 16 Brooklyn College's tennis team scored its 49th straight victory today, beating the Merchant Marine Academy, 81. The Kingsmen, Division A winners, meet Iomi, Division B victor, at the St. John's courts in Queens tomorrow for the Met ?? Conference title.

title: AARON NEAR MARK AFTER 2 DOUBLES
description: CINCINNATI, May 16 (UPI) Jim McGlothlin stopped the Atlanta Braves on five hits and ended Rico Carty's hitting streak at 31 games today while pitching the Cincinnati Reds to a 20 victory.

title: Reilly Wins Two Awards As Top Fordham Athlete
description: Twelve Fordham athletes in 13 sports were named most valuable players in their sports at last night's 36th annual Block F Dinner at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

title: Saboteurs in Bolivia Pose Threat to Rally Drivers
description: LONDON, May 16 (UPI)  Crews In the LondontoMexico World Cup rally, fighting the effects of high altitude with oxygen masks as they sped along the rugged Andes today, faced the added hazard of sabotage.

title: 10,000 March in Parade on Fifth Avenue Marking Armed Forces Day
description: About 10,000 military men marched down Fifth Avenue without incident yesterday afternoon in celebration of Armed Forces Day. The par ticipants in the 21st annual parade, marching in a light drizzle, were received with applause, cheers and flag waving by the spectators lin ing the avenue. A number of bystanders held up placards reading We Love Our Coun try, Support the President and the like. Elsewhere in the nation, Armed Forces Day ceremonies were canceled at 23 military bases because of threats of neace demonstra tions but went on without trouble at hundreds of others. At Fort Dix, N.J., where it was announced on Friday that there would be no cere monies, 3,000 antiwar demon strators massed outside the base but were prevented from entering by a line of soldiers. Some youths tried to out flank the troops by running through the woods, but the State Police stopped them. A halfdozen demonstrators were clubbed. At Fort Meade, Md., where ceremonies were also canceled, about 300 anti war youths  perhaps 30 of them offduty G.I.'s in civilian clothesheard Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie, call for a war of liberation by young people in the United States to force an end to the fighting in Vietnam.

title: People's Park a Rebel Symbol Now
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Just off Telegraph Avenue, not far from the Berkeley campus of the University of California, a tall steelmesh fence surrounds a blocksquare plot of land. In side the fence, two vacant parking lots flank a deserted soccer field and two empty basketball courts. The site is peaceful.

title: RED SOX HOMERS BEAT INDIANS, 62
description: BOSTON, May 16 (AP)Carl Yastrzemski broke a 22 tie in the eighth inning by cracking a threerun homer, one of the longest ever hit in Fenway Park, and the Boston Red Sox defeated the Cleveland In dians, 62, today. The victory ended a fivegame losing streak.

title: Soviet Singer's Witty, Private Performances Make Him Intellectuals' Hero
description: MOSCOW, May 12In the planned, censored but not com pletely controllable world of Soviet culture, Vladimir Vysot skya professional actor and throaty folksingerhas become the champion of intellectuals, who feel that his provocative, emotional, witty songs often carry a message that the Gov ernment does not want to hear.

title: Harvard Expert on Presidency Views Nixon Policy With Fear
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 Prof. Richard E. Neustad, whose classic study. Presiden tial Power, distinguished be tween shadow and substance, views the Nixon Presidency with distress and apprehension.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONReporters no ticed an odd thing on the bul letin board in the White House press room last Wednesday. The President's list of appointments included, among other dignitar ies, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Leonard Garment. The Thursday schedule indicated that Mr. Nixon would see George Romney. What was odd about all this is that until last week the White House press office had made no particular effort to identify the names of aides and Cabinet members who meet with the President.

title: Perry to Quit Bowling Green
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio., May 16 (UPIDoyt. I., Perry announced today he had re signed as athletic director at Bowling Green State Univer sity. effective January, 1971. The 60yearold Perry will com plete 37 years in Ohio high school and collegiate athletic circles whrn he leaves here for a position as athletic advisor for Florida. International Uni versity.

title: Bridge
description: WHEN the President is carrying out his perennial search for new sources of revenue, he might do worse than consider a tax on bridge conventions. Apart from the obvious budgetary advantage, the benefits to the players would also be consider able.

title: WORKERS DEBATE STUDENTS ON WAR
description: To Judy Solomon, a 20year old English major at City Col lege, it's important to get la bor against the war because they're so powerful.

title: A'S SLAM 4 HOMERS TO STOP ANGELS, 113
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 16 (UMChuck Dobson of the Oakland Athletics went the distance for the third time this season to gain his third vic tory, beating the California Angels, 113. Tie was helped by homers by Felipe Alou. Dave Duncan, Dick Green and Bert Campaneris.

title: Chesapeake Bay Bridge Reports Revenue Drop
description: CAPE CHARLES, Va., May 16Traffic on the Chesa peake Bay BridgeTunnel still has not recovered from the effects of the sixweek clo sure of the facility after it was struck by a Navy ship, the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel Commission has been told.

title: G.M. Challenged on Responsibility
description: Calling themselves the Project on Cor porate Responsibility, a handful of young lawyers in Washington several months ago began a campaign to make General Motors responsible. Backed by, but not directly linked to, Ralph Nader whose Unsafe at Any Speed did not make him Detroit's favorite authorthe legal activists successfully convinced the Securities and Exchange Commission to put consumeroriented resolutions be fore shareholders at General Motors' annual meeting this Friday.

title: BAPTIST SEMINARY PLANS TO MERGE
description: CINCINNATI, May 16Crozer Theological Seminary, one of seven seminaries maintained by the American Baptist Conven tion, will close in the fall and merge with Colgate Rochester Bexley Hall, a divinity school in Rochester, N.Y.

title: Hillside house
description: The art of compromise is usually the first one that has to be mastered by anyone building a house on a limited budget, as John Christian, an industrial designer, and his wife discovered when they bought a bargain lot that had gone unsold for 40 years in a Maryland subdivision. The price was right, but the lot was only 40 feet wide and on a precipitous slope. Neighboring houses extended to within eight feet of the line on either side. Christian's design takes advantage of the lot's drawbacks. He placed it at the very top of the slope to gain a treetop view and left the side walls blank except for tall, narrow windows that frame views of his neighbors' trees.

title: HOCHHUTH UNVEILS A PLAY ABOUT C.I.A.
description: STUTTGART, May 16Rolf Hochhuth, whose first play, The Deputy, attacked Pope Pius XII for not speaking out against Nazi atrocities and whose second, Soldiers, accused Sir Winston Churchill of involvement in the death of his Polish ally, Gen. Igor, I. Sikorski, has now taken on the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Harvard Sociologist Calls Integrated Schools Needed
description: WASHINGTON. May 16 (AP) Dr. Thomas F. Pettigrew, Harvard social psychologist, has testified that he is con vinced integrated education is an essential for the future viability and harmony of our country.

title: Casasola Breaks 4 Marks On Way to A.A.U. Lift Title
description: BRENTWOOD, L.I., May 16, Gene Casasola of the York (Pa.) Bar Bell Club established four records today in winning the 114pound class at the Amateur Athletic Union na tional junior weightlifting, championships at the Brent wood Recreation Center.

title: CROWN IS SHARED BY JOHNS HOPKINS
description: BALTIMORE, May 16Johns Hopkins and Virginia gained a share of the national lacrosse championship with victories to day. The Blue Jays beat Mary land here, 74, and the Cava lires defeat Hofstra, 143, in Charlottesville, Va.

title: New York
description: We went down with the stock market, it's as simple as that, an aide to Robert M. Morgenthau said last Thursday as the former Federal attorney dropped out of the race for Governor and the DowJones Industrial Average dipped below 700.

title: U.S. JUDGE REVERSES ARMY ON DISCHARGE
description: It is impermissible for the military to punish an admitted ly competent soldier merely be cause it disapproves of the com pany he keeps, a Federal judge ruled here last week in ordering the Army to grant an honorable discharge to a soldier it accused of having Commu nist sympathies.

title: Annual Indy 500 Rules Dispute Focuses on Wings This Year
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 16 Here we go again. One of the elements that gives Indian apolis its air of permanence is the constant and pre dictable dispute over rules changes of rules, confusion over rules and interpretations of rules. This year's subject, comparable to the question of how many angels can dance on the head of a pin, is The Wing. There is not even much agreement whether to call this object a wing, a spoiler or an airfoil, a se mantic problem that the United States Auto Club has circumvented by identifying it as The part of the body having aerodynamic in fluence.

title: A Few Prejudices
description: When it comes to the nations of the world and their problems, I am convinced that the best possible instru ment of change over the long haul is human interchange. Tourism, overall, is a subtle but strong force for world stability: It enlarges understanding, it breaks down bar riers and at its best it evokes a human warmth that erodes the edges of political propaganda and challenges the assumptions of narrow, nationalistic thinking.

title: Soccer Match Put Off
description: TORONTO, May 16 (Cana dian Press)A Toronto Cup soccer match scheduled for to night between Glasgow Celtic and Bari of Italy was postponed today to 3 P.M. tomorrow be cause of poor weather.

title: Flood's Antitrust Trial Starts Tuesday
description: Curt Flood's antitrust suit against baseball goes to trial on Tuesday, in Federal Court here before Judge Irving Ben Cooper, and for the first time baseball's lawyers will have to argue formally on the merits of the reserve system.

title: Soviet Caspian Port Struck by Quake
description: MOSCOW, May 16A se ries of earthquakes have struck the area of Makhach kale, the capital of the Dag estan autonomous republic on ?? Caspian Sea.

title: 12 ASIAN NATIONS MEET ON CAMBODIA
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 16 The 12 nations participating in the Asian conference on Cambodia held their first day of discussions today and pro claimed a new era of Asians' responsibility for their own destiny.

title: CUBAN PROTESTERS IMPRISON SWISS AIDE
description: HAVANA, May 16 (Reuters) A Swiss official and a Cuban night watchman have been im prisoned in the former United, States Embassy here by thou sands of shouting antiUnited States demonstrators.

title: I Never Thought of College But Here I Am Weaving
description: BEREA, Ky.Spoonbread? asks the softspoken youth, offering a steaming casserole for a guest's inspection. And as he serves a portion of the nutlike cornmeal deli cacy (not quite light enough for a souffle, nor quite firm enough for a regular bread), the teenage waiter answers his guest's inquiry:

title: New OpenAir Churches Minister to Travelers
description: GANANOQUE, Ontario  An inter denominational outdoor church at which boats serve as pews, ushers paddle around in canoes to pass out prayer books and clergymen deliver ser mons from behind a huge granite boulder on a rocky riverbank will observe its 83d season this summer. This rustic place of worship is known as the Church in the River.

title: For Young Readers
description: A Mitzi? That's easy; it's a girl's nameI think. No, I'm sureexcept her name is Martha. You see it's all in the beginning: Martha asks her mother to tell her a story, which she does. Once upon a time there was a Mitzi. She had a mother and a father and a brother who was a baby. His name was Jacob.

title: JACKSON TO QUERY POLICE IN KILLINGS
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 16 A biracial committee investigat ing the slaying of two Negroes by the Mississippi Highway Pa trol here Thursday night en countered initial resistance to day from several Jackson po licemen who had been asked to testify.Mayor Russell C. Davis, who had formed the committee after the shootings took place on the Jackson State University cam pus, said several officers had balked at testifying in the closed hearings but had later reconsidered.

title: SETON HALL BEATS ST. JOHN'S TWICE
description: Seton Hall won the Metro politan College Baseball Confer ence championship for the sec ond consecutive year yesterday as the Pirates downed St. John's in a doubleheader, 43 and 32, at the Redmen's field in Jamaica, Queens.

title: CHURCHES URGED TO LIST PROPERTY
description: The Episcopal Diocese of New York has approved a strong statement urging its member churches to make a thorough, public review of their property holdings with the pur pose of offering for taxation any land not used exclusively for religious purposes.

title: Forclharn Selects Burik For the O'Donnell Award
description: John Burik, a regular On Ford ham's varsity basketball and baseball teams, has been named the winner of the 16th annual Terrence J. O'Donnell award.

title: TEXT STUDIES CITE NEGLECT OF JEWS
description: Materials used In church schools are seriously lacking in information concerning the Nazi holocaust and the State of Israel and its meaning for Jews, according to two parallel studies made by a Roman Catholic and a Protestant edu cator.

title: U.C.L.A. Trackmen Keep Pacific8 Crown
description: LOS ANGELES, May 16 (AP)Rick Riley of Wash ington State ran the year's first sub4minute mile and U.C.L.A. scored 28 points in the last two events to retain its Pacific8 track champion ship today. The University of California, Los Angeles, fin ??ed with III points, heat ing Oregon, the leader after yesterday's events, by 9 points.

title: Detective Who Balked at Questions About Attempt on His Life Demoted
description: A Police Department detec tive who was shot six times as he left a Bronx nightclub last July 17 and who twice balked at grand jury questions about his attempted murder has been demoted to the rank of patrol man and on May 25 will be tried by the department on charges of misconduct.

title: In the Footsteps of Jean Valjean
description: PARISI first became an aficiona do of sewers during a leisurely and rather uneventful visit to London. The romance of sewers had somehow escaped me; then, one quiet Sunday afternoon not too long ago, I picked up a chatty English guide book called London on 1 a Day to see if there was some inexpensive ad venture I had missed.

title: Mendicino Where Squares, Longhairs Mix
description: MENDOCINO, Calif.  Ever since the great lumbershipping days of the mid1800's, life has been quiet in this isolated village on the coast of northern California. But tonight, like other nights of late, the surf's boom, usually Mendocino's dom inant sound, is mixed with the racket of plunking guitars, twanging banjos, a rock'n'roll band and, to give nature her due, the plaintive bleating of a goat.

title: FARM AGENCY ACTS TO HELP MINORITIES
description: WASHINGTON. May 16 (UPI)Responding to criti cism the Agriculture Depart ment is taking steps to help members of minority groups win election to its farm pro cram local committees.

title: MALAYSIA PASSES A FATEFUL DATE
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 16Malaysia has passed the anniversary of last year's racie riots without widespread new racial disorders, but the emergency Government has built a careful case for retain ing the extraordinary powers it assumed last year.

title: HOLY CROSS ELEVEN DRILLS TOMORROW
description: Spring football practice at Holy Cross, originally sched uled to start June 2 and end June 13, will begin tomorrow.

title: POST TRACK TEAM BEATS NAVY, 7875
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 16 C. W. Post and Navy each won nine events but the Pioneers scored two of the three sweeps recorded in the 18event track meet to defeat the midshipmen, 7875, today.

title: Rent Plan Close To Rand's Ideas
description: MAYOR LINDSAY'S sweeping plans for revising rent control, presented to the City Council last week, have their roots firmly in studies and recom mendations by the Rand Cor poration, the Mayor's Com mittee on Rent Control and Prof. George Sternlieb of Rutgers University.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Retailers can sit back and look at the general scene with some equanimity even though events are not encour aging to the economy as a whole. There is a broad base of buying power in the coun try, despite a rise in unem ployment to 4.8 per cent of the labor force, the largest total since 1964. And the sum total of personal income is rising.

title: Atlanta Bridal For Mrs. Wendt
description: ATLANTA, May 16Mrs. Kathrine Newman Wendt of New York and Delray Beach, Fla., widow of William Wendt, who was general solicitor of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was married here today to Samuel Yates Aus tin Jr., president of Cromp ton  Shenandoah Company, manufacturer of corduroy, velveteen and velvet, in Waynesboro, Va.

title: FOR THIS WEEK
description: Plant rosebushes promptly upon arrival; soak the roots in a bucket of water while preparing the planting holes. ... For larger herbaceous peony flowers, pinch out the small side buds when they are the size of peas.... Be on the alert for rhododendron borer, especially around lower portions of the trunk.... Use Sevin to control holly and birch leaf miner; repeat in 10 days.... Apply fertilizer to tuberous begonias, caladium:, etc., about 10 days before transplanting them outdoors.... Plant beans.

title: Michigan Lutherans Urge 2Child Limit for Families
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., May 16 (AP)Michigan ministers of the American Lutheran Church have been told by the church's state convention to encourage fami lies in their congregations not to have more than two children.

title: DR. RALPH BANAY, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Ralph S. Banay, a foren sic psychiatrist and author, died Friday in New York Hos pital. He was 73 years old and lived at 927 Fifth Avenue.

title: ARMY TRACKMEN TOP NOTRE DAME
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 16 Army scored sweeps in four field events and posted 10 first place finishes today in notch ing a 9064 track victory over Notre Dame.

title: Impossible Dreams?
description: AS the shattered dreams of the old season are swept briskly into limbo, the new season peers over the horizon, rosyfaced and hopeful. With it come the inevitable purpleprosed press bulletins. Unhap pily, like most of the projects heralded a year ago, few of this spring's grandiose plans will see the light of autumn. Here are some typical announcements we'll soon be reading. Ignore them. They are such stuff as dreams are made on.

title: News Without Fear
description: New York State's amendment to the civil rights law by protecting the right of journalists to seek, write and broadcast news without fear of subjecting their sources and themselves to harassment by Government agenciesis, at the same time, a vital assurance that the news itself will be pursued and published for the public. Implicit in a free press is not simply privilege but the broader principle of the people's right to know.

title: C. A.B. Action Awaited on PlaneShip Cruises
description: TAMPA, FLA.  Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, gave hope here recently for a nonlegalistic decision on cases be fore the board involving airlines that have purchased ship lines and intend to operate combination airship cruises.

title: A World In Flames
description: Here is an account of World War II from beginning to end, encompassing the invasion of Poland and the RussoFinnish War, the Sitzkrieg and the Blitzkrieg, the Battle of Britain and Hitler's attack on his ally Russia, Pearl Harbor and the

title: Article 9  No Title
description: BARBARA SCHAECHTER, Newton Cen tre, Mass., writes that the passage by Karl Menninger queried by C.J.C. on April 5 is the opening sentence of the first selection in a collection of his writ ings A Psychiatrist's World. The se lection, entitled Take Your Choice, originally appeared in This Week maga zine, Oct. 16, 1949.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: THE extensive turmoil and deep gloom that have en veloped the financial markets for several months continued last week with increasing intensity.

title: To Plant,
description: APOND or a brook pool where the water runs warm, can be spruced up with waterlines. Hardy and tropical waterlines and other aquatic plants are available in exotic shapes and colors. I planted a garden of lilies in a backedup section of a brook that runs near my New Hampshire garden. Blooms appear from June until early fall.

title: CoinOperated Device Ending TennisCourt Time Arguments
description: Those tennis players who hog the courts and keep telling others, Wait, we're in the last set, are about to be crushed.

title: OTTINGER SAYS U.S. LETS CRIME GROW
description: Representative Richard L. Ot tinger, a candidate for the Dem ocratic nomination for United States Senator, called on the Federal Government yesterday to provide at least $3billion annually for the fight on crime.

title: KILLEBREW BELTS HIS 11TH OF YEAR
description: MILWAUKEE, May 16 (AP) Home runs by Tony Oliva, Harmon Killebrew, Rod Carew and Brant Alyea sent the Min nesota Twins to an 117 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers today. The triumph put the Twins in first place in the American League's Western Division, 10 percentage points ahead of California.

title: Fast Music Takes Sprint By 3 Lengths at Tropical
description: MIAMI. May 16 (AP)Fast Music captured his second stakes of the summer meeting today with a 3length vic tory in the $7,500 Florida Keys Handicap at. Tropical Park.

title: AL UNSER TAKES POLE FOR INDY 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 16AI Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., who has been the hottest shoe in the last two weeks of prac tice, won the pole position this afternoon for the 54th running of the Indianapolis 500 on Me morial Day.

title: KELLEY SETS MARK IN STEEPLECHASE
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 16 (AP)  Indiana, scoring heavily in The sprints and weight events, won its first Big Ten outdoor track and field title in 13 years today.

title: U.S.MEXICO FORCE BREAKS DRUG RING
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) The Justice Department said today that Mexican and Ameri can agents had broken up al major narcotics smuggling operd ation that had been supplying illegal drugs to the United States for 15 years.

title: Authors' Query
description: I am preparing an annotated checklist of Utah and Mormon diaries, and would appreciate hearing from anyone who knows of such diaries, many of which are still in private pos session.

title: Martha Beard Plans Nuptials
description: RYE, N. Y., May 16Mr. and Mrs. Josephus Simmons Beard 2d have anounced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Martha Lyndley Blaine Beard, to Peter Will liam Retchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Retchin of Greenwich. Conn.

title: The Choice Is Limited
description: American troops advance in Cambodia! Bomb North Vietnam! Four students killed at Kent State! Oil slicks imperil Florida coast! Atomic wastes pollute inland waters!

title: Revolt in Chad Drags On Despite Help by French
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, May 10 In parched desert lands near the center of Africa, French soldiers are fighting Moslem nomads in a battle that some describe as neocolonial ist and others call legitimate foreign aid. The guerrilla insurgency has dragged on for years, and the lack of French progress has contributed to demands in Paris for a quick withdrawal.

title: 4 MARINES FACING TRIAL IN 16 DEATHS
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 16 (AP)The United States Marine Corps said today that it would try four young marines for murder in the deaths of 16 Vietnamese civilians Feb. 19.

title: Article 3  No Title
Basketball Officials to Cite Moskowitz and Silverman
description: The Collegiate Basketball Of ficials Association will hold its spring meeting tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the Wheatley Hills, Tavern, 170 Post Avenue, West bury, L. I.

title: ISRAELIS ATTACK 2 EGYPTIAN CRAFT AT RED SEA BASE
description: JERUSALEM, May 16Israeli planes attacked and sank an Egyptian destroyer and a mis sile boat in the Red Sea this afternoon, in what was offi cially announced as a reprisal for two recent Egyptian blows.

title: U.S. in Land Accord With Pueblo Indians
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP)  The government an nounced yesterday a $6.1 million outofcourt settle ment of a 19yearold land claim brought by the Acoma Pueblo Indians of New Mexico.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Martha Beard Plans Nuptials
description: RYE, N. Y., May 16Mr. and Mrs. Josephus Simmons Beard 2d have anounced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Martha Lyndley Blaine Beard, to Peter Will liam Retchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Retchin of Greenwich. Conn.

title: In The Nation: But Does It Really Work?
description: WASHINGTON  Sporadic violence is still breaking out on some college campuses, and once again, at Jackson State wanton shooting by the forces of law and order has unnec essarily taken students' lives. But it is now clear that the primary response of students to the Cambodian invasion and the student deaths is not in the streets. They have returned to the system. even to the old politics, with a vigor and in genuity that has astonished many politicians. So a major question now is what the re sponse will be from the system.

title: North Dakota Dam Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) A $20million darn and reser voir on the Sheyenne River in North Dakota was recom mended to a Senate Public Works subcommittee by Army Engineers Wednesday as a pro ect to provide flood control, water quality control and recreation.

title: KANSAS CAPTURES BIG 8 TRACK TITLE
description: LAWRENCE. Kan., May 16, (AP)Mel Gray staged one of the greatest oneman perform ances in Big Eight track history today, but the Missouri foot ball star could lift his school no higher than fourth place as Kansas streaked to its fourth straight outdoor title.

title: Why Did Matisse Have to Wait?
description: HOMMAGE a Ma tisse: the French like their pomp and circumstance more than most, and especially so in the name of culture. The third of the big Grand Palais oneman shows is devoted to France's own, native artist hero  after Picasso and Chagall. Those two are still alive and active. Matisse died in 1954 and we all hold him in such high regard that it's obvious to ask why he has had to wait till now.

title: Beyond screaming
description: Here is one of those novels in which a crowd of charac tertypes is stranded on an is land in order to demonstrate that civilization is just a frag ile shell. The island this time is Greek; a vague world cata clysm (a rain of gray dust) gets the plot going; and the game of survival which sus tains the narrative quickly be comes a war between the local villagers and a representative assortment of tourists and ex patriates. By the end of the book the foreigners are all dead, the villagers have become prosperous pagans, and the reader has supped full of atroc ities. is Greek; a vague world cata clysm (a rain of gray dust) gets the plot going; and the game of survival which sus tains the narrative quickly be comes a war between the local villagers and a representative assortment of tourists and ex patriates. By the end of the book the foreigners are all dead, the villagers have become prosperous pagans, and the reader has supped full of atroc ities.

title: A Promise of Greatness
description: IT is now exactly 10 years since the English sculp tor Anthony Caro em barked upon the series of large, openform, painted steel constructions that have earned him a worldwide re nown. At the age of 46, Mr. Caro stands today all but un rivaled as the most accom plished sculptor of his gen eration. He is unquestionably the most important sculptor to have come out of England since Henry Moore. As both an artist and a teacher, he has wielded a considerable influence in a very short time not only in England but in this country as well. If he continues on his present course, adding distinction and eloquence to an already powerful oeuvre, he must cer tainly be counted among the great artists of his time.

title: Martha Beard Plans Nuptials
description: RYE, N. Y., May 16Mr. and Mrs. Josephus Simmons Beard 2d have anounced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Martha Lyndley Blaine Beard, to Peter Will liam Retchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Retchin of Greenwich. Conn.

title: Opera Today Opera's Future?
description: A CONSTANT subject for discussion, debate or even wrangling these days is the direction in which opera is headed. Some say it isn't headed anywhere, it's dead. Others believe it is slowly ossifying and will die. As long as there are good singers around, the vocal buffs cry, there's nothing wrong with it. A few think that good composers, sticking to tradition, will keep it alive.

title: Cannibal charade
description: Ancient and Modern starts with a camera crew shooting a film on the promenade of a small seaside town. The town, we learn, is meant to reflect our world. The characters sometimes play assigned roles in the script; sometimes they sit back, a passive audience.

title: Virginia Girl Is Picked Miss U.S.A. in Florida
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 16 (AP)Miss Virginia, Debbie Shelton, a brunette from Nor folk, was named Miss U.S.A. tonight over 50 contestants from across the land. The winner will go on to the Miss Universe pageant in July, hoping to succeed to the in ternational beauty title. Miss Shelton, a 5 foot 8 student at Old Dominion University, is 21 years old, with measure ments of 392436.

title: S. L. Babcock and Mrs. Austern Marry
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Mrs. Hope Sinauer Austern and Stephen Lee Babcock, lawyers, were married here this morning at the home of the bride by the Rev. Wil liam Gardiner, a Unitarian minister.

title: Disorders Spur Larger College Security Forces
description: Student political upheaval and rising campus crime rates have brought about a signifi cant expansion of security police at colleges and univer sities across the country with in the last few years, accord ing to college officials.

title: Miss Jane Arena Wed To Arthur Brown 2d
description: Miss Jane Therese Arena and Arthur Voorhees Brown 2d were married here yester day aftenoon in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Paul C. McKenna.

title: Jennifer McWilliams Bride of B. B. Ellison
City Seeks Battleship
description: MARTINEZ, Calif, May 16 This San Francisco Bay area port city, wants to have the battleship Missouri brought here and established as a national monument. Resolutions were in troduced in both houses of the California Legislature Monday at Sacramento calling on the Navy to turn over the 45,000 ton ship, scene of the 1945 sign ing of the World War It peace treaty with Japan. She is in mothballs at Bremerton, Wash.

title: Louis Kreek Jr. to Wed Miss Schoepfle
description: KENT, Ohio, May 16Dr. George Kern Schoepfle, chair man of the physics depart ment at Kent State Univer sity, and Mrs. Schoepfle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwendo lyn Schoepfle, to Louis Fran cis Kreek Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kreek of Washington. The wedding is planned for Sept. 12 at the United Church of Christ here.

title: Andalusia, the Cradle of the Great Discovery
description: HUELVA, Spain  The Columbus Coast, as the natives call this area along the Gulf of Cadiz, is authentic Andalusia. It is away from towering concrete and in stant flamenco, it has miles of quiet beaches and it boasts enough history and legend to satisfy the most inquisi tive mind.

title: Doctor to Wed Dr. Jane Haher
description: EAST WILLISTON, L. I., May 16Mr. and Mrs. J. Kenneth Haher have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Jane Nancy Haher, to Dr. Robert T. Walsh Jr. of Elizabeth N.J.

title: ST. LOUIS GOLF LEAD SHARED BY 2 WOMEN
description: ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP)  Jo Ann Prentice missed a six loot putt on the final hole today to drop into a tie with Kathy Whitworth for the secondround lead in the $20,000 St. Louis women's professional golf tour nament.

title: The Harried Leisure Class
description: Staffan B. Linder's witty and sophisticated tract amounts to a refreshingly subversive as sault upon one of his profes sion's best nourished sacred cowsthe benefits of economic growth. With such honorable exceptions as E. J. Mishan in England, J. K. Galbraith in this country and Linder, who teaches in the Stockholm School of Economics and is a Member of the Swedish Parliament, economists have generally held that economic welfare increased whenever percapita national income got bigger. Harry John son's position, as quoted by the author, exemplifies his peers' language and conclusions: The argument . . . leads to the com forting conclusion that the fact of wantcreation does not in validate the assumption that an increase in national income carries with it an increase in welfare.

title: Stock Slump Cuts Resales Of Coops
description: BUYER resistance is caus ing some erosion in the resale price of Man hattan cooperative apart ments in a market that has fallen off substantially in volumeover the last several months, a number of real estate men report.

title: CARLO MORELLI DIES; EXBARITONE AT MET
description: Carlo Morelli, a former bari tone of the Metropolitan Opera Company, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Mexico City, where he had lived for the last 21 years. His age was 72.

title: The Vietnamese And Their Revolution
description: Can the general public be persuaded to read yet another book about Viet nam? John T. McAlister Jr., a Prince ton political scientist and Vietnam veteran, hopes so; and the hope gives him a chance to pay rather fervent homage to his late mentor, the French archeologist and anthropologist Paul Mus.

title: The Farm Boy and The Angel
description: Whatever unbelievers may think of the theory of the Church of Jesus Christ of Lat terday Saints, the Mormon community is astonishing. Its history is a drama embedded in the American epic. Much has been written about the Mor mons, by their own chroniclers, by enemies and by those at tempting objectivity.

title: Vietnamese Reds Enter Key City Near Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 16Kompong Charn, Cam bodia's second city, northeast of here on the Mekong River, was in imminent danger tonight of falling to North Viet namese and Vietcong forces.

title: That New Black Magic
description: SOUL defined is soul necessarily mis understood. The term brooks no interpretation. Not really. To com mandeer a phrase offered in an other context, if you have to ask what is (what it costs), you can't afford it. Soul, in that regard, is expensive. In America, one pays for it in very specific human terms, and much more often than not  nearly always  the rate of ex change is Blackness.

title: The New Shows
description: WHAT THE BUTLER SAW, a comedy by Joe Orton, got five favorable, one un favorable and three mixed reviews. Clive Barnes: In common with all of Orton's work, this is a black come dy of mannersfunny, out rageous and almost terrify ing in its anarchistic acceptance of logic as a way of life. It is a wonder fully verbal play, toying with words as if they were firecrackers, and sentences as if they were bombs. Of all his plays, I'm inclined to think What the Butler Saw is the most riotously funny. The play has its rough momentsI believe it was not its final draft at Orton's deathbut as a whole it dazzles. Joseph Hardy is to be congratu lated for the cool and classic approach of his staging, which makes this by far the most successful Orton production seen in New York. Laurence Luck inbill has just the right approach to the belea guered psychiatrist; Jan Farrand is equally comical ly adept, and Diana Davila, Lucian Scott, Tom Rosqui and Charles Murphy all Jones, pleased eight of the nine critics who reviewed it, although two had reser vations. Clive Barnes: I forget when it was that I first read Colette, but I know I instantly fell in love with her. In Miss Cald well's performance I can see just what it was that made me adore this writer. Miss Caldwell is a delight and her performance, cal culatedly and neatly stagy, is a privilege to watch. What of the play? The play starts strongly enough, but in the second act the chaos of too many succeeding years takes command. The first act sounds like a biog raphy, the second like a scurried digest. Gerald Freedman has staged the show with a sense of pe riod not impaired by a very clear sense of reverence for his subject. It is Miss Caldwell's show, but she is surrounded by an unusual ly good cast. Mildred Dun nock is marvelous as Colette's mother and Charles Siebert, Barry Bost wick and Keene Curtis also scored. As a dramatic mas terpiece, Colette,' with all its lovely virtues, does not reach first base. Yet its lovely virtues warm the heart. Dear Miss Caldwell. Dear Colette.

title: Field Of Travel
description: AN antique is an antique when it is 100 years old, according to a re cent ruling by the Bu reau of Customs, Prior to this latest directive, the cus toms people would waive duty only on items manufac tured prior to 1830. For rugs and carpets, the date was 1701; for violins, voiles, vio lincellos and double basses, 1801.

title: ITALIAN REGION A RED SHOWPLACE
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, May 14 This is the most interesting place in all of Western Eu rope, a high Government of ficial said of the prosperous region of EmiliaRomagna. Here, Communism is not pro test. It is power.

title: Lady and the Tiger
description: I LIKE to think of mont bretias and tigridias as the lady and the tiger of summer  blooming bulbs.

title: Expected Return of Gulf Oil to B olivia Poses Problem for Regime
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 10 The Bolivian military Govern ment, beset by mounting eco nomic and political problems since it seized power here last Sept. 26, is bracing for a new test.

title: When Zoe Is Good, She Is Very, Very Good, But...
description: WHEN Zoe Caldwell is good in Co lette she is very, very good, and when she is less good she is florid. The line between the two is thin because Miss Caldwell is, by nature, a magnetic overdose of an ac tress, equipped with double everybody else's machinery. Her voice, to begin with. She does not have to project her voice into the auditori um, on principle, with prac tice. She simply opens her mouth and a high wind pass es through her, instantly reaching the far brick walls of the Ellen Stewart Theater, whistling through its crev ices, and echo.

title: PIPING ROCK TEAM INTERCLUB CHOICE
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches that have been taking place for the last three weeks over 148 district courses with 600 women playing were completed last Tuesday. Before closing out these interclub matches, however, the winner of Series I in all districts must play off for the Metropolitan team title.

title: Lefkowitz Sets Up Division Of Environment Protection
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday the establishment in his office of a division of environ mental protection that will take legal action against mu nicipalities, individuals and companies found to be polluting water or air.

title: News of Camera Doings
description: THE Eastman Kodak Company, in coopera tion with the Univer sity Film Foundation, has just announced its 1970 Kodak TeenAge Movie Award Contest for all youngsters 12 to 19. Any 8mm, super 8 or 16mm film on any subject may be entered in one of four stegories: Junior, for super 8 and 8mm films, ages 12 throught 15: Senior for super S and 8mm films, ages 16 through 19; OneReeler, for super 8 and 8mm, ages 12 through 19, single 50foot reels: Sixteen, for all 16mm films, ages 12 through 19. Prizes will vary from $25 to $150, plus one grand prize, a sixweek summer scholarship to the University of Califor nia. Requests for entry forms should he sent to: Kodak Teenage Movie Awards, Dept. 8.10F. Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, N. Y.

title: Dickens and Wordsworth
description: ROSALIND Dease de signed the block of four 5pence stamps that Britain will re lease June 3 to commemorate the death of Charles Dickens (reported here last week). Miss Dease also designed a fifth stamp that will be issued the same day, a 1 shilling 6 pence stamp commemorating the bicentennary of the birth of William Wordsworth. All commemorative Literary An niversaries set will be multi colored, from the photogra vure presses of Harrison & Sons, the British stamp print ers.

title: MUSKIE IS FIRST IN SPEECH PROFIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine topped all Senators with earnings from speeches and writings last year with a total of $80,183  almost twice as much as his salary as a Senator.

title: Guidebook for Congress
description: The ethical standards of Congress have risen impres sively since the days when members regularly repre sented clients in the courts and Daniel Webster, a prime mover of financial legislation, could complain to a private bank that his retainer had not been refreshed as usual. But the recent record shows that these standards have a long way to go before reaching the level proposed in an independent study just issued by a special committee of the New York City Bar Association, chaired by Louis M. Loeb.

title: Martha Beard Plans Nuptials
description: RYE, N. Y., May 16Mr. and Mrs. Josephus Simmons Beard 2d have anounced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Martha Lyndley Blaine Beard, to Peter Will liam Retchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Retchin of Greenwich. Conn.

title: Martha Beard Plans Nuptials
description: RYE, N. Y., May 16Mr. and Mrs. Josephus Simmons Beard 2d have anounced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Martha Lyndley Blaine Beard, to Peter Will liam Retchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Retchin of Greenwich. Conn.

title: Roxon's Rock: From A (Acid) to Z (Zombies)
description: LIKE Oscar Wilde, what she writes is but a pale imitation of what she says: her life is her art, man. She has a rare wit, Muhammad All reflexes, and an insatiable craving for ex perience at whatever the cost. She s the mistress of the putdown and the send up, the comeon and the comeuppance, the double faced aboutturn and the blunt, uncompromising insult. She blurts out what she thinks with impossible, cal culating honesty, reels off aphorisms, bon mots and sa lacious insights like a virtu oso, and treats life as an ex ercise in instant improvised Drama, a hairy Happening.

title: DEMOCRATS SPLIT IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 16  Four years ago Milton J. Shapp, millionaire Philadelphia busi nessman, bucked the Democrat ic organization and upset its choice for Governor, Robert P. Casey, in the Pennsylvania pri mary election. He hopes to do so again Tuesday in what has been a bitter rerun of that con test.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, May 17, 1970

title: Poisons Kill Fish in Missouri
description: TROY, Mo., May 16Deadly poisons filled an estimated total of 349,000 fish in Crooked Creek and almost wiped out about seven miles of the stream, the State Conservation Depart ment reported Monday. A chlor dane and malathion solution had been dumped into a drain age ditch near the creek. The source of the poisons was not known, the state authorities said.

title: Bell and Pierson Sign With Jets for '70 Season
description: Two more draft choices of the New York Jets have agreed to contract terms, Weeb Ewbank, head coach and general manager, has an nounced. They are Ed Bell, a wide receiver, and Bill Pier son, a center.

title: Industry, Spending To Fight Pollution, Faces Dislocations
description: American industry, frequent ly castigated for not doing enough about pollution, is plan ning to spend more than $2 billion this year to clean the environment.

title: SPORTS EDITOR'S MAILBOX
description: Holman Taught Holzman

title: The Market's Gloomy, but Parties Aren't
description: Until Friday, the stock market kept sliding, and everybody said they were plunged in gloom but life must go on. And it follows, as Bull does Bear, that when there is life in New York, there are parties for worthy causes and sig nificant events.

title: Scholars' Federation Issues PostDoctoral Fellowships
description: The American Council of Learned Societies has awarded 40 fellowships for periods of six months to one year. The awards are for postdoctoral research in the humanities and social sciences.

title: Canadians Discuss Monetary Shift
description: OTTAWA  Although Ca nadian officials insist, con vincingly, that they have ab solutely no interest in the idea, some monetary students here believe that now would be a good time for Canada to let the Canadian dollar fluctuate through a wider range in international cur rency dealings.

title: Dance
description: HOW long, I wonder, can we continue with the monolithic mod ern  dance company.

title: FiveRun Rally in Eighth Erases 32 Detroit Lead
description: The Yankees, after moving into second place in the American League's Eastern Division Friday night, spotted the Tigers a 30 lead and then won, 74, yesterday in a game played in a constant drizzle and chill winds.

title: DEMOCRATS SHIFT NATIONAL STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) A complete reorganization of the Democratic National Committee staff designed to be more geared to the technology of the 1970's was announced today by Lawrence F. O'Brien, the party's chairman.

title: Education
description: During a climactic scene in Good By Mr. Chips, the old teacher continues intrepidly with the reading of a Latin text about war in another age as German bombs shake the class room. He is proud that neither fear nor crisis interferes with the business at hand.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MAY 17, 1970

title: Labor Official Urges Nation To Help Nonwhite Workers
description: CHICAGO, May 16 (AP)A Labor Department official says the nation's leftout workers must have relief from economic discrimination.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayHollandia Farms, Mo riches Road. St. James, L. I. Green. regular, junior and ama teurowner working hunters; open jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Is Everyone Going to St. Ives?
description: ST. IVES. EnglandThe answer to this old Mother Goose rhyme has puzzled children for centuries. But there are times on a warm summer afternoon in St. Ives, when the wind sweeps in from the sea and the fishing boats bob up and down in the harbor, that you'd swear the whole kit and caboodle of them were on their way here.

title: PROXMIRE TO FACE SPORTS EXECUTIVE

description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI)The Veterans Admin istration reports that home fi nancing benefits for 2.1 million World War II veterans would expire July 25.

description: Msgr. James R. Searson, di rector of the Catholic Center of New York University, was named yesterday as acting president of Notre Dame Col lege on Staten Island.

title: U.S. Riders Place 9th, 10th In Jumping at Wiesbaden
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, May 16 (AP)Joe Fargis, on Dante and In My Cap, placed ninth today to be the top United States rider in the two horse jump at an International equestrian tournament.

title: EDITORS' GROUP HEAD IS JOINING COLUMBIA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 (AP)Norman E. Isaacs, out going president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and editor and vice president of The Louisville Courier Jour nal and The Times, is retiring from active newspaper work to help operate a newspaper work shop at Columbia University.

title: European Notebook
description: To celebrate his 75th birth day on March 31, Jean Giono, one of France's leading writers, proved his creative vigor by publishing L'Iris de Suse (Gallimard), a story of bandits and herdsmen. It opens in the spring of 1904 with the flight of Tringlot, a former convict and a member of a criminal gang from Toulon. Having hid den away money and jewels the loot of recent robberies he fears the vendetta of his companions and takes refuge in the Provencal mountains There he joins shepherds who lead big flocks of sheep to the high pastures. In the wilder ness Tringlot relives his recent holdups and murders in his imagination. But gradually his rowdy past seems to recede and dissolve. The peace and beauty of nature strangely af him.

title: The Wild Azaleas Grow In Home Landscapes
description: IN May and June the east ern mountains, upland valleys, moist woods and swamps glow with azalea bloom. The little Rhodora spreads its leafless, purple pink butterflyblooms in damp New England nooks and pinxterbloom casts a rosepink glow over dry rocky woods and swamp bor ders. In the south, there is the orange of the flame azalea blinding with the deli cate rosy tones of the pink shell. Latest to bloom is swamp honeysuckle which opens its fragrant white or pinktinged flowers in July.

title: Irishmen Seize Castle And Schedule FishIn
description: LISMORE, Ireland, May (AP)Thirty Irishmen seized Lismore Castle, owned by an English Duke, tonight and an nounced plans for a public fishin at his private sal mon stream. The estate's nor mal charge for fishing rights is $480 a day.

title: Bushtype Summer Squash
description: NEXT to tomatoes, sum mer squash are my favorite vegetable for the small plot. Most modern varieties have com pact bush growth rather than sprawling vines.

title: Alumina Maker Sets Expansion
description: MONTREAL(UPI) Queensland Alumina, Ltd., a large Australian alumina producer, will spend $150 million (Canadian funds) for the third stage of its expan sion program designed to raise capacity by nearly 57 per cent. Alcan Aluminum, Ltd., one of four partners in the venture, said the third stage would bring capacity to 2,240,000 tons a year when completed in mid1972. It takes two tons of bauxite to make one ton of alumina and two tons of alumina to make one ton of aluminum.

title: GREECE OPENS DRIVE TO LIMIT IMPORTS

title: Home Improvement

Their lighter weight makes them much easier to handle, and there is little or no main tenance to worry about (alu minum does not need a pre servative coating, nor does it need protection from the weather).

Young, of any further authority or respocsi bility in the decision whether to rehire Angela Davis, a con troversial philosophy instructor.

description: JERUSALEMIt was David Ben Gurion, among others, who said that Israel could win and win and still lose everything with her first de feat, while the Arabs could lose and lose and win every thing with their first victory.

title: 4 Held in Theft From U.S.

They work in the branch that opens and processes more than 10.000 mail orders for publica tions daily.

description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 16 (AP)President Nixon to day nominated John G. Hurd, a member of an oil and cat tle investment company in Texas, to be United States Ambassador to South Africa.

description: JUST a few years ago the turnof thecentury apartment building in which I live was a typically de pressing lowmiddleincome rentcon trolled house. description: DETROIT, May 16Sure, a lot of workers feel Nixon should have gone to Congress before the Cambodia thing. But they go right back to supporting the President when they see what's happening on the campus.

title: Art: Anything The Artist Says It Is?
description: BILL BOLLINGER is one of those new a tists including Alan Sar et, Rafael Ferrer, Bar ry Le Va and, occasionally, Robert Morriswho make sculpture out of formless or readyformed materials variously strewn, stacked, jumbled or jerrybuilt, there by carrying to new heights the Duchampian proposition that art is anything at all the artist says it is. One such new height is the 19th floor of the StarrettLehigh Build ing, a massive structure on the waterfront at 601 West 26 Street, the site of Bollinger's current show. The artist has artfully cluttered the place with 20 freeform works which will be dismantled, probably forever, when the show closes later this week. For sale are only xeroxed photographs of the pieces and one edition of ready made components which the buyer is to assemble as he sees fit.

title: Monica Cavanagh Is Married To Jose Juan Cebrian, Artist
description: EAST NORWALK, Conn., May 16Miss Monica Gar van Cavanagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Cava nagh, was married here today at her parents' home to Jos Juan Cebrian Luengo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Juan Ce brian Garcia of Madrid. title: Texas Student Sets Mark In Winning Motorcycle Race

title: Buffalo Levies Sales Tax
description: BUFFALO, May 16 (AP)  The Buffalo Common Council has voted to impose a 1 per cent city sales tax effective Sept. 1. The action, taken Thursday, will raise the sales tax in the city to 6 per cent  3 per cent levied by the state, 2 per cent by Erie County and 1 per cent by the city.

title: Where to Go In a Wicked World
description: For many Americans, travel to some areas of the world poses a problem with significant political and ethical overtones. Simply stated, it is this: Should they support with their presence and their tourist dollarsa foreign nation with whose policies they are in profound disagree ment? To provide the reader with some possible guid ance, the Travel Section solicited the views of five writ ers. Their responses appear below.

About 40 institutions, known as Sea Grant colleges, have partici pated in the program so far.

title: Observer: Passions in Search of an Understanding
description: WASHINGTON, May 16At some point in the business of the New York construction workers last week a photogra pher took a picture that makes you wonder what's going on here. The workers are seen waving flags and fistsnear City Hall, says the caption which is routine demonstration stuff, but the odd thing is this sign which is being held up by several of them.

title: Still the Poles go on living, making love, rebuilding their countryand writing about
description: For more than 200 years Poland has lived between the hammer of Germany and the anvil of Russia, cloven by partition after partition, inflamed by insurrection after insur rection, molded by anguish, tribula tion and death. Still the Poles go on living, making love, drinking vodka oh yes, drinking vodka! and occa sionally and sporadically working to rebuild their wartorn country. They seem to be a people without incentive, their lives without luster, their spirits without hope. And yet, though over all of them hangs the pall of physical desolation and spiritual despair, the most interesting writing in Commu nist Europeincluding the Soviet Un ionhas emerged from postwar Po land. These three novels, newly trans lated into English by David Welsh, are an excellent introduction to con temporary Polish letters. In them one almost has a capsule history of the temper of Polish life in the past three decades.

title: Television
description: WHAT is the proper role of the Ford Foundation, partic ularly under such activists as McGeorge Bundy, president, and Fred W. Friendly, television consult ant, in public broadcasting? Essentially, the answer in volves both social considera tions and the distinctive chemistry of the two men in volved.

title: VICTORY MARGIN IS TWO LENGTHS

College were commissioned today as officers in the Navy and Marine Corps. The commencement was marked by military pride and flourishes.

title: 1971 Troop Pullout Urged
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., May 17 (UPI)  Representative Robert T. Stafford, Republican of Ver mont, called today for the withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam by the end of next year. Mr. Stafford, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, told the graduating class at the Univer sity of Vermont that Congress should restrict defense funds so that all combat units would be out of Vietnam by Christ mas, 1971.

title: Medical Dean Named By Columbia University
description: Columbia University an nounced yesterday that Dr. Paul A. Marks, a hematolo gist and authority on human genetics, would become dean of the faculty of medicine and vice president for medi cal affairs on July 1.

title: Revson Sets 2dDay Pace and Gains 18th Spot in Indy 500 LineUp
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 17  Peter Revson of New York, driving one of the bright orange cars representing the Britain based McLaren racing team, won the top position in today's qualifying for the Indianapolis 500.

title: Research Spending Heading for a Record
description: Research and development spending, which played a major role in landing a man on the moon in July, 1969, may reach a record this year.

title: Jailing Union Leaders
description: Albert Shanker, starting a twoweek jail term for leading the illegal school strike two years ago, has delivered himself of the usual blanket denunciations the Taylor Law prohibiting strikes by public employes. The fact, as Mr. Shanker well knows, is that the Taylor Law is by far the best state law anywhere the country for protecting the right of civil servants to unionize and for establishing impartial machinery to break deadlocks over wages or other issues without any necessity to strike. Just last month, a taskforceof the Twentieth Century Fund concluded a nation wide study of labor disputes in public employment by urging that all states create machinery comparable that guaranteed under the New York law.

title: NIGEL BALCHIN, 61, BRITISH NOVELIST
description: LONDON, May 17 (Reuters) Nigel Balchin, a former brigadier general in the British army who became a bestselling novelist, died in a nursing home here today at the age of 61.

title: TRACK BILL SIGNED BY ROCKEFELLER
description: ALBANY, May 17 (AP)  Governor Rockefeller signed without comment today legis lation that would help finan cially the New York Racing Association, which operates the Aqueduct, Belmont and Sara toga tracks.

title: Battle Waded to Preserve Georgian Dublin
description: DUBLIN, May 10Dublin is divided over the fate of its dwindling rows of tall Georgian houses.

title: Lake Carriers Elect Chief
description: The Lake Carriers' Associa tion has announced the elec tion of Vice Adm. Paul E. Trim ble, as president. Admiral Trim ble, scheduled to retire from the Coast Guard on June 30, will succeed Vice Adm. James A. Hirshfield, a retired Coast Guard officer and president of the group since 1962.

title: Brandeis Lauds Two Generations in Arts Awards
description: Two generations of artists were honored last night in the Whitney Museum as Brandeis University conferred its 1970 Creative Arts Awards Medals and citations in four fields: fine arts, literature, music and the theater arts.

title: SENATORS SCORED ON WAR BY AGNEW
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 Vice President Agnew and two heading Senate Democrats Staked out bitterly opposing po sitions today for a forthcoming Congressional challenge to pres idential power in foreign pol icy.

title: GONZALES DEFEATS LAVER, WINS $17,500
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 16 (AP)  Pancho Gonzales, the 42yearold tennis pro, posted a stunning victory over the top seeded Rod Laver of Aus tralia today in the $47,000 Howard Hughes champion ships.

title: TREND UNCERTAIN IN BOND MARKET
Heyerdahl's Papyrus Boat Embarks Anew
description: SAFI, Morocco, May 17 Eight men of different national ities left this harbor today bound for Central America in a frail little boat in a second attempt to prove that the an cient Egyptians could have reached the Caribbean 4,000 or 5.000 years ago.

title: Zambia Seeks Rise For Copper Output
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 17 More than $48million is to be spent at copper mines associ ated with the AngloAmerican Corporation of South Africa, Ltd., in Zambia to increase pro duction by 25 per cent in the next four years.

title: Maritime Law Unit Elects
description: The Maritime Law Associa tion of the United States has announced the election of John C. McHose of Los Angeles as president. The 71  year  old group has as its objective re forms and improvements in maritime law.

title: Yambrick Defeats Benham In New York A.C. Handball
description: Billy Yambrick of the St. Paul (Minn.) Athletic Club won the New York Athletic Club invitation handball tournament yesterday by defeating Dr. Claude Benham of the Norfolk (Va.) Y.M.C.A., 2115, 2110.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for the week follows:

title: RAIN, FOG CURTAIL SCHOOLS' REGATTA
description: A pelting rain, broken rigging and the absence of crews from three Long Island schools failed to keep the Metropolitan inter scholastic crew championships from being held yesterday.

title: LingT emcoVought Chairman Yields Post to a Dallas Banker
description: James J. Ling, who built an obscure electrical contracting concern into a $3billion con glomerate giant, stepped down yesterday as chairman and chief executive of LingTemco Vought, Inc., under pressure from creditors.

title: Dr. Rusk Honored by Club
description: SCARSDALE. N. Y., May 17 Howard A. Rusk, M.D., the director of the Institute of Re habilitation Medicine of New York University Medical Cen ter, received the Scarsdale Town Club Public Service Award for 1970 this afternoon. The award, conferred upon Dr. Rusk, a contributing editor of The New York Times, at con vocation ceremonies at the Scarsdale Junior High School is given to a past or present Scarsdale resident who has par ticipated in civic activities while a resident and has ren dered significatn public service in the professions, arts, busi ness, government or civic af fairs.

title: Arts and Letters' Racing Future Imperiled by Leg Injury
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 17 The racing career of Arts and Letters, 1969 horse of the year, appeared to be in jeopardy to day.

title: Books of The Times
description: I realized long ago that, despite all vows and efforts, I was never really going to swear off reading books about Nazi Ger many. So I'm not really surprised at how easily I tolerated the somewhat Teutonic writing style and Germanic determination to underline every point in Joachim C. Fest's The Face of the Third Reich. I

title: Neighborhoods: Many Puerto Ricans Realize a Dream in Soundview Area of the Bronx
description: Neighborhoods: Many Puerto Ricans Realize a Dream in Soundview Area of the Bronx

title: A Designer's Wife Has to Get Used to Losing the Furniture
description: ST. LOUIS There are times when I think we shouldn't treat our living room like a display window, where things are always changing, Joyce Suttle said. But that doesn't always make the parting with some of the objects created by her hus band, David, an architectur al designer, any easier for her.

title: Julie Heldman Beats Miss Bartkowicz For Tennis Crown
description: BRUSSELS, May 17 (AP) Julie Heldman of New York beat Peaches Bartkowicz or Hamtramck, Mich., 62, 61, ir the final of the women's sin files in the Brussels internation al open tennis tournament to day.

title: GEN. OSCAR W. KOCH
description: MARION, Ill., May 17 (UPI)  Brig. Gen. Oscar W. Koch, U.S.A., retired, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration hospital here. He was 73 years old and lived in Carbondale.

title: Vainglory on the Civilian Side
description: LONDONThe cause of the environment, for all its deep significance, has seemed some thing of a distraction in recent months. The moral disquiet of Americans about the Vietnam war was channeled into en vironmental protesttoo often into rather empty, abstract gestures instead of the specific, difficult, controversial pro grams really required to reduce the destruction of our sur roundings.

title: HEINZ HARTMANN, ANALYST, 75, DEAD
description: Dr. Heinz Hartmann, an in ternationally known psycho analyst and author, died yes terday of a heart attack at his summer home in Stony Point, N. Y. He was 75 years old and lived at 1150 Fifth Avenue.

title: POPE BIDS PRIESTS ALWAYS BE LOYAL
description: ROME, May 17Pope Paul VI ordained 279 young priests in an openair ceremony today and urged them to remain united with their bishops and never betray!

title: The Immigrant Captures Crown at Buffalo Show
description: BUFFALO, May 17  Wil liam T. McLachan's The Immi grant captured the open jumper stake tonight and won the championship with 16 points at the closing session of the Buffalo international horse show. The Immigrant was handled by Jim Elder, captain of the Canadian Equestrian Team.

title: Status of Bills in Congress
PUSHOVER DEFEATS SALEM IN JUMPING
description: ST. JAMES, L. I., May 17 Carol Hofmann, a former Uni ted States Equestrian Team star, dominated the open jump er division at the Hollandia Farms horse show today by riding both the winner and re serve champion.

title: JOHN J. M'ARDLE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 17 John J. McArdle, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion for the last 25 years, died at the Methodist Hospital here Friday of a heart attack. He was 62 years old, and had lived in Indianapolis for the last 12 years.

title: Students Turn to Politics in Effort to Change System
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17  Two years ago, when the na tion's college students propelled the Presidential campaign of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Jeannie Kemper could not have cared less. I was a home eco nomics major, she recalled the other day. All I worried about were recipes and parties.

title: Casasola Breaks 4 Marks On Way to A.A.U. Lift Title
description: BRENTWOOD, L.I., May 16 Gene Casa sola of the York (Pa.) Bar Bell Club established four records today in winning the 114pound class at the Amateur Athletic Union na tional junior weightlifting championships at the Brent wood Recreation Center.

title: Fete to Mark 21 Years Of Israeli Boys Town
description: Boys Town Jerusalem will mark its 21st anniversary at a dinner tomorrow at the Americana. Arnold Schwartz, an industrialist who is presi dent of Brooklyn's Brookdale Hospital Center, will be honored for his philanthropic activities in behalf of youth.

title: Yanks and Mets Rained Out; Orioles at Stadium Tonight
description: Steady morning rains forced postponement of yesterday's scheduled doubleheader be tween the Yankees and the De troit Tigers at Yankee Stadium. The Yanks won the first two games of the scheduled four game series and took over sec ond place in the American League's Eastern Division.

title: Aaron Gets Infield Single for 3,000th Hit, Then Caps It With 570th Homer
description: CINCINNATI, May 17 (UFO Hank Aaron joined eight Hall of Famers in baseball's exclu sive 3,000hit circle today when he had two singles and the 570th homer of his career but his historic day was marred as the Cincinnati Red swept a dou bleheader from the Atlanta Braves, 51 and 76 in 15 in nings.

title: What's Defeat Taste Like?
description: ALAMOSA, Colo. (AP)Don McKillip, who resigned as foot ball coach at Adams State Col lege to become director of ath letics at St. Mary's College in California, saw his teams win 116 games against 29 losses and four tics going back to Red Cloud, ??, High School.

title: POLICE SCORNFUL OF LEARY'S ORDER
description: City policemen interviewed at random responded with nearly unanimous hostility and scorn yesterday to Police Commis sioner Howard R. Leary's direc tive urging them to report in stances of corruption directly to him, District Attorneys or the city's Department of Investiga tion.

title: U.S. FIVE CRUSHES URUGUAY, 76 TO 39
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, May 17 (Reuters)  The United States, the Soviet Union and Brazil won secondround games in the world basketball championship finals today.

title: NEWSWEEK REPORTS ON LAIRD MESSAGE
description: Newsweek magazine report ed yesterday that Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird had sent a topsecret message to Gen. Creighton W. Abrams saying that the American pub lic would be impressed by the capture of highranking pris soners, major enemy headquar ters and arms caches in Cam bodia.

title: CELLO RECITAL GIVEN BY LOUIS RICHMOND
description: Louis Richmond, the cellist who gave a recital at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon proved to be curiously unequal in his accomplishments. As he performed sonatas by Beethoven (Op. 102, No. 2) and Barber (Op. 6) and shorter pieces by Schumann, Hindemith and Ben Haim, Mr. Richmond revealed that he had commendable in stincts for the interpretation of works in various staples, and that his bowing had the se curity, flexibility and authority to translate his ideas about phrasing, accent and dynamics into wellorganized musical patterns.

title: Hofheinz Satisfactory
description: HOUSTON, May 17 (AP) Rov Hofheinz, owner of the Na tional League Houston Astros, who entered a hispital on May 10, was reported in satisfactory condition today with what was described as a vascular dis order, or a stroke.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: MISSILE SITE WORK BY U.A.R.REPORTED ALONG SUEZ CANAL
description: JERUSALEM, May 17Mil itary sources here said today that the United Arab Republic had been attempting to build reinforced missile sites along the Suez Canal, where they could threaten what Israel re gards as an essential line of her defense.

title: HARVARD TRACKMEN DEFEAT YALE AGAIN
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 17  Harvard's track team splashed to its seventh con secutive outdoor victory over Yale, 9955, today in the rain.

title: TV Masks Burning Sauna
description: USALMI, Finland (UPI)A family here became so en grossed in watching a skiing event on television that the heating of their sauna went on unnoticed. After the televi sion show, they found their sauna house in ashes.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Teacher of the Year Named
description: Johnnie T, Dennis, chairman or the science department and physics and mathematics analy sis instructor at the Walla Wala, Wash., High School, was named yesterday as national teacher of the year, United Press International reported. Mr. Dennis was chosen by committee of educators in national competition sponsored by Lock magazine and the Council of Chief State School Officer.

title: TV Review
description: The persistence of history in repeating itself was illus trated last night in Lewis Freedom's superior produc tion of The Andersonville Trial, seen over the Public Broadcasting Service network (Channel 13).

title: JERSEYTAKESOYER 2 SEWAGE PLANTS
description: BOONTON. N. J., May 17 New Jersey's new state De partment of Environmental Protection has taken over oper ation of two municipal sewage treatment plants  one owned by Jersey City here and oneo Kearny's in Kearnyafter ob taining court orders.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In 1859, according to Cleon Jones, the warlike Daho meyans of West Africa overwhelmed the peaceable, farm ing Tarlcars and sold them into slavery. The Tarkars arrived in the lastknown shipload of slaves from Africa to the United States, and were shuffled among plantations and hidden in the forests north of Mobile, Ala., to avoid seizure by Federal troops.

title: 2 IRT Cars Will Get AirConditioning in Test
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chair man of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, an nounced yesterday that tests would be made in the sum mer of 1971 to adapt air conditioning to the smaller cars of the IRT rolling stock.

title: SUSPECT CHARGED WITH 35 BOMBINGS
description: A 41yearold man was charged yesterday with the bombings at the New York Pub lic Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue and 34 other buildings over a sevenmonth period. The police said the man described himself as a militant Puerto Rican nationalist.

title: 400 at Connecticut U. Promise To Aid in Cleanup After Strike
description: STORRS, Conn., May 17 More than 400 students and some professors at the Univer sity of Connecticut here, dis turbed by property damage done during the current strike, have pledged to help restore their campus.

title: Nixon Names I.C.C. Aide
description: KEY BISCAGNE, Fla., May 16 (UPI)  President Nixon nominated W. Donald Brewer deputy administrator of the Small Business Administration to fill a vacancy on the Inter state Commerce Commission.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE WINS SAIL HONORS
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 17American Eagle, R. E. (Ted) Turner 3d's converted 12 meter sloop entered out of Annapolis Y.C., won the Wing ed Foot trophy for the second year in a row today by placing first in the New York Athletic Club Y: C.'s 61st distance race, annually the season's first over night event on Long Island Sound.

title: CARDS DOWN CUBS ON PINCH HITS, 43
description: St. LOUIS, May 17 ( UPI)  Vic Davalillo, pinchhitter, tri pled home the tying run and scored the winning run on a pinch single by Leron Lee with two out in the seventh inning today to give the St. Louis Car dinals a 43 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Personal Finance: Consumer Help
description: Last year, in what has since become a landmark legal case, the city, suing for itself and for thousands of con sumers throughout the coun try, obtained an outofcourt settlement for $120million from five major drug compa nies charged with illegally fixing prices and overcharging Purchasers.

title: Panthers and the Law
description: The unusual narrative by the Federal grand jury on the Chicago police raid which killed two Black Panthers last December confirms earlier suspicions of a police shootin rather than a Panther shootout. The evidence adds up to a flagrant case of police violence, followed by deliberate official distortions. Moreover, the Chi cago police appear to have taken the offensive with the advice and consent of the Federal Bureau of In vestigation, thus strengthening the suspicion of politi cal persecution.

title: Mala Powers Remarried
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17 Mala Powers, the actress, was married here this after noon to M. Hughes Miller, president of Book Publishers Projects, Inc., in New York and former president of the BobbsMerrill Company, pub lishers. The Rev. John Hinkle performed the ceremony in the West Valley Unity Church.

title: LAWS TO TEST WAR ASKED IN 8 STATES
description: Bills have been introduced in at least eight state legislatures this year that are patterned after one passed by the Massa chusetts Legislature challeng ing the legality of the Amer ican war effort in Southeast Asia.

title: NASSAU WILL SPEED HEART ATTACKS CARE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Mav 17 A mobile cardiac care network that will provide aid within five minutes for Nassau County residents stricken with heart attack was announced last week by County Executive Eugene H, Nickerson.

title: Catching the Train
description: What had promised to be a rejuvenation of railroad passenger service in the United States now seems destined at best to preserve it in a curtailed but tidier form. The bill which was overwhelmingly passed by the Senate would turn the country's essential passenger lines over to a quasipublic corporation which, with only the meagerest financial support from the Govern ment, would be expected to turn trains into pleasant vehicles and deficits into modest profits.

title: Books, Old or Rare, Are Sold In Stealth on Moscow Sidewalk
description: MOSCOW, May 18  The tall, suntanned youth walked through the crowd, his right hand shaking nervously as it held in front of him a long outofprint volume of Boris Pasternak's poetry. His other hand clutched an American edition of a book on Russian icons:

title: Bannister Wins 7 Events And East Decathlon Title
description: EMMITSBURG, Md., May 17 Jeff Bannister, a 24yearold University of New Hampshire senior, won the United States Track and Field Federation East ern decathalon championship today at Mount St. Mary's Col lege.

title: Liguori Looks Forward to '72 After Glancing Back at Keino
description: The day before his 1,500 meter race with Kipchoge Keino, Marty Liguori borrowed a book from his 13yearold sis ter, Lynne. It was not a psy chological novel about African distance runners ur a study of the aesthetics of track and field, but a collection of poems and essays, including one by Francis Bacon on revenge.

title: San Francisco Commuters Shun Car Pool Campaign
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 The operators of the San Fran ciscoOakland Bay Bridge have spent nearly two months learn ing something sociologists have known for a long timecom muters who use cars hate to give them up.

title: Bishops Shun Brazil's Leaders During Assembly in the Capital
description: BRASALIA, May 17The Ro man Catholic bishops of Brazil began their annual assembly this weekend here at the seat of the military Government. The absence of any formal con tact between the bishops and the Government here underlined the Roman Catholic Church's growing role as a center of pas sive opposition to the regime.

title: PageIs Retains Sailing Title In SingleHanded Meet
description: SAYVILLE, L.I., May 17 Billy Pagels of the Wet Pants Association captured his second straight Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association singlehand ed championship today by out scoring 10 other skippers.

title: REP. CLIFFORD HOPE, 30 YEARS IN HOUSE
description: GARDEN CITY, Kan., May 17 (AP)Former Representa tive Clifford R. Hope, Repub lican of Kansas, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 76 years old.

title: Oarsman Unhurt in Crash
description: PERRYVILLE, Mo., May 17 (AP)Members of the Univer sity of Alabama, Huntsville Branch, rowing squad escaped serious Injury today when their bus was involved In a three vehicle accident on U. S. Route 61. One person was killed and 23 injured.

title: Reuther's Legacy for Social Stability
description: When Walter Reuther recov ered consciousness in a Detroit hospital in 1948 after surgeons had operated to save the arm shattered by a thug's shotgun blast, the union leader took his mind off the racking spasms of pain by focusing on the array of cords and pulleys that held his arm in traction.

title: Center to Aid the Retarded Dedicated at Einstein College
description: Dedication ceremonies for the Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy Center for Research in Mental Retardation and Human Devel opment were held yesterday in the Bronx.

title: South's Football Generals Joined by a Black Coach
description: BURLINGTON. N. C.,  When the Bulldogs of Walter Williams High School clasp hands before taking the field one Friday night next September, most of those hands will probably be white.

title: F.C.C., lN REVERSAL, VOTES TO EXPAND CABLE TELEVISION
