description: WASHINGTON, May 17In a policy shift that could radi cally expand the program choices on American television, the Federal Communications Commission has tentatively voted to permit virtually un limited importation of outof town programing on cable tele vision, or CATV, systems.

title: City Schools Will Counsel Students on Draft Options
description: The city's Acting Superintendent of Schools, Irving Anker, announced yesterday that he would establish soon la network of draft counselors to serve students in each the 92 high schools. The coun selors represent the first or ganized attempt by the city school system, the largest in the nation, to provide stu dents with information and advice on the military draft and its legal alternatives.

title: 2 JAZZ GROUPS SHOW DIVERGENT STYLES
description: Two jazz groups with strong but divergent stylesthe Tyrone Washington Quartet and a quintet called Messiahjoined forces in a concert at Judson Hall on Friday night.

title: Blacks Start Wide Protest On Police Killings in South
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 17 Angry Negroes have begun a broad protest, including forma tion of an armed defense league and a statewide boy cott of whiteowned businesses, because of the police killing of two black students here Thurs day night.

title: Army Comments
description: WASHINGTON, May 17An Army spokesman said today that the Army was aware of the requests of the two soldiers for particular legal counsel, but said he was not aware of a final decision on their requests.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MAY 18, 1970

title: HomeFurnishings Field Seeks Ideas to Spur Big Ticket Sales
description: A lot of soulsearching is go ing on in the home furnishings industry, where, as one retail executive put it, Things are worse than they were, but not as had as they had been.

title: EARLY A.B.A. VOICE ON COURT IS ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Attorney General John N. Mitchell was urged today by the American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judi ciary to consult with leaders of the legal profession in the fu ture before recommending per sons to the President for nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Harvey Is Marathon Victor; Muhrcke Second at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, May 17  Bill Harvey, a 27yearold New York City schoolteacher, won the Metropolitan Amateur Ath letic Union marathon cham pionship today. The race, in which 95 started and 60 fin ished, began and ended in front of the Chippewa Club in some times heavy rain.

title: U.S. Wares Shown in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 17 (AP) Sixtyfive United States man ufactures of goods for use in production and advanced equip ment are showing their wares here at the largest United States industrial exhibition ever held in the Middle East.

title: U.S. Feels Sihanouk's Bloc Includes Reds, Leftists, Neutralists and Guerrillas
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  A complex political organization comprising Communists, left ists, neutralists and leaders of the guerrilla group known as the Khmer Rouge is reported to be operating in Peking to help Prince Norodom Sihanouk regain power in Cambodia.

title: Bridge:
description: THE phenomenal success of Swiss team tournaments during the last year, at every level from club games to na tional championships, has generated a plan to have similar contests on a pairs basis. This is much more complex technically, and it remains to be seen whether it will appeal to players in the same fashion.

title: Briere Better After Surgery
description: MONTREAL, May 17 (AP) Michel Briere, rookie center with the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League, was reported in satisfactory condition today after undergo ing a 4hour operation for head injuries suffered in an auto ac cident Friday night.

title: PORSCHE IS FIRST IN BELGIAN RACE
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, May 17 (Reuters)Jo Siffert of Switzerland and Brian Redman of Britain thundered to victory today in the Francorchamps 1,000kilometer (650mile) race. The triumph gave the West German Porsches an unbeatable lead in the world manufactur ers championships.

title: H.E.W. Employes to Confront Finch With Criticism of His Actions
description: WASHINGTON, May 17A confrontation without known precedent will unfold here at 4 P.M. tomorrow when em ployes of a Cabinet depart ment call its Secretary on the carpet to account for his ac tions.

title: Robert Christopher Marries Miss Rita Goldstein, a Teacher
description: Miss Rita Goldstein was married here yesterday after noon to Robert C. Christo pher, executive editor of Newsweek magazine. The Rev. Chadbourne Spring per formed the ceremony in the chapel of the Community Church. A reception was held at the Yale Club.

title: Chess:
description: IN the last decade. Svetozar Gligoric, the Yugoslav mas ter and an 11time national champion, has finished near the top in every tournament in which he played. He has produced many stunning in dividual victories. None, how ever, was as amazing as his recent defeat of Tigran Petro sian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, in the 18man Tournament of Peace in Rovinj and Zagreb, Yugoslavia.

title: LONG ISLAND WINS IN LACROSSE, 1410
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 17  The Long Island Athletic Club's lacrosse team virtuously assured itself of the northern division title today by beating leagueleading New York, 14 10 in Hofstra Stadium. The victory was Long Island's fourth against club opponents and its 10th of the season. It has lost twice. New York has two losses in club competition against eight victories.

title: Royals Post 32, 84 Victories; Angels Win, 71, Then Bow, 65
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (AP)  Joe Keough's fourth hit of the game, a groundrule double, scored the winning run as the Kansas City Royals downed the Chicago White Sox, 32, today in 10 innings.

title: ASIAN GROUP ASKS INDOCHINA PARLEY
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 17  The Asian foreign min isters' conference on Cambodia called today for a reactivation of international peacekeeping machinery in Cambodia and for the early convening of a new international conference to resolve the conflict in In dochina.

title: MAINE DEMOCRATS VOTE ANTIWAR PLANK
description: PORTLAND, Me., May 17 Delegates to the state Demo cratic convention gave noisy approval last night to a strong antiwar plank in the party's platform after Senator Edmund S. Muskie discarded his prepared speech and spoke in support of the plank.

title: R. B. MARSTON, AIDE OF L. S. ROCKEFELLER
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., May 17Randolph B. Marston, who had been associated with Laur ance S. Rockefeller since 1941, died of cancer today at his home here. He was 61 years old.

title: TWINS WIN, 61, FOR 4TH IN ROW
description: MILWAUKEE, May 17 (AP)  Jim Perry pitched a six hitter and the Minnesota Twins exploded for five runs in the sixth inning today and defeat ed Milwaukee, 61, for theiqr fourth straight victory.

title: 3 Robbers Buy a Suitcase And Put Store's Money in It
description: CHICAGO (AP)  Three en terprising robbers walked into a South Side Chicago depart ment store, bought a suitcase and walked out with $21,000 of the store's receipts in it.

title: Christopher Wadsworth Weds Jenny Morgenthau
description: HOPEWELL JUNCTION N. Y., May 17The marriage of Miss Joan Morgenthau to Christopher D. Wadsworth took place this afternoon at Fishkill Farm, the country home of the Morgenthau fam ily here. Judge Sidney H. Asch of the Civil Court of the City of New York per formed the ceremony.

title: President Walks on Beach
description: GRAND BAY, Bahamas, May 17 (UPI)  President Nixon spent Sunday strolling on the white, sandy beach of this pri vate island and cruising on the Atlantic. He was the house guest of Robert H. Abplanalp, president of the Precision Valve Corporation, of Bronxville, N.Y. With Mr. Nixon over the week end were his soninlaw, David Eisenhower, 22 years old, and the President's friend and con fidant, Charles G. Rebozo of Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Balaguer ReElected President in Dominican Vote
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domin ican Republic, May 17Pres ident Joaquin Balaguer won reelection today to a second fouryear term by a wide margin over four opponents. The returns from yesterday's orderly election indicated that the Dominican Republic would continue under a conservative government backed by the military and business interests that responds to political un rest with repressive measures and is slow to adopt social reforms. Mr. Balaguer's vic tory total of 607,717 votes out 1,111,853 valid ballots cast was smaller than his winning margin in 1966, when he re ceived 750,000 votes against 499,000 for Juan Bosch, can didate of the leftofcenter Dominican Revolutionary party. The Revolutionary party abstained, contending that repressive police action and Mr. Belaguer's access to state funds for his campaign had made the election a fraud.

title: A Road Project Spurs Home for Wild Ducks
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 A home for wild ducks is a byproduct of the construc tion of Interstate Route 94 in westcentral Minnesota, the Federal Highway Ad ministration reports.

title: TUROK MUSIC MARKS TULLY HALL CONCERT
description: The audience for new, seri ous music. Paul Turok wrote two months ago, is infinite simally small. Nonetheless, he continues to compose it, and a reasonably goodsize audience turned out to hear it Friday night, at Tully Hall. The 40 yearold New Yorker, who has studied with, among others, Roger Sessions and Peter Men nin, was represented by two String Quartets, Three Songs for Soprano and Flute, and Three Transcendental Etudes for piano.

title: OPEN JUMPER LEAD TO THE IMMIGRANT
description: BUFALO, May 16The Im migrant, ridden by Jim Elder, longtime captain of the Can adian Equestrian Team, took a commanding lead for the open jumper championship at the Buffalo international horse show tonight when he won the time event.

title: SHIRLEY ENGLEHORN VICTOR BY 2 STROKES
description: ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) Shirley Englehorn broke out a flock of birdies to win the $22, 000 St. Louis women's open golf tournament by two shots with a final 68 for 216 today.

title: Cannes: A Festival in Quest of Films
description: CANNES, France  This Isn't a festival, the man said cheerfully, just before the film festival ended over the weekend. It's a wake, a big, happy French version of an Irish wake.

title: Braves' 3,000 Hitter
description: THE first name listed in the Baseball Register, a com pilation of the records of approximately 10,000 men who have played major league baseball in the last 100 years, is that of Henry Louis Aaron of the Atlanta Braves.

title: Collegiate Chorale Sings Haydn Mass At Philharmonic
description: The Collegiate Chorale sang one of Haydn's most interest ing choral works at Philhar monic Hall Friday night. It was the Mass in Time of War, which was composed in 1796 when Austria and France were battling each other. This Mass is neither mournful nor blatant ly militant, but it does have a certain solemnity about it, and Haydn's use of tympany is so pronounced and so expres sive that the work is some times called the Paukenmesse (Kettledrum Mass).

title: Mr. Wilson's Miracle
description: The right to call new elections at will, when the timing favors the party in power, is one of the most potent political prerogatives of a British Prime Min ister. A year ago, polls indicated Harold Wilson's popularity had sunk to the lowest level of any Prime Minister in recent history; his Labor party ran almost 25 per cent behind the Conservatives. Today the polls show Labor running 3.2 to 7.5 per cent ahead.

title: Jewish History Bibliography
description: The American Jewish Com mittee yesterday announced the publication of a 32page bibliog raphy, Writings on Jewish His tory, to overcome what it de scribed as a lack of information about Jewish cultural, spiritual and historic history in social science textbooks in high schools. Copies at 35 cents each are available at the national headquarters of the committee at 165 East 56th Street.

title: BLACKS LOOT STORES IN HOT SPRINGS, ARK
description: HOT SPRINGS, ARK., May 17 (UPI)Negroes rampaged through a predominantly black section of Hot Springs last night and this morning, hurling stones and bricks and smashing storefront windows from which they looted merchandise.

title: PADRES TRIUMPH OVER ASTROS, 53
description: SAN DIEGO, May 17 (AP) Steve Huntz and Chris Can nizzaro hit home runs and Ivan Murrell drove in three runs to day, helping the San Diego Padres beat the Houston Astros, 53.

title: Wash. State Senior Takes Mile in 3:59.2
description: LOS ANGELES, May 16 (AP)Rick Riley of Wash ington State ran the year's first sub4minute mile and U.C.L.A. scored 28 points in the last two events to retain its Pacific8 track champion shin today. The University of California, Los Angeles: fin ished with 111 points, heat ing Oregon, the leader after yesterday's events, by points.

title: 1 IN 4 IS ENROLLED IN MEDICAID HERE
description: Nearly one of every four persons in New York City was authorized to get help under the Medicaid program as of the start of this year1,903,810 persons, or 23.5 per cent of an estimated 8.110.000 residents.

title: 5 U.S. Cultural Centers Close on India's Orders
description: HYDERABAD, India, May 17  Late yesterday the heavy mahogany doors of the modern threestory building shut and a printed notice went up: Closed by orders of Government of India.

title: Looking for Salted Jellyfish?
description: RED bean flour and salted jelly fish. Dried bellflowers, ground shavings, seaweed. Sesame oil and relish. A hot sauce called Kochee Chang. Dried anchovies ranging from tiny (about a halfinch long) to large (2 inches). Rice dumplings filled with a red bean paste called An. Pickeld garlic, dried cut tlefish. Small packages of yel low rice and 50 pound sacks of small grained white rice. All these and many more exotic foods are on the shelves and in the freezer of a new Korean sup ermarket at 127 West 43d Street next door toand named forits parent, the Sam Bok restaurant.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Key to Market's Fall

title: 2 Songmy Defendants Call Army Unfair
description: ATLANTA, May 17 (UPI) Two soldiers facing a possible death sentence for charges re sulting from the alleged mas sacre at Songmy, South Viet nam, declared today that the Army machine was rolling over them in efforts to gain a conviction.

title: Cadwallader W. Kelsey Dead; Early Auto Maker and Dealer
description: GUILFORD, Conn., May 17 Cadwallader W. Kelsey, an early automobile builder who retired 10 years ago as presi dent of Rototiller, Inc., of Troy, N. Y., makers of rotary tillage machines, died here today after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: TEAMSTER ACCORD REPORTED BACKED
description: WASHINGTON. May 17 (AP)  A majority of the rank and file of the International Brother hood of Teamsters has ap proved a new nationwide con tract. an informed source said tonight.

title: International Group Begins Study to Predict Air Pollution Levels
description: PARIS, May 17Will Paris's air sting a stroller's eyes in 1980? Will dust storms still sweep west Texas? Will smoke hang over the Ruhr?

title: Pan Am Promotes Two
description: The promotion of two main tenance  engineering specialists to staff vice presidents has been announced by Pan American World Airways. They are Klein Mitchell and Norman S. Smith.

title: Tornado Toll Climbs to 23
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., May 16 (AP) A tornado that struck here last Monday claimed its 22d and 23d lives Saturday. Jos Luz Leyva, 14 years old, of Browns ville, who was visiting here when the twister struck, died shortly before noon. Earlier to day, Joe Garrett, 29, died of injuries he received when the tornado ?? his home.

title: Ireland Dodging Crackdown on Inflation
description: DUBLIN  The Republic of Ireland has run into serious in flationary problems, and the Fianna Fail Government seems reluctant to tackle them head on.

title: FARM COLLEGE FINDS FEW ENTER FARMING
description: ITHACA, N. Y. (AP)The number of graduates of the State College of Agriculture at Cornell University who enter farming has dropped substanti ally over the last 20 years.

title: A.B.A. Playoff
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Oil Boom Spurs Canadian Arctic Aviation
description: INUVIK, Northwest Terri tories, CanadaAviation is booming in the Canadian Arctic as the result of the current intense search for oil and against the background of controversy over whether the oil should be moved by pipeline or by icebreaker tanker.

title: One Boat Shows Upfor Race
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 16 Only one boat, Ole Skaarup's Soling Class sloop, Gosling, showed up off Belle Haven Club today for the scheduled open ing of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association cham pionship season for fleets based EastofRye. Gosling took an eightmile sailover for a shake down in a 12knot easterly. Conflict with other regattas and the fact that many boats are not yet in the water all but depleted the expected fleet.

title: Foreign Policy: New Issue in Old Fight
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee finds itself the vic tim of two centuries of Ameri can constitutional history in the current maneuvering over United States action in Cam bodia.

title: Conservative Democrats Feel Left Out in Gubernatorial Primary
description: One recent private poll on the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor showed that 35 per cent of the Dem ocrats questioned were still un decided. And the neighborhoods where voters tended to be un decidedover 50 per cent in parts of Brooklyn and Queens were lowermiddleincome, heavily Italian and Irish neighbor hoods that gave Mario A. Procac cino a majority in last year's mayor al election.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: A Brief for Injustice
description: The Justice Department now has openly joined the segregationist cause by backing the taxexempt status of the Southern private schools in Mississippi estab lished for the sole purpose of evading desegregation. With this latest move the Administration has dropped its mask of deceptive hedging; it is now the ally those white supremacists.

title: LOSER IN I.O.S, BID PUSHES OWN FUND
description: LONDON, May 17Hell has no fury like a woman scorned or, apparently, like a tycoon spurned.

title: Milwaukee Fans Cheer Aaron, Once T heir Star
description: MILWAUKEE, May 17 (UPI)They still remember Hank Aaron in County Sta dium here.

title: Centenarian Recalls Suffragette Days
description: MRS. SIGMUND POLLIT ZER doesn't feel old un til she remembers that her two daughters are over 70. Mrs. Pollitzer will celebrate her 100th birthday May 31.

title: Dart Throwers Aim at Fun and Fame
description: There were Dynamite Dale and Midnight Liz and the Brickleys from Dayton and the stewardess from T.W.A. Big John Benn came in from Detroit and the Star flew up from Ashville.

title: Professor Proposes Insurance Plan as an Antipoverty Measure
description: A plan for antipoverty in surance, in which subscrib ers would insure themselves against risk of income falling below a poverty line, has been proposed as a more efficient and cheaper alternative to President Nixon's welfare re form.

title: Personality to Seek New Glory In Jersey Derby and Belmont
description: BALTIMORE, May 17Per sonality, the star of the show, left this morning for his home grounds at Aqueduct. Mrs. Ethel D Jacobs's colt, who won the $203,800 Preakness Stakes yesterday by a neck over Ray mond Curtis's My Dad George, was vanned northward to gether with his stablemate, High Echelon, who finished fourth in the 13/16mile event.

title: Blancas Takes Colonial Golf With 67 for 273
description: FORT WORTH, May 17 (AP) Lee Trevino and Gene Littler failed to sink birdie putts on the final hole today, allowing Homero Blancas to take the $25,000 first prize in the $125, 000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament.

title: Georgia March Planned
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., May 17 The Rev. Ralph David Aber nathy announced today that a 100mile mass march would be conducted through Georgia's Black Belt to combat the growing repression of blacks and students in the state and in the nation.

title: 2,500Acre Hudson Tract Acquired as a State Park
description: A rugged wilderness tract of 2,500 acres has been put to gether as a state park on the east bank of the Hudson River, acquired with $1.5million in state funds and $1.5million in Rockefeller family programs.

title: SAMUELS ASSAILS GOVERNOR ON WAR
description: Howard J. Samuels charged yesnterday that Governor Rockefeller was resorting to election year hypocrisy if he did not take action to back his proposal to become the link be tween college students and President Nixon on peace and other national problems.

title: REFORM IS URGED IN U.S. BORROWING
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank suggested yesterday that basic institutional reform in the techniques the Treasury Department uses to borrow money may be required for the Federal Reserve to gain effec tive control over inflation.

title: Handball Title to Rochester
description: NEWARK, May 17Roches ter won the national team handball championship today by defeating the Newark Swim and Sports Club, 2612, at the College of Engineering.

title: MailOrder Marriage Is Out
description: SALEM, Ore. (UPI)  The state Attorney General has ruled that a mailorder minis ter is not entitled to perform marriages. To qualify, he said, a minister must be assigned to a church in the state.

title: BICYCLE STEALING MOUNTING IN CITY
description: Three men stood some dis tance from a bicycle chained to a tree on a quiet Greenwich Village street recently. The first man examined the bicycle and signaled an allclear. The sec ond man removed a pair of fold ing clippers from a paper bag and cut the locked chain, and the third quickly approached the bicycle and rode off.

title: The Cities: Police Role Shifting
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 Wes Uhlman, the young, mod Mayor of Seattle, was anxious. His police force felt it could handle a major peace demon stration not long ago. But then, two days before the march, the Justice Department indicted eight of the march leaders.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: It's almost like Puerto Rico, said Bertha Calo as she weeded her garden out side her $41,000 house at 1033 Underhill Avenue in the Soundview section of the Bronx. It's very quiet and pleasant here.

title: 1969 LOSS LISTED BY GENERAL HOST
description: The General Host Corpora tionwhich after a bitter fight won apparent control of Ar mour & Co. and then decided to sell itreported yesterday a $67.25million loss for 1969. Its transactions involving the Chi cago meat packer accounted for the loss.

title: Major Urban Renewal Set For Southeast Paris Area
description: Two hundred fifty acres of the Porte d'Italie section of southeastern Paris will he changed by an urban renewal project that includes office buildings, apartment towers and a commercial area, the magazine Architectural Recore reports.

title: MRS. M. F. UNTERMEYER
description: ELBERON, N.J., May 17  Mrs. Mary Kelly Untermeyer died today at here home, 900 Ocean Avenue. She was the wife of Milton F. Untermeyer, a member of the brokerage firm of Untermeyer & Carton, Inc., in Asbury Park, who is a former Mayor of Long Branch and now president of the Monmouth Ocean County Development Council.

title: TRADITION LOSES SWAY ON THE QE2
description: Midnight buffets and deck luncheons, either informal or gala, have been streamlined out of the operational pattern of the Cunard superliner Queen Elizabeth 2. The 65,863ton vessel completed her first year in transAtlantic and cruise service last week.

title: 2 INDICTED IN ATTACK ON SON OF CHIANG
description: Two Taiwanese accused of attempting to assassinate Chiang Chingkuo, Nationalist China's Deputy Premier, were indicted by a New York County grand jury yesterday on charges of attempted murder.

title: 10 Clashes Reported
description: SAIGON, May 18North Vietnamese soldiers ambushed American troops at four points in Cambodia and bottled South Vietnamese forces at six other locations yesterday according to military spokesmen, in what was termed the heaviest enemy resistance met thus far in the drive into Cambodia.

title: PLAYER BOYCOTT HITS PRINCETON
description: I think that what those 13 boys did at Princeton was out standing, declared Richie Mo ran, the Cornell lacrosse coach. They proved an excellent point that the athletic field is not a political arena.

title: Red Sox Pick Jensen To Manage Jamestown
description: BOSTON, May 18 (AP) Jackie Jensen, 43 years old, a former Boston Red Sox slugger who was the Ameri can League's most valuable player in 1958, was named today manager of Jamestown, the club's affiliate in the New YorkPenn League.

title: U. S. Aide Denies Protectionism
description: LONDON, May 18A Wash ington trade official denied to day that the United States was moving toward protectionism in an oldfashioned sense. But, he said, a few industries are going to have to be given special consideration.

title: N.C.A.A. Officials Expect No Threat to Title Tourneys From Campus Unrest
description: LEMPSTER, N. H.  There are times when trout in lakes and ponds refuse to hit, and there is nothing a fly fisher man can do to change this.

title: ARTHUR MANCHEE, STORE EXECUTIVE
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 18Arthur L. Manchee, former president of Macy's New York and chairman of L. Bamberger & Co., the department store, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Liv ingston. He was 70 years old and lived in Llewellyn Park.

title: G.M. STOCK PROJECT BARRED AT HARVARD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18 (AP)The president and fel lows of Harvard College re jected today proposals that the college's shares of General Mo tors stock be voted for two proposals made by an organi zation called the Project on Corporate Responsibility.

title: Dr. Rusk Honored by Club
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 17 Howard A. Rusk, M.D., the director of the Institute of Re habilitation Medicine of New York University Medical Cen ter, received the Scarsdale Town Club Public Service Award for 1970 this afternoon. The award, conferred upon Dr. Rusk, a contributing editor of The New York Times, at con vocation ceremonies at the Scarsdale Junior High School, is given to a past or present Scarsdale resident who has par ticipated in civic activities while a resident and has ren dered significatn public service in the professions, arts, busi ness, government or civic af fairs.

title: Witnesses Sharply Split Over Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)  Limitations on imports of foreign goods were de scribed today both as the sal vation of threatened United States businesses and the open ing guns in a destructive trade war.

title: BIG BOARD VOTES TO EXPAND FUND
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its board of governors had voted approval of constitutional amendments to permit the ex pansion of the exchange's Spe cial Trust Fund from $25million to $55million.

title: MOSCOW CHARGES MAO SEEKS RULE OVER ALL OF ASIA
description: MOSCOW, May 18The So viet Union today delivered a sharp attack on Communist China, accusing the Mao Tse tung leadership of seeking dom ination in Asia, of rejecting calls for concerted action in Indochina and creating an anti Soviet war psychosis at home.

title: WORKERS HARASS STUDENT PICKETS
description: Construction workers, hurl ing raw eggs and bags of water, pelted students demonstrating yesterday outside Board of Edu cation headquarters in down town Brooklyn.

title: Yevtushenko Honors a Girl Killed at Kent State
description: MOSCOW, May 18  Yev geny Yevtushenko, one of the Soviet Union's leading poets, published today a long poem dedicated to Allison Krause, a 19yearold girl from Pittsburgh who was one of the four stu dents killed at Kent State Col lege in Ohio May 4 when Na tional Guardsmen opened fire during a demonstration.

title: Snowball Meets Scandy And Is Barely Affected
description: The 5yearold Swede and the 6yearold American, each weighing about 700 pounds, looked at each other. He nar rowed his orange eyes. She growled furiously and the reconnoitering began.

title: The Threat of Violence
description: The terrible succession of official gunfire and death at Kent State University, Jackson College and Augusta calls for renewed determination at every level of public life to put an end to such fatal violence com mitted in the name of law and order.

title: South African Police Seize 150 Students in Protest
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, May 18 (Reuters)  The police arrested about 150 uni versity students among several hundred who staged a protest march here today against the continued detention of 22 blacks and other persons held without trial.

title: Press Card Robber Jailed
description: Henry M. Gehman, a former Columbia University student, was sentenced yesterday to seven days in jail for illegal possession of a. Police Depart ment working press card. Mr. Gehman, who was convicted on May 11, allegedly took a press card fgom Martin Gershen of The Newark StarLedger on April 1, 1968, during a demon stration at Columbia.

title: FLAGRAISING BRINGS DISPUTE DOWNTOWN
description: The management of the Wall Street Journal Building put out a flag yesterday in response to demands last Friday by con struction workers who were demonstrating in the financial district against Mayor Lndsay and students opposed to United States policy in Indochina. But the flagraising disturbed re porters and editors on the staff of the newspaper.

title: Raffaello and Tanker Collide in the Bay of Algeciras
description: LONDON, May 18 (UPI) The 45,933ton Italian lux ury liner Raffaello and the Norwegion oil tanker Cuya hoga collided today in Alge ciras Bay, opposite Gibraltar and the liner put into Gibral tar for repairs, the Italian line reported in London. It is expected to sail on Friday.

title: Skiers Hall of Fame Inducts Clair, Founder of L. I. Club
description: John J. Clair Jr., who found ed the Long Island Ski Club 34 years ago and who was chairman of the 1956 American Olympic team, received the Ski Hall of Fame Award last night at a reception held by the New York Ski Council at the Wil liams Club.

title: Sex Cake Is a Shock
description: DUXFORD, England (Candi an Press)Miss Roberta Canon bought an icecream cake for a party, but blushed when she opened the carton. Written across the top was the word SEX. The manufacturers, who apologized, explained it was a parting gesture by a cook who had been discharged.

title: U.S. CHURCH GROUP ENDS MOSCOW TIES
description: MOSCOW, May 18 (UPI) The Russian Orthodox Catholic Church of America ended its 175yearold ties with the Rus sian mother church and became fully independent in ceremonies today at the Moscow Patri archatethe seat of Russian Orthodoxy.

title: DUBIN'S 66 POINTS WIN HOCKEY TITLE
Helen Lipsett Wed To Ricardo Boehm
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18 Miss Helen Elizabeth Lip sett and Ricardo S. Boehm were married here this noon in the Appleton Chapel of Harvard University by Rabbi Edward Umen.

title: FINCH ENDORSES CAMBODIA ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Robert H. Finch, hospitalized by a puzzling arm ailment, today sent a message endors ing the movement of American troops into Cambodia to 800 Federal employes he had been scheduled to meet to hear com plaints of his leadership of the Department of Health, Educa tion and Welfare.

title: The Dominican Continuismo
description: President Joaquin Balaguer's election victory can scarcely be considered an overwhelming mandate either for him or for the United States policies which helped to put him in office and to sustain him there after the American intervention in the Dominican Republic in 1965.

title: Outlawed Diesels Run to Grand Central
description: The Penn Central Company acknowledged yesterday that it had been running diesel powered locomotives in and out of Grand Central Terminal, resulting in complaints from commuters over pollution and the stench of diesel fumes.

title: BRITISH INMATES TO BUILD PRISONS
description: LONDONPlans for setting up a task force of prisoners to be equipped and trained to build prisons have been an nounced by the Home Office.

title: HUNTS POINT MARKET IS SLOWED BY STRIKE
description: A wildcat strike by members of the Teamsters union over workers' parking fees dras tically slowed operations yester day at the city's huge Hunts Point Market in the Bronx, the Bronx, the major produce dis tribution point for the metro politan area.

title: Miss Devlin, in Ulster, Gets Suspended 3Month Term
description: OMAGH, Northern Ireland. May 18 (AP)Bernadette Dev lin, a leader of Northern Ire land's civilrights movement an a member of the British Parlia ment, received a threemonth prison sentence, suspended for two years, today.

title: Federal Suit Challenges Nixon Move in Cambodia
description: A group of potential draftees, a lawyer and a Navy enlisted man filed suit in Fed eral Court yesterday challeng ing President Nixon's right to send troops to Cambodia.

title: Nearby Resorts See a Boon in Offing
description: Last year I took a cruise down the Caribbean and sat, a stockbroker said re cently. This year I'll be at Deal Lake on the Jersey shore, eating peanut butter and jelly sandwiches.

title: Hofheinz Is Improving
description: HOUSTON, May 18 (UPI) Roy M. Hofheinz, owner of the Houston Astros of the Na tional Lague, was reported improved today in his recovery from a mild stroke.

title: POLICEMAN SEIZED AS EXTORTIONIST
description: A plainclothes policeman was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on a charge of extorting money from a cab driver by threaten ing to accuse him of selling nar cotics.

title: Nixon's AntiInflation Measures Add Up to Disaster, Reuss Says
description: A gloomy audience of mortgage bankers yesterday heard Representative Henry S. Reuss, an influential member of the House Banking Committee, deliver his strongest attack to date on the Nixon Admin istration's economic policies. The Wisconsin Democrat charged that the antiinflation measures taken by the Admin istration were actually pro ducing only stagnation and unemploymentand they add up to a disaster. He spoke to more than 1,200 members of the Mortgage Bankers Associ ation of America at a national mortgage conference at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: INDIA MOVES TO END PAYMENTS TO RAJAHS
description: NEW DELHI, May 18After three years of indecision, the Congress party introduced a bill in Parliament today to abolish the 279 ramaining former rajahs' privy purses.

title: HousingProject Venture Starts With $41Million
description: The National Corporation for Housing Partnerships, which in December announced plans to raise $50million to be used as seed money for low and middleincome housing projects, said yesterday it had managed to, line up subscriptions for $41.75million.

title: WOMAN IS CALLED PANTHERS' DRIVER
description: A detective testified yester day in State Supreme Court that Joan Bird, a 21yearold Black Panther, told him she had been assigned to prove herself by acting as chauffeur for two Panthers the night she was arrested following a al leged shootout between the two Panthers and two police men.

title: California Police Are Linked by Network of Data Computers
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 18  Law enforcement officers in California have been linked together by a computerized information system providing them with nearly instant in formation on wanted persons, firearms and stolen property.

title: A Saltonstall May Odvose McCormack
description: BOSTON, May 18  A pri mary race challenge for the House seat held by John W. McCormack, the 78yearold Speaker of the House of Rep resentatives, is under serious consideration by John L. Sal tonstall Jr., a descendant of a famed Republican Massachu setts family. He will make an announcement soon after June 1, informed sources say.

title: SIGNORILE LED N.Y.U. IN SCORING, REBOUNDS
description: For the second straight sea son, Jim Signorile led the New York University basketball team in scoring and rebound ing, according to the final sta tistics.

title: MRS. RATHMELL'S 73 PACES QUALIFIERS
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 18 (AP)Mrs. James Rathmell of Houston beat 158 other con tenders with a oneunderpar 73 today and won the medal in the qualifying round of the 55th annual women's Southern ama teur golf chamnionship.

title: Ellington to Be Honored
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (UPI) Duke Ellington, the composer and band leader, will receive an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from Christian Theological Seminary on June 5 at the 12th annual commence ment of the schl perated by the Disciples of Christ religious brotherhood. The announce ment of the honor said Mr. El lington would be cited for his contributions to the field of sacred music.

title: Ross Army Pistol Captain
description: Vic Ross of Columbus, Ga., is captain of Army's pistol team which was unbeaten the last two seasons.

title: City Towaway Fee Rises to $50 June 1
description: The fee charged for towing away illegally parked cars in midtown will be doubled to $50 starting June 1.

title: Lightning Sets Mine Blast
description: MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) Lightning struck into a mine tunnel and ignited an explosive charge being laid by Anthony Tucker, who dragged himself out of the mine with a shat tered leg over a mile of rail tracks. The leg was ampu tated.

title: Con Ed Power Reserve to Rise
description: The Consolidated Edison Company's power reserve at the start of summer should be about 12 to 17 per cent not a comfortable reserve, but still somewhat improved over last year, Louis H. Roddis Jr., its president, told some 1,200 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at the company's headquar ters here.

title: 500 Walk Out of Penn Commencement
description: About 500 of the 3,784 stu dents receiving degrees at the University of Pennsylvania's commencement exercises yes terday walked out in response to an appeal by an antiwar speaker.

title: Police in Florida Disperse 200 Campus Demonstrators
description: OPALOCKA, Fla., May 18 (UPI)Policemen firing canis ters of tear gas routed 200 dem onstrators tonight at Florida Memorial College.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Theasury statement and some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Ex change quotations are omit ted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings. Canadian stock tables are omitted because markets were closed in observance of Vic toria Day.

title: Mahanga Beats U.S. Boxer
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, May 18 (AP)Kahu Mahanga, 161 pounds, New Zealand middle weight, outpointed Billy Marsh, 162, of Little Rock, Ark., in a 10round bout tonight. Mahanga weighed 161 pounds. Marsh 162.

title: Screen: The Passengers and Naked Hearts Open
Grumman Expects Profit Rise
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., May 18  The annual meeting of the Grumman Corporation here to day was exceptional in one respect  no antiwar demon strators tried to disrupt the proceedings. The onehour meeting, attended by more than 1,000 shareholders, ran smoothly without interruptions.

title: Art Community Here Agrees on Plan to Fight War, Racism and Oppression
description: The issues of war, racism and oppression brought the New York art world together last night in an unprecedented joint political action meeting.

title: Freight Car Ages Limited
description: The maximum age of freight cars permitted in interchange service on American railroads is to be cut a year annually so that the present limit of 50 years will drop to 49 years by Jan. 1, 1972, and will go on until it reaches 40 years on Jan. 1, 1981, the publication Railway Age reports.

title: 10 News Programs Win Emmy Awards
description: Ten network television news and documentary programs and five individuals were named winners of Emmy awards yes terday by the National Acad emy of Television Arts and Sci ences.

title: Chilean TakeOver Cited
National Steel Raises Prices
description: The National Steel Corpora tion announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would match the actions of other major pro ducers by raising prices, effec tive June 1, for the important flatrolled category of finished steel products by an average of about 4.7 per cent.

title: NEWSWEEK REPORT IS DENIED BY LAIRD
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird denied today a report by Newsweek magazine that he had sent a topsecret cable gram to Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States com mander in Vietnam, suggesting that the American public would be impressed by the capture of highranking prisoners, enemy headquarters and arms caches in Cambodia.

title: Tourists Lured by Smithsonian By a Sky Ballet of Inflatables
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 As 200 spectators watched, the last tentaclelike segment of a strange heliumfilled tube snaked out from the lawn in front of the Smithsonian Insti tution here, twisting and bend ing skyward.

title: DDT CONTENT IN FISH EBBS IN CONNECTICUT
description: NEW HAVENThe average amount of DDT in fish caught in Connecticut rivers and lakes has decreased since airplane spraying of woodlands with the compound was reduced in 1963 and abandoned in 1965.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
KENT SLAYINGS LAID TO MILITARY BULLETS
description: KENT, Ohio, May 18 (AP) The Portage County coroner, Dr. Robert Sybert, said today that the wounds that killed four Kent State University stu dents May 4 were caused by bullets similar to .30caliber military ammunition

title: PRINCETON COOLS ITS WAR PROTEST
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 18 Two and a half weeks ago, when a student strike erupted here in angry response to the movement of American troops into Cambodia, many wondered if 1970 was to be Princeton's year of revolution as 1969 had been Harvard's year and 1968 Columbia's.

title: Bradshaw Faces Surgery
description: PITTSBURGH, May 18 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Steelers said today that Terry Bradshaw, the top choice in his year's pro football draft, would undergo surgery next Monday to re move a calcium deposit from his right thigh. The former quarterback is expected to be hospitalized a week.

title: PEKING CANCELS SESSION WITH U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, May 19Peking has canceled a meet ing scheduled for tomorrow in Warsaw between envoys of the United States and Communist China.

title: Stage: Vivid and Honest
SOVIET FIVE TOPS URUGUAY, 9543
description: LJUBLJANA, Jugoslavia, May 18 (UPI)The Soviet Union, an upset loser in the first round to Brazil, routed Uruguay, 9543, today in a thirdround game of the world amateur basketball championship. It was the So viet's second triumph.

title: CUBAN FISHERMEN REPORTED FREED
description: MIAMI, May 18The anti Castro exile group Alpha 66 an nounced today the release of 11 Cuban fishermen whom it had held as hostages for about two weeks.

title: Discontinued Crack Trains Still Operateas Models
description: CHICAGO, (AP)  Those greatname trains of America, such as the 20thCentury Lim ited, Golden State and Chief have not passed completely into oblivion.

title: Israeli Aircraft Attack Targets in Jordan 3 Hours
description: JERUSALEM, May 18  Is raeli planes carried out three hours of strikes against positton in Jordan today, an army spokesman said. It was the big gest such military effort in number of weeks.

title: Comments on WorkerStudent Clash
description: To the Editor:

title: Garment District Gambler Sentenced to Year in Jail
description: State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh sentenced a convicted gambler who alleg edly received police protection to one year in prison yester day.

title: Daley Shocked at Report On Black Panther Raid
description: CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) Mayor Richard J. Daley said to day he was shocked by a Fed eral grand jury report that charged the Chicago Police De partment with sloppy investi gative work after a raid in which two Black Panther party leaders were slain.

title: Peru to Get Housing Loan
description: LIMA, Peru May 17 (Reu ters)The InterAmerican De velopment Bank will lend Peru $12.5million to finance 3,850 lowcost housing units in nine Peruvian cities, the Govern ment said.

title: Wilson, Cheered by Polls, Sets British Vote June 18
description: LONDON, May 18Prime Minister Wilson, buoyed a tide of favorable publicopinion polls, today called general election on June 18. A brief conversation with Queer Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace made it official. The formal announcement, issued a few minutes after Mr. Wil lson had driven back to 10 Downing Street, said:

title: Coffins Disappear in Britain
description: LICHFIELD, England (UPI) A load of coffins fell from a truck on a major highway here and disappeared.

title: Don't Forget Bob Hopkins
description: BATON ROUGE, La. (UPI) Pete Marovich of Louisiana State scored 3,667 points in three years to become the greatest scorer do major basket ball, but Bob Hopkins, who tal lied 3,756 points in four years at Grambling, is still the top scorer in college history.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 The Supreme Court took the Allowing actions today:

title: WAR CRITIC AIDED IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 18 Some 5,000 college students campaigned across Pennsylvania today for Norval D. Reece, in dependent peace candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Senate in tomorrow's pri mary election.

title: Clues to Spiny Lobster Queues Uncovered by a Marine Biologist
description: A deepsea mystery puzzling marine biologists is the habit of migrating spiny lobsters of travelling headtotail across the ocean bottom in two parallel lines.

title: Moran Again Is Low Bidder On Towing City's Garbage
description: The Moran Towing and Transportation Company has submitted the low bid, $1,790, 764, for towing New York City's sanitatibn waste to Staten Island in the next fiscal year.

title: Dentist Pulls Wrong Tooth
description: CAPETOWN (AP)  When the Swedish tanker Artemis stopped at Trinidad, one of its engineers asked a dentist to extract a tooth that had been troubling him. Only when the ship was at sea again did he realize that the dentist had Dulled the wrong tooth.

title: Restrictions Assailed by U.S. Trade Aide
description: Carl J. Gilbert, the Admin istration's chief tradepolicy of ficial, warned yesterday that unilateral import restriction by the United States would in evitably lead to a loss of ex ports.

title: Texas Litter Costs High
description: AUSTIN, Tex. (UPI)Despite laws against throwing trash on highways, special driveby trash barrels and statewide campaigns against littering, Texas highway officials figure it costs $1.9million a year to pick up litter along Texas roads.

title: AlmaAta Aware China Is Near
description: ALMAATA, U.S.S.R., May 17The people of this Soviet Central Asian capital are acutely aware that they live only 200 miles from the Chi nese border and that China re mains a threat to their security.

title: Cornfeld, a Tycoon Bereft of His Empire
description: GENEVA, May 18Bernard Cornfeld, who was ousted last last week as head of the problemridden mutualfund empire he had erected, re mains locked in the 20 room villa built here by Na poleon for Josephine, in the company of half a dozen security men, four Great Danes, three eyefilling women in their early twenties, two oce lots, a basset hound and his 82yearold mother.

title: David Cryer Leaves 1776
description: John Cullen will take over the role of Edward Rutledge, the South Carolina delegate, in 1776, at the 46th Street The ater. He replaces David Cryer, who has signed to star in the Off Broadway production of Whispers on the Wind, open ing June 3 at the Theatre de Lep.

title: Excerpts From Attack by Moscow on Policies of Mao
description: Following are excerpts from an editorial in Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, titled Pseudo revolutionaries With Their Masks Off, as distributed in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: FLOOD CASE GOES TO COURT TODAY
description: With Curt Flood expected to be the first witness and Arthur Goldberg acting as defense counsel, a trial on the merits of baseball's reserve system will begin for the first time in Federal District Court here to day. It will be tried before Judge Irving Ben Cooper and is likely to last two or three weeks.

title: Cadets' Foil Captain From L.I.
description: Nick Costantino, of Lake Ronkonkoma, L. I., captains Army's fencing team.

title: North Dakota Man Collects Barbed Wire as His Hobby
description: GRAND FORKS, N.D. (AP) Most people avoid barbed wire, but not William Crogan. The missile site construction worker collects it as a hobby.

title: Only an African Safari Can Keep This Cook Out of the Kitchen
description: SOUTH KENT, Conn.  It isn't often that Mrs. Paul Linz allows cooking to take a back seat in her peripatetic life. The kitchen, animals and traveling are her consuming interests, but there have been times  such as during the four East African safaris she has taken in the last eight years  when she has read justed her priorities.

title: LEVINTOWNSEND AND I.B.M. AT ODDS
description: The friendly negotiations be tween the LevinTownsend Computer Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation over the question of LevinTownsend's $11.2mil lion debt to the giant computer manufacturer have turned, acrimonious.

title: 4 EVENTS SLATED FOR LATE JUNE
description: National Collegiate Athletic Association officials believe there will be no interruption of their four major championship tournaments in June despite current student protests.

title: NATIONAL AIRLINES IN ACCORD ON PACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)  National Airlines, grounded for 108 days by strike, agreed today to a settle ment giving 3,600 ground per sonnel a 33 per cent raise over a threeyear period.

title: Pope Calls for Accords in Indochina and Mideast
description: ROME, May 18Pope Paul IV, in an address to a consistory of Cardinals and Bishops, made a pressing appeal today for a negotiated settlement of the conflicts in Indochina and the Middle East.

title: U.S. Court Asked to Force Guarantee of Speedy Trial
description: Two New York bar associations and the American Civil Liberties Union have asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here to force the city and state courts to guarantee all criminal defendants a trial within four to six months of arrest.

title: CANADIAN RECEIVES ALIMONY FROM WIFE
description: TORONTO (Canadian Press) A 62yearold welfare recipi ent has become the first man in Canada to be granted ali mony payments from his wife.

title: Urban Blacks Press for Gains With Reasoned Radical Tactics
description: ST LOUISOn the wall in a community center here there was a large felt heart covered with a BandAid and the words, Love Heals. Beneath it sat a gentle, 29yearold urban priest named Buck Jones, who for nine months had administered misery to the St. Louis Housing Authority.

title: BenGurion, Now 83, Resigns From Knesset
description: JERUSALEM, May 18 Former Premier David Ben Gurion, who has lived vir tually retired from political life for the last few years, has made the break complete by resigning his seat in Parlia ment.

title: ARMSTRONG QUITS ASTRONAUT CORPS
description: WASHINGTON, May 18(UPI) Neil A. Armstrong, the first man to set foot on the moon, is leaving the astronaut corps to take a Washington desk job with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Yankees Trounce Orioles, 104
description: Five games behind the 1970 Baltimore Orioles and five games ahead of the 1969 Yan kees, that's where the Yankees stand after their 104 ramble over the Orioles last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: In The Nation: For White Readers Only
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Suppose you were black. What would you think if you had read these items in your news paper in the last ten days?

title: President Rejects Meeting With 9 Negro Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) President Nixon has refused a request to meet with nine Negro members of Congress to discuss problems concerning black America, Representative William Clay, Democrat of Mis souri, said today.

title: MAYOR DESCRIBES GIFT TO CAMPAIGN
description: Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday that the very sub stantial contribution that a Cincinnati lawyer had made to the Mayor's reelection cam paign was $3,000. The con tributor had testified that he made the payment for legal services due the Mayor's twin brother.

title: Roundup: Senators Stir With Brunet's Arm, Bat
description: George Brunet, the Wash ington Senators' vagabond pitcher, last night had one of his most gratifying games since he came out of Hough ton, Mich., in 1953 to start a professional career that has taken him to seven major league and 15 minor league teams.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MAY 19, 1970

title: Yanks' Home Run Starts Off Best Inning of Season
C. W. Post, Conqueror of Navy, Hits Track Conference Hurdle
description: Last September, when C. W. Post College still was struggling to establish its identity in East ern track and field, the school filed formally for membership in the Metropolitan Intercolle giate Track and Field Associa tion.

title: WAGE GUIDE URGED BY BURNS IN BREAK WITH NIXON POLICY
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 18 Arthur F. Burns, who until last winter was one of Presi dent Nixon's closest advisers on domestic affairs, parted company with the Administra tion today by calling for an in comes policy to help speed the return to price stability.

title: CopperSupply Bill Is Offered in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Legislation aimed at insuring a supply of domestic copper to small, independent fabricators was introduced today by Rep resentative Ray Blanton.

title: Caufield Supports Gibson in Newark
description: NEWARK, May 18John P. Caufield, the former city Fire Director who ran fourth in the city's mayoral election last Tuesday, formally announced today his support for Kenneth, A. Gibson, a Negro civil en gineer who ran first and faces Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, the secondplace finisher, in a run off on June 16.

title: A McCarthy Adds Max To Richard and Dean
description: Why not? They've been calling me Max for years.

title: COLLEGE HEAD HERE QUITS AFTER STRIFE
description: Dr. Murray H. Block re signed Sunday as president of the Borough of Manhattan Com munity College, following dis orders last week, which forced the closing of the school.

title: Freightman to Travel
description: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) After more than a half century with the Santa Fe Railway freight office here, Iva Garrett is retiring with a lifetime rail road pass and plans to do a lot of traveling.

title: Cambodia Appeals to Asian and Pacific Countries to Send Troops
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 18Cambodia has asked Asian and Pacific Ocean countries to send troops to help her repel the North Vietnamese and Vietcong attackers, but the initial reac tion has been negative.

title: Lam Reports Crossings
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 18  Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Vietnam said tonight that United States soldiers as well as South Viet namese soldiers had been cross ing the Laotian border in hot pursuit of enemy forces for several years.

title: Piper, Jaffray to Acquire IowaBased Member Firm
description: Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood, Inc., a large regional broker age house based in Minne apolis, announced yesterday that it was acquiring T. C. Henderson & Co., a firm with headquarters in Des Moines, Iowa. Both houses are mem bers of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A.B.A. Playoff
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Mighty Ruth Still Prevails
description: Babe Ruth is the only player to hit three home Tuns in one World Series game, accomplish ing the feat in 1926 and again in 1928.

title: GINNY MAY SETS A SALE OF BONDS
description: In a step that is part of a program to pump more money into the sagging housing mar ket, the Government National Mortgage Association moved yesterday to ready $400million of mortgagebacked bonds for sale today.

title: Observer: Status of Red Menace Threatened
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  After 25 years of being the Unit ed States' leading menace, Com munism is finding its suprema cy Older challenge this year by an upstart new menace. It is called permissiveness, and the people involved in it are called permissivists.

title: Manila Tower Planned
description: MANILA (UPI)Mayor An tonio Villegas plans to build with private funds a tower of fering a panoramic view of Ma nila Bay in time for the 400th anniversary of the founding of Manila on July 24, 1974.

title: House Calls for MakeUp
description: The time when a woman wants to put on her most attractive facewhen she's going to an important party or to the altaris usually when nervousness makes her all thumbs about makeup. It helps to know that the fluttery bridal party, the un skilled debutante or the time pressed hostess can call on pro fessional help to take over the tricky business of eyeliner and false lashes. The rescuer is a pleasant young man named Nilo Viyella, who has re cently arrived at the Lupe salon, 149 East 72d Street. Niln works in the salon normally, hut by appoint ment will go to a client's home to do a professional makeup. In addition to his facial skills, Nilo is an ex perienrecl ??.

title: Stage Rises to a New (Balcony) Level
description: A meeting is being ar ranged this week at the ANTA Theater by which those two distant relatives, the balcony and the stage, will come together for the first time.

title: Strengthening the Economy  I
description: The United States economy today presents a bleak picture, as Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Fed eral Reserve Board, conceded to the Joint Economic Committee last week. The real Gross National Product has dropped and the odds have increased that the economy is in a genuine recession.

title: Senator's Son, 19, Charged In Jersey Marijuana Case
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 18, (AP)  The son of Senator Ernest Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina was released in $515 bail today following his arrest on a marijuana charge on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: U.S. SURVEY REPORTS STATUS OF FAMILIES
description: WASHINGTON  While the number of young adult Ameri cans who live in their own homes apart from relatives is increasing, they are far fewer than the elderly who similarly reside alone, according to report by the Census Bureau.

title: THEATER FOR 1,800 GETS ZONE PERMIT
description: The City Planning Commis sion approved a special zoning permit yesterday to allow the construction of a 43story office building, including an 1,800 seat legitimate theater, on the west side of Broadway between 52d and 53d Streets.

title: LADO's Spring Lunch Is Set for Tomorrow
description: The annual spring luncheon of LADO, Inc., will be held tomorrow in the Plaza's Ter race Room. Mrs. Aaron Shack is chairman of the event and Mrs. Morris Ehrenstoft is co chairman. Proceeds will be used for LADO scholarships and awards to bring talented young musicians to public attention.

title: LittleBossi Bout July 3
description: MILAN, Italy, May 18 (AP) Freddie Little of Las Vegas, Nev., the world junior middle weight boxing champion, is slated to defend his title against Carmelo Bossi of Italy in Monza July 3, Romolo Sab batini, an Italian matchmaker, said today.

title: NATIONALGUARDSMEN LEAVE AUGUSTA, GA.
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., May 18 (AP)  National Guard troops were withdrawn today and a curfew was lifted from this city, where six Negroes were shot to death by the police last week.

title: Sears and Dayton Dip
description: Profits of the nation's giant retailers are facing strong pres sure from a combination of re duced customer buying and in creased operating costs.

title: Note to Readers
description: Reviews of last night's dance and music perform ances are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings. They will appear in tomorrow's editions.

title: Visit to Ballet and a Reception Set for Collegiate School Fund
description: A champagne reception will be held at Le Pouailler restaurant on West 65th Street Thursday night after a performance by the New York City Ballet at the State Theater. Honorary chairman for the evening, planned as a benefit for the Endowment Fund of the Collegiate School, is Mrs. Aristotle Onassis. Her son, John F. Kennedy Jr., is a pupil at the school.

title: EXAIDE TO JOHNSON WARNS OF VIOLENCE
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Unless the nation is willing to meet domestic commitments as completely as overseas commit ments, its troubled youth will turn significantly more violent, the man who was the chief do mestic affairs adviser to Presi dent Johnson said today.

title: Landlords Bar New Wage Offer Here
description: Negotiators for the Realty Advisory Board that the would make no wage offer to the Building Service Employes Un ion unless Mayor Lindsay al tered his recent rentcontrol proposals. The landlords thus made more likelya strike by 25,000 apartmenthouse em ploves on Thursday.

title: BREWERS GET PENA IN TRADE WITH A'S
description: MILWAUKEE, May 18 (UPI) The Milwaukee Brewers ac quired Roberto Pena, an infield er, from the Oakland Athletics today in exchange for John Donaldson, also an infielder, who has been with the Brewers' Portland club of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Ottinger and Sorensen Lay Strife On Race, Housing Jam to Nixon
description: Two of the four candidates for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate from New Yor kblamed domes tic policies of the Nixon Ad ministration yesterday for vio lence against blacks in the South and worsening of the housing shortage over the country.

title: DR. JULIUS B. WAGER
description: Dr. Julius B. Wager, a psy chiatrist at Hillside Hospital in Glen Ooaks, Queens, died yesterday at his home in Hart sdale, N.Y. He was 54 years old.

title: Miss Nancy Gail Ott Is Betrothed
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 18The engagement of Miss Nancy Gail Ott to Luke Daniel Lynch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lynch, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert R. Ott, parents of the prospective bride.

title: CLINTON RETAINS CROWN IN TRACK
description: DeWitt Clinton High retained the team title yesterday in the Bronx Public Schools Athletic League track and field cham pionship at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: Police Investigate Puerto Rican Unit In Bombings Here
description: Police Department officials said yesterday that they were investigating a reported link betwen a 41yearold man ar rested Saturday in connection with several New York City bombings and a Puerto Rican revolutionary group known as MIRA. More arrests are expect ed shortly, they said.

title: High Court Rejects Fingerprint Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)The Supreme Court re jected today a challenge to a New York law requiring em ployes of stock exchanges and brokerage houses to be finger printed.

title: Old Folks Form a Band
description: PUEBLO, Colo. (AP)  A rhythm band has been added at a nursing home here, made up of tomtoms from cans, inner tubes and old string, tambou rines from pop bittle caps, and pie tins and maracas from card board cheese cartons and oat meal boxes: The ages of the band members run from 75 to 102.

title: TENANTS IN JERSEY YIN REPAIR RIGHTS
description: TRENTON, May 18. (AP) The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a tenant who had tried without success to get his landlord to make re pairs could order the repairs himself and deduct the cost from his monthly rent.

title: Curtis Plant Option to G.E.
description: Shareholders of the Curtis Publishing Company voted at the annual meeting in Phila delphia yesterday to grant an option to the General Electric Company to purchase Curtis's Sharon Hill, Pa., printing plant for $9.25million.

title: TV Camera Is Sunproof
description: ELMIRA, N. Y. (AP)West inghouse Electric Corporation said it had developed a tele vision camera tube that could withstand glare from the sun, solving a problem that spoiled man's first color telecast from the moon.

title: Dolphins Sign Fleming, Send Clancy to Packers as Compensation
description: MIAMI, May 18 (AP)  Mary Fleming, a tight end who played out his option at Green Bay, was signed today by Miami and the Dolphins sent a wide receiver, Jack Clancy, to the Packers as compensa tion.

title: Congress and the Mails
description: Prospects for postal reform legislation are consid erably better than they were when President Nixon, early in the term, proposed a public corporation to take over the mails. Under the combined prod of a strike and the calling out of troops, the Administra tion, the unions and Congress have all moved suf ficiently far in the same direction to encourage the hope that in a few years Americans may enjoy a service guaranteed to get a letter from New York to Washington in less than three days.

title: DUGOUTS ON PRAIRIES ARE USED FOR WATER
description: MOOSE JAW, Saskatchewan (Canadian Press)  Henry Checker and his two nephews were returning from Regina to their homestead when they noticed that ditches along the railway lines were filled with water.

title: Wolf Goes to State Capitol
description: LANSING, Mich. (UPI)The fourthgrade class of Brookside School in Grand Rapids took Star, a 2yearold, 75pound timber wolf, to a meeting of the senate state affairs committee. The pupils told the committee members that Star's breed was in danger of extinction.

title: U.N. Youth Assembly Finds an Angel on Broadway
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18Michael Butler, pro ducer of the Broadway hit Hair, offered today to be the angel of the financially ailing world youth assembly and Secretary General Thant promptly accepted.

title: Italians Fight Neon's Taint In Taormina
description: TAORMINA, SicilyGreek colonists founded it. Romans fortified it. Saracens con quered it and lost it to the Normans. The French held it. Art lovers cherished it. But, some of Taormina's present inhabitants fear, tour ists and those who make money on them may shortly ruin it.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Governor Approves A Law to Shorten Waits for Divorce
description: ALBANY, May 18 (UPI)It will take longer to get married, but less time to get divorced in New York State under legis lation signed today by Gov ernor Rockefeller.

title: Toboggan Trip Is Symbol
description: YEELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories (AP) A 10  man power toboggan made a 20day trip across 800 miles of track less wilderness to this capital, of the Northwest Territories in honor of the Northwest Terri tories Centennial.

title: Mayor Calls Meeting Today of Narcotics Council
description: Mayor Lindsay's Narcotics Control Council, given top pri ority by the admiinstration to deal with the current narcotics crisis, is scheduled to meet to day after three weeks in limbo.

title: Heyerdahl's Papyrus Boat 100 Miles Out on First Day
description: SAFI, Morocco, May 18 (AP) Gale winds and 15foot waves pushed Thor Heyerdahl's pa pyrus boat Ra II steadily south westward into the Atlantic to day on the Norwegian explorer's second attempt to sail to Cen tral America.

title: ROMNEY ASKS UNIT TO CURB INFLATION
description: The appointment of a Presi dential commission to alert the public to instances of inflation ary wage and price increases was urged here yesterday by George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment.

title: 310 M.P.H. Train Planned For the TokyoOsaka Line
description: TOKYO (AP)The president of Japan National Railways said his line hoped to haye a 310 mileperhour wheelless train in service by 1980.

title: PINCH HIT BY EXPO CAPS 5RUN NINTH
description: MONTREAL, May 18  After having hit three consecutive home runs for the first time since 1962, the New York Mets today revived memories of their disastrous farces, too, in that first season. But now, it's not funny.

title: Fanny May Results Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Mortgage prices declined for the second consecutive time at this week's auction, the Fed eral National Mortgage Association reported today.

title: Aide of Lon Nol Says China Was Ready to Recognize Him
description: TOKYO, May 18 (AP)  A top Cambodian official said to day that Communist China ap peared at one time to be pre pared to recognize the Cam bodian Government that ousted Prince Norodon Sihanouk last March.

title: Dutch Inmates Get A Civilian Board To Right Wrongs
description: THE HAGUE (AP)The Neth erlands has a kind of civilian review board for its prisoners that has drawn the admiration of at least one prominent Amer ican.

title: Market Place
description: YOU'VE heard the poser, How High is Up? It is hard one to answer. And it may be equally difficult to answer, How Low is Down?

title: JERSEY RACE WON BY MORE PRINCELY
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 18 (AP)More Princely had to battle his way through horses at the head of the stretch, but emerged to win the Realtor purse by three lengths at Gar den State Park today. Imabove, the pacesetter, finished as the runnerup, two lengths in front of the lateclosing Joe Namath.

title: Finger Control Proposed To Keep Prisoners in Line
description: SAN DIEGO (AP)  By put ting the finger on criminals we aikido, deputy sheriffs hope to keep their prisoners in hand

title: Economic and Social Differences Separate the Races in Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., May 18An automobile ride along this city's Scenic Tour Trails goes far toward convincing a visitor that Augusta deserves its repu tation as the Garden City of the South.

title: Prudent Dominican Leader
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domi nican Republic, May 18 When President Joaquin Ba laguer received a sample of moon rock recently as a gift of the United States Govern ment, his prudence exceeded his curiosity.

title: 2 ON WALL ST. PAPER TAKE BERGER AWARD
description: Two reporters for The Wall Street Journal, Art Sears Jr. and Donald Moffitt, were named yesterday as wineners of Co lumbia University's 1970 Mike Berger Award.

title: Shapiro Takes 3d to Pace U.S. Riders at Wiesbaden
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, May 18 (AP)Riders from the United States took four of the first seven places yesterday in a speed trial event over 10 obstacles and 12 jumps at the Wiesbaden international eques trian tnurnament.

title: Wellesley Alumnae Plan a Party
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 18Wellesley College alum nae who are members of WellesleyinWestchester will gather Thursday at Lynd hurst, a Gothic Revival man sion here, for an allday party. Proceeds of the event will go to the college's scholarship and faculty salary funds.

title: PRICES MAKE GAIN ON STOCK MARKET
description: The stock market paused yes terday to catch its breath as some popular averages showed token gains after the surge in prices last Friday.

title: Ecuador Gets Help on Rice
description: QUITO, Ecuador (AP)A Nationalist Chinese mission has arrived here to help improve Ecuadorean rice production, in keeping with a cooperation agreement signed in 1966, the Goverment announced.

title: Tax Exemption for Elderly Approved by Nassau Board
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 18 (UPI)  The Nassau County Board of Supervisors unani mously approved a county law today that will increase prop erty tax exemptions for senior citizens.

title: Gaelic Dancer Snaps Foreleg After Finishing Second to Reviewer in Roseben
description: Reviewer, Ogden Phipps's highly regarded colt, scored in a thrilling finish against Wil liam Pascoe's Gaelic Dancer yesterday in the $27,650 Rose ben Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: House and Garden Tour to Aid Rehabilitation Medicine Unit
description: PAWLING, N. Y., May 18  The 17th annual house and garden tour to benefit the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine of the New York University Medical Center, of which Dr. Howard A. Rusk is director, will be held next Tuesday from 10:30 A. M. to 5 P. M. in the Quaker Hill area.

title: Johnny Cash Wins 4 Awards
description: LONDON, May 18 (AP) Johnny Cash, the American folk singer, won four major awards presented by the British Coun try Music Association last night. He was named entertain er of the year and male singer of the year. His longplaying record, At San Quentin, and the single, A Boy Named Sue, were judged best of kind for the year.

title: New Meeting Is Likely
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Chinese Communist representa tives informed the United States today that they would probably be willing to set a new date for an ambassado rial level meeting in several weeks. the State Department said today.

title: Bill Rates Show a Sharp Decline At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Treasury bill rates declined sharply at todays auction from last weeks levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon.

title: Many British Children Feel Sting of the Drunken Wasp
description: LONDON (AP)Tipsy wasps have been on an orgy of child stinging in Britain, a beekeeper revealed.

title: DRIVERS APPROVE TEAMSTERS' PACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Truck drivers around the coun try have approved by a 7to5 margin a new national contract that includes a 27 per cent raise over the next 39 months.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ralph E. Waite, formerly vice president and con troller of Gimbel's New York, has joined Peck & Peck, a group of women's specialty shops, as vics presidentfinance. Miss Dorothy Teubler, who has been with the company since 1951, has been named controller of Peck & Peck.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: LATINS IN BASEBALL CHECK DOLLAR DRAIN
description: Ninetythree Latin baseball players were on major league rosters this spring and more are on the way.

title: FOOD ANALYSIS AIDS ALLERGIC CANADIANS
description: TORONTO (Canadian Press) About 2 million Canadians are allergic to certain foods.

title: PAPERS SAY ISRAEL WARNED BIG POWERS
description: JERUSALEM, May 18 (AP) Israeli newspapers said today that Israel had warned the big nations that she would do ev erything in her power to pre vent Egypt from strengthening her Suez Canal defenses, even if it meant hitting at Soviet personnel and material there.

title: DISPUTE DISRUPTS WALL ST. JOURNAL
description: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., charged the Newspaper Deliv erers Union yesterday with blocking distribution of The Wall Street Journal because of a jurisdictional dispute over work at the company's South Brunswick, N. J., plant.

title: Bargain Flights Spur Travel Overseas
description: Despite a slumping econo my and tight money condi tions at home, more Ameri cans than ever before are planning to travel abroad this summer, They are un willing to cancel vacations now that bargain air fares have reduced the cost of foreign travel to a level within the reach of most middle class families.

title: Amex Index Up 0.03, to 21.14 As Volume Falls to 2.5 Million
description: Advances topped declines yesterday in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange.

title: LIBRARY ENDOWMENT WILL AID MUSICIANS
description: WASHINGTON  A new endowment in support of mu sic for violin and piano, to be known as the McKim Fund, has been announced by the Li brarian of Congress, L. Quincy Mumford.

title: Yasha Yakovlev, a Dancer And Photographer, Is Dead
description: Yasha Yakovlev, a dancer and photographer, died Sunday apparently of a heart attack, at his home at 212 West 22d Street. He was 58 years old.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON RISE MODERATELY
Kissing Record Is Claimed
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind. (UPI) John Lyons, a Notre Dame senior, and a St. Mary's fresh man established an American kissing record of six and a half wurs. They fell short of the world record8 hours 45 min utesset by a South African nourge.

title: 2 ExPlayers With Lunceford Head a Spirited Jazz Quintet
description: Two veterans of Jimmie Lunceford's orchestra  Elmer Crumbley, trombone, and George Clarke, tenor saxo phoneheaded a highspirited quintet Sunday night at Uncle John's Straw Hat, 316 West 49th Street.

title: Intelligence Costs For Military in '70 Put at $2.9Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI)  Army, Navy and Air Force intelligence is costing $2.9billion this year, the Nixon Administration's new intelli gence coordinator disclosed in testimony published today.

title: Lamont and Stevens Gain 9th in A.B.C. With 1,302
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 18 (AP)William Stevens and Jim Lamont of Bellaire, Ohio, both substituting for other bowlers who could not come to Knox ville, combined for a 1,302 to day to grab ninth place in the regular doubles standings of the Amercan Bowling Congress tournament.

title: Canadian Says Rich Lands Owe Support to Poor Ones
description: TORONTO (Canadian Press) John Gellner, a writer on political and military affairs, say there will be a world revo lution unless the economic im balance between rich and poor countries is redressed.

title: Naples Police Free Woman Kept in Stable for 20 Years
description: NAPLIES, Italy (UPI)  The police said they had found and freed a 74yearold woman who had been kept locked in a win dowless, ratinfested stable for 20 years.

title: PHILIP M. HOLSTEIN, ACTIVE IN CHARITIES
description: SYRCUSE, May 18Philip M. Holstein, vice chairman of the board of the Syroco divi sion of Dart Industries, Inc., (formerly the Rexall Drug and Chemical Company,) died Satur day at his summer home in Cazenovia, N.Y., apparently of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: 1971 Troop Pullout Urged
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., May 17 (UPI)  Representative Robert T. Stafford, Republican of Ver mont, called Sunday for the withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam by the end of next year. Mr. Stafford, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, told the graduating class at the Univer sity of Vermont that Congress should restrict defense funds so that all combat units would be out of Vietnam by Christ mas. 1971.

title: Supreme Court Curbs Libel Suits Over Reporting of Exaggerated Charges
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Supreme Court broadened the constitutional defenses of news men against libel suits today by ruling that the press cannot be held liable for reporting exag gerated charges leveled against public figures when it is clear that the accusations are polit ical hyperbole.

title: SHIP'S TELEGRAPH GETS A REPRIEVE
description: The engineroom telegraph, widely believed doomed through increasing automation of ship bridges, is making a comeback on the world's six largest tankers.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: State's Redistricting Law Upheld by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  The Supreme Court upheld to day the constitutionality of the 1970 New York Congressional redistricting law, despite a complaint that some of the state's 41 districts were gerry mandered to aid Republican candidates.

title: Doctor Derides Ulcer Belief
description: DUBLIN (AP)The popular belief that hectic city life is the cause of most digestive dis orders was discounted by Dr. F. Avery Jones, a British spe cialist. He told a medical con ference here that the incidence of duodenal ulcers in the west of Ireland was very high, de spite the slower tempo of life.

title: LAIRD SAYS ALLIES HAVE CARRIED OUT MISSIONS IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Secretary of Defense Melvin R.
