description: Wednesday, May 20, 1970

title: The Sister of Malcolm X Leads 300 in a Pilgrimage to His Grave
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 19 The sister of Malcolm X led a pilgrimage of 300 today to the grave of the slain black militant in Ferncliff Cemetery here where she said that her brother would have pre vented black riots had he lived.

title: Mishap Leaves Scot Flush
description: GLASGOW, Scotland (UPI) A court awarded Gordon Mc Leod 412 awarded Gordon Mc for injuries received when a public toilet collasped. City at torneys argued unsuccessfully that Mr. McLeod sat down more heavily than usual be cause he had been drinking.

title: Voter Leaves Issue Hanging
description: FRANKFORT, Ky. (AP)  State Representative Ed Hollo way is puzzled by an unsigned letter from a Louisville con stituent that says in its en tirety: I have not made up my mind on this issue as vet.

title: RESTON TRIO PLAYS WORK BY MONDELLO
description: Back in the era when you could call a musician a swinger without implying that his social life was a scandal, Nuncio Mon dello was a swinger. He played lead saxophone with Benny Goodman Red Nichols and other swingband masters.

title: STARS TOP PACERS ON COAST, 109106
description: ANAHEIM, May 19 (UPI)  The Los Angeles Stars out scored Indiana, 253, in the first 10 minutes of the last quarter last night and posted a 109106 victory, their first in the Am erican Basketball Association championship playoff series.

title: WARREN PRAISES LOBBY FOR PEACE
description: Former Chief Justice Earl Warren said last night that the was in Indochina has brought to fevor pitch our crisis, al ready heightened by racial ten sions, crime, poverty, inflation and pollution of the environ ment.

title: Wheat Futures Stage a Rally On Chicago Board of Trade
description: fter dropping sharply early in the session, wheat futures staged a rally on the Chicago Board of Trade and finished higher yesterday. The day was saved by a late wave of buy ing and shortcovering, which trimmed the early lows.

title: Stocks Decline Sharply
description: Stock prices took another sharp slide yesterday, with the DowJones industrial average falling 14.85 points, to 676.55. The broad setback, on the heels of Tuesday's retreat, left the average at a sevenyear low.

title: Vote Supervisors Get Raise
description: New York City election in spectors, who supervise regis tration and voting, were, granted a pay increase by the city yesterday. The inspectors, will receive a daily increase: from $8.75 to $11.25 on days when registration is open from 5 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. On clays when registration hours are from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. and on Election Day the increase is from $26.25 to $37.50.

title: Pollution Treaties Pushed
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 President Nixon asked the Sen ate today to consent to the ratification of two treaties deal ing with the threat of oil pollu tion by ships at sea and the liability of ship owners for coastal damage from oil spills from tankers.

title: Teachers in Catholic Schools Picket for Higher Salaries
description: The diocesan office for Roman Catholic schools in Brooklyn and Queens was picketed yesterday by 400 high school teachers who are seek ing higher salaries and im proved fringe benefits.

title: Misusing the United Nations
description: The United Nations Security Council once more has condemned Israel for a raid against an Arab neighbor in this case the May 12 attack into southeastern Lebanonwithout mentioning the guerrilla blows that provoked the Israeli reaction. Such onesided propa ganda gestures are not only futile but they undermine the credibility, and therefore the utility, of the world organization as an instrument for peace in the Middle East or anywhere.

title: Coast Firebombs Break Campus Quiet
description: Most college and university campuses were relatively quiet yesterday, with the emphasis as much on political planning as on demonstrations, although one episode of violence oc curred, apparently unrelated to the nationwide protest move ment.

title: Fair in Brooklyn
description: The junior committee of the ColonySouth Brooklyn Houses will hold its fifth an nual street fair between Orange and Middagh Streets on Columbia Heights in Brooklyn Heights from noon to 9 P.M. on Saturday. A of the Bakers Trust Company in New York. He died in 1938.

title: WASHINGTON GETS 3 DECIDING POINTS
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Ma 20 (AP)  Ken Washington of the University of California, Los Angeles scored 3 points in the closing seconds today giv ing the United States a 7572 victory over the Soviet Union in the world amateur basket ball tournament.

title: U.S. Returns $97,642 in Confiscated Cash to Bookie (After Deducting Taxes)
description: Emilio Pizzarello, who lost $125,882 to Federal agents during a bookmaking raid on his store in Mount Vernon, N.Y., in 1965, got $97,642.88 of it back in cash yesterday. He hired an armored truck to haul it off.

title: Brown's 53 Points Help Pacers Gain A 31 Playoff Lead
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 19 (AP)Coach Bob Leonard of the Indiana Pacers predicted early in the season that Roger Brown would score 50 to 60 points in a game. And Brown picked just the right time to do it.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW BIG DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday to their lowest level in almost three years as most issues con tinued to decline in more ac tive trading.

title: British Sub to Fire Missiles
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla,, May 20 (AP)The British nuclear submarine Revenge ar rived here yesterday to conduct two firings of Polaris A3 mis siles. The missiles will he launched next month.

title: Nasser Quoted on Pilots
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 20 (Reuters)President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic was quoted in an interview pub lished today in the newspaper Die Welt as having said that Soviet pilots were flying Egyp tian Air Force jets and could have encountered Israeli planes.

title: Defense Panel Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Car olina, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has appointed a subcommittee to study the impact of equal employment opportunity programs on defense procurement. Representative Charles H. Wil son, Democrat of California, is chairman of the threeman sub committee. Representative W. C. Daniel, Democrat of West Vir ginia, and Donald D. Clancy, Republican of Ohio, are the other members.

title: U.S. Says It Will Discourage SouthWest Africa Investments
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20The United States an nounced here today that it would henceforth actively dis courage American investment in SouthWest Africa as long as South Africa continued to rule the area in defiance of the United Nations.

title: SEYMOUR H. RINZLER OF NUTRITION BUREAU
description: Dr. Seymour H. Rinzler, a cardiologist and director of the Department of Health's Bureau of Nutrition, died at Beth Is rael Hospital Tuesday of a heart attack. It was his 56th birthday.

title: Lesotho, Once Lush Region, Is Now Parched and Eroded
description: MASERU, Lesotho, May 11 The French missionaries who came to Basutoland in the last century described in their jour nals a fat and lovely land. Hip popotamuses played in clear, willowlined streams. Teal, wa terbirds and game came to little lakes and basins carpeted with watercress under tim bered hills.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Article 2  No Title
EUGENE FLAM GIVES WINTERREISE RECIT AL
description: Schubert's Winterreise, a gloomridden cycle of 24 songs about a man whose fiance married someone else, is not a usual choice for a New York debut recital program, but Eu gene Flam, a baritone, selected it for his appearance at Carne gie Recital Hall on Tuesday night.

title: Cancer Rife on St. Helena
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. (AP) A United Nations Secretariat paper on the British South At lantic island of St. Helena, where Napoleon died of cancer in 1821, says that 1968 health figures indicate the principal causes of death there were degenerative heart disease and cancer.

title: Pennsylvania Democrats Select Shapp
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20  Milton J. Shape, an insurgent, narrowly won the Democratic nomination for Governor for the second consecutive time yesterday, again beating State Auditor General Robert P. Casey and the disorganized Democratic organization.

title: M.I.T. Will End Relationship With a Research Laboratory
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20  The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced today that it was divesting itself of the Charles Stark Draper Labo ratory, a key center for space and military research. It has developed the guidance systems for the Apollo spacecraft and various guided missiles.

title: In The Nation: A Long Way to '72
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Since last May, President Nix on's lead over Senator Edmund Muskie (in a threeway race with George Wallace) has de clined from a comfortable 5133 to a close 4238, as measured by Louis Harris just after the Cambodian invasion.

title: 50 IN STATE DEPT. CHIDED ON LETTER
description: WASHINGTON. May 20 Fifty Foreign Service officers who signed a letter to Secre tary of State William P. Rogers, two weeks ago protesting the United States operation in Cambodia have been warned by their superiors that they acted out of turn in publicly criticizing the Administration.

title: Hong Kong Hotels Thrive
description: HONG KONG (UPI)  Hong Kong hotels maintained an all year occupancy rate of 87 per cent in 1969.

description: BASEBALL

title: Bridge:
description: This time next month the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl will be ending its qualifying stage in Stockholm. The five teams taking part will be weaker, on paper, than on any pre vious occasion, largely be cause the Italian Blue Team will be missing for the first time since 1957.

title: Bermudan Says Only the Color Of Your Shirt Counts in Soccer
description: LONDON (AP)A dream has come true for Clyde Best, 19 yearold Negro soccer star from Bermuda.

title: Christian Science Monitor Now Using Offset Printing
description: BOSTON, May 20 (AP)The Christian Science Monitor has changed to the offset printing method for its chain of publish ing plants in Beverly, Mass.; Somerset, N.J.; Chicago, Los Angeles and London.

title: Huntley, at Luncheon, Cited As Broadcaster of Year
description: Chet Huntley, who will retire as a newscaster on Aug. 1. received the Broadcaster of the Year award yesterday from the International Radio and Television Society at its final luncheon of the year at the New York Hilton Hotel.

description: NEWARK, May 20United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. acknowledged yesterday that he once was an apparent alcoholic, but he said he had stopped drinking.

description: Following is the text of Speaker McCormack's an nouncement:

title: ERROR BY MICHAEL LEADS TO 2 RUNS
description: An error by Gene Michael set up two unearned runs in the fourth innin gand they gave the Senators a 20 victory over the Yankees last night.

title: SEAVER DEFEATED FOR SECOND TIME
description: MONTREAL, May 20With an opportunity to move into first place in the Eastern Divi sion of the National League, the New York Mets put their best arm forward tonight. But as good as it was, it wasn't good enough.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Five battalions of South Vietnamese troops with American advisers thrust across the Cambodian border yesterday in an area northeast of Saigon, between the northern most allied operation near the river Se San and the operation in the Fishhook region. No significant contact with North Vietnam ese troops was reported. The new operation plugs a large gap in the pattern of thrusts into Cambodia. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Note to Readers
description: The Treasury statement, short interest tables, the re port on insiders' stockhold ings and some of the Mid west and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations, as well as Canadian stocks and Gov ernment bond tables are omitted from this issue be cause of composing room delays caused by union meet ings.

title: NEGRO, 16, CONFESSES TO N.A.A.C.P. SLAYING
description: SAVANNAH, Ga May 20 (UPI)The Police said tonight that a 16yearold Negro boy had confessed to the fatal shooting of a longtime black leader, James M. Floyd. Sgt. Coy James said the police had taken the youth and two other Negro juveniles into cus today in the shooting last night of Mr. Floyd, 57, a member of the executive committee of the local branch of the National as sociation for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: 6 Seized on Charges of Stealing $6Million From Post Offices
description: A postal burglary ring that yielded more than $6million in United States savings and post age stamps and cash from 15 post offices in the New York metropolitan area and upstate was reportedly smashed yester day with the arrest of six sus pects.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) The following servicemen from le New York area weer adentified by the Defense De pariment today as having been killed in Southeast Asian.

title: Building Delays Shut Out Phils From New Park in '70
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP)  The Philadelphia Phil lies have given up on playing this season n the city's still unfinished $45mllion stadium, and the Eagles are not sure when they wll be able to play there.

title: HUMPHREY SCORES NIXON'S WAR MOVE
description: ST. PAUL. May 20Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey laid today that he privately warned President Nixon last fall that any step enlarging the war in Indochina would be a disaster for this country.

title: Planning Group Elects Four
description: The Regional Plan Associa tion, a research and planning agency to coordinate develop ment of the metropolitan area, has elected four new directors. They are Eugene S. Callender, president of the New York Ur ban Coalition; Mrs. Kenneth W. Greenwalt, a member of the Na tional Board of the League of Women Voters; Donald S. Myers, vice president, secretary and treasurer of the New York Telphon Company, and Jose phine Nieves first director of the department of Puerto Rican studies at Brooklyn College.

title: Queen's Epsom Derby Entry Is Easy Winner in England
description: GOODWOOD, England, May 20 (Reuters)Queen Elizabeth saw her Epsom Derby entry, Charlton, race to a convincing victory today in the Predomi nate Stakes today.

title: The Cast
description: THE LAST GRENADE, directed by Gordon Flemyng; screenplay by Ken neth Ware, adapted by James Mitchell and John Sherlock, based on the novel The Ordeal of Major Grigsby by Mr. Sherlock; produced by Josef Sheftel; released by Cinerama Releas ing Corporation. At neighborhood the aters. Runing time: 94 minutes. (The Motion Picture Association of Amer ica's Production Code and Rating Ad ministration clasilies this film: M suggested for mature audiences, paren tal discretion advised. )

title: Fund Benefits Red Cross
description: When you give to the United Fund of Greater New York, you also give to the American Red Cross. Even though many people contrib ute to their fa vorite agen cies, no one can ignore the Red Cross and the essential services it performsaid to servicemen and veterans and their families, to the Greater New York Blood Program, and to disaster services. It also offers youth programs and free courses in swim ming, life saving and first aid, and nursing services that include instructions for com munity and civic groups. When you give where you work to the United Fund of Greater New York, you also give to the Red Cross.

title: Strengthening the Economy: III
description: After inveighing against jawboning and wageprice guideposts since he took office, President Nixon is now confronted with important defections in his own ranks from this position.

title: 75 INJURED AT CIRCUS AS GUST FLIPS TENT
description: GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., May 20 (AP)At least 75 per sons, many of them children, were injured tonight when a sudden gust of wind uprooted the side of a circus tent and flinned it over.

title: TROT RACES DRAW FANS ON 2 FRONTS
description: YONKERS, May 20  Har ness racing under the aegis; of Yonkers Raceway was pre sented on two fronts, 30 miles, apart, today and tonight. The action started at 1:30 P.M. with four baby races at Roosevelt Raceway and was completed about 10 hours later with the regular nineevent card here at the Westchester County course.

title: Economic Slowdown Hampers Programs to Aid Poor in Cities
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The national economic slowdown has become so severe that it appears to be wiping out gains made in the last few years by the poor of many of the nation's big cities.

title: Brother of Slain Negro Rights Worker Held on Murder Charge
description: The younger brother of James E. Chaney, one of three civil rights workers murdered in Mississippi in 1964, was being held in Columbia, S. C., yester day with another Negro youth on charges of involvement in at least three killings in Florida and South Carolina.

title: MANY SEES LOSS IN BUYING POWER
description: George Meany described the nation's unemployment situa tion yesterday as very seri ous.

title: Party to Aid Schomburg Collection
description: Funds for the preservation of the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature and His tory will be raised Tuesday at a cocktail party and enter tainment from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. in the garden of the Mu seum of Modern Art.

title: Peter Artaserse Jr. to Marry Miss Barbara Jeanne Hensler
description: STEVENS POINT, Wis., May 20Mr. and Mrs. Ray mond L. Hensler, formerly of Rumson, N. J., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jeanne Hensler, to Peter P. Artaserse Jr., son of Judge and Mrs. Artaserse of Jersey City.

title: Trade Bars Abroad Make U. S. Restive
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 20 Secretary of the Treasury Da vid M. Kennedy bluntly warned Japan and the nations of the European Common Market to day that, if they do not lower their barriers to in creased world trade, Congress might well take action to re strict imports into the United States.

title: Big Money at Belmont
description: Belmont Park was the scene of the two top singleday purse distributions by the New York Racing Association is 1969. On Oct. 11 when the Champagne was run, purses totaled $194, 000. On Belmont Day, June 7, horseowners vied for purses of $194,200.

description: Washington at New York (8 P.M.) Hannan (00) or Shellenback (01) vs. Stottlemyre (33). Detroit

title: SAIGON'S FORCES OPEN NEW FRONT ON CAMBODIA LINE
description: DUCLAP, South Vietnam, May 20  Some 2,500 South Vietnamese soldiers supported by American air power and advisers opened a new front in Cambodia today, thrusting across the border near this Special Forces camp 125 miles northeast of Saigon.

title: BOUT OUTSIDE U.S. IS DENIED TO CLAY
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 20 (AP)  The Federal Appeals Court here denied today a request by the former heavyweight boxing champion, Cassius Clay, to leave the country for a fight with the champion, Joe Frazier, in Canada.

title: Personal Finance
description: The new tax law ap plicable this year did not make any significant changes in the realm of medical de ductions, but the pace of in flation and a more liberal attitude on the part of the Internal Revenue Service have brought about modifi cations.

title: SCHOOL APOLOGIZES FOR GAGGING OF BOY
description: LONDONA school has apologized over the case of a 5yearold boy who was gagged with sticky tape for talking in class.

title: Huge City Hall Rally Backs Nixon's Indochina Policies
description: Marching under a sea of American flags, helmeted con struction workers led tens of thousands of noisy but peaceful demonstrators yesterday in a rally and parade supporting the Vietnam policies of Presi dent Nixon and assailing Mayor Lindsay and other op ponents of the war in Indo china.

title: Noses Says Plan For Staten Island Is a Trial Balloon
description: Robert Moses characterized the proposed South Richmond project on Staten Island last night as a gaudy trial balloon which, like so many before it will float harmlessly off into space and evaporate.

title: Hudson County G.O.P. Chief Indicted
description: NEWARK, May 20The Re publican chairman of Hudson County and a reputed Mafia figure were indicted by the state grand jury in Trenton to day on charges of conspiring to gain the appointment of Hudson Prosecutor who would not move against gambling.

title: Investigating the Police
description: The panel of five city officials established by the Mayor to sift complaints of police corruption has wisely recommended that its work be assumed by a wholly independent citizens group to avoid even the appearance of any conflict of interest. In making this recommendation, the panel disclosed that it received 375 specific complaints of police corruption in the brief period of its operation. There can be no doubt that the problem exists and requires fuller examination.

title: LIBERALS IN HOUSE AIM FOR NO. 2 JOB
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The departure of John W. McCor mack, one of the Capitol's most conspicuous symbols of the Old Politics, may not usher in that new era in the House of Repre sentatives that his critics have been seeking at all.

title: Instant Basements Offered By Canadian HomeBuilder

title: 'I Am Curious (Blue)' Colors a Collage of People
description: Aside from the fact that "I Am Curious (Blue)," which opened yesterday at the Evergreen, Cine Malibu and neighborhood theaters is decidedly less blue than "I Am Curious (Yellow)," it is so similar to the first that it almost seems to be the same movie, which indeed, it is.When he was making his film in 1966 and 1967, Vilgot Sjoman, the Swedish director, called it simply "I Am Curious," and in its first rough cut, its running time was something more than three hours. Sjoman thereupon took the footage and edited it into the two parallel films that can be immediately distinguished only by the title parentheses, which refer to the colors of the Swedish flag.Sjoman has thus been able to indulge himself in a way denied to most movie directors, who judge every bit of exposed film to be unique and dear. If "I Am Curious" were nothing else (and I think it is), it would still be noteworthy in cinematic history as a stunt, one that recalls Billy Wilder's suggestion that Hollywood give an Oscar each year to the most successful wheeler-dealer.One West Coast critic, who saw both films back-to-back at the Sandrews screening room in Stockholm, has written a long and careful essay in Film Quarterly noting the schematic differences in the two. 'Yellow," he says, emphasizes social ills and is "a man's film." "Blue," a woman's film, is "more concerned with the relations between people." It's possible to make such distinctions, but it's difficult and precious work, and I'm not at all sure it's really valid."Because "Yellow" and "Blue" were conceived as a single film, they overlap and reiterate each other, and to discuss them as separate works is no more rewarding than seeking out the differences between the first 16 chapters of "Women in Love" and the last 15.As in "Yellow," Sjman, who describes himself in one of "Blue's" many title cards, slogans and chapter headings as a "young film director, age 42," is his own leading actor, playing a film director named Vilgot Sjman, who is making a movie starring Lena Nyman, age 20, with whom he is having a rather bumpy, unsatisfactory affair.Mostly through Lena, both the actress in real life and the character in the film-within-the-film, Sjman conducts a relentless, often very funny inquiry into Swedish political, social and sexual attitudes. Sjman's methods amounts to a kind of cinematic collage consisting of man-in-the-street interviews, fiction, still photographs, posters and newsreels.Not so surprisingly, smugness and hypocrisy are rampant. Nobody quite manages to practice what he preaches. One of Lena's former lovers, the man who schooled her in nonviolence, can only make love after he has beaten up his partner-to-be. Lena herself spends a lot of time trying to be unfaithful to Sjman with Borge Ahlstedt, her co-star in the film-within-the-film.In "Yellow," Lena was militantly concerned on behalf of disarmament and peace. In "Blue," she is concerned with women's liberation, with religion and with prison reform. As in "Yellow," she exhibits a marvelous faith in the efficacy of home-made, wall posters ("Message to the Prison Board/You have stopped thinking radical").In "Yellow," it was often impossible to tell whether you were watching the main film, or the film-within. There is no such confusion in "Blue," but because the differences between the frame and the interior movie are so slight, they effectively become a single, slightly mocking experience.I'm not very fond of this sort of moviemaking, which tries to disarm conventional criticism by exploiting formlessness as meaningful itself, but I like Sjoman's sense of humor and sense of humanity, and his obvious affection for Lena of the earnest, pretty face and the somewhat rotund figure that betrays every candy bar she has ever eaten. It looks like real love.

title: Screen: 'Last Grenade':Mercenaries in Battle While Love Blooms
description: Gordon Flemyng, as director, is faced with an insuperable tactical problem in "The Last Grenade," which landed with a dull thud at local houses yesterday. He is simultaneously manipulating a sanguinary vendetta between tough mercenary fighters, Stanley Baker and Alex Cord, and a sudden, improbable love affair between Mr. Baker and Honor Blackman, the general's lady. The crossfire between the battlers and the boudoir is a deadly Anglo-American standoff that would befuddle any commander as well as an attentive viewer.Sadly enough, neither the script nor the director and his athletic cast do or say anything impressive enough to justify a willing observer's wholehearted belief in the half hectic, half romantic proceedings, which were shot in good color in Hong Kong and in Spanish and London locales. The reason for all the shooting? Mr. Baker, as a former English major who has been clandestinely fighting Chinese Communists near Hong Kong, has seen Mr. Cord, an erstwhile American buddy, turn on him  for money, of courseand he is out to get him on secret orders from Whitehall. Mr. Cord, an equally wily operator, is, naturally, a hard man to get.Why Miss Blackman, the cool, willowy, seemingly happy wife of Richard Attenborough, a slight caricature of the clipped speech, reserved but appreciative general, should develop an instant passion for Mr. Baker, a gruff, insulting type she detests at first, is one of this adventure's minor mysteries. Nor is it explained completely why Mr. Baker, apparently a terminal tubercular case despite his droopy mustache, hard exterior and grim dedication to seek out and destroy his enemy, should take time out for dalliance.Mr. Cord, wearing an equally droopy mustache, unshorn locks that would not be out of place among the mod set of London's King's Road and given to such hip dialogue as "I got some heavy bread to lay on you, man," appears to be somewhat of a displaced preson in the Communist-held Hong Kong hinterland. Even though most of the principals are dispatched with "The Last Grenade," the end leaves a disturbing, unanswered question. Mr. Cord constantly wears a Dartmouth sweatshirt while cackling sophomorically after each kill and twirling his six-shooter, Western style. Why involve the Ivy League, which has its own problems, in Far Eastern Communist imbroglios?

title: Short Interest Gained In Month Ended May 15
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange increased 374,084 shares in the month ended May 15, marking the sec ond consecutive monthly in crease for this widely watched stockmarket indicator. Accord ing to figures released by the exchange yesterday, the total short interest as of the mid May settlement date was 14, 579.740 shares up from 14,205, 656 at midApril. The total was the highest since the month ended last Dec. 15, when short interest reached 16,862,771 shares.

title: M'CORMACK SAYS HE WILL NOT SEEK NEW HOUSE TERM
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Speaker of the House John W. McCormack announced today that he would retire from Con gress at the end of this session.

title: Hill, Gifford Head Program
description: Calvin Hill of the Dallas Cow boys, a divinity student at Southern Methodist, will give the invocation and Frank Gif ford will be the master of cere monies at the annual dinner on Monday in the Americana Hotel of the New York Chapter of the Pro Football Writers Asso ciation.

title: Another Massengale on Links
description: Rik Massengale, 22yearold brother of Don, the pro golfer, won the Southeast Conference golf title this year playing for the University of Texas.

title: 50 Hurt in School Bus Blast
description: REXBURG, Idaho, May 20 (UPI)About 50 students were injured today when a vial of hydrochloric and nitric acid ex ploded on a school bus. Sheriff Jeff Butts of Fremont County said a 15yearold high school student, James Johnson, had been given the vial of acid by his biology teacher to conduct a home experiment.

title: Indefinite Stay by Saigon Troops In Cambodia Hinted by General
description: BIENHOA, South Vietnam, May 20A South Vietnamese general hinted today that South Vietnamese troops would stay in Cambodia until the Vietcong and North Vietnamese were driven back to North Vietnam.

title: Market Summaries
description: (Volume 3,820,470 shares)

title: U.S. Urges ABM's Protect Washington And Moscow Only
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The United States has proposed to the Soviet Union a strategic. arms control agreement under which the two sides would be limited to missile defense sys tems protecting Washington and Moscow.

title: U.S. FINDS THE COST OF OPERATING A CAR
description: WASHINGTONThe Ameri can Motorist spends more on parking and tollroad fees than he does for taxes to build and maintain the highways over which he drives.

title: Bay State Democrat to Run
description: BOSTON, May 20 (AP)The president of the Massachusetts Senate, Maurice A. Donahue, announced yesterday that he was a candidate for the Demo cratic gubernatorial nomination. The Rolyoke lawmaker has two Democratic opponents for the nomination, Mayor Kevin H. White, of Boston and Kenneth P. O'Donnell, former assistant to President Kennedy.

title: City Says Detective Sold Data in Files For $10,000 Yearly
description: A detective assigned to po lice headquarters here has been suspended on charges that he was making more than $10,000 a year selling confidential in formation from police files to banks, airlines, detective agen cies and other companies.

title: Sifford Cot 28 for 9 Holes
description: The best ninehole score on the 1969 Professional Golfers' Association golf tour was turned in by Charles Sifford in the Los Angeles Open. He shot a 28.

title: Pollution Ticket for Ship
description: CHICAGO May 20, (UPI) City officials have flagged down a ship on lake Michigan and handed the captain a ticket. The Environmental Control Commissioner H. Wallace Poston, said he had noticed dense smoke from the freighter Ferndale as he was driving to lunch Monday at a yacht club. He called the police and order ed a boat. It was the city's first air pollution ticket for a ship under steam.

title: Washington: For the Record
Decision on the SST
description: Present indications suggest that the supersonic transport program will face the most determined oppo sition to date when its fiscal 1971 appropriation comes before the House of Representatives next week. One reason, though not necessarily the most important, the fact that the appropriation requested by the Nixon Administration, almost $290 million, is the largest for any single year to date. The incongruity between the massive spending for SST and the crippling limitations on funds available for much more pressing national needs is only too evident.

title: The Shattering of a Routine Day
description: At midafternoon yesterday, Anna Bovino lay under a white sheet in a mobil stretcher in a corridor of the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Portugal Eases Curbs, but Only Slightly
description: LISBON, May 20The Portu guese are openly showing their cigarette lighters now, without fear of prosecution or denunci ation. This and other smaller movements reflect a slight liber alization of the Portuguese re gime, but Premier Marcello Caetano has not taken action to restore fundamental freedoms.

title: SLIGHT GAIN SEEN IN 1970 BUSINESS
description: BOSTON, May 20Business in 1970 should be a little bet tor than 1969, but not much.

title: PROPOSAL IS FILED IN SIMMONDS SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)The Justice Department today filed a proposed antitrust settlement that would require Simmonds Precision Products, Inc., of Tarrytown, N. Y., to sell its Liauidometer division.

title: New Guinea Bans Leg Irons
description: PORT MORESBY, New Guinea (Reuters)  The Papua  New Guinea administration has banned the use of leg irons and similar devices in its jails.

title: The Laughing Woman Arrives at Neighborhoods
U.S. Acknowledges South Vietnamese May Remain in Cambodia After June 30
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  The United States today pub licly acknowledged for the first time the possibility that South Vietnamese troops might re main in Cambodia after the withdrawal of United States forces, scheduled to be com pleted by June 30.

title: Czechs Score Rock Bands
description: PRAGUE (AP)  Czechoslo vak rock bands that have such names as Hoboes and Sky walkers are kowtowing to a foreign language and culture, the Communist party paper Rude Provo complained.

title: U.S. Holds 6% Rail Rate Rise Set for June 2 Is Unjustified
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The Nixon Administration challenged today the railroad industry's claim that economic disaster will follow if it is denied a 6 per cent acrossthe board increase in freight rates.

title: 160Mile Everglades Hike SpursRise of Florida Trail
description: NAPLES, Fla, (AP)  The Florida Trail is being blazed because James Kern, a Miami realestate man, likes to hike.

title: Welcome, Class of '70
description: Of the first 10 college football players drafted by the National Football League, only five are expected to be graduated with their classes. Teammates of the top 10, a fairly representative sampling of the next 432 players selected, had a slightly greater proportion of baccalau reatestobe: 23 of 41 would be graduated with their classes.

title: Key Cambodian Road Cleared
description: TAKEO, Cambodia, May 20 (Agence FrancePresse)South Vietnamese troops linked up with Cambodian soldiers today in a small town 25 miles north of here after a crosscountry drive from the South Vietna mese border in which they re ported killing more than 400 Vietcong.

title: Other Merger Moves
description: In other merger develop ments, the MGIC Investment Corporation said it has agreed to buy 56 per cent of the cur rently outstanding common stock of the CIC Leasing Cor poration, Buffalo, N. Y., from the Coburn Corporation of America. Terms call for a cash purchase totaling $3,007,215, or $5 a share, for the CIC com mon. Terms include purchase from Coburn of $3,500,000 of S per cent debentures converti ble into common of CIC Leas ing at $5.50 a share. Also MGIC will guarantee CIC's debt of $5,500,000 to Coburn.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: I am concerned about the suggestion of a simple causal relation between environmental contamination and population growth. This juxtaposition has been placed in the minds of the public by advertising by special interest groups, news paper editorials and magazine articles.

title: Everglades Funds Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) An additional authorization of $20million to enable the Government to acquire the re maining 58,400 acres of private ly owned land in the Everglades National Park in South Florida was urged yesterday by Sena tor Spessard L. Holland, Demo crat of Florida and George B. Hertzog, Jr., director of the National Park Service, in testi many to a Senate Interior sub committee.

title: Cuba's Infant Deaths Rise
description: MIAMI (AP)Dr. Iielindoro Martinez Junco, Cuba's Health Minister, reports that the in fant mortality rate is on the increase in our entire country.

title: Nixon Aide, Voices Concern
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20 Mrs. Virginia Knauer, Presi dential assistant for consumer affairs, said today that 30 per cent of community water sup ply samples taken in a Federal survey had shown excessive amounts of germs and chem icals.

title: NEGRO EDUCATORS IN PLEA TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Fif teen presidents of predominant ly black colleges and universi ties told President Nixon today that his policies had led to anger, outrage and frustration among the nation's Negroes.

title: LIVING COSTS HERE UP 3% IN 4 MONTHS
description: The Consumer Price Index in the New York metropolitan area rose by 0.7 per cent last month, pushing the total in crease for the first four months of this year to 3 per cent  the biggest jump recorded in a similar period since the war boom days of 1943.

title: ANTIU. S. REVOLT IS URGED BY MAO
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, May 21In one of his rare public pronouncements, Mao Tsetung, Chairman of the Chinese Com munist party, issued a personal call yesterday for world revolu tion against United States im perialism.

title: Abernathy Asks Nixon to Protect Georgia Marchers
description: FORT VALLEY, Ga., May 20  The Rev. Ralph David Aber nathy appealed to President Nixon today to provide Fed eral protection for the march against repression, the 110 mile, fourday walk to Atlanta that began yesterday in Perry, Ga.

title: FIFTH AVE. COACH ADJOURNS SESSION
description: The longawaited annual meeting of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., was ad journed yesterday without tak ing any action when it was determined that there was not a quorum present.

title: Government Pacifies War Critic, 9
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 Commissioner of Education James E. Allen Jr. has sent a letter of conciliation to a 9yearold California girl who had received a harsh reply to her criticism of the war.

title: Article 1  No Title
Credibility of Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The credibility of the Nixon Ad ministration's efforts to control the Federal budget was dealt another blow by the disclosure, yesterday of new and more realistic estimates of spending and receipts for the current and the new fiscal years. The one striking fact that emerges from the flood of figures is this: Be tween Feb. 2 and May 19, the Gov ernment's estimate of what it would spend in fiscal year 1971 was increased by $4.8billionand this before the fiscal year has even begun.

title: Synagogue Scene Of Soviet Protest By Jewish League
description: Fifty members of the Jewish Defense League occupied an Orthodox synagogue opposite the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday to protest persecution of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: ULOZAS RETAINS DODGE GOLF LEAD
description: DENVILLE, N. J., May 20 Tom Ulozas, a 27yearold pro fessional from Bamm Hollow, added a secondround 71 to his firstday 68 to retain the lead in the $25,000 Dodge open golf tournament over the lush Rock away River Country Club course today.

title: Nixon Facing G.O.P. Revolt on Curb on War Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The White House was reportedly faced today with the possibility of a revolt by some moderate and liberal Republican Senators if it failed to go along with an amendment cutting off funds for future military involvement in Cambodia.

title: Peeved Adderley Insists He Won't Play for Packers
description: In these times of discontent, one pro football player rea vowed his protest yesterday while another received an ex tra chance. Herb Adderley, at odds with the Packers since the end of last season, said he would retire rather than re turn to Green Bay.

title: CAMPAGNA NEXT, 4 LENGTHS BACK
description: Deceit, E. P. Taylor's un defeated filly, extended her victory streak to four in taking the $29,750 Fashion Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The Ken tuckybred daughter of Prince John and Double Agent surged in the stretch to overtake the frontrunning Campagna, whom she defeated by four lengths. Campagna, with Jorge Velas quez up, had another four lengths on the third finisher, Lady Herald.

title: Manufacturers Join Unions in Urging Textile Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The American Textile Manu facturers Institute was joined by the Textile Workers Union of America in urging the House Ways and Means Committee today to enact legislation on textileimport quotas.

title: G. Mennen Williams in Race
description: DETROIT, May 20 (UPI)  Former Gov. G. Mennen wil liams announced yesterday his candidacy for Justice of the Michigan Supreme Court. Mr. Willians, 59 years old, most re cently served as Assistant Sec retary of State for African Af fairs and as Ambassador to the Philippines in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

title: Nixon to Offer Formula on Funds to Aid Desegregating Schools
description: WASHINGTON. May 20 President Nixon is expected to ask Congress tomorrow for $500million, including $150 million on an emergency basis, to ease school desegregation problems in the next fiscal year.

title: NegligeeWearing Waitress Is Ordered to Don Clothes
description: LIVERPOOL, England (UPI) Nick Watson, having a run of bad business at his cafe, added 18yearold Miss Diane Bell as waitressin a seethrough neg ligee.

title: Columbia Club Names Head
description: The election of John T. Garn jost as president of the Colum bia University Club was an nounced yesterday. Mr. Garn jost, who at 35 is the youngest president in the club's history, is a financial analyst for the BristolMyers Company.

title: For the Flag and for Country, They March
description: The rally and march in sup port of President Nixon's Indo lchina policy, held yesterday in lower Manhattan, included blue collar workers, businessmen, secretaries and housewives, Here is a random sampling of some marchers and their views:

title: Thursday Baseball
Text of 20Point Plan Presented by Brandt to Stoph
description: KASSEL, West Germany, May 21Following in an un official translation from the German is the text of a 20 point proposal offered today by Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany to Premier With Stoph of East Germany:

title: Thailand May Aid Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 21 (Reuters)Thailand is ready to give military equipment and medical aid to Cambodia. In terior Minister Praphas Cha rusathien said in a news con ference today. He said that Premier Thanon Kittikachorn indicated this to the Cambodian Foreign Minister, Yem Sam baur, who paid a visit here this week on his way home from the Asian conference in Jakarta.

title: The Screen: Bo Widerberg's 'Raven's End'
description: Anders (Thommy Berggren), a remarkably patient, sensitive young man, sits in an ancient armchair, brooding. His first novel has just been rejected, although the publishers have offered encouragement. His mother is at the dining room table, torturing her hair with an antique curling iron. "Whenever I smell burn, hair," says Anders, "I know we're off to the circus." "It's not the animals and the music I like," says his mother. "It's because we actually go."Bo Widerberg's "Raven's End," set in 1936 in the working class district of Malmo, Sweden, that gives the film its title, is not only about the 1930's but also it has a kind of 1930's literacy sensibility. It is a fine, full cinematic equivalent to those novels by young, socially conscious writers who once started their careers by writing about young, socially conscious writers trying to move out of closed environments (and who, quite often, wound up with houses in Hollywood and Gstaad).For most of "Raven's End," nobody goes anywhere, not even to the circus. Finally, however, Anders, faced with a future with the pregnant girl he doesn't want to marry, and with the spectacle of his alcoholic father who knows how to smoke cigars properly but not how to pass out handbills ("Can I help it," asks his father, "if I have good taste?"), abandons Raven's End for what could be a career as a novelist, and maybe even as a film director."Raven's End," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater with Chris Marker's "Letter From Siberia," was shown at the 1965 New York Film Festival and preceded the production of Widerberg's "Elvira Madigan" and "Adalen 31." It is actually the Swedish director's second feature (his first, "The Baby Carriage," has not been released here), but, if we are receiving Widerberg's movies in reverse chronological order, we also are receiving them in an ascending order of excellence.Of the three Widerberg films seen in this country, "Raven's End" most perfectly integrates the director's exuberant lyricism and the social consciousness he wears on his sleeve.Widerberg, who was a novelist before becoming a movie director, makes movies with a novelist's appreciation for detail of time and place, character and speech. "Raven's End" has a completeness to it that seems almost archaic today. Throughout the film, you are aware of a world outside Raven's End, whether it is communicated by radio broadcasts from the German Olympics, or by Anders's friend fantasizing about French whores who wear fur coats in summer as well as winter coats.Widerberg also shoots his scenes with an equivalent visual thoroughness, moving from close-ups of people to long shots of places, often without cutting. The characters behave with an exasperating, touching contrariness made up of love and hate and exhaustion, and they talk well. "A cigar," lectures Anders's father, "should never be stubbed out. It should die in the ash tray, its band like a shroud, until the servants carry it away."Berggren (who played the young officer of "Elvira Madigan"), Keve Hjelm (his father) and Emy Storm (his mother) are all admirable.Chris Marker's "Letters from Siberia" is a 60-minute, documentary made by the French director of "Joli Mai" and "The Koumiko Mystery" in 1957. There are lots of shots of vast forests, broad rivers, dams, hydroelectric plants and new cities, all accompanied by English narration that is full of statistics and occasional attempts to satirize its own, rather stolid form. The whole thing looks quite safely "authorized," but that doesn't make it any less interesting. I meanhow many Siberian travelogues have you seen recently?

title: Murder Conviction in Ohio
description: CINCINNATI, May 21 (UPI) Raymond Kassow, 24 years old, was found guilty of firstdegree murder in connection with the laying of four women in a sav ings and loan company holdup last year. Kassow and two other men found guilty of murder in the same case will be formally sentenced later.

title: Prosecutors Explain Court Delays
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has told a panel of Fed eral judges that criminal courts in Manhattan are so badly overcrowded and congested that many defendants seek de lays in hopes that he will re duce the charges against them.

title: Trainmen Ask Court To Ban All Diesels From Grand Central
description: Contending that its members are being forced to breathe noxious, unwholesome, and in jurious oil fumes, the United Transportation Union has sought a court order to prevent the Penn Central from operat ing diesel locomotives at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: (Hours are given in Eastern Standard Time.)

title: Xerox Forecasts Sales and Net Rise For the Full Year
description: The Xerox Corporation ex pects to have very substan tial increases both in revenues and profits this year, C. Peter McColough, president, told some 2,000 stockholders at yes terday's annual meeting in the Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden.

title: Court Pardons Drinker Who Lost Son in Vietnam
description: BUFFALO, May 21 (AP) Natheniel James stood before a City Court judge today, accused of public intoxica tion. Were you drunk? Judge Michael E. Zimmer asked Mr. James, 43 years old.

title: METS PRIME BATS FOR CUBS TONIGHT
description: When the New York Mets open a fourgame weekend se ries against the Chicago Cubs tonight, Shea Stadium will be vibrating with at least 50,000 spectators.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS PUSH ARMS TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 The United States and the So viet Union are discussing an agreement on the control of strategic arms that would im pose a freeze on the current level of offensive missiles and would limit antiballisticmis sile defense to the protection of Washington and Moscow.

title: A.B.A. Playoff
description: (4of7 game series)

title: SAIGON IS QUERIED ON PULLOUT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The Nixon Administration, clearly embarrassed by the controver sy over the future status of South Vietnamese forces in Cambodia, was reported today to have instructed its two senior representatives in Sai gon to discuss the problem urgently with the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.I

title: Leader Tells Jews They Are Obligated To Aid City Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, May 21An American Jewish leader criti cized Jewish organizations to night, saying they had failed to confront the problems of the inner city.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MOUNTAINDALE, N. Y. He tripped frequently over his long poncho and cold rain dripped off the end of his nose, but little 12yearold Jay De Pol was altogether happy.

title: 2 Man of Conscience Awards To Be Presented on Tuesday
description: Man of Conscience awards will be presented to J. Peter Grace, president of W. R. Grace & Co., and Gustave L. Levy, senior partner of Gold man, Sachs & Co., at a din ner dance sponsored by the Appeal of Conscience Foun dation at the Plaza on Tues day.

title: JENS NYGAARD LEADS WESTCHESTER GROUP
description: The Westchester Chamber Chorus and Orchestra is a small organization for such a large name. As heard Wednes day night at Carnegie Recital Hall, the chorus was 19 strong, and the orchestra at its largest had all of four players: three strings and organ in the Schu bert Mass in C. Three more players were heard in two VillaLobos works, the Bachia nas Brasileiras No. 6 for flute and bassoon and the Choros No. 2 for flute and clarinet.

title: Note to Readers
description: The box scores of all base ball games between nonlocal teams are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: Barnard Girl Held As Drug Supplier
description: A 21yearold Phi Beta Kappa student at Barnard College was arrested last night and charged with being a major supplier of drugs at Columbia Univer sity after detectives said they found $100,000 worth of illegal drugs in her Upper West Side apartment.

title: New Books
description: From Dillomacy to Resistance: A History of Jewish Palestine. 19391945. by Ychuda Bauer, translated from the Hebrew by Alton M. Winters (Jewish Pub lication Society of America; Philadelphia, $6).

title: PRESBYTERIANS ELECT INDIANAN
description: CHICAGO, May 21  A 54 year  old Indiana preacher is the new moderator of the 3.2 million member United Presby terian Church.

title: Swift Mile Is Foreseen Tonight As Yonkers Pacing Series Ends
description: YONKERS, May 21An over abundance of speed may help fashion the season's fastest mile when eight freeforall stand ardbreds go to the post for the National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Even if a somewhat unseasonable bliz zard were to swirl into Shea Stadium today, the chances are that Ernie Banks of the Chicago Cubs would hardly notice it. What a beautiful day for baseball! he probably would exclaim with all the joyous enthusiasm that has kept him young throughout his 18 years as a bigleague ballplayer.

title: SCHOLARS SEE CRISIS ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: A poll of 394 political scien tists who teach at United States colleges shows that, if Ameri can involvement in Indochina continues at its present level, twothirds fear a struggle be tween the President and Con gress over whose decision on foreign policy shall prevail.

title: WEDNESDAY NIGHT FIGHT
description: Las Vegas, Nev.  Polo Corona, 164 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed Ronnie Wilson, 166, San Diego, 10 rounds.

title: Greyhound Clarifies Its Armour Stand
description: CHICAGO, May 21  Ger ald H. Trautman, president and chief executive officer of the Greyhound Corporation, in press conference here today ex panded on some of the details of the fight for control of Ar mour & Co., which has been going on for 16 months be tween the General Host Corpor ation and Greyhound.

title: Dr. William Levine, Headed Brookclale Center Division
description: Dr. William Levine, director of the department of obstetrics and gynecology of Brookdale Hospital Center from 1953 to 1963, died Wednesday in Pres byterian Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 303 Beach 149th Street, Neponsit, Queens.

title: Democrats Fire Salvo
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (Reu ters)Democrats were quick to zero in on the Administra tion today after the disclosure of the latest upward leap in the cost of living.

title: Nixon Signs Tax Bill to Improve Aviation Facilities
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  President Nixon signed today a vast development program for aviation facilities, designed to meet an expected threefold increase in the use of air trans portation in the 1970's.

title: InHospitalsOnly Rule Drafted for Abortions
description: City health authorities said yesterday that abortions should be performed only in hospitals when the liberalized law goes into effect on July 1. and they indicated that hospitalization would he made mandatory later.

title: SOVIET DISAVOWS THREAT TO ISRAEL
description: MOSCOW, May 21The So viet Union appeared today to be opening a campaign to dis credit charges that its military and to the United Arab Repub lic threatened the security of Israel.

title: Bridge
description: If there was an award for outstanding performance in amateur bridge organization it would surely go to Mrs. Samuel Stayman, known to all tournament players here as Tubby. Largely due to her efforts, the annual charity game of the United Jewish Appeal produces more money for a worthy cause than any comparable event anywhere in the world.

title: Samuel (Cappy) Hoffman, Vice King of Atlantic City
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (UPI)  Samuel (Cappy) Hoff man, who had a reputation vice king of Atlantic City in the 1930's died of cancer ves terday at Lankenau Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Medical Checkups on Rise
description: ATLANTA, May 21 (UPI) Sixtytwo per cent of Ameri cans, or 7 per cent more than in 1961, were getting medical checkups in 1970, the American (Cancer Society reported yester day. William B. Lewis, chair man of the hoard of the society, reported the findings which were made in a nationwide Gallup study.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: As a clergyman who for fifty years in the parish ministry has been a member of most of the peace, interfaith and ecumeni cal agencies. I plead for under standing and support of Presi dent Nixon in his efforts to achieve peace.

title: Theater: Engagement Baby Arrives
description: There is so little that need he said of a poor minor comedy, The Engagement Baby, which turned up at the Helen Hayes Theater last night, that I find it difficult to raaise the energy to say it. It was written by some one called Stanley Shapiro, who once won an Academy Award for a Doris Day movie. He should have rested on his laurels.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Treasury statement, Federal Reserve tables, stock market highs and lows, and some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations are omitted from this issue because of com posing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: JACKSON FUNERAL TO DRAW LEADERS
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 21 The funeral of a 17yearold Negro delivery boy, shot down at Jackson State College by Mississippi highway patrolmen, was expected to bring together tomorrow the largest group of civil rights sympathizers since the funeral of the Rev. Dr. Mar tin Luther King Jr. two years ago in Atlanta.

title: Soviet Craft at Peak Speed
description: MOSCOW, May 21 (UPI) The Soviet Union's supersonic jetliner has broken the sound barrier for the second time and has attained its highest speed since flight tests began in 1968.

title: MICHAEL CUDAHY, MEAT PACKER, 83
description: MILWAUKEE, May 21 Michael F. Cudahy, hoard chair man of Patrick Cudahy, Inc., the meat processing company, died in a Milwaukee nursing home last night after a stroke. He would have been 84 years old next Wednesday.

title: L.I.U. HEAD TAKING TOP POST AT CLARE
description: Glenn Walker Ferguson, Chancellor of Long Island Uni versity for 11 months, an nounced yesterday that he was resigning, effective July 1, to become the president of Clark University in Worcester, Mass.

title: SYDNEY R. REDECKER OF FOREIGN SERVICE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 21  Sydney Brayton Redecker, retired career Foreign Service officer, died yesterday in Green wich Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here at 111 Park Avenue.

title: Ky Says Troops Will Stay
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. May 21Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky declared today that South Vietnamese troops were deter mined to remain in Cambodia after the planned withdrawal of American troops from that country by the end of June.

title: TRICKETT AND TUFT OFFER FOLK SONGS
description: The bright, ringing sound of a hammered dulcimer enlivened a program of folk songs by Ed Trickett and Harry Tuft on Wednesday night at the Wash ington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: Dance: Classic Criterion
description: The classics remain the touch stone of ballet, and while the Royal Ballet's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House is past the midway mark, there could not fail to be an opening night flavor to its first Swan Lake of the season Wednesday evening. Antoinette Sibley and Anthony Dowell headed the superb cast.

title: Police Admit Panther Informer Lied and Was a Mental Patient
description: A Brooklyn police detective testified yesterday that he had obtained information about Black Panther party activities for $100 a week from a con fidential informant who was a member of the party.

title: LINDSAY APPOINTS CORRUPTION UNIT
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of a special fiveman commission to investigate charges of wide spread police corruption in New York City. The group also is to develop methods to pre vent departmental corruption.

title: Suffolk School Strike Ends
description: LINDENHURST, L. May 21 An 11day strike by members of the Lindenhurst Teachers Association ended early today when negotiators for the School Board and the association agreed to submit their differ ences to binding arbitration. The strike by 583 teachers had closed all II schools and af fected 11,000 students.

title: Brochure Backs Wallace
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. (UPI) The Ku Klux Klan mailed edi tions today of its monthly mag azine and included a 24page campaign brochure supporting George C. Wallace for Governor of Alabama. The brochure, en titled The Life of George C. Wallace, is an official cam paign publication. On the last page is a notation that it was paid for by Mr. Wallace's broth er, Jack W. Wallace.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MAY 22, 1970

title: Fanny May Picks Clay as Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Retired General Lucius D. Clay was picked today as the first board chairman of the Federal National Mortgage As sociation after its reorganiza tion as a private corporation.

title: 9 Hurt as Police Disperse Group in Midtown After City Hall Peace Rally
description: Nine antiwar demonstrators were injured yesterday when the police forcibly dispersed at Avenue of the Americas and 39th Street a militant group that had marched uptown from a peace rally of 20,000 at City Hall.

title: Woodcock Assured Post As Auto Union President
description: DETROIT, May 21  The elevation of Leonard Woodcock to president of the United Auto mobile Workers was assured today by the withdrawal of his single opponent.

title: COUNTS OF LAKERS IS TRADED TO SUNS
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 21 (AP) The Phoenix Suns of the Na tional Basketball Association today acquired MeI Counts, a 7foot center, from the Los An geles Lakers for Gail Goodrich, a guard.

title: Article 2  No Title
Childrens' Group Elects
description: The Citizens Committee for Children of New York, Inc., 112 East 19th Stret, yesterday elected Mrs. Thomas B. Hess president. She succeeded Mrs. Milton Gordon. Mrs. Hess, chairman of the children's rights section of the commit tee and long a director, is a member of the board of the Elearnor Roosevelt Foundation and a trustee of the John F. Kennedy Library. The commit tee is a non profit organization devoted to improving services for children and to protectig the rights of children.

title: Beaches Open Tomorrow
description: The city's eignt oeacnes will open tomorrow for the season, August Heckscher, the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator, announced yes terday. The 27 municipal out door pools will open May 30.

title: PRICES SLIP AGAIN ON LONDON BOARD
Park of Rangers Is Named To First Team of AllStars
description: Brad Park became the young est Ranger ever seleected to the National Hockey League's allstar team yesterday. The 21yearold defenseman joined Bobby Orr on the defensive pairings for the first team.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES SHOW SHARP RISE
description: Heavy buying by commercial interests and large local pro fessionals, together with heavy exports, sent soybean futures prices soaring yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Memorial Services
description: MORGANMary Ellen, of New York city and Reston, Virginia, on May 16, 1970. Memorial services 2 P.M. Sunday May 24, 1970, at First United Presbyterian Church, 54th St. and Queens Blvd., Elmhurst, L.I.

title: RACE WIDE OPEN FOR ALBERT POST
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 With Representative Carl Al bert of Oklahoma all but as sured of the speakership, House Democrats turned their attention today to a wideopen race for majority leader among a halfdozen or more candi dates.

title: Hickel Aide Explains Delay In Oil Shales' Development
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)  Secretary of the Inte rior Walter J. Hickel delayed the private development of Western oil share resources be cause of possible damage to the environment, an offical for the Interior Department told Con gress today.

title: ALFRED B. LORBER, 49, LED MUSIC CONCERN
description: TEANECK, N. J., May 21  Alfred B. Lorber, president of the Transcontinental Music Corporation and a former vice president of the Columbia Rec ords division of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of cancer today at Englewood Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived at 631 Wyndham Road.

title: AMEX PRICES SLIP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Prices took another beating on the American Stock Ex change yesterday in the heavi est trading of the year.

title: ULOZAS, WITH 286, WINS DODGE OPEN
description: DENVILLE, N. J,. May 21 It took Tom Ulozas, the 27year old pro at Banun Hollow, about four minutes to add his final scorecard. Amid the sound of spectators' voices in the scorer's tent, Ulozas just was making sure that his figures were correct.

title: Tornado Toll Reaches 26
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., May 21 (UPI)A tornado May 11 that injured 1,000 persons and caused $150million in damages took its 26th victim today. Helen Valdez Alafa, 30 years old, died in West Texas Hospi tal of injuries she received when the twister struck her home.

title: Washington: Are the Democrats Serious?
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Now that Speaker McCormack of Massachusetts and the House of Representatives has an nounced his retirement, the Democratic party has a problem and an opportunity. As the party in opposition, it has been howling at the Nixon Adminis tration to change with the changing times, and now it has a chance to change itself.

title: Four Dialogues on Germany
description: BONN, May 21Four in ternational dialogues involv ing Germany are currently under way. According to most of the participants, they are so intimately connected that the failure of one would gravely prejudice the others. The four, none of which has reached the negotiating stage, are the following:

title: Shirley Chisholm: Willing to Speak Out
description: Mrs. Shirley Chisholm, who went to Congress as the first black woman member of the House of Representatives 16 months ago, sat forward in her office chair and suc cinctly assessed herself and her colleagues.

title: Rockefeller Vetoes Film Bill
description: ALBANY, May 21 (UPI)  Governor Rockefeller today vetoed legislation that would have made it a felony to ex hibit a motion picture that de picts nudity, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse which would be harmful to minors at locations near public high ways so that the pictures could be viewed by persons not actu ally inside the drivein theater. Mr. Rockefeller said the bill was too broad in its scope.

title: Nixon Says Budget Allows Easing of Monetary Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  President Nixon said today that the Government's budget, despite recent revisions that throw it into deficit this year and next, is still restrictive enough to permit easing of monetary policy.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Reed Athlete of the Month
description: Willis Reed of the New York Knickerbockers was voted pro fesssional athlete of April yes terday in the S. Rae Hickock balloting.

title: A General Strike Is Threatened in Italy
description: ROME, May 21 (Reuters)A general strike was threatened, today by three major labor un ion federations dissatisfied with a Government pledge for social and economic reform.

title: DARIUS A. DAVIS, 87, AIDED WAR CAPTIVES
description: WESTWOOD, N.J., May 21 Darius A. Davis, who directed aid to war prisoners for the Young Men's Christian Associa tion during both World Wars, died here yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived at 90 Hurlbut Street.

title: Sing Sing Loses Chair
description: OSSINING, N.Y., May 21 (AP) Sing Sing Prison's electric chair was moved yesterday to Grren Haven Prison in Storm ville. The chair installed in 1891 has been used in 614 legal ex ecutions.

title: ExStars Back Reserve Clause Change
description: Two members of Baseball's, Hall of Fame and the only re lief pitcher of modern times who is the author of two pub lished books testified yester day against the present form, of baseball's reserveclause sys tern on the second day of Curt Flood's antitrust trial in Fed eral Court here.

title: MICROSCOPE AIDS MINIATURIZATION
description: By using me electron micro scope, the most powerful type microscope known to man, sci entists are making electronic circuits such as are used in computers, on a scale that, for compactness, may rival that within the human brain.

title: Builder Picked to Succeed Devereux as President
description: W. J. (Josh) Barney was named president of the National Horse Show yesterday, succeeding Walter Devereux, who died two weeks ago.

title: Governor Vetoes Car Insurance Bill
description: ALBANY, May 21Governor Rockefeller today vetoed a bill imposing new restrictions on the mass marketing of auto in surance, thus clearing the way for insurers to offer lowcost auto insurance on the payroll deduction plan.

title: City May Be Grim, but So Is Paris
description: A visitor from Paris, who was a New Yorker himself but in calmer days, finds many New Yorkers who say I have had it up to here, or the country is being torn apart, or we are in a pre revolutionary situation, or I'm frightened.

title: Mail Cleaned, but Good
description: BUFFALAO, May 21 (AP) Postal authorities say a sack of stolen mail was put through a washing cycle at a coinoperat ed laundry. The sack was dis covered yesterday, and postal officials said the letters inside had disolved into one big lump of paper.

title: Miniskirts Bar Journalists
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (UPI)Two reporters wearing minskirt were barred from en tering the palace of the Sultan of Selangor State because the Sultan does not like miniskirts as they expose too much, a palace official told the news women.

title: Sweeny Gains in French Title Golf
description: PARIS, May 21 (AP) Robert J. Sweeny, 59yearold Californian now living in Lon don, was one of 10 of Amer ica's 15 original starters to advance today to the second round of the French amateur golf championship.

title: Dalton School Fair Will Start Monday
description: The Dalton School's three day fair will begin Monday at 8 P.M. with a gala cham pagne preview for adults and an auction and a couture boutique of new designs from Donald Brooks, Norman Nor ell. Bill Blass and other fash ion designers.

title: Thursday Baseball
description: Batteries  McNally, Leon hard (7), Watt (8) and Etche barren; Cain, McRae (9). Hiller (9) and Frechan. Winning pitch erCain (22). Losing pitcher McNally (72). Home Runs Baltimore: Rettenmund (3), Blair (5); Detroit: Wert (1).

title: TV DRAMA FACES CUTBACK IN FALL
description: Serious television drama will be even scarcer next season than it has been in recent years, a victim of tightened budgets and a paucity of good plays. The major casualties will be two of television's most prestigious series  Pruden tial's On Stage, which will not be back, and C.B.S. Play house, which will have fewer productions.

title: 10 AfterSchool Centers In Manhattan Are Closed
description: Ten afterschool centers that have been operating throughout downtown Manhattan for the last fifty years closed down yesterday because of lack of funds. They will reopen July when the 1970 school budget goes into effect.

title: Devon Horse Show Opens An EightDay Run Today
description: DEVON, Pa., May 21The eightday Devon horse show gets under way with Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill's Idle Dice favored to dominate the open jumper division.

title: Drawing District Lines
description: In upholding the constitutionality of the 1970 New York State law redrawing Congressional district lines, the United States Supreme Court has underscored the need for this boundarydrawing task to be performed by an independent, nonpartisan commission.

title: Real VIP's
description: VIP's are Volunteers in Parks, making them very important persons, indeed. They are members of scout troops, school groups, block associations and just plain neighborhood people, young and old, who are of the opinion that a blade of grass grows better when not covered by a chewinggum wrapper, that benches sit well when freshly painted, that nothing fails like excess in the city's parks.

title: Note to Readers
description: Reviews of last night's dance and music perform ances are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings. They will appear tomorrow.

title: They Stand Together: Draft Resisters in Jail, Families at Home
description: ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt.To get to the Herbert Elliotts, it is necessary to leave U.S. Route 91, cross an iron bridge and follow a dirt road to the summit. There, on a rolling, green hill, sits the clapboard farmhouse with its tidy white shutters and matching red barn.

title: Environmental Power
description: The Hudson Highland State Park at Little Stony Point in Philipston, which will be dedicated by Gov ernor Rockefeller tomorrow, marks an important vic tory in the continuous struggle to safeguard the famous scenic gorge and riverbank from exploitation. What might have become a gypsum wallboard factory will now be preserved as parkland. But the struggle goes on.

title: Times Subsidiary In Pact to Acquire Filmstrip Makers
description: The New York Times an nounced yesterday that Teach ing Resources, Inc., its wholly owned subsidiary, had agreed in principle to purchase for cash the assets of Filmfax Productions, Inc., of Bedford Hills, N. Y., and Educational Enrichment Materials, Inc., of Norwalk, Conn., both producers of filmstrips for classroom, in dustrial and other uses.

title: GUARD IS CALLED TO OHIO STATE U
description: About 5,000 Ohio National Guardsmen were alerted to active duty in the area of Ohio State University in Colum bus last night after demonstrat ing students, led by militant blacks, smashed dozens of store windows and looted shops in the campus area.

title: No More Cambodias
description: The firmness with which Senators of both parties are resisting efforts to kill or cripple the Cooper Church amendment on Cambodia is encouraging evi dence of a new determination in Congress to restore the constitutional balance in reaching vital decisions on war and peace.

title: Surfing Called, No Surt
description: BELLS BEACH, Australia (Reuters)The first day of the world surfing championships here was postponed because there was no surf.

title: J.H.S. 120 IN HARLEM SHUT AFTER BRAWL
description: Junior High School 120 in East Harlem was closed yester day morning after more than an hour of disorder, including the occupation of an office by pu pils, a telephoned bomb threat and a skirmish outside in which eggs and bottles were thrown at the police.

title: The Steak Was Fine, but the Shrimp
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

title: Line to Get Gun Detectors
description: LONDON, May 21 (UPI)  British Overseas Airways Cor poration said today It would buy two antihijacking devices for use at Heathrow Airport. The devices detect heavy metal objects such as concealed weap ons when passengers walk through an electronic beam as they hoard the aircraft.

title: HARVESTER'S NET DIPS IN QUARTER
description: Net income of the Interna tional Harvester Company fell in the second fiscal quarter ended April 30 to $21,696,000, or 79 cents a share, from $23, 605,000, equal to 85 cents share, in the comparable quarter last year. During the period sales advanced 3.7 per cent to $731,422.000.

title: Sabotage in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 21Acts of insurgency were reported today from two re gions of Cambodia considered secure by the Government until now.

title: Pesticide Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON May 21 (UPI) A bill to give Federal health authorities the responsibility for banning potentially harmful pesticidesan area now han died by agriculture officials was introduced Wednesday by Senator Philip A. Hart, Demo crat of Michigan.

title: SEYMOUR DRIBBEN, BANKING EXECUTIVE
description: Seymour Dribben a senior vice president of the Interna tional Division of Chemical Bank, died yesterday at his home in Colebrook, Conn., after a long illness. His age was 60.

title: Clashes in Streets Mar Stoph's Visit to West Germany
description: KASSEL, West Germany, May 21The second meeting of Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany and Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany took place here today in a stiff atmosphere made more tense by political incidents in the streets.

title: O'BRIEIN SEES LACK OF TRUST IN NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 The Democratic National Chair man, Lawrence F. O'Brien, ac cused President Nixon today of failing to generate an essen tial atmosphere of confidence, in the foreign and domestic policies of his Admistration.

title: Article 1  No Title
Stocks Tumble Again
description: The stock market contin ued to tumble yesterday, with the DowJones industrial av erage falling 11.30 points to 665.25. This marked a new low for the indicator since Jan. 2, 1963. Volume was 16.71 million shares. Details on Page 49.

title: TIMES TO SUSPEND IF IMPASSE HOLDS
description: The New York Times an nounced yesterday that it would temporarily suspend publication after Sunday's is sue unless a contract settle ment was reached with Typo graphical Union No. 6.

title: J. & L. BOARD VOTES TO OMIT DIVIDEND
description: Directors of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation voted yesterday in Pittsburgh to omit the regular quarterly dividend on the company's common stock, an action that surprised many Wall Street analysts.

title: FILM OF ATROCITY IN DISPUTE RERUN
description: The Columbia Broadcast Sys tem reran with supporting evi dence last night a film that the network said was the target of a White House undercover campaign to discredit C.B.S. News.

title: INTEREST RATES AT RECORD LEVEL
description: The credit market deteriorat ed markedly yesterday, pushing interest rates to their highest levels on record.

title: Critical Point Is Seen for Autos
description: DETROIT, May 21The American automobile industry has reached a critical point in its history and its actions in the coming months could affect the business health of the na tion in years to come, Lee Iacoc ca, president of Ford Motor Company's North American auto operations, said in an interview.

title: 67th Paris Session On Vietnam Fails To Break Impasse
description: PARIS, May 21The 67th session of the Paris conference on Vietnam today produced agreement only to meet again next Thursday.

title: A New Intrepid Is Launched: 12Meter Defended Cup in '67
description: Intrepid slid into opaque wat er at the Minneford yacht yard on City Island yesterday with her rear quarters draped in canvas maxi skirts that were worn for secrecy, not some sort of fashion.

title: U.S. FIVE IS UPSET BY ITALY, 6664
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, May 21 (UPI)  Renzo Bariviera scored with six seconds remain ing tonight, enabling Italy to upset the United States, 6664, in the world basketball cham pionship. It was the Americans' first loss.

title: Godard's Mao and Pravda Begin Run
description: The DzigaVertov Group, named for a Soviet documen tary filmmaker and experi mentalist whose real name was Denis Kaufman (1896 1954), consists of JeanLuc Godard and a young French revolutionary named Jean Pierre Gorin. Sometimes, ac cording to Gorin, it consists only of JeanLuc Godard.

title: Junior League Elects
description: Mrs. Raymond Z. Fahs was elected last evening presi dent of the New York Junior League, succeeding Mrs. Roy M. Goodman. Also elected to the executive committee at the meeting at league head quarters, at 130 East 80th Street, were Mrs. Richard M. Beebe, Mrs. Ralph F. Colin Jr., Mrs. Frederick W. Wah lers, Mrs. Christopher H. Clutz, Mrs. John W. Espy and Mrs. Daniel R. Murphy.

title: Somerset Hills Again Captures Women's Interclub Golf Crown
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., May 21 Somerset Hills, the New Jer sey representative, successfully defended the Women's Metro politan Golf Association's inter club intersectional team cham pionship today.

title: SCHOOL TRACK TITLE WON BY STUYVESANT
description: Stuyvesant won its first Manhattan Public Schools' Ath letic League outdoor track and field championship in more than a decade yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: New York G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The Pentagon today identi fied 44 servicemen as having been killed in the war in South east Asia, including S. Sgt. Ar nold L. Robbins of North Evans, N Y., of the Army.

title: Seergy Challenges Crews For Brooklyn G.O.P. Post
