description: Edmund R. Seergy, leader of the 49th Assembly District Republican Club and a major figure last year in John J. Marchi's mayoral campaign, will announce tonight that he is a candidate for the Republican leadership of Brooklyn.

title: AntiVietnam Feeling Voiced
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 21The spokesman for Cam bodia's military command to day stepped beyond his normal military briefing to address correspondents emotionally on his feelings toward the Viet namese. Venturing outside the present policy line, Major Am rone, declared that any Cam bodian would rather die than live under Vietnamese domina tion.

title: Maddox Warns of Plot
description: MACON, Ga., May 21 (AP) Gov. Lester G. Maddox called in additional state troopers to day after announcing that he had been informed of a plot to murder someone during the march.

title: Conference Honors Blount
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The National Conference of Chris tian and Jews gave its natural citation for distinguished serv ice in human relations tonight to Winton M. Blount, the Post master General.

title: Justice Marshall Improved
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court, 61 years old, hospitalized almost a week with pneumonia, was reported considerably improved today at Bethesda Naval Hospital.

title: Outfielders Go All Out for the Out
11 WALKS YIELDED BY STOTTLEMYRE
description: Danny Cater's stiff back and Mel Stottlemyre's stiff elbow loosened up sufficiently for a 20 Yankee victory over the Senators last night.

title: Amalrik, Dissident Author, Reported Seized in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 21  Soviet authorities today were report ed to have arrested Andrei A. Amalrik, a dissident author, on the ground that he slandered, the Soviet state through his book Will the U.S.S.R. Sur vive Until 1984, which was published abroad.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, S P.M. (Television Channel 9, 8 P.M.) (Radio WJRZ, WNBCFM, 8 P.M.)

title: Episcopal Council Urges Total Troop Withdrawal
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 21 The executive council of the 3.5millionmember Episcopal Church passed a resolution yes terday calling for total with drawal of all American forces from Southeast Asia now and and end to the war.

title: ROSEWALL, LAYER ADVANCE IN TENNIS
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 21 Four months after the $200. 000 Tennis Champions Classic began its sporadic, helterskel ter worldwide schedule, the first of the world's nine top pro fessionals was eliminated to night when Ken Rosewall of Australia defeated his country man, John Newcombe, 57, 75, 61, 62, at South Mountain Arena here.

title: Wearer of Flag to Fly It
description: WATERLOO, N.Y., May 21 (AP)William K. Chambers, 18 years old, admitted in court that he unlawfully displayed the American flag by appearing in public last Friday wearing trou sers fashioned from a flag. Town Justice Verne Sessler of Junius fined Mr. Chambers $100 and sentenced him to 30 days in the Seneca County Jail. He further odered that during the jail term Mr. Chambers raise and lower the American flag each day.

title: AN OLD REGATTA TRIMS ITS CRAFT
description: The HarvardYale crew race, the oldest intercollegiate sports event, will not be quite the same this year. The preliminary freshman race was eliminated yesterday for the June 13 re gatta when Yale dropped out because of its inability to man a freshman boat.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert K. Dix, president and a director of the Enjay Chemical Company, has been elected a senior vice president and director of the Esso Chemical Company, effective June 1. Enjay is the United States affiliate of Esso Chemical, the chemical af filiate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

title: Blast Hurts 50 Students
description: REXBURG, Idaho, May 21 (UPI)A vial of hydrochloric and nitric acid exploded on a school bus yesterday, injuring more than 50 students, one seriously. James Johnson, 15 years old, had been given the vial of acid by his biology leacher to conduct a home ex periment.

title: PANTHER TRIAL RULE IS UPHELD IN APPEAL
description: The United States Court of Apeals for the Second Circuit upheld yesterday a series of special courtroom rules imposed for the trial of eight Black Panthers accused of murder And kidnapping in New Haven.

title: Breezes Stir on Capitol Hill
description: By serving notice now of his intention to step down from the Speakership, John McCormack may well be staving off a rebellion of historic dimensions in the House of Representatives. Had he chosen to run again, there is no question that a large segment of Democrats would either have fought his reelection to the end or demanded as the price of acceptance a pledge of reforms in the institutional workings of that chamber.

title: Washington: For the Record
Rhodesians Greet Vorster
description: SALISBURY, Dhodesia, May 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  Rhodesians gave Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa an enthusiastic welcome upon his arrival at Salisbury airport today for a twoday official visit. As Mr. Vorster left the aircraft a crowd of about 100 Europeans cheered and shouted Well done.

title: OPERATION HELD THREE WEEKS AGO
description: Terry Sawchuk, one of hockey's biggest names, was taken yesterday from the in tensivecare unit of Long Beach (L. I.) Memorial Hospital, where he has been a patient without fanfare for more than three weeks. He is expected to remain in the hospital at least another week.

title: Festival Focus Is Black Arts
description: Black, red and green, the colors of the black liberation slag, representing color, blood and country, symbolize the theme of the first black arts festival now under way at the Riverside Church.

title: $300Million Rise Followed a Sharp Drop in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 New orders for durable goods turned upward moderately in April after having dropped sharply in March, the Com merce Department reported today.

title: Service on National Airlines Awaits Tally on Agreement
description: The resumption of service by National Airlines, struck since Jan. 31 by the Air Line Em ployes Association, appeared in definite yesterday. Negotiators announced agreement on a new contract on Monday.

title: Judge in Illinois Restricts Subpoenas for Newsmen
description: CHICAGO, May 21 (AP)A Circuit Court judge has upheld a motion to prevent the issu ance of subpoenas for newsmen and their accounts of street disorders that ocurred last Oc tober.

title: We Are Still Waiting, Eban Says on Jets
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel called on the United States today to stir up an international climate of criticism against Soviet mili tary involvement in the United Arab Republic.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS NEW SST OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee approved today an additional $290million for con tinued development of a civil supersonic transport aircraft.

title: Canadians List Child Aid
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia (Canadian Presc)  A total of 50,837 individual articles of children's clothing worth $71, 795 were shipped from British Columbia to Red Cross ware houses in troubled parts of the world in 1969, says S. R. Hay den, chairman of the British Co lombiaYukon division of the organization.

title: Brewster Tells U.S. Court He Is Set to Stand Trial
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Daniel B. Brewster, the former Senator from Maryland, in formed a Federal District Court in Washington today that he had recovered his health and was ready to stand trial on charges that he took $24,500 for his votes against higher postage for junk mail.

title: Shift to Defeatism By Arnold W esker Noted in Friends
description: LONDON, May 21It is ne surprise to find Arnold Weskei equating his own social obses sions with those of the com munity at large: What is sur prising about his new play. The Friends, at the Round house, is its change from doc trinaire optimism to a context of defeat.

title: Autos Set Ablaze As Rahway Faces 2d Troubled Night
description: RAHWAY, N. J. May 21 (AP) Several cars were set ablaze and more than a dozen persons were arrested here tonight in the second night of racial dis turbances.

title: Sextuplets Born Here, All Die; Mother Had Used Fertility Drug
description: A 25yearold woman who had been taking a fertility drug gave birth to sextupletsfive girls and a boyat the New York University Medical Center last night, but hospital au thorities reported that all died within seven hours.

title: Advertising: Agency Offers Media Plan
description: Ogilvy & Mather, it is un derstood, is going to allow nonclients to avail them selves of the expertise of its media department. For a fee, of course.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: Salk Institute Appoints Physicist to a Top Post
description: Dr. Frederic de Hoffmann, a physicist, vice charman of Gulf General Atomic, Inc., has been elected to the new post of chancellor of the Salk Institute in San Diego, Calif. He was formerly a vice presi dent of the General Dy namics and Gulf Oil Corpora tions.

title: ANOTHER SLUMP BATTERS STOCKS
description: The stock market moves through another shock session yesterday, with the DowJones industrial average hammered down by 18.49 points at 2:30 P.M. before a finalhour rally reduced the loss to 11.30 points. Closing at 665.25, the Dow industrials hovered at their lowest level in more than seven years and four months. The poorest previous closing was at 646.79 on Jan. 2, 1963.

title: Ronan Is Said to Ignore Complaints of Subway Riders
description: The head of the Mayors' Sub way Service Watchdog Com mission said yesterday that Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority, had ignored his repeated requests to discuss thousands of complaints by subway riders about safety.

title: Market Place
description: Will someone please say something nice about the bro kerage business? Fred will. Fred's broker sent Fred's letter along saying that some favorable publicity certain ly wouldn't hurt.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE full impact of Sylvia Ashton Warner's latest novel probably de pends on identification with its el derly protagonist, and I confess that my underlying inclination was to shun the bleak landscape of her interior. All the same, one recognizes art when one sees it. And one respects one's elders. It seems at first as it we are trapped in some wasteland of sententiousness  the mind of this nameless New Zealand woman who pads through corridors in quest of endless cups of tea, and registers in her diarylike monologue that men are more than close to truth when they are close to death; they are truth it self and what's wanted here is discipline. But it turns out that the mind has little trap doors. One of them leads to something of a sense of humor, which prompts the old woman to refer to her quarters as the nonliving room and to the hallway that divides it from the rooms of her son and daughterinlaw as the Generation Gap. Another leads to unpredictable tearful out bursts of bitterness toward her children. There may be more to this woman than her elliptical prose reveals.

title: Reserve Chief Here Supports Surtax to Fight Inflation
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York threw his prestige yesterday behind the call by the Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, for an incomes policy to help speed the return to price stability.

title: 3 Boys Held in Slaying Of Park Holdup Victim
description: Three teenagers have been arrested and charged with homicide in the slaying of man during a holdup in Cen tral Park Saturday night.

title: NEW YORK GROUP LOBBIES FOR PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The president of Bloomingdale's, the head of Random House, the au thor of The Rothchilds, an in vestment banker, the former Gloria Vanderbilt and her hus band, Wyatt Cooper, and as sorted envoys from New York's worlds of culture, business and fasihon became lobbyists today.

title: Governor Gets Preview of the Campaign to Come
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 21Governor Rockefeller faced angry students who were de nouncing him as a Fascist pig and businessmen who were saluting progress with Ameri can flags in a twoday swing across the northern arc of the state that ended today.

title: A. Warren Norton Dies at 73; Retired Newspaper Executive
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 21 A. Warren Norton, a newspaper man and publishing executive who became a Christian Science practitioner, died yesterday in a nursing home in Bedford, N. Y. He was 73 years old and lived at 37 Ethelridge Road.

title: 60 Wesleyan Girls Join Protest On 3d Day of March in Georgia
description: MACON, Ga., May 21Clap ping their hands and singing, Nixon, you cannot jail us all, at least 60 white girls at Wes leyan College here joined the spirited and predominantly black march against repres sion late today.

title: Cites forfeits Status As an Amateur Golfer
description: Marvin (Vinny) Giles of Richmond has forfeited his amateur status because of his acceptance of golf balls, the United States Golf Associa tion announced yesterday.

title: SCIENTISTS WARY ON DIABETES PILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 21An official of the Food and Drug Administration said today that, the agency would probably is sue a statement tomorrow con cerning a longterm study that casts doubt on the usefulness of an antidiabetes pill for treat ing mild adult diabetics.

title: Senate Sponsors Soften Language of the Cambodian Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The White House and its Senate critics were at an impasse to day in their attempt to reach an accommodation on a move to prohibit future military ac tivities in Cambodia without the consent of Congress.

title: Kodak Shifts Ranks
description: The giant of the photographic industry, the Eastman Kodak Company, announced yesterday a change in its high command and the formation of a new division.

title: PATTERSON ABOARD 5 JERSEY WINNERS
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 21 (UPI)  Garth Patterson stole the spotlight at Garden State Park today by winning five races in the ninerace card.

title: DR. ALLEN OPPOSES NIXON WAR POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, May 21Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the United States Commissioner of Educa tion who was appointed by President Nixon, disagreed today with the Administration over the Indochina war.

title: New Bausch and Lomb Plant
description: OAKLAND, Md., May 21 (AP) Bausch and Lomb, Inc., of ficials announced today that construction would be started immediately on a $ 30 million Iens plant near this western Maryland community.

title: Salvation Army Names Nelson
description: The Salvation Army an nounced Wednesday that Col. Emil Nelson of New York had been named national chief secretary of the organization. He succeeds Lieut. Commis sioner John Grace, who retires next Tuesday. Colonel Nelson has been the Salvation Army's national consultant for evan gelism since 1967.

title: DRIVES ARE AIDED BY HARD FAIRWAYS
description: ATLANTA, May 21Bound ing the ball long distances over hard fairways today, Toni Weiskopf carded a 65 and shared the lead with Homero Blancas, in the opening round of the $125,000 Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: 14 Counties and Six Towns Added to Food Stamp Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Clif ford M. Hardin designated 14 more counties and six towns today for Government fond stamp programs for needy families.

title: Lady Alexandra Jellicoe Bride of Philip Wilson
description: LONDON, May 21Lady Alexandra Jellicoe, grand daughter of the late Admiral Jellicoe, British naval com mander in chief in World War I, and Philip Wilson, son of the chairman of Sotheby & Co., of London and its New York affiliate, the ParkeBer net Galleries, were married here today.

title: Balauer's Reelection: A Mixture of Relief and Concern to U.S. Officials
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, May 21For the United States, which has been deeply involved in the Domini can Republic since its military intervention here in 1965, the peaceful reelection of Presi dent Joaquin Balaguer has brought a mixture of relief and preoccupation. The relief is felt by United states officials here be cause widespread violence and a pos sible crisis in the military over the Presidential election last Satur day did not materialize. The preoccupation arises out of the worry that in the next four years Mr. Balaguer's conserva tive and unimaginative regime might continue to make little or no headway in dealing with the social and economic prob lems that under the political unrest here.

title: King's I.O.S. Intentions Still a Mystery
description: John M. King, the 43year old Denver millionaire who has been in Geneva negotiat ing for control of the be leaguered Investors Overseas Services, returned to New York yesterday to outline his plans for the first time.

title: 18 DRUG CONCERNS ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: WASHINGON, May 21 The The Government filed suit to day against six American and 12 foreign drug companies for recovery of money it said it had fraudulently been de prived of. The alleged fraud was connected with the sale of large amounts of quinine, quinidine and othe chinchona products that had been stockpiled by the Government.

title: Elaine Biddle Fiancee Of Bradford Whitman
description: PENN VALLEY, Pa., May 21Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Biddle Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Biddle, to Bradford Flint Whitman, son of the late Clarence Whitman of New York and the late Mrs. Carolyn Whit man.

title: Foreign Affairs: The American Image in Spain
description: MADRIDThe United States, in formulating policy toward Spain, has twice been wrong. Right after World War II we took the lead in trying to isolate this country, hoping thereby to oust its regime. The attempt accomplished little but the stiffening of Franco's proud back and continuing economic backwardness.

title: HOUSE APPROVES LINKING PENSIONS TO RISES IN PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  The House handed President Nixon a major victory today by voting to tie future Social Secu rity increases to increases in the Consumer Price Index.

title: CRAFTSMEN DISPLAY CREATIONS AT BANK
description: New oneofakind creations by the ArtistCraftsmen of New York are having their first public showing through June 1 on the street floor of the First National City Bank, Park Ave nue and 53d Street.

title: Choice for Auto Union President
description: DETROIT, May 21  He could have been an ambassa dor, to Taiwan or Pakistan, or a Government official at the subCabinet level. Those who know him say he would have fitted inintellectual, analytical, and yet an opera tor in the world of action. But Leonard Woodcock said no to these offers from the Kennedy Ad ministration and, instead tomor row he will be elevated to presi dent of the uni ted Automobile Workers, the nation's second largest union, succeeding Walter P. Reuther, who died May 9. Mr. Wood cock does not conform to the stereotype of a labor union boss.

title: O.E.C.D. MINISTERS PONDER INFLATION
description: PARIS, May 21  Ministers from the industrial countries expressed the conviction today that the world can avoid sliding into a general recession despite the economic slowdown and stock market drop in the United States.

title: Black Artists' Show On View in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 21The ex hibition entitled AfroAmer ican Artists: New York and Boston, currently on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, is the largest survey of Amer ican black artists ever mounted. Consisting of 158 works  painting, sculpture; drawing, graphics, and other visual mediaby 70 artists, the show occupies the mu seum's main exhibition gal leries, and is being promoted by the museum as one of the major events of its current centennial celebrations. It is cosponsored by the museum, the museum school and Bos ton's National Center of Afro American Artists, and has been organized by Edmund B. Gaither, the black curator of the National Center's own museum who also serves on the Museum of Fine Arts staff, and Barnet Rubenstein, a white member of the mu seum school faculty.

title: U. S. WAR DEATHS FOR WEEK AT 217, A 9MONTH PEAK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21The United States com mand said today that 217 American soldiers were killed in Southeast Asia last week. This was the highest weekly toll since last August.

title: Colombia Airliner Hijacked
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 21 (AP)  A Colombian Avianca DC3 airliner was hijacked while on a domestic flight to day with 26 persons aboard for a forced flight to Cuba. The plane was seized after taking off from Villavicencio, in east ern Colombia, and landed in Barrancabermeja. It is to pro ceed to Barranquilla to refuel for the flight to Santiago. Cuba, Avianca officials reported.

title: Urbanists Find Suburbs Hostile To Cities, Pinched for Money
description: ST. LOUIS  A patrolman gestures at the dark, three block corridor of small stores, cafes, and row houses. Not even a rat, he says drily. Abandoned.

title: Saigon to Reopen Schools, But Universities Stay Shut
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21A Government spokes, man announced today the re opening of high schools and primary schools, which have been closed since May 6 be cause of student unrest. The universities, however, will ap parently remain shut.

title: MET MUSEUM ADDS HOURS IN EVENING
description: As a mark of concern, the Metropolitan Museum will stay open today from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., even though a city wide artists' strike aimed at war, racism and repression has closed down a number of other facilities.

title: G.M. Will Win Proxy Battle With Nader, but the War May Just Be Starting
description: DETROIT, May 21When the spring offensive against the Gen eral Motors Corporation ends late tomorrow, the businessmen will be able to claim victory. Their proxy count will show more than 200million shares voted for the corporation and no more than a few hundred thousand for the insurgents. That's the way conventional proxy wars are fought in the world of busi ness. But Cam paign G. M., the attack on the big automaker that was begun by a handful of Washington lawyers in the name of the public interest and which was backed by Ralph Naderis not a conven tional war. It's a guerrilla war, a battle, as George Romney used to say, for the hearts and minds of the people.

title: Pentagon Says Drives Disrupted Foe
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 In a preliminary assessment of the United States and South South Vietnamese troop thrusts into Cambodia, the Pentagon said today that enemy head quarters units had suffered se rious disruption and had been forced to flee deeper into the interior.The estimate of damage in flicted on the enemy forces avoided any assertion that the Communist headquarters, known as the Central Office for South Vietnam, or COSVN  had been captured, but it pre sented a picture of confusion and retreat in the enemy camp.

title: CAPITAL OUTLAYS DOWN IN QUARTER
description: If capital appropriations are criteria, it is apparent in vestment for new plant and equipment this year will not be quite as heavy as recent surveys have indicated, accord ing to the National Industrial Conference Board.

title: Corporate Responsibility
description: Two novel resolutions will he voted on at the annual meeting of General Motors in Detroit today, designed to emphasize the role of responsibility that such giant corporatings as G.M. must expect to play in respect to the social and environmental problems directly effected by their operations.

title: President Asks for Funds For School Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  President Nixon formally asked Congress today for $1.5billion over the next two years to be used primarily to help finance the desegregation of Southern schools and to provide incen tives for Northern school dis tricts to integrate.

title: 4 Supertankers Ordered By Shell for Mideast Run
description: An order for four super tankers to operate mainly be tween Middle East oil fields and northwestern European ports for the Royal Dutch Shell group of companies was announced in London yesterday by Shell International Marine.

title: Hickel Welcomes Students in Politics
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel welcomed to day the movement of thousands of college students into the political process, saying that, regardless of its effect on political parties, it will help the country.

title: Roundup: Phils' Comeback Sours Allen's Vengeance
description: Philadelphia fans made Richie Allen feel at home last night, and he almost spoiled the homecoming for them.

title: Two ATests Conducted
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 21 UPI)The Atomic Energy Com mission conducted two under ground nuclear tests today and reported a minor leakage of radioactivity from one of them. A spokesman said the radio activity had been confined to within a few hundred feet of the shaft and posed no health hazard.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
British Cabinet Asks Cricket Group to Bar South African Team
description: LONDON, May 21The Gov ernment today asked the con trolling body of British cricket to withdraw its invitation to a South African team whose tour threatened to divide and dis rupt England during the June election campaign.

title: PROTEST UPSETS HOUSING HEARING
description: Thirtyeight policemen were called to clear the Board of Estimate chamber yesterday after more than 100 lowincome Coney Island residents set up a clamor over a delay in a new housing plan for their area.

title: In Memoriam
description: GROSSMANFaye, May 22, 1958,

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: * Apprentice.

title: 4 Women on a Horse a Hit Show As No. 8 Comes Home at Big A
description: The syndicate's horse was leading the field into the stretch at Aqueduct yester day, and the members were doing their best to keep him there.

title: Knicks Promote Two To Executive Positions
description: The New York Knicks gave additional titles yesterday to Frank Blausohild and James Wergeles of their publicity department.

title: Sanitation Strike Ends
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) The District of Columbia's 1,700 sanitation workers have voted to end a fourday strike. The sanitation workers ac cepted a oneyear contract last night that call for a wage in crease of 35 cents an hour. The current starting salary is $2.94 an hour. cepted a oneyear contract last night that call for a wage in crease of 35 cents an hour. The current starting salary is $2.94 an hour.

title: WILLIAM C. HENCHY
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 22 William C. Henchy, a retired vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died at the St. Agnes Hospital here Mon day. He was 77 years old and lived at 20 North Broadway.

title: DR. ROBERT BRECHT, OF WHARTON SCHOOL
description: MEDIA, Pa., May 22  Dr. Robert P. Brecht, a leader in management education, who re tired as professor of industry at the Wharton School of Fi nance and Commerce, Univer sity of Pennsylvania, in 1967, died yesterday after a short ill ness. His age was 71.

title: Miss Mary L. Baldwin Is Engaged
description: GARRISON, N. Y., May 22 Mrs. William Ludwell Bald win has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Ludwell Baldwin, to Cary Gresham Bayne. He is the son of Rear Adm. Mar maduke Gresham Bayne and Mrs. Bayne of Bahrain, Per sian Gulf, where Admiral Bayne is stationed as com mander of the Navy's Middle East Force.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED IN THE WEEK
Power of New Boards Is Defined
description: The new community school boards will have the power to do the following under the decentralization law:

title: Marcis, 11 Others Qualify For World 600 Tomorrow
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 22 (AP)  Dave Marcis drove a Dodge Daytona at 153.082 miles on hour today and led 12 qualifiers for the $193,080 World 600 stock oar race that is scheduled Sunday at Char lotte Motor Speedway.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: EDUCATION STUDY

title: Heyderdahl Craft Becalmed
description: SEMINOLE, Fla., May 22 (UPI)Thor Heyerdahl's pa pyrus boat Ra II has been drift ing with the current the last three days with absolutely no wind, the navigator Norman Baker, reported today in a rado transmission monitored here. He reported the craft's position at noon as 120 miles northeast of Cape Juby on the African coast, a little more than 250 miles from Sunday's starting point at Safi, Morocco.

title: Hailstorm Buffets City
description: A heavy downpour dumped hail and .39 inch of rain on the city last night. The brief storm, with lightning and thunder, lasted from 10:40 P. M. until 11:05.

title: Thieu Asks Power To Combat Inflation By Decreeing Tax
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 22 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu asked the National As sembly yesterday for broad new powers for five months to deal with the nation's economic problems.

title: SAIGON IS HALTING REFUGEE PULLOUT
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 22 The Government of South Vietnam has decided to halt the mass evacuation of refugees by boat down the Mekong River, leaving about 70,000 Vi etnamese stranded in assembly camps here.

title: OilDrilling Ban Is Urged
description: CAMPBELL RIVER, British Columbia (Canadian Press) The Associated Chambers of Commerce of Vancouver Island urged the provicial government to stop all oil exploration and drilling in waters around the island, to avert pollution.

title: BERNARD M'CORMICK
description: PITTSBURGH, May 22Ber nard J. McCormick, former superintendent of Pittsburgh public schools, died at Presby terianUniversity Hospital yes terday. He was 63 years old.

title: TALKS RESUMED IN PAPER DISPUTE
description: Negotiators for the typo graphical union and the four major daily newspapers here met for about 90 minutes last night but failed to resolve their contract dispute.

title: Edwards, on 73, Wins Medal In Travis Golf for Third Time
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 22Bill Edwards, an outstand ing metropolitan area amateur for more than two decades, carded a par on each of the last 11 holes at the Garden City Golf Club today and won the medal in the 59th Walter J. Travis invitation tourna ment. His score for the 6,689 yard course was par 73.

title: ARMY TV WAR FILM IS REPORTED STAGED
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Senator J. W. Fullbright said today that Lhe Senate Foreign Relations Committee had re ceived sworn testimony from an Army sergeant that military television team in Vietnam had staged several combat incidents by South Vietnamese troops.

title: E.E.C.U.S. ACCORD ON TRADE AID SET
description: PARIS, May 22A compro mise between the United States and the European Economic Community brought a fresh ad vance today toward establish ment of generalized trade preferences for developing countries.

title: PETERSON VICTOR WITH AKER'S HELP
description: CLEVELAND, May 22  The Yankees, in good hitting form and aided by some astoundingly bad fielding by the Indians who were formally charged with five errors, struck for six quick runs tonight and coasted to a 74 victory over Cleveland at Municipal Stadium.

title: Ralph Houk's Father Dies
description: CLEVELAND, May 22 (UPI) George Houk, the father of New York Yankee manager Ralph Houk, died early today in Lawrence, Kan. He was 84 years old.

title: A.T.&T. Confirms Real Estate Deals On Both Coasts
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company confirmed yesterday major real estate purchases on both the East and West Coasts.

title: U.S. AGENTS TO GET CHICAGO RAID ROLE
description: CHICAGO, May 22States Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan, who was criticized by a Federal grand jury for his handling of a raid Dec. 4 on a Black Pan ther apartment, said today that Federal agents would be invited to participate in all future searches for illegal guns and ammunition.

title: 2 Benefits Set At Met Games
description: Supporters of the Museum of the City of New York have bought a block of seats for Tuesday evening's base ball game between the New York Mets and the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium. Tickets are $25 each and in clude cocktails and a buffet dinner in the Press Level Ter race.

title: Article 2  No Title
Magnuson Criticizes Nixon's Plan for Tax on Leaded Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Senator Warren G. Magnuson said today that President Nixon had displayed good inten tions but bad judgment in his proposal to reduce lead pollu tion by a tax on leaded gaso line.

title: Bridge:
description: A declarer who is prepared to plan the play conscienti ously when the dummy ap pears can sometimes visualize an endgame possibility, such as a throwin or a squeeze.

title: Supreme Court Clears Hair for Boston Run
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (Reuters)The Banned in Boston label was removed from the musical Hair to day by the Supreme Court.

title: JURY SPLITS IN CASE OF EXPANTHERS HERE
description: The trial of three former Black Panthers on charges of conspiring to rob a hotel to get funds for the Panther party ended in a hung jury last night, four weeks after the trial be gan in State Supreme Court here.

title: U.S. SAID TO SHIFT VIEW ON AIR COVER IN CAMBODIAN WAR
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  The United States was reported today to be prepared to con tinue air cover, if needed, for South Vietnamese forces that are considered almost certain to remain in Cambodia after the American withdrawal deadline, July 1.

title: CAMBODIA ARMS BID REJECTED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, May 22The For eign Policy Council decided to day that the Philippines would not grant Cambodia's request for military assistance but would offer humanitarian aid as a civic undertaking through several organizations. Direct Government aid, the council was told, would imply full rec ognition of the new Cambodian regime. Manila has so far given only de facto recognition.

title: L.I.R. Winning More Supporters Among Riders
description: Nine months after Governor) Rockefeller promised that the Long Island Railroad would be come the nation's finest com muter line, a growing number of Long Island commuters rec ognize significant improvements and have begun to concede that perhaps it is no longer one of the worst.

title: The Arts Feeling Economic Squeeze
description: The arts, which in recent years have been grappling with inflation, are now threatened by the slowed economy and the precipitous fall in the stock market.

title: A Correction
description: WASHINGTON, May 22In an artfcle on urban problems in Thursday's editions of The Times, it was reported that Re public Steel in Birmingham, Ala., had reduced its work force from 25,000 to 15,000. The company named should have been United States Steel rather than Republic.

title: Mrs. Delia Akeley Howe Dead; Explorer and Hunter in Africa
description: Mrs. Delia Akeley Howe, Af rican explorer, big game hunter and writer, died yesterday in Daytona Beach, Fla., where she was living, at the age of 95. She formerly lived in New York and borset. Vt.

title: Mao Attack on U.S. Viewed As a Reply to Moscow, Too
description: HONG KONG, May 22Mao Tsetung's call this week for world revolution against Unit ed States imperialism and yesterday's mass rally that he attended in Peking's Tienanmen Square supporting the call are regarded here as moves to emphasize further Communist China's revolutionary leader ship role.

title: Marshall Recovering
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Doctors at Bethesda Naval Hospital said today that Justice Thurgood Marshall was making good progress toward recovery from pneumonia. The Justice has been at Bethesda a week.

title: Blake Signs 5Year Pact As Piper General Manager
description: PITTSBURGH, May 22 (UPI) Marty Blake, who resigned last month after 17 seasons with the Atlanta IIawks of the National Basketball Associa tion, signed a fiveyear con tract today as general man ager of the Pittsburgh Pipers of the American Basketball As sociation.

title: Where Burns Stands
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Arthur F. Burns has let it known that he is disturbed by connotations of a clash between himself and the Nixon Administration on the issue or some Hum or voluntary wage and price restraint.

title: Bridge Hand Is Truly Rare
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland (Canadian Press)  Each of the four players in a bridge game at a golf club was dealt a com plete suit of cards. The odds against the cards coming up that way are billions to one.

title: Batavia Downs Figures Drop
description: ALBANY, May 22 (AP)The attendance fell to 264,469 from 278,608 last year and the handle dropped to $18,201,787 from $18,727,389 during the spring meeting at Batavia Downs har npess track, the State Tax De artment reported today.

title: RIGHTS UNIT CHIEF HAILS NIXON MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  The chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, which has been sharply critical of the Administra tion's civil rights policies, today applauded President Nixon's new program to encourage school desegregation.

title: GOODWIN J. KNIGHT OF CALIFORNIA DIES
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 22 (AP)Former Gov. Goodwin J. Knight died of pneumonia to day at the age of 73.

title: Delay in Addonizio Trial Is Denied by Court Again
description: TRENTON, May 22 (UPI) For the second time, Federal Court Judge George H. Barlow has denied a delay of Newark Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio's con spiracy and extortion trial until after the June 16 election.

title: The News Refuses an Ad By Its Staff Against War
description: The Daily News refused to accept an advertisement yester day from more than 100 of its editorial employes condemning the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Thousands in Mississippi Mourn Student Who Was Slain in Jackson
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 22 The second victim of the police shooting at Jackson State College was buried to day, and the rich and the powerful came to Jackson to pay their respects and to ex press concern over this violent spring on American cam puses. James Earl Green, 17 yearold student and part time grocery clerk, was buried in the dusty Missis sippi earth after thousands of mourners walked under a broiling sun to a little green cemetery onehalf mile from where he and another Negro student were killed and seven others wounded by Mississippi state police last week. Gov. John Bell Wil liams amassed 1,300 National Guardsmen and a large con tingent of highway patrol of ficers here in case of vio lence, which he said he feared. But the munch was peaceful. You've seen me here five times in 10 years, Charles Evers, the black May or of Fayette, Miss., told the 4,000 mourners who jammed the oppressively hot hall where the service for the dead student was held. It was in this building in 1963 that services were conducted for Mr. Evers's brother, Medgar, who was head of the Mississippi chapter of the National Asso ciation for the Advancement of Colored People when he was shot to death by a sniper in Jackson.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Air Force. The President assigned Lieut. Gen. Albert P. Clark as the superinten dent, United States Air Force Academy, effective Aug. 1, 1970. General Clark, 56, has been serving as commander, Air University, MaxwellAir Force Base, since August, 1968. He will relieve Lieut. Gen. Thomas S. Moorman, who is to retire on July 3.

title: Louis A. Gibbs, 70, Dead; BrokerageHouse Officer
description: Louis A. Gibbs, who retired last year as vice president and a director of Laird, Bissell & Needs, stockbrokers, died Thursday of a heart ailment in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Ile was 70 years old and formerly lived in New York and Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Marichal Gives Few Walks
description: SAN FRANCISCO) (UPI) Juan Marichal of the San Fran cisco Giants had the best con trol of National League pitchers in 1969, walking an average of ?? 1.62 per game.

title: Ice Follies '70 Bows Here
description: The Ice Follies of 1970, in the 34th edition of the rink show that opened Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, is playing it cool, restrained and lovely. The taste and restraint of it all, amid the swirling verve and skill, is a delightful surprise for anybody expecting a gaudy, Cecil B. DeMille salute to the hot months ahead. Like the oldfashioned revue it is, the show is simply constructed, cleancut and charming.

title: AGNEW ATTACKS HIS PRESS CRITICS
description: HOUSTON, May 22  Vice President Agnew renewed his attack on his critics in the liberal news media to night, dismissing statements by editorial writers and column ists that he and President Nixon had contributed to re cent campus disorders with their public comments.

title: BAY WINS 2D TIME IN 3RACE SERIES
description: YONKERS, May 22When Fulla Napoleon is right, I don't, think there is a pacer in the world that can beat him, Dick Thomas said before tonight's $50,000 National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Market Place
description: Penn Central stock chugged to a new low yesterday.

title: Brandt Urges Stoph to Ease His Stand
description: BONN, May 22Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany appealed today to the East Ger man leadership to show a bit more goodwill and a little less legal formality in its dealings with his government.

title: WashingtonMoscowPeking
description: Since Moscow and Peking coordinate virtually noth ing important these days, it was sheer coincidence that on the same morning this week the Chinese called off the scheduled meeting with American repre sentatives in Warsaw while Pravda loosed one of its most severe attacks against Mao and his policies. Nevertheless the juxtaposition of these two events helps provide a useful perspective on present relation ships in the vital WashingtonMoscowPeking triangle.

title: Text of Agnew's Speech Scoring Press
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 Following is the text of an address by Vice President Agnew as prepared for Texas Republican fund rais ing dinner in Houston to night and released nere:

title: Topics: In Defense of the Pentagon
description: There seems to be quite a difference of opinion about the proper size and role of the military. It varies from doing away with it entirely to dra matically increasing its size and influence. As in most things the answer lies somewhere be tween the two extremes. The extremists are vitally inter ested in our military posture but for different reasons.

title: But Problems Still Remain, Roche Says
description: DETROIT, May 22James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, told the shareholders at the annual meeting today that, although it appears that the low point in automobile sales is behind us, the world's largest cor poration still faced serious fi nancial problems.

title: The Dance
description: The New York City Ballet's prolific young choreographer, John Clifford, has done it againwhich means not only that he has produced still another ballet, his fifth, for the company, but that it bears as little outward re semblance to the past four as each of these did to the others.

title: Three Arabs Beaten Near U.N. After Bus Is Attacked in Israel
description: Three Arabs were severely beaten here yesterday in their offices near the United Nations.

title: First Family in Maryland
description: THURMONT, Md., May 22 (UPI)President Nixon and his whole family went to Camp David today for the weekend. The President was accompanied on the 30minute helicopter ride to the Maryland retreat by Mrs. Nixon; their daughters, husband, David Eisenhower.

title: Student Protests Continue
description: Student protests continued across the nation yesterday. In the New York area, demon strations were few and peace ful.

title: COURTNEY SECOND; 3 ARE TIED AT 136
description: ATLANTA, May 22  Tom Weiskopf gained the lead in the $125,000 Atlanta Golf Clas sic today with a 133, and didn't slam my car door on my hand.

title: In Memoriam
description: BURDERichard A., May 23, 1969, In con stont oving memory of your charm, fove, devotlon as husband, father and son.

title: Careless City Officials Could Become Carless
description: Mayor Lindsay warned members of his administra tion yesterday that if their cityowned cars were tagged for traffic violations they would permanently lose the use of the cars.

title: PACERS CAN CLINCH N.B.A. TITLE TODAY
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP)  Los Angeles is not coming here just to see the playoffs come to an end, Bob Leonard, coach of the Indiana Pacers, said today.

title: Joseph Wood Krutch, Naturalist, Dies
description: TUCSON, Ariz., May 22 (UPI) Joseph Wood !Crutch, the au thor, critic and naturalist, died here today at the aee of 76

title: ROYAL CALL BLOCKS OKKER'S TENNIS DATE
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 22Tom Okker of the Nether lands, who was to have played a $10,000 challenge match with Tony Roche of Australia to night in the $200,000 Tennis Champions Classic at South Mountain Arena, didn't show up because he had more im portant things to do.

title: Nixon Aides to See Business Leaders On Stock Markel
description: Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security ad viser, and Budget Director Rob ert P. Mayo are scheduled to meet with Wall Street and busi ness leaders within the next 10 days to discuss the effect of the Government's policies on the stock market.

title: OHIO STATE CLASH PUZZLES CAMPUS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22  National Guardsmen with loaded rifles kept Ohio State University sealed off today while students pondered an un usual streak of interracial vi olence that has suddenly sur faced here.

title: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN IN GRAPE'S BOYCOTT
description: FRESNO, Calif., May 22 (AP)  In the first major break through in a fiveyear Cali fornia table grapes labor dis pute, two large growers have agreed to twoyear contracts with Cesar Chavez's union.

title: Benefit for Girls' Club
description: A supper dance in behalf of the new Girls' Club of Manhattan has been ar ranged for Wednesday at L'Etoile. Junior tickets for persons under the age of 35 are $15 each. Other tickets are $25 each. All are avail able from Jonathan Michaels of 308 East 51 Street. The beneficiary, while opened last summer at 300 East Six Street, has a membership of 330 aged 6 to 19.

title: Heat Cuts Into the Ranks Of Marchers in Georgia
description: BARNESVILLE, Ga., May 22  A broiling sun cut into the ranks of the black and white marchers against re pression today as they walked the black asphalt stretches of Highway 49 through the rolling hills of central Georgia.

title: Presbyterians Defeat Proposal To Bar 9Church Merger Plan
description: CHICAGO, May 22An at tempt to take the 3.2 million members of the United Presby terian Church out of the Con sultation on Church Union was defeated here today after brisk debate. The consultation is a 10yearold Protestant merger movement involving nine de nominations with a constitu ency of some 25 million per sons.

title: HULICK IS VICTOR 3 TIMES AT DEVON
description: DEVON, Pa., May 22Jim Hulick of Sterling, Mass., the son of two professional riding instructors, piloted Hombre to victory in the first junior jump er class today at the opening of the Devon horse show.

title: Phils' Money in Hospital
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (UPI)Don Money, third base man for the Philadelphia Phillies entered the University of Pennsylvania hospital today for treatment of a broken bone near his right eye. A team spokesman said Money would remain hospitalized for three or four days.

title: Miss Hite, Mrs. Griffith Gain Southern Title Golf Final
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 22 (AP)  Kathy Hite of Florence, S. C.. and Mrs. John Griffith of Fort Worth, Tex., scored 3 and2 victories today to gain the final of the Women's Southern amateur golf cham pionship.

title: War Against Children
description: The heroes of the Palestinian liberation, as they refer to themselves, have committed an act of barbaric savagely with their cowardly attack on an Israeli school bus.

title: Antiques: Some Rare Birds in Ceramic
description: An early 18thcentury Ger man porcelain teapot and a 1960 American porcelain fig ure of a bird were both in cluded in last week's im portant ceramic auction at the ParkeBernet Galleries.

title: Strike Planned at WNEWTV
description: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, rep resenting 120 sound and light ing studio engineers, said yes terday that it would strike WNEWTV here and WTTGTV in Washington at midnight. The union's contrast with the two Metromedia stations expired May 12, but work has continued after agreement on an exten sion. The union's locals, 794 and 519, say that Metromedia presented a list of demands they said would destroy union jurisdiction.

title: RAMBERT PRESENTS CHESWORTH BALLET
description: LONDON, May 22An in triguing new ballet by John Chesworth, Four According, was given by Ballet Rambert at the Jeannetta Cochrane Theater last night.

title: 500 in Art Strike Sit on Steps of Metropolitan
description: Nearly 500 participants in the New York Art Strike artists, art students, art teach ers and gallery employessat in yesterday on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum and suc ceeded in drastically reducing its normal daily attendance of 4,000.

title: Oakland a Night Team
description: Outside of Saturday and Sun day games and a day game with Detroit on Monday, Aug. 17, all of Oakland's home base ball games will be played at night this year.

title: Saigon Force in Cambodia Doubles in Week to 40,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 22South Vietnam has dou bled the size of its forces oper ating within Cambodia during the last week.

title: Emerson Wickwire Marries Miss Barbara Nancy Schmidt
description: PITTSBURGH, May 22 Miss Barbara Nancy Schmidt and Emerson MacMillin Wick wire were married this after noon in the Heinz Memorial Chapel of the University of Pittsburgh by Canon Hugh S. Clark, an Episcopal min ister.

title: MEYERSON TO END BROKERAGE BUSINESS
description: Meyerson & Co., Inc., a stock brokerage concern based in San Francisco, announced yes terday that it had ended its gen eneral borkerage business and would close its offices in Bur lingame and Modesto, Calif., and New York.

title: Auto Makers List a 9.3% Sales Gain
description: The nation's car makers came up with their best news in several months as they an nounced yesterday a sharp im provement in newcar sales during the May 1120 period.

title: Nixon Plans to Ask $16Billion Increase In U.S. Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  The Nixon Administration plans to ask Congress on Mon day for an increase of almost $16billion in the public debt ceiling, which would raise it to a record $393billion.

title: O'Dwyer, 62, Finds His Age an Aid
description: Paul O'Dwyer, who is 20 years older than any of his three opponents for the Dem ocratic nomination for United States Senator, says that re election would never be on his mind if he became a Sen ator, and that he would play an independent Washington role, like the LaFollettes.

title: CRITICS DOMINATE MEETING OF G.M
description: DETROIT, May 22  Crit ics of the giant General Motors Corporation received only min iscule support from sharehold ers for their proposals today, but they used the annual meet ing here to stir debate on pol lution control, car safety and minority hiring.

title: BRITISH BAR TOUR BY CRICKET TEAM
description: LONDON, May 22A sched uled tour of England by an all white South African cricket team was called off today fol lowing pressure from the Brit ish Government and threats of demonstrations against the ra cial separation policies of South Africa.

title: Mayor Calls Power Parley
description: Disturbed that the city faces a possible power shortage dur ing peak hours this summer, Mayor Lindsay asked Consoli ated Eidson representatives yes terday to mete with his Emer gency Control Board on Wed nesday. The company will be asked to review its plans for dealing wtih potential black outs and brownouts.

title: Israeli Children Are Principal Victims of an Ambush Close to Lebanon
description: JERUSALEM, May 22Elev en persons were killed and 21 wounded, most of them chil dren, when a school bus was ambushed this morning in Is rael, about 500 yards from the Lebanese border.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Treasury statement, the Government bonds table, stockmarket highs and lows, and some of the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange quotations are omitted from this issue because of com posing room delays caused by union meetings.

title: G.M. Contends Sales Have Passed LowPoint
Senator's Son Pleads Guilty
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., May 22 Michael M. Hollings, 19, son of United States Senator Ernest F. Hollings, South Carolina Demo crat, pleaded guilty in Munic ipal Court today to charges of possession of marijuana and speeding on the New Jersey Turnpike here Sunday. Mr. Hold lings, a sophomore at the Uni versity of Virginia, was given a sixmonth suspended jail sen tence, was fined $200 and lost his driving privileges in New Jersey for a year on the mari juana charge. He was fined $15 on the speeding charge by Mu nicipal Judge John T. Soja.

title: Canadiens, Kings in Trade
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 22 (UPI)The Los Angeles Kings announced tonight they had ac quired Jack Norris, a goalie, along with Lucien Grenier and Larry Mickey, wings, in a trade with the Montreal Can adiens. The Kings gave Leon Rochefort, a Wing, and Greg Boddy, a defenseman, to the Canadians. Montreal also ac quired the rights to an amateur goalie, Wayne Thomas of the University of Michigan.

title: College Golfer Has Ace
description: A Wayne State University golfer, Richard Burnosky, scored a holeinone in a prac lice round at the Rouge golf muse on April 23, firing a 73 for the round on the W.S.U. home course.

title: Mrs. Barnette And Economist Marry Upstate
description: TONAWANDA, N. Y., May 22  Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Lasher Barnette and Law rence Brumfield Myers of Snyder, were married today at the bride's home. The Rev. J. Donald Johnston of the Unitarian Universalist Church of Niagara Falls performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. WOMEN BEAT SO. AFRICA AT NET
description: FREIBURG, West Germany, May 22 (UPI)Peaches Bartko wicz of Hamtramck, Mich., and Julie Heldman of New York won their singles matches to day as the United States routed South Africa, 30, and gained the semifinal round of the Women's Federation Cup ten nis tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Three years ago the increase given the apartment building service employes was passed along to the tenants in the form of annual increases spread over three years. Therefore landlords are not entitled to wail about the cost of the raise given the service employes at that time. Surely the same thing will happen this time.

title: Miss Ella Foshay Is Bride Here
description: Miss Ella Milbank Foshay and Michael B. Rothfeld were married yesterday afternoon in the Georgian Suite at lA East 77th Street. State Su preme Court Justice Theodore R. Kupferman performed the ceremony.

title: Costello Revealed Details of His Bets Before Jury Here
description: Frank Costello, who once served an 18  month prison term for refusing to answer the questions of a United States Senate crime commit tee, has given a New York County grand jury not only the name of a man with whom he said he placed recent bets but also the dates and amounts of the bets.

title: The Azores, Awakening NeverNever Land
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores, The biggest event here in recent months was the mad dash of a pig from the wharf along the main avenue and into the window of a Portuguese Airlines agency.

title: Sentiment Against War Deluges A Nixon Emissary at Columbia
description: President Nixon sent a young aide to Columbia University to find out why he had a problem with the academic community.

title: President Thieu or President Nixon?
description: LONDON, May 22Through all the years of war and frus trated negotiation and plans for American withdrawal, there has been one central question for the United States in Vietnam: to what extent would we he committed to the objectives of the Saigon Government?

title: STOCK PRICES DIP TO ANOTHER LOW
description: Stock prices registered an other new low yesterday since early 1963 as measured by the DowJones industrial average, but activity was restrained and cautious in the preweekend session.

title: Mrs.Carter Upset in Bowling
description: TULSA, Okla, May 22 (AP) Mildred Martollea of Pochester, N. Y., advanced to the finals today Of the 10th annual Woman's International Bowling Congress tournament with an ??72728 victory over Mrs. ?? Carter of St. Louis.

title: D. EARL FLEMING
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 22 D. Earl Fleming, vice presi dent and a director of Clark Metal Products, Inc., Fairfield, Conn., died Wednesday in his home at 16 Hillview Drive. His age was 87.

title: Benefit at Applause
description: The Mental Health Asso ciation of New York and Bronx Counties will hold a theaterbenefit at Applause on Monday to be followed by a supper dance at the Plaza Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller and Mrs. Alan N. Sidnam are cochairmen of the blacktie event. Tickets, at $50, $75 and $100, are available at the association, 11 West 42d Street.

title: Friday Night Baseball Scores
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: VAN LINGE WINS ON FRENCH LINKS
description: PARIS, May 22 (APB Charles Van Linge of Portola Valley, Calif., Friday led threeman American chal lenge into the quarterfinal round of the French amateur golf championship today.

title: Buffalo G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) The Defense Department to day identified 21 servicemen as having been killed in the war in Southeast Asia, including S./ Sgt. Roger T. Lagodzinski of Buffalo, N.Y., of the Army.

title: Cairo Paper Reports U.S. Is Sending Israel Copters
description: CAIRO, May 22 (Reuters) The authoritative Cairo news paper Al Ahram reported today that the United States had agreed to supply Israel with 130 military helicopters.

title: JUDY KIMBALL'S 67 LEADS BY 4 SHOTS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22 (UPI)  Judy Kimball, her sprained left wrist encased in a bandage, carded a fiveunder par 67 today and took a four stroke lead in the first round of the $20,000 Bluegrass invita tion tournament.

title: Columbia Students Profiting in Drugs
description: Some students at Columbia University are grossing from $200 to $3,000 a month dealing in LSD, mescaline, marijuana, hashish and amphetamines, a number of undergraduates said yesterday.

title: Cruise for Vietnam Veterans
description: WASHINGTON May 22 (AP)  President Nixon's daughter and soninlaw, Julie and David Eisenhower, accompanied Viet nam war veterans on the first of a planned series of Potomac River cruises on the Presiden tial yacht Sequoia. On the trip yesterday were 37 soldiers from service hospitals in the capital area.

title: Nickel Aide Explains Delay In Oil Shales' Development
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)  Secretary of the Inte rior Walter J. Hickel delayed the private development of Western oil share resources be cause of possible damage to the environment, an offical for the Interior Department told Con gress Thursday.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: CAPETOWN, May 22 (AP) Pieter Johannes Smith, a heart transplant patient, died early today at Groote Schuur Hos pital. He was 53 years old. His death was attributed to cancer of the stomach.

title: To Purser, Lure of Sea Was an Ad
description: Paul Marcel Georges Ermel, who was in port last week as the new chief purser of the French Line's France, ex plained in an interview how an advertisement drew him to the sea.

title: U.S. Assails Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (Reu ters)  The State Department today condemned the attack on an Israeli school bus by Arab guerrillas and expressed shock at the killing of Lebanese civilians in an Israeli counter action.

title: California Relays Draws Top Stars To Modesto Today
description: MODESTO, Calif., May 22 (UPI)  John Carlos, never at loss for words, has taken Charlie Greene's measure this spring and now it's for him to find out how good Eddie Hart really is.

title: GraftInquiry Head
description: About a week ago Mayor Lindsay telephoned a trim, grayhaired lawyer to ask him to undertake a special assignment.

title: SINGING RAIN 65 TO WIN TOP FLIGHT
description: The final program of Aque duct's spring meeting will be held today, with the $50,000 added Top Flight Handicap heading the bill. For fillies and mares at a distance of 1 miles, the Top Flight has at tracted a field of 10 for its 31st running.

title: Slow but Significant Progress Indicated at Arms Talks in Vienna
description: VIENNA, May 22American and Soviet disarmament nego tiators met today for two hours the longest session to date amid indications that slow but significant progress was being made in the fiveweekold Vi enna talks on the limiting of strategic arms.

title: Quarry Bout Ticket Sale Set
description: Tickets for the Jerry Quarry Mac Foster heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden on June 17 will go on sales Mon day, the Garden announced yes terday. Ticket prices are scaled from $25 to $5 and will be available at the Garden's main ticket office.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: A Relative Stranger, by Anne Ste venson (Putnam, $5.95). Sus pense and intrigue.

title: Executive Changes
description: Roger D. Williams has been elected chairman the hoard of the S. S. Pierce Company, replacing William T. Pierce, who becomes honorary chairman. Robert F. Gammons, a vice president of Laird Enterprises, which acquired S. S. Pierce in 1967, becomes president and chief executive officer and a director of S. S. Pierce. Also elected a director S. S. Pierce was Henry C. Montgomery, a vice presi dent of Laird.

title: Music: Rare Schumann
description: One of Robert Schumann's leastplayed yet most ambiti ous scores was presented by the New York Philharmonic Thursday night to start the final week of subscrpition concerts. It was Das Para dies and die peri, a secular oratorio composed in 1843 to a section of Thomas Moore's poem Lalla Rookh. It is safe to saw that this city has not heard a performance for generations.

title: Stores With General Goods Found to Do Most Business
description: Stores that sell a general line of retail goods do better than stores specializing in one type of merchandise, according to a study of retail sales trends made by the MeinhardCommer cial Corporation, which supplies many millions of dollars in credit to retail stores every year, United Press International reported

title: National Maritime Day, '70: By the Sea, by the Sea, by the NotSoBeautiful Sea
description: National Maritime Day, traditionally an annual cele bration of the nation's nauti cal enterprise, shifted to a protest against seaborne polu tion and waterfront decay in its observance here yes terday.

title: EINTRACHT DOWNS CELTIC IN SOCCER
description: After proving their defense was a match for the quick striking Glasgow Celtic of fense, Eintracht of Frankfurt turned on the power last night and scored a brilliant tactical soccer triumph, 31.

title: U.S.Italian Air Accord Ends a FourYear Dispute
description: ROME, May 22The United States and Italy announced to day agreement in principle on a new air transportation ac cord. A statement here said that a formal agreement would be signed in Rome in the near future after the two govern ments approve the draft text and route schedules.

title: Nixon Postal Reform Wins Backing of 2 Key Senators
description: WASHINGTON, May 22A tentative agreement on a pro posed Senate bill that would give President Nixon most of what he seeks in regard to postal reorganization and increased postal rates was announced today.

title: COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES
description: COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES

title: ITALIANAMERICANS ASK INQUIRY ON F.B.I.
description: A group that has been pick eting the New York headquar ters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, at 69th Street and Third Avenue, called yes terday for a Congressional in quiry into the alleged harass ment of ItalianAmericans by the F.B.I.

title: Red Forces in Cambodia Nearing the Laos Border
description: VOEUN KHAM, Laos, May 20  The thumping sounds of mor tar and artillery fire can be heard clearly in this tiny village on the Cambodian border as military officials report that Communist troops on the other side have swept north within two and a half miles Of the frontier.

title: GRACE TO RAISE FERTILIZER PRICE
description: W. R. Grace & Co. an nounced yesterday it planned to increase its prices for phos phate fertilizer by $2 to $3 a ton, effective Sept. 1.

title: Democrats List Party Reform Groups
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 Two new groups with the power to screen reform recom menations being prepared for the 1972 Democratic National Convention were created today by the partys executive com mittee.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Down the Subway Tracks
description: Even before the multiple investigations of this week's fatal subway crash get under way, several points are painfully clear. One is that an understaffed, partially dilapidated and poorly maintained subway system endangers the safety of its fourandahalf million daily riders. Another is that sweeping reforms are called for. Still another is that no real improve ment is likely without basic changes in attitudes.

title: Transit Workers in IND Crash Seek Immunity Before Talking
description: Three Transit Authority em ployes who were on the dis abled subway train that smashed into a crowded IND train in Queens on Wednesday refused to testify yesterday be fore a Queens grand jury un less they were granted immun ity.

title: Seton Hall Picks President
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., May 22 (AP)Seton Hall Univer sity's board of trustees an nounced today that it has chosen the Rev. Thomas G. Fahy as the school's 14th presi dent. Father Fahy, who suc ceeds the Most Rev. John J. Dougherty, Auxiliary Bishop of Newark, has been serving as vice president in charge of in struction at the school since 1963.

title: Cuban Reply Assails the Swiss For Protest on Demonstrators
description: MIAMI, May 22 (AP)  Cuba has sent a sharp note to Switzerland, the Havana radio reported today, accentuating suddenly deteriorating relations between the two nations as an indirect result of the kidnap ping of 11 Cuban fishermen by Cuban exiles based in the United States.

title: U.S. Aide Asked Panel Not to Study Panther Deaths
description: CHICAGO, May 22Assist ant Attorney General Jerris Leonard met with members of the newly formed Goldberg Commission early this year to dissuade them from conducting an independent investigation of the deaths of two Black Panthers in a police raid here last Dec. 4.

title: Girl in Kent Sfate Photo Identified as Runaway
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP)Mary Ann Vecchio, 15 years old, whose picture kneeling beside a slain Kent State University student was circulated throughout the world, waited in an Indianap olis juvenile detention center today for her parents to send an airplane ticket to bring her home to Florida.

title: National Airlines Planning To Resume Flights Monday
description: MIAMI, May 22 (AP)  Na tional Airlines began requalify ing its flight crews today and moved ahead with plans to resume passenger operations Monday in spite of new picket lines thrown up by a striking union.

title: U.S. Examining Possibility Of CopperPrice Trust Suit
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Justice Department's antitrust division is examining the pos sibility of bringing suit against the unusual, but longstanding, twoprice system under which copper is sold in the United States.

title: SENATE SETS A TEST ON CAMBODIAN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) The Senate agreed today to a test vote next week on the drive to curb United States ac tivities in Cambodia.

title: 4 MORE LEAVING KISSINGER'S STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The National Security Council staff headed by Henry A. Kissinger is losing at least four more members and there are unveri fied reports that one other is also quitting.

title: 10 FILLIES, MARES TO RACE ON COAST
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 22 (UPI)Tipping Time and Pattee Canyon, female horses raised and raced at opposite ends of the country, head the field of 10 fillies and mares in the $S0,750 Vanity Handicap to morrow at Hollywood Park.

title: 2 Policemen Here Sell Keystone Pig Buttons
description: Two young patrolmen have gone into business to prove that policemen have a sense of humor. With an initial in vestment of $500, the two, both members of the special events squad assigned to pa trol demonstrations, formed Keystone Pig Enterprises.

title: BENVENUTI FACES CONQUEROR AGAIN
description: UMAG, Yugoslavia, May 22 (AP)  Tom (The Bomb) Be thea, the virtually unknown New Yorker who stopped Nino Benvenuti in a nontitle fight in March, gets his chance at Ben venuti's world middleweight championship tomorrow night in a 15round bout in this city just across the border from Italy.

title: G.O.P. Women Urging A Nonsitent Majority
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 The National Federation of Republican Women is trying to end the silence of the silent majority.

title: Cavett to Entertain Writers
description: Dick Cavett, the host of the televised latenight talk show of the American Broadcasting Company, will entertain Mon day night at the Americana during the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Professional Football Writers Association.

title: SENATE PETITIONS FOR M'CARTHY CUT
description: The petitions to put Repre sentative R. D. Max McCarthy on the ballot for the Demo cratic nomination for Senator were cut down to the bare minimum of 47 counties yes terdaywith the validity of the signatures from two of those counties still in doubt.

title: ONLY 2 NEW ISSUES OFFERED PUBLICLY
description: The newissue market, which has been virtually stagnant in recent weeks, continued in the doldrums this week as only two companies made first public of ferings of their common stock.

title: Czech Conductor Shows Assurance In American Debut
description: Miro J. Pansky, a Czech con ductor in his early thirties who has been living here for a cou ple of years, made his American debut Thursday night in Town Hall leading an ensemble called Musici of New York. In a way it was a resumption of a career, because one of Mr. Pansky's chief activities in Europe was touring with a chamber orches tra, Musici XIII.

title: American Exchange Prices Fall to Lowest Level Since June, 1967
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday dropped to their lowest level since June, 1967, as most stocks continued to decline in slower trading.

title: Roundup: Merritt's No. 9, Courtesy of Reds' Power
description: Going into their encounter last night, Jim Merritt and Larry Dierker both were eightgame winners.

title: SAMUELS TOURS 3 AREAS UPSTATE
description: ONEONTA, N. Y., May 22 Howard J. Samuels, who is seeking the Democratic nomi nation for Governor, pledged today to be an 18houraday Governor dedicated to thwart ing vested interests ranging from featherbedding laborers to highsalaried full profes sors who balk at carrying full teaching loads.

title: ECONOMIST ASSAILS THE RESERVE CLAUSE
description: Robert R. Nathan, the econo mist, testified yesterday that the reservesystem arrange ments common in baseball and other professional sports had no parallel in any other sec tor of the American freeen terprise system and that it tended to depress the level of wages paid to players who had no opportunity to bar gain with an alternative user of their skills.

title: YOUTH CORPS HELD LIMITED IN HIRING
description: A Bronx grand jury recom mended yesterday that the Fed eral poverty income index be raised for the city to keep the Neighborhood Youth Corps from violating the law by hiring youngsters from families whose income is higher than the index.

title: 600 JOIN RALLY HERE OF SILENT MAJORITY
description: An enthusiastic crowd of 600 attended a rally advertised as being for the silent majority last night at Manhattan Center, cheering speeches by former mayoral candidates Mario A. Procaccino and John J. Marchi and applauding a selfpro claimed police undercover in formant.

title: Woodcock Pledges U. A.W. Goals Will Not Change
description: DETROIT, May 22Leonard Woodcock was elected presi dent of the United Automobile Workers today. He is the fourth president in the union's 34year history, and he immediately pledged that the U.A.W.'s di rectionfor social causes and economic goalswould not change.

title: Misdirected Memorial
description: The Board of Education cannot he faulted for its deci sion to close the city's schools yesterday in memory of the nine victims of the police shootings in Jackson and Augusta. Refusal to accede to the appeal by Negro and Puerto Rican students would certainly have been in terpreted as insensitivity to the deaths of Negroes after schools had previously been suspended in mourning for the four white students killed at Kent State.

title: Article 1  No Title
Kicks Set N.C.A.A. Mark
description: LARAMIE, Wyo. (AP) Bob Jacobs of Wyoming set a Na tional Collegiate record by kick ing 18 field goals in the 1969 season. He also led the Western Athletic Conference in punting with an average of 42.5 yards for 79 kicks.

title: PRICES OF FUTURES IN PLATINUM FALLS
description: Platinum futures dropped in price again yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as precious metals continued to lose their luster.

title: SEXTUPLETS HERE HAD CHANCE OF 3%
description: The sextuplets born here Thursday, all of whom died within seven hours, had less than a 3 per cent chance of surviving because of their im maturity, the obstetrician who delivered them said yesterday.

title: Note to Readers
description: Reviews of last night's dance and music perform ances are omitted from this issue because of composing room delays caused by union meetings. They will appear tomorrow.

title: Prisoner Flees Jersey Jail
description: LEESBURG, N. J., May 22 (UPI)A 44yearold convicted killed escaped from the mini mumsecurity state prison here last night, soon after being turned down on a parole appli cation. The prisoner, Walter Beckworth of Cliffside Park in Bergen County, was admitted to the prison in 1964 to serve a 15to20year term following a homicide conviction.

title: Sarah Churchill to Rewed
description: LONDON, May 22 (AP) Sarah Churchill, the actress and 55yearold daughter of Sir Winston, said today that she would marry next week for the fourth time. Her hus band is to be Oloff de Wet, a 58yearold sculptor who was French Resistance agent during World War II.

title: DETECTIVE LINKED TO CRIME FIGURES
description: A detective working with the headquarters unit that col lects intelligence about top figures in organized crime in New York has been dismissed from the Police Department for having unauthorized dealings with known criminals.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW ADVANCES
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed slightly firmer yesterday after a weak open ing. Most Continental markets eased further, but the down trend appeared to be slacken ing. The Tokyo market ad vanced moderately with a late rally.

title: Costs Seen as Most Serious Problem
description: More than 1,000 steel executives will pack and head for New York early next week, most of them in a rather bleak frame of mind.

title: Unicef Seeks CleanWater
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. (AP) The executive board of the United Nations Children's Fund has approved a fouryear multi milliondollar project aimed at providing clean water for 10 million people in 12,000 villages of hardrock areas in rural India.

title: 2d French Nuclear Test Is Carried Out in Pacific
description: PARIS, May 22 (Reuters) France exploded an experimen tal nuclear device today in the Pacific, the second in the cur rent series of tests, the De fense Ministry announced to night.

title: MEDIA ARE WARNED AGAINST DIVERSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, ON, May 22  The nation's mass media were warned today against being di verted by Vice President Ag new and other critics from their central role of reporting and analyzing significant issues of the day.

title: JOHN J. BALLENTINE, RETIRED ADMIRAL, 73
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  Adm. John J. Ballentine, former commander of the air arm of the Atlantic Fleet, died yesterday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 73 years old and retired in 1954.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the attention being paid these days to all sorts of offcenter fiction, to the antinovel that blurs time, setting and char acter, to the mythmaking fabulists, to the mixedmedia writers who look to tapes and playback machines for assists, even to such categories as the nonfiction novel, there is a tendency to slight the well made, storytelling entertainment. It is a genre that demands as much skill and craft as the less conven tional works, though skill and craft of a different order. One reason they are less pro voking is that when they are done well, the nar rative element is so compelling that the reader forgets that there is any artifice involved at alla trait that may call forth high praise from the reader but draws few analytical essays from the literati. These novels are terribly symbolic, archetypical They only readable.

title: The College of Your Choice
description: Pro football scouts call them producers, and they are the colleges and universities that serve as a farm system for the National Football League. Some of them offer their athletes a quality education, and some of them make an effort to keep their athletes eligible for graduation as well as for games. But others lose interest in their athletes when the season is over and let them leave school without a degree.

title: PERCY V. HINKSON
description: Percy V. Hinkson, a member of the credit department of The New York Times since 1945, died Thursday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Kingsbridge, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 1270 Webster Avenue, in the borough.

title: Setback at Kassel
description: West German Chancellor Willy Brandt had no illu sions from the beginning about how difficult he would find the task of trying to normalize relations with East Germany. Even so, however, he must have been stag gered by the harshness of East German Premier Willi Stoph's attitude at Kassel.

title: Ruined Cambodian Town Can't Understand Why
description: SNOUL, Cambodia, May 19 None of the people here understand why it has hap nened to them.

title: Tropical Storm Dies
description: MIAMI, May 22 (UPI)A Caribbean tropical storm, des ignated Alma, disappeared to day after two days on the weather charts. The National Hurricane Center said the storm had broken up.

title: At Boarding Schools, Many Girls Really Like Their Uniforms
description: IN this day of doyour ownthing and a choice among minis, midis and max is, a surprising number of girls at exclusive New York and New England boarding schools don't seem to mind wearing uniforms.

title: Mrs. Lenore Lyons Is Wed in Plandome
description: PLANDOME, L. I., May 22 Mrs. Lenore Lyons was married today to Jonas Rosenfield Jr. in the North Shore Unitarian Church by the Rev. J. Harold Hadley.

title: Incres Line Names Officer
