description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23 Famished drought victims in the periodically stricken states of Brazil's Northeast have bro ken into food stores and trains, it was reported today as offi cial agencies took relief, meas ures.

title: Brief Stiike Ended By Rochester Police Asking Pay Change
description: ROCHESTER, May 23Police men in this city went on strike for nearly eight hours today before reaching a temporary backtowork agreement with police department officials at 11:15 tonight.

title: Barney Plans to Delegate Duties To the New Officers of National
description: When Josh Barney retired from the presidency of the National Horse Show in 1960, he never thought he'd head the organization again.

title: Hundreds of Greeks Find Junta Bars Them From Trips Abroad
description: ATHENS, May 23Although the threeyearold military gov ernment of Greece recently per mitted the leftwing composer Mikis Theodorakis and French journalist Jean Starakis to leave prison and the country, hundreds who are less well known are finding that their path to foreign travel is barred.

title: 5Day March in Georgia Ends With Massive Rally
description: ATLANTA, May 23Close to 10,000 persons, walking four miles through the hot streets of Atlanta, ended today a fiveday, 110mile march against repres sion.

title: Soviet Aerial Challenge Suspected by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 23A number of military and diplo matic analysts here believe that Soviet military activity in the United Arab Republic may well be aimed at challenging and destroying much of the Israeli Air Force.

title: Polar Bear Breeding Area Found
description: OTTAWA, May 23Biolo gists have identified in north ern Manitoba what they re gard as one of the most im portant polarbear denning, or reproduction, areas in the world.

title: Jewish Activists See Ranks Growing
description: Since its founding in the summer of 1968, the Jewish Defense League has withstood the criticism of most major Jewish organizations and has pursued its vision of militant preparedness with karate classes and neighborhood patrols.

title: Dayan Warns Lebanese To Curb Guerrilla Raids
description: TEL AVIV, May 24Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned Lebanon today that Israel would take action if Lebanese officials did not act to curb activities by Arab guerrillas along the border.

title: Chess:
A'S WIN BY 51, 52 FROM WHITE SOX
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI)  The Oakland Athletics swept a doubleheader from the Chi cago White Sox today, win ning the first game, 51, be hind Chuck Dobson's one  hit pitching. They took the second game, 52, aided by Don Minch er's tworun homer that sailed out of the nark.

title: Columbia Gives Author Ifs Top Academic Rank
description: Dr. Lionel Trilling, author and literary critic, has been appointed university profes sor at Columbiathe highest academic rank and one of only three such posts at the university.

title: Staten Island City
description: No one can accuse the Rouse Company of failing to think big about the development potentials of South Richmond, that vast and underdeveloped south ern third of Staten Island for which Rouse proposes a $6.5billion city within a city.

title: JOHN R. MOORE JR.
description: John Robert Moore Jr., a textile designer for Fieldcrest Mills, Inc., and a painter, died Saturday of hepatitis in New York Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 130 East 18th Street.

title: Billy Graham Expects Second Coming Soon
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 24 (UPI)Billy Graham said today that he believed all the signs are now in place for the second Coming of Christ.

title: 8 Leftist Parties in Bengal Join to Oppose Militant Reds
description: CALCUTTA, India, May 24 (AP)  Eight leftist political parties in the state of West Bengal announced today that they were forming a mas move ment against militant Marxist Communists.

title: When Nothing Is Beyond Belief
description: LONDONAn American pro fessor now teaching at Oxford has just made a brief visit to his old campus in the United States. He came back here with a new insight into the psycho logical gulf between so many American students and their elders.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Armstrong in Leningrad
description: LENINGRAD, May 24 (AP) Neil A. Armstrong, the first man on the moon, received a warm welcome today from Soviet astronauts, but there was no advance publicity about his arrival to attend an international space conference.

title: Larchmont Yacht Summaries
description: DIVISION I

title: 4 Democratic Senate Nominees Trade Charges in Their First Debate on Television
description: The four candidates for the Democratic Senate nomination met for the first time yester day in one of the television debates that have become a feature of New York political campaigns, and two of them went on the attack.

title: Tunisian Trial Ends Era of Farm Reform
description: TUNIS, May 23The spec tacular failure of Tunisia's col lectivefarm program was flaunted here at the show trial of the country's former eco nomic boss.

title: Professor Weds Joan M. Helpern, Medical Student
description: Miss Joan Marilyn Helpern and Dr. Alfred Lewis Gold berg were married here yes terday afternoon at the Park Avenue Synagogue. The cere mony was performed by Rabbi Judah Nadich, assisted by Rabbi William Braude and Cantor David Putterman.

title: Taylor Wins Title, 7 and 6, In French Amateur Golf
description: PARIS, May 24 (AP)  Reg Taylor of South Africa, making a golfing comeback after five years, defeated Didier Charmat of France, 7 and 6, today and won the French amateur cham pionship.

title: Gypsies Honor Patron In French Pilgrimage
description: LES SAINTES MARIES DE LA MER, France, May 24 (Reuters)About 10,000 gyp sies gathered today for their annual pilgrimage in this Mediterranean town near Arles, carrying the statue of their patron saint, Sarah, along the beach in a cen turiesold ceremony.

title: Sandler Handball Victor; Dikman Is Upset by Levine
description: Steve Sandler, the national Amateur Athletic Union one wall handball champion, took another step yesterday to re tain his title. The 92d Street Y.M.H.A. star scored a 1321, 214, 2110 secondround vic tory over Charlie Shelvon of the Brownsville Handball Club.

title: Police and Youths Clash In Milan for 2d Day in Row
description: ROME, May 24 (AP)Police men battled rampaging youths in Milan today for the second day in a row.

title: Leftists Oppose O.A.S. Meeting in Santo Domingo
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 24Dominican leftist opposition to a scheduled meeting of American foreign ministers here next month is causing concern among dip lomats here.

title: Ashton, Leaving the Royal Ballet, Eyes Fresh Fields
description: Sir Frederick Ashton, di rector of Britain's Royal Bal let, who has just come to town, is going.

title: Courtaulds Closing 2 Plants
description: LONDON, May 24 (UPI)  Courtaulds, Ltd., said this week end it would close two uneco nomic manmadefiber plants, laying off 1,500 workers.

title: Marine Lieutenant Charged With Murder in Vietnam
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 24 (AP)A lieutenant in the Marine Corps has been charged with premeditated murder in the death of a Viet namese near Danang on March 28, a marine spokesman re ported today.

title: BOARD SETS HEARING ON TRENCHES IN PARK
description: With the support of Manhat tan Borough President Percy E. Sutton, a community board with planning jurisdiction on the Upper East Side will hold a public hearing Wednesday night to air protests against plans to dig up sections in the southeast corner of Central Park for a new subway tunnel.

title: Table of Annual Costs Of Cleaning Up Litter
description: Following are some repre sentative current annual gov ernmental expenditures for cleaning up litter (as distinct from regular refuse collection) as estimated by qualified offi cials:

title: 7 Cubans Die in Floods
description: MIAMI, May 24 (AP)Seven Cubansincluding a 4yearold boy and a 14monthold baby drowned in flood caused by rains from tropical storm Alma, the Havana Radio reported to day. The rainswollen Vicana River swept away a concrete bridge and destroyed several homes in the coastal commu nity of Media Luna where all seven drownings occurred, ac cording to a broadcast moni tored in Miami.

title: Truman Institute Dedicated
description: JERUSALEM, May 24 (Reu ters)The $1million Harry S. Truman research institute of the Hebrew University was ded icated here today on Mount Scopus in the presence of Presi dent Zalman Shazar of Israel. The institute has been working in the areas of peace research and in the field of development in emerging countries.

title: Agnew Calls for Greater International Cooperation in Drive Against Disease
description: HOUSTON, May 24  Vice President Agnew proposed to day that the nations of this world, plagued by many ills some of our own making, some born of nature  declare the nineteenseventies the de cade against disease.

title: 5 NEWSMEN IN WAR DETAINED AND FREED
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 24 (AP)  Five newsmen, in cluding a Pulitzer Prizewinning photographer, were detained by North Vietnamese soldiers in Cambodia this weekend but were quickly released.

title: Star Rejoins Plaza Suite
description: Maureen Stapleton will re place Peggy Cass tonight for a twoweek period as costar op posite Don Porter in Plaza Suite at the Plymouth Theater. Miss Cass is slated to undergo minor throat surgery. Miss Sta pleton, who, with George C. Scott, created the starring roles in the tripartite comedy, ap peared in the Neil Simon play from its opening on Feb. 14, 1968, through December of last year.

title: SPAIN AND FRANCE GAIN CUP SWEEPS
description: Spain and France completed 50 sweeps yesterday and moved into the next round of European Zone Groupm Davis Cup tennis play, the Associated Press reported. They will op pose each other June 12 through 14.

title: Miss Ruth Ann Slawson Married
description: Miss Ruth Ann Slawson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Slawson, was married at the Central Synagogue yesterday to Allan Bennett Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Schwartz of Hamden, Conn. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony.

title: UNIVERSAL PRAYER LED BY STOKOWSKI
description: Andrzej Panufnik is Polish by birth (1914) but in 1953 he settled In England. How re markably he has adapted to the language of his new home was heard yesterday in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, where Leopold Sto kowski led the world premiere of Mr. Panufnik's setting of Alexander Pope's Universal Praver.

title: Pollution Index Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) Representative Bertram L. Podell, Democrat of Brooklyn, proposed today a comprehen sive environmental quality in dex to monitor the effective ness of all antipollution efforts. He said the Environmental Science Services Administra tion of the Commerce Depart ment would be the monitoring agency and would make daily reports to the people in the same manner that daily weather reports are made.

title: NATO MINISTERS MEET TOMORROW
description: ROME, May 24The foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization open a twoday meeting here Tuesday. The most significant result is expected to be a renewed call to the Warsaw Pact countries to join the West in a mutual and balanced reduction of forces in Central Europe.

title: A Radical Declaration Warns Of an Attack by Weathermen
description: CHICAGO, May 24  An underground declaration of war purportedly issued by the Weathermen warns that the revolutionary group will at tack a symbol or institution of American injustice within the next two weeks.

title: SENATORS SCORE OVER TIGERS, 64
description: DETROIT, May 24 (UPI) Rick Reichardt's grandslam home run capped a sixrun sec ond inning today and gave Joe Coleman his seventh career victory without a loss over De troit as the Washington Sena tors defeated the Tigers, 64.

title: O'BRIEN CLARIFIES ROLE OF 2 PANELS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Dem ocratic national chairman, said today that two new commit tees named last week were created solely for the purpose of speeding implementation of the reform proposals of party commissions working toward the 1972 Democratic National Convention.

title: Sedate British Company Jarred by Wildcat Strike.
description: ST. HELENS, England, May 24In this red brick Lanca shire industrial town, a pater nalistic company and a co operative union have been shaken by a violent seven week wildcat strike, the first serious labor trouble here for 100 years.

title: HOMER IN TENTH TOPS BOSTON, 21
description: BALTIMORE, May 24 (UPI) Dick Schofield's sacrifice fly scored Tony Conigliaro with the winning run in the ninth inning today as the Boston Red Sox scored a 43 victory, after the Baltimore Orioles had won the first game of their doublehead er, 21. Brooks Robinson's 10th inning leadoff homer decided the first contest.

title: MRS. REEVE SCHLEY
description: FAR HILLS, N.J., May 24 Mrs. Reeve Schley, a former Re publican national committee woman, died of a heart attack Friday at her home. She was 85 years old. Her husband, a bank er, died In 1960.

title: LINDSAY SUPPORTS PAYPRICE FREEZE TO CURB INFLATION
description: Mayor Lindsay called yester day for a mandatory sixmonth freeze on wages and price rises as the first step in bringing in flation under control.

title: A Python Printed Rabbit Is Just the Beginning
description: Like the man who made lemonade out of the lemon fate had handed him, the furriers are turning adversity into profit. With the angry cries of conservationists ring ing in their ears, a number of furriers have quit fighting and joined the movement to preserve endangered beasts.

title: McElreath Speeds Back into Indianapolis 500 Field, Pushing Bartlett Out
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 (AP) Jim McElreath, with a tre mendous lift from A. J. Foyt, a fellow Texan, shouldered his way back into the 500mile Memorial Day 33car race field in the final trials today.

title: BOND PROSPECTS CONTINUE BLEAK
description: Since record bond yields failed to attract investors last week, interest rates will continue to move higher this week.

title: Nixon Leaves Retreat
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House this afternoon after a quiet weekend at Camp David in the Catoctin Moun tains of Maryland. Mrs. Nixon and the Nixon's daughter Tricia accompanied the President on the helicopter flight.

title: Retailers Seek Answer To Continuing Sales Lag
description: What's bothering the con sumer these days? merchants are asking with some exaspera tion in the face of a continuing flatness in retail sales. Is it the new lifestyle or a reaction to the troubled economy? they wonder.

title: Rumanians Evacuated in Flood Threat
description: ALBAIULIA, Rumania, May 24 (Reuters)Thousands of Ru manian families were evacuated today from towns in central Rumania as new floods threat ened. At least 130 have died so far in widespread flooding that has left 265,000 homeless.

title: AUSSIES REGAIN FEDERATION CUP
description: FREIBURG, West Germany, May 24 (UPI)Australia re gained the women's world Fed eration Tennis Cup today with a 30 sweep over West Germany.

title: L.I.A.C. Routs Carling, 147, To Gain Final in Lacrosse
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 24 The Long Island Athletic Club clinched the Northern Division championship of the United States Club Lacrosse Associa tion by defeating Carling L. C., 147, today at Hofstra Univer sity.

title: C5A in Emergency Landing
description: ATLANTA, May 24 (UPI)A C5A, the world's largest air plane, made an emergency land ing tonight after an electrical failure, the Air Force reported. The big craft landed at Dobbins Air Force Base near Atlanta without its landing lights about 11 P.M. There was no further damage and no injuries to the crew of seven aboard, the Air Force said.

title: JOHN B. WOODBURY JR.
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., May 24 John B. Woodbury Jr. of 45 Yale Street; a former mathe matics teacher at Columbia High School here, died yester day in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. His age was 52.

title: Giants Make Fox's Debut a Winning One
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 (AP)Three San Diego errors helped the San Francisco Giants get seven runs in the fifth in ning today and beat the Padres, 76, to complete a doublehead er sweep in the managerial de but of Charlie Fox.

title: Cyprus Finds Stolen Arms
description: LIMASSOL, Cyprus, May 24 (UPI)Some of the weapons stolen early yesterday from Limassol police headquarters have been recovered and 50 per sons have been arrested, the police said today. Some 70 Greek Cypriotes cleaned out the armory and left the guards bound and, locked in jail cells.

title: Con Edison Prices Shares Of New Issue at $22.50
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has fixed a subscription price, of $22.50 a share for the 3,263,751 shares of common stock being offered to holders of record as of the close of business on Thursday, May 21. The offer is based on one new share for each 12 shares held on the record date.

title: Bari Ends American Tour By Beating Eintracht. 10
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) Bari of Italy defeated the Eintracht Soccer Club of Frank fort, 10, today at Temple Stadium.

title: Conservative Party's Influence on State Politics Expected to Grow
description: Sixtyfive Republican candi dates for the Senate and As sembly this year have accepted Conservative party endorse ment compared with 50 two years ago, according to a sur vey of legislative races around the state. That figure is just one of many indicators of the growing stature of the party formed in 1962 by a few young men protesting what they felt was the unRepublican lib eralism of Gover nor Rockefeller and Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: 11 at City U. Turn LawEnforcement Theory into Fact
description: EAST ORANGE N. J. May 25Eleven graduate students at John Jay College of Crim inal Justice of the Ctiy Uni versity of New Yorkall but one of them lawenforcement officersare jointly engaged in producting a master's essay that will not, like thousands of others written each year, molder unread on a library shelf.

title: Civic Group Urges Assistance to Avert Crises Among Aged
description: The Federal, state and city government were urged yester day to set up programs to provide services to the elderly, to prevent the aged from hav ing to face personal crises.

title: Dodgers Triumph Over Braves, 81, As Joshua Stars
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) Von Joshua, a rookie, drove in the deciding run with a sec ondinning single and then tripled in the eighth to trigger a fourrun burst today as he led the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 81 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: SISTER LOUISE
description: CONVENT STATION, N. J., May 24 Sister Louise Mary Brennan, a former grammar and high school teacher, died yesterday at St. Anne's Villa of the Sisters of Charity here. She was 69 years old.

title: Cliff Jackson, Jazz Pianist Here Many Years, Is Dead
description: Clifton Luther (Cliff) Jack son, a popular jazz pianist here for many years, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 818 Ritter Place, the Bronx, after playing the night before at the RX Room, 1638 York Avenue. His age was 67.

title: Pilic Beats Riessen, 63, 75
description: AMSTERDAM, The Nether lands, May 24 (AP)Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia defeated Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 63, 75, in the first round of a professional tennis tourna ment yesterday.

title: Ziemiski Wins 8Mile Run
description: Robert Ziemiski of Queens captured the eightmile run sponsored by the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union at Van Cprtlandt Park, the Bronx, yes terday. He won by three seconds in 44 minutes 58 seconds from Jose Velasquez.

title: TV Review
description: In commercial television's slow season it is enlighten ing to realize how often its output can come close to that of noncommercial TV. A case in point over the weekend was the National Broadcast ing Company (Channel 4), which wandered interestingly through several fields with out undue concern for ratings.

title: In Memoriam
description: DOWNINGBernard. In memory of Sena for Bernard Downing, May 25, 1931.

title: Christmas Seal Chairman
description: CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) Mrs. Gail Patrick Jackson, a television producer and former actress, was named the national honorary chairman of the 1970 Christmas seal campaign today by Dr. William B. Tucker, presi dentelect of the National Tuber culosis and Respiratory Disease Association.

title: A.J.C. CONDEMNS ALL TERRORISTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The national biennial convention of the American Jewish Congress called today on Jews to con demn and repudiate the indefen sible recourse to lawlessness exemplified by the attacks on three Arabs in New York last Friday.

title: ASTROS BEAT REDS WITH 7 IN 8TH, 107
description: HOUSTON, May 24 (AP) The Houston Astros overcame a sevenrun deficit with two runs in the sixth inning, one in the seventh and seven in the eighth to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 107, today. The victory ended Houston's fivegame los ing streak.

title: U.S. May Give Up Miller Field In a Trade for Willard Hotel
description: The Federal Government has been discussing acquiring the famed but nowclosed Willard Hotel in Washington in a trade for either Miller Field, a deacti vated Army airfield on Staten Island, or two other Govern ment surplus properties.

title: Ecological Backlash
description: The movement to save the environment has already come of age, with a small but growing backlash all its own. In the Daughters of the American Revolution it recently confronted for the first time those diehard opponents of change who will not be saved from a fire without suspiciously demanding to know where they are being taken and whether the danger of flames may not have been exaggerated for some sin ister purpose. The worldwide pollution of air, water and land, the Daughters recently resolved, is being distorted and exaggerated by emotional declarations and by intensive propaganda.

title: Paris: Timely Requiem for Les Halles
description: PARISThe sentence has been passed at last: Les Halles, the only original monument. as Emile Zola called it, built in France dur ing the 19thcentury, one of the most important archi tectural achievements of the incipient industrial age, will soon be destroyed. Les Halles, Paris's central market from 1867 to 1969, are among the earli est and most graceful iron and glass buildings in the world. Their 12 pavilions are identical: huge glass tents stretched on soaring, slender metal columns. Inside, daylight, modulated by a system of latticed bays, is so subtle as to remind one of the mira culously controlled play of light in Istanbul's Saint Sophia Mosque. Underneath, the cellars, with their brick vaults resting on seemingly countless iron pillars, recall the magic stone forest of the mosque at C6rdoba in Spain.

title: Dance: Nutcracker and Coppelia
description: It was like a children's ben efit weekend at the Metropol itan Opera House, where the Royal Ballet, most agreea bly, unblushingly offered two performances of Rudolf Nureyev's staging of The Nutcracker on Saturday, and a couple of perform ances of Coppli for good kiddymeasure on Sun day. Yet, these are respec table works, suitable as those engaging movie tags go for mature audiences (has any movie yet adver tised itself as suitable for immature audiences? and there was a great deal of good dancing to be seen over the weekend.

title: ANDERSEN'S ROLE IN I.O.S. IS ASSAYED
description: PARIS, May 24A well known American accounting concern had a larger hand than is generally realized in the con troversial markup of assets late last year in one of the mutual fund portfolios of In vestors Overseas Services.

title: Black Driver Complains Of Racial Bias at Monticello
description: A 37yearold harnessrac ing driver and trainer has filed a complaint with the State Di vision of Human Rights charg ing Monticello Raceway with racial discrimination.

title: Article 1  No Title
MILS WIN IN 10TH ON TAYLOR SINGLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (UPI)  Tony Taylor hit a basesloaded single with none out in the 10th inning today to give the Philadelphia Phil lies a 65 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Larry Hisle of the Phils had tied the game with a twoout tworun homer in the ninth.

title: Books of The Times
description: ASIDE from the fact that no one died, the biggest advantage that The Sat urday Evening Post had over the Titanic and the Hindenburg was that it had Otto Friedrich on board when it went down. And he was keeping a secret jour nal. And he can write. And now he has turned it into a book that reviews the 147  year history of the Post and details the last eight years of its life. You may not have been that fond of the Post, nor felt that sorry when it finally crashed on Jan. 10, 1969. I know I wasn't and didn't. But the point is that Otto Fried rich was not only fond of the maga zine that he helped to edit during its de clining years; he loved it with all his quiz zical German soul. So if 500 pages seem like more than you'd care to read about the squashing of a slice of apple pie, then let me promise that what Decline and Fall may lack in grand significance it more than makes up for with its author's deep concern and his ability to tell hair raising stories out of school.

title: Black Students Challenge the Order at Mississippi Valley State
description: ITTA BENA, Miss., May 22 Good afternoon, M.V.S.C., the college with a million friends!

title: Molloy Trackmen Place First In Section Fifth Year in Row
description: Archbishop Molloy won its fifth straight team title yester day in the BrooklynLong Island sectional championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at St. John's Uni versity in Queens.

title: A PROTESTER LOSES NARCOTICS UNIT JOB
description: A psychologist who has headed a protest movement at the Narcotic Addiction Control Commision's Edgecombe Ave nue treatment center was dis charged last week.

title: Argus of Greywitch, Greyhound, Takes Best in Show in Jersey
description: METUCHEN, N. J., May 24 Dr. Elsie Neustadt paced nerv ously outside the show ring to day the way the West Hanover, Mass., psychiatrist usually does when one of her greyhounds is in the ring for the bestin show judging.

title: ONRUST TRIUMPHS IN LUDERS16 EVENT
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 24 Jacques F. Bulterman led with Onrust over the entire 8.5 mile course on Long Island Sound today and won the Lud ers16 Class race by 1 minute 50 seconds and 15 boatlengths during the Riverside Yacht Club regatta.

title: City Beautifiers Have Rakes, Paint, Pansies and Hope
description: For weeks after he heard there were plans afoot to plant flowers in a trash strewn lot on Freeman Street, the Bronx, Raymond Medina would stop at the Bethany Family Circle office, summon up the courage of his eight years and ask if the big day had come.

title: CANDIDATES HOPE TO ALTER SCHOOLS
description: Candidates tor positions on Manhattan's six local school boards appear to be more anx ious for major school changes, increased local autonomy, inte gration and sex education than their colleagues in the other, four boroughs, according to a survey by the Public Education Association and the League of Women Voters.

title: OKINAWANS ASSAIL U.S. ACTION ON GAS
description: NAHA, Okinawa, May 24 Okinawan leaders denounced today the White House de cison to cancel the planned shipment to Oregon of 13,000 tons of nerve gas and chemical weapons stored here.

title: 3 Rare Hawklish Put On Display at Aquarium
description: Three longnosed hawk fish, one of the world's rarest fish, have been placed on ex hibition at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island.

title: Kunstler Barred on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP)Glenn Dumke, chancellor of the California state college system, banned today the sched uled appearance Tuesday night of William M. Kunstler at San Jose State College. Mr. Kunst ler was the chief defense law yer of the Chicago 7. In a directive, Mr. Dumke said: Disorders involving personal Injuries and property damage have occurred following cer tain of Mr. Kunstler's appear ances. He then barred the lawyer.

title: Leader of Presbyterians Is Host To Submarine Church Group
description: CHICAGO, May 24The Rev. Dr. William R. Laws Jr., newly elected moderator of the United Presbyterian Church, was the host today at a private lunch eon for eight longhaired, T shirted and bluejeaned mem bers of the socalled Submarine Church.

title: Texan Leads in Qualifying For Rich AllStar Bowling
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill., May 24 (AP)  Bobby Cooper, a 25 yearold touring professional from Houston, and Carmen Elias, 41, a housewife from Fullerton, Calif., took the lead today in the first of three qualifying days in the annual $65,000 AllStar bowling tour nament.

title: Suspect Seized in Holdups Of 3 BMT Change Booths
description: A man who told the police that he was a drug addict with a $24aday habit was arrested yesterday morning by Queens policemen after he had alleged ly held up three BMT Jamaica elevated change booths within half an hour.

title: Miss Stefanie Dash Is Married To Jonathan Hopkins Marvel
description: UPPER GRANDVIEW, N.Y., May 24Miss Stefanie Dash was married here this after noon to Jonathan Hopkins Marvel, son of Mrs. Frank Elliott of Philadelphia and the late Josiah Marvel Jr., former Ambassador to Den mark. The Rev. Diether Gehrmann of the First Unit arian Society of Rockland County performed the cere mony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey IX Dash, parents of the bride.

title: TORNADOES IN TEXAS RESULT IN 34 INJURIES
description: ZAPATA, Tex., May 24 (AP) Tornadoes injured at least 34 persons today and caused dam age of up to $400,000 in this South Texas town.

title: Screen: Optimistic Rider on the Rain
description: Mellie (the diminutive of Mlancolie), a waif with a taste for white miniskirts, white wetlook raincoats and white Courrges boots, seems to go through most of Ren Clment's Rider on the Rain (Le Passager de La Pluie) with tears the size of gumdrops hanging from her lower lashes. Mellie is entitled. Her mother, who runs a bowling alley in a not very chic section of the south of France, ridicules and bul lies her. Her husband, an Air France navigator, who may or may not be dabbling in illegal currency transactions, is so pathologically jealous he gets upset when she goes to the basement to check the furnace.

title: Sansone Denies Charge
description: ST. LOUIS, May 24  An thony Sansone said today in a statement, I have been in some political deals, but have never done anything that I am ashamed of in any fashion.

title: Princess Anne Unhorsed
description: TIDWORTH, England, May 24 (AP)  Princess Anne was thrown from her horse in jump ing competition today and was heard to say: I saw bloody stars. The 19yearold daugh ter of Queen Elizabeth II went flying when her horse balked at a fence. She landed on her back but remounted and fin ished the round.

title: Political Police Close Largest Paper in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 24 Argentina's political police last night closed the daily newspaper Crnica, which claims the largest circulation in Latin America.

title: Gomulka Urges Punishment For Management Errors
description: WARSAW, May 24 (AP) Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Com munist party leader, has called for exposure and punishment of persons responsible for bad economic management in Po land.

title: MARVIN C. STEIN
description: NORTH MERRICK, L.I., May 24Marvin C. Stein of 1529 Jerusalem Avenue, general sales manager of the New York Plumbers Specialties Company, died yesterday in Meadowbrook Hospital after a long illness. His age was 54.

title: Credit Card Law Signed
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said last night that Governor Rockefeller had signed a bill making it a misdemeanor for a credit card issuer to send out a card unless requested in writing.

title: Berlin Protesters Freed
description: BERLIN, May 24 (Reuters) The West Berlin police re leased today all but one of more than 300 youths arrest ed yesterday following fight ing between policemen and leftwing demonstrators at the Technical University. The bat tles began after the youths shouted insults and protests at an allied military parade.

title: Advertising: Agencies Enlarging Services
description: Last week ended up with Benton & Bowles setting up a new division geared to providing a whole bagful of merchandising and sales promotion services to clients and nonclients.

title: TIMES AND UNION REACH AN ACCORD
description: The New York Times and Typographical Union No. 6 reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday that would provide 41.69 per cent in wage increases over a threeyear period.

title: Bonnefous of Paris Makes His Debut With City Ballet
description: Weekend performances at the New York City Ballet brought in not only JeanPierre Bonnefous's debut with the company but also a new part ner, Earle Sieveling, for Vi olette Verdy in Jerome Rob bin's In the Night.

title: Apartheid Under New Pressure
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, May 24 South African sportsmen and administrators are calling for a national con ference to discuss future of country's sports. They are ex pected to press for a relaxation of apartheid in sports to en able racially integrated national teams to be picked in future.

title: Pope, After Beethoven Mass, Deplores Capricious Music
description: ROME, May 24 (AP)Pope Paul VI today deplored capri cious art or music.

title: OSWALD'S HATRED LINKED TO CASTRO
description: A new study of Lee Harvey Oswald contends he shot Presi dent Kennedy because of the President's opposition to Fidel Castro's regime in Cuba and that Oswald had the same mo tive in his hatred of Richard M. Nixon, then a private citi zen, and former Maj. Gen. Ed win A. Walker.

title: Fresh Yankee Triumphs In $36,000 Bavarian Trot
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 24 (UPI)Fresh Yankee, the North Anierican trotting champion owned by Duncan MacDonald of Nova Scotia and driven by Joe O'Brien, won the $36,000 Grand Prix of Bavaria trotting race today by a half length over Americanbred Dart Hanover of Sweden.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Terry Bradshaw, the No.  selection of the 1970 pro football draft, will report to the Pittsburgh Steelers training camp this summer without his college degree. So what. Bradshaw is attractive, articulate, newly rich and a talented quarterback headed toward a losing team. A college di ploma for Bradshaw would probably be as fancy a piece of unnecessary baggage as his Burgundy Thunderbird his boxer pupa But for many of the other 441 draftees about half of whom will not be graduated with their classes, eitherthe lack of a diploma may, be a real hardship.

title: Palafox Takes Final
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 24 (AP)  Gustavo Palafox, the Mexican now teaching at Lit tle Rock, Ark., defeated Frank Parker of Chicago, 62, 97, in the final of the Southern senior tennis championship to day. Both are former Davis Cup players,

title: 11Man Team Races Snows In Effort to Scale Annapurna
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 24 (Reuters)An exhausted Brit ishled expedition is racing against fierce monsoon weather in an attempt to be the first to scale the summit of the 26,502 foot Annapurna I by the dan gerous south face, it was re ported today.

title: BRAZIL FIVE DEFEATS U.S. FOR. 2D PLACE
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, May 24 (UPI)  Brazil handed the United States its second straight defeat today, 6965, to gain second place in the world basketball championship.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rochester Dispute Settled
description: ROCHESTER, May 24 (AP) The City of Rochester agreed today to the chief demand of policemen who struck for five hours last night. The city, at a bargaining session, agreed in principle to pay policemen for overtime. The city had previ ously compensated policemen with additional time off.

title: As American as Antiwar Dissent
description: The flags waved and the speeches jingoed when the United States embarked on its first armed adventure in Asia. Even before the shooting war began in the Pacific the dis senting war broke out in America.

title: OPTIMISM FOUND IN STEEL OUTLOOK
description: PITTSBURGH, May 24Steel producers are starting to talk about a relatively mild summer letdown.

title: HUNTER TITLES GO TO DELEYER HORSES
description: ST. JAMES, L. I., May 24  Harry deLeyer had the green working hunter division all to himself today as his horses took both the championship and the reserve at the Long Island Professional Horsenien's Association horse show.

title: SCHOOLS TOLD TO BAR LANGUAGE BARRIERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)  The Government notified more than 1,000 school districts today that they must remove language barriers that handicap Spanishsurnamed pupils and other nationalorigin minorities.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Incursion Scored

title: Users Upset as Riverside Park Is Dug Up
description: One morning last February, Robert S. Green was startled to see a high fence going up In Riverside Park near 80th Street, enclosing a two  block section that included his son's favorite ball field.

title: Bridge:
description: The current feeling that injustice is widespread in our society finds an occa sional echo at the bridge table, and the diagramed deal is an example. The players sitting East and West were members of a team that was leading in the final round of a Swiss team cham pionship in a recent Con necticut tournament.

title: EDLU TROPHY WON BY PHELPS'S SONNY
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 24 The Larchmont Yacht Club's 15th annual race for the Edlu Trophy was wrapped up today and Albert D. Phelps Jr.'s Whit by 45 Class sloop, Sonny, from the Stamford Yacht Club, one of the yachts that finished well up in the late afternoon yester day, was established as the winner. The distance race was not entirely wrapped up how ever. There was a loose end in the first division.

title: England 20 Soccer Victor
description: QUITO, Ecuador, May 24 (AP)England defeated Ecua dor, 20, today in a dull warm up for the World Cup soccer matches next month. Francis Lee scored in the third minute of play and substitute Brian Kidd in the seventh minute, but the pace was slow in the 9,212 foot altitude.

title: PEKING SQUEEZING JAPANESE TRADE
description: TOKYO, May 24Business circles here are optimistic about expansion of trade in mainland China, despite Peking's recent tough four conditions that Ja panese companies must accept in order to do business with Communist China.

title: ROSS LEADS ADVANCE IN BROOKLYN TENNIS
description: Four seeded players won matches yesterday in the third annual Brooklyn men's tennis championship at the Hiway Club in Flatbush.

title: 1Billion State Development Plan For Bennett Field Scored by City
description: Without consulting the Lind say administration, the State Division of Housing put forth a plan yesterday for a $1.35 billion housing development, industrial park, recreation cen ter and shopping mall on the 1,282acre Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. There was immedi ate, sharp opposition from the City Planning Commission.

title: J. George Stewart Dies at 79; Controversial Capitol Architect
description: WASHINGTON, May 24J. George Stewart, the controver sial Architect of the Capitol, died here today of cancer at the Mar Salle Convalescent Home. He was 79 years old.

title: STEEL TRUCKERS WILL PRESS FIGHT
description: PITTSBURGH, May 23Like John Henry, the legendary steeldriving man of the 19th century railroads, the men who literally drive steel in their, huge steelhauling trucks here are engaged in a furious strug gle with technology and eco nomic pressures.

title: STRIDER, RAMPANT WIN YACHT RACES
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 24 A. Shawhan Fox sailed his Strider past James Sykes's Dixie on the leeward leg of a 12.4mile course on Long Island Sound today and won the Shields Class race by 1 minute 4 seconds and nine boatlengths in the second regatta of the Yacht Racing Association championship season.

title: Soviet Frees U.S. Smuggler
description: MOSCOW, May 24 (UPI)  United States Embassy officials disclosed today the release of an American who served two years in a Soviet labor camp for having smuggled hashish into the Soviet Union. They said that Pedro Generalao, 30 years old, of Arizona, left Mos cow by plane for New York yesterday.

title: 9 Other Unions Seek Contracts in Talks, Too
description: Besides the printers, there are nine other newspaper unions with which contracts are being negotiated. Their basic wage rates follow:

title: CHARLES C. JOYCE, 74, EXBANKING OFFICER
description: Charles C. Joyce, a former trustee and senior vice presi dent of the East River Savings Bank, died Saturday at his home, 267 Old Mill Road, Man hasset, L. I. His age was 74.

title: London Group Asks Security
description: LONDON, May 24 (Reuters) Several hundred Pakistanis today mardhed to the residence of Prime Minister Wilson to ask for protection from attacks by skinheads. These short haired gang youths who usual ly wear bluejeans, boots and teeshirts with suspenders, re cently have made several at tacks on Pakitani residents in the tough East End district.

title: Some Conservative Books...
description: The information branch of the United States Governmentwhich tells the world via radio, films, exhibits and books about American life and American purposeswalks a fine line between open communi cation and outright propaganda. When such profes sionals as the late Edward R. Murrow directed the U.S.I.A., the presumption was that truth was the best policy and the firmest base on which to achieve respect and mutual understanding.

title: Constance Rogers Will Marry Aug. 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Rogers of Rome and Wash ington have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Lane Rogers, to Theodore Roosevelt 4th, a greatgrand son of President Theodore Roosevelt. The wedding is planned for Aug. 1 in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Aaron's 275 Wins Atlanta Classic for His First Victory on U.S. Circuit
description: ATLANTA, May 24  The long dusty road ended for Tommy Aaron today. Thwarted, since joining the pro tour in 1961, the 33yearold native of Gainesville, Ga., thrilled a home state crowd by winning the Atlanta Golf Classic for his first triumph on the United States circuit.

title: Donna Caponi Wins With Birdie At 18th for 214 in $20,000 Golf
Mets Down Cubs, 31, on Ryan's 2Hitter After Bowing, 31
description: The New York Mets and Chi cago Cubs broke off their dial ogue yesterday by dividing a doubleheader before 53,284 fans in Shea Stadium, the largest crowd of the season in the National League.

title: Wicker Says Americans Hunger for a Useful Life
description: CARLISLE, Pa., May 24  Tom Wicker, associate editor of The New York Times, told the graduating class of Dick inson College today that the deepest hunger in the Amer ican soul today... is for something truly useful to do with one's life.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Monday, May 25, 1970

title: Women's Suffrage Revisited
description: WASHINGTONThe first time Miss Lavinia Engle wore her cream lace and brocade dress was 50 years ago, at a banquet marking the end of the National American Woman's Suffrage Association and the begin ning of, the League of Women Voters of the United States.

title: EBAN SEES DISASTER IF U.S. DENIES JETS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel has declared that a United States refusal to strengthen Israel's air force would have disastrous results internationally. He also pledged resolute defense of the cease fire line, coupled with avoidance of combat with Soviet pilots in Egypt.

title: Cambodia Foreign Minister Arrives in Saigon for Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, May 25 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Yem Sambaur of Cambodia arrived here today for talks with South Vietna mese leaders about incursions into his country by South Viet namese and American troops.

title: Swiss Authors' Group Backs Protest Against Its Leader
description: GENEVA, May 24The Swiss Society of Authors gave its backing today to Friedrich Drrenmatt, the playwright, and 20 other members who resigned last week in protest against the rightist views of Maurice Zermatten, the socie ty's President.

title: Hanagata Stops Lumacad
description: TOKYO, May 24 (AP) Su sumu Hanagata of Japan scored a seventhround knockout over Fernando Lumacad of the Philippines today in a scheduled 10round elimination match to choose a challenger to Charchai Chionoi of Thailand, the World Boxing Council flyweight cham pion. Hanagata, 24 years old, weighed 115 pounds; Lumacad, 23, scaled 114.

title: PANEL FAVORS RISE IN POVERTY FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  A group of 93 leaders, represent ing a broad crosssection of the economy and acting under the auspices of the National Plan ning Association, recommended today that a larger share of the nation's resources be devoted to attacking poverty.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here.

title: Wavertree, 3Master, Will Come to Sea Museum
description: A new painting of the sail ing ship Wavertree in her days of glory 85 years ago has taken its place in the South Street Seaport Museuni, where the refurbished ship itself is to become the largest exhibit. Charles Lundgren is the artist.

title: GOOD FUTURE SEEN FOR HUDSON RIVER
description: The Hudson River should re gain its ability to support fish life in the New York City area around the mid1970's, and Jamaica Bay may become suit able for swimming in the late 1970's, according to the city'g Commissioner of Water Re sources.

title: Fordham to Honor Moses
description: Fordham University has an nounced that it will name its new plaza in the Lincoln Cen ter campus after Robert Moses. The plaza will be dedicated on June 2. The 115,000square foot area is part of a new eightacre campus just south of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

title: MALAYSIA WIDENS MIDDLE EAST TIES
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 23A scheduled visit of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia next month is further evidence of the growing ties between Malaysia and the Middle East.

title: King Memorial Parade Brings Blacks and Whites Together
description: Gray skies added somber touch yesterday to an otherwise spirited memorial parade honor ing Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Fifth Avenue as 15,000 spectatorswhite and black turned out.

title: Senate to Be Wired for Sound
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 Washington's greatest cave of the winds, the United States Senate, is about to be wired for sound.

title: FINLEY SAYS JACKSON MAY GO TO MINORS
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) Reggie Jackson, who hit 47 home runs for Oakland last year and was a holdout during most of spring training, is fac ing the threat of being shipped to the minor leagues.

title: Young British Millionaire Is Arrested In Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 24 (Reuters)  An arrest warrant has been issued against a young British million aire, George Drummond, on suspicion of involvement in the disappearance in London of $500,000 in American Express traveler's checks, the police said today.

title: Brooklyn Children March To Mark Jewish Festival
description: Several thousand schoolchil dren from the metropolitan area marched from Eastern Parkway and Kingston Avenue to the Boys High School sta dium at Maple Street and Troy Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday torn mark the Jewish festival of Lag B'omer.

title: Onassis and Wife in Athens
description: ATHENS, May 24 (Reuters) Aristotle S. Onassis, the Greek shipping magnate, and his wife, the former Mrs. John F. Kennedy, arrived by plane from Paris tonight.

title: Eastern Seniors Capture Atlantic Coast Team Tennis
description: Bobby Riggs, the nation's topranking senior, led the Fast to the Atlantic Coast senior team tennis championship yes terday at the West Side Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: APPROVAL URGED OF BASEBALL PACT
GOLDBERG BACKS WAR OBJECTORS
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, a candi date for the Democratic nomi nation for Governor, urged yesterday that conscientious objection to war on any ground be recognized by the Govern ment as the basis for exemption from military service.

title: 2 MANILA EDITORS FACE TAIPEI TRIM
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 24 Two Philippineborn Chinese journalists, deported here from Manila three weeks ago for alleged Communist sympathies and activities, are being held in a military prison while the Government prepares evidence for a trial and determines what charges to bring against them.

title: Cambodia Denies Spokesman Was Attacking Saigon's Role
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 24 (Agence France Presse) The Government radio today countered a declaration by a military spokesman Thursday that Cambodians would prefer to die rather than live under Vietnamese domination.

title: ROGERS HINTS U.S. WON'T CURB ALLY
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Sec retary of State William P. Rogers indicated today that the Administration would not op pose continued South Viet namese operations in Cambodia after American forces are pulled out, and he left open the pos sibility that American air sup port would be provided.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
U.S. DELAY IS SEEN ON SPANISH PACT
description: WASHINGTON. May 24The Nixon Administration is ex pected to delay for several months the signing of a new agreement with Spain on mili tary bases because this com mitment is being questioned by key members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: R.E.Barnett Weds Karen Samuelson
description: Miss Karen Samuelson, daughter of Mrs. Joseph H. Reiner of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Samuel Samuelson, was married here yesterday afternoon to Rob ert Elliot Barnett, son of Mrs. Frank Drucker of New York and Joseph Barnett of Las Vegas, Nev.

title: State Official Appointed For Banking Department
description: The appointment of John T. Morgan as first deputy super intendent of the New York State Banking Department was announced over the weekend, by William T. Dentzer Jr., the State Superintendent of Banks.

title: Italian Ends Cairo Visit
description: CAIRO, May 24 (Reuters) The Italian Foreign Minister, Aldo Moro, left here today af ter a threeday visit and ex pressed his Government's readiness to participate in in dustrial and economic projects in the United Arab Republic., The Egyptian Foreign Ministry said Mr. Moro and the Egyp tion Foreign Minister, Mahmoud Riad had exchanged views on the Middle East situation, world problems and bilateral relations.

title: Staten Island Cricket Draw
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club played a draw with the Guyanese Cultural Association at Walker Park in Staten Island yesterday. Staten Island scored 150 runs for four wickets de clared, while the Guyanese had 98 runs for seven wickets.

title: PRO ARTE CHORALE PRESENTS HANDEL
description: One of the finest per formances of a major work this llistener has heard in many a season was given Saturday night by the Pro Arte Double Chorale and Orchestra with John Nelson conducting at Carnegie Hall.

title: Nixon's Economic Aides Calm About Market Drop
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Normally, we don't talk about the stock market at all. Now we do, of course. But it's just one of a dozen things we dis cuss and considernot the be ginning and end of everything the way it is in New York.

title: Howard W. Burns, Broker And Harvard Athlete, Dies
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., May 24 Howard W. Burns, a stock broker and noted Harvard ath lete, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 66 years old and lived her

title: Hungary Reforming Economy to Attract Tourists
description: BUDAPEST, May 24 (Reuters) Hungary is experimenting with competitive, Westernstyle business methods in an inten sive campaign to attract more foreign tourists.

title: Angels Cut Twins' Lead With 6'5 Triumph
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 24 (AP)Sandy Alomar's sin gle in the ninth inning enabled the California Angels to nip the Minnesota Twins, 65, today after losing a 51 lead. The vic tory moved the Angels within a half game of the firstplace Twins in the American League's Western Division.

title: Walker Takes Off Hat To Bench as Catcher
description: HOUSTON, May 24 (UPI)  Johnny Bench of the Cin cinnati Reds is the best catcher in baseball in the last 25 years, Manager Harry (The Hat) Walker of the Houston Astros said today.

title: PHAN KHAC SUU, 65, SAIGON OFFICIAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24 (AP)Phan Khac Suu, a political leader, died today after a brief illness. He was 65 years old.

title: DON ALLISON'S FORD TAKES WORLD 600
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 24 (AP)Lee Roy Yarbrough, his own car out with a dead clutch, took the wheel of teammate Donnie Allison's Ford today and won the World 600 stock car race at Charlotte Motor Speed way. He sped past the stalled leader, David Pearson, near the finish.

title: President to Name A Panel to Study Kent State Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A White House aide disclosed today that President Nixon would appoint this week a highlevel commission to get to the bottom of the Kent State tragedy in which four students were killed during an antiwar demonstration May 4.

title: LondonMexico Auto Rally Starts Final 2,000Mile Leg
description: PANAMA, May 24 (UPI) The 26 remaining crews in the LondontoMexico auto rally began the final 2,000mile leg today to Aztec Stadium in Mexico City.

title: COUNCIL OF ARTS SEEKS EXPANSION
description: ST. LOUIS, May 24On the cover of the program of the Associated Council of the Arts, which completed a fourday meeting here last week, are six words that summarize the countless speeches and discus sion sessions at the organiza tion's fifth annual conference:

title: Japanese Colony Thrives in Canada
description: LETHBRIDGE, AlbertaThe JapaneseCanadian Citizens Association in this southern Alberta town faced a crisis recently: it lacked serious problems to occupy its busi ness meeting.

title: DualPurpose Funds
Inflation and Foreign Trade
description: Treasury Secretary David M. Kennedy recently told a group of American and foreign bankers, I must emphasize that, under the pressure of rising imports, our current policy of freer trade is being challenged more strongly than at any time in memory by business and labor groups directly affected by a weakened competitive position. These groups are gaining con siderable political support.

title: Injuries Haunt Phillies, Third Catcher Is Hurt
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24 AP)Injuries further crip pled the Philadelphia Phillies as they lost a third catcher today.

title: Margaret Cawley Bride of Engineer
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 24 Miss Margaret Elizabeth Cawley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ralston Cawley, was married at her parents' home here today to Brian Wilson Kernighan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Seviwright Kernighan of Milton, Ont.

title: JUMPER LAURELS TO SPRINGBOARD
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., May 24 Springboard won two of the three classes to capture the open jumper championship with 11 points today at the. Strat ford Stables horse show..

title: Youngsters Improvise Plays
description: YONKERS, N. Y.  The Sneaker Players, a group of 13 Sarah Lawrence stu dents, paid a call on two classes at Public School 7 on a recent afternoon and neither has been quite the same since.

title: Student Group Finds All 4 Democratic Senate Candidates in State Acceptable
description: In the belief that all four candidates would support the goals they seek to achieve, student representatives for the New York Region of the Move ment for a New Congress have not endorsed any of them for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

title: Blacks Stage a Racial Critique
description: CHATTANOOGA, May 24 On a bare college stage a mere cannonshot from some of the Civil War's bloodiest battle grounds, a talented company of young black students has mounted a bittersweet attack on racial inequities they see in their community and their country.

title: Orban of N.Y.A.C. Captures Metropolitan Saber Title
description: Alex Orban, the national champion, yesterday won the metropolitan saber champion ship on his home strip at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Launch Time in Huntington Harbors
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 24  Walt Whitman once wrote of my own beautiful town of Huntington. That was in 1839, when the town's population was about 6,500 and its borders stretched from Long Island Sound to the Atlantic Ocean. Today, many residents feel, in a similar vein with the spirit of the na tive poet, that the E in the center of the town's seal stands for excel lence. However, with a popu lation of almost 200,000 in an area almost half the size it was in Whitman's day, the town's E is also being interpreted as exasperation.

title: Fires Set in Reformatory
description: LORTON, Va., May 24 (UPI) Fires set by inmates after a power blackout at Lorton Re formatory last night and destroyed three buildings and caused at least $100,000 dam age, prison officials said. Five persons, including four guards, were injured and four inmates were reported missing.

title: BIG RUBBER TRACT IN CAMBODIA FALLS TO SAIGON TROOPS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 24A South Vietnamese task force seized the large rubber plantation of Chup late yester day and witnesses reported to day that the force had confis cated all movable assets and had given the French managers three days to leave.

title: Urtain Scores 30th Knockout
description: BILBAO, Spain, May 24 (AP) Jose Manuel Ibar Urtain, a Basque from Spain, scored his 30th straight knockout in quick fashion today. The European heavyweight champion stopped Karl Heinz Brunnholz of West Germany at 2:35 of the first round of a scheduled 10 rounder. Urtain weighed 197 pounds; Brunnholz 183

title: Drive to Clean Up Litter Intensifies in Many Areas
description: Public zeal against littering is on the upswing across the country, but not yet enough so to offset a costly worsening in the scourge of trash.

title: Manhattan's 2d Trip Spurs Hope
description: The S.S. Manhattan will head home this week from her sec ond voyage into Arctic ice with new hope of having proved the economic feasibility of opening the Northwest Passage to com metcial shipping.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MAY 25, 1970

title: Eleanor Pam Wed To Robert Juceam
description: Miss Eleanor Pam, associ ate dean of Queensborough Community College in Bay side, Queens, was married last evening to Robert Juceam, a lawyer with the New York firm of Strasser, Spiegelberg, Fried & Frank. Rabbi Louis I. Newman per formed the ceremony at the St. Moritz.

title: GRABLE CAPTURES CONTINENTAL RACE
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, May 24 (AP)Ron Grable of Cuper tino, Calif., led from start to finish today in winning the sec ond race of the Continental Formula A series in a Lolo T190. The victory was worth $4,000.

title: Independent Labor Chief
description: On a cold, windy Christmas afternoon in 1914, a tall, blackhaired young man stood in Webster Hall on the Lower East Side and listened as the Amalgamated Clothing Work ers of America was created.

title: LAOS OPENS SERIES OF ATTACKS ON REDS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  Lao tian Government forces, seizing the initiative with the advent of the rainy season are launch ing a series of attacks against Communist forces.

title: Edith Mossberg Becomes Bride
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 24Miss Edith Bette Mossberg, daughter of Dr.. and Mrs. David Mossberg, was married here this after noon to Mark Howard Me doff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney L. Medoff of Larch mont

title: A Plan for Borrowing by Banks Is Aired
description: George W. Mitchell, a mem ber of the Federal Reserve Board, is pressing an imagina tive plan to simplify borrowing by commercial banks from the Federal Reserve System.

title: Mikkelsen to Rejoin Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers will activate a relief pitcher, Pete Mikkelsen, tomorrow and re turn Gary Moore, an outfielder, to Albuquerque of the Texas League. Mikkelsen has been on the disabled list since being stricken with infectious hepa titis during springt training.

title: Personal Finance: PreHos pital Tests
description: If you've ever had to spend as much as a week in the hospital, nobody has to tell you that it's much cheaper to spend a week in the best suite at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: EUROPEANS GLUM ABOUT U.S. STOCKS
description: PARIS, May 24We think that some American stocks, par ticularly those with low price earnings multiples, can be bought at these levels, a Zu rich investment specialist said last week. But he added, with a shrug, It's hard to get our clients interested.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for the week follows:

title: ...Some Closed Libraries
description: The importance of preserving the objectivity, and thereby the credibility, of United States Information Agency libraries is illustrated in India, where the Government has just bowed to leftist demands and closed down five American cultural centers, charging they were engaging in undesirable activities.

title: Jersey Jazz Buff Is Host to Beiderbecke Memorial
description: LONG VALLEY, N. J., May 24  The sounds of 45 jazz musicians celebrating the memory of Bix Beiderbecke, the jazz cornetist who died in 1931 at the age of 28, echoed yesterday through the normal weekend drowsi ness of this village at the foot of Schooley's Mountain, 18 miles west of Morristown

title: Posts 2Up Triumph After Ousting Cox in Semifinal Round
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 24 Billy Edwards, hitting straight from the tees and rarely hav ing to scramble, became the second golfer to win the Wal ter J. Travis Invitation tourna ment a fourth time when he beat Paul Wise, 2 up, in the final today at the Garden City Golf Club.

title: BenGurion Urges Return Of Some Arab Territories
description: David Ben  Gurion, Israel's first Premier, said yesterday that, to obtain peace, his coun try should return all captured territories except for its Old City in Jerusalem and the Gol an Heights.

title: Youths Burn U.S. Flag in Manila
description: MANILA, May 24 (AP) About 200 leftist Filipino youths ended a noisy but peaceful anti  Government and antiUnited States dem onstration here tonight by burning an American flag.

title: New York Lacrosse Club Tops New Jersey in Finale
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., May 24The New York Lacrosse Club closed its season today by defeating the New Jersey La crosse Club, 96. Tom Quaran to and Don Thompson scored two goals apiece for New York while Bruce Cohen added a goal and four assists.

title: UNION CHALLENGES IND CRASH REPORT
description: The Transport Workers Un ion accused the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yes terday of having attempted to clear itself of responsibility for the fatal subway collision in Queens last Wednesday by issuing a report blaming a mo torman, a car inspector and a conductor.

title: Status of Bills in Congress
Potofsky, in Labor Split, Denounces War Policy
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May, 24 The head of one of the nation's largest trade unions broke to day with the leadership of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and condemned the Vietnam and Cambodian war policies of the Nixon Ad ministration.

title: INDIANS ARE DEALT 65, 87 SETBACKS
Officials Say They Will Reject Jacobson's Bid for Belmont Stall Space Today
description: Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, one of the most successful and embattled trainers in the United States, will apply without suc cess this morning for stall space at Belmont Park, where the thoroughbreds begin a 30 day meeting.

title: Life Accuses St. Louis Mayor Of Having Ties With Gangsters
description: Life magazine accused Mayor Alfanso J. Cervantes of St. Louis yesterday of business and personal ties with gang sters operating in his city, ac cording to United Press Inter national. Mr. Cervantes charged the magazine with reckless sensationalism and irrespon sible disregard for the truth.

title: Soviet Officials Accused of Hunting in Preserves
description: MOSCOW, May 24Leonid Leonov, a prominent novelist and conservationist, today con demned the use of forest and game preserves for private hunting parties by leading So viet figures.

title: King Hussein Tours Aqaba
Darts Score in Soccer, 41
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The Washington Darts de feated the Kansas City Spurs, 41, today in a North American Soccer League game. Victoria Casa, Leroy DeLeon, Billy Frazer and Juan Archibald notched goals for the Darts.

title: 2 Fires Set in Racial Clash After Fight in Jackson, Ga.
description: JACKSON, Ga., May 24 (AP)Two fires were set and damage to some stores was re ported tonight in a brief racial outbreak involving about 100 persons that was prompted by an altercation between a white man and a Negro.

title: YEMENI ROYALISTS RETURN AFTER WAR
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, May 24Scores of former royalist leaders and military men have arrived in Sana, the capital of the neighboring Republic of Ye men, in the vanguard of a mass return of royalists after seven years of warfare.

title: Thieu Going on Channel 13
description: News in Perspective, Na tional Educational Television's weekly topical discussion pro gram, will present an exclusive interview with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam tomorrow night. The program, to be seen here on WNDT, Channel 13, was filmed last Saturday in Saigon. Clifton Daniel, an associate Editor of The New York Times is the moderator.

title: Presbyterian Leaders Ask Nixon to Explain Asia
description: CHICAGO, May 25The General Assembly of the Unit ed Presbyterian Church, em broiled in debate over the Vietnam War, asked today that President Nixon or an official representative come here and outline United States policy in Southeast Asia.

title: Amex Prices Drop To ThreeYear Low
description: The American Stock Ex change had its biggest daily loss in almost 10 months yesterday as prices fell to their lowest level in almost three years. Trading was moderate.

title: F.C.C. Petitioned to. Curb Talks By Nixon on TV About War
description: A group of Yale University professors, law students and leaders of the New Haven black coalition have filed a petition with the Federal Communica tions Commission asking a curb on President Nixon's access to the television networks when opponents of the Indochina war have not been accorded an equal opportunity for air time.

title: RICHARD TAYLOR, CARTOONIST, DIES
description: WEST REDDING, Conn., May 25Richard Taylor, a cartoon ist whose heavylidded, sexy women and similarly lidded, sophisticated men were well known to readers of The New Yorker, Playboy and other magazines, died of cancer to day at his home here. He was 67 years old.

title: David Rockefeller Urges WagePrice Plea by Nixon
description: David Rockefeller, perhaps the nation's bestknown banker, called on President Nixon yes terday to urge both business and labor to take a more re sponsible attitude toward wage and price increases.

title: White House Talk Has Finch Moving In as a HighLevel Adviser to President
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 When a report was printed not long ago suggesting that Secretary of Health, Educa tion and Welfare Robert H. Finch might join the White House staff, the Presidential press office issued a prompt denial. But there is indeed talk about such a move for Mr. Finch, and it is coming from a most influential quarter: H. R. Haldeman, the President's chief of staff. A fellow Californian. and one of Mr. Finch's closest friends (their families vaca tioned together last year in the Caribbean), Mr. Halde man senses that Mr. Finch is not at all happy at H.E.W. and would like to keep him the Nixon team.

title: Study Shows Hospitals Understaffed
description: A, state survey indicated yes terday that hospitals in New York City needed 8,791 full time doctors, dentists and other health personnel beyond the 106,392 people that they had on their staffs a year ago.

title: U. S. SAID TO PLAN TO QUIT CAMBODIA BEFORE DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  The withdrawal of all United States ground troops from Cambodia is to be completed ahead of the June 30 deadline under present plans of the Nixon Administration, senior. Government officials said to day.

title: Washington Mews: Beguiling Houses on a Cobblestone Street
description: Question: Where in Man hattan would you be tret passing every time you h your hat in your closet off the bedroom. Answer The converted stablestudio at 60 Washington. Mews that is home to the Robert Baths.

title: Fanny May Results Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Average prices of mortgage purchasecommitments continued to drop in all three cate gories at this week's freemarket auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association, according to Fanny May president, Oakley Hunter.

title: Coast Meet Adjusts Marks Of Miss Brill and Pennel
description: MODESTO, Calif., May 25 (AP)Tom Moore, the meet director said today that Debbie Brill's winning high jump at the California Relays Saturday was incorrectly listed by meet stat isticians as one inch too high.

title: DART INDUSTRIES IN BID FOR AMREP
description: Dart Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agree ment to acquire the Amrep Corporation through an ex change of stock worth more than $81million.

title: Pacification Set Back Slightly in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25Pacification in South Viet nam is reported to have suf fered a slight setback last month.

title: Bridge:
description: Many attempts have been made to devise a satisfactory twohanded bridge game, but none have achieved any wide popularity. The only such game to receive the endorse ment of topranked bridge players such as Von Zedt witz, Jacoby, Kaplan and Root is Bridgette, which attracted widespread interest when it was mentioned in this column two years ago. At that time prototype ver sions were available but there was no commercial product. This month the game became available to the public. The set, including rules, strategy advice and two decks of cards, can be obtained by sending $6.95 to Bridgette Games, Inc., 527 Lexington Avenue, New York, N. Y.

title: Theater: Don Tuan as Religious Object
description: NEW HAVENThe effect of Robert Brustein's Yale Repertory Theater version of Moliere's Don Juan is to stand the play on its head. That the production is emi nently successful is a tribute not only to Mr. Brustein's di rection and Yale's ensemble of actors but also to the so lidity and depth of Moliere's play. It is a classic that can be enforced by reinterpreta tion.

title: Marang Killed in Crash
description: PANAMA, May 25 (UPI)  Ido Marang of France was killed and his codriver, Paul, Coltelloni, was injured today in a collision during the last leg of the LondontoMexico City World Cup auto rally.

title: Cricket in Britain Is Bowling a Very Sticky Wicket
description: LONDON, May 25  The bewildered American, view ing a cricket match for the first time, turned to a Brit ish spectator in the stands and asked when it would get interesting.

title: Hijacked Jet Lands Here Before Flying to Havana
description: A hijacked American Airlines Astrojet landed its passengers at Kennedy International Air port, refueled and took off for Cuba yesterday on orders of a stealthy pirate who never left the rear galley.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: MORTGAGE COSTS DECLINED IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Ayerage interest costs on con ventional mortages declined slightly in April, the first dip in 16 months, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board re ported today.

title: Skinheads and Greasers Battle at British Resorts
description: LONDON, May 25 (AP)  Rampaging gangs of youths skinheads with short hair and greasers with long hair battled with bottles and boots on the southern seacoast today.

title: Administration's Credibility: Doubts Inside and Out
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  This capital is worrying about credibility again, but the worry this time is just as great inside the Government as among its critics.

title: U.S. Will Give Cambodia $7.5.Million in Weapons
description: The type of arms was not disclosed, but on the basis of earlier statements by Adminis tration officials it was believed the assistance consists largely of small arms that could be readily used by th Cambodian Army.

title: Dr. Alonzo Myers, Adviser on Age, Dies
description: VENICE, Fla., May 25Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, former chair man of New York University's department of higher education, in the School of Education, and an authority on retirement planning, died yesterday at the Venice Medical Inn after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: CHARLES A. RUBENS
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 25 Charles A. Rubens, founder and former president of Fili gree Foods, Inc., wholesale grocery distributors in Totowa, died yesterday at the Ingle moore Nursing Home. He was 92 years old and lived at 192 Chadwick Road, Teaneck.

title: Screen: Dubliner on Way to Nowhere
description: I'm going to have a baby. Yours . . .and . . . mine! announces Maureen, with rather more surprise at na ture's law than her situation warrants, near the end of Daniel Haller's Paddy, which opened yesterday at the 72d Street Playhouse. For Maureen has earned her sit uation, as parttime mistress but one true love of Paddy, a poor young Dubliner on his way nowhere, by enduring many springtime rambles and protestations of love, much softfocus romancing, and one hard midnight tumble in what looks to me like the middle of a suburban street.

title: OPEN QUALIFIERS PACED BY PITTMAN
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I. May 25The Rockville Links golf course turned into a soggy green monster today an not one of the players trying to qualify for the United States Open was able to equal the par of 72 for the 6,700yard course.

title: Fire Kills Mother and Girl
description: READING, Pa, May 25 (UPI) A mother and her 11year old daughter were killed today when fire swept their small home near Birdsboro, but two state troopers saved her invalid son. Mrs. Ann Parker, 39, and her daughter, Lynn, were killed. Steven Parker, 15, was reported in good condition at St. Jo seph's Hospital here.

title: Subway Commission To Study Reports On IND Collision
description: The Mayor's Subway Service Watchdog Commission said yes terday it would meet Thursday to study reports on last Wednesday's IND subway col lision from three transportation organizations making investiga tions. Two persons were killed and more than 70 were in jured in the crash.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President saw Dr. John A. Hannah, ad ministrator for the Agency for International Develop ment. The President also met with Samuel Pierce, general counseldesignate of the Treasury Department and he met with David A. Keene, na tional chairman of the Young Americans for Freedom.

title: Georgia Is Ruled Home For Civil War General
description: CINCINNATI, May 25 (UPI) Kennesaw, Ga., and not Chattanooga will become the final resting place of the Civil War locomotive The General, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit has ruled.

title: DAIWA REPORTED READY TO AID I.O.S.
description: TOKYO, May 25 (Reuters) Japanese stockmarket sources said today the Daiwa Securi ties Company has told an in fluential overseas financial or ganization it was ready to take part in any consortium that might be formed to save In vestors Overseas Services (I.O.S.).

title: MRS. CRIMMINS FACES NEW SLAYING TRIAL
description: Mrs. Alice Crimmins will be arraigned Thursday on a charge of firstdegree manslaughter as a preliminary step toward a new trial fin the 1965 strangu lation slaying of her 4yearold daughter, Alice Marie, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: MiniSession Is Scheduled BY Assembly Committees
description: ALBANY, May 25 (AP)New York Assemblymen will meet at the Capitol June 24 and 25 in the year's first minises sion, Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. announced today.

title: U.S. Court Orders Army to Release a Draftee
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 A Federal judge here today or dered a draftee released from the Army and thereby may have begun a process that will lead to discharges for 6,000 men inducted because their draft boards decided they were de linquent.

title: Commodities Retreat in Light Trading
description: The commodities futures markets resembled the stock markets yesterday Virtually every commodity traded, with the exception of potatoes, showed a decline or was un changed from the day before

title: Saving Cambodia
description: The strong public opposition to widening the war in Southeast Asia has not prevented the Administra tion from pursuing the Cambodian intervention by proxy, sustaining South Vietnamese troops in opera tions that go far beyond the announced objective of cleaning out border sanctuaries.

title: Unruh Confident of a Victory on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, May 25  Jess Unruh is displaying the kind of confidence that most politicians try to avoid.

title: Mosaics Brighten a Reborn Tashkent
description: TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., May 24 This sunbaked capital of So viet Uzbekistan, ravaged by a major earthquake four years ago, is rebuilding itself with bricks, concrete slabs, mosaic tile and psychology.

title: L.I.R. Starts New Schedule
description: The Long Island Railroad put Into effect yesterday a summer schedule that was designed to provide improved service for riders on all its branches. The line said it has posted the schedule changes in all the sta tions affected.

title: Some Officials of H.E.W. Say Health Part of the Department Is in Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  The health side of the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare is in serious trouble, according to a growing con sensus among officials there, ranging from high policy mak ers on down.

title: 3 Senators and Former Defense Aide Attack War
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 Former Assistant Secretary of Defense Paul C. Warnke and three United States Senators called here today for speedy disengagement by the United States from the wars in Viet nam and Cambodia.

title: Pan American Airways Fills an Executive Post
description: Richard S. Mitchell has been named executive vice president of Pan American World Airways. He succeeds General Laurence S. Kuter (U.S. Air Force retired) who is retiring from the com pany.

title: Exposure to Urban Life Held Aid to Psychic Health
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Urban living has much to offer: noise, pollution, crowding, the as saults of mass media and the drudgery of factory work or bureaucratic routine.

title: Money
Five Are Accused Of Relocation Fraud On Port Authority
description: Four downtown businessmen and the head of a Long Island moving company, were accused yesterday in State Supreme Court of scheming to defraud the Port of New York Authority by submitting exaggerated statements for moving business concerns during relocation for the World Trade Center.

title: BACHE REORGANIZES ITS BRANCH GROUP
