description: Bache & Co., the brokerage house, announced yesterday reorganization of its branch management group, involving separation of its branchoffice structure into four regional divisions.

title: Advertising: Transit Displays in Demand
description: Business is at an alltime high.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Advance On Both 91 and 182Day Issues
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Treasury bill rates advanced sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon.

title: WILLIAM C. COX DIES; DOW JONES DIRECTOR
description: BOSTON, May 25 William C. Cox, a senior director of Dow Jones & Co., died in Massa chusetts General Hospital here today after a long illness.

title: CATALONIAN RAIMON SINGS EXILE'S WOES
description: Raimon, a Catalonian singer and poet in exile, last night sang his songs about peace, against fear at the Washing ton Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: Four U.S. Women Post Surrey Tennis Victories
description: SURBITON, England, May 25 (Reuters)  Four American women advanced today in the Surrey tennis championships.

title: Jockey Pilar Returns Home
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 251 (AP)Hector Pilar, the jockey who fell from his mount, Holy( Land, in the Kentucky Derby, has returned to his home inl Hialeah, Fla. He was discharged from a hospital here Saturday.

title: Jersey Gardeners Are Wary Of Pollution From Pesticides
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 25  Until this spring most folks didn't even bother to read the labels on the bug spray cans, said Joseph Roberts, manager of the Farm ers Cooperative Association Garden Supply Center here. Now they are asking some really sharp questions about what insecticides really do and how dangerous they are.

title: In The Nation: Still Running Against Hoover
description: WASHINGTON, May 25A fairly good political case could be made that in every election since 1932, each time the Demo crats have had a good chance to run against Herbert Hoover and the Depression, they have elected a President. In this anal ysis, the Republicans have taken the White House only when they have been able to shift the issue from the state of the economy to Korea and Commu nism (1952) or to Vietnam and crime (1968). President Nixon, for one, is said to be convinced that it was the recession of 1960 that really did him in, the first time he ran.

title: Editor Gets Interior Post
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) Edward P. Essertier, editor of The Pasadena (Calif.) Star News, has been named infor mation director for the Interior Department, Secretary Walter J. Hickel announced today. Mr. Essertier, 48 years old, who was an assistant to Represen tative Edgar W. Hiestand, Re publican of California, from 1955 to 1958, succeeded Alex Troffey, who resigned.

title: Economist Rejects Credit Bars, But Sees an Easing of Inflation
description: The United States has set a proper economic course, one that if pursued will lead by the end of 1970 to renewed expan sion, progressively less infla tion, an abatement of strikes and high wage settlen gents, de clining interest rates and rising sales and profits, Albert H. Cox Jr. told financial executives at a meeting yesterday sponsored by, the American Management As sociation.

title: A Hudson to Swim In Must Wait
description: Governor Rockefeller, who had promised earlier that the Hudson River would be clean enough to swim in this year, set back that date yesterday to 1975.

title: PARIS STOCK MARKET AFFECTED BY WAR
description: PARIS, May 25Battle dam age to French investments in Cambodia is aggravating both the pessimism on the Paris Stock Exchange and the anxi ety in France over latest Amer ican policy in the Far East.

title: Schaeffler Is Chosen To Coach U.S. Skiers
description: DENVER, May 25 (AP) Willy Schaeffler, University of Denver coach, was named today as head coach of the United States national ski team.

title: MONTE APPEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Monte Appel, Washington lawyer and former Assistant At torney General, died at his home here Saturday. He was 83 years old.

title: BETTER TREATMENT OF RETARDED ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)  A Presidential com mittee urged today that insti tutions housing the mentally retarded in what it called environments experienced by prisoners of war adopt a new philosophy protecting the human and civil rights of the retarded.

title: 6 SAVED AND 11 HURT IN BROOKLYN BLAZE
description: A woman and her five chil dren were rescued by firemen last night after a threealarm fire broke out in their apart ment house in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: The Chief Awards
description: Preliminary JumpersGerald Pack's Baile wick.

title: SovietBloc Diplomats, Still in Pnompenh, Are Uneasy
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 25The feeling of instability in this city, which makes air line schedules the foreigner's primary reading matter, is most pronounced among the citizens of the Communist countries.

title: Spur to Desegregation
description: President Nixon's request to Congress to appropriate $500 million for the coming school year and $1 billion for the year after that to speed integration is a com mendably forwardlooking step. Properly implemented, it could do much to offset the Administration's lack action up to now in the cause of school desegregation.

title: 35 MAYORS SEEK RENEWAL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  about 35 Mayors and scores of other city officials and com munity workers from across the country began a special nonpartisan lobbying effort to day to raise the urban renewal appropriation from the $1bil lion recommended by President Nixon to $2.3billion, the amount authorized by law.

title: G.E. to Reassign 4 Key Executives
description: The General Electric Com pany made four toplevel ex ecutive changes yesterday as part of an evolving plan de signed to separate the staff work for planning and shap ing the future of the company from the daytoday operating work required at the corporate level.

title: RON DAVIS DANCERS SHOW YOUTHFUL ZEST
description: Ron Davis, a charismatic young man whose involvement in social projects led him to form the Ron Davis Dancers in 1964a group of young black and Puerto Rican performers seen last year at Carnegie Hall presented another concert by the Ron Davis Dancers last night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: UTILITY ISSUE SOLD AT A RECORD YIELD
description: A topquality electric utility bond issue was offered to in vestors yesterday at a record 9.20 per cent yield15/100ths higher than a similar issue mar keted only four days earlier.

title: Cambodian Minister, in Saigon, Plans No Talks on Military Ties
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25Foreign Minister Yem Sambaur of Cambodia said here today that although his country highly appreciated the coop eration of the South Viet namese armed forces in rooting out Communist military bases in Cambodia, he did not intend to raise the question of a for mal military alliance with South Vietnam.

title: In Memoriam
description: FRANKClara. MY beautiful beloved mama. Deeply missed these 4 saddest years. MOLLIE.

title: Jersey Unit Alleges Bias On Housing
description: TRENTON, May 25 (AP) The State Division on Civil Rights charged today that 18 of the largest apartment com plexes in Parsippany  Troy Hills discriminated against Negroes.

title: Governor Is Opposed to Controls Now
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he did not agree with Mayor Lindsay's call for immediate wage and price con trols to curb inflation.

title: BREWSTER TRIAL SET ON BRIBERY CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Former Senator Daniel B. Brewster pleaded not guilty to day to charges of accepting a bribe to influence his vote on postal rate legislation.

title: Illinois Lawmakers Advised on Unrest
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 25 Illinois legislators, disturbed by recent student unrest in the state, were told today to pay more attention to its root causes.

title: BROAD RIOT CURBS UPHELD BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The power of bigcity Mayors to avoid disturbances by for bidding public gatherings dur ing periods of urban unrest was upheld today by the Su preme Court.

title: Victories Claimed in Hamm Case
description: Last week a Federal judge in New Haven handed down a decision on a request by Consumers Union for a preliminary injunction against the Theodore Hamm Brewing Company from using material from its Consumer Reports in advertising and promotion.

title: EXTENSION IS LIKELY ON COTTON ACCORD
description: GENEVA, May 25The agree ment that now regulates the international trade in cotton textiles will probably be ex tended for three years beyond its present expiration date of Sept. 30, 1970, qualified sourc es said today.

title: LUBOVITCH ST AGES THEATRICAL DANCES
description: It is undeniable that Lar Lubovitch has a sense of thea ter, for he shows flashes of throughout his works. That which his pieces lack for the most part is a sense of sus tained flow. Last night at the American Theater Laboratory he presented three dances of which Variations and Fugue on a Theme of a Dream was the most completely realized.

title: KNEEL ADVOCATES MORE AUTOMATION
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the chief mediator in the city's news paper negotiations, urged the typographical union and The New York Times yesterday to take all possible steps to ex pand the newspaper's opera tions and improve the product by employing the latest tech nology.

title: 14 COLLEGE PAPERS TO BE MICROFILMED
description: Microfilming Corporation of America, a subsidiary of The New York Times, announced plans yesterday to publish, on microfilm, the complete edi tions of 14 college newspapers on a continuing basis.

title: Mississippi Agency, in Shift, Will Allow Sesame Street
description: JASKSON, Miss., May 25 (UPI)The board of directors of the Mississippi Authority for Educational Television has re versed its stand and approved the broadcast of the Sesame Street children's series.

title: PASARELL, RICHEY ADVANCE IN PARIS
description: PARI5, May 25 (AP)  Ar thur Ashe and Mrs. Billie Jean King led a contingent of Amer icans into the second round of the $100,000 French open ten nis championships today.

title: POLICEMAN KILLED RESISTING HOLDUP
description: An offduty probationary pa trolman who had gone to a hamburger drivein in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn with his wife was shot to death last night when he tried to pre vent a holdup.

title: Court Upsets Ban on Uniforms Worn by Actors Mocking Army
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The Supreme Court unani mously struck down today a provision of a Federal statute that makes it a crime for an actor to wear United States military apparel in a theatrical production if the portrayal re flects discredit on the armed forces.

title: BANKERS ATTACK MOVE FOR A CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)Brushing aside charges that banks give favored treat ment to businesses they con trol, the banking industry asked the senate today to reject de structive bankregulating leg islation adopted by the House.

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON FRAUD IN USING SWISS ACCOUNTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The House this afternoon unani mously passed a bill designed to curb massive tax evasion, stock and bond frauds and other forms of socalled whitecollar crime through the use of secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: Passport Offices Open on Foley Sq. And the Concourse
description: Two new passport offices were opened in the city yester day to help relieve what Feder al officials called the almost chaotic overload at the main passport office, 630 Fifth Ave nue in Rockefeller Center.

title: BETTING RECORDS SET AT YONKERS
description: YONKERS, May 25On a damp, fogbound night when the 25,093 fans had trouble seeing the horses they were backing, the firsthalf season at Yonkers Raceway was con cluded tonight with $3,123,726 poured into the mutuel ma chines. It was the third time in the sport's history that the $3million mark has been sur passed and all three were ac complished at the Westchester County course.

title: M.D.'s Needed
description: Experience with Medicare and Medicaid in recent years has demonstrated that the supply of trained personnel is even more important than the flow of dollars in determining the adequacy and availability of medical care. That is why the nation should give particularly warm welcome to the roughly 8,500 young physicians who are receiving their M.D. degrees this spring.

title: FRONTIER AIRLINES WILL LAY OFF 200
description: DENVER, May 25 (AP)  Frontier Airlines said today it would lay off more than 200 employes and embark on a cost cutting program in an effort to reduce losses totaling $13mil lion since the first of 1968. Frontier has 3.455 workers.

title: British Official Visits Pope
description: ROME, May 25Foreign Sec retary Michael Stewart of Brit ain had a 50  minute private audience with Pope Paul VI in the Vatican this afternoon. Of cial sources declined to iden Iffy the topics they discussed.

title: William H. Schroder Dead at 64; Won $3Million Libel Judgment
description: ATLANTA, May 25  Wil liam H. Schroder, the Atlanta lawyer who represented Wal lace Butts, former University of Georgia athletic director, in his successful libel action against The Saturday Eve ning Post, died today after a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Sylvania's New TV Line
description: Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., introduced yesterday its new 1971 color television re ceiver line featuring an elec tronic device called a silicon, highvoltage tripler that is said to eliminate the possibility of xray generation. The new line includes a 25inch diagonal, screen in certain models. Prices range from $259.95 for a porta ble set to $1,500 for a home entertainment center including color TV, stereophonic phono graph and AMFM tuner. Syl vania is a subsidiary of General Telephone and Electronics Cor poration.

title: A Voice That Carries
description: When David Rockefeller makes a speech just about everyone listens, even those to whom his views are anath ema. A member of one of America's first families, the chairman and chief exec utive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank is a man whose name seems to pop up whenever a new philanthropic or social project mentioned. His voice is probably one of the most important in the United States and certainly one of the most powerful in New York.

title: Graham Center Concert Of Dance Is Postponed
description: Thursday night's concert by Bertram Ross and members of the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance in Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Young Men's Young Women's Hebrew As sociation has been postponed until June 17.

title: Coast Test Over Red Professor Is Near
description: LOS ANGELES, May 25The University of California's Board of Regents and its Los Angeles campus are heading for a con frontation over the case of Angela Davis, an assistant pro fessor of philosophy who be longs to the Communist party.

title: Puerto Rico Strike Averted
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., May 25 (UPI)A threatened strike at four major tourist hotels here was averted today with an agreement on a new labor con tract two hours before the old one expired; The Hotel and Restaurant Employes' and Bar tenders' International, Union said the new threeyear con tract included an 80cent hour ly raise for workers at the Ca ribe Hilton, San Jeronimo Hil ton, Condado Beach and El San Juan Hotels.

title: HerculesMitsui Agreement
description: Hercules, Inc., announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with Mitsui Petrochemical Industries, Ltd., under which Hercules would market in the United States highdensity polyethylene made in Japan by the Mitsui process. The polyethylene will be mar keted under the registered trademark Hifax.

title: TREASURY SEEKS $18BILLION RISE IN CEILING ON DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Sagging corporate profits and other economic woes have re duced the Government's tax revenue, Administration spokes man said today as they asked Congress for $18billion more in borrowing authority.

title: ROZELLE TESTIFIES AT TRIAL OF FLOOD
description: Pete Rozelle, the Commis sioner of the National Football League, testified yesterday that professional football had been able to live with its player option rule and profitably so on occasion.

title: PACERS TOP STARS, TAKE A.B.A. TITLE
description: LOS ANGELES, May 25 (AP) Roger Brown and the Indi aria Pacers finally grunned down the plucky Los Angeles Stars tonight, 111107 and won the American Basketball Asso dation championship. Indiana, the Eastern leaders, beat the Western Division representative, 4 games to 2, in the final play offs.

title: Court Rejects Challenge Over Walinsky's Residence
description: ALBANY, May 25A Su preme Court justice today re jected a residency challenge as an effort to preserve politics for a political aristocracy.

title: Panel Said to Veto A SingleCity Fair For U.S. Birthday
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  A Presidential commission ap pointed to plan for the 200th anniversary of the American Revolution is reported to have rejected the idea of a world's fair in any single city.

title: OFFTRACK BETTING SCORED IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 25 A proposal to authorize off track betting in Nassau County was opposed vigorously today, mostly by racetrack interests, at a public hearing held by the Board of Supervisors.

title: SISTER DIES OF DRUG; BRONX MAN SEIZED
description: A 24yearold Bronx resident was arrested yesterday and charged with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide following the death of his 21 yearold sister apparently from an overdose of heroin.

title: XRAYS OF HURLER UNCOVER NO CHIPS
description: The New York Mets were advised yesterday that Jerry Koosman, their No. 1 left handed pitcher, was suffering from tendonitis near the elbow and that his immediate return to work considered doubtful.

title: Canadian Pollution Inquiry Told Tanker Equipment Was Faulty
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 25 (Canadian Press)  The captain of the tanker Ar row said today his ship was operating with faulty radar, a disabled echo sounder and a gyro compass that read several degrees off course when the ship grounded in Nova Scotia's Chedabucto Bay on Feb. 4.

title: Apollo Astronauts May Have Seen Cosmic Rays
description: SAN DIEGO, May 25  A space agency scientist said to day he believed that, when astronauts close their eyes in space, they can sometimes see the tracks of cosmic rays.

title: Foreign Money Reserves Of U.S. Declined in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  United States International monetary reserves declined by $431million in April as hold ings of foreign currencies con tinued to drop, the Treasury reported today.

title: Three Pitchers Are Banned In Japan Baseball Scandal
description: TOKYO, May 25 (AP)The Japan Professional Baseball Commission suspended for life today three pitchers of the Pa cific League's Nishitetsu Lions for allegedly having taken bribes and thrown games in the 1969 season.

title: War's Effect on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) About 250 medical personnel from Harvard University visited Capitol Hill today to tell Sena tors, Representatives and aides of the impact that the Vietnam war was having on the health care profession. They voiced concern about the ability of the nation to meet critical needs in the quality of health care, medical search and education becaure of the war.

title: 3 ISRAELI PROBES MADE IN LEBANON
description: AVIVIM, Israel, May 25 Israeli forces made three limit ed incursions into southern Lebanon today, one of them With a tank column that was said to have engaged and knocked out a Lebanese Army artillery position north of Yarun.

title: Room Service Wits Dip Into the Past
description: They were the sons of mirth, now they are the fathers of laughter. The years that have aged them do not seem to have aged their play, Room Service, which is running at the Edi son Theater to yet another round of critical hurrahs.

title: 19 Students Seized in Occupation of the New School
description: Most of the country's col lege campuses were quiet yes terday, although National Guardsmen still patrolled Ohio State University and 19 stu dents were arrested for occupy ing a graduate school building of the New School for Social Research in New York City.

title: Liberace's Stepmother Dies
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 (AP)Mrs. Zona Gale Liberace, the stepmother of Liberace, the pianist, died yesterday in a con valescent hospital here after long illness. She was 66 years old. Sam Liberace and his wife, parents also of George Liberace the violinist, played in the Mil waukee Symphony Orchestra before they moved here in 1961.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Hank Stram, the fashion plate of Kansas City, was garbed in the mantle of super coach last night and the bestowal came from the New York Chapter of the Pro Football Writers' Association at their an nual blacktie dinner at the Hotel Ameri cana. On him it looked good. It also fit him beautifully because his ingenious di rection led his Chiefs to a stunning but convincing victory over the Minnesota Vikings in the Super Bowl last January. In case you've forgotten, the score was 237.

title: Community Hearing Scheduled On Museum's Expansion Plans
description: An open community hearing on the Metropolitan Museum's new master plan will be held June 4 at 6 P.M. in the audi torium of the American Mu seum of Natural History, Cen tral Park West at 79th Street.

title: Fallout Bunker Kept Ready
description: ALBANYThe director of the Civil Defense Commission leaned back thoughtfully in his chair in the state's shock proof underground bunker and put his feet up on his desk.

title: Continental Oil Co. Votes Purchase of Own Shares
description: Directors of The Continental Oil Company announced yester day that they had authorized management to purchase up to 400,000 common shares. The directive said the purchases could be made over a period of time whenever the best inter ests of the shareholders would be served.

title: SCOTT URGES A CUT IN INTEREST RATES
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 (UPI)Hugh Scott, the Senate minority leader, urged the nation's banks today to lower their interest rates and allow easier credit for small busi nesses, nonprofit housing and pollutioncontrol projects.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Many fisheries biologists believe Atlantic salmon can be brought back to the Con necticut River if provisions are made for them to move upstream past various power dams during their spawning runs, but those who would accomplish this are as yet unable to persuade the utili ties that control these dams to construct adequate fish passage facilities.

title: Tape Recorders for Vietnam
description: TOKYO, May 25 (AP)Japan exported to South Vietnam last year 213,897 tape recorders worth $22.5million, Finance Ministry officials said today. They said most of the tape re corders were believed to have been purchased by American soldiers in South Vietnam.

title: Soviet Develops Dense Water
description: MOSCOW, May 25 (UPI)  The Soviet Union reported today that its scientists had developed a form of water as thick as Vaseline that cannot turn to ice. A similar discovery was reported by United States scientists several months ago.

title: BIG BOARD SINKS TO A 7YEAR LOW
description: The stock market was battered down yesterday to its lowest level in nearly seven and a half years as the Dow Jones industrial average, falling 20.81 points to 641.36, posted its biggest oneday break since the assassination of President Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963. More than half of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange set new 1970 lows.

title: April Check Writing Grew at City Banks
description: Charges against checking accounts in New York City banks last month advanced 1.98 per cent from the March level to $4.42trillion, the Federal Reserve Board re ported yesterday.

title: Rain Postpones Golf Day
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., May 25 (UPI)Orville Moody, the United States Open golf champion and Ray Floyd, the Professional Golfers' Associa tion titleholder, had no chance to set a mark for the nation's club shooters today, when rain washed out their Golf Day match at the P.G.A. National Golf Club. The two will try again tomorrow.

title: Russia to Launch 2 French Satellites In Space Research
description: PARIS, May 25  Soviet rockets will launch two French research satellites into orbit in the next two years, Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced today from Leningrad.

title: Soviet Warns Pnompenh Of Long Fratricidal War
description: MOSCOW, May 25The So viet Union has warned the cur rent Cambodian leaders that Cambodia will be plunged into a long fratricidal war un less United States and South Vietnamese forces are with drawn from their country.

title: Shift in Arab Oil Pumping
description: KUWAIT, May 25 (UPI) Saudi Arabia has begun pump ing oil through a pipeline to Ras Tannoura on the Persian Gulf and may give up using the Trans Arabian Pipeline (Tap line) through Syria to Lebanon, Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, Zaki Yamani, said here today. He denied Beirut newspaper reports that Saudi Arabia has taken a final decision to stop using the Tapline, but he said his country was still seriously studying the issue.

title: The AlgerianAmerican Plan To Ship Gas Is Stepped Up
description: The joint AlgerianAmerican plan for liquefied natural gas (L.N.G.) into this country from Africa in giant tankers is being stepped up, Dr. Robert L. Pur vin, a leading industry consult ant, announced yesterday at an industry conference at Seattle.

title: Observer: Miss de Rigor's Modern Etiquette
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  From the mailbag of Miss Cor nelia de Rigor, the distinguished authority on contemporary American etiquette:

title: Prudential Entering Auto and Home Fields
description: NEWARK, May 25The Prudential Insurance Com panythe largest insurer in the worldtook the plunge today and announced its longexpected entry into the emotion  charged automobile and homeowner insurance business.

title: Suharto Arrives in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 President Suharto of Indonesia arrived today at Williamsburg, Va., to begin a state visit to the United States. He will he re ceived by President Nixon at the White House tomorrow morning.

title: Adelphi Nine Upheld on Protest, To Replay 31 Loss to C. W. Post
description: Since there is no such thing as an instant replay in col lege baseball, Adelphi and C. W. Post have scheduled a doover to decide the cham pionship of the Knickerbocker Conference at 3 P.M. tomorrow on the Panthers' field in Gar den City.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Communications Company Raises Income in Quarter
description: Western Union International, Inc., reported yesterday first quarter operating revenues of $13,256,000 against 88,521,000 a year earlier.

title: Butkus, Alworth, W. Brown Lead Polls
description: Lance Alworth, the flashy wide receiver of the San Diego Chargers, and Willie Brown, the clever corner back of the Oakland Raiders, emerged yesterday as the players most coveted by coaches who worked in the American football league last season:

title: Goldberg Endorses State Role AS Employer of Last Resort
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, a candi date for the Democratic nomi nation for Governor I said yes terday that the state should act as an employer of last re sort, providing jobs for people who can't find them in private industry. If elected Governor, Mr. Goldberg said, he would immediately call a conference on unemployment to delineate a specific statewide plan of guaranteed public employment and manpower training oppor tunities.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: The Times did a disservice to the state primary by suggesting [editorial May 13] that with the Liberal party supporting my op ponent the primary race for Governor was now academic. I disagree.

title: Dr. William M. Hekking, 85, Painter Directed Museums
description: WOOLWICH, Me., May 25 (AP)Dr. William M. Hekking, a seascape painter who directed several art museums, died at his home here Saturday. His age was 85.

title: AGE MAIN FACTOR IN HOCKEY DEAL
description: ST. LOUIS, May 25 (UPI) Jacques Plante, a 41yearold goalie who has played in 106 Stanley Cup playoff hockey games, has been traded by the St. Louis Blues to the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: David Fox Fiance Of Pamela Davis
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 24Miss Pamela Davis and David Lawrence Fox, law yers with the New York firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie & Alexander, plan to be mar ried here in September.

title: Simone and Gamma Rays Share Off Broadway Prize
description: Winners of the 15th annual Village Voice Obie awards for the best Off Broadway works and performances were an nounced yesterday.

title: SURVEY CONDEMNS SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: The school lunches served to 400,000 children here daily are so unappetizing, poorly pre pared and illsuited to the chil dren's tastes that a great deal of the food is dumped in gar bage cans after the first bite, the Citizens Committee for Children of New York charged yesterday.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The Administration has in formed Congress that it has decided to give about $7.5million worth of arms to the military Government in Cambodiam on

title: Reasons for Panther Wiretap Challenged in PreTrial Hearing
description: A Brooklyn assistant District Attorney and a Brooklyn de tective were sharply questioned yesterday by lawyers for 13 Black Panthers accused of plot ting to bomb public places.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: Market Place:
description: A return to vigor in the stock marketand the bat tered bond market too for that matteris an eventual ity devoutly to be wished.

title: Senate Test on Mines Offkial Delayed by Plagiarism Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The Senate Interior Commit tee delayed today a vote on confirmation of President Nixon's nominee to head the Bureau of,Mines until it could examine two background re ports by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: BETTER TREATMENT OF RETARDED ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)  A Presidential com mittee urged today that insti tutions housing the mentally retarded in what it called environments experienced by prisoners of war adopt a new philosophy protecting the human and civil rights of the retarded.

title: LIFE FACES LAWSUIT BY ST. LOUIS MAYOR
description: ST. LOUIS, May 25Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes said to day that he would file a $12 million libel suit against Life magazine and Denny Walsh, author of a Life article ac cusing the Mayor of having personal ties with underworld figures.

title: FILLY PAYS $17.60 IN RACE ON GRASS
description: Angel Cordero took posses sion of Belmont Park yester day. The amiable Puerto Rican rider was the star of the open ing day's program at the huge plant as he came through with four winners in eight attempts.

title: SUIT STILL STIRS MARYMOUNT GIRLS
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 25Marymount College is still feeling the effects of a court suit filed earlier this month against a strike at the college even though the suit was settled out of court and the college says it was never on strikp to begin with.

title: College Group to Explain Political Endorsements
description: Considerations that entered into endorsements by the New York Region of the Movement for a New Congress, a college political action group, will be among subjects discussed at 2:30 P.M. news conference to day by Stephen A. O. Golden, regional director, in the. Co lumbia Law School faculty lounge.

title: U.S. Told by Eban of Evidence Soviet Seeks Aerial Dominance Over Suez
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel has told the Nixon Ad ministration there are intelli gence indications that the So viet Union intends to seek domination of the air over the Suez Canal region and possibly will try to reopen the canal under its own auspices.

title: $99 Student Air Fare to Europe Urged
description: Pan American World Air ways said yesterday that it would propose a new oneway space available transAtlan tic fare enabling collegeage youths to fly between New York and Europe for $99.

title: Cambodia War Said to Cause Major Peking Shift
description: Information reaching New York from sources close to Communist leaders in Asia sug gests that the United States move into Cambodia has trans formed the Indochina situation more radically than originally estimated. This evaluation is be ing taken seriously in Wash ington.

title: Vote Violence Grows in Ceylon; Government's Backers a Target
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 25 With only two days to ga before the seventh general elec tion since independence, the tension of the monthlong cam paign has erupted into violence across a large part of the country.

title: Pearson Says U.N. Must Change or Die
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25Former Prime Minis ter Lester B. Pearson of Can ada opened a conference on human survival here today with a call for drastic reforms in the United Nations.

title: A Correction
description: In a review of the Whitney Museum show, The Reality of Appearance, which appeared on Saturday In The New York Times, the admission price was incorrectly listed as $5. Admission to the show is $2 for the general public and 75 cents for students.

title: Sorensen's Try for Technical KO
description: The Secretary of State's office is expected to hand down its decision today on a challenge being mounted by Theodore Sorensen against qualifying petitions filed in behalf of Representative R. D. Max McCarthy the Democratic Senatorial primary contest. Paul O'Dwyer and Representative Richard Ottinger are the other candidates in the June 23 election, but are not directly involved in the present dispute.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert F. Gammons, a vice president of Laird Enter prises, has been elected president, chief executive officer and a director of the 140yearold S. S. Pierce Company, Boston. He succeeds Roger D. Williams, who becomes chairman of the board, while William T. Pierce becomes honorary chairman. Laird was acquired by a group of private investors, headed by Laird International, in 1967.

title: Dutch Priests Ask Talks
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, May 25 (Reuters)A group of Roman Catholic priests in the Netherlands was report ed today to have called on the Vatican to open talks with Dutch bishops on the question of compulsory celibacy for priests.

title: NATALIE LAMB GIVES HOUR OF SOLO SONGS
description: Natalie Lamb, who usually belts out blue songs from the repertoires of Bessie Smith and Ma Rainey with the Red Onion Jazz Band, gave a dinner recital last night at the Roosevelt. Grill, accompanied only by a pianist, Dick Miller. It was the first of a series of onehour recitals she will give there, Tuesdays through Friday at 7:30.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Newark Strategy
description: NEWARK, May 25As the political forces in this city re aligned themselves for the run off of what they regard as the most crucial mayoral election campaign ever waged here, the major opposing factions were in general agreement today on what they had to do to win.

title: ROGERS, IN ROME, BIDS U.S. AIDES BACK NIXON
description: ROME, May 25Secretary of State William P. Rogers today defended United States inter vention in Cambodia as one of the most courageous and suc cessful actions for many years.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS APPEAL BY UTILITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corpora tion from an order that it pass about $10.5million in refunds on to its customers.

title: Election Board Rejects Basil's Bid for Surrogate
description: The Board of Elections an nounced yesterday that Crim inal Court Judge Amos Basil had been disqualified from the Democratic primary for surro gate in New York County be cause of insufficient signatures on his petitions.

title: FRANCIS TAUSSIG OF GROLIER DEAD
description: Francis Brewster Taussig, president of Grolier Interna tional, Inc., and executive vice president of its parent com pany, Grolier, Inc., publishers of encyclopedias and textbooks, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 14 Sutton Place South.

title: BETTY DONNELLY, 74, A.F.L.C.I.O. OFFICER
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., May 25 Mrs. Betty Hawley Donnelly, a vice president of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O., died yesterday at the Brunswick Nursing Home. She was 74 years old and lived at 102 South Peconic Drive, Massa pequa.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: the ground that such assist ance is important to the security of the United States.

title: Dance Awards Are Made
description: The 16th annual Dance magazine awards were pre sented yesterday to Sir Fred erick Ashton, director of Britain's Royal Ballet; Carolyn Brown, principal dancer of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company; and Ted Shawn, co founder with his wife, the late Ruth St. Denis, of the famed Denishawn company and school, and director of the Jacob's Pillow Festival.

title: Steel Output in U.S. Dropped by 0.6% During Last Week
description: Steel production dipped by 0.6 per cent last week, com pared to output in the preced ing week, the American iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Stage: Chicago 70 at the Martinique
description: Of course it had to happen. The socalled Chicago Con spiracy was the purest form of theater rather than poli tics. Starring Julius Hoffman, the wellknown judge from Chicago, and Abbie Hoffman, the wellknown Yippie from Woodstock Nation. At the time I was always expecting an announcement of the sale of film rights to be delivered with the verdicts.

title: Pushover Beats The Spoiler In Devon Horse Show Jumpoff
description: DEVON, Pa., May 25  One lapse  even if your name is Rod Jenkins  when you are in the ring against United States Equestrian Team riders and you finish among the alsh rans.

title: Joseph Wood Krutch
description: A world in which environment has become the word of the day might profit from looking back at the prescient works of Joseph Wood Krutch, who died last week in Arizona. Twenty years ago that cultivated critic and teacher exchanged Manhattan for an adobe home in the Southwest to escape the crowds, to get air he could breathe and to enjoy the natural beauty of the desert and its wildlife.

title: PUBLIC BROADCASTS GET $600,000 GRANT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has granted $600,000 to the Cor poration for Public Broadcast ing to set up a public broad casting environment center.

title: Marine Brig at Lejeune To Begin Reform Program
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., May 25 (AP)Prisoners in the ma rine brig here will soon begin each day with a halfhour of drill and end it with a halfhour of physical training under a new reform program. They will also get lectures on military subjects.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: A VIDEO RECORDER OFFERED BY AVCO
description: The Avco Corporation became yesterday the fourth entrant in the home electronic video re cording field with a new prod uct to be marketed under the name Cartrivision (CTV).

title: JAMES IS ELECTED PRESIDENT OF NEWS
description: The board of directors of The New York News has announced the election of W. H. James as president, succeeding F. M. Flynn, who was elected to the newly created post of chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Gimbel Shows Lower Net; Other Retailers Also Lag
description: Sagging consumer purchas ing tied into the accelerating economic slowdown has taken its toll on operating results of four department store chains, all of which reported yesterday lower profits for the quarter ended with April.

title: LANDLORDSASSAIL PLAN FOR RENTS
description: About 200 landlords filled a hearing room at City Hall yes terday to denounce Mayor Lind say's plan for revising the city's 27yearold rent  control law.

title: JOHN F. DWYER
description: BUFFALO, May 25 (AP) John F. Dwyer, a former State Supreme Court justice and one time Erie County District At torney, died in Deaconess Hos pital yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: 12 Days of Peace Cost City an Extra Million
description: The city spent $1,158,000 in overtime pay for police men assigned to keep order during downtown demonstra tions in the 12day period from May 11 to May 22.

title: ROBERT GERBER
description: CLARK, N. J., May 25Rob ert Gerber, a stockbroker with the New York firm of Troster, Singer & Co., for many years, died Saturday in Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. He was 66 years old and lived here at 74 Sweet Briar Drive.

title: YODER EARNS CROWN IN SINGLES BOWLING
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 25 (UPI)  Jake Yoder of Fort Wayne, Ind., who bowled the tournament's only 300 game, was crowned regular division singles champion today as the 67th American Bowling Con gress closed.

title: New Amsterdam Group Plays Joep Straesser
description: The New Amsterdam Ensem ble, a friendly group of chamber music experts, played at Car negie Recital Hall last night.

title: Five Americans Missing On British Honduras Flight
description: BELIZE, British Honduras, May 25 (UPI)  A chartered Cessna aircraft has been miss ing 24 hours on a scheduled 20minute flight with five Amer icans aboard, authorities re ported today.

title: Entertainment Events Scheduled for Today
description: Theater

title: Bridal on July 4 In France Is Set By Miss Gowen
description: The engagement of Miss Gwynedd Anne Gowen, a junior at Vassar College, to Guy Felix, a law student at the University of Paris, has been announced by the pros pective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William E. W. Gowen of New York.

title: S. E. C. SUSPENDS D. H. BLAIR & CO.
description: WASHINGTON, May 25A major New York Stock Ex change member firm, D. H. Blair & Co. was ordered suspended from some aspects of the se curities business today and three other large, wellknown brokerage houses were censured by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: O'Dwyer Calls for Giving Free Narcotics to Addicts
description: Paul O'Dwyer broke yester day with the other three can didates for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate by urging estab lishment of government centers to administer free drugs to narcotics addicts.

title: Books of The Times
description: Just as each publisher must have his sex book, his sports book and his Vietnam book, so each publisher must also have his autobiography of a young radical. Auto biographies of young radicals arrive these days in dozens, like cartons of eggs, and reviewers tend to try to make omelets out of them. It won't work. All the eggs may look alike to the eye of a construction worker or a Vice President or a Bruno Bettelheim, but inside each Is inconvenient ly unique. James Kunen is not Dotson Rader is not Paul Cowan is not Jerry Rubin is not Don MacNeill is not Bobby Seale.

title: NEW FACES APPEAR IN PEKING REGIME
description: HONG KONG, May 25Two public ceremonies this month in Peking attended by Mao Tse tung and the hierarchy around him have provided an unusual opportunity to study the ranks of the Chinese Communist lead ership.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Pentagon today identi fied the following men from the New York Area as having been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Roundup: 5Hitter Buoys UpandDown Morehead
description: Dave Morehead's unspec tacular career has not been without its high spots. There were, for example, the no hitter he pitched against Cleveland in 1965 and the three innings of hitless relief he pitched for Boston in the 1967 World Series.

title: James Earl Jones Moving Off Broadway
description: James Earl Jones, who won star status last year and the Tony award as Broadway's best actor for his role of the black heavyweight champion in The Great White Hope, will appear in an Off Broad way show next month.

title: A.B.A. Playoff
description: CHAMPIONSHIP

title: PROBLEM IS POSED BY OPEN HYDRANTS
description: The annual epidemic of open fire hydrants with water cascading down filthstrewn streets, inevitably leading to clogged catch basins and flood ing, has become of growing concern to the city's Water Resources Department.

title: SIHANOUK ARRIVES IN HANOI FOR VISIT
description: VIENNA, May 25 (Reuters) Prince Norodom Sihanouk. the deposed Cambodian Chief of State, arrived in Hanoi to day amid indications that North Vietnam would not send more troops into Cambodia.

title: TV VETO OVER PANEL ON VIOLENCE SCORED
description: STANFORD, Calif., May 25 (UPI)The television networks were allowed to veto appoint ments to a Federal panel in vestigating television violence, a group of scientists said today.

title: BASE BALL'S PACT PUT AT $4MILLION
description: Marvin Miller, director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, announced yesterday details of the new contract agreed to by negotiat ing committees for the players and club owners.

title: Newspapers Will Fight To Retain TV Licenses
description: CHATTANOUUA, May Z (AP)The Southern Newspaper, Publishers Association will take an aggressive part in a coordi nated defense of a newspapers right to continue owning radio and television stations and CATV systems, the associations president Ralph W. Callahan, said.

title: U.S. Says 201 G.I.'s Have Died In 25 Days of Cambodia Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 25 (AP)  The United States command reported to day that American battlefield deaths had reached 201 in 25 days of operations in Cam bodia.

title: A Lone Frenchman Tends Farm in Southern Laos
description: PAKSONG, Laos, May 22 Jean Fivaz is the last French farmer on the verdant Boloven Plateau, which has become the target of the new Communist offensive in southern Laos.

title: Stocks Fall 20 to 7Year Low; Bond Interest Rates Hit Peaks
description: Security markets came under relentless pressure yesterday as Wall Street registered the big gest singleday decline since the assassination of President Ken nedy on Nov. 22, 1963. The DowJones industrial average plunged 20.81 points to 641.36, its lowest close since Dec. 18, 1962.

title: Whales Sing Siren Song for Scientist
description: The cavernous sound, strangely melodious, began on a low pitch, rose slowly to a higher frequency at which it sounded for a moment like a combined oboe and muted cor net, trailed off into an eerie highpitched, undulating wail like melancholy bagpipes and then faded into silence.

title: U.S. Aide Assails Swedish Protesters
description: STOCKHOLM. May 25Dr. Jerome H. Holland, the United States Ambassador to Sweden, complained today that he had been subjected to disgrace ful demonstrations protesting United States policy in South east Asia and warned that they could have farreaching im plications.

title: Ford Foundation to Distribute $2.1Million to Arts
description: The Ford Foundation, which usually thinks big when it comes to supporting the per forming arts, can also think small. Hiding modestly in its announcement yesterday of grants totaling $2.1million to 17 organizations was a $10,000 oneyear grant to the Whatcom Museum of History and Art in Bellingham, Wash., to finance an Indian youth apprentice program.

title: Tests Support Biochemical Link to Schizophrenia
description: KENOSHA, Wis., May 25 New evidence supporting the view that internal biochemical defects are an important factor in schizophrenia was reported here today at an international symposium on the chemistry of the brain.

title: Susan Schweikert Prospective Bride
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 25Mr. and Mrs. William P. Schweickert have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan. Alice Schweickert, to William Kingsland Macy 3d, son of Mrs. Francisco Parra of Nor folk, Va., and Puerto Val larta, Mexico, and Mr. Macy Jr. of Win. L. T.

title: Tracy, Street Singer, Greets Senior Citizens
description: Arthur Tracy, well known in the nineteenthirties on radio as The Street Singer, greeted an assembly of 1,900 senior citizens yesterday with his theme song, Marta.

title: Investment Need Is Cited in Quebec
description: TORONTO, May 25  The business leaders of Quebec told their new provincial premier, Robert Bourassa, today that an investment increase of more than 50 per cent was needed to reduce the province's chron ically high unemployment and raise living standards.

title: School Election Delay Denied By Court and Albany Official
description: Two attempts to postpone the local school board elections in Manhattan again because of the racial and ethnic make up of the six school districts in the borough were denied yesterday.

title: Jordan Officials Visit Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 25 (UPI)Premier Bahjat alTal houni of Jordan arrived here today, accompanied by the chief of staff of the Jordanian armed forces, Maj. Gen. Mash fur Haditha.

title: Project Hope Chief Cited
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The University of Notre Dame's highest award, the Laetare Medal, went today to Dr. William B. Walsh, the founder, president and medical director of Project Hope.

title: Crew Escapes as a C5A Catches Fire on Ground
description: PALMDALE, Calif., May 25 (UPI)A huge C54 transport plane caught fire today as it was preparing to take off from an Air Force test and training facility at Palmdale Airport.

title: STOCKS IN TOKYO DECLINE SHARPLY
Morton Shows Poll Backing Nixon Move
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Countering Democratic charges that Americans are losing con fidence in President Nixon, the Republican National Chairman released poll figures today in dicating that a majority of the voters approve of the Presi dent's decision to send Ameri can troops into Cambodia.

title: REGENTS CHARTER SCHOOL FOR POOR
description: A twoyear college that com bines academic study and on thejob training for impover ished students was chartered last week by the State Board of Regents.

title: Jackie Robinson to Speak
description: NORTHFIELD, Mass., May 25 (AP)The former baseball star Jackie Robinson will deliver the commencement address at Mount Herman School June 6. His son, David, will be among the graduates.

title: Reynolds Raises Prices
description: RICHMOND, May 25 (AP) The Reynolds Metals Company announced today price increas es on some chemical products of onehalf cent to 2 cents a pound.

title: Israeli Post to Schmiedeler
description: John Schmiedeler, who re cently resigned from St. Mary of The Plains College in Dodge City, Kan., has been named coach of Israeli national bas ketball team, it was announced yesterday. Schmiedeler will coach and teach physical edu cation in Natanya.

title: Ken Scott Missed Home Cooking, So ...
description: MILAN, Italy  Ken Scott, the designer, opened a bet ter mousetrap at the entrance to his boutique here last No vember. Three weeks later, city authorities snapped it shut and, temporarily at least, closed off Milan's only commercial source of apple brown Betty, corn bread and chili con came.

title: FRANCIS M. SEAMAN, JERSEY OFFICIAL, 65
description: PERTH AMBOY, N. J., May 25Francis M. Seaman, Perth Amboy's city attorney, senior, partner in the law firm of Sea man & Clark, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Perth Am boy General Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 442 Barclay Street.

title: ExI.R.S. Agent Is Fined
description: Julius Rosenerg, a former In ternal Revenue Service agent, was fined $3,000 in Federal Court yesterday for bribing an other tax agent. Judge Marvin E. Frankel imposed the penalty after a trial in which Rosen berg, 45 years old, of Inwood, L. I., was convicted of paying $200 for information: on how much the I.R.S. knew about bribes he had taken while an agent.

title: Medical Leader Is Installed
description: Dr. Vaughan C. Mason, di rector of obstetrics and gyne cology at Sydenham Hospital and a member of the New York City Board of Hospitals, was installed last night as president of the New York County Medical Society. The installation of Dr. Mason, who succeeds Dr. Edward A. Burk hardt, took place at the so ciety's annual meeting at the New York Academy of Medi cine, 2 East 103d Street.

title: Army Has 513 Generals
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) There are now 513 Army generals, about 50 per cent more than before the Vietnam war. Part of the reason is the increased size of the armed forces and part is that promo tions come more quickly in time of combat.

title: Hundreds Evacuated Again As Floods Plague Rumania
description: BUCHAREST, May 25 (Reu ters)Torrential rains, high winds and rising rivers today forced hundreds of families in central Rumania to evacuate their homes for the second time in two weeks.

title: Mrs. Walter Pfizenmayer, Clubwomen's Leader, 75
description: UNIONDALE L. I., May 25 Margaret J. Hancock Pfizen mayer, former secretary of the National Association of Ameri can Composers and Conduc tors, and twice president of the Long Island Federation of. Wo men's Clubs, died today at the A. Holley Patterson Home for the Aged. She was 75 years old and had lived until recently at 292 Maryland Avenue, Free port.

title: Gramco in I.O.S. Bid
description: LONDON, May 26 (UPI) Gramco International, a large international realty concern based in London, says it still is interested in acquiring control of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd. of Geneva if Denver fin ancier John King does not com plete his 2 bid to acquire I.O.S.

title: Women Militants Disrupt Cavett Show With Hefner
description: Two members of the Women's Liberation movement tried to get onto the stage of the Dick Cavett show last night as the program was being taped for presentation later in the eve ning on Channel 7.

title: TENANTS ASSAIL RENT PROPOSALS
description: Numerous tenants and their organizers threatened rent strikes yesterday if the City Council approved Mayor Lind say's proposal to relax the city's 27yearold rentcontrol law.

title: TV: White House Guide
description: Tricia Nixon, the Presi dent's 24yearold daughter, proved a charming, lively and poised hostess last night in a televised tour of the family living quarters on the second floor of the White House.

title: Theater: Wilson in the Promise Land Begins Run
description: Wilson in the Promise Land, which the Trinity Square Repertory Company of Providence, R. L, brought to the ANTA Theater last night, is a play about Wood row Wilson and a play about America. In it, as the author Roland van Zandt states in a program note, there are con frontations between Dream and Reality, the Past and Present, Fathers and Sons, the Presidents and the Hip pies.

title: HOUSTON IS FACING JOB BIAS HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  The Equal Employment Op portunity Commission has charged that minorities do not benefit from Houston's growing economy and it has scheduled public hearings in the nation's space headquarters next week.

title: FLOODS IN RUMANIA PERIL CITIES' DIKES
description: VIENNA, May 26 (Reuters) Waves whipped by high winds pounded the dikes pro tecting Rumania's industrial ports on the Danube River to day as new flooding swept across the country.

title: 61 City U. Seniors Are Hailed; List Includes a Former Convict
description: A 30year old black student who had spent time at Sing Sing Prison for armed robbery and a philosophy major who dropped out of college to be come an actor, were among 61 students honored by the City University yesterday and given awards for advanced study.

title: Leaders of New Police Union To Seek A.F.L.C.I.O. Charter
description: DENVER, May 26Leaders of a newly organized union of policemen said today they would ask the A.F.L.C.I.O. for a charter next week to bring the weight of organized labor behind their goals.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Take Part In Park Ceremony Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will blow a whistle tomorrow to signify completion of the Filene Center at Wolf Trap Farm Park for the performing arts in near by Vienna, Va.

title: 1,500 Hear Kunstler Speed
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 26 William M. Kunster, a defense attorney in the Chicago con spiracy trial, addressed a crowd of 1,500 tonight at San Jose College here after a Federal judge had ruled earlier today that college officials could not cancel Mr. Kunstler's speech on the ground that it might precip itate trouble.

title: Article 3  No Title
A Container Yard For RailShip Trade Slated for Jersey
description: Plans for the construction of a rail container transfer yard, especially intended for the handling of international car goes, were announced here jointly yesterday by the Port of New York Authority and the Penn Central Company.

title: Patrolman Suspended In MoneyFinding Case
description: A Bronx patrolman has been suspended from the Police Department after being Accused of refusing to give a receipt to a man who had found a very large sum of money and turned it over to the police.

title: DANCERS RESTATE MERITS OF JEWELS
description: There are so few ballets that merit the accolade wondrous in our pantheon that it is indeed a pleasure to welcome Jewels in its first appearance in this truncated New York City Ballet spring season. Last night at the State Theater, the company presented its varied humors with genuine consideration if not always glittering brilliance.

title: City Schools Will Close Friday In Observance of Memorial Day
description: The Board of Education an nounced yesterday that all public schools in the city would close this Friday in nonor of Memorial Day.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Case for the SST

title: BOTEIN IS ELECTED HEAD OF BAR GROUP
description: Bernard Botein, former Pre siding Justice of the Appellate Division's First Department, was elected president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at the group's annual meeting last night.

title: Farm Credit Post Approved
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) The Senate today approved the nomination of Ernest G. Spivey of Jackson, Miss., as a member of the Federal Farm Credit Board.

title: SENATEUNIT BACKS POSTAL REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 The Senate Post Office Com mittee today approved pro posed reforms removing Con gress and politics from the postal system and giving post office employes an 8 per cent pay rise.

title: Turbochargers Give Indy 500 A Noisy Increase in Horsepower
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 For the first time ever, the entire field of 33 cars in the Indianapolis 500 have en gines augmented by turbo chargers, which account for the highpitch wail that dom inates the sound effects at Indianapolis Motor Speed way. Noise is part of the excitement t h e fans come to en joy, but for the drivers turbo chargers mean more horsepow er, as much as 40 per cent What is remarkable

title: Accountant Jailed in 1961 Bribery Case
description: Saul I. Birnbaum, a wealthy accountant, was sent to jail yesterday to begin serving a oneyear prison sentence im posed on him in Federal Court four years ago for bribing a tax agent in 1961.

title: Nixon's SoninLaw Takes a Baseball Job
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)  David Eisenhower, soninlaw of President Nix on, has taken a temporary job with the Washington Senators, the White House said today.

title: BritishJapanese Air Pact
description: TOKYO, May 26 (Reuters) The British Overseas Airways Corporation and Japan Air Lines announced a new agreement to day under which their planes will fly between London and Tokyo by way of Moscow. The new service starts June 2.

title: STOCKS AGAIN FALL AS RALLY FIZZLES
description: A brisk selling breeze snuffed out a rally attempt in the stock market at midsession yesterday and prices then ground downward to a new low for the last seven and a half years.

title: Law Catches Up to Monkey
description: ST. LOUIS (AP)After more than a threehour chase, Robert L. Dowdle, a patrolman, spied ??is runaway literally up a tree; Cleo, a woolly monkey.

title: NORTON CONNECTS OFF STOTTLEMYRE
description: DETROIT, May 26The name Horton continued to bedevil the Yankees tonight as Willie Horton, the Tiger left fielder, broke up a scoreless game with a threerun homer in the ninth inning.

title: Brezhnev Compares Unrest of Youth in West With Calm in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 26Leonid I. Brezhnev, the head of the Communist party, said at the opening session of a congress of the Young Communist League today that the stormy upsurge of youth in the West provided evidence of the deep ening social crisis of capitalism.

title: GUARD IS ACCUSED OF SELLING HEROIN
description: A 48yearold correction of ficer was arrested on Rikers Island yesterday and accused of selling five packets of heroin to an inmate who was acting as an undercover agent for the Bronx District Attorney's of fice in a continuing investiga tion of narcotics traffic in the island's prison complex.

title: 1,600 Barrels of Crude Oil Pour Into the Mississippi From Barge
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 26 More than 1,600 barrels of crude oil poured from a dam aged barge into the Mississippi River south of New Orleans last night.

title: MANY TO FORGO CONVENTION TALK
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 George Meany, who was billed as the sole speaker Thursday at the convention of the Amal gamated Clothing Workers of America, will not come here to address the 417,000member union.

title: McCormack Lauded by Nixon, Johnson and Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)  Members of Congress of both parties, led by President Nixon and an occasionally tearful Lyn don B. Johnson, joined today in praise for Speaker John W. McCormack, the Democratic legislator from Boston who is retiring after 42 years in the House.

title: Mrs. Luigi Rossignani, 89, Sister of Pope Plus XII
description: ROME, May 26Mrs. Elisa betta Pacelli Rossignani, sister of the late Pope Pius XII and his closest surviving relative, died here Saturday, the Vatican announced today. She was 89 years old, and had suffered a fall six months ago.

title: Big 4 Confer on Mideast, Say Aides' Study Goes On
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26The Ambassadors of the Big FourThe United States, Britain, France And the Soviet Unionmet again today in their search for a perma nent peace settlement in the Middle East based on the Se curity Council's Nov. 22, 1967, resolution. They announced only that the work would con tinue.

title: WALLACE GIRLING, PUBLISHING AIDE
description: Wallace S. Girling, a former publishing executive and chair man of Ade1phi University's board of trustees, died after a, heart attack at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L. I., Monday night. He lived at 40 Fairview Avenue, in East Wil liston, and was 74 years old.

title: I.O.S. OFFICERS HOLD $2.5MILLLION LOANS
description: GENEVA, May 26  Board members and senior executives of the troubled Investors Over seas Services mutual fund em pire hold $2.5million in se cured loans obtained from its banking subsidiaries, according to a notice sent to the parent I.O.S. Company's shareholders.

title: P.B.A. URGES CITY TO CURB INQUIRY
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association called upon the City Council yesterday to deny subpoena powers to the special commission set up last week by Mayor Lindsay to investi gate charges of widespread po lice corruption in the New York Police Department.

title: Grand Jury in Queens Hears Conductor in Fatal IND Crash
description: The conductor of the IND local that smashed into a crowded rushhour train last Wednesday testified for more than an hour yesterday before a Queens grand jury looking into the accident.

title: SAIGON TO RENEW TIES TO CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 27  The Governments of South Vietnam and Cambodia agreed here to day that South Vietnamese troops would be pulled out of Cambodia as soon as their mission is completed.

title: Neiman World Festival To Highlight Ruritania
description: Department stores and spe cialty shops just love to pro mote excitement through the gambit of having a festival honoring some foreign land. Out in Dallas, NeimanMar cus has been running what it calls its International Fort night for the last 13 years. Now, apparently, they've run out of suitable countries, so they'll honor Ruritania.

title: MAJETTE IS FIRST IN WESTBURY PACE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 26 Rain that, had fallen through most of the afternoon and through the first race had little or no effect on the synthetic rubber surface at Roosevelt Raceway as the second harness tracing meeting of, the season started at the Nassau County course tonight.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Arts. President Nixon an nounced the appointment of 49 persons to be members of the Advisory Committee on the Arts of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Per forming Arts.

title: Knicks Sign Jackson, Out Year With Ailment
description: Phil Jackson, who missed the New York Knickerbock ers' world championship sea son while recuperating from a spinal fusion operation, has signed his contract for the 197071 season.

title: ITALIANS WORRIED BY DRUG SCANDALS
description: ROME, May 26A sensation al narcotics scandal in which two popular entertainers have been jailed has given the popu lar newspapers an opportunity to revive the shopworn legend of La Dolce Vita.

title: YABLONSKI GROUP CRITICIZES SHULTZ
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz was accused today by supporters of the late Joseph A. Yablonski of a deliberate effort to try to sweep under the rug the numerous govern ment investigations of the United Mine Workers of Amer ica that began when Mr. Yab lonski was murdered five months ago.

title: Anaconda's Brass Unit Calls Off Increase Set for Monday
description: The Anaconda American Brass Company, a major fabri cating subsidiary of the Ana conda Company, announced yesterday in Waterbury, Conn. that it would not impose a price increase, tentatively scheduled for Monday, on copper water tube.

title: Roundup: A Full Measure From a PartTime Worker
description: Chico Salmon doesn't deny he used to sleep with the lights on, the windows closed and the keyhole plugged. How else was he supposed to keep the evil spirits away?

title: Franklin R. Brown, 84, Dies; Headed State Bar in 1953
description: BUFFALO, May 26 (AP) Franklin R. Brown, a former president of the New York State Bar Association, died to day in Deaconness Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Constance Wohlgemuth Affianced
description: BRICKTOWN, N. J., May 26Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Wohigemuth have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Con stance Louise Wohigemuth, to David Purinton Chamber lain, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Roe Chamberlain of Northport, L. I. The wedding is Planned for June 21 here.

title: Gillette Co. Elects 2
description: Colman M. Mockler Jr., has been elected an executive vice president and Edward G. Mel augh senior vice presidentfi nance of the Gillette Company. Mr. Mockler will be responsible for the company's financial, le gal and administrative staff functions.

title: Wilbur Daniel Steele, 84, Dies; A Leading ShortStory Writer
description: ESSEX, Conn., May 26Wil bur Daniel Steele, whose care fully crafted short stories put him in The first rank of Ameri can storytellers for many years, died at a nursing home here to day after a long illness. He was 84 years old and a resident of Lyme.

title: While Market Fell, a Bullish Auction at Dalton
description: Silkscreen posters by Andy Warhol and Jack Younger man went for $200 each; others by Ernst Trova and Charles Hinman brought in $175 and $155. A painting by Gloria Vanderbilt Cooper sold for $425. A fivebottle wine basket went for $200 and a magnum of Dom Peri gnon 1961 for $40.

title: Liberalized Abortion Bill Is Vetoed in Maryland
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Mary land vetoed today legislation that would have removed all state restrictions on abortions.

title: FINCH WILL RETAIN HIS POST IN CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Robert H. Finch told the White House today that he intended to return to his de partment and proceed with vigor to overcome depart mental problems.

title: Badillo Ruled Out as G.O.P. Candidate
description: The name of Herman Badillo, former Bronx Borough Presi dent, was removed from the ballot as the Republican desig nee for Representative from the 21st Congressional District on Monday, the Board of Elections said yesterday. According to the board, he lacked sufficient Republican petitions.

title: Fall Buying Begun By Milliken Show
description: One of the annual signs of the start of the wholesale buy ing period for women's fall merchandise arrived in New York yesterday with the first performance of the 1970 MT liken Breakfast Show.

title: Cost of Films and Their Yields
description: This list, composed of films first released during 1969, estimates their boxoffice grosses to date. The grosses are compiled from Variety's weekly chart, which esti mates receipts in 24 mar kets.

title: LOAN FIGURE SET FOR WORLD BANK
description: PARIS, May 26A quarrel between the United States and France over development aid has been settled with a provi sional, compromise agreement that would dump $800million a year into the Soft Loan Agency of the World Bank over the next three years.

title: Truck Splits, Road Buttered
description: NOKOMIS, Ill., May 26 (UPI) A portion of Route 16 was closed today while workmen washed off 5,000 pounds of melting butter. A truck driver said the load of butter dropped all over the highway when his trailer split in half after it hit a bump.

title: N. F. L. Coaches Vote for a Rule Against Jumping Over Tacklers
description: Joe Kapp, an inventive ath lete who quarterbacks for the Minnesota Vikings, brought hurdling back to professional football last season but the coaches have decided to ban the practice. The coaches con cluded their meeting here yes terday with this news while the owners began theirs at the National Football League offices on Park Avenue.

title: NASA Loses an Astronaut
description: SPACE CENTER, HOUSTON, May 26 (UPI)  A Veteran Apollo pilot will quit the astro naut corps next month and the man in charge of advanced manned spaceflight planning will take another Government job, the space agency an nounced today. Donn F. Eisele, who flew aboard the first orbital mission of the Apollo command ship, will take a desk job in midJune at a National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion research center in Virginia, and John D. Hodge, who spent 10 years with the space agency.

title: Mrs. Cici Posts 79 to Lead Cross County Golf by Shot
description: JERICHO, L. I., May 26 Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, the 1962 and 1967 winner, took a onestroke lead today with 38, 4179 in the 20bh annual Women's Cross County 54hole medal play championship at the Meadow Brook Club. Par for the 5,919yard course is 36, 3672.

title: New President Chosen By Lane Bryant, Inc.
description: Arthur Malsin, executive vice president of Lane Bryant, Inc., was elected yesterday president of the diversified retailing company. Raphael Malsin, who has been the company's president since 1938, was named chairman and chief executive officer, a new post.

title: OREGON DEMOCRAT WINS 8WAY RACE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 26 State Treasurer Robert W. Straub won, an eightway fight tonight for the Democratic nomination for Governor, set ting up a rematch in Novem ber with Gov. Tom McCall, a Republican.

title: Bridge:
description: A record field of 312 play ers, including almost 50 ex perts, took part in the annual United Jewish Appeal charity event Monday night at the Essex House on Central Park South. The event produced more than $25,000 toward its objective of building a library in an Israeli border village.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Mrs. Elizabeth Sidney Is Married in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 26 In the Princeton University Chapel this afternoon, Mrs. Elizabeth Sophia Sidney, daughter of Viscount De L'Isle of Penshurst Place, Tonbridge, Kent, England, and the late Jacqueline Vis countess De L'Isle, was mar ried to Andrew H. Lane Paneyko. He is a son of Mrs. Lane Paneyko of Princeton and Mirko Paneyko of Fair field, Conn. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, dean of the chapel, performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Article 4  No Title
U.S. Reports Increased Attacks in Fishhook Region
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26 (AP)United States infan trymen were reported battling enemy forces at four points around the Cambodian town of Memot today, the third straight day Americans have reported increased enemy attacks in the Fishhook region over the bor der north of Saigon.

title: Court Gets Indictments in Troy Corruption Case
description: TROY, N. Y., May 26Ten sealed indictments resulting from a grand jury investigation into charges that officials of this Republicancontrolled city were involved in corruption were presented today to a State Supreme Court justice by the Rensselaer County District At torney.

title: Parvin Shares to Remain In Escrow, S.E.C. Agrees
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed yesterday to let 88,060 shares of the Par vinDohrmann Company stay in escrow pending the outcome of the S.E.C: s suit to block a sale of the shares to Harold Butler, president of Denny's Restau rants. Inc.

title: U.A.R. LEADER BRIEFS ALLIES IN KHARTOUM
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, May 26 (Reuters)Presiden't Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt today briefed the heads of state of the Sudan and Libya on devel opments in the Middle East at the start of their third con ference since signing a tri partite alliance.

title: New Books
description: A Cry of Crickets, by Brian Glanville (Coward  McCann, $5.95). Two women force vacillating poetnovelist to face himself.

title: TWO ARE SENTENCED IN '68 POLICE SLAYING
description: Two men convicted earlier this spring of murdering a po liceman were sentenced yes terday to prison terms of 25 years to, life by Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson.

title: New President Chosen By Holy Cross College
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 26 (AP)The Rev. John E. Brooks, 46 years old, vice president and dean of Holy Cross College, has been elected the 25th president of the college, it was announced tonight by Charles S. Horgan, chairman of the board of trustees.

title: Alberta Reath Plans Nuptials
description: DEVON, Pa., May 26  The engagement of Miss Al berta Pancoast Reath to Grant Coffin Manheim of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Manheim of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Pancoast Reath.

title: Enforceable World Laws Urged by Thant for Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26  Secretary General Thant called on all govern ments today to establish en forceable world laws, world police and world courts to preserve peace and justice. Otherwise the United Nations cannot survive, he said.

title: ROMNEY DEFENDS CAMBODIA POLICY
description: CHICAGO, May. 26George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, today asked the general assembly of the United Preshyterien Church to withhold judgment on the in vasion of Cambodia, for a few weeks.

title: F.B.I. Raids Miami Office Of Group Opposing Castro
description: MIAMI, May 26 (AP)  Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the headquarters yesterday of Al pha 66, a militantly antiCastro group, days after a Government decision that attacks on Cuba from United States territory by exiles must stop.

title: FLORIDA WEIGHING COLLEGE PROJECT
description: The chancellor of Rollins College, Hugh F. McKean, has proposed a new system of granting college degrees to those unable to attend regular classes.

title: Samuels Would Reform Legislature
description: Howard J. Samuels, a can didate for the Democratic nomi nation for Governor, called yes terday for a complete restruc turing of the Legislature and pledged that if elected he would campaign actively in future pri maries against legislators who did not support such reform.

title: Prices Resume Their Rise After Being Level in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 Wholesale prices resumed their rise in May after being level in April, the Labor Department reported today on the basis of preliminary estimates.

title: FRANULOVIC TOPS BARTH IN 3 SETS
description: PARIS, May 26 (AP)Roy Barth, America's eighthranked player, and Peaches Bartkowicz, No. 4 among the women, were eliminated today from the $100,000 French open tennis championships.

title: Airline Selects Chief Of Subsidiary Company
description: American Airlines an nounced yesterday that Jerry N. Jordan, who has served as vice presidentmarket planning and development, had been named president of its subsidiary company, Res ervations World. Mr. Jordan succeeds James N. Sowers, who resigned from the com pany.

title: 22Nation Group Suggests U.S. PayPrice Guidelines
description: PARIS, May 26An econom ic body representing 22 nations has cautiously suggested that the United States resolve its growing difficulties in combin ing high employment with price stability by installing formal wage and price guidelines.

title: Washington: The Most Inflated Commodity in America
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  Outside of baloney and the small sirloin steak, which now costs over ten dollars in the fancy joints in New York, the most inflated commodity in America today is the English language. The smaller the thoughts the bigger the words. A month ago people here were satisfied to say that the coun try was in a terrible mess, but now you can't go to a dinner party without finding some nor mally sensible character blow ing off about the collapse of the economy, the second Ameri can Revolution, or the fall of Rome.

title: 3 OBSERVERS SIGHT BRIGHT NEW COMET
description: A student in Australia, an observatory attendant in Chile and a mystery man in the In dian Ocean have discovered a new comet, bright enough to be seen without a telescope.

title: CONVICTED MARINE IS SEEKING RELEASE
description: PORTLAND, Me., May 26A former Marine Corps lance cor poral who was convicted by a courtmartial of murdering five Vietnam civilians in 1968, is trying for the third time to be released from his 20year sen tence.

title: AUTOMATION STEP PLANNED BY AMEX
description: The American Stock Exchange announced plans yesterday for a major step forward in auto mation, in which data on trans actions will be routed by com puter directly from the trading floor to the exchange's Clear ing Corporation.

title: LAIRD SAID TO ASK IF ASIA PULLOUT CAN BE ADVANCED
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is said to have asked American commanders in Viet nam whether, in light of recent operations against suspected enemy base areas in Cambodia, the United States can withdraw more troops from Vietnam by May 1, 1971 than the 150,000 announced by President Nixon last month.

title: Donna Caponi's Golf Victory Puts Her 10th in Earnings
description: ATLANTA, May 26 (AP) Donna Caponi has vaulted from 17th to 10th place on the Ladies Professional Golf Association monevwinninz list for 1970.

title: JAMES P. M'ANDREWS
