description: ADAMS, Mass., May 26 James Patrick McAndrews, a former state representative and senator, died at his home Sunday. He was 67 years old.

title: 4 Bankers Ask Congress Not to Curb Their Field
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)  Four of the country's leading bankers asked today that Congress avoid placing their industry in a legislative straitjacket. Banks need flexi bility to meet the needs of a growing and complex economy, they contended.

title: Group Favors Equal Time For Reply to Talks on War
description: The Yale University group of professors and law students, expanding on the release of their petition to the Federal Communications Commission, stressed yesterday that it did not wish to impair the right of President Nixon to use the television networks as he felt necessary in the public interest.

title: But Sales Rose 7.6%
description: Litton Industries, Inc., a di versified industrial producer on the West Coast, achieved they second highest quarterly sales in its history and a record volume for the nine months end ed April 30, the report dis closed yesterday. Earnings, however, declined 25.6 per cent in the three months ended April 30 and 12.6 per cent for the ninemonth period.

title: Tribute to Masefield Set
description: John Masefield, late Poet Lau reate of England, will be hon ored by the Poetry Society of America at a reception cele brating his 92d birthday on June 1. The reception, which will be held at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, from 5 to 7 P.M., will include readings of the poet's works, some by Mr. Masefield in re cordings, sand messages from members of his family and friends.

title: METALS FUTURES CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Metals futures continued to drop and closed irregularly yesterday with platinum fu tures sales at a record of 3,647, compared with the pre vious record of 3,264 sales achieved on Nov. 3, 1969. Trading in these futures started in 1948.

title: PITTSBURGH NEGROES GET SKILLEDJOB PLAN
description: PITTSBURGH, May 26 (UPI) A plan to put more blacks in highpaying skilled construc tion jobs has been approved by leaders of the Black Construc tion Coalition and the city con struction industry, ending a 10 month stalemate.

title: F. A. A. Says Phone Notes Show Air Controllers Planned Strike
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  The Federal Aviation Adminis tration disclosed today memo randa of telephone conversa tions by leaders of the Pro fessional Air Traffic Controllers Organization in support of the agency's contention that the or ganization's sickout last March 25 to April 15 was a concerted strike.

title: Meeting at Harlem Hospital
description: Elliott C. Roberts, the admin istrator of Harlem Hospital Cen ter, has called an open com munity meeting for tonight to discuss the implications of the new city Health and Hospitals Corporation on medical care in the community. The meeting will begin at 7:30 in the hospi tal, at Lenox Avenue and 135th Street.

title: FOUR KILLED IN CRASH OF CHARTERED PLANE
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 26 (AP)A light plane missing with five Americans aboard, in cluding an official from the University of Bridgeport and his family, crashed on a beach in British Honduras, the university reported today.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW SHARP DROP
description: Stock markets in London and in the major Continental centers slumped heavily yester day in reaction to the continued slide on Wall Street Monday. The Tokyo market made a partial recovery from the pre vious day's sharp decline.

title: Manhattan School Board Vote Draws Field of 153 Candidates
description: Amid lastminute campaign ing by candidates and nonpar tisan appeals to the public to vote, preparations were being completed yesterday for tomor row's community school board elections in Manhattan.

title: Fraudulent Issuing of Licenses Found in Jersey Motor Bureau
description: TRENTON, May 26At least 300 fraudulent licenses have been issued to unqualified drivers by a ring that involved up to six responsible mem bers of the State Motor Ve hide Division, the director of the division said today.

title: Muriel Spark Calls for New Art Forms
description: Muriel Spark, the British poet, playwright, novelist and critic, said yesterday that art and literature of sentiment and emotion, however beau tiful in itself, however strik ing in its depiction of actuali ty, has to go. She declared:

title: Times to Cost 15c; News Accepts Pact
description: The New York Times an nounced yesterday that the newsstand price of the daily newspaper would be raised to 15 cents on Monday and that advertising rates would be in creased later as a result of a wage settlement with union printers.

title: Article 5  No Title
Rubin to Speak on Coast
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 26 (AP)Jerry Rubin, the Yippie leader whose wife, Nancy, spoke for him when he was banned from the campus five weeks ago, will speak for himself Friday at the Univer sity of California at Santa Bar bara. The chancellor, Vernon Cheadle, said yesterday he would not interfere with the speech.

title: WARD W. DE GROOT
description: RED BANK, N. J., May 26 Ward W. De Groot, a former official of the Diamond Match Company of New York, died yesterday in Riverview Hospi tal of a heart attack. He was 70 years old, and lived in At lantic Highlands.

title: Some Launchers in Place For U.S. MIRV Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The Pentagon repeated today its announced intention to deploy multiple warhead missiles next month and said some missile launchers  without warheads were already in place.

title: KENTUCKY PRIMARY WON BY FOE OF WAR
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26 (UPI)State Senator Romano J. Mazzoli, 37 years old, a dove on the Vietnam war, won today the Democratic nomination for Representative from the Third District (Louisville and south ern suburbs) by a substantial margin over his hawk oppo nent, State Senator Tom Ray.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES HOME LOAN BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 The House Banking Committee approved by a vote of 32 to 1 today an emergency housing finance bill very similar to the one already passed by the Senate.

title: Benefit for U.S.O.
description: A threenight benefit for the U.S.O. of New York City will be held at the Lambs Club, 130 West 44th Street, June 4, 5 and 6. Each night 300 people will dine on filet mignon, see Woody Allen's play Don't Drink the Water, and attend an after show party. The contribution is $35 a person. Reservations may be made through U.S.O. at 2 Penn Plaza.

title: Methadone Is Found to Improve Behavior of Addicts
description: The majority of heroin ad dicts being treated under the DoleNyswander methadone procedures have stopped reg ular use of heroin, reduced or eliminated previous pat terns of antisocial behavior and have either got jobs or started school, according to an evaluation of, the program released yesterday.

title: SENATE SUPPORTS NIXON ON PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, May 26In the first vote in a prolonged Cambodia debate, the Senate made clear today that it en dorsed President Nixon's troop withdrawal plans, although it remained divided on curbing any future military involvement in Cambodia.

title: Jawboning Definition: Threat or Rational Talk
description: The word jawboning, as used by most Government officials and businessmen these days, refers to public exhortations and/or implied threats by the Administra tion as a means of convinc ing business or labor to adopt certain attitudes and policies.

title: Telltale Primaries
description: Interest in next Tuesday's continuation of the 1970 primariesa political series that has already elim inated such veteran operatives as Senator Yarbbrough of Texas on the liberal side and Governor Rhodes of Ohio on the conservativewill center in Cali fornia. That state, not conspicuous for conventional politics, presents several complicated battles, all with national implications.

title: GONZALEZ PACES U.S. OPEN TRIALS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 26 The lightest player, the 124 pound Juan Gonzalez of Do rado Beach, Puerto Rico, proved a heavyweight today in the Westchester section's United States Open qualifying round.

title: Man's Ocean Heritage
description: President Nixon's proposal to declare the ocean floor beyond the depth of 200 meters (660 feet) the com mon heritage of mankind marks a significant advance in United States policy toward a more responsible role in promoting international law, cooperation and de velopment.

title: Some Seek Landmark Unit's Protection, Others Chafe Under Its Restrictions
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission heard some serene testimony yesterday, favoring the establishment of a 22block historic district in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn.

title: Newport's Folk Festival Put Off Until Next Year
description: NEWPORT, R. I., May 26 (AP) The Newport Folk Festival, an annual event since 1959, will be postponed until 1971, accord ing to George Wein, producer pf the festivals.

title: Rain Cuts Brooklyn BMT Power, Trapping 5,000 Up to 2 Hours
description: About 5,000 subway pas sengers, some of whom had been trapped for more than two hours, had to be evacuated from powerless trains last night after a heavy downpour caused flooding that resulted in a short circuit on the Fourth Avenue BMT line in Brooklyn.

title: 4 Students Are Suspended In Clashes at Rahway High
description: RAHWAY, N. J., May 26 (AP) Four students were suspend ed today when fighting broke out between black and white pupils at the racially tense Rah way High School.

title: Owner Finds Towed Car Ended Up in Hudson
description: John Delaney of 48 East End Avenue went to the po lice yesterday to find where his black and white MG con vertible was. The answer was: at the bottom of the Hudson River.

description: FIRESUPPORT BASE SA BER, Cambodia, May 21 The Indochina war could not look meaner or messier than it does here, with tanks and men and guns in the mud.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26 Premier Rashid Karami said to night in the National Assembly that the Lebanese Government was considering calling in troops from Morocco and Tuni sia or other Arab countries to help defend Lebanon against Israel.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: GUILTY PLEA MADE BY TURNPIKE AIDE
description: The suspended general coun sel of the Pennsylvania Turn pike Commmission pleaded guilty yesterday to attempting to ex tort money from a company that was trying to settle a $1 million claim against the com mission.

title: Antiwar China Scholar
description: In 1929, when he went to Oxford as a Rhodes scholar, John King Fairbank found an old Chinese textbook and be gan to teach himself Chinese because he had heard that the Chinese Government was beginning to publish its previously untouched 19th century diplomatic archives.

description: JERUSALEM, May 26  Pre mier Golda Meir warned today that the Soviet Union's involve ment in the Middle East threat ened not only Israel's security, but also that of all the smaller nations in the world.

title: Namath, the Actor, Unsure of His Role in Pro Football
description: On a stopover here yester day between motion pictures, Joe Namath, the actor, sounded confused about his football future.

title: CLARENCE A. BARNES, REPUBLICAN LEADER
description: OAK BLUFFS, Mass., May 26 (UPI)  Clarence A. Barnes, former state attorney general and a power in the Republican Party for half a century, died yesterday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital after an illness of sev eral months. He was 87 years old.

title: Maoist Youths in Eastern India Are Bombing the Establishment
description: CALCUTTA, May 26There are many ways to make bombs, and the growing numbers of Maoist youths in West Bengal are making them by the hun dreds and using them.

title: 2 Underground Tests Held
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., May 26 (UPI)Scientists exploded two nuclear devices in underground tests today. One was an experi ment to develop an explosive for excavations and the other was a weapons test.

title: MEMPHIS COURSE IS CALLED EASY
description: MEMPHIS, May 26Golfers on the pro circuit utilized a day off from the tour today to play in the local qualifying trials for the United States Open championship.

description: WASHINGTON, May 26 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

description: WASHINGTON, May 26  The Nixon Administration, un der a barrage of criticism from, politicians and financiers, stood firmly by its economic policies today.

Spokesmen for the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said they had not yet taken action on the request.

description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminis tration has quietly demoted the man who accused some agency bureaucrats of altering labora tory conclusions that cast doubt on established F.D.A. regula tory policy.

title: JOAN TURNER PLIES MUSIC HALL STYLE
description: Joan Turner chose Carnegie Recital Hall for her American debut last night, and she prob ably shouldn't have. Even with spotlights and twin amplifiers, the formal atmosphere of the place worked against the cal culated mayhem of the British music hall star.

description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican, today intro duced President Nixon's $1.5 billion proposal to help school desegregation after the Admin istration backed down on its prohibition against busing to achieve racial balance.

title: Article 2  No Title
Flood's Side Finishes Its Inning, Baseball Gets Up to Bat Today

The trial will con tinue today in Federal Court here with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn as the first witness for the defense.

description: Generally, when agency folks gather, a favorite topic of conversation is who is los ing what to whom. These days, however, you're liable to overhear such comments as I don't ever remember it being this slow, or Not much switching.

It said the chief test pilot, Eduard Yelyan, had reached that speed at an altitude of 10 miles.

title: Quinn to Join Producer

The multi million dollar deal, it was stated, involves all the assets of Mr. Quinn's wholly owned company, the Franlor Company, including several story proper ties. Mr. Quinn will function as a producer and director of movies and television proper ties, as well as an actor.

title: Debate on Guideposts
description: The guideposts represent an intelligent gamble in an important direction. They have probably served at the very least to direct attention toward the issues involved in trying to link individual market prob lems to those of economic growth, to the efficiency of the productive system as a whole, and to the distribution of in come.John Sheahan, profes sor of economics, Williams Col lege. The guide post approach, backed by the sanction of pub lic disapprobation, probably did have some effect at first, but this decreased rapidly as time went on and inflationary pressures became more severe . . . The results of this policy were . . not only discriminatory and inequitable, but also sharply limited in terms of potential area of influence.Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Hanoi Discloses China Increases Aid for 1970
description: HONG KONG, May 27Com munist China will provide more military and economic aid to North Vietnam under an agree ment announced today.

title: Nixon Greets Suharto and Briefs Him on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 President Nixon welcomed President Suharto of Indo nesia to the White House today and told him during a 90minute conference that the joint United States South Vietnamese operation in Cambodia was a success. The two men held the first of two meetings scheduled during President Suharto's threeday stay in Washing ton. He is on a weeklong state visit to the United States. At his arrival at the White House President Su harto said that my visit comes at a time when the need for sincere and realistic efforts in the interest of peace and stability in the world, and in Southeast Asia in particular, has become ever more pressing. Speak ing in Indonesian during the welcoming ceremonies, Presi dent Suharto told Mr. Nixon through an interpreter: The restoration of peace and stabil ity in this region will require the combined endeavors of all countries in the area as well as of those external powers hav ing a responsibility; in the maintenance of world peace.

description: Judy Heumann, a 22yearold polio victim, filed suit in Fed eral District Court yesterday for the right to become the city's first teacher in a wheel chair.

Later the Governor was reported to be resting comfortably at the mansion. A spokesman said pre liminary tests indicated that the Governor's discomfort might have been caused by kidney stone. However, he said additional medical tests were scheduled.

description: It was another installment of the same story on the Ameri can Stock Exchange yesterday, as prices continued to decline, finishing at their lowest level in almost three years.

title: House Panel Passes A $650Million Bill For Anticrime Unit
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) A $650million authorization for the Law Enforcement As sistance Administration, the Federal agency designed to help local officials fight crime, was approved unanimously today by the House Judiciary Commit tee.

title: Strike of Rome Lawyers Delays Minichiello Trial

title: DR. THOMAS H. JOHNSON
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 26 Dr. Thomas H. Johnson, an ophthalmologist, died today of a heart attack. He was 91 years old and lived at 167 Nelson Road.

title: Is It in the Cards?
description: We've been lucky so far this season, said Red Schoendienst with a cheerful and reassuring smile. We haven't gotten straightened away yet but neither has any one else in our division. All the top teams Cubs, Mets, Pirates and ourselvesgot beat together.

title: Screen: A Plastic Garden:Don Johnson Portrays 'Stanley Sweetheart'
description: Stanley Sweetheart, a junior at Columbia, lost his virginity at 16, wears his hair discreetly long and has the kind of trouble with girls that a liberated Henry Aldrich might have. After a very earnest campaign, he succeeds in deflowering one of Grosse Pointe's prettiest and dimmest candidates for higher education. Later, he himself is seduced by her ravenous, overweight roommate (while starring her in an underground movie called "Masturbation"). Depending on the way you regard such things, Stanley finally hits bottom, or top, when he winds up in an East Village mnage  trois with two extremely cheerful (and flexible) Lesbians.Stanley is a role-playerbasically innocent. "The Magic Garden of Stanley Sweetheart" isn't.It peers and peeks more than any average Russ Meyer movie, and it talks dirtier than just about any commercial movie that I can remember. Its camera swings and there is a lot of rock music on the soundtrack. However, like so many other places of expensive, modish, retail merchandise, it remains calculatingly bland, with no more wit or point of view than "Search for Tomorrow," although it occasionally takes a reproving, almost motherly look at the dirty dishes, the piled-up garbage and empty beer cans that litter Stanley's apartment.The film, which opened yesterday at the Paris Theater, was adapted for the screen by Robert T. Westbrook from his own quite funny, reportedly semi-autobiographical novel. Although the novel was not specifically dated in time, it was apparently meant to be more or less contemporary.The novel's Stanley is not a political animal (the book makes no attempt to cover the Columbia riots of 1968), but its Stanley is facing Vietnam and, in one of Stanley's nicest, Mittyesque moments, he commits himself to non-commitment by tearing up his draft card and sending it off to his draft board with a letter that starts: "I've been watching your ugly, stupid viciousness on TV for long enough. . . ."In spite of the fact that the movie's Stanley goes to the real-life Columbia (the film was photographed entirely in New York), there is no draft and no Vietnam. There is only a terrible feeling of dj vu about the life styles it does cover. Underground movies were funny about seven or eight years ago, and Don Johnson plays Stanley as if he were imitating Marlon Brando, who was imitable 20 years ago. Stanley's encounters with women seem not to be patterned on life as much as on movies like "Finders Keepers, Lovers Weepers." Women rampant leave him exhausted, and exhaustion, more than anything else, is the basis of his sentimental education.Of the women in the film, two are memorable: Dianne Hull, who manages to act the role of a sweet, dull girl without ever being dull, and Holly Near, who plays a big fat girl with the unfinished facial features of an irritable 6-year-old and the sexual hungers of Catherine of Russia. The film is the first theatrical feature directed by Leonard Horn, who comes from television where, among other things, he directed segments of "Mannix" and "Mission: Impossible." He's been a bad boy and someone should take away his zoom lens.

title: Retailer's Volume Gains
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., the largest retailer in New York and one of the country's lead ing departmentstore chains, re ported yesterday its biggest decline in earnings for a fiscal quarter in at least 30 years.

title: Mrs. Onassis Brushes Aside Reports of a Marital Rift
description: ATHENS, May 26  Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis brushed aside today rumors of strain in her marriage with the Greek shipowner.

title: Hospital Costs in 1980 Seen At$1.000aDay in Big Cities
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) Estimates have been made by experts that hospital costs in 1980 will reach $1,000 a day in major urban centers, Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, said today.

title: OUSTED PRINCIPAL CHARGES RACISM
description: William B. King, former act ing principal of Junior High School 120 in Harlem, charged yesterday that he was dismissed May 14 without due process, a victim of an effort to rid the public school system of black principals.

title: Dance: Swan Lake by Royal Ballet
description: Vice can as easily be taken for granted as virtue. The fact is the despair of moral ists the world over. Now that we have become so accus tomed to the glaring faults and more marginal infelici ties of the Royal Ballet's current production of Tchai kovsky's Swan Lake, there is a temptation to take them in our stride. It is, like few temptations, one to be re sisted.

description: When schoolage children paint and draw, they often reflect in their work some of their interests, their sur roundings or their culture, for by the time a child be comes 8 or 9 or 10, he begins to be concerned with repro ducing the reality he sees.

Included were fringe benefits, such as den talcare coverage, scholarships for workers and a drugaddic tion rehabilitation program.

He retired from the Reserve post on Feb. 1 after serving in it since 1951. Mr. Martin had been president of the New York Stock Exchange from 1938 to 1941.

A Harvard professor of the humanities complained that it simply wasn't true that scientists (in my experience) know more about literature than humanists know about science. A Harvard professor at the Medical School said that nobody in the field really worried about the moral consequences of genetic engineering except the two young ingrates who recently isolated a single gene. A Columbia molecular biologist of

title: Convict to Represent Himself
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26 (UPI)  Robert K. Beausoleil, con demned to death for the knife murder of Gary Hinman, a bagpipe musician, was granted permission today to act as his own attorney in seeking a new trial after he presented an affidavit contending that a key prosecution witness lied. Judge William B. Keene of Superior Court put off formal sentencing and gave Beausoleil until June 9 to bring in new evidence.

title: Power Cut Off in Queens
description: Failure in a feeder cable from the Alley Park substation of Consolidated Edison cut off power to 1,880 customers in Queens yesterday at 8:40 A.M. Power was restored to 500 of the customers at 10:15 A.M., to 1,080 more at 11:30, and to the remainder at 2:20 P.M. The area affected was bounded by 56th and 69th Avenues and by 218th and 224th Streets in Bay side.

title: Isolating Apartheid
description: The international sports community is proving more effective than the international political com munity in letting the Republic of South Africa know that its policy of racial separatism is repugnant and rejected by the outside world. There are new indica tions that the message is getting across to the average South African through the back door of sports. It would be ironic if a tennis racket and rugby ball achieved more change from within than the moral assaults upon the Pretoria Government.

title: Marine Gets 21 Years
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 26 (AP)  Marine Pfc. Mi chael Galloway, 20 years old, of Kansas City, was sentenced yes terday to 21 years in Federal prison after being convicted of unpremeditated murder. A gen eral courtmartial found him guilty last week in the shooting of Pvt. Steven Woolfolk, 19, of Robbins, Ill.

title: Article 1  No Title
Disaster Loan Rule Altered
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) The Small Business Adminis tration today announced an in crease from $1,000 to $2,500 in the amount of disaster repair loans it would make without requiring the borrower to put up collateral. Loans above the ceiling may be secured by lien on the property to be re paired or by other collateral.

title: Mrs. Krakower Rewed
description: Mrs. Nana Robles Kra kower of New York, widow of Arnold R. Krakower, the lawyer, was married here last evening to George A. Gozan, a widower, also of New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the cere mony at the bridegroom's home. Mr. Gozan is secretary of Plaza Mills, Inc., a director of Ramer Industries, Inc., and secretary and a director of the First Republic Cor poration of America.

title: Poverty Train Being Designed For West Virginia Coal Region
description: WASHINGTON, May 25An antipoverty railway is being designed with Federal funds to bring social services to thou sands of poor families in West Virginia's remote coal mining country.

title: Trainer of Dust Commander Resigns
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., May 26 (UPI)Don Combs said today he had resigned as trainer of dust Commander, the recent Kentucky Derby winner, be cause his owner, Robert E. Leh mann, didn't seem to trust my judgment.

title: Drew Plans CoEd Living
description: MADISON, N. J., May 26 (AP) Drew University has an nounced that it will open a co educational dormitory next fall. The dormitory, only one of 12 on campus, will replace the present openhouse arrange ment that permits visiting be tween noon and midnight.

title: BOND PRICES DROP IN SPOTTY TRADING
description: Bond prices tumbled broadly to record lows again yesterday with no sign of any outside development that, could reverse the market's course and revive its confidence on the horizon.

title: HOUSE TIGHTENS ITS ETHICS CODE
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 Two relatively modest pro posals to tighten its code of ethics were approved today by the House of Representatives after an hour of explanatory speeches but no debate.

title: Mayor Seeks Added $5Million To Give Youths Jobs in Summer
description: Mayor Seeks Added $5Million To Give Youths Jobs in Summer Citing a new ingredient in the coming summer's tensions a faltering economy with fewer jobs available  Mayor Lindsay asked yesterday for an additional $5million for the city's Federally financed Neigh borhood Youth Corps program.

title: Noise Control Tests Set By the F.A.A. at Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Representative Joseph P. Ad dabbo, Democrat of Queens, an nounced today the Federal Avi ation Administration would conduct noise control tests for la fourmonth period at Kennedy Airport in order to reduce jet aircraft noise in the surround ing communities.

title: 66 BLACKS TO BE PAID FOR POLICE DAMAGE
description: NEWARK, May 26Federal District Court Judge Lawrence A. Whipple formally approved an outofcourt settlement to day to compensate 66 black persons whose homes were entered in a mass search for weapons during the Plainfield riot of July, 1967.

title: Hesburgh Delivers a Plea In Defense of Nation's Youth
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hes burgh, president of the Univer sity of Notre Dame, delivered a plea in defense of the younger generation last night and said that the conscience of America today is coming from its youth.

title: Movies Leaving Hollywood Behind
description: LOS ANGELES  Holly woodthe old studio system is dead, but movies as a medium have never been more alive.

title: A Tireless Worker
description: It was a wonder that Wilbur Daniel Steele wrote. To hear him tell it, it was an awful process.

title: DR. RONALD FERRY
description: CONCORD, Mass., May 26 Dr. Ronald M. Ferry, a former associate professor at Harvard University and the first master of the institution's Winthrop House, died at his home here this morning. He was 78 years old.

title: ExU.S. Rights Aide Given City Post
description: Leon E. Panetta, who was forced out as director of the Federal Office of Civil Rights after accusing the Nixon Ad ministration of softening its stand on equal rights, was ap pointed an executive assistant to Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: PUDDLEJUMPERS AMONG PROBLEMS
description: Jockeys may be the brightly plumaged peacocks of the sports world, but they have eyes like hawks when it comes to sizing up a muddy track.

title: National Gallery Elects
description: Kennedy C. Watkins has been elected secretary of the National Gallery of Art in Washington. He had been dep uty secretary since 1965.

title: New Scuba Diving Record
description: GREAT LAMESHUR BAY, V. I., May 26 (AP)One of America's aquanauts, Charles Evans Berkeland of the Univer sity of Washington, set a scuba diving record in the Tektike maninthesea program here yesterday. He was out of the habitat, 50 feet below the sur face, for 10 hours and 14 min utes, studying effects of preda tory fish on marine life of coral reefs.

title: MRS. GLENN FARMER
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 26 Mrs. Marjorie D. Farmer, a for mer state legislator, died last Thursday in Phoenix, Ariz. She was 72 years old. She and her husband, Glenn Farmer, lived in Old Saybrook.

title: EASTERN LEAGUE
description: MONDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Most Indonesians Welcome Stability Under Suharto
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 Peace and stability have settled over this archipelago na tion of some 120 million people.

title: Parkway Link to Reopen
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., May 26 (UPI)  The East Hudson Parkway Authority announced today that a section of the Saw Mill River Parkway near the Yonkers water treatment plant, closed for repairs since May 20, was scheduled to reopen Thurs day.

title: Nixon Meets Heads Of 2 City Unions; Hails War Support
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  President Nixon told leaders of the building trades and long shoremen's unions of New York today that he had found their public demonstrations of sup port for his Vietnam policy reassuring and very meaning ful.

title: Time to React
description: The fall of the stock market has reached alarming proportions. Quite apart from the precipitous drop in socalled glamour stocks or conglomerates whose prices had been bid up to ridiculous levels, there have been steep declines in the value of solid com panies beyond anything experienced in the postwar years.

title: Three Institutions to Benefit At Belmont Ball Set for June 5
description: ELMONT, L. L, May 26 Proceeds from the Belmont Ball, to be held at the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park here on June 5, will go to the National Museum of Racing, the Saratoga Per forming Arts Center and Skidmore College.

title: Social Security Aide Resigns With Attack on Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)  The chief actuary of the So cial Security Administration has resigned after charging that Democrats in the agency have attempted to undermine the Nixon Administration.

title: City College Dean Leaving
description: William Allan, the dean of the City College School of En gineering since 1947, will re tire Sept. 1, the college an nounced yesterday. Dr. Josep J. Copeland, the acting presi dent, named Prof. Alois X. Schmidt as acting dean of the 2,350student school.

title: SOVIET CAR STONED ALONG RACE ROUTE
description: LONDON, May 26 (AP)  Armed police in El Salvador broke up a mob that stoned Soviet car in the World Cup auto rally after the automo bile's windscreen was smashed by a rock, organizers here said yesterday.

title: From Hot Dogs to Haute Cuisine, the Tab for Dining Out Grows
description: Restaurant eating is going the way of other regular luxuries for many New Yorkersby the boards. The soaring cost of eating out one of the most popular topics of current conver sation  has just been con firmed by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. One of the fastest rising ele ments in the Consumer Price Index is the price of res taurant meals, up 13.2 per cent during the last year.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) The following servicemen from the New York area were identified by the Defense De partment today as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: Calling Manhattan Voters
description: Manhattan residents tomorrow have a special op portunity to help improve public education by voting in the delayed community school board election. In each of the borough's six districts, the voters will elect nine candidates.

title: Environmental Agency Has Too Much Work to Go Crusading
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The new agency President Nixon described as the environ mental conscience of the na tion is finding that the con science business is complicated.

title: Major League Baseball
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: A Correction
description: David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, believes that the halfpoint re duction in the prime, or mini mum lending rate of major com mercial banks to 8 per cent last March was a mistake. The transcription of some of Mr. Rockefeller's taperecorded re marks in yesterday's editions of The New York Times inadvert ently gave the opposite impres sion.

title: Greeks on Albanian Line Feel No Thaw
description: IEROPIYI, Greece, May 24 Townspeople and soldiers in this sheepherding village of stone houses on Greece's des olate and mountainous border with Albania find it hard to believe that relations between the two countries are thawing.

title: 300 Cambridge Pupils To Tutor Their Peers
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26 (AP)About 300 young sters in the Cambridge school system  from first through twelfth graderswill be paid $10 a week this summer as tutors.

title: Thurmond Backs Attorney
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) Senator Strom Thurmond, Re publican of South Carolina, said today that he was recom mending Joseph O. Rogers Jr., United States Attorney for South Carolina, to be the new Federal district judge in that state.

title: In Memoriam
description: HUGHESJames H. A man amongst men. No task was too large or small for him to engage in to help his fellowman. He went to extremes to see that the downtrodden and disheartened received Justice, coming to their aid In his quiet manner and distinguished way. The extraordinary mo ments and the happy sense of our many long years of marriage still remain with me. What wonders Our Dear Saviour has wrought in our behalf by honoring us thusly.

title: Experts Ask That National Records Be Kept on Cancer
description: HOUSTON, May 27  Three New York State health experts proposed today that cancer be reported nationally through tu mor registries in each state.

title: ExPoverty Official Jailed 2 to 7 Years For $400,000 Theft
description: Coy D. Smith, onetime chief fiscal officer of the Neighbor hood Youth Corps, was sen tenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to two and a third to seven years in prison for the 1968 theft of nearly $400,000 in Youth Corps paychecks.

title: Nuclear Site Is Purchased By Commonwealth Edison
description: CHICAGO, May 27 (AP)The Commonwealth Edison Com pany announced today that it had contracted for turbine gen erators and was acquiring land for a nuclear power station near Seneca. Ill.

title: Dance: The Royal Ballet's Treasures
description: The Royal Ballet has had three great influences on its life. First, foremost and ob vious is Dame Ninette de Valois, who founded the com pany in 1931. Second, equally obvious, is Sir Frederick Ash ton, who not only has been the company's principal choreographer for all those years, but also has made his concept of the classic style the very touchstone of British ballet style.

title: Apollo 13 Blast Laid to Damage Before Launching
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 Space agency investigators re ported tonight that the oxygen tank that exploded aboard the moonbound Apollo 13 prob ably had been damaged dur ing launching pad operations just prior to blastoff.

title: Aide Hints a Veto by Nixon If War Curb Is Too Severe
description: WASHINGTON, May 27An official of the Nixon Adminis tration raised the threat today that the President would veto any measure on Cambodia en acted by Congress that re stricted his constitutional powers as Commander in Chief.

title: Foe of Status Quo
description: FROM the beginning of his career, the Rev. Leo low den McLaughlin has been at tracted to controversy and, the way he looks at it, the excitement of new ideas. A fellow classmate at the Jesuitrun Loyola Prepara tory School in New York City, where Father McLaugh lin received his primary and sec ondary education, once recalled that he was always getting thrown out of the room for doing or saying something danger ous.

title: Brazilian Bishops Ask Social Reform And an Opposition
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 27 The bishops of Brazil, meeting in Brasilia, the capital, today urged the Government to carry out social reforms, give more voice to the opposition and in vestigate reports of the torture of prisoners.

title: Lopez to Fight Torro June 11
description: LOS ANGELES, May 27 (UPI), Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez, knocked out in the 15th round in a bid for the welterweight championship in February, agree today to meet Pete Torro of New York in a 10round fight at the Olympic Auditor ium June 11.

title: Books of The Times
description: Let's float a generalization and see who shoots it down. With the exception of Henry James, I can't think of a major American male novelist who has been able to write convincingly from the point of view of a woman...not even Gore Vidal. (For that matter, I have my doubts

title: Major League Baseball
description: Thursday, May 28, 1970

title: OSCAR MYERS
description: Oscar Myers, a systemsplan ning director of the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died yesterday after heart surgery at the New York University Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived at 190 East 72d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Liberal Party Backing in Democratic Primary

title: Gimbel Brothers, Inc.
description: Bruce A. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., told shareholders at yesterday's an nual meeting that the sales trend continues at about the same pace as in the first fiscal quarter, ended April 30. That period's volume, as announced, Monday, was $153.8million, up from $150million a year earlier when there were five fewer stores.

title: KENNETH JUDSON, 75, COMMODITY BROKER
description: Kenneth G. Judson, a com modity broker, whose family was among the founders of Forest Hills Gardens in Queens, died yesterday at his home, 61 Olive Place, in Forest Hills. He was 75 years old.

title: Method to Dispose of Oil Spills Tested
description: Shell Oil Company has come up with a new method to dispose of large oil spills at sea.

title: KING'S I.0.S. MOVE BLOCKED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  The Securities and Exchange Commission turned down today a request by John M. King that it permit him to assume control of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., without having the com mission's order that bars most I.O.S. operations in the United States, automatically extended to other companies controlled by Mr. King.

title: G.O.P. SUMMONS 2 IN OHIO SCANDAL
description: COLUMBUS, May 27The Republican State Central Com mittee of Ohio called upon the party's nominees for Attorney General and treasurer today to appear before it on June 4 to explain their role in a scan dal that has enveloped party officials.

title: New Books.
description: GENERAL

title: Personal Finance
description: Spring may be busting out all over, but the dismal economic weather over Wall Street has turned quite a few budding securities into weeds for the small investors who own them.

title: FORD SEES OUTPUT CLIMBING IN JUNE
description: DETROIT, May 27  The Ford Motor Company said today it would be closer to full pro duction at its United States plants in June than in any ether month this year.

title: ExJudge DeVita Gets 1 to 2 Years
description: NEWARK, May 27Former Union County District Court Judge Ralph DeVita was sen tenced today to one to two years in State Prison on his conviction last month of ob structing justice.

title: Transfer of Arms Authorized
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 State Department officials dis closed today that the South Vietnamese and Thai Govern ments were empowered to turn over to the Cambodian Army military equipment that had been supplied by the Unit ed States.

title: Sargent's Veto Sustained
description: BOSTON, May 27 (AP)The Massachuetts House sustained today Gov. Francis W. Sar gent's veto of a bill that would have granted pay rises to po lice and fire chiefs in the state.

title: Sports of
description: Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State says that any college that wants to protect their athletes need only require them to progress normally, semester by semester, so they may be graduated with their classmates. Paterno may be slightly smug on the subject. He gave 21 football scholar ships four years ago; 17 of the recipients stayed to become seniors and all but two will be graduated with their class. Of eight players drafted by the pros from Penn State this year, only one will go to training camp without his under graduate degree. Paterno's score is very high. A sam pling of 124 of the 442 drafted players disclosed that only 53 per cent would go to training camp with degrees, and many took five years to get them. Many college coaches are report edly concerned lest the spreading political aware ness affect their athletes, especially around election time next fall when they will be in the midst of their schedules. It would seem that coaches should be less concerned about their play ers' campaigning for candi dates and more concerned that they might form a un ion and strike for higher wages.

title: But Suppose He'd Listened to His Wife
description: Sergio Asti's wife wanted him to design a baby's feed ing dish. But his manufac turer wanted him to devise a desk accessory for paper clips, pencils and note paper. What resulted was a desk organizer that looks like an outsized baby's feeding dish.

title: Maureen Cain Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry V. Bogack have made known the engagement of Mrs. Bo gack's daughter, Miss Mau reen Ann Cain, to Andrew J. Grieco, son of State Assem blyman Salvatore J. Grieco and Mrs. Grieco. Both fami lies live in Brooklyn.

title: Spain Presses for U.S. Commitment on Security
description: MADRID, May 27  United States reluctance to give Spain even a vaguely worded security commitment appears to be the principal difficulty facing a new agreement on American bases, according to qualified sources here.

title: Foreign Ministers' Pact
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27The foreign ministers of South Vietnam and Cam bodia signed documents here today giving South Vietnam a broad and openended mandate for military operations in Cam bodia.

title: GOLDBERG AIDING BOSTON CANDIDATE
description: Arthur J. Goldberg took time out yesterday from his own campaign yesterday to aid an antiwar Roman Catholic priest in Bosfon in his bid to take the Democratic nomination away from an incumbent Con gressman generally favorable to President Nixon's policies on Vietnam.

title: CEAUSESCU AFFIRMS RUMANIA'S POLICIES
description: VIENNA, May 27Nicolae Ceausescu, Rumania's President and party chief, indicated yes terday that his policy of inde pendence within the Warsaw bloc remained unchanged in spite of his visit to Moscow a week ago.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Elaine L. Berol, Scott B. Taylor To Wed Sept. 16
description: Miss Elaine Lois Berol, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Berol of New York and Waynesboro, Ga., plans to be married on Sept. 16 to Scott Bevan Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Palm er Taylor of Darien, Conn., and Pompano Beach. Fla.

title: Action Needed on Rents
description: Organized landlords and tenants have had their say on Mayor Lindsay's rent plan, and have made no use ful contribution whatever. Emotionalism all but pushed reason out of the City Hall hearings, giving the City Council's Housing Committee little help in revising the Lindsay proposals for overhaul of the World War II rent control law.

title: MRS. LUDWIG LUSTIG
description: Mrs. Else Lustig, who for many years was active in the field of concert management and as an artists' representa tive in New York, died May 7 in Baden Baden, Germany. Her age was 69.

title: Spot Ads on Radio Will Underline Subtle Racism
description: A trio of awardwinning radio spot announcements underlin ing some subtle manifestations of white racism will, be offered for broadcast nationally next month under the auspices of the Episcopal Church.

title: Hickel Urges a Plan to Convert Alcatraz Into a National Park
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 The Department of Interior asked today for title to Alca traz Island and said that the former prison in San Francisco Bay would be converted into a national park.

title: John F. Driscoll Jr. Is Engaged To Mary Randolph Emerson
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 27Mr. and Mrs. George Waldo Emerson of Northamp ton and of Newport, R. I., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Mary Randolph Emerson, to John Francis Driscoll Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Driscoll of Holyoke. The wedding is planned for Aug. 22 in New port.

title: Roundup: Homers Count, Some of Them Sheepishly
description: It would not be too far fetched to think that when Woody Fryman and the Mont real Expos went to bed last night, they fell asleep count ing home runs.

title: Griffon's Owner Points Proudly
description: If you see a man walking a wirehaired pointing griffon around 51st Stret and First Avenue, the man most likely will be Bernard Cooper, pres ident of Cove Advertising, Inc., and his charge a strong looking, shaggy dog named Griff. The neighborhood is where they live.

title: The New York Times
description: The board of directors of The New York Times Company yesterday declared the regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on the Class A and Class B common stock, payable June 26 to stockholders of rec ord of June 12.

title: BIPARTISAN GROUP BACKS POLICY CURBS
description: Fifty members of the Young Republican and Young Demo cratic Cubs of New York City voted last night at a joint meet ing here to support two Senate bills aimed at ending American involvement in Southeast Asia.

title: ABRAHAM MARKHOFF
description: Abraham Markhoff, a special ist in workmen's compensation law, a partner in the law firm of Markoff, Gottlieb, Lazarus & D'Auria, 401 Broadway, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hos pital. He was 61 years old and lived at 255 Pennsylvania Avenue. Mount Vernon, N. Y.

title: LABOR AND TORIES OFFER PLATFORMS
description: LONDON, May 27  Britain today moved toward the of ficial opening of her election campaign this weekend with the publication of Labor party and Conservative party plat forms, both built on promises and compassion for all and deri sion for each other.

title: Court Dismisses Charges Against DrugRaid Suspect
description: Charges were dropped yes terday against Harold Prezzano, a 24yearold graduate of New York University who was ar rested last week in an apart ment where large quantities of drugs were allegedly being supplied to Columbia Univer sity students.

title: Shriver Urged to Help Democrats' Fall Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 Friends of Sargent Shriver are trying to persuade him to accept a new national role as campaign speaker and fund raiser for the election of liberal antiwar Democrats to Congress He was said to be undecided.

title: 2d Patrolman Suspended In MoneyFinding Case
description: Patrolman Louis A. D'Alessio of the Tactical Patrol Force was suspended without pay yes terday pending trial after being accused of failing to report the receipt of a quantity of money last Saturday night.

title: Lonesome River and Royal Tom Gain Victories at Belmont
description: Lonesome River, with Bobby Woodhouse riding, and Royal Tom, guided by Braulio Baeza, shared honors in the main ac tivity at Belmont Park yester day. Each won a section of the feature presentation of a mile and a sixteenth, Lonesome River by five lengths and Royal Tom by a neck.

title: Cotton Accord Is Extended
description: GENEVA, May 27Major im porting and exporting nations agreed today to extend for three more years a pact regu lating international trade in cotton textiles.

title: JOHNSON STARTS DEMOCRATS' DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  The Democratic party, pleading a lack of funds but not of issues, started its 1970 Con gressional campaign tonight with a $500aplate dinner, starring former President Lyn don B. Johnson.

title: Grey Now Organizing Ethical Drug Division
description: Grey Advertising confirmed yesterday that it, too, was in the process of setting up an ethical drug advertising division.

title: Laver, Ralston Advance In St. Louis Pro Tennis
description: ST. LOUIS, May 27 (UPI) Rod Laver of Australia and Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., gained the quarterfinals tonight in the $30,000 Rawlings professional tennis tournament at the Dwight Davis Tennis Center.

title: PHOSPHATES UNUSED IN SOME DETERGENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 27Ex tensive use of a new compound in detergents to replace phos phate, which has been criti cized as a water pollutant, was reported today at a Senate hearing.

title: Batter Up in Court
description: In a landmark case in 1922, Federal Club vs. National League, the United States Supreme Court said that baseball was not engaged in interstate commerce and therefore not subject to the antitrust laws. That same year in Babbitt, Sinclair Lewis wrote about things of eternal importance like baseball or the Republican party.

title: BABCOCK & WILCOX REDUCES DIVIDEND
description: Directors of the Babcock & Wilcox Co. voted yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend to 12 cents a share from 34 cents, which had been paid quarterly since 1967.

title: Arrests of Youths Who Use Narcotics Doubled Since '67
description: The number of young people arrested in 1969 for crimes prompted by drug use was more than double the 1967 figure, a police study revealed yesterday.

title: Friends Academy Benefit
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 27An exhibition and sale of lithographs and art posters by artists including Miro, Giocometti, Calder, ToulouseLautrec and Lger will be held from June 5 through 14 at the Learning Center Gallery of Friends Academy here. Proceeds will help raise additional endow ment for the school.

title: NEW UNREST JOLTS WASHINGTON HIGH
description: New student disorders broke out yesterday at George Wash ington High School as union teachers refused to take build ingpatrol assignments and to perform certain other duties. They were protesting the Board of Education's recent reinstatement of two students accused of taking part in earlier disturbances at the school.

title: Airline Strike Ended
description: MIAMI, May 27 (UPI)Na tional Airlines resumed partial operations today following a 116day strikelongest in the history of commercial flight by the Air Line Employes Asso ciation. National's first sched uled passenger flighta DC8 left Miami's International Airport shortly after midnight bound for Los Angeles.

title: G. O. P. CHAIRMAN INDICTED UPSTATE
description: TROY, N. Y., May 27The Rensselaer County Republican chairman and three others were indicted today on felony charges resulting from a year long investigation of govern ment and politics here.

title: Presbyterians Will Seek $70Million to Help Poor
description: CHICAGO, May 27  The general assembly of the 3.2 millionmember United Presby terian Church overwhelmingly approved today a campaign to raise more than $70million to be used its depressed areas and among deprived people.

title: Thieu Sees Indefinite Stay
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27South Vietnamese troops will continue to operate in Cambodia for an indefinite period after United States units are withdrawn and will require continued American logistical and combat support to sustain those operations, President Nguyen Van Thieu has de clared.

title: TECHNICAL GAIN
description: Technical reasons were cited yesterday by Wall Street analysts for the biggest one day gain in the history of the DowJones industrial average. This means that the stock surge happened for no fundamental reasons at all.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: HEARING ORDERED ON PRIMARY BALLOT
description: The Appellate Division yes terday ordered a hearing for June 4 on a charge by 53 Dem ocratic primary candidates for Federal, state and local office that a section of the new elec tion law assuring incumbents first place on the ballot was illegal.

title: Minor Leagues
description: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE

title: NATO ASKS TALKS WITH SOVIET BLOC ON CUT IN TROOPS
description: ROME, May 27Fifteen For eign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization tonight invited the Soviet Union, the Warsaw pact powers and other interested govern ments to explore mutual and, balanced reduction of forces in Central Eurone.

title: A Leftist Coalition Is Winning Big Victory in Ceylon Election
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Thurs day, May 28 (AP)  Former Prime Minister Sirima Bandara naike's Communistbacked coa lition headed today toward a landslide victory in yesterday's parliamentary elections.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW AN ADVANCE
description: Soybean futures prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board Trade, with the July contract advancing 2 cents a bushel in the early trading before los ing some of the gain near the close.

title: U.S. Envoy to Sweden Is Praised Amid Epithets
description: STOCKHOLM, May 27The new United States Ambassador to Sweden, Dr. Jerome H. Hol land, is winning applause here for his spirited efforts to repair SwedishAmerican relations de spite the eggs and epithets hurled against him by youthful eictremists.

title: I.S. Relaxing Curbs On Exports of Nickel
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Commerce De partment loosened its restric tions on exports of nickel today because of the further improvement in the nickel supply and demand situa tion.

title: Mrs. Dempsey's 83 for 163 Leads CrossCounty by Shot
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 27Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Piping Rock carded 38, 4583 in the second round for a total of 163 to gain a onestroke lead in the 20th Women's Cross County Golf Association 54hole medalplay championship at the Cedar Brook Country. Club to day. Par for the 5,975yard lay out is 37, 3875.

title: Firestone Profits Fall as Sales Rise
description: The Firestone Tire and Rub ber Company reported yester day that profits fell while sales rose in the fiscal quarter and six months ended April 30.

title: Hopeful Decision in Beirut
description: If the Lebanese Government sticks to its decision to curb guerrilla activity on its southern borderand can make the decision stickthere is still some hope for restoring a degree of stability to what had been Israel's most quiet frontier.

title: Kinney National Files Suit For Libel Against Forbes
description: Kinney National Service, Inc., announced yesterday that it has filed a $50million libel suit against Forbes, Inc., and three executives of Forbes in New York State Supreme Court.

title: Ottinger and Sorensen Support Sale of U. S. Warplanes to Israel
description: The prompt sale of United States jet planes to Israel was urged yesterday by two of the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senator.

title: Benton & Bowles Gets Klooman Mills Account
description: After about six months with Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, Klopman Mills is taking its knitting to Benton & Bowles The account bills about $1million.

title: Soviet's Reserve Goalie Warms Up for World Cup
description: MEXICO CITY, May 27 As the Soviet Union's soccer team prepares to meet Mex ico in the opening game of the World Cup tournament on Sunday, Lev Yashin prac tices guarding the goal as the probable substitute for Yevgeny Rudakov, the first string goalie. Rudakov broke his left clavicle in an exhibi tion in Bogota, Columbia, against Millonarios, May 13.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON LONDON BOARD
Financier Rejoins General Dynamics
description: FORT WORTH, May 27 Shareholders of the General Dynamics Corporation, a major defense contractor, met quietly here today in an atmosphere of rigid security.

title: FUND FOR THE SST IS VOTED IN MUSE BY A SLIM MARGIN
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  The House narrowly defeated today the first concerted effort against the supersonic trans port, approving a $290million appropriation to extend the development of two prototype aircraft. The rollcall vote, against a motion to consider a complete halt in SST spend ing, was 176 to 163.

title: Russians Stream To New Romeo
description: MOSCOW, May 27  A sense of gloom and despair hangs over Anatoly Efros's unusual production of Shake speare's Romeo and Juliet, which has quickly become the theatrical sensation of an otherwise mediocre season.

title: TEMPERED YANKEE DRAWS NO. 8 POST
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 27 Tempered Yankee, on the strength of his 1970 record (five victories in seven out ings, including his last four straight, was made the 2to1 favorite today to capture Sat urday night's ninth annual Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Dioguardi Conviction Upheld In Bankruptcy Fraud Case
description: The 1967 convictions of John (Johnny Dio) Dioguardi, a re puted Mafia member, and two other men on bankruptcyfraud charges were upheld here yes terday by the Federal Court of Appeals.

title: Tuesday Night Fights
description: Miami BeachFrankie Otero, 130 pounds, Hialeah, Fla., out pointed Casto Ramirez, 129, San Juan. P. R.. 10 rounds.

title: Baseball Draft Here June 4
description: Baseball's annual draft meet ings will be held here June and 5.

title: Mayor Cites Slump Impact
description: Mayor Lindsay, in Washing ton yesterday for the swearing in of Noel H. Klores as director of New York's City's office there, said that the city was beginning to feel the impact of the squeeze in the economy and was being very seriously hurt by inflation. He said also that further declines in the economy could have an adverse effect on the city's tax rev enues.

title: TV:StudentsScanNews
description: One of television's unre searched questions is how college students respond to news coverage by the net works. Last night's edition of All About TV, seen on WNYCTV (Channel 31) found the host, Steven H. Soheuer, hardpressed to elicit spe cific examples of complaint. Such viewpoints as were ex pressed had a genuine inter est, and conceivably could be an omen of further media criticism by the young.

title: BUSING IS LIMITED IN SOUTHERN CASE
description: RICHMOND, May 27In a 4to2 decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit ruled today that not every school within a dis trict must be integrated in order to Meet the Supreme Court's demand for a unitary, nonracial system.

title: ALASKA WILL ACT ON PIPELINE ROAD
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 The Alaska legislature is ex pected to vote tomorrow on a $120million appropriation bill to finance state construction of a 390mile pipeline access road from the Yukon River to Prud hoe Bay on the Arctic north slope.

title: Chiefs Out at Host And Data General
description: The resignation or two top executives in widely divergent businesses was announced yesterday.

title: Pakistani to Visit Peking
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 27 Air Marshal Rahim Khan, commander in chief of Paki stan's Air Force, will pay a week's goodwill visit to Peking beginning May 30, it was an nounced today. He is going at the invitation of Wa Fahsien, commander of the Chinese Air Force.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President had a morning meeting with his economic advisersTreas ury Secretary Kennedy; Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Ad visers; Dr. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Budget Director Mayo. The President had a private meeting with former Presi dent Johnson. He gave a lunch for Speaker McCor mack and in the evening was host at dinner for leading business and financial leaders.

title: Leading Democrats Oppose Lindsay's Rent Plan
description: An array or Democrats, most of whom had supported Mayor Lindsay for reelection, gath ered on the steps of City Hall yesterday to attack Mr. Lind say's proposal for revising rent control as illconceived and fashioned in haste. They urged the Democraticcon trolled City Council to reject the Mayor's recommendations.

title: Warren De Motte, Wrote Recorded Music Guides
description: Warren De Motte, an author, editor and music critic, died at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan Tuesday after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 26 Perry Street.

title: Neighborhoods: West Side Is Undergoing Renaissance
description: Skyscraper skeletons of luxury, apartment houses are rising over Lincoln Center and Sherman Square. In the West Sixties and Seventies, sleazy rooming houses are becoming posh apartments.

title: Army Denies Developing Poison Dart Gun in Secret
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI)The Army denied today a statement attributed to Rep resentative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of New York, that it had developed a secret poison dart guntype weapon.

title: Rock of Ages
description: Did the Apollo 12 astronauts bring back the Rosetta Stone of space? Any such conclusion is still prema ture, but a surge of excitement has gone through the world's scientific community with the announcement that rock 13 found on the moon's Ocean of Storms is as old as the solar system: 4.6 billion years. Put another way, rock 13 is the oldest rock known to be indigenous to either the earth or the moon, roughly a full billion years older than any known terrestrial or lunar rock hitherto studied.

title: TEENAGERS FACE SCARCITY OF JOBS
description: About 140,000 more teen agers will be seeking jobs this summer in the New York met ropolitan area, beyond the 240, 000 youths aged 16 through 19 employed this spring, the Fed eral Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated yesterday.

title: 3 Former Addicts Tell Bronx Students of Horrors of Narcotics
description: About 500 eighth graders in a Bronx junior high school that has been beset by drug prob lems listened attentively yes terday while three former ad dicts told of their degrading experiences.

title: MRS. JACOB SLATIN
description: Mrs. Kate Satin, widow of Jacob Slatin, a civil engineer, and mother of Dr. Harvey Slatin, an atomic scientist here, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 82 years old.

title: Democrats in House Urge Nixon WagePrice Power
description: WASHINGTON, May 27Democrats on the House Banking and Currency Committee voted today to push for legislation giving President Nixon, for eight months, the power to freeze wages, prices and rents. The President has consistently opposed any form of controls, mandatory or vol untary, and there is no sign that he would use the power if Congress granted it.

title: What Steinway Is to Pianos Fred Bridge Is to Pots and Pans
description: When a local socialite telephoned Fred Bridge, who owns what may be the finest pot and pan shop in Amer ica, he was in the middle of a sale.

title: Weekend Toll Put at 350
description: CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) National Saftey Council esti mated today that between 350 and 450 persons will be killed in traffic accidents over the Memorial Day weekend.

title: Economists Clash on Nixon Inflation Policy
description: Two economists clashed re peatedly yesterday on whether the nation should adopt new and tougher methods to fight inflation.

title: 2 U.S. Jets, in Reprisal, Attack Gun Positions in North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 A Pentagon spokesman said today that two American fighterbombers attacked anti aircraft gun sites in North Viet nam on Monday after a recon naissance plane they were es corting had been fired on about 90 miles north of the demili tarized zone.

title: 2 ExNazi Aides Sentenced For Roles in Euthanasia
description: BONN, May 27A court in Frankfurt today imposed prison terms on two former officials in Hitler's euthanasia program of killing mentally and physi cally handicapped persons.

title: Westinghouse Gets Order For $60Million Turbines
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day receipt of a $60million order from the Duke Power Company for the design and construction of two nuclear turbinegenerators.

title: Glass Project Planned
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., said yesterday it planned to in vest $10million to produce flat glass by the float process, li censed from Pilkington Broth ers, Ltd.

title: City Revises Manual
description: The official Manual of Ac counts of the City of New York, which Controller Abra ham D. Beame said would be useful to all civic, community and social service organizations concerned with the financing of vital municipal programs, has been revised, updated and sim plified. One copy of the new manual, Mr. Beame said, will be made available to any organiza tion that requests one in writ ing by addressing a letter to Joseph Nardi, Chief Accountant, Room 822, Municipal Building, New York, N. Y. 10017.

title: MICHAEL E. BENJAMIN
description: Michael E. Benjamin, a public accountant for 60 years, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hos pital. He was 84 years old and lived at 320 Central Park West.

title: Congressional Mail Reflects Mood of Anguish in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 27If Congressional mail is any gauge of the mood of the country and most Congressmen have no doubt that it isthere is a feeling of quiet anguish sim mering in the big cities, the suburbs and the small towns across America.

title: Green's Trial to Resume
description: OTTAWA, May 27 (UPI) The common assault trial of Ted Green, Boston Bruins' de fenseman, resumes tomorrow after a sevenweek recess. Green is charged with assault in his stickswinging battle with Wayne Maki of the St. Louis Blues during a National Hockey League exhibition here Sept. 21. Maki was acquitted in February in his trial.

title: Wheelwright Is Asked by Rozelle to Sell His Interest in New Orleans Bar
description: Ernie Wheelwright, once a fullback with the New York Giants and now with the New Orleans Saints, has been re quested by Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of pro football, to divest himself of ownership in a Nev Orleans bar because of alleged relationship with undesirable associates.

title: End of Argentine Ban on Daily Is Linked to Protest
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 27 The newspaper Crnica, largest in Argentina, appeared on news stands here today, three days after Argentina's political police had banned it indefinitely.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Col. Richard Gimbel Dies at 71; Flier Was Yale Library Curator
description: Col. Richard Gimbel, U.S.A.F. retired, curator of aeronautical literature at the Yale Univer sity Library and a former de partment store executive, died of a heart attack in Munich, Germany, yesterday, while on a tour with the Grolier Club. He was 71 years old and lived at 801 Forest Road, New Haven, and 405 Newbold Road, Jenkin town, Pa.

title: Gil Hanover Triumphs
description: Gil Hanover, John Froehlich's promising 3yearold trotter, made his season's debut with a 2:06 3/5 clocking for the mile Wednesday night. Haughton drove the bay colt to a three quarterlength decision over the 22to1 Tout Atout D. Gil Hanover paid $3.20. Last year, Gil Hanover won six of his seven starts, then was turned out with a hairline fracture of the knee.

title: COALITION URGED FOR FOUNDATIONS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 The creation of a national or ganization to improve founda tion practices and represent foundations to the public and government has been urged by a committee formed by founda tion leaders.

title: BURNS REASSURES BUSINESS LEADERS
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 28Wall Street and other business leaders, worried about the slump in the stock market and in the economy generally, received private assurances last night from the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board that it would continue to supply enough credit to the economy to keep it moving ahead.

title: A Case History of The Way We Live Now Opens
Screen: 'Grasshopper,' a Rare Truth:Work by Jerry Paris at Local Theaters Jacqueline Bisset Stars in Girl's life Story
description: If I were to construct a vehicle for the romantic sensibility in the movies, I should avoid all the lush presences of, say, "A Man and a Woman," or the misty distances of, say, "Elvira Madigan," and choose instead the bright colors and clear perspectives of Jerry Paris's "The Grasshopper," a film of ordinary ambitions and of limited but sometimes stunning success."The Grasshopper," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, does not simply invoke, but actively seeks to earn its moods. And although it strikes little new ground and discovers few new combinations, it achieves a fairly rare kind of intelligence and truth in the clarity and fluidity of its style.The ad copy says it is "the story of a beautiful girl's lifetime between the ages of 19 and 22," and though I wouldn't have put it quite that way, the ad copy does not lie. Christine (Jacqueline Bisset) descends from Canada upon a Los Angeles boyfriend, splits when the future (a bank job and many sound investments) seems too dull, and heads for Las Vegas. She dances in a club and, after a few adventures, marries a black former football star (Jim Brown, surely the most type-cast actor in the movies), demeans herself advancing his career, and learns she doesn't like domesticity.When her husband dies (murdered in a hood's revenge for a well-deserved beating) her decline begins in earnest. She goes from call-girl to kept woman (for Joseph Cotten), to $50 whore, to ultimate despair in which, with the help of a flying fool, she sky-writes an appropriate message (which I cannot repeat) while on the ground, young America applauds and the silent majority faints dead in its tracks.As usual among us, failure is more instructive, more complicated, and more attractive than success. Committed to the morality of each moment, Christine is never wise but also she is never wrong, and her very aimlessness (like the many non sequiturs of the plot) has a kind of shapeliness to it that justifies imprudence and even indecision on esthetic grounds.I don't think the film intends any program of maturation through hard times, but Christine at the end suggests a lovely and reckless intensity that Christine at the beginning could scarcely have imagined.As a movie, "The Grasshopper" lives in its visual rhythms, and I am not sure that the photographer (Sam Leavitt) and the film editor (Aaron Stell) shouldn't share major credit with the director. Nothing else really equals the handsome montage of Las Vegas shows that appears early on, but the film repeatedly transcends its own vulgarity, always survives its actors (there are no performances to speak of except for Miss Bisset's), and improves upon the conventions that keep it moving.Jacqueline Bisset looks rather like a more voluptuous Julie Christie, and her role in "The Grasshopper" probably owes a little to the heroines of "Darling" and "Petulia." But she seems more durable and forthright, less secretive and sensitive than Julie Christie, and better adapted to suggest, without pathos, tough luck that is more than misfortune and less than tragedy.When her movie is over, she has gotten somewhere; she really has won the knowledge for which she has lost in innocence.

title: Manhattan Polls to Open For School Boards Today
description: Voters in Manhattan will go to the polls today to elect members to the new com munity school boards being set up under the school de centralization law. At stake in the elections are 54 board seats nine in each of the borough's six local school districts.

title: Jail Ordered on Tax Charge
description: The president of a company that deals in steel racks and shelves was ordered yesterday to serve a twomonth prison sentence starting next Tuesday, and to pay a $10,000 fine for attempted tax evasion. Federal Judge Thomas F: Croake im posed the sentence upon Ben jamin Comnier, 53 years old, who owns A. Alert Rack and Steel Equipment, Inc., 979 Ave nue of the Americas, near 36th Street.

title: Observer: All Right, Everybody, Drop the Hot Rhetorie
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Highly placed columnists, edi torial writers and cartoonists of the Eastern press may at last be ready to come to the bar gaining table for coolerrhetoric talks with Vice President Agnew.

title: NEWSMAN REQUESTS SUBPOENA BE VOIDED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 (UPI)Lawyers for Earl Cald well, a reporter of The New York Times, moved today to set aside a second subpoena by a Fedetal grand jury investi gating the Black Panthers on the grounds it is a sort of Instant replay of the earlier one.

title: New Parking Bureau to Track Scofflaws
description: The day of the scofflaw is over. Transportation Adminis trator Constantine Sidamon Eristoff said yesterday as he announced details of his ad ministration's new parking vio lations bureau.

title: Madrid Exchange Attacked
description: MADRID, May 27 (AP)Four youths broke a window of the Madrid Stock Exchange today and threw rocks and firebombs into the building, starting a small fire but causing no injur ies. Two youths were arrested.

title: REORGANIZATION SET FOR BANKAMERICARD
description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, an nounced yesterday a complete reorganization of its nationwide BankAmericard credit card pro gram designed, its officials said, to give a greater voice to the 300 or so other banks that are now licensed to offer the card. BankAmericard, Inc., has been formed, the announcement stat ed, which all of the Bank Americard banks are expected to join. The present licensing arrangements will be termi nated and all of the banks, in cluding the Bank of America, will join the new company on an equal footing.

title: RECOVERY IS WIDE IN BOND MARKETS
description: The bond market, which has been declining more or less steadily since late March, ral lied yesterday in a recovery sparked by a seemingly spon taneous decision by many trad ers and investors that the mar ket had sunk far enough.

title: Fire and Argument Mark Auto Trials
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27A it often does just before the running of the Indianapolis 500, trie afternoon heat had a sear ing effect on race cars and on the edgy nerves of men with so much at stake.

title: In The Nation: The University of Crime
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  James V. Bennett, Who served as director of the Federal pris ons system for 27 years, has given Congress a hardheaded, practical, down  to  earth ap praisal of the Nixon Adminis tration's proposals for preven tive detention. They are likely to make a bad situation worse, Mr. Bennett told a Senate sub committee.

title: Thai Group in Cambodia for Aid Talks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 27  A highlevel Thai Govern ment delegation, dominated by military leaders, flew to Cam bodia today for a critical con ference to decide the amount and kind of aid  including possibly even combat troops  that Thailand will give her em battled neighbor to the east.

title: RussianSpanish Theme Marks First Promenades of the Season
description: It was less springlike out doors last night than it was in Philharmonic Hall, where the New York Philharmonic was blossoming into its annual Promenades.

title: Packard Urges Approval Of Lockheed C5A Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Deputy Secretary of De fense, David Packard, urged Congress today to approve budgeted funds permitting the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to continue Government proj ects such as the C5A super transport. But he said the ailing firm must get private financial support to avoid bankruptcy.

title: Interim FreightRate Rise Of 5% Granted Railroads
description: The nation's railroads won the Interstate Commerce Com mission's approval yesterday of an interim freightrate increase of 5 per cent, while the regula tory agency investigates their right to a requested 6 per cent increase.

title: Wedding Planned By Roberta Shapiro
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., May 27Dr. Robert Shapiro, an orthopedic surgeon, and Mrs. Shapiro have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Roberta Shapiro, to Marc Saperstein, son of Rabbi Harold Saperstein, president of the New York Board of Rabbis, and Mrs. Saperstein of Malverne, L. I. The wedding is planned for June 17 in Boston.

title: PETERSON VICTOR WITH AKER'S HELP
description: DETROIT, May 27The Yan kees, whose bats had been silenced yesterday by the pitches of Earl Wilson, erupted for three runs in the first inning tonight and went on to a 42 triumph over Detroit at Tiger Stadium.

title: Suharto Says Red Troop Intervention in Asia Must Be Prevented
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 President Suharto of Indonesia declared today that other for eign troops must be prevented from replacing those of the United States as Americans withdraw from the Asian main land.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The plight of the Atlantic salmon, a glorious gamefish prized by many anglers above all other species, is attracting international atten tion.

title: U. S. Reported Recruiting Cambodians in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27American soldiers were re ported today to be recruiting ethnic Cambodian residents of the Mekong delta for fighting in Cambodia.

title: STOCKS UP 32.04; RISE SETS RECORD FOR A SINGLE DAY
description: The stock market, struggling to fight its way out of one of the deepest slumps in history, soared yesterday to the largest Ioneday advance ever recorded.

title: SAMUELS OFFERS A PLAN FOR. LIR.
description: ALBANY, May 27  Howard J. Samuels declared today that if he were elected Governor he would press for a fourpoint program to improve the Long Island Railroad and for freez ing fares until the program was in effect for at least a year.

title: Suspect in Bank Robbery Seized in Bus Terminal
