description: Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley last night issued an order obliging every mem ber of the Police Department to protect antiwar demon strators here against actual or threatened physical harm dur ing the Memorial Day weekend.

title: Vacations for the Aging
description: Leaving their chairs in front of the dismal tene ments where they spend their lives, five thousand elderly and impoverished New Yorkers manage to escape every summer from lonely and confined rooms for a few weeks in the country. There, they suddenly come alive again by taking up painting, gardening and the creative arts. And they make new friends that lift them from the slough of despond.

title: MARKET EXTENDS RALLY FOR 2D DAY
description: The stock market rally continued in high gear yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to the highest level of the year. Prices raced upward in the first hour of trading in a continuation of Wednesday's strong recovery, slipped downward for the next two hours, and then began a new advance that carried major market indicators to their top levels of the day at the close.

title: 5% Rate Increase Held Disappointing To Railway Groups
description: The chief counsel of the railroad industry yesterday expressed the carriers' disap pointment with the 5 per cent interim freight rate in crease that the Interstate Commerce Commission ap proved on Wednesday.

title: Prouty to Tell Plans June 15
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)  Senator Winston L. Prouty, Republican of Vermont, will an nounce his political plans June 15, an aide said yesterday. The Senator is expected to seek re election to a third term.

title: A NEW U.S. JAIL HERE IS ASKED BY SEYMOUR
description: United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr. called for replacement of the Federal detention center here yesterday after disclosing that there had been two escape attempts in the last two months at the 41 yearold facility.

title: JetGiant Meetings to Be Rare
description: The Giants won't play the Jets at Yankee Stadium until 1974, and their rivalry won't resume after that at Shea Sta dium until 1979 at the earliest, according to a tentative sched ule of opponents through the 1978 season announced yester day by the National Football League.

title: The Screen
description: The OutofTowners cov ers 24hours in the life of an Ohio businessman (Jack Lem mon) who, with his wife (Sandy Dennis), flies to New York City to be interviewed for a company vice presi dency.

title: Ireland Holds 2 Ousted Aides; Charges Arms Smuggling Plot
description: DUBLIN, May 28 (Reuters) Two dismissed Cabinet minis ters were charged today with having conspired to smuggle arms into Northern Ireland.

title: The Unsung, Ectoplasmic Eminences Behind Politicians
description: The next phrase of the po litical campaign could be anybody's. It might even be the candidate's. But in the race for New York Gover nor and Senator the chances are much better than it will have originated in the mind of a speech writer.

title: MAYOR REAFFIRMS STATUS WITH G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 Mayor Lindsay, who has said in the past that he has no plans to change his Republican enrollment, appeared to strengthen that stand today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Track nuts have an insatiable thirst for record performances and their exultant shrieks at a thrilling finish will take an abrupt U turn into groans of disappoint ment if the winning time doesn't measure up to their expectations. But they should slurp up their fill today and tomorrow at Franklin Field in Philadelphia during the 94th track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Ath letes of America.

title: Costs Trim U.S. Donations Of Meat for School Lunches
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)  Rising meat costs have slowed the Agriculture Depart ment's hamburger donations for school lunch programs, which currently help feed about 22 million children.

title: GRAIN FUTURES HAVE MIXED DAY
description: Grain futures prices were ir regular yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade while soy beans futures prices fell after rising the day before.

title: WallaceBrewer Race Close but Mild
description: ALEXANDER CITY, Ala., May 28  For all its national import, the runoff primary for Governor of Alabama has been la strangely tepid affair.

title: ClevelandCliffs Offer
description: The ClevelandCliffs Iron Company announced yesterday that it would make a cash tender offer of more than $50 million for 80 per cent of the outstanding stock of the De troit Steel Corporation.

title: North Vietnamese Reported Recruiting Guerrillas in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28 North Vietnamese troops are reportedly conduct ing an intensive recruiting and proselytizing campaign among the rural population of Cam bodia in what official sources here see as an attempt to cre ate a broadly based Communist guerrilla organization similar to the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

title: KAZIN DELIVERS LECTURE ON FLAG
description: Alfred Kazin, the author and literary critic, denounced yes terday what he called the flag business, the use of the Ameri can flag by construction work ers and others as a patriotic symbol against war dissenters.

title: OLIVER C. REYNOLDS, FOUNDED LAW FIRM
description: Oliver C. Reynolds, a found ing partner of the law firm of Reynolds, Richards, Ely & La Venture of 68 William Street, died Wednesday night at Pres byterian Hospital after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in New York and Wash ington, Conn.

title: U.S. GIVEN 30 DAYS TO JUSTIFY DDT USE
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals told the Department of Agriculture today to suspend the use of DDT within 30 days or justify to the court its fail ure to do so.

title: HeartLung Machine Devised by Youth, 17
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 A Virginia inventor will re ceive a patent for a heart lung machine next week, a few days before he gets his high school diploma. Craig R.Rudlin or Rich mond, 17 years old, will be awarded Patent 3,515,640 for his combined blood pump and oxygenator. He hopes to license a manufac turer to produce the machine and to use the royalties to put himself through Prince ton University and a medical school.

title: Pembroke Women Elect
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 29 (AP)Mrs. Helena Shea of Cranston was named president of the Pembroke College Alum nae Association today at the annual dinner meeting. Mrs. Shea is the chief clinical psy chologist for the Rhode Island Division of Alcoholism.

title: Hotel Corp. Shows a Loss
description: The Hotel Corporation of America lost $618,000 in the first quarter of this year con trasted to a net profit of $511, 000 for the corresponding period in 1969, Robert P. Son nabend, president, yesterday told the annual meeting at the Plaza Hotel. Operating revenues rose to $31,309,000 from $28, 951,000.

title: Slowdown in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, May 29 (AP) The current slowdown in business in the United States is affecting the Hong Kong textile industry and industrial ists say they expect the situa tion to worsen before it im proves.

title: Race at Indianapolis To Be Heard on Radio
description: The Indianapolis 500 today will be broadcast by many ra dio stations and will be car ried on closedcircuit color television in many theaters.

title: ANITA'S LAD WINS HUNTER LAURELS
description: DEVON, Pa., May 29Anita's Lad won the green conforma tion hunter championship at the Devon Horse Show today under Dave Kelley to give the Southern Pines, N. C., profes sional two foxchaser titles. Yes terday, Kelley rode uncertain Sign to the firstyear green working hunter crown.

title: PORT ON MISSISSIPPI GETS OCEAN SERVICE
description: The Mississippi River is con sidered a barge waterway these years, but now Greenville, Miss., on the river 450 miles above its mouth, has become an ocean port, the Fairplay In ternational Shipping Journal re ports.

title: TALK SHOWS GETTING THEIR OWN EMMIES
description: Talk shows will have their own category in the Emmy Award nominations next year.

title: Memorial Day
description: Today is Memorial Day. Following is a list of the serv ices that are affected:

title: KING ENDS EFFORT TO CONTROL I.0.S.
description: John M. King, 43yearold Denver oil millionaire, gave up yesterday his battle for control of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the giant mutualfund complex based in Geneva..

title: Airlines Voting on Rise in Atlantic Fare
description: GENEVA, May 29A pro posal for an acrosstheboard emergency increase in North Atlantic passenger fares of $5 in each direction is being voted on by member airlines of the International Air Transport As sociation.

title: POST AND PRINTERS REACH AGREEMENT
description: The New York Post and Typographical Union No. 6 reached an understanding in their contract negotiations yes terday.

title: HAMMER ACQUIRES PORTRAIT BY EAKINS
description: A large portrait by Thomas Eakins that failed to reach its reserve price at auction on May 21 has been purchased by Dr. Armand Hammer, art collector and chairman of the board of the Occidental Petroleum Com pany.

title: Pope Will Visit Philippines and Australia
description: ROME, May 29The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI would visit the Philip pines and Australia in the sec ond half of November. The projected 25,000mile air jour ney will take the widely trav eled Pope farther from Rome than he or any of his prede cessors has ever been.

title: Third Boy in Family Is Killed by a Car
description: TRENTON, May 29 (AP) A 10yearold boy, two of whose brothers died when they were hit by cars, was killed in the same manner today while attempting to cross a street here.

title: Chaplains Find New Role on Campus
description: PAWLING, N. Y., May 29 College chaplains have found a new sense of pur pose as a result of recent turmoil on the nation's cam puses, where they have more and more been acting as me diators between conflicting factions.

title: Ross Tops 2 Rivals to Gain In Brooklyn Title Tennis
description: Steve Ross of Brooklyn, top seeded, gained the quarter fi nals of the Brooklyn men's tennis championship yesterday by defeating Herb Charlop of Brooklyn, 61, 62, and Richard Scheer of New York, 61, 61, at the HiWay Tennis Club.

title: CATHY HONEY IS 2D AS1110FAVORITE
description: Office Queen's ability to keep a straight course, while her favored rival, Cathy Honey, had to change paths several times, enabled the filly to carry Stephen Calder's colors to vic tory in the $119,625 Mother Goose at Belmont Park yes terday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Veterans Will Vie With Peace Groups In Parades Today
description: Vetreans organizations and antiwar groups have announced plans for competing patriotic and peace demonstrations today as the nation observes Memo rial Day.

title: Market Place:
description: Ban the short sale? That's what one Wall Streeter suggested here couple of days ago. In his view, it would prevent the killers from stopping rallies cold.

title: Peru Curbs Private Bank Operations
description: LIMA, Peru, May 29The private banking system in Peru, still groggy from the heaviest blow dealt foreign banks in Latin America since the Cuban revolution, is awaiting a second punch from the military regime that is expected to put at least two foreign banks out of busi ness here.

title: EVA HESSE DIES; SCULPTOR WAS 34
description: Eva Hesse, a wellknown young sculptor, died at New York Hospital yesterday morn ing of a brain tumor. She was 34 years old and lived at 134 Bowery.

title: J.P. STEVENS NET INSHARP DECLINE
description: J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., the nation's second largest textile manufacturing company, an nounced yesterday sharply lower sales and earnings for the fiscal quarter and sixmonth period ended May 2.

title: C.I.A. Says Lon Nol Sold Reds Rice
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 A report of the. Central In telligence Agency asserts that Premier Lon Nol of Cam bodia, who led the ouster of Prince Norodom Sihanouk as Chief of State in March, sold rice to the Vietcong on sev eral occasions a few years ago.

title: I.T.T. PROCEEDS IN MERGER PLANS
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation an nounced yesterday that it was proceeding with its plans to merge with the Hartford Fire Insurance Company despite third round of legal maneuvers by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, to delay the plan.

title: Thoughts at the NATO Conference
description: OMEThe meeting of the NATO Council just concluded here was quite a satisfactory one by the standards of alli ance gatherings. The foreign ministers did enough to achieve the underlying purpose of such occasions  a demonstration that NATO is alive and well and still has a purpose in inter national life.

title: Leslie Rogers, A. B. Schilling Wed in Jersey
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N. J., May 29Miss Leslie Robinson Rogers and August Bernard Schilling were mar ried here this evening in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Michael Lease performed the cere mony. He was assisted by the Rev. G. P. Mellick Bel shaw, rector of St. George's bytheRiver Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Biographical Memoirs, Vol. XLI, National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (Columbia University, $5).

title: Citadel Names President
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., May 29 (AP) A 58yearold career staff member at The Citadel, James W. Duckett, will become president of the school Sept. 1.

title: ONDINE IS LEADING BLOCK ISLAND FLEET
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 29 Sumner A. (Huey) Long's 73 foot ketch, Ondine, out of Larchmont (N. Y.) Yacht Club and the scratch boat in the Storm Trysail Club's 25th an nual Block Island race, was re ported leading the fleet home this afternoon.

title: Part of Car Lot Vanishes
description: A 4,000squarefoot section of a parking lot sank into the Harlem River yesterday, carry ing a car with it and injuring a man slightly. The police said a 20by200foot, asphaltcov ered plot at 145th Street serv ing as an apartment building parking lot broke loose from the shore and crumbled into the river. Robert Hagood, 36 years old, of 129 West 147th Street, jumped clear and was slightly injured. He was treated at Harlem Hospital.

title: Plot Against Police Charged by Union; Reward Is Offered
description: James Radice, president of the Traffic Squad Benevolent Association, charged yesterday that there was a nationwide conspiracy to degrade law en forcement and said that his or ganization was offering a $10, 000 reward to anyone who could supply information to identify the alleged conspira tors and lead to their prosecu tion.

title: Fails to Meet Capital Ratio
description: The bear market has forced a brokerage house out of busi ness and has discouraged an other from replacing employes who have left the company for one reason or another.

title: Grand Union Company To Open 24 New Branches
description: The Grand Union Company, the food supermarket chain, will open 24 new branches this year, several more than were opened a year ago, Charles G. Rodman, president, told share holders at the annual meeting last week.

title: Maddox to Picket Two Papers; Bars Sales Near State Capitol
description: ATLANTA, May 29  Gov. Lester G. Maddox announced today that the would personal ly picket the offices of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlan ta Constitution next week. He ordered sales of the two papers stopped in the vicinity of the Capitol.

title: Rx for Addiction?
description: Could New York City dimin ish the high crime, rate among heroin addicts by adopting legal heroin program similar to that in Great Britain?

title: Robber, a Negro, Gets Death Penalty in South
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 29 (AP)An allwhite jury has decreed the death penalty for a Negro t convicted of robbing a white girl of $30 and a wrist watch.

title: Hospital Strike a Charleston Milestone
description: CHARLESTON, S. C.A hos pital workers' strike last spring so thoroughly upset the hoary equilibrium of this historic port city that even those who would now prefer to forget it cannot.

title: Zoning Imagination
description: A potential small boom in the transfer of air rights over landmark buildings is blowing up the usual storm that touches any aspect of zoning in this city. Money, as always, is at the root of the matter, in the form of the grotesquely high cast of Manhattan land.

title: Majority of U. of California Found Involved in Protests
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP)For the first time, stu dent protest on University of California campuses encom passes a majority of the aca demic community, the system's president, Charles H. Hitch, said today.

title: Royals Sign 2 Draft Choices
description: CINCINNATI, May 29 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Associa tion signed two of their 1970 draft choices todayWade Ful ler of Loyola of Chicago and Mike Bernard of Kentucky State.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Pro football is a silly game, says Chip Oliver. It dehumanizes people. They've taken the players and made them into slabs of beef that can charge around and hit each other. But where is their esthetic soul, the feeling they can accomplish higher things?

title: Bridge:
description: The Goldman Open Pairs, one of the most famous events in the history of the game, will begin this after noon in the New York Hil ton Hotel, on the second day of the Eastern Regional Championships. Among the competitors will be most of the topranked experts in the metropolitan area and many from farther afield.

title: Mrs. Lenore Lyons Married in Plandome
description: PLANDOME, L. I., May 29 Mrs. Lenore Lyons was married today to Jonas Rosenfield Jr. in the North Shore Unitarian Church by the Rev. J. Harold Hadley.

title: Parliament Dissolved; British Campaign Opens
description: LONDON, May 29 (UPI) Queen Elizabeth II, acting at the request of Prime Minis ter Wilson, today dissolved Parliament until July 2. Her royal warrant opened the official campaign for the June 18 national elections.

title: SAIGON'S MARINES TRY TO END SIEGE NEAR PNOMPENH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 30More than 1,000 South Vietnamese ma rines battled North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops today in the besieged Cambodian town of Preyveng, 30 miles south east of Pnompenh.

title: KERSTIN THORBORG OF THE MET WAS 73
description: STOCKHOLM, May 29 Ker stin Thorborg, Swedish mezzo soprano and contralto who sang at the Metropolitan Opera in New York from 1936 to 1947, died April 12 in a hospital in Falun in the Swedish province of Dalarna. She was 73 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AT RCA CORPORATION
description: The resignation of Delbert L. (DebS) Mills as senior vice president of consumer products and components of the RCA Corporation has been an nounced by Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and president. Mr. Mills, who is 62, was a key figure in the development of color television into a multi billiondollar commercial in dustry.

title: 6 DEAD IN OUTBREAK OF WHOOPING COUGH
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., May 30 (AP)At least six infants have died of whooping cough in Bell and adjacent Southeastern Kentucky counties this year, the State Health Department says.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastem Standard Time

title: Courthouse Contract Voided
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29 (AP)The Middlesex County commissioners announced can cellation today of a contract with the Gevyn Construction Corporation of Mamaroneck, N. Y., for a 21story courthouse in Cambridge. The building was to he completed in 1967 at cost of $16million. The county has spent $28.5million on it so far, and the structure is still incomplete.

title: 45 Jersey Reservists Flee Burning Bus on Highway
description: BINGHAMPTON, N. Y. May 29A group of about 45 Army Reservists escaped from their chartered bus moments before flames engulfed it on Interstate Highway 81 here at noon today.

title: Ferry to the Moon
description: The nickel fare on the cityowned Staten Island ferry is the biggest travel bargain in the country. In this period of staggering municipal costs, there is no more reason to consider it sacrosanct than was the old nickel subway fare, which almost pushed the city into bankruptcy. But the fivefold increase proposed by Mayor Lindsay is much too steep, even when the price of everything is skyrocketing. The Mayor spoke elo quently just a few months ago of the cruel burden dime increase in subway fares placed on lowincome families. A 20cent jump in the cost of a ferry ride is as illogical as it is unjust.

title: Economist Joins Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29 (AP)Harvard University an nounced today the appointment of John T. Dunlop, 55yearold economist, as dean of the fac ulty of arts and sciences. Pro fessor Dunlop, who was chair man of the Department of Eco nomics from 1961 to 1966, is serving as acting dean in the absence on leave of Dean Frank lin L. Ford.

title: O'Dwyer Is Endorsed by Eugene McCarthy
description: Praising Paul O'Dwyer as a man with a commitment on all of the really critical issues that have faced the country in the last ten years, Senator Eu gene J. McCarthy endorsed Mr. O'Dwyer yesterday for Senator from New York.

title: 12th Vienna Session Is Short
description: VIENNA, May 29 (AP) United States and Soviet nego tiators today held their short est session in the present round of strategicarms limitation talks, but this was said to have had no significance. It was the 12th meeting since the talks opened here April 16.

title: U.S. Pledges Safety of Angkor Wat
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 The Government has privately assured scholars and art ex perts that steps are being taken to protect important cul tural sites, including the his toric temples at Angkor Wat, during the fighting in Cam bodia.

title: Art: Surprise From Nancy Grossman
description: In a new exhibition at Cordier & Ekstrom, 980 Madi son Avenue near 76th Street, called Black and White, which this time is not a ref erence to the skin colors of the participants, there are drawings by such big names as Marcel Duchamp, Jean Dubuffet, Max Ernst and Rich ard Lindner, as well as a group of sculptures in black or white marble by Isamu Noguchi. All these are fine, but the stars of the show are three unexpected drawings by Nancy Grossman.

title: Big Board Members to Vote On Trust Fund Amendments
description: The New York Stock Ex change has sent to its members for ratification amendments to its constitution that would in crease as an interim measure the maximum size of the Spe cial Trust Fund program to $55 million.

title: Fund Aids 2 Firemen
description: WHITEWATER, Wis., May 29 (AP)Two firemen, badly in jured in fighting an arson blaze at Whitewater State University last February were presented today with checks totaling more than 1,300 by concerned stu dents. The fund was established by students to benefit Gary Gebhart and Jim Dunlap who were injured when the ladder they were on fell.

title: Vietcong Long a Fixture at Snoul, Deputy Says
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 29Heour Lay Inn is the Na tional Assembly Deputy from Snoul and Chhlong, his native town. He cannot go home to his district because the ruins of Snoul, leveled and captured by the Americans earlier this month, are inaccessible from here and the Vietnamese Com munists hold Chhlong.

title: A Brooklyn Grocer Wounds 3 Youths In Foiling Burglary
description: Three youths were shot yes terday by a Brooklyn grocer while they reportedly were loot ing his store in the Bedford Stuyvesant section.

title: Suharto on T.V.A. Visit
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 29 (Reuters)President Suharto of Indonesia arrived here tonight from New York to visit the Ten nessee Valley Authority's power projects.

title: DELAWARE NINE, SETON HALL WIN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 29 Seton Hall battled into the championship of the National Collegiate Athletic Associa tion's District II baseball play off today and joined Delaware in tomorrow's final round.

title: 177 Stranded Aboard a 747 In Milwaukee for 5 Hours
description: MILWAUKEE, May 29 (AP) Weather and mechanical problems kept 177 passengers stranded aboard their Boeing 747 jetliner in Milwaukee for nearly five hours today before the detoured flight resumed to Chicago.

title: Fijian or Afro, the Comb Makes Sense
description: SUVA, Fiji  The image projected by Fiji, a Brit ish colony of several hundred beautiful islands that will be come an independent state on Oct. 10, has to include a magnificently proportioned race of tall, robust, smil ing women with a distinctive bushy hair style.

title: Fickle Cucaracha Lures Timid to Bronx Library
description: We'll do almost anything to get people to come into the library, said Lillian Lopez, di rector of the South Bronx project of the New York Public Library. We've found so many people that have never used a library or know that they exist. They don't know that they can take books out free.

title: TYDINGS DISCLOSES LOSSES IN MARKET
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) Senator Joseph D. Tydings, a millionaire Democrat from Maryland said today he had suffered heavy losses in the de clining stock market over the last year.

title: STOCKS UP 16.29 AS RALLY PUSHES DOW ABOVE 700
description: The stock market moved up ward again yesterday to close a tumultuous week in which the 18month decline in prices was at least temporarily halted.

title: EDWARD E. HALE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29 Edward E. Hale, a retired mutual fund executive, died yes terday at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston after a short illness. He was 64 years old and had homes here and in Manchester.

title: Miss Hogan and Mrs. Jones Gain Surrey Tennis Final
description: SURBITON, England, May 28 (UPI)Patti Ann Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., upset Mrs. Mary Ann Curtis of St. Louis, last year's tourney winner, 36, 62, 62 today and reached the wo men's singles final at the Sur rey grass courts tennis cham pionship.

title: Foundations Told to Relate To Minorities and the Poor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP)Alan Pifer, president of the Carnegie Foundation, said today that organizations such as his must relate to minority groups, youth and the poor or face extinction.

title: Cambodian Foray After a Month: From Arms and Rice to Buttons
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 29The allied military campaign in Cambodia is a month old.

title: Agnew Discerns Tensions Between Factions Easing
description: MIAMI, May 29 (UPI)Vice President Agnew said today he believed dissent between oppos ing factions in the United States was lessening because we have opened lines of com munication.

title: Texas Educator Resigns
description: EL PASO, Tex., May 29 (AP) The University of Texas re gents announced today the resignation of Dr. Harry Ran som as chancellor of the sys tem, effective Jan. 1, 1971. The board named Dr. Ransom as chancellor emeritus of the sys tem, also effective Jan. 1. The board took no immediate action on a new chancellor.

title: MARYLAND LEADS IN TWODAY MEET
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 29 Dick Buerkle, a 22yearold sen ior who entered Villanova with out an athletic scholarship, started the Wildcats toward an other I.C. 4A. team champion ship today with an impressive 30yard victory in the sixmile run.

title: Alexander Hamilton Dies at 67; Aide in Conservation Activities
description: Alexander Hamilton, a great greatgrandson of the American statesman and first Secretary of the Treasury, died of emphy sema yesterday in London, where he was on vacation. He was 67 years old and lived in Sloatsburg, N. Y.

title: GUERRILLAS SEIZE ARMS IN URUGUAY
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 29 (AP)A band of urban guer rillas overpowered personnel at a Uruguayan naval training center here today and fled with more than 700 weapons and a large Quantity of ammunition.

title: Swigert to Be Honored
description: DENVER, May 29 (UPI) John L. Swigert, one of the Apollo 13 astronauts, will be honored with a Memorial Day parade tomorrow. Gov. John A. Love proclaimed tomorrow as John Swigert Day.

title: HICKEL CANDIDACY IN ALASKA DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, May 29A spokesman denied today rumors that Walter J. Hickel would re sign as Secretary of the Interior because of differences with President Nixon. The Secretary, the spokesman said, will not leave the Cabinet to return to Alaska to run for Governor or any other public office.

title: Starving Brazilians Are Invading Towns From Drought Area
description: BRASILIA, May 29 (Reuters)  Official sources said today that thousands of starving peasants were invading towns in droughtstricken northeast ern Brazil and were breaking into stores and private homes in search of food.

title: Finnish Master Fashions Library for Abbey in Oregon
description: MOUNT ANGEL, Ore., May 29Importing the work of a famous Finnish architect known for his beautiful use of wood to the Pacific North west may seem like bringing coals to Newcastle. The woods here are as full of architects as they are of Douelas fir. But imported architecture, unlike some imported wines, can travel well. The new library of the Mount Angel Abbey, a Benedictine monas tery 40 miles south of Port land, being dedicated this weekend, brings a small and perfect work of the 73year old master of the modern movement, Alvar Aalto, to the United States.

title: COURT NULLIFIES ORDER TO POLICE
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit nullified a Federal District Court order yesterday that would have required the city's Police Department to remind every member of the force this weekend of his duty to protect antiwar demonstrators from physical assaults and threats.

title: DEALERS BATTLE ON BOND CLEARING
description: COPENHAGEN, May 29A battle over who is to manage a system of clearing interna tional bonds sold in Europe Americans or Luxemburgers broke out on the floor of bond dealers' annual meeting today.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges this week is sued their latest reports of changes in ownership by di rectors, officers and large stockholders of listed corpora tions. The list include the fol lowing:

title: In Memoriam
description: GEORGESGeorge. In memoriam. George Georges. 40 day memorial service at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74th St., 10:30 A.M., Sunday, May 31. Forever in our hearts Sweet Prince.

title: Businessmen's Commitment Found Lacking
description: LOS ANGELES, May 29 Harold Willens, Los Angeles businessman, is desperately poring over Fortune's list of the 500 largest corporations.

title: Leslie J. Nathan Bride Of D. R. Weinberger
description: Miss Leslie Joan Nathan was married here yesterday afternoon to Daniel Roy Weinberger in the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Allan Shedlin of New York.

title: Dance: La Sonnambula and Agon
description: One of the less easy as pects of being a kindly neigh borhood critic is that once in a whilewould you believe the next night?you have to venture into territory that was not altogether happy with whatwould you be lieve the past morning?you last wrote about it. To any critic in this situation, I would most seriously suggest that this is the price he pays for not working. After all, whoever told you that being a theater critic would be easy, bloodless?

title: Mayor Appoints Group to Study How to Curb Attacks on Firemen
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ap pointed a fourman, highlevel committee to review recom mendations to curb unprovoked assaults on firemen.

title: WERBLIN COLT SET FOR JERSEY DERBY
description: Silent Screen may not be able to go a mile and a quar ter, but David (Sonny) Werblin still thinks his colt can win the big ones at a mile and an eighth.

title: St. Mark's Rector to Head Seminary
description: The Rev. Michael Allen, rec tor since 1959 of historic St. Mark'sintheBowery Episcopal Church, yesterday was named dean of Berkeley Divinity School in New Haven.

title: Thousands of Saigon Students Demonstrate at State Funeral
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 29 (UPI)  Several thousand students today staged the big gest antiGovernment demon stration in recent weeks at the state funeral of Phan Khac Suu, a former South Vietnam ese Chief of State.

title: Thursday Night Fights
description: BaltimoreBobby Lee, Wash ington, D. C., outpointed Mario Saurennann, Philadelphia, 10 rounds, lightweights; Adrian Davis, Washington, D. C., knocked out Johnny Gant, Washington, 2, welterweights; Josh Hall, Baltimore, out pointed Domingo Ortiz, Hobo ken, N. J., 10 middleweights.

title: Books of The Times
description: In one regard this memorial volume to Beethoven, which celebrates the bicen tenary of his birth, cannot be faulted. It looks like a memorial volume. It is large, hefty and elaborately illustrated. The spaciousness of the layout suggests that the publishers were not trying to save pennies in production. The picturesand no page is free of portraits of the composer, his friends, pupils and patrons; outdoor scene and inte riors in and around Vienna connected with his name; title pages of his scores; facsimiles of his letters and musical note books; memora bilia such as his piano, working desk, ear trumpets, and a gorgeous set of old instru ments for string quartet that was a gift of Prince Carl Lichnowsky. A great many of the distant prospects, city squares, buildings in their settings appear in a pastellike coloring that pretties them up and substitutes a calendar coziness for any striking individuality. They are pleas ant enough to look at but they are also a little cloying. In another way, the manu scripts, scores and notebooks have a brownish chromo finish as if they had been instantly antiquateda quality that sug gests venerable age.

title: Alexandra Russell Is Married To Timothy Birch of the Army
description: Miss Alexandra Brenda Russell, granddaughter of the 10th Duke of Marlborough and a descenant of Commo dore Cornelius Vanderbilt, was married here yesterday to Specialist 5 Timothy Campbell Birch, whose Army service has included duty in Vietnam.

title: Veterans Occupy Ministry
description: SAIGON, May 29 (AP)Some 200 disabled veterans tempo rarily occupied offices of the Veterans' Ministry here today.

title: GOLDBERG URGES TRANSIT SUBSIDY
description: Arthur J. Goldberg yester day called for a permanent state subsidy for mass trans portation operating expenses as the only way to prevent new fare increases and to improve services.

title: CHARGES RIDICULED BY CAPTAIN'S FATHER
description: SCRANTON, Pa., May 29 (AP)  The father of an Army captain charged with attempted murder of an unspecified num ber of human beings in Viet nam says the charges are ri diculous.

title: Samuels Urges New Directions In Domestic and Foreign Policy
description: Howard J. Samuels told audi ences in Manhattan and West bury, L. I., yesterday that the state needed a new direction in domestic policy just as the na tion did in foreign policya direction challenging the Es tablishment and the status quo at home and abroad.

title: Wife Says Her SoninLaw Betrayed Treblinka Chief
description: BONN, May 29  Franz Stangl, who commanded the Treblinka extermination camp in Poland in World War II, was caught on a tip from his son inlaw, Mrs. Therese Stangl, the former SS officer's wife, told a Diisseldorf court today.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Dear Pierre Trudeau: If at First You Do Succeed Don't Try It Again
STOCKS ADVANCE IN AMEX TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change scored its third con secutive advance yesterday as the list continued to make gains in fairly active trading.

title: Fiscal Talks Held in Venice
description: VENICE, Italy, May 29 (Reut ers)Common market finance ministers and central bankers of the common market exam ined today the first concrete steps in their plan to create an economic and monetary union over the next 10 years, in formed sources said.

title: SCM Plans Reimbursement If OvenCoater Suits Arise
description: The SCM Corporation said yesterday it will indemnify us ers of its disputed interior coat ing for selfcleaning ovens against any damages resulting from patent infringement suits.

title: KENNEDY FEARS U.S. IS BEING TORN APART
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said yesterday that the increas ing polarization of Americans over age, race and geography was threatening to really tear the nation apart, and is doing so today.

title: 4 a Big Number Today for Foyt, in 500 for 13th Time
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 29  Fifteen drivers have been killed during the Indianapolis 500 mile race and 18 more when practicing for the 59yearold event. Although the rewards are considerableperhaps as much as $275,000 to tomor row's winnerit is expensive to prepare a car (about $100, 000) and difficult to aualify.

title: COUNCIL HEARING SET ON LINDSAY TAX PLAN
description: A public hearing will be held next Friday by the City Council on five new taxes proposed by Mayor Lindsay that are designed to raise $84million a year. The Council will also consider the Mayor's proposal to raise the 5cent Staten Island ferry fare to 25 cents.

title: Christy Brown Displays Mind's Rein Over Body
description: DUBLINThe lionization of Christy Brown is the new in thing in DublinChristy the writer, Christy the paint er, Christy the poet, Christy the embodiment of heroic human resilience, Christy the living proof that an ar tistic mind can gloriously blossom in a desolate phys ical waste.

title: INTER TRIUMPHS OVER SANTOS,10
description: In a farcical ending, during which 3,000 fans were allowed to run onto the field, the Inter Milan Soccer Club of Italy de feated the great Santos team of Brazil, 10, at Randalls Island last night as the game was halted with 11 minutes to play.

title: GILLINGHAM WINS IN A RELIEF ROLE
description: The Mets finally figured how to knock Tom Griffin out of a ball gamehit him on the elbow. But they still haven't figured out how to beat him or score on him, and they still haven't figured out how to beat the Astros, either.

title: Army Track Team Vanquishes Navy for Fifth Straight Year
11 Guerrillas From Jordan Reported Killed by Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, May 29The Israeli Army spokesman said today that Israeli troops along the Jordan River drove off a landing party of Arab guerril las last night, killing 11 of them and capturing a 12th.

title: Pirates Recall Cash, Nelsor
description: PITTSBURGH, May 29 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates re called Dave Cash, a second baseman, and Jim Nelson, a righthanded pitcher, from the Columbus (Ohio) Jets of the International League today. Jose Martinez, an infielder, was optioned to Columbus on 24 hour recall, and Joe Gibbon, pitcher, was placed on the dis abled list.

title: Student Is Sentenced
description: BOSTON, May 29 (UPI)An Emerson college student who killed his roommate after the pair had taken drugs was sen tenced to eight to 15 years in jail today by a Superior Court judge, Wilfred Paquet, who gave a stern lecture against the use of drugs. Harvey Alter, 25 years old, of Maplewood, N. J., pleaded guilty to a charge of manslaughter in the death of his roommate, Richard Philip, 22, of Brighton.

title: Huey Newton's Conviction Reversed by Coast Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 The voluntary manslaughter conviction of Huey P. Newton, the imprisoned Black Panther leader, was overturned today by the California Court of Ap peal.

title: Friday Night Baseball
description: BatteriesCuellar and Hend ricks; Messehsmith and Egan.

title: Music: Palestrinal, Act I
description: Hans Pfitzner called his opera Palestrina a dra matic legend. Ironically enough, the work itself has become legendary to music lovers outside the German speaking countries.

title: EXG.I. DESCRIBES SHOOTING AT HUTS
description: SAN. FRANCISCO, May 29 An eyewitness to a shooting incident in South Vietnam that led yesterday to charges of at tempted murder against two Army officers said today that he and other soldiers saw ci vilians moving around a clus ter of huts in the Mekong Delta before the huts were fired on for target practice.

title: Nixon Names A.E.C. Aide
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 29 (AP)  President Nixon an nounced today he was nominat ing T. Keith Glennan, a former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, to be United States representative to the Inter national Atomic Energy Agency.

title: New Issues Make a Comeback Following Stock Market Rally
description: The newissue market, where shares of companies that had been privately held are traded overthecounter, bounced back a bit in the general stock mar ket rally the last three days of this week.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 29 (UPI)The Western White House announced today that President Nixon sent Congress a request yesterday for a sup plemental appropriation of $250 million for the fiscal year 1970 to provide more money for home mortgages.

title: Rabbi and Woman Arrested For Disrupting Temple Rite
description: Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman adviser to the Radical Jewish Union of Columbia University and 22yearold Annie Rosen a member of the union, were arrested last evening after they disrupted services at Temple EmanuEl. They were charged with interfering with a wor ship service.

title: Antiques: Wide Diversity of Folk Art
description: Diversity is the theme un derlying the current Museum of American Folk Art exhibi tion, Collectors' Choice, Part II.

title: G.M. Plant Set for Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 29 (AP)President Eduardo Frei yesterday authorized General Motors to set up a $7million truck assembly plant in central.

title: Brewers Option Lauzerique
description: MILWAUKEE, May 29 (AP) The Milwaukee Brewers op tioned George Lauzerique, a righthanded pitcher, to Port land today to make room for Dave Baldwin, a relief pitcher who was recalled from Port land last night.

title: GREEK COURT FREES CONVICTED EXAIDE
description: ATHENS, May 29An Athens magistrate today released from custody Paul Vardinoyannis, former member of Parliament who has been held since his return to Greece six days ago after three years in exile.

title: LAOS REPORTS GAINS OVER ENEMY TROOPS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 29 (UPI)  The Laotian military command announced the start of an offensive today and re ported successes against Com munist troops in wide areas of the countryside.

title: Two European Bankers Backing New Art Fund
description: PARIS, May 29Eighty seven years after Paul Gauguin quit banking to become a painter and poor, two of Eur opes most prestigious bankers have gone into art, parttime, to net richer.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, May 30, 1970

title: Kosygin and Maurer Confer
description: MOSCOW, May 29 (Reuters) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin held talks here today with Pre mier Ion Gheorghe Maurer of Rumania on economic, scien tific and technical cooperation between their countries, Tass, the Soviet press agency, re ported.

title: Jersey City Theater Razed
description: JERSEY CITY, May 29A threealarm fire early today de stroyed the Palace Theater, at one time a major vaudeville house in downtown Jersey City. The cause of the fire, which was discovered at 2 A.M., was undetermined. The theater had been closed for more than year and before that had been used for showing Spanishlan guage films.

title: Lutherans Reconsider Plan To Hold Meeting in Brazil
description: GENEVA, May 29 (Reuters)  The World Lutheran Feder ation said today that it was reconsidering a decision to hold its fifth assembly in Brazil be cause of concern on the part of some members about alleged violations of human rights there.

title: PATIENT'S RELEASE DEFENDED BY CITY
description: City health officials told Mayor Lindsay yesterday that a man suspected of fatally stab bing a policeman on Thursday was considered to be in an im proved condition two days earlier when he was released from Bellevue Hospital after three weeks of psychiatric care.

title: Tufts Trustee Honored
description: MEDFORD, Mass., May 29 (AP)The final meeting of the year of the board of trustees of Tufts University was inter rupted today by a longhaired student, Charles McLean, 19 years old, who said the oldest member of the board, Mrs. Etta P. MacPhie, 79, was to become an honorary member of the student body. He said students, appreciative of her rapport, had donated money for a scholarship in her name and for a gold charm for a bracelet she often wears.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Rent Tied to Stocks' Level
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 29 (AP) Using the stock market as its guide, a Miami Beach highrise apartment building is seeking prospective dwellers who will pay no rent until DowJones hits 800 again. But the build ing management, in a newspa per advertisement, said that the offer would end Oct. 1 regard less of the DowJones indus trial average, which was 700.44 today.

title: Dutch City Hall Here Believed Found
description: In what they call the first scientific dig on the site of old New Amsterdam in lower Man hattan, an archeologist and a research historian for the Land marks Preservation Commission have unearthed what may be portions of the foundation of New York's first City Hall.

title: RITES AT RUTGERS CITE MEDICAL UNIT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. May 29  Rutgers University today dedicated a new $18mil lion medical science building on the Piscataway Campus amid doubts as to whether the medical school will remain part of the state university.

title: Oil Contaminates Galveston Beach After Fatal Blast
description: GALVESTON, Tex., May 29 (UPI)Crude oil from an off shore explosion that left four dead and five missing oozed onto the most popular resort beach in Texas today, coincid ing with the arrival of thou sands of holiday tourists.

title: Coast Wine Connoisseurs Toil in Own Vineyards
description: TEMECULA, Calif.  Vincent Cilurzo regularly joins the Fri day exodus from the Los Angeles metropolitan area for the great outdoors of weekend California living. But instead of heading for the beach or his boat, the camping sites or the I desert dune buggy romping areas, Mr. Cilurzo drives down here to oversee his vinevards.

title: RALPH G. HAMBLEN
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 29 Ralph Gordon Hamblen, retired personnel director of the Mach lett Laboratories Division of Raytheon, Inc., died yesterday while visiting in Hadley, Mass. His age was 58, and he lived on Pequot Drive here.

title: O'Brien Assails President On Aid to War Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)The Democratic Nation al Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, accused the Nixon Ad ministration of a negative, foot dragging attitude toward Con gressional efforts to improve the lot of Vietnam war vet erans.

title: Rogers Meets Franco;Progress on Bases Is Hailed
description: MADRID, May 29Secretary of State William P. Rogers met with Generalissimo Francisco Franco today as their countries hailed substantial progress toward a new agreement on American bases in Spain.

title: Victor in '61, '64 and '67 Favored Again at Indianapolis
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 A. J, Foyt, who wants to be the first fourtime winner of the Indianapolis 500, and Al Unser, seeking his first victory, are the favorites to win the 54th running of the race to morrowif it does not rain.

title: SOVIET SAID TO MOVE DISSIDENT TO URALS
description: MOSCOW, May 29Andrei A. Amalrik, the dissident So viet author who was arrested on May 21, has been trans ferred from Moscow to the city of Sverdlovsk in the Urals for his pretrial investigation, reli able sources said today.

title: Federal Food Stamp Program Begins 10th Year
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) The food stamp program be gan its 10th year today, hav ing grown from a onecounty program in hardcore Appala chia to an operation that cov ers more than 60 per cent of the country.

title: Roundup: StandIns Steal the Show as Red Sox Win, 43
description: The scene in Boston last night resembled high camp featuring the Red Sox, but to the Chicago White Sox, it was more like black comedy.

title: ASHE AND RICHEY ADVANCE IN PARIS
description: PARIS, May 29 (AP)Arthur Ashe advanced to the quarter finals of the French open ten nis championships today along with Cliff Richey, a fellow American.

title: Overturn in Ceylon
description: Ceylon's Prime Minister, Dudley Senanayake, went into this week's general election confident that his United National party would emerge triumphant. His confidence was based on the knowledge that during the past five years he had led his country in a period of peace, economic advance and relative harmony among the varied religious and racial groups that make up Ceylon's population. However, many ob servers anticipated a close race; and on that predic tion there was much talk before the election of a grand coalition between the United National party and its chief opposition group, Mrs. Sirimavo Bandar anaike's Sri Lanka Freedom party.

title: Chief Executive Appointed By Brooklyn Industry Unit
description: The appointment of Donald F. Benjamin as chief executive of the Commerce Labor Indus try Corporation of Kings has been announced by John C. Hilly, chairman of the organi zation's board of directors.

title: Anniuersaries
description: ROSENfsidore and Etta. Happy 53d wedding anniversary from all the children, grand children and greatgrandchildren.

title: Oil Executive Sees More Finds In Alaska if U.S. Aids in Risks
description: PARIS May 29 (UPI)  An American oil executive warned today that American depen dence on foreign petroleum would increase unless the United States Government helped tap further resources in the Alaska region.

title: Valiant, Cup Contender, Has Her Mast Stepped
description: Valiant took another step along the America's Cup trail yesterday, and this one was literal as well as figurative. The recenty launched 12 Meter yacht had her mast stepped.

title: Podgorny Meets Selassie
description: MOSCOW, May 29 (UPI) Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia met with President Nikolai V. Podgorny in the Kremlin today, Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported.

title: Argentine Workers and Students Clash With the Police in Cordoba
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, May 29The civil strife that has gripped this inland city sporad ically for the last year broke out again today, and the smoke of burning vehicles began to rise.

title: Sihanouk Acknowledges He Aided Reds
description: HONG KONG, May 29  Prince Norodom Sihanouk said in Hanoi yesterday that while in office he had given to the Vietnamese people fighting against the United States im perialists an effective support and assistance that is not verb al.

title: Alaska House, in Reversal, Defeats Antiwar Measure
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, May 29 (AP)The Alaska House recon sidered and defeated today bill that would have prohibited compulsory service by Alas kans in undeclared foreign wars.

title: MARY MILLS LEADS GOLF BY SHOT AT 68
description: WINCHESTER, Va., May 29 (AP)Mary Mills, the former, United States women's open champion, clipped three strokes from par on the front nine and finished with a fourunderpar 68 today for a onestroke lead after the first round of the 54 hole O'Sullivan open golf tour nament.

title: Rosita Arias Wed to G. B. Hanily
description: Miss Rosita Arias, daugh ter of Dr. Roberto Arias, the former Panamanian diplomat, was married here yesterday afternoon to George B. Hani ly, a former Marine captain, who is with the treasury de partment of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here.

title: Two Folk Singers Show Varied Styles At Village Clubs
description: Townes Van Zandt, a pleas antsounding folk singer from Houston, is appearing through June 7 at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: Wildenstein Joins Select Circle In Losing French Racing Plea
description: PARIS, May 29  Daniel Wil denstein has reluctantly joined a select circle of thoroughbred horse owners, including Queen Elizabeth II of England, who have had winners disqualified because of the awesome stern ness of the French racing stew ards.

title: Memorial Day 1995?
description: At a Conference on Human Survival held here this week to consider the prospects for the United Nations on its 25th birthday, Canada's Lester B. Pearson warned that unless the world community begins to deal more effectively with problems of peace and development we will not be celebrating a fiftieth anniversary of our world organization.

title: Vietcong Reports Newsmen Were Held in Rear Areas
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 29 (AP)A captured Vietcong officer said today that his su perior told him a month ago that captured American, Japa nese and French correspondents had been moved to rear areas and were alive.

title: DAVE HILL, GRANT TRAIL BY STROKE
Fighting Increases in Angola
description: LISBON, May 29 (Reuters) African guerrillas appear to be intensifying their attacks in Portuguese Angola. In a series of actions last week 11 Portu guese troops were killed, 24 were wounded and four are missing, the army high com mand reported today. Five ci vilians were killed, 12 were injured and 23 have disap peared, the command said.

title: AUTO MAKERS EYE JAPAN FOR STEEL
description: DETROIT, May 29The American automobile industry apparently is looking abroad, as a possible source for steel.

title: Diplomas to Remember
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 29 (UPI)  The Rhode Island School of Design will hand out unusual diplomas tomorrow at the annual commencement ex ercisea black and white re production of an Ingres nude. Talbot Rantoul, the design school's president, told the stu dents earlier in the term that he would sign any diploma they wished to design themselves. He called the diploma festive.

title: Nixon Asks Mortgage Funds
description: Nixon Asks Mortgage Funds

title: TOLEDO APPROVES CURB ON WEAPONS
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, May 29  Toledo's City Council, after long dispute, approved last night a controversial measure banning the carrying of rifles and other lone guns.

title: Rebellious Grand Jury
description: Attorney General Mitchell would serve the cause justice and respect fore law by letting in the light on the findings of a Federal grand jury in Baltimore which has been investigating alleged corruption high places. He can do so easily enough by directing District Court Judge Roszel C. Thomsen, who invites the action, to make public a sealed presentment one on the basis of which the Justice Department has so far declined to sanction an indictment.

title: Indian Project Planned
description: GORE, Okla., May 29 (UPI) The Oklahoma Industrial De velopment and Park Depart ment plans to rebuild the first Cherokee Indian capitol, a small village known to the Indians as Tahlonteeskeem. The wood and thatch capitol, council house and chief's home is expected to be completed by late summer at a cost of $45,000.

title: OHIO STUDENTS SUE OVER DISRUPTIONS
description: A group of Ohio State Uni versity students, angered by campus strikes and violence, filed suit in Common Pleas Court in Columbus yesterday asking $1million in damages and a permanent injunction against further disruptions of academic life.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS ROSE FOR THE WEEK
description: DETROIT, May 29 (UPI)  United States auto output con tinued on a strong note this week despite the Memorial Day holiday as the major auto mak ers produced 172,356 cars dur ing the week, the second best of 1970, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: U.S., Soviet Teams Record Shooting Match Victories
description: WIESBADEN, Germany, May 29 (AP)The United States and the Soviet Union recorded team victories today in an inter national shooting competition United States marksmen collected 2.285 of a possible total of 2,400 points to win the standard pistol firing match ahead of the Soviets, who had 2,277 points. Italy was third with 2,222 and West Germany fourth with 2,217.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Concerts

title: STUDENT PROTEST TRACED IN STUDY
description: A study sponsored by the Carnegie Commission on Highe Education indicates that the big urban universities that focus on graduate research and the granting of doctoral degrees are more likely to encounter a high incidence of student protests than the national norm.

title: Enjoining the Police
description: The cancellation by the United States Court of Appeals of a lower court order requiring the New York Police Department to fulfill its legal obligation to protect antiwar demonstrators on this Memorial Day weekend removes an unwarranted slur on the entire police foreeone that was particularly unfor tunate in a week when two young policemen were brutally killed in the line of duty.

title: FOREIGN MARKETS CONTINUE GAINS
description: Prices on foreign stock mar kets continued a general ad vance yesterday in response to the further gain by Wall Street on Thursday. The rise yesterday was more moderate, however, than on the previous day.

title: 7 House Democrats Begin Jockeying for Election as Floor Leader
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 Dan Rostenkowski was born the year that John W. McCor mack entered Congress. That was 1928.

title: Trustee Being Sought
description: ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) Henry J. Richter & Co., a bro kerage concern enjoined earlier this week from engaging in stock transactions, filed an in voluntary bankruptcy petition today in United States District Court.

title: Wrestling Site Chosen
description: Wisconsin State College in Superior, Wis., was named yes terday the site for the United States amateur wrestling asso ciation's June 13 to July 2 training camp. The United States team will compete in the 1970 world championships at Edmonton, Alberta.

title: Cancer Parley Site Chosen
description: HOUSTON, May 29 (AP) Florence, Italy, was selected to day as the site of the 1974 International Cancer Congress. The congress is held every four years.

title: Barbirolli in Hospital
description: LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) Sir John Barbirolli, the con ductor, was taken to a hospital here today after a minor upset while rehearsing the New Phil harmonia Orchestra in a local hall. Sir John, who is 70 years old, has been the leading con ductor for the famous Halle Orchestra based in Manchester, Northern England, since 1943, and became the orchestra's con ductor laureate for life in 1968.

title: 12 Subway Bottlenecks Create Massive Delays Daily
description: Massive subway tieups af fecting thousands of riders are occurring almost daily at a dozen stations in the city, even when no equipment failures slow down the trains.

title: City Is Planning for Abortions At the Rate of 25,000 a Year
description: The municipal hospital sys tem here has committed itself to full implementation of New York's liberalized abortion law, to take effect July 1, and funds were earmarked this week to make possible 25,000 to 30,000 abortions a year on city resi dents.

title: Kimberly Updates Its Styles In Its Own Gentle Manner
description: Kimberly dresses change more quickly than Bentleys, but only because fashion is more volatile than cars.

title: Dutch Are Back in Jakarta, but They Have a New Role
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 21The Dutch are returning to Jakarta.

title: Miss Steen Wed To Gary Gomes
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 29Miss Leslie Steen and Gary Clifton Gomes were married this evening at the Reformed Church by the Rev. Charles Copenhaver.

title: U.S.JAPAN TALKS NEAR A PROPOSAL
description: TOKYO, May 29 (UPI)  Foreign Minister Kiichi Aichi said today a proposal to set tle the United StatesJapan tex tileexport issue would be com pleted over the weekend.

title: Film Rating System Attacked By Two Major Church Groups
description: A declaration that the screen industry's selfregulating film ratings system and its Produc tion Code face danger of fail ure unless remedial action is initiated immediately has been made by two leading church film offices.

title: DOW RISES 16.29 AND BREAKS 700
description: The stock market continued to steam full speed ahead yes terday, fueled by a White House statement that stopped early profit taking and pushed the averages to higher ground.

title: RENICK CONNECTS TWICE FOR LOSERS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 29The Yankees relied on two trustworthy items  strong hit ting and superb relief pitching to down the Minnesota Twins, 42, tonight before 14,194 dampanddisappointed fans at Metropolitan Stadium.

title: Article 2  No Title
John Gunther Dead; Wrote Inside Books
description: John Gunther, journalist and author of the bestselling In side books, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 1 East End Avenue.

title: Danger to Industry Seen In Jersey Sewage Ruling
description: The chief engineer of the sewage authority in the Passaic Valley said yesterday that most large industries in the most heavily populated areas of New Jersey would have to be shut dawn if the court granted a farreaching order being, sought by state officials to control wa ter pollution.

title: Argentine ExPresident Is Kidnapped
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 29 A former Argentine provisional President, Lieut. Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, was kid napped this morning by four men, two of them wearing army officer's uniforms. The Interior Minister, Gen. Fran cisco Imaz, confirmed the kid napping this afternoon at news conference.

title: MOORE SET TO REJOIN ENGLISH SOCCER TEAM
description: MEXICO CITY, May 29 Bobby Moore, captain of the English soccer team that will participate in the World Cup tournament starting here Sun day, left Mexico City today for Guadalajara, where he will re join his teammates. England, the defending champion, plays its first game Tuesday against Rumania.

title: Peronists Claim Responsibility
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 29 (AP) Twelve hours after Mr. Aram buru disappeared, a group of followers of Mr. Peron an nounced it had seized the for mer president.

title: Drug Raid in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 29 (UPI)State narcotics officers said today that they had bro ken up an operation designed to supply 10,000 mescaline tab lets to youngsters attending a pop music festival. The officers arrested four persons and seized 20 pounds of mescaline as well as a small quantity of LSD tablets and marijuana.

title: Jose Rohm Marries Miss Mary Wallau
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., May 29 Miss Mary Susan Wallau was married this evening to Jose Enrique Rohm at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alex ander Lee Wallau 2d, parents of the bride. The Rev. Vin cent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony and concele brated the nuptial mass with the Rev. John J. McLaughlin.

title: BUDAPEST CAUTIOUS ON NATO TROOP PLAN
description: BUDAPEST, May 29 (UPI) Janos Peter, the Hungarian Foreign Minister, said today that the Warsaw pact nations should take into consideration the proposal of the North At lantic Treaty Organization on mutual troop cuts in Europe.

title: A Pioneering Judge
description: In this era of militants who throw fourletter words around and are avowedly bent on overturning the Es tablishment, Constance Baker Motley's mild manner, soft voice and amiability come as a shock to those who knew her only by her formidable reputation. For 20 years, be tween 1945 and Woman 1965, Mrs. Motley fought as a law in the ver in court bat tles ties that struck down stateen forced segregation laws in the South. She worked on all the major school segregation cases supported by the Legal Defense Fund, with which she was associated during those years. As the fund's as sociate counsel, she argued and won nine civil rights cases before the. United States Supreme Court.

title: Police Find Cache of Weapons In Raid on West Side Apartment
description: A 26yearold man and his pregnant wife, wanted for questioning in connection with bombings in California, were arrested last night in an Upper West Side apartment in which detectives said they found a cache of loaded guns and radi calleft literature.

title: President, on Coast, Confers With Aides On Southeast Asia
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 29After nearly seven weeks of almost continuing crisis, President Nixon settled in here today for a vacation weekend at his Western White House.

title: Maoist Students Take Over A High School Near Paris
description: PARIS, May 29  Maoist youths seized a suburban high school building today. Riotpo lice patrols kept the Latin Quarter calm, but there were widespread signs that the last two days of rioting there had bred fresh bitterness within France's already polarized body politic.

title: Joint ThaiMalaysian Force Reports Taking 4 Red Bases
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 29 (Reuters)A joint ThaiMalay sian border force has driven Communist guerillas from four main bases in four weeks, po lice sources said today.

title: Malfatti of Italy Is Named To Head Common Market
description: BAGNAIA, Italy, May 29 The foreign ministers of the European Common Market agreed today on the Ital ian Communications Minister, Franco Maria Malfatti, as its next president.

title: SAMUEL SUISMAN
description: HARTFORD, May 29 Samuel Suisman of West Hart mord, chairman of the board of Suisman & Blumenthal, scrap metal dealers, died today at Mount Sinai Hospital after brief illness at the age of 69.

title: A House in Village, Far From Country
description: Ron Field can't see having a house in the country. I have too many frustrated friends with places in the Hamptons or Connecticut who can't get out to their house on weekends or can't get people to visit them be cause everybody else has a house too.

title: RCA Names Executive
description: Thomas J. McDermott has been named staff vice president in charge of program develop ment for Select A Vision, RCA's new color television playback system, it was announced yes terday by Chase Morsey Jr., executive vice president. Before joining RCA, Mr. McDermott was president of his own pro duction firm, serving as a con sultant in broadcasting and de veloping program ideas for tele vision series and motion pic tures.

title: Human Relations Unit Urged
description: WARREN, Mich., May 29 (AP)The City Council in this Detroit suburb gave prelimi nary approval last night to creation of a citizen's human relations hoard in a step aimed at qualifying the city for at least $10million in Federal funds.

title: Hoover Lauds Chandler
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation, has congratulated for mer Gov. A. B. Chandler of Kentucky for striking an ag gressive student in the nose during a campus demonstration.

title: Rogers in Lisbon
description: LISBON, May 29 (Reuters) Secretary of State Rogers ar rived here from Madrid today on the last stage of his round of talks in European capitals. He is scheduled to leave for Washington Sunday.

title: De Beers Sees No Threat In G.E. Diamond Discovery
description: LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) The largest diamond mining combine in the world today said it had little to fear and was not altering future plans because of an announcement by General Electric yesterday that it has developed a process to make clear, gemquality diamonds.

title: Ceylon Leader Sworn In; Policeman Dies in Clash
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 29 (AP)Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaran aike was sworn in today as Ceylon's Prime Minister while 5,000 of her supporters at tacked the offices of the coun try's largest newspaper group. Later, a policeman was killed during another demonstration.

title: SHANKER IS FREED AFTER JAIL TERM
description: Albert Shanker was released from Civil Jail yesterday after serving a 15day sentence for leading the illegal teacher strikes in 1968 here.

title: Commodity Market Closed
description: The commodity exchanges were closed yesterday in ob servance of the Memorial Day Holiday.

title: Peace Seats Ruled Out
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 29 (AP) The Kansas Board of Regents informed Gov. Robert Docking today that there would be no special seating section or recog nition for peace advocates at commencement exercises Mon day at the University of Kansas.

title: Births
description: BARNESMr. and Mrs. Richard K. Barnes of Mt. Kisco, N. Y. announce the birth of a daughter, Amanda Knapp, on May 18, 1970.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To Back President

title: Topics: The Chinese Way Is Not Aggressive War
description: Will the Chinese make ag gressive war one of these days?by a foreign power on her soil. To the Chinese mind, the armies of the United Nations, in this case mainly American Armies, being on Korean soil, were aggressors therefore, and China behaved as she had al ways done. She sent a volun teer army to help Korea.

title: Sawchuk, Rangers' Goalie, Moved to Hospital in City
description: Terry Sawchuk, the New York Rangers' goalie was trans ferred to New York Hospital yesterday from Long Beach, (L. I.) Memorial Hospital and was reported in serious condi tion.

title: GOOD CHASE PACES A MILE IN 1:59
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 29 Good Chase of New Zealand and Del Insko of South Beloit, Ill., collaborated handsomely and daringly tonight to break their losing streaks at Roose velt Raceway.

title: SEYMOUR ROSEN
description: Seymour Rosen, chairman of the board of Combined Media, Inc., a holding company of communications concerns at 10 East 40th Street, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 52 years old and lived at 147 Darling Avenue, New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: Cynthia Owens Wed in Jersey
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., May 30Miss Cynthia Ann Owens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sydney Owens of Summit, was married here this afternoon to Paul L. Lurix Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Lurix of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: 11 IN SOUTH DAKOTA RUN FOR CONGRESS
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D., May 30 South Dakota voters will re place both of their members of the United States House of Representatives this year and in Tuesday's primary there will be 11 candidates for the two positions.

title: Jacobs Colt Is Easy Victor In $128 400 Jersey Derby
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 30Personality tuned up for next. Saturday's Belinont Stakes today with a snappy $83,460 workout at Garden State Park.

title: Seattle Divided by Controversy Over Slaying of Black by Police
description: SEATTLE, May 30The fatal shooting of a black man by white Seattle policeman has di vided this city and led to an attack on the inquest method of investigating such occur rences.

title: Host Mexico Opposes Soviet Union Today in World Cup Soccer Opener
description: MEXICO CITY, May 30The ninth world soccer champion ship begins here tomorrow when the Mexican national team plays the Soviet Union at Aztec Stadium.

title: Educator Weds Susan Forbes
description: SUDBURY, Mass., May 30 Miss Susan Young Forbes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gil bert B. Forbes of Rochester, N.Y., was married here today to William Arthur Martin, an assistant professor of man agement at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Martin of Oklahoma City.

title: Panther Lawyers in New Haven Subpoena Newspaper Records
description: NEW HAVEN, May 30Law yers for Lonnie McLucas, a defendant in the impending kidnappingmurder trial here of Black Panther party mem bers, have subpoenaed repre sentatives of 16 news organ izations in an effort to show that prejudicial publicity has made a fair trial for their client impossible.

title: 747 Jet Arrives in Chicago After an Emergency Stop
description: CHICAGO, May 30 (UPI) A Pan American 747 jet finally arrived in Chicago last night on its flight from London after an unscheduled landing in Mil waukee. The pilot changed course because of a drop in oil pressure during violent thun derstorms over the Chicago area.

title: Brown, Sifford Enter Golf
description: MONTREAL, May 30 (Cana dian Press)Two of the world's top Negro golfers, Pete Brown and Charlie Sifford, are the lat est entries in the Canadian Open scheduled for June 29 through July 5 at London, Ontario, the Royal Canadian Golf Associa tion announced yesterday.

title: AREA SOCCER LEAGUE ENDS SEASON TODAY
description: The GermanAmerican Soccer League will finish its regular season today with a contest at Throgs Neck Stadium, the Bronx, between Elizabeth of New Jersey and the New York GreekAmericans.

title: All dated up
description: A highrise hot souffle is an impressive way to conclude a light spring or summer meal. The fresh dateflavored concoc tion here is not made in the traditional way, but does have the traditional lightness. This version, adapted from an old family recipe, is light and rath er moist. A citrus sauce goes with it. Another unusual date flavored dessert is a creamy, rum and date pie in a sesame seed crust. The pie, a make aheadandchill affair, has real hotweather appeal.

title: Klecatsky,Quinn Named To Row for U.S. Abroad
description: Lieut. Larry Klecatsky, a United States Navy physician from Long Island, and Thomas Quinn, a New Jersey public school teacher, will represent the United States in two international regattas in Germany next month.

title: NAVY DEFEATS ARMY IN 3 SPORTS EVENTS
Upstate Man Seized For Flying U.S.Flag With Peace Symbol
description: HAMBURG VILLAGE, N. Y., May 30 W. Fleming, former associate dean of the University of Buffalo Law School and now the university's advocate, was arrested here this afternoon and charged with descrating the flag.

title: The World
description: In the last week, Israeli lead ers have been proclaiming that the arrival of Soviet antiaircraft missiles and backup air cover in Egypt tipped the balance of power against Israel. But in the view of analysts here, the bol stered air defences created, for the first time, a deterrent bal ance between the two com batants.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Though I agree far more often than not with the Vice President, I submit that his ulti mate glory lies in an unblem ished sense of personal integ rity that by all rights should have been defeated long ago. Defeated by those who see in his presence a reminder of that which they themselves have be trayed and compromised many times over through their eva sions, halflies, Inconsistencies, unyieldinc, conformity to dog main short, an intellectual hypocrisy of the worst sort.

title: ZIONISTS OREATE UMBRELLA GROUP
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30  A new organization has been es tablished to coordinate major Zionist activities in this country and enroll American Jews in groups not now affiliated with the Zionist movement.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The adventures of rogues lie on a wellweathered fringe of the mystery genre, having been so well established as early as 1907 to inspire a booklength discourse (The Literature of Roguery by Frank W. Chan dler). They are not found so widely in more recent years, consistent with a shifting em phasis from mental to physical triumphs in the genre as whole. If exploits of men who live by their extralegal wits are to rise from their literary doldrums, a debt will be owed to Robert L. Fish. We met smuggler Kek Huuygens in Mr. Fish's 1967 novel The Hoch mann Miniatures, and now he is back again in WHRLIGIG (World, $5.95).

title: KeysinCar Penalty Voted
description: LEXINGTON, Ky, May 28 (UPI)  The City Commission voted today to impose fines of up to $100 on motorists who leave ignition keys in their cars while the vehicle is parked on a public street..

title: Laborers Accept Offer
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., May 30 (AP)Members of Local 66 of the Laborers International Union have accepted a contract offered by the Association of General Contractors, ending a fourweek strike here.

title: Leftist Victory In Ceylon
description: Mrs. Sirimavo Bandara naike is a conventeducated Buddhist who entered poli tics when her husband, the Prime Minister of Ceylon, was assassinated in 1959. A year later she was in office herself as the world's first woman Prime Minister. Her Government, in which Cey lon's Trotskyite party and small Moscoworiented Com munist party played minority roles, took over private and religious schools and nation alized life insurance compa nies, but fell in 1965 when it tried to nationalize the press.

title: Family Plans 11th Year as Part Of a Fresh Air Fund Program
description: This summer will mark the 11th consecutive year that Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Gilbert of Yorktown Heights, N. Y., and their six children have served as hosts in the Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Town program.

title: French Youth: Maoists On a Rampage
description: PARISMao! Mao! Mao! the chant rang down the boulevards to the rubadub beat of sticks on garbage cans. Student rioters surged through Paris's Latin Quarter this past sunny spring week, as they have now and then ever since the high Middle Ages.

title: Coins
description: THE history of man's space explorations is depicted in the June exhibition at the Chase Manhattan Bank Money Mu seum, 1254 Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street. Equipment used by the first, as well as the current astro nauts, plus pictures and stories related to their experiments, are among the hundreds of items in the Man in Space display.

title: Monmouth to Begin Centennial Anniversary With Tomorrow's Opening
description: When the first Monmouth Park opened on July 30, 1870, it helped make Long Branch, N. J., the focal point of sum mer social lifean unbeat able team of resort and sport, as one journal put it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: With regard to Ada Louise Huxtable's comments on the new Juilliard Theater [May 24] one wonders whether ar chitects and architectural cri tics reason from bases quite different from those which distinguish laymen.

title: FasigTipton Will Auction Horses in Kentucky Again
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., May 30 (AP)  FasigTipton Co., the New Yorkbased firm that ranks with the Keeneland Association as the largest thoroughbred auction companies in the na tion, announced yesterday it would return to the Bluegrass sales market Oct. 5.

title: Col. Llewellyn Fondly Recalls His Heyday Aboard Foxhunter
description: DEVON, Pa., May 30  Lieut. Col. Harry Llewellyn, probably the greatest rider of show jumpers in the his tory of Britain, hasn't been in the ring in competition for 13 years.

title: Low Vote Is Expected Tuesday In Iowa Governorship Primary
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, May 30 The lowest voter turnout at an Iowa primary election in 25 years has been predicted by Secretary of State Melvin Syn horst.

title: Johnson Resigns Tulsa Post
description: TULSA, Ukla., May 30 (UPI) Reed Johnson, the Tulsa Uni versity assistant football coach, resigned yesterday to accept the defensive backfield job at New Mexico and Tom Ososkie, a graduate assistant, was hired on a fulltime basis.

title: 4 LOCAL WOMEN GAIN WORLD TRACK SPOTS
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 30 Four members of Bedford Stuyvesant's Adams track club qualified today at the National Collegiate women's track cham pionships at the University of Illinois to represent the United States at the World University Games in Italy this summer.

title: NORWALK ISLANDS BEING CLEANED UP
description: RAM ISLAND, NORWALK, Conn.Earth Day has started spreading from the land to the sea in Long Island Sound.

title: Architecture
description: THE greatest nation in the world stumbles on in the fight for the environment.
