We give you the story of historic preservation and urban re newal, as the greatest nation in the world has pursued the objectives of saving its her itage and its inner cities, while losing almost every round.

title: Maior League Baseball
description: Sunday, May 31, 1970

title: Gardens
description: IN today's world our senses are assaulted by strong colors used not for contrast but for im pact. In art, great splashes of orange, purple and red on large canvases are intended to shock and excite. In grand mother's day, gardens were colorfully quiet, with pastels, creams, whites and rosey pinks. In recent years, hy bridists have developed flow ers of strong and vibrant shades for bold color effects. The more subtle and misty shades add contrast, separate otherwise clashing colors.

title: Bullet Is Taken From G.I.'s Heart
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30 (AP)Army surgeons have removed an enemy bul let from the heart of a 20 yearold American soldier. Pfc. Donald H. Light of Red bud, 1ll., who was wounded in Cambodia Tuesday, was reported in good condition today and was able to talk with members of his family by telephone.

title: Demonstration in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, May 30 (Reu ters)  About 100 youths ran through Raffles Square in cen tral Singapore today and smashed windows in a British bank in what the police de demonstration. The police ar rested four demonstrators as the crowd dispersed.

title: Bonn Navy Ship Damaged
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 30 (AP)One man was killed and two were injured today in a gas explosion that ripped a hole in the side of the West German destroyer Bayern. The police said the explosion had occurred in an empty munitions storeroom where the fatally injured man, ?? oivilian, was doing welding work.

title: U.S. GENERAL DENIES OKINAWAN CHARGE
description: NAHA, Okinawa, May 30 The commander of the United States Army here has cate gorically denied as unfound ed the charges that veterans' organizations on military in stallations in Okinawa were selling taxfree alcoholic bev erages and tobacco products to unauthorized persons and per mitting them to play slot machines.

title: Natural Landscaping Yields Dividends
description: THE trend toward natural landscap ing welcomes native shrubs and small trees to the home property. Where taller oaks, hickories, beeches and hemlocks are left as natural setting, smaller natives provide delicate spring bloom, interesting sum mer fruit and fall color, as well as an irresistible attraction for bird life. To those who as children loved the woods, they bring also a bit of nostalgia.

title: The truth is there in essence, if not in details
description: After the recent autobiographies of Lillian Gish and Brian Aherne, both models of their kind, Pola Negri's longpromised book repre sents very much the other side of the coin. Together with Greta Garbo and Gloria Swanson, Miss Negri is the last of the tempestuous Great Ladies of the silent screen, and the first one since Mae Murray to wrap up a colorful career with an even more colorful volume of memoirs. She rises to the occasion superbly: it is written with dash, flourish, cine matic understatement here, dramatic overemphasis here. The only trouble and this is a criticism only in terms of its value as a reference work, certainly not in terms of its entertaining readabilityis that one cannot ever really believe it.

title: Anne D. Nelson Becomes Bride
description: BALTIMORE, May 30 Miss Anne Demarest Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nor man Travers Nelson, was married here today to Mah lon Apgar 4th, son of Mrs. Dorothea Tipper Apgar of Baltimore and Mahlon Apgar of Ridgewood, N. J.

title: In The Nation: Bitter Fruit in Charlotte
description: WASHINGTONThe Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that the city of Charlotte, N.C., need not go so far in the desegregation of its school sys tem (84,000 students, about 30 per cent of them black) as Dis trict Judge J. B. McMillan had ordered. Instead, the Circuit Court directed for the city's elementary schools the prepa ration of a new desegregation plan that would meet a stand ard of reasonableness, even if that plan permitted some all black schools to remain in ex istence.

title: Down, Up And Up A Wild Week for Market
description: The [stock] market is not a weighing machine, on which the value of each issue is re corded by an exact and imper sonal mechanism, in accord ance with its specific qualities. Rather should we say that the market is a voting machine whereon countless individuals register choices which are the product partly of reason and partly of emotions.

title: LeRoi Jones Defines Role in Newark Race
description: NEWARK, May 30Kenneth A. Gibson's most controversial supporter, LeRoi Jones, the poet and playwright, has cate gorized his involvement in the black mayoral candidate's cam paign as the sort of thing open to any citizen backing the man of his choice.

title: Ghosts Are CleverSo I Baffle Them
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.A stairway that leads nowhere, a window that opens to reveal only a wall, doorway that leads to nothing. These are parts of a disjointed, 160 room Victorian mansion that Mrs. Sarah Winchester built on the north ern outskirts of San Jose after the sudden loss of both her husband, the son of Oliver Fisher Winchester, the rifle magnate, and her daughter.

title: African Officers to Visit U.S.
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 30 (Agence FrancePresse) Eight Frenchspeaking army officers from West African nations left here today for a month's factfinding tour of the United States. They will study tactics and military procedures that could possibly be applied in West Africa.

title: Ginger Baker, CultHero
description: LONDON THE night before I in terviewed him, Ginger Baker was very drunk. He had worked through a whole bottle of Scotch and gone to an Indian restaurant, where he clashed with two strangers, who were also drunk and who started singing dirty songs. One of them was bald and he made Baker angry. So Baker stood up, grabbed a coffee pot and raised it high in the air. Bald heads split easy, he said, and the bald man was frightened and backed away, leaving Baker triumphant.

title: JAMS DABBS, 74, LIBERAL IN SOUTH
description: James McBride Dabbs, a product of plantation aristoc racy who became one of the leading Southern exponents of integration, died yesterday at Rip Raps, his family's ancestral plantation near Mayesville, S.C. His ace was 74.

title: JAZZ GROUPS JOIN IN SPIRIT OF LOVE
description: Jazz concerts tend to be slapdash variations of some thing that might be encountered in a nightclub, but the concert by the McCoy Tyner Quartet and the Yusef Lateef Quartet at Town Hall on Friday night was the real thingplanned, prepared and executed specifi cally for the concert hall. And it was far better jazz than is usually heard in the slapdash offerings.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN POLICE MURDER
description: A 21yearold man was ar raigned yesterday in Criminal Court in Brooklyn on a charge of murdering an offduty po liceman last Monday at hamburger stand in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Someone There Is Who Loves a Wall
description: DAVID BLOMBERG loves walls. He dotes on walls: nice, big, flat walls of buildings on which artists can paint vibrating blues, yellows and greens, ar ranged in abstract patterns. He walks around New York with his head in the air, look ing at walls, thinking how nice it would be if the dirty, weathered bricks could be covered with art forms that would bring gaiety to the neighborhood and joy to the viewer.

title: Granite Workers Agree
description: BARRE, Vt., May 30, AP Striking granite workers in Barre, Vt., voted 435108 today to accept a contract proposal and return to work Monday, ending a fourweek strike.

title: NODULE SCORES IN METROPOLITAN
description: Nodouble traveled the fastest mile ever run at Belmont Park in winning the $114,600 Metro politan Handicap yesterday. The steady Arkansasbred, owned by the Verna Lea Farm, came from off the pace to beat Og den Phipps's favored Reviewer by a head in the 77th running of the event.

title: ATrip With Rosenquist
description: OF the four top Ameri can Pop artists (in cluding Andy Warhol, Claes Oldenburg and Roy Lichtenstein), James Rosenquist is the only one who has not had a major retrospective devoted to his works this season. And, while I am generally opposed to rushjob retrospectives for artists whose careers span barely a decade, Rosenquist is the one Pop artist whose oeuvre I would really like to see gathered together. For he has been consistently the most changeable, difficult and problematicconsistent ly the most inconsistent, as it weremember of the club. Curatorial nerve being what it is, however, a relatively orderly body of work (such as Lichtenstein's, Oldenburg's or Frank Stella's), though it stands least in need of retro spective presentation, almost always gets the nod over one that's more truly various.

title: Lund Gains Pole Position For Delaware 250 Today
description: DOVER Del., May 30 (AP) Tiny Lund, seeking his record tying 12th straight victory, re corded the best qualifying time of 129.917 miles an hour today to win the pole position for tomorrow's Diamond State 250 at Dover Downs International Speedway.

title: Rower Across Pacific Quits
description: TOKYO, May 31 (AP)  Arthur Hornsby of Osset, Eng land, who set out from Japan a month ago hoping to be the first man to row alone across the Pacific, was towed into the Japanese port of Kamaishi to night, complaining of fatigue and blisters. He was found by Japanese fishermen about 30 miles off the coast of north eastern Honshu, Japan's main island.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Miss Sheila Hennessey Is Doctor's Bride
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 30 Miss Sheila Louise Hennes sey and Dr. Giuseppe Enrico Mignone were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows. The Rev. Robert Sealy, chairman of the de partment of modern lan guages at Fordham Univer sity, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Adolfo Bartolini.

title: 12 Powerboats Race at Tampa Today
description: The big boats will go into action this week both on the ocean and on the bay, starting with the Suncoast Cup race for unlimited hydroplanes in Tampa today and then in the Bahamas on Friday for a world cham pionship 500mile offshore con test.

title: Press in Argentina Leads a Risky Life
description: BUENOS AIRES  In explicably, the French movie Z, an attack on military totalitarianism, got by Ar gentina's censors. Crowds of Buenos Aires residents packed the street waiting to see the film and cheered the downfall of the movie's main villain, a general who bears a striking physical similarity to Argentina's Interior Min ister.

title: Unveilings
description: CHERNOWSKYWalter M. In toying memory of my darling husband, unveiling will take place Sunday, June 7, 1 P.M., at Adath Jehurun Cemetery, West Roxbury, Mass.

title: R.O.T.C. PROTESTS WORRY PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI)More than 30 Reserve Officers Training Corps build ings have been firebombed on campuses this term by antiwar protesters, and the Defense De Dartment is worried.

title: 4 Prizes Await the Top Dog at Greenwich
description: A trophy in memory of Jo seph C. Quirk, widely known in show and field trial cir cles, will go to the bestin show winner at next Satur day's Greenwich Kennel Club event. The silver bowl brings to four the number of prizes the winning doe will acauire.

title: Bridal Market Gains a Star
description: Looking crisp in pants and a starched white tunic with ascot, Maureen O'Sullivan sipped a midafternoon crme de menthe recently in the liv ing room of her apartment overlooking Central Park. She was discussiniz her latest role.

title: Warships May Be Used As Floating Factories
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 23The Federal Gov ernment is considering the possibility of utilizing obso lescent World War II cargo ships as floating factories for the assembly and service of prefabricated homes.

title: The newest heroes in Catholicismasentertainment
description: If someone was asked 15 years ago whether the Roman Catholic Church would become one of the prime commodities offered by The New Yorker magazine, the first re action would be to doubt the sanity of the question asker. While it was supposed that The New Yorker would continue to run J. F. Powers's short stories, nobody would have expected that its editors would consider the Catholic Church permanent enter tainment material.

title: Now He's Curious (Striped)
Article 4  No Title
Television
description: ALONG with the rest of the economy, televi sion is facing anxious months ahead. Not only are sponsors hedging their bets by not making too many firm commitments be yond January 1, but already the sales of spot announce ments on a network basis are proving soft, while the sales of local spot announcements around the country are ap parently even softer.

title: Harvard Law Student Gets 6 Months in War Protest
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30 (AP)Judge Lawrence F. Fel oney has sentenced a Harvard Law School student to six months in jail and lectured him for arrogant demeanor in Cambridge District Court.

title: Shriver Backers Gloomy About Party
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Be hind the widely publicized agonizing of Sargent Shriver over whether to run for Gover nor of Marylandand if not, what political alternative would be usefulthere lies an as sessment by a group of young liberal Democrats in Congress that their party is nationally leaderless and next to dead at a time of unequalled American peril.

title: PennCornell Track Team To Meet OxfordCambridge
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP)  A combined PennCornell track team will meet an Ox fordCambridge team June 11 in London officials said today.

title: The Way We Speak Body Language
description: A NUMBER of the country's top flight psychiatrists have taken their patients on a trip to Philadelphia in recent years for a visit to a research lab at the Eastern Pennsylvania Psychiatric Institute. There, psychiatrist and patient hold a therapy session while movie cameras purr in the background. Psycho therapy is perhaps the most verbal of all 20thcentury experiences. Yet what the filmmakers are primarily interested in is nonverbal communi cation: shifts of posture and muscle cont="y">tone, gestures, eye movements, and the like. They are looking for recur ring patterns, the constellations of tone, gestures, eye movements, and the like. They are looking for recur ring patterns, the constellations of body movement which they see as kind of subliminal language that can be translated by the trained inter preter.

title: To Achieve Price Stability
description: Bipartisan pressures are building on President Nixon to act against inflationary wage and price de cisions. Last week the Democrats on the House Bank ing and Currency Committee voted to give the Presi dent the power, for eight months, to freeze wages, prices and rents. And three Republican Senators, led by Jacob K. Javits or New York, proposed that the President's Council of Economic Advisers hold up to public scrutiny price decisions and collective bargain ina agreements with inflationary potential.

title: The World
description: The World

title: A PUBLIC HEARING SET ON OIL LEASES
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The first public hearing on the pos sible leasing of more Federal offshore oil and gas lands will be held next month.

title: THE OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: THE NUNS  Tomorrow, Cherry Lane, 38 Commerce Street, 7. A play by Edu ardo Manet, English adap tation by Don Parker and Paul Verdier.

title: ADDONIZIO TRIAL STARTS TUESDAY
description: The trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and 12 other men on charges of extor tion will open Tuesday in Fed eral Court in Trenton, 14 days before the Mayor faces a run off election to determine wheth er he succeeds himself in office.

title: BLACK DEMOCRATS PLAN OWN PARTY
description: CLEVELAND, May 30  A group of Negro Democrats, dis satisfied with the recent elec tion of Democratic party offi cials, are planning to go their own way in the future.

title: All The News Fit to Smoke
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 30 A new fortnightly newspaper to be published in Papua, New Guinea, in pidgin English will be called Wantok, which is pidgin for Friend. Its editors promise a wide coverage of world and New Guinean news and as a special selling point announce that the paper will be nambawan smokpepa that is, the pages will be emi nently suitable for cigarette paper.

title: A.I.A. Awards For 70 Given To 14 Entries
description: BUILDINGS as diverse as a skyscraper apartment house in Chicago, a small residence outside Washington and a laboratory complex at Cornell University have been selected for honors in excellence of design by the American Institute of Architects.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TODAY

title: Photography
description: THE newest photography show at the enterpris ing New York Cultural Center is entitled The Photograph as a Permanent Color Print, and I would as soon try to write up the en tire Frick Collection in a paragraph as try to review it nicture by nicture, or even photographer by photogra pher, in the space at my dis posal. The show consists of 50 large color prints by 13 of the world's most famous living practitioners of the art. The full lineup, in alphabet ical order, is: Ansel Adams, Arthur d'Arazien, Eliot Elis ofon, Andreas Feininger, Toni Frissell, Philippe Hals man, Art Kane, Victor Kepp ler, Erich Lessing, Gordon Parks, Emil Schulthess, How ard Sochurek and Pete Turn er. See what I mean by fa mous? Seven of the 13 have won international reputations through their work for Life magazine. The others are known through reproductions in other magazines and in books, as well as through mu seum and exhibitions.

title: Jane Morgan Birchard Is a Bride
description: LENOX, Mass., May 30 Miss Jane Morgan Birchard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ar thur Ramage Birchard Jr., was married here at noon today to David Moulton Kel logg 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kellogg Jr. of Weston.

description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., May 30Miss Valerie Van Houten, daughter of Dr. Robert W. Van Houten, president of Newark College of Engineer ing, and Mrs. Van Houten, was married here this noon to Ens. Gary Scott Smith, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Denton L. Smith of West Simsbury, Conn.

description: BUENOS AIRES, May 30 (Reuters)A search was begun today for former provisional president Pedro Eugenio Aram buru, who was kidnapped from his home here early yesterday.

description: Thomas M. Roberts has been named captain of the 1971 golf team at Lafayette College.

description: RYE, N. Y., May 30Miss Jennifer Kern and Peter M. Bloomsburgh were married here today in Christ Epis copal Church by the Rev. Wendell Phillips.

title: Can Nixon Avoid the Controls Which He Abhors?
description: WASHINGTON  The puz zling, and in some respects dis appointing, performance of the American economy led last week to a new wave of support for some form of direct Government intervention in the setting of prices and wages.

title: Article 3  No Title
Mrs. Morris Tulipan Dies; Brooklyn Welfare Leader
description: Mrs. Minnie Shonkoff Tu lipan, welfare administrator and former director of social service at the Kingsbrook Jew ish Medical Center in Brook lyn, died there today. She was 76 years old and lived at 822 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: SON MAY OPPOSE DEARBORN MAYOR
description: DEARBORN, Mich, May 30 (AP)John Jay Hubbard, the son of Mayor Orville Hubbard, the man who has held this Detroit suburb's top elected of fice for 29 years, has taken out petitions to run for mayor in the fall.

title: For a Freewheeling Holiday: Pedal Power
description: AVEHICLE that neither pollutes the air nor raises the noise level, that permits a passenger to es cape crowded highways and see the countryside at close range, is en abling everincreasing numbers of Americans to enjoy a new kind of va cation trip that is as old as the hills.

title: 6 Die as Plane Plunges Into Car on Atlanta Highway
description: ATLANTA, May 30A pri vate plane carrying 36 per sons 32 on a landbuying excursion to Florida and a crew of fourcrashlanded to day atop an automobile on an interstate highway, killing at least six persons and injur ing 35 others. A man and a woman and three chil dren died in the white, 1963 model car that was flattened by the crippled plane. The Martin 404, a twinengine craft, was attempting an emergency landing in the rain on a grassy median strip di viding Interstate 285. The sixth victim was a guest aboard the flight to Fort My ers, Fla., where Lehigh Acres Inc. is developing a large tract of land. The passengers had been offered a free Memorial Day trip to the Gulf Coast site to examine land. A Fed eral Aviation Administration official, Jack Barker, said the pilot lost the use of one engine about 9:21 A.M., five minutes after takeoff, and was directed to make an instrument landing at the main Atlanta Airport south of the city.

title: Friendly Obstacles Spice Grossinger's New Course
description: With the joy of a week end golfer finally getting even, Paul Grossinger shout ed, Oh, I'm so happy. The architect hit his own tree.

title: SOVIET FILM FRANK ON YOUTH CRIMES
description: MOSCOW, May 30  On a warm April night, a teenage boy is talking with his girl friend in the courtyard of a new highrise apartment house, in Moscow when they are sud denly and senselessly attacked by four other youths.

title: Bridge
description: An anecdote of great antiquity concerns the experienced moth er who instructs her older son to check the activities of his smaller brother: Go and see what Donald's doing, and stop him doing it. Sub stitute declarer for Donald and you have a sound rule for bridge defenders. If you can work out why the declarer is adopting a particular line of play, you may be able to de vise a countermeasure.

title: A Building in City Slips Unnoticed Into Foreclosure
description: THE fivestory walkup at 120 East 102d Street in East Harlem went through a change in life a few days ago, unknown to most of the 18 impoverished families that live there.

description: NEW DELHI, May 30  A smile flashed by Mao Tse tung at Indian and Soviet envoys in Peking during the May Day reception seems to have caused stir among diplomats here.

title: Reagan Loses Appeal To Bar His Own Voice
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 30 (AP)The oneminute po litical commercial on radio begins with a woman's voice saying: Governor Reagan said it on Jan. 7, 1967.

description: The city must develop a com petent workforce for the future or look forward to an accel eration in increasing costs and deteriorating public services, Solomon Hoberman, the city's Personnel Director and chair man of the Civil Service Com mision, has declared.

description: Tourists visiting New York for the first time frequently come to the city with much the same attitude that Dante had approaching the Inferno: it would be a fascinating expe rience, provided they came out alive.

description: Milt Williams, a guard who played a key role in the Eastern League basketball championship drive by the Allentown Jets last season, has signed with New York Knickerbockers.

description: MOSCOW, May 30Zhores A. Medvedev, a Russian biolo gist known for his attacks on the genetic theories made offi cial during the Stalin era, was reportedly arrested yesterday.

title: Personality :
description: Would he come up to New York immediately? Yes, he would, but what was up? Don't ask until you get here, was the gist of the cryptic reply. Industries, Inc., for reasons unknown.

title: Berkeley Council Rejects Copter Patrols by Police
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 30 A police proposal to purchase two helicopters for aerial sur veillance of this east bay city was defeated this week when the Berkeley City Council voted of remove from the 197071 municipal budget the $60,000 needed to begin the program.

title: Benjamin Brenner Dead at 66; ExState Supreme Court Justice
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., May 30 Benjamin Brenner, who re tired last December from the New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn because of ill health, died today of a heart ailment in Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and had moved from Brooklyn to Fort Lauderdale.

title: Alan Dunning Weds Anne Cuckler
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 30 Miss Anne Catherine Cuck ler, who will be a senior at Yale College this fall, was married here this afternoon to Alan Smith Dunning, a stu dent at Yale's Law School.

title: Cairo Concerned At Israel Reaction to Soviet Role
description: CAIRO"If the Israelis think they can provoke the Soviet Union, they had better consider the consequences first. This comment by a Russian in Cairo was made without elaboration a few days ago amid a growing sense of uneasiness over Israeli outcries against the bolstered Soviet military assistance to Egypt.

title: Drive to Top of Racing World Is Mostly Downhill for Unser
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 No auto race driver ever won so much money, about $300, 000, so easily as did Al Unser today capturing the Indiana polis 500. In an event fraught with dangers and disasters, everything went well for Un ser, the little brother of a famous racing family from Albuquerque. N. M.

title: SWEDEN VIGOROUS IN POLLUTION WAR
description: STOCKHOLM, May 30  Sweden, long a social laboratory and lately a center for radical politics, is attracting increasing attention for her broad, en thusiastic fight against pollu tion.

title: Convention Site Shifted
description: DEVON, Pa., May 30The board of directors of the Ameri can Horse Shows Association switched the site today of the 1971 convention from Char lottesville, Va., to Washington. The meeting is scheduled for Jan. 14 through 16 at the May flower Hotel.

title: National Seashore Parks Struggle With Vast Crowds and Litter
description: ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, Md.This, place already gets so jammed in summer that there are days when we cant'cope with all the peo ple, the park ranger said as he drove a visitor along the bumpy beach road at Assa teague Island National Sea shore, the country's newest Federally operated coastal recreation site.

title: Klemperer Has Always Come Back
description: LONDON. IN 1907, Gustav Mahler scribbled on his calling card a recommendation for an aspiring 22yearold conduc tor, Otto Klemperer. A few days ago, Klemperer celebrated his 85th birthday here with a rendering of Mah ler's Das Lied von der Erde that drew standing ovations at the Royal Festival Hall.

title: Kirstein Argues About Petrouchka
description: To THE EDITOR: INFORMATION provided, prestige maintained by The New York Times must be an onerous re sponsibility; its unique serv ices must weigh heavy on re porters, critics and editors. Not only are their opinions definitive, but, due to gen eral apathy or inertia, they filter down to weekly, month ly and annual journals to stand for an historical truth. The Delphic oracles had the advantage of ambiguity which priests interpreted po litically to their convenience; this has not been the case Times.

title: New Battle Cry Inspires Mac Foster
description: Emotionally, it affected Mac Foster because the memory of where he was at the time has stayed with him.

description: GREENWICH, Conn. May 30 Jacques F. Bulterman, by 1 minute 55 seconds 25 boat lengths with his Luders16, On rust, and Thomas Hume, by 1:03 and 15 lengths with his shields Class sloop, Pantomime, won their second races in two starts on Long Island Sound yesterday when the Belle Haven Club conducted the fifth cham pionship regata of the Yacht Racing Association season for fleets based eastofRye.

title: Joanne Babcock, Gerard Hallock Wed in Suburbs

I. The Rev. Frederick B. Stim son Jr. performed the cere mony.

title: The School Bus Issue
description: The ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit sanctioning more limited school Integration need not be a body blow to desegregation. The question is whether the court's 4to2 ruling will be viewed as a rational attempt to bring about orderly desegregation in compliance with past court orders or as a signal to segregationists to renew their mas sive resistance.

title: What's New in the Theater?
description: THE ME NOBODY KNOWS, a musical by Gary William Friedman and Will Holt, got an enthusiastic recep tion from five critics, mixed from two and turn downs from three. Clive Barnes: I loved it. I loved its understanding and com passion, and I felt its pain and yet also its un sentimental determination for hope. This dark and lovely rock musical has a strange genesis. Stephen M. Joseph teaches in the ghetto. A year ago he col lected some writings from his classes. The result was a published anthology of children's voices from the ghetto. This writing is enormously vivid and hon est. Herb Schapiro had the idea to transform this anthology into a musical and with the help of Gary William Friedman's elo quent music and Will Holt's tersely apt yet poet ic lyrics, the work is somehow both bitter and joyous. This is not only one of the most meaningful and ultimately joyful shows of the season, it is also technically one of the more advanced. For Walter Kerr, see page 1.

title: Phyllis Rowley Will Be Bride Of Carl Jacob Schmidlapp 3d

I. A Sep tember wedding is planned.

description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Hal Randel man of New York on May 12 in Le Roy Hospital. Mrs. Randelman is the former Miss Nancy Cypres of New York. The child has been named Nicole Leigh. Her father is television producer with Grey Advertising, Inc.

title: Johnny Hodges 19061970
description: FOR the better part of 40 years, Johnny Hodges sat in the midst of the saxophone section in Duke Ellington's orchestra, his face an expressionless, impassive mask as he studied the dancers and concert au diences that passed before him night after night. When he stood up, a short, com pact man, and strode out in front of the band to play solo, he spread his legs in stolid, flatfooted stance, his eyes coolly surveying the distant corners of the hall. He seemed casual to the point of utter disinterest. And then, with a shrugging tug at his pants, he swung his alto saxophone into posi tion and began to play.

description: A University of Pennsylvania heavyweight eight swept to a twolength victory at the New York Rowing Association's 103d annual regatta yesterday.

description: JERUSALEM, May 30Arab shops in Jerusalem were closed today in a silent demonstra tion of resistance to Israeli rule in East Jerusalem, the Arabpopulated part of the city.

title: Ron Lunt and Linda Fontanne?
description: OPENING night of Room Service at the Edison Theater Ron Leibman cried. For a few brief mo ments in the privacy of his star dressing room, he covered his face with his hands and sobbed. But as soon as places were called, he raced out on the stage quivering with energy and proceeded to whoop snort and dance his way through the show. Clive Barnes likened his performance to an overactive washing ma chine. John Lahr called him a great clown. The show is a hit and certainly much of the credit is due to Leib man's originality and forcefulness.

title: Red Sox Top White Sox, 75, on 6thInning Homer by Ramo, Relief Pitcher

Samuels, cam paigning yesterday at the Brooklyn beaches with his wife, Bobbi, and their four daugh ters, aged 11 to 24, urged that hereafter Memorial Day be ob served also as a national day of sanity in which the genera tions would communicate with each other. title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE reactions of your re viewers to Mod Don na follow the pre: dictable pattern of antifeminist polemics. First ridicule, which Walter Kerr knows makes dandy, titillat ing reading and avoids con fronting an issue seriously, then the almost hysterical fear expressed by Grace Glueck that women are being divested of their femininity which seems to be embodied in the brassiere, that ultimate symbol of American woman hood.

The Greek Colonels are part of an old tradition
description: It is not necessary to carry a torch for the Greek Colonels to suggest that ever since their midnight coup three years ago they have had a dispropor tionately bad press in the Western world. Disproportionate, that is, not only to what is said about comparable regimes elsewhere, but also to what is known about Greek history, ancient, medieval and modern.

description: A tank truck delivering liquid oxygen exploded outside the Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday morning, killing two persons and injuring 40 others, including 30 pa tients, none seriously.

description: By tonight some 8,000 American families will have had their Memorial Day week end ruined because someone stole their car. And to make matters worse about 1,500 of these 8,000 stolen cars will have been involved in accidents, some of them fatal.

description: TEL AVIV.

title: Going to hell in a wheelbarrowone man's view of the country
description: While reading The End of the American Era I acquired the im pression that Andrew Hacker, its au thor, had to be a fogy, 100 years old or so. Dutifully I checked Who's Who and I found, instead, that Mr. Hacker a, professor of government at Cornell, is a Republican and only 40. Far too young, I thought, for such utter disillusion and worldweariness. Alas, not even Senator Goldwater had betrayed as much despair as Mr. Hacker at the nation's loss of its moral fiber, and even the Weather men have demonstrated more faith than he in our future. Indeed. Andrew Hacker is convinced not only that America is going to hell in a wheel barrow but, what's worse, that it's much too late to alter the course.

description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 30 Ray Huard, a 21yearold junior from Waterville, Me., has been elected captain of Princeton University's 1971 baseball team.

title: Headliners
description: I've been talking about race relations for years now, and I felt it was about time I put my life where my mouth is. With that explanation, the Rev. Leo McLaughlin, a rangy 57yearold Jesuit priest, announced last week that he would resign as chancellor of Fordham University June 30 to be come director of freshman studies at Johnson C. Smith Uni versity, a small, predominantly Negro school in Charlotte, N. C. He thus will follow the path taken by John U. Monro who left his post as dean of Harvard College in 1967 to work at Mills College, another Negro institution in Birmingham, Ala. Father McLaughlin's announcement was no great sur prise to those who know him: He has been a leader in re form at Fordham, a champion of new ideas in all fields, and a supporter of student innovation. Noting that his ac tivities as chancellor dealt almost exclusively with fund raising, Father McLaughlin said, I want to be associated with students again. I was hungry.
