title: REDS WIN IN 10TH FROM EXPOS, 5 TO 4
description: CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP)  The Cincinnati Reds, down by four runs before they Went to bat, got shutout pitching the rest of the way tonight and beat the Montreal Expos, 54, on Darrel Chaney's oneout single in the 10th inning.

title: Newport News Shipyard Plan On Minority Hiring Held Near
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Two Federal agencies were re ported close to settling a dispute over minority hiring that has held up Navy ship building contracts totaling $700million.

title: Cunard Deals With Spain
description: LONDON, May 30  The Cunard Steamship Company said that is has placed an order for eight bulkcarriers with a Spanish shipbuilding group be cause British shipyards could not compete on price and deliv ery. The order, $48million, has been awarded to Astilleros Es panoles of Madrid

title: $150,000 BAIL SET FOR 2 HELD IN RAID
description: A young couple in whose West Side apartment the police said they found a cache of weapons and some drugs in a raid Friday night were held in $150,000 bail in Criminal Court yesterday after an assistant dis trict attorney said they were wanted in California on charges of attempted murder, arson and other crimes.

title: ASTROS SUBDUED
description: The New York Mets crossed one of their last frontiers yes terday before 54,424 persons in Shea Stadium, the largest crowd of the major league baseball season.

title: Universities in Saigon, Shut May 6, to Reopen Tomorrow
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30(Reuters)  Universities and colleges in Saigon will resume classes on Monday after having been closed for more than three weeks, the Saigon radio an nounced today.

title: Laver and Emerson Reach St. Louis Net Semifinals
description: ST. LOUIS, May 30 (UPI) Rod Laver defeated Ismail El Shafei and Roy Emerson de feated Dennis Ralston today to gain the semifinal berths in the $30,000 Rawlings Classic at Dwight Davis Tennis Center.

title: Tony Kubek to Aid O.E.O.
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) Donald Rumsfeld, director of the Office of Economic Oppor tunity, has announced that a former New York Yankee base ball star, Tony Kubek, 34 years old, and former Gov. Robert Blue of Iowa, 72, has been ap pointed chairman and vice chairman of the agency's older persons advisory council.

title: Merchant's View:
description: Wait until next year the Dodger fans used to say at the end of a disastrous sea son when that ofteninept baseball team played in Brooklyn.

title: Science
description: Probably the most exciting specimen brought back by either of the first two suc cessful Apollo missions to the moon is a rock, the size of a small lemon, that is not only more ancient than any other moon sample studied so far, but is also far more radio active.

title: Marriages
description: COHENDORFMAN, Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Dorfman of East Hills, L.I., announce the marriage of their daughter, Ellen, to Mr. Steven Cohen, on Thursday, May 21, 1970.

title: Four Skippers Unbeaten In Great South Bay Sail
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., May 30 Four skippers were unbeaten after two races today in the Sayville Yacht Club's invita tion regatta in Great South Bay. The final event is slated tomorrow.

title: Irwin to Seek Dodd's Seat
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 30 Former Representative Don ald J. Irwin said last night that he would formally announce on Monday his candidacy for the States Senate on the Demo cratic ticket. The other Demo crats in the race so far are Senator Thomas J. Dodd, who is campaigning to be nom inated for reelection, Alphon sus J. Donahue of Stamford, the Rev. Joseph Duffey of Hartford and State Senator Edward L. Marcus of New Haven.

title: Bradford Team Replaced
description: LONDON. May 30 (Reuters) Cambridge United has voted today into the Fourth Division of the English Soccer League to replace Bradford. Bradford finished among the last four teams in the league the last four years.

title: Observer: The Aquarians in Their Television Chains
description: WASHINGTON, May 30All the trouble worth speaking of is of course, being caused by people under 26 years of age. This is the television genera tion. Onehalf the entire pop ulation, andsobering thought that half has never known a world where there was no television.

title: Mary McPadden Wed
description: STRATFORD, Conn., May 30Miss Mary Wanda Mc Padlen, daughter of Mrs. Edward W. McPadden and the late Judge McPadden, who was surrogate here, was married in St. James Roman Catholic Church this after noon to Paul Andrew Landry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Landry of Halifax, Nova Scotia, where his father is a retired chiropractor. The cer emony was performed by the Rev. Joseph N. Murphy.

title: Boom in MailOrder Schooling Marked by Dubious Practices
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Education  hungry Americans are quietly pouring hundreds of millions of dollars each year into an industry plagued by overblown advertising, fast talking salesmen, questionable instruction, and marginal re sults.

title: Margaret Dewar Buckman Is Married
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., May 30 In the Sewickley Presby terian Church today Miss Margaret Dewar Buckman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ustick Buckman, was married to Ottho Gerhard Heldring, who expects to re ceive a master's degree in September from the Colum bia University Graduate School of Business. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Heldring of Leid schendam, the Netherlands. The Rev. Jack M. Maxwell performed the ceremony.

title: Third French Nuclear Blast
description: PARIS, May 30 (Reuters) France today set off the third in her current series of nuclear tests in the Pacific, the Defense Ministry announced here. A statement from the ministry said the explosion, over Gan gataufa atoll, was of high power but gave no further details.

title: Sandler Gains Semifinals In A.A.U. Title Handball
description: Steve Sandler of the 92d Street Y.M.H.A., the No. 1 seeded player, advanced to the semifinal round of the national Amateur Athletic Union one wall handball championships yesterday by defeating Steve Weissner o f the Brownsville Handball Club, 2117, 217, at the Municipal Courts in Coney Island.

title: Himalayan Peak Scaled By 2 Japanese Women
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 30 (AP)Two Japanese women have climbed the 24,853foot Annapurna 3 in the Hima layas, the first women to scale the peak, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: RUSSIAN SAYS MOON WILL BE LEFT TO U.S
description: MOSCOW, May 30 (UPI)  The Soviet Union will concen trate on building large space stations around the earth while the United States explores the moon, according to a Soviet astronaut, Aleksei Yelisevev.

title: Goldberg Asks Job Aid and Hospitals for War Veterans
description: Arthur J. Goldberg promised yesterday that, if elected Gov ernor, he would appoint a special task force to seek to improve job opportunities for former servicemen as well as to improve hospital facilities for veterans needing such care.

title: Dodgers Top Cards
Operating Profit Slumps for Rails
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI)Net operating income for the nation's railroads dropped 57.6 per cent to a 10year low in the first quarter of 1970, despite rec ord operating revenues, the Association of American Railroads reported.

title: Job Changes:
description: Werner C. Brown has been elected president of Hercules, Inc., becoming the concerns fifth president in its 57 years of existence.

title: Miss Sorensen Is Bride
description: HIGHLANDS, N. J., May 30 Miss Harriette Alicia Soren sen was married at her par ents' home here today to Wil liam Robertson 4th, a doc toral student in engineering at the University of Texas. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harry Kraft of the Central Baptist Church in Atlantic Highlands. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sverre Sorensen and a granddaughter of the late Arthur Dyer, who was president of the New York Produce Exchange. Her hus band is a son of Mrs. Rodger M. Volpe of Doyles town, Pa., and the late Mr. Robertson 3d.

title: Nixon Counting On Time To Ease Twin Crises
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.Pres ident Nixon was busily marking time last week. He rushed be tween conferences with prowar students and antiwar students, hawkish labor leaders and nervously dovish financiers, uni versity presidents and Bible Belt fundamentalists. Yet there was something oddly static about all this activity, as if he had de cided to let his twin crises of Cambodia and the economy simmer for a while.

title: Rangers Replace Buffalo With Seattle as Affiliate
description: SEATTLE, May 30 (AP)The Seattle Totems of the Western Hockey League signed a con tract today to affiliate with the New York Rangers for the 197071 season.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The reminder came from Jack McDon ald, a longtime comradeinarms as a San Francisco columnist and a basker in Mex ican sunshine ever since his retirement. His letter from south of the border drew attention to the fact that the longest base ball game in major league annals took place 50 years ago this month, a 26inning pitching duel between Joe Oeschger of the Boston Braves and Leon Cadore of the Brooklyn Dodgers. It became a historic 11 deadlock when encroaching darkness terminated it just one inning short of the equivalent of three full games.

title: Dance
description: YEARS ago one of the standard articles in British newspapers right alongside those pieces on the Queen's corgi dogs and Harold Wilson's childhood ambitions, was the eternal conjecture on who might succeed Dame Margot Fonteyn as Queen of the Royal Ballet. So many names have been mentioned, but to day most of them are in re tirement, and Dame Margot, still smiling radiantly, con tinues on her untroubled way.

title: Home Improvement
description: AWALL paneling system specifically designed for bathrooms, kitch ens, laundry rooms and other highmoisture areas has recently been introduced for use over almost any type of wallnew or old.

title: Burtis Steers Gauchero To Victory in Star Class
Those Biting Words Are Agnew's Own
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Vice President Agnew's most pungent speech writer does not intend to tone down Mr. Ag new's comments. The Vice President's most pungent writer is the Vice President.

title: Despite the booze and the brawls, a talent for survival
description: This hallucinating novel be gins with a blow of the fist a murderand ends, two world wars later, a few years after the Hungarian uprising of 1956. It is a saga of the murderer.

title: MRS. MONROE POLLACK
description: Mrs. Rita Harris Pollack, wire of Monroe W. Pollack, retired senior vice president of U. S. PlywoodChampion Papers, Inc., died here yesterday. She was 61 years old and lived at 166 East 61st Street and Wayne, N. J.

title: 30,000 IN ILLINOIS ATTEND ROCK FETE
description: HEYWORTH, Ill., May 30 (UPI)  About 30,000 persons flocked to a muddy farm field today for the Kickapoo Creek Rock Music Festival, which had been banned by a court.

title: MISSISSIPPI CURBS RIOT PROCEDURES
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 30 The state's Law Enforcement Assistance Division henceforth will require police forces to have well enunciated com mand and control procedures assuring proper restraint be fore they will be allotted funds for lethal weapons in riot con trol.

title: A Correction
description: An article on the arrest of the Soviet writer Andrei Amairik which appeared in this section May 24 said his wife was arrested with him. That was incorrect Mrs. Amairik was not arrested. The Times regrets the error.

title: Nixon Summons Top Aides
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 30President Nixon summoned his ranking military advisers today for a fullscale review of the Cambodian operation and his program to turn the war over to the South Vietnamese.

title: Daria Stemple Wed To Peter Bjonerud
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., May 30Miss Dania Cheryl Stem ple and Peter Michael Bjone rud were married here this evening at All Saints Episco pal Church by the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Berger.

title: MATSON PUTS SHOT 714 ON COAST
COOPER CAPTURES ALLSTAR BOWLING
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill., May 30 (AP)Bobby Cooper of Hous ton and Mary Baker of Central Islip, L. I., scored victories yes terday in the $65,000, 29th All Star bowling tournament.

title: Federal Strike Force to Begin Scrutiny This Week of Alleged Mafia Influence in New Orleans Area
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 30 An organized crime strike force coordinated by the Jus tice Department will join other investigators next week in scrutinizing alleged Mafia in fluence in the New Orleans area.

title: SAVAGE, KEOGH WIN IN SECTIONAL TRACK
description: NEWARK, May 30Joe Sav age of Roselle Catholic and Mike Keogh of Essex Catholic were well off their best form today as they won sectional titles in the first round of the New Jersey interscholastic track and field championships.

title: Michele Marie Carpenter Fiancee
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 30 Mr. and Mrs. William J. Carpenter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michele Marie Carpenter, to Richard Risley Day, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Day of Rokeby Farm, Barrvtown. N.Y.

title: Forrest Church Weds Amy Furth
description: LAFAYETTE, Calif., May 30 Miss Amy Melville Furth and Frank Forrester Church 4th, who is known as Forrest, were married here today after a hectic week complicated by the uncertainty of whether the bridegroom's father, Sena tor Church of Idaho, would be able to leave Washington. He is coauthor of an amend ment to limit United States intervention in Indochina.

title: Dance: 2 by Balanchine
description: One of the less easy as pects of being a kindly neigh borhood critic is that once in a whilewould you believe the next night?you have to venture into territory that was not  altogether happy with whatwould you be lieve the past morning?you last wrote about it. To any critic in this situation, I would most seriously suggest that this is the price he pays for not working.

title: Texans See Downturn In Economy
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 30 The Texas economy, on a downturn since mid1969, continued cool during March, according to the latest report of the University of Texas Bureau of Business Research. The bureau's economic indi cators in March showed either further declines or sta bility at new lows.

title: Summer splash
description: The summer fun season begins by tradition this weekend, and designers are making a splash with a fresh group of swimsuits. Coverage is the news. Both mail Iots and twopiece styles bare less flesh than in previous years, but achieve a new kind of allure with sleek lines and stretchy fab rics. Don't be the last one in!

title: Brewers Top Tigers, 97
description: MILWAUKEE, May 30 (UPI) A fluke grandslam homer in the first inning by Roberto Penaon a play in which Al Kaline was injuredgot the Milwaukee Brewers started to night and they went on to snap a sevengame losing streak with a 97 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Pompidou Assails Violence and Drugs
description: PARIS, May 30  President Pompidou said today that the quality of French life was threatened by violence that is spreading everywhere, by per version and by drugs.

title: Survey Shows Difficulty In Filling Banking Posts
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30  A significant number of banks in the Third Federal Reserve District are having difficulty recruiting and training management person nel, a survey has disclosed.

title: EDWIN C. JOHNSON, EXSENATOR, DEAD
description: DENVER, May 30 (AP)Ed win C. Johnson, who served three terms as Governor of Colorado and three terms as a United States Senator, died to day at St. Joseph's Hospital, where he had undergone a hernia operation May 7. He was 86 years old.

title: Still the Least Populous
description: MENTONE, Tex., May 30 (UPI)The nation's least popu lous county per square mile has gotten even sparser. Census fig ures for 1970 released on Thursday showed that Loving County, a 647square mile sec tion in west Texas, had 150 persons, a drop from 226 per sons in 1960.

title: For Young Readers
description: In 1962, one John Pappas and one Robert Lipsyte made their spring training debuts with the New York Mets. Pappas, a young hopeful from New York City, popped up unan nounced and unheralded at the new born Mets camp, trying to land pitching job. Lipsyte had just been handed his first major assignment as a sports reporter for The New York Times. The facts are that Pappas didn't make it, the Mets did in 1969, and Lipsyte makes it in this book, a collection of sport profiles loosely based on his Times columns. (Most of the materialsome of it is new has been rewritten and adapted for book audience.)

title: A CAMPAIGN OFFICE ON FIRST AVE. RIFLED
description: Paul T. Rao's auxiliary cam paign headquarters was broken into, rifled and smashed this weekend, the police said.

title: On the roof of the world, disaster waited
description: In the annals of Arctic ex ploration, no enterprise seems as gallantly quixotic as S.A. Andre's illconceived and ul timately tragic attempt, in 1897, to reach the North Pole by what was intended to be a navigable balloon. On June 11

title: Ottinger Uses TV As Medium For the Message
description: Three months ago Senator Charles E. Goodell took a poll that evaluated his potential Democratic opponents and found that 63 per cent of the state's enrolled Democrats had never heard of Richard L. Ot Unger. An Ottin2er poll turn weeks ago showed that 63 per cent had not only heard of him, but knew he was a Congress man running for Senator and was against the war in Vietnam and pollution of the Hudson River and was for Israel and old people.

title: Giants Outscore Pirates, 1311, Sparked by FiveRun Flurry in Fifth inning
News of the Rialto
description: THE London triumph, Conduct Unbecom ing, which our peri patetic, transplanted Englishman, Clive Barnes, cited last summer as the one play likely to appeal as Much to American as to Eng lish tastes, is going to test the man's perspicacity in the fall.

title: Reader's Report
description: A Sephardic Jew with fourteenthcentury conscience is how a friend characterizes Stanley Bendana, the peripatet is ??hero of this engaging book. Carrying a heavy burden of lapsed orthodoxy (his father's as well as his own), Stanley lights out from Flatbush for Ma laga on a graduate fellowship, and tries living at once in the present and the past. The past is the dense ambience of Spain, itself evoking in our hero an cient memories of charred au tosclaf The present is typi fied by a chicey fellowstudent named Alma Scott, whom the Sephardic Quixote pursues un der false assumptions. The mediator between past and present, between guilt and lib eration, is Jacob Perlman, a Chagall4Bre painter Stanley runs across in Malaga. Perlinan a wise old guru with big moral problems of his own, has a talent for exorcising other peo ple's demons.

title: Advertising:
description: If Heaven should ever need an ad agencyand with all that Godisdead talk perhaps an image campaign might well be in orderit could do worse than Merling, O'Brien, Pintauro & Kleber.

title: CANDIDATES HERE LINK CAMPAIGNS TO HOLIDAY THEME
description: Pleas for better treatment of veterans and for sanity in the discussion of national prob lems were voiced by political candidates yesterday as they intensified their campaigns on Memorial Day.

title: In Memoriam
description: DIAMONDRuth (nee Goldman). In cher ished memory of our beloved sister's birthday. The Family.

title: Article 7  No Title
CANADA RESENTS U.S. FUEL POLICY
description: OTTAWA, May 30  Per sistent demands by the Nixon Administration that Canada ne gotiate a common policy for the use of North American energy sourcesoil, coat, gas, uranium and hydropowerare meeting increasing resistance here, They are also causing a rare outburst of nationalism that Canadians normally hold in reserve.

title: England dicks History
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, May 30History, wrote Karl Marx, repeats itself, the first time as tragedy, the second as farce. When Bob by Moore, the tall, blond and Olympian captain of Eng land, was arrested in Bogota, a city where trumpedup charges are a cornmonplace, it was the second time that England's football team had suffered at the hands of Col ombia on the eve of a World Cup. Strange coincidence, in deed, when one recalls that the English players' recent 40 success in Bogota was the firit time they'd ever played the Colombians.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: In Praise of Willie M.

title: Q:
description: Friend

title: Algeria and Morocco End Dispute
description: TLEMCEN, Algeria, May 30 (AP)Algeria and Mo rocco have settled their bor der dispute and have resolved jointly to eject Spain from her remaining enclaves in North Africa.

title: ENEMY ASSAULTS MOUNTAIN RESORT IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. May 30Enemy troops attacked the mountain resort city of Dalat and surrounding military posts early this morning. It was the most serious attack since the Tet offensive in early 1968.

title: Ondine Triumphs in Block Island Sail
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 30 Huey Long's big light blue ketch, Ondine, was first to cross the line off Great Cap tain Light in the Storm Trysail Club's 25th annual race around Block Island at about midnight last night.

title: Greene Leads by 5 Strokes In Brazilian Golf With 204
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 30 (AP)Bert Greene of Sun River, Ore., took a fivestroke lead over his closest competitors in the Brazilian open golf tourna meat today with a thirdround score of 204.

title: OffDuty. Policeman Shoots Housing Patrolman in Bronx
description: An offduty city policeman shot an offduty Housing Au thority patrolman in the chest last night in the East Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: Govern Gets Sherman Prize As Hamilton's Top Golfer
description: John M. Govern was the captain and outstanding golfer at Hamilton last year and he is the captain and outstanding golfer again this year, receiv ing the Thomas M. Sherman award.

title: Suharto : He Can Point to Some Gains
description: Many Americans last week suddenly discovered that even Southeast Asia may have a silver; lining. The lining is Indonesia, the largest coun try in the region in area (735,000 square miles), popu lation (118 million) and na tural resources (forests, oil, tin, bauxite, nickel, copper, manganese).

title: Columbia to Give Prizes To McMillian, Dotson
description: Columbia's two basketball stars, Jim McMillian and Heyward Dotson, will receive special awards at the univer sity's annual Class Day cere monies tomorrow.

title: R. W. Baker 3d, Diplomat, Weds Margaret Kerr
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30 Miss Margaret Royal Kerr and Richard Wheeler Baker 3d of Princeton, N. J., were married this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church of Chest nut Hill by the Rev. Lincoln T. Griswold.

title: Israel Pursues Scorched Border Policy
description: JERUSALEM  On Israel's northern border, a narrow line of empty fields and crumbling, deserted villages is mute evi dence of a new line of defense. They were shelled from posi tions in Israel and emptied of their populations after an Israeli school bus was ambushed close to the border a week ago Fri day, leaving 12 children and teachers dead and the rest of the 20 people on the bus in jured.

title: Bye ByeSam, $11.80, Captures $98,835 Pace by 1 I/4 Lengths
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 30 Post position made the differ ence as Bye Bye Sam, driven by Stanley Dancer, defeated Tem pered Yankee, handled by Danc er's older brother, Vernon, in the ninth annual Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway to night.

title: RENT COMPUTER IN CITY OPPOSED
description: The chairman of the City Council's Housing Committee, contending that Mayor Lind say's plan to computerize rents in 1.3 million apartments lacked the human element, plans to join other Democratic leaders in rewriting the Lindsay bills to put more decision making power in the hands of an independent panel.

title: Italian Airliner Hijacked to Cairo
description: ROME, May 30An armed man hijacked a DC9 jet plane of the Italian national airline, Alitalia, on a domes tic flight from Genoa to Rome this afternoon and forced the pilot to fly to Cairo after a refueling stop in Naples.

title: Susan Peck Is Married To Peter Wilmerding
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30 Miss Susan McCracken Peck was married here this after noon to Peter Wilmerding, son of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Wilmerding of Berwyn and greatgrandson of the late Charles Pratt, a founder of the original Standard Oil Company and of the Pratt In stitute in Brooklyn, New York.

title: Mr. Nixon Speaks to Youth
description: President Nixon is understandably anxious to show that he is able to speak facetoface to the nation's youth. His early morning stroll among student dem onstrators at the recent peace rally in Washington fitted into that effort; his address to the Billy Graham meeting in the football stadium at the University Tennessee was a more spectacular appeal to a massed audience of young America.

title: Stamps
description: BRITAIN'S first decimal postage stamps are to be released June 17, in 10p, 20p and 50p denominations. Designs remain the same for these de finitive stamps, which first came into use in 1967 and show a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II. The only changes will be in denomination fig ures, and colors. The portrait by Arnold Machin depicts a classic profile of the queen facing left (pictured above).

title: Gibson Drives in Newark To Get Blacks to Polls
description: NEWARK, May 30Black strategists, political leaders and precinct workers will take to the streets in the Negro dis tricts here next week to bring out the voters for a black may oral candidate, Kenneth A. Gib son.

title: Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:

title: What's Doing in the Camera World
description: THE Graphic Design Of fice of the Yale School of Art and Architec ture has just published the first edition of a new magazine that will be issue dannually as a showplace for photographs taken by past or present students and faculty members at Yale. Called STILL/1, the magazine con tains blackandwhite pic tures reproduced with a new ly developed technique known as simulated gravure a twopress nongravure process. Included in this first edition are four previously unpublished photographs by Walker Evans, as well as photographs by John Hill, a commercial photographer based in New York. STILL/1 is a nonprofit magazine and sells for $2. It can be ordered from Wittenborn & Co., 1018 Madison Avenue, N.Y.C. 10021; or from Graphic De Madison Avenue, N.Y.C. sign, Yale, 180, York Street, New Haven, Conn. 06250.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: June 68Scuderia X and Long Island Sports Car Association competition school and races at Bridgehampton (L. I.) Race Cir cuit. E.M.R.A. event; mufflers not required; drivers must be over 21. Registration: 8 A.M., race practice 1:30 P.M. Informa tion: odd numbers: Mrs. Cally Kruger, phone (201)4447014; even numbers: Mrs. Ginny Kill mer, phone (516)4279315.

title: SST: Arguments Louder Than Sonic Boom
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time in the long history of the Government's supersonic trans port project, taxpayers' hostil ity, scientists' anxiety and in dustry's skepticism about the airliner combined last week to make continuation of the pro gram a close political question in the House.

title: Late TV and Radio Listings
description: The following information about today's television and ra dio programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: List of Contests in June 23 Primary
description: Following are the contests in the June 23 primaries for Re publican, Democratic, Liberal and Conservative nominations for public office in the city to gether with primary contests in the state for the House of Representatives. Unopposed candidates are automatically nominated and their names will not appear on the ballot. Asterisks (*) denote incum bents. Because of reapportion ment of the Congressional dis tricts, this does not mean they are necessarily incumbents in the districts in which they are running.

title: Hundreds Turn to Soil for Life Styles
description: FRANKLIN, N. H.  Six years ago Joe Ryan quit his job as a chemical engineer making aerosol cans in Bos ton and sank his savings into 55 farmedout acres in the foothills of the White Moun tains that had been aban doned since the 1920's.

title: ATHLETICS' CLOUT TOPS INDIANS, 54
POLLUTION CURBS ON PAPERS ASKED
description: Newspapers are facing in creasing charges that they are key contributors to the nation's growing refuse problem.

title: Indochina 1: Saigon's Plans in Cambodia Ambiguous
description: SAIGONIn a small ante chamber just off the main en trance to South Vietnam's For eign Ministry building last week, the Foreign Ministers of Cam bodia and South Vietnam signed a series of documents reopen ing diplomatic relations between the two neighbors after a lapse of seven years.

title: Shirley Englehorn's 68 Gains Tie at 139 With Mary Mills in Virginia Golf
description: WINCHESTER, Va., May 30 (UPI)Shirley Englehorn shot a fourunderpar 68 today and gained a tie with Mary Mills at 139 for the secondround lead in the $15,000 O'Sullivan women's open golf tournament.

title: Sorensen Is Celebrity In a Visit to the Catskills
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 30 The first event chalked on the board at the patio at the Evans Hotel in Loch Sheldrake today was a golf tournament at 10; the second was, Yoga: wear shorts. at 11.

title: Wendy Bolton Becomes Bride Of Stepbrother
description: MONTVILLE, Me., May 30 Miss Wendy Bolton was married here this afternoon to her stepbrother, Daniel Bruce Rowland, whose moth er is married to the bride's father.

title: Turf Dinner Set July 12
description: Harold Kirsch, president of the Turf Lodge No. 2503 of B'nai B'rith, has announced that the fifth annual gold medal dinner and dance will be held July 12 at the Top of the Fair at Flushing Meadow, Queens. The dinner will honor David (Sonny) Werblin horse owner and former head of the Jets. The Turf Lodge is com posed of those affiliated with thoroughbred racing.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.  Beginning tomorrow, travelers to a heavily visited section of Vermont will find themselves part of an ex perimental project that substitutes color andpicturecoded directional signs for billboards and other offpremise road side signs.

title: The Day Wall St. Met the President
description: In a suite at Washington's Madison Hotel Wednesday evening, a group of Wall Street chieftains got to gether to talk about the day's events. Their host was Bernard J. Lasker, chairman of New York Stock Ex change's Board of Gover nors, and all of them were about to attend a White House dinner.

title: DAVID GORDON
description: David Gordon, treasurer and chief engineer of the Delma Engineering Corporation in the Bronx, died Thursday in Mon tefiore Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 1566 Unionport Road, the Bronx.

title: A twicetold tale with practically no moral at all
description: Otto Friedrich, author of the latest I suffered, I was there account of the decline and fall of The Saturday Evening Post and the Curtis Publish ing Companya story that is fast taking on overtones of business le gendcame from Newsweek to the Post as foreign editor in 1962, just when the decline was getting fairly started, and was still there, as manag ing editor, on the day in January, 1969, when Martin S. Ackerman an nounced at the Overseas Press Club that the magazine dead.

title: Eastern to Resume Service
description: Eastern Airlines will resume jet service from the improved TweedNew Haven Airport on June 17, after suspending it in January, 1968, during construc tion of a control tower and work on runways. The airline said it would use DC9's leav ing New Haven at 7:10 A.M. for La Guardia Airport and At lanta and at 3 P.M. for Wash ington and Miami. Northbound flights to New Haven will be from Miami and Washington and from Fort Lauderdale, At lanta and Newark.

title: Pete Gogolak Weds Miss Sauer
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 30Miss Katherine Jerusha Sauer and Pete Gogolak, place kicker with the New York Football Giants, were married here this afternoon in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Charles Meade. The Rev. Benedict J. Dudley, a Roman Catholic Driest, assisted.

title: Sihanouk Says U.S. Foiled Him
description: TOKYO, Sunday, May 31 (AP)  Prince Norodom Siha nouk, ousted March 18 as Cam bodia's Chief of State, says forces loyal to him would have captured Pnompenh, the Cam bodian capital, if United States and South Vietnamese forces had not intervened, the Com munist Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported today.

title: Politics Stirs Ocean HillBrownsville
description: A new battle has broken out in the Ocean HillBrowns ville section of Brooklyn, but the lines this time have been drawn on the political front.

title: W. B. Asher Jr. Weds Diane A. Anderson
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., May 30Miss Diane Amy Ander son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Robert Anderson of Sum mit, N. J., was married here this afternoon to William Blaine Asher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Asher of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: SOUTHWEST FOCUS OF NEW U. S. STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 The Federal Government, sud denly and belatedly in the esti mation of some sociologists, has turned some attention to the problems of the country's secondlargest minority, Mexi canAmericans.

title: Seventh Avenue Feels a Financial Pinch
description: Rosie Smith (the name is fictitious) is looking for a job. Mrs. Smith is 42 years old, lives in the Bronx with her husband and three children and she has had steady work in a dress factory as a sewing ma chine operator for the last six years. Last week she was told that the shop was going to close on June 1, and her earnings of $108.50 a week would be terminated.

title: Memorial Day: 2 Outlooks
description: Two Memorial Day parades, widely separated in ideology, were held here yesterday to honor America's war dead.

title: CITY TO STIFFEN GRAFT INQUIRIES
description: The daytoday procedures for investigating charges of po lice corruption here are soon to undergo radical change, sev eral high Lindsay administra tion officials said yesterday.

title: LEBANON ALLOWS A PROTEST DRAMA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30 For the last year the right of a Lebanese theater workshop to present a play advocating domestic revolution as well as allout war against Israel has been, something of an obsession among Lebanese intellectuals.

title: Peace March in Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 30 The Stamford Peace Fellow ship and Students for Peace Or ganization paraded quietly to day a half mile beyond the city's official parade, as ordered by the Superior Court. They had been denied a place in the regular parade by the Patriotic and Special Events Commission. There were no incidents.

title: STUDENTS IN POLL FOUND LIBERAL
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 30 College students who describe themselves as liberals out number self  designated con servatives by more than 2 to 1, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: Point of View
description: WASHINGTON  Following are excerpts from a speech by Attorney General John N. Mitchell to the Delta Council, a group of Mississippi business leaders, in Cleveland, Miss., May 19.

title: Soviet Youth: Not All Party Liners
description: MOSCOW In addressing the opening meeting of the 16th congress of the Young Communist League (Komso mol) on Tuesday, the party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, was full of praise for Soviet youth. Soviet young people are growing up morally healthy, active and purpose ful. They are full of energy and enthusiasm in the strug gle for the cause of the party, for the cause of Commu nism, he said.

title: Jet Fire Alarm Is False
description: GENEVA, May 30 (Reuters) A Luxair jet plane flying from Luxembourg to Tunis with 88 passengers aboard made an emergency landing at Geneva airport today after a fire alarm sounded on the air craft, the police said. The pilot said no fire was dis covered when the airliner landed.

title: Arctic Sport
description: With some stretching of the mind it is possible for the most sedentary layman to grasp the challenge of climbing Mount Everest or descending to the depths of the Atlantic in a bathysphere. They are there, the explanation goesand danger is the spur. But the challenge of hunting polar bears by airplane a practice reported from the Arctic with deplorable frequencyis beyond all imagining.

title: Trying To Define Black Art: Must We Go Back to Social Realism?
description: BOSTON. WHAT is black art? Is there a black esthetic discernible in the visual expression of black American artists that distin guishes it from the work of their white contemporaries? If so, what are its characteristics? If not, are there none theless sufficiently compelling social reasons why segregated exhibitions of art by black artists should now be encouraged?

title: Miss Wendy McCreath Is a Bride
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 30 Miss Wendy McCreath and Graham Godfrey Argent Belcher were married here this afternoon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Cathe dral.

title: APPRENTICES SOUGHT BY PLUMBERS' UNION
description: Local 2 of the Plumbers Union and the Association of Contracting Plumbers of the City of New York have started a recruiting effort for a joint fiveyear apprenticeship train ing program.

title: Mansfield Assays R.O.T.C.
description: HELENA, Mont., May 30 (AP) IThe Reserve Officers Train ing Corps program plays an im portant part in balancing the military establishment between professionals and civilians, the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Mon tana, said today.

title: The Happy Jackie, The Sad Jackie, The Bad Jackie, The Good Jackie
description: STORY 1: One day in January, 1952, John Husted Jr. took his fiance Jacqueline Bouvier to see his mother. Mrs. Husted offered her prospective daughterinlaw childhood snapshot of her son. No, thank you, Miss Bouvier said. If want any photos I can take my own.

title: Kansas Marijuana Panel
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 30 (UPI) Gov. Robert B. Docking has appointed a sixmember com mittee responsible for an ex perimental project on the con trol of marijuana growth in Kansas. Thousands of acres of marijuana grow wild each year in Kansas and the law was prompted by the arrest of 160 persons caught illegally harvest ing the weed.

title: Misses Heldman, Casals Reach Quarterfinals in French Tennis
description: PARIS, May 30 (AP)Julie Heldman of New York and Rose mary Casals of San Francisco advanced to the quarterfinals of the $100,000 French open tennis chamnionshins today.

title: Traffic Accident Rate Reported 13.5% Higher
description: Traffic accidents through out the country for the first quarter of this year climbed to 2.6 million, a 13.5 per cent higher rate than for a cor responding period last year, the Insurance Information Institute reported yesterday.

title: Best Seller List
description: This Last Week Week Weeks on List

title: Foreign Affairs: The Arrogance of IgnoranceI
description: PARISJust one month ago the President announced that American ground forces had been ordered into Cambodia. At that time I wrote: If Nixon can swiftly smash the sanctu aries outside Vietnam without dangerous escalation or con frontations elsewhere, he will ultimately emerge triumphant at home as well as overseas. Nothing succeeds like success but, if he fails, nothing fails like failure.

title: Hong Kong Moves to Forbid New Concubines After June, '71
description: HONG KONG, May 30A practice that has been sanc tioned by law or custom for more than 3,000 years will end with the enactment of a bill now before Hong Kong's Legis lative Council.

title: Medicine's War Role
description: The Army, which accounts for more Vietnam war casual ties than any other service, reports that more than 81 per cent of its wounded are sur viving in Vietnam, compared with 74 per cent in the Korean War and 71 per cent in World War II.

title: ExPolice Chief Fined
description: FALL RIVER, Mass., May 30 (AP)  Former Police Chief Norman Bowers was fined $25 today for leaving the scene of an accident. The police charged that Mr. Bowers struck a parked car Dec. 7, 1969, and failed to stop. He retired as police chief in January, 1969, after 31 years on the force.

title: No way to run a publishing house
description: In March, 1928, the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, led by John Sumner, brought the firm of Boni & Liveright into court for publishing an obscene novel, Replenishing Jessica, by Maxwell Bodenheim. Charles Boni had been out of the business for several years, and the burden of defending the ac tion fell on Horace Liveright, a dap per, 42yearold exsecurities sales man who had become a legend in literary circles for his flamboyant promotional schemeshe sold books as though they were tickets to sport ing eventsand a list of authors that included some of the best known names in the country. Liveright wasalso an irritant to his colleagues in publishing who preferred not to roil the censorship waters in the hope that they would simply evaporate.

title: Symbols to Replace Words on U.S. Traffic Signs
description: The American highway is about to acquire a conti nental look.

title: Chess
description: BOBBY FISCHER, with fighting spirit intensified after an extend ed absence from tournament play, scored a brilliant first place during the recent starstudded interna tional at Rovinj and Zagreb, Yugo slavia.

title: Minor Leagues
description: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE

title: AFRICAN DROUGHT HURTS GAME PARK
description: SKUKUZA, Kruger National Park, South Africa, May 30 (UPI)A drought parching halt of South Africa and SouthWest Africa is worrying humans, but it is the animals that are thirst ing.

title: GRISCOM CUP GOLF BEGINS TUESDAY
description: The 63d playing of the Wom en's Intercity golf team match es for the Griscom Cup will be held over the rolling hills of the Huntingdon Valley (Pa.) Country Club course, Tuesday, and Wednesday.

title: Miss Heller Bride Of Michael Libman
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., May 30  In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Valerie Heller, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Heller, was married to Michael L. Libman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max L. Libman of Reston, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard B. Andersen.

title: Movies They Are No Joke, Mes Amis
description: PARIS ON the Rue Champollion, a narrow, ancient al ley that runs for one block just behind the Boulevard St. Michel, near the Sorbonne, there can still be seen some faded graffiti dating back, I assume, to the galvanizing days of February, 1968, when the Government tried to oust Henri Langlois as director of the Cinema theque Francaise. (The effort failed, but it is credited with having set the scene for the evenements of May, 1968, which eventually led to De Gaulle's retirement.) On a wall on which Francois Vil lon might have written a blue poem, an anonymous, 20th century cinephile, equipped with a can of black spray paint, has scrawled: Vive Langlois! There is something immensely cheering about the message, especially to an American who cannot con ceive of the possibility of turning a corner in the Vil lage and finding say, Sup port James Card!, or Good health to Willard Van Dyke!, or even Who is Richard Roud?

title: America As Only Bikers See It
description: WE took a sharp right off the main road, coasted down gentle hill and began pedaling faster and faster. Around the bend waited the end of a long day. In minutes, we saw it: a big, white New England farmhouse and a shining jumble of handlebars and wheels. We sped up the driveway, dodged a basket ball and squeezed into a bikefilled ga rage. On legs that still seemed to be pedaling, we walked into that most wel come of places a hostel.

title: Allen: A Very Uneasy Member of The Team
description: WASHINGTONOne day last week, C.B.S. radio reported that President Nixon had asked for the resignation of his Commis sioner of Education, Dr. James E. Allen Jr. The report turned out to be false, but at the time it was entirely believable. Dr. Allen, himself, did not know whether to believe it, and, just in case it should be true, he sat down and wrote out a resig nation statement.

title: LARCENY KID WINS DELAWARE OPENER
description: STANTON, Del., May 30 (AP) Cragwood Stables' Larceny Kid, ridden by Bill Hartack, won the $30,600 Brandywine Turf Handicap today as Delaware Park's meeting opened with at tendance and wagering exceed ing last year's holiday inaugu ral program.

title: CHARLES B. M'CABE OF MIRROR IS DEAD
description: Charles B. McCabe, publisher of The New York Mirror from 1936 until the morning tabloid was sold to The News in 1963, died Friday night at Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old. burg, Pa., and wire editor in New York to Washington cor respondent.

title: Miss Maria M. Farley Is Married
description: LOUDONVILLE,. N. Y., May 30Miss Maria Morrow Far ley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Farley, was mar ried here this noon to Daniel Wallace Gerrity, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Gerrity. Both families are of Loudon ville, where the Rev. J. Thomas Going performed the ceremony in St. Pius X Ro man Catholic Church.

title: Facing the Future At Forty
description: AT the age of 40 an insti tution is often ready to take stock of its situa tion and perhaps do a bit of reorganizing for the future. This is exactly what the National Orchestral As sociation has been doing.

title: 3 Cancels By U.N. On Friday
description: THE United Nations on June 12 will inaugu rate three new slogan cancellations commem orating its 25th anniver sary. One is for use on mail bearing United Nations stamps to be cancelled at the U. N. headquarters here read ing Twentyfifth Anniversa ry/ 19451970. The second cancellation will be a meter slogan, with the same word ing. A third cancellation will be applied on mailings at U. N. Geneva, Switzerland, headquarters, reading in French VingtCinquieme An niversaire/19451970. The United Nations was founded in San Francisco a quarter of a century ago.

title: Susan Holland Becomes Bride
description: WEST TRENTON, N.J., May 30Miss Susan Holland, daughter of Mrs. Joseph S. Holland and the late Mr. Hol land of Trenton, was mar ried at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church here this morning to Ray L. Hurst Jr., a broker with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., in Trenton.

title: Philadelphia to Continue Its Drive for '76 Celebration Despite Panel's Opposition to OneCity Festival
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30  Philadelphia, stunned by the disclosure that a Presidential commission opposes an inter national exposition to mark the nation's bicentennial in 1976, adopted plans this week to work for one anyway.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1SAM FALK

title: Advance in Food Prices Proves Hard to Chart
description: All consumers know that food prices are up, but get ting figures as to exactly how much higher they are on a given date can be a frustrating experience.

title: Spotlight:
description: As the great 196970 bear market sank to its lowest level early last week, the stocks that ranked among the lowest of the low were those of the conglomerate corporations.

title: Point of View
description: THE supply of new apart ment space in New York City is just about run ning dry. With the demand for new housing greater than it has ever been, New Yorkbased builders have been completely alienated from the housing market here. They are exporting their initiative and resources to producing housing in areas outside New York.

title: The YS11 Solves a Problem for Piedmont
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., May 30Piedmont Airlines searched the world for a plane that would carry a sub stantial load of passengers in and out of small, mountain ous airports. It found the an swer in Japan's Nihon YS11.

title: FARRELL CAPTURES 50MILE BIKE RACE
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., May 30 Robert Farrell, a 20yearold bicycle rider from Trinidad: now living in New York, survived a fourman stretch duel to win the 27th annual 50Mile Kugler Anderson Memorial Tour of Somerville today. Farrell's time was 1 hour 59 minutes 49.8 seconds.

title: Foe's Cambodia Strategy Alters U.S. Aides' Views
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Senior officials of the Nixon Administration are reportedly moving to the conclusion that Cambodia will need increasing military assistance from South Vietnam and Thailand, includ ing troops from South Vietnam at least.

title: WOMEN SOUGHT FOR AIR CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON May 30 (AP)  There are only about 50 women among more than 21,000 American air traffic controllers, but there are indications that the picture is changing.

title: Miss Neufville Sets Mark
description: LONDON, May 30 (UPI) Marilyn Neufville, a 17yearold Londoner who has chosen to run for Jamaica in this sum mer's Commonwealth Games, set a United Kingdom all corner's 400meter record of 52 seconds today in the final at the Southern women's athletic championships. Her time was threetenths of a second above the world record.

title: Saigon Seeks U.S. Funds To Meet Economic Crisis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30  South Vietnam is seeking up to $200million in emergency aid from the United States to help tide it over an economic crisis caused by severe inflation at a time of its increasing commitment in Cambodia.

title: Martial Law in Cambodia To Be Invoked Tomorrow
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, May 31 (AP)The Cambodian radio said today that martial law would go into effect in Cambodia tomorrow and that heavy prison terms or death sentences would be im posed for a long list of crimes.

title: Casa Guidi, To Be Lost Or Saved
description: Robert Browning is coming back, as one 19thcentury poet curiously suited to the modern mind in thought and to the modern style in expres sion. Since my biography appeared, I have read him by request not only to proper Bostonians but to hippies in New York and elegant young Hindu ladies in Madras.

title: RIGHTISTS ASSAIL BRANDT AT RALLY
description: BONN, May 30The League of Expellees, a Rightwing or ganization representing many of the several million Germans from former German territories in East Europe, staged a rally here today against the Govern ment policy of seeking normal relations with the European Communist states.

title: Brendan Takes Open Jumper Crown
description: DEVON, Pa., May 30Bren dan, a reject of international riders of two continents, won the open jumper championship at the Devon Horse Show to night.

title: Who Makes Music And Where
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA

title: Engagements
description: HAYESLeSEURMr. and Mrs. William S. LeSeur of Hewlett, N. Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann LeSeur to Donald Robert Hayes, also of Hewlett. The future bride teaches at Stuyvesant H. S. In New York and her fiancee associated with the Kendall Company of New York, plan a fall wed ding. Mr. Hayes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Haves of Hewlett N. Y. attended New York University and was graduated from UCLA. The bride to be was gradu ated from St. John's University and at tended Columbia University of Arts and Sciences graduate school.

title: Settlement Group Elects
description: CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP) Mrs. Elizabeth Pittman, a law yer from Omaha, was elected president today of the National Federation of Settlements and Neighborhood Centers. Mrs. Pittman won over William Banks, a New York City settle ment director.

title: Indochina 2: ARVN Improved But Tests Lie Ahead
description: SAIGONBefore the invasion of Cambodia, American military officers responsible for shouting the praises of the South Vietna mese armed forces would pain stakingly plead their cases. The army still had a lot of weakness es, they would argue, but it was slowly but surely improving. Yes, there were failures, losses and corruptions, but building a func tioning army takes time. Of course, they were not as good as the Americans, but most peo ple expect too much.

title: Browning was embarrassed and changed the subject
description: I am quite other than a Brown ingite, Robert Browning wrote, yet he agreed that the London Browning Society and the many similar so cieties in such English towns as Shef field, Birkenhead and Cambridge and in American centers at Cornell (the oldest, founded in 1877), Chicago, New York and Boston, did him great service. When asked by a hostess if he objected to all this adulation, he replied Object to it? No, I like it.... I have waited 40 years for it, and now I like it. Having been known.

title: De Gaulle to Visit Spain
description: PARIS, May 30 (Reuters)  Former President Charles de Gaulle will take a brief vaca tion in Spain during June, usu ally reliable sources said here today.

title: Shrewd Pilot Leads Angels' Ascension
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 30 The man they call Lefty Mumbles could be the most misunderstood manager since Casey Stengel. Also perhaps one of the most successful. You could ask the California Aneels way up there.

title: Amherst, Mass.: Memorial Day1970
description: AMHERST, Mass., May 30 Memorial Day seems to have a little more meaning here in the little New England villages with their gleaming white spires and air of peace and learning, but even here the paradox of human suffering is unavoidable.

title: Indianapolisa Long Shot Heard Across the Sea
description: NEWMARKET, England, May 30 (Reuters)An Ameri canowned colt named Indi anapolis rewarded hunch players at the Newmarket track today by winning a race at 1008 odds two hours be fore the 500mile auto race began at Indianapolis.

title: Mollenhoff Resigns as President's Special Counsel to Take Capital Post for Des Moines Newspaper
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 30Clark R. Mollenhoff, spe cial counsel to the President, has resigned, the West Coast White House announced today.

title: First Grapes With Union Label Shipped to Market From Coast
description: DELANO, Calif., May 30 The first table grapes bearing a union labela fierce black eagle in a white circle on a red flagwere shipped to market this week.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: June
description: May ends with fifteen hours of daylight, and here is June with a new moon at hand and the shortest nights of the year. June, with the summer solstice, the year's midpoint, and proof that four seasons are a good ar rangement. Proof too that the year is not dependent on the ticking of a clock. June is not timeless, but it is a span of existence that sets both its own tempo and boundaries. For those who will stop the microsecond chase long enough to look and feel, June provides a pause that helps to restore nersnectivp.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Effective tomorrow, June 1, the regular newsstand price of the weekday issues of The New York Times will be 15 cents. (Higher in air delivery cities.)

title: Floods Kill 30 Mexicans
description: CHILPANCINGO, Mexico, May 30 (Reuters)Floods from the Xalet River swept away be tween 30 to 40 peasants and their homes in the village of Ilapa, northeast of this state capital near Acapulco, the po lice said today. More than 100 huts in the village, situated in a gorge, were reportedly de stroyed.

title: Brown Reelected to Head Eastern Saddle Horse Unit
description: DEVON, Pa., May 30James Wingate Brown of New York was reelected president of the Eastern Saddle Horse Breeders Association today at the group's annual meeting here.

title: An Actor's Right
description: In the street outside the armed forces induction center in Hous ton in December, 1967, an ama teur guerrilla theater group was putting on an antiwar skit. One of the actors, Daniel Jay Schacht, an electronics consul tant, was playing the part of an American soldier and wore an enlisted man's blouse, an old Army cap and an upsidedown insignia. In the middle of the skit, police arrested Mr. Schacht under a rarely invoked Federal law that makes it a crime for un authorized persons to wear a dis tinctive part of a military uni formexcept as part of a theat rical production, and then only if the portrayal does not tend to discredit the armed forces. Mr. Schacht, whose portrayal was found to have discredited the armed forces, was sentenced to six months in jail and fined $250.

title: Durable Durham, More English Than Oxford
description: DURHAM, England  Although this university town of 23,000 people is situated in an old coalmining area off still another of those proverbial wellbeaten paths, it remains, despite its ready accessibility, one of the most un discovered parts of Britain. During a stay of several weeks, my husband and I met only one other couple who appeared to be fellow tourists; appropriately, like us, they were busy recording the beauties of Dur ham Cathedral on film.

title: Congressional Workhorse
description: Big Ed Johnson, a Democrat, served as Governor from 1933 to 1937, as Senator from 1937 to 1955, and again as Governor in 195556.

title: Various Techniques Are Tried
description: LONDON  British gov ernments since World War II have searched for ways to moderate wage and price in creases and thereby slow the rate of inflation.

title: A close friend and Secretary of the Treasury
description: A Revision and Condensation of From the Morgenthau Diaries.

title: Miss Catoggio, R. C. Kullen Jr. Plan Nuptials
description: Miss Barbara Elizabeth Ca toggio, a lawyer with Willkie Farr & Gallagher, plan to be married Nov. 7 in Jamaica Estates, Queens, to Richard Charles Kullen Jr., a lawyer with Townley, Updike, Carter & Rodgers.

title: A Few Grains Of Salt for The Sibyl
description: THE exhibition African Sculpture looks so much better as now installed at the Brook lyn Museum than it did in Washington last February, that if this had been our first sight of it, the objections inspired by the same 200 sculptures at the National Gallery might not have arisen.

title: Lawyer to Wed Kerry S.Miller
description: WARREN, Conn., May 30 Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Miller of Warren and Valley Cot tage, N. Y., have announced that their daughter, Miss Kerry Susan Miller, will be married on June 27 to Capt. Robert Arthur Bartlett, who is serving with the Army Judge Advocate General Corps at Fort Jackson, S. C. The ceremony will take place at Cornwall Bridge.

title: LEADERS SPLITTING U.S. KENNEDY SAYS
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., May 30 Senator Edward. M. Kennedy at tacked the national leadership in a commencement address at Manhattanville College here to day, declaring that its conduct was tearing the nation apart.

title: Spain Seems Unhappy By RICHARD EDER
description: MADRID, May 30Secretary Rogers has come and gone after spending 23 hours herethe number was sharply noted by the Spanish pressleaving be hind a decided air of public un happiness with the United States and the base agreements he came to talk about.

description: HOCKEY

title: Vollmar Wins Pistol Event
description: BERLIN, May 30 (UPI) Harald Vollmar, an East Ger man Olympian, won the free pistol event today in an inter national shooting match at Leipzig, getting 574 points of a possible 600. Second place went to Dr. Hynek Hromada of Czechoslovakia with 568.

title: I.O.S. UNINTERESTED IN BID FROM BRITAIN
description: GENEVA, May 30A spokes man for Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., a giant mutual fund complex based here, said today that the organization was not interested in receiving participation bid from Gramco, a Londonbased real estate mu tual fund, despite the loss of John M. King as a possible res cuer.
